title: Fantasy Football: Week 5 Matchup Breakdown
description: Every N.F.L. season has its share of surprise fantasy performers, and one could argue that 2013 has had more than usual.

title: Inside the World of Big Data
description: You had to live  did live, from habit that became instinct  in the assumption that every sound you made was overheard, and, except in darkness, every movement scrutinized.

title: 1915: Trade in Dolls
description: From The New York Herald, European Edition, January 5, 1915

title: Republicans Say Boehner Has Offered Assurances on Default
description: WASHINGTON  With a budget deal still elusive and a deadline approaching on raising the debt ceiling, Speaker John A. Boehner has told colleagues that he is determined to prevent a federal default and is willing to pass a measure through a combination of Republican and Democratic votes, according to one House Republican.

title: Malcolm Gladwell: By the Book
description: The author of David and Goliath compares Michael Lewis to Tiger Woods: Ill never play like that. But its good to be reminded every now and again what genius looks like.

title: Brooklyn Prosecutor, in Reversal, Will Run as a Republican to Keep His Job
description: Last month, after losing the Democratic primary for Brooklyn district attorney by 10 points, Charles J. Hynes said he would give up his bid for a seventh term in the office he has occupied since 1990. His name remained on the ballot on the Republican Party line, but he promised a smooth transition for the man who defeated him, Kenneth P. Thompson.

title: The Latest Fashion Accessory Is an I.P.O.
description: An initial public offering instead of a contract. LVMH may have found an original way to keep close the hot designers that made it worth 75 billion euros and created the worlds largest luxury group.

title: Its Easy to Say I Need This. Its Harder to Find Solutions.
description: Q. Were you in entrepreneurial roles as a child?

title: Excerpt: 'Bad Jews'
description: Philip Ettinger and Tracee Chimo in a scene from Joshua Harmons comedy at the Laura Pels Theater.

title: SACs Forceful Ways Shown in Massachusetts Citi Case
description: The hedge fund was so desperate for an upper hand that four of its employees pleaded with a Wall Street analyst one morning to reveal private insights.

title: Drivers Wife Describes Fear of Angry Mob of Bikers
description: For the first time since a weekend confrontation with a large group of motorcyclists led to the beating of the driver of a sport utility vehicle, the wife of the driver publicly addressed the episode on Thursday, saying she and her husband were terrified when a crowd surrounded their vehicle after it struck one of the riders.

title: Skiing, the Next Generation
description: A cluster of Colorado ski resorts is playing the long game this year, opening new trails and adding perks for families in an effort to nurture the next generation of skiers and snowboarders.

title: TV Talk: Comedy Catastrophes
description: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the many tanking comedies that had their premiere this season.

title: Chirlane McCray on Love, Politics and Bloomberg
description: Chirlane McCray, the wife of Bill de Blasio, sat down with me recently for a two-hour interview at Little Purity Diner in Park Slope, speaking openly about her personal life, her politics and her role in the campaign.

title: Vanska to Conduct Two Farewell Concerts With Musicians of Minnesota Orchestra
description: MINNEAPOLIS  As had widely been expected here in recent days, Osmo Vanska, who resigned as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra on Tuesday, will conduct concerts on Friday and Saturday evenings presented by the orchestras locked-out players. The Musicians of the Minnesota Orchestra, as they call themselves in their independent activities, announced Mr. Vanskas participation on Thursday, saying that the concerts will be his thank you and farewell to Minnesota.

title: Lorde, Miley and the Different Flavors of Pop
description: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss different approaches to pop stardom, as embodied by Lorde and Miley Cyrus.

title: Short and Sweet: Reading and Writing Flash Fiction
description: Overview | What are the essential elements of a story? How can writing flash fiction help us become better writers? In this lesson, students will consider the nature of stories and learn to write more concisely by reading and writing flash fiction.

title: With the Jobs Report, No News Isnt Good News
description: The monthly employment report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics is the most important source of information onhow the economy is delivering (or not) for the American people.

title: T FALL TRAVEL
description: With its last-frontier appeal and magical mixed bag of culture, New Orleans is quietly luring a circle of expats, who find an evolving city thats just the right amount of undone.

title: Document | A Photographers Pit Stops Along Americas Highways
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Some Economic Consequences of the Shutdown
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Samsungs Mobile Chief Departs
description: Kevin Packingham, the chief product officer for the mobile division of Samsung Electronics, who was involved in introducing several of Samsungs popular Galaxy devices, has left the company.

title: Reuters Plans to Lay Off 5% of Newsroom Staff
description: Turmoil continues at Thomson Reuters after the company announced on Wednesday that it was laying off staff members.

title: New York City Marathon to Have Tighter Security
description: All bags brought anywhere near the New York City Marathon will be searched. Family members heading to the finish line will go through a special screening. People marching in the kickoff parade will not be allowed to carry bags of any kind.

title: Life, Interrupted: A Golden Opportunity
description: Earlier this week I found myself surrounded by journalism royalty. Many of the most-talented and most-courageous broadcast journalists, editors, producers and videographers had gathered at New Yorks Lincoln Center for the News and Documentary Emmy Awards.

title: Roth, in His Own Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Shrews. Princes and Kings.
description: In Shakespeares plays, women put on mens clothes so they can travel where they like, marry whom they like, and speak their minds. Actresses from the 1600s to the present have followed suit  literally  dressing as men in search of better parts and more lines. Here are some of the most famous examples of Shakespearean male drag. ALEXIS SOLOSKI

title: France Moves to Shore Up African State in Turmoil
description: France is drafting a United Nations Security Council resolution aimed at stabilizing the Central African Republic, the chronically dysfunctional country in which a transitional government has failed to stop months of lawless rampaging, atrocities and dire shortages that are attracting extremist militants from neighboring states.

title: Renaissance Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Duplex
description: To the Editor:

title: Straight Sets Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting Straight Sets. This blogs regular features, including live tournament analysis, news and notes from Christopher Clarey, Ben Rothenberg and others, and other coverage, can now be found on the tennis section front. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely tennis news.

title: A Short History of the Morgue
description: Inside the New York Times photo archives, known as the "morgue," the filmmaker Katerina Cizek and the archivist Jeff Roth discuss the making of "A Short History of the Highrise."

title: Show Is Back at Carnegie, but Without a Settlement
description: A concert at Carnegie Hall by the American Symphony Orchestra went on as scheduled Thursday night, a day after a strike by union stagehands caused the cancellation of the halls gala opening concert, which had been scheduled for Wednesday evening.

title: Can You Read Peoples Emotions?
description: Are you tuned in to the emotions of others? Or have you been accused of being insensitive?

title: For Better Social Skills, Scientists Recommend a Little Chekhov
description: Say you are getting ready for a blind date or a job interview. What should you do? Besides shower and shave, of course, it turns out you should read  but not just anything. Something by Chekhov or Alice Munro will help you navigate new social territory better than a potboiler by Danielle Steel.

title: Both Men and Women Should Uncover Family Responsibilities at Work
description: Of course people cover up aspects of themselves on the job. The workplace is generally no place for a rehash of a drinking binge or to flaunt your Axl Rose tattoo (depending, of course, on the workplace). But when people cover up their families needs, theyre putting family responsibility in the category of things we dont talk about at work, and the results are wide reaching.

title: Manning Has Time to Hit Right Notes
description: Eli Manning might have made one too many rap videos in the offseason, but William C. Rhoden says Manning is the perfect quarterback to lead the Giants out of their early season funk.

title: What to Do With Your Retirement Plan if You Change Jobs
description: Kya Gream, 25, recently started a new job as a medical office assistant in Champaign, Ill. Her old employer sent her a thick packet about her options for rolling over her retirement plan, but she has not taken the time yet to digest the information, since it looks a bit daunting.

title: Novel by Michael Hastings to Be Published Posthumously
description: Michael Hastings, the journalist and author, had written a novel based on his own life before he was killed in a car crash in June.

title: Video Sports of The Times: Manning Has Time to Hit Right Notes
Streetcar From Another Era
description: That Blanche DuBois  what a cutup!

title: California Institute of Technology Tops English Magazines University Rankings
description: The California Institute of Technology has been ranked the best university in the world by the Times Higher Education magazine of London for the third year in a row, leaving Harvard University and Oxford University tied in second place.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

title: San Francisco Ballet Reaches Agreement With Dancers Union
description: The San Francisco Ballet has resolved its dispute with its dancers, the ballet company and the executive director of the dancers union confirmed on Thursday. On Wednesday, the dancers voted significantly in favor of accepting the Ballets offer, said Alan Gordon, the executive director of the American Guild of Musical Artists. The companys planned New York tour, which includes performances at Lincoln Center, will go ahead as planned, he and Ballet officials said.

title: Obama Will Not Unilaterally Raise Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will not invoke a constitutional amendment to unilaterally increase the nations debt limit if an impasse with House Republicans causes that ceiling to be breached Oct. 17, his spokesman said.

title: Papas Kitchen
description: Inside the tiny Filipino restaurant in Woodside, Queens, where its karaoke night every night.

title: Listen Up | The Fiery, Fashion-Forward Stylings of Iggy Azalea
description: The trash-talking Australian MC Iggy Azalea knows that her modelesque, fashion-forward appearance is at odds with her persona. Its just easier to be aggressive than to play nice, she said with a laugh. The 23-year-old, who dropped out of high school and moved from the small town of Mallumbimby, New South Wales, to Miami when she was 16, broke out in 2011 with a pair of explicit videos that caught the attention of the rapper T.I., now her mentor, who appears on Azaleas new EP, Change Your Life (out Oct. 8 from Island Def Jam). A remix of the title track by DJ Shift Key has its premiere here. Azalea says shes still getting used to the experience of being remixed. Its like changing a hair color, she said. Its nice, but it takes some getting used to.

title: Closing the Government to Save Face
description: Marlin Stutzman was, until today, a little-known Republican back-bencher, representing northeast Indiana in the House. But with just one off-message statement that he was quickly forced to retract, he became the prominent public face of the House Republicans who are refusing to re-open the United States government.

title: Sing for Your Dinner
description: Purple Haze crashes from the speakers as stingrays flap languidly across the flat-screen TV. The singer, leaning over the rubble of his dinner (monumental pig hooves, broken crab shells), nails every throwaway whoop. The crowd, if thats what you can call three tables, erupts.

title: Exploring the Challenges and Opportunities in the New Communication Climate
description: I just returned from my first visit to Japan, which was limited to a small slice of Tokyo, a megacity offering a dizzying mix of ancient and modern, exuberant consumption and reflective modesty. I was there to speak at an annual forum on the environment organized by the Asahi Shimbun newspaper.*

title: Car Chase, White House to Capitol, Has Fatal End
description: WASHINGTON  A woman with a young child was shot to death after turning her vehicle into a weapon on Thursday afternoon, ramming her way through barriers outside the White House and on Capitol Hill.

title: A Tortilla Trove Inspired by Street Food
description: Homemade corn tortillas  supple, tender, pleasantly chewy and with a deeply satisfying flavor  bear little resemblance to the packaged discs sold in supermarkets. Fortunately for those of us without a tortilla maker, they are being served seven days a week, hot off the press, at Fresco, a Mexican restaurant in the Savin Rock area of West Haven.

title: Warhol Death and Disaster Work to Be Sold by Sothebys
description: After Christies announced that Balloon Dog (Orange), Jeff Koonss 10-foot-high sculpture resembling a childs giant party favor, would be the star of its Nov. 12 postwar and contemporary-art auction, it started an international advertising campaign featuring the lovable pooch. The auction house also sent gushing e-mails to its top clients that read, The Stage Is Set to Make History.

title: For Med Students, Love From the Drug Rep
description: In the social and culinary wasteland that was residency training, it had been easy for Cheryl, a bubbly brunette in her mid-30s, to become our den mother. She never tired of listening to our grousing, had unerring taste in take-out, made it a point to come to our parties when invited and every so often brought in a plate of her homemade brownies.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: In the latest installment of Before and After, four book designers discuss recent examples of their work. Each designer shared early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

title: In Louisiana, a Craft Brew Tour
description: Louisiana recently introduced a new craft brewery trail, aimed to complement the states rich culinary and music tourism.

title: Trimmings: Paris Fashion Week
description: Accessories from the Chanel, Herms, Valentino, Chlo spring shows, and more.

title: A Hotel Room With 140 Characters
description: First there was vacation.

title: When Israel Stepped Back From the Brink
description: NEXT week is the 40th anniversary of the Yom Kippur War, perhaps the most traumatic moment in Israels history. On Oct. 7, 1973  the second day of the war  Israels borders along the Suez Canal in the south and the Golan Heights in the north collapsed under a massive assault by a coalition of Arab armies. Israel was caught unprepared.

title: If You Are Normal, You Search for Mushrooms
description: What is it with Russians and their mushroom hunts?

title: Want to Go to the Olympics? Dont Tarry
description: Questions about the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, abound. Some people wonder whether the construction of the Olympic Park and other infrastructure in the resort city along the Black Sea will be completed when the Games begin on Feb. 7 (or will be worth the expected price tag of $50 billion). Others question the ethics of attending an event in a nation that recently passed a law that is widely interpreted as an effort to restrict open advocacy of homosexuality.

title: 'Only'
description: Joseph J. Lhota's first television ad for the general election campaign focused on some of the similarities between him and his opponent, Bill de Blasio.

title: Fighting Between Rebels Intensifies Over a Strategic Town in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A group of powerful rebel brigades in northern Syria is struggling to defuse an armed standoff pitting insurgents against an affiliate of Al Qaeda for control of a strategic town near the Turkish border.

title: 'Everyone'
description: The first general election ad from the de Blasio campaign features excerpts from the candidate's primary night speech.

title: Russia Evacuates Embassy in Libya After Attack
description: MOSCOW  The Russian Foreign Ministry said Thursday that it evacuated its embassy in Libya after armed men stormed the complex the day before, apparently seeking revenge for the killing of a Libyan Air Force officer.

title: The Trip Up the Mountain That Left 11 Dead
After Fraud, Regulators Go After a Bank
description: You cant run a Ponzi scheme without a bank.

title: Now Screening | The King of Modern Longboarding Looks Back
description: The surf legend Joel Tudor has appeared in more than 100 surf films, but The Ductumentary, a documentary short presented by Vans that will have its premiere on Monday, is the first one hes been involved with making. Its a portrait of the Duct Tape Invitational Series, an unorthodox longboarding contest that Tudor, the two-time longboarding world champ, started in 2010 as an antidote to the Association of Professional Surfings longboard competition circuit. At 25 minutes, the documentary is equal parts surfer porn and examination of Tudors roots and impact on the sport.

title: A Treacherous Trip Through the Mind of a Spy
description: Finn and Parker are not just another patient and therapist facing off in a dreary institutional office. They both work for the C.I.A., and they both have significant secrets to keep. But then thats how they were trained.

title: Forgotten Faberg Comes Out of the Attic
description: Russian royals loved to collect figurines of their subjects. The Faberg workshops produced about 50 sculptures in semiprecious stones and gold representing peasants, servants and the occasional Gypsy singer and street sweeper.

title: The Writer and Man, Evermore
description: Edgar Allan Poe, among the unluckiest and most misunderstood of writers, is the subject of a tasteful, thoughtful exhibition that opens on Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum  about 100 years too late to do his reputation much good. Among Poes misfortunes is that many of his American contemporaries found his work morbid and unreadable. In some ways, he was the Mickey Rourke or Jerry Lewis of 19th-century letters, better appreciated in France, by writers like Baudelaire and Mallarm, than he was at home.

title: Visiting a Forgotten Nest of Early European Melody
description: MUSICIANS who specialize in early music might take umbrage at the suggestion that the major works of the German, Italian, French and English repertories have been thoroughly picked over. Yet in recent seasons, there has been a restlessness among these players that has led them to investigate less traveled works by composers from Spain, Latin America and other countries that were largely overlooked in the early-music booms first few decades.

title: Development Comes With Downsides in Cambodia
description: Kalyanee Mams documentary A River Changes Course has won several prizes at film festivals, and deservedly so. Her intimate portrait of three Cambodian families struggling to maintain their ways of life amid environmental degradation caused by development is a beautiful example of the form. Instead of delving into the politics of their plight, Ms. Mam delivers a universal story.

title: Colorful Guests Around the Plaza
description: COMING of age in San Antonio in the 1970s and 80s, the artist Aaron Curry knew nothing about opera or ballet  or fine art, for that matter. His preferred entertainment was Scooby-Doo and Jonny Quest cartoons, Star Trek episodes and Iron Maiden heavy-metal music. I grew up watching TV, he said one afternoon in the shade of Lincoln Centers leafy London plane trees. Id sleep with it on.

title: Giant Hornets Kill Dozens in China
description: SHANGHAI  Swarms of giant hornets have killed 42 people in Shaanxi Province and injured more than 1,600 in recent months, according to Xinhua, the official news agency. Government officials have yet to figure out why their attacks have been so widespread and deadly.

title: Uncaging the Cage Fighter Within
description: ALTHOUGH New York still bans live professional mixed martial arts competitions, that regulation has no bearing on training. And this year the Ultimate Fighting Championship  the sports biggest promoter  opened its first gym in New York City.

title: Advice From Elders Rivets a Couple on the Path to Marriage
description: One way to hit a conversational dead-end at a dinner is for a couple to gush over an unusual shared hobby. Were just really into brewing craft kvass right now, they might announce, while giving each other mincing grins. Weve never felt better. And you would not believe the varieties! It may be difficult for two so enmeshed in their own private world to realize that not everyone shares their enthusiasm.

title: Victim of Military Hazing to Be Immortalized in Opera
description: On Oct. 3, 2011, Pvt. Danny Chen, a 19-year-old Chinese-American soldier from New York City who had been hazed and racially taunted by fellow soldiers, climbed into a guard tower on a military base in Afghanistan and killed himself with a gunshot to the head.

title: Swimming With White Horses Away From the Battlefield
description: Its difficult to know how to categorize Vikingdom, an English-language Malaysian epic starring a Briton (Craig Fairbrass) and an accentless Aussie (Dominic Purcell) as Vikings battling the god Thor (Conan Stevens, from Game of Thrones).

title: The Thinking Persons Guide to Elizabeth Gilbert
description: The magazines profile of Elizabeth Gilbert a couple of weeks ago not only drew comments about that authors well-known book, Eat, Pray, Love, but it also instigated a debate about readers own intellects.

title: BRIC House Celebrates Opening Weekend
description: Since it was founded in 1979, the annual Celebrate Brooklyn! music festival in Prospect Park  the strains of which the Miser has been known to enjoy, cold beverage in hand, as they stream through the living room window on summer nights  has been the primary public face of BRIC, an arts and technology incubator operating out of modest headquarters in a former vaudeville playhouse.

title: Video of Police Chase and Eyewitness Reports of Shooting Near U.S. Capitol
description: Jordan Sekulow, executive director of the American Center for Law and Justice, was in his office at Second Street and Constitution Avenue Northeast in Washington when gunshots erupted outside, prompting a lockdown at the nearby United States Capitol about 2:30 p.m. Thursday.

title: Robert Motherwell: Early Collages
description: A look at the new show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: A Hit Maker by Any Name
description: Directed by William Hechter and Peter Miller, A K A Doc Pomus shines a light on the soulful, big-hearted man behind many magic moments in popular music. Born Jerome Felder, he called himself Doc Pomus, and, hobbled by childhood polio, he reached down deep, bringing forth hundreds of songs, some of them among the most poignant pop ever written. This static documentary portrait relies on the usual panning over photos and tag-team interviews, but the format, like the radio length of a song, doesnt get in the way of its subjects heart.

title: Wheelies: The Pit of Vipers Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Anything for a Laugh
description: Babli is a lovable lout, a cocky car thief in Delhi with loud shirts and the inevitable heart of gold. But thats not enough for a Bollywood hero. Bablis also an orphan who gives his ill-gotten gains to the orphanage where he grew up and still lives, sharing a bed with his sidekick, T2, as in Terminator 2.

title: Your Essential Thanksgiving Recipes
description: Updated | Nov. 7, 2013 We are no longer taking suggestions for essential Thanksgiving recipes, but we would love to keep hearing your thoughts and comments on dishes you consider Thanksgiving favorites. Feel free to continue posting in the comments section below.

title: Stability, a Real Suburban Curve Ball
description: Last week, on the season premiere of Eastbound & Down, Kenny Powers was back, sort of. A schlub in a company-issued shirt and a would-be Michael Scott for a boss, he was a shell of the boorish ex-big leaguer he once was. The first words he uttered, sitting in his car on the way to work, were, Love NPR. He might as well be dead.

title: Scenes From Capitol Hill During Lockdown
description: The Capitol was locked down briefly on Thursday afternoon after shots were fired in front of the building.

title: Twitter I.P.O. Filing Opens Books on High-Flier
description: Updated, 10 p.m. | SAN FRANCISCO  If Lady Gaga were to send a message to her 40 million followers on Twitter summarizing the companys debut on Wall Street, it might very well say: Twitter IPO. Mobile. Born This Way.

title: At the S.B.A., Disaster Loans Continue, but Little Else
description: For the Small Business Administration, the government shutdown is not as complete as one might think. Nearly 40 percent of the agencys employees remain on the job, according to a shutdown plan published on the agencys Web site. But even so, the agency has stopped processing regular small-business loans, leaving would-be borrowers in limbo.

title: Iran Frees Another Reformer, but Netanyahu Warns Iranians, in Persian, Not to Be Dupes
description: As Iran released another political prisoner on Thursday, Israels prime minister slipped into Persian to suggest that only sadeloh, or dupes, would be fooled by recent diplomatic overtures from the clerical government in Tehran.

title: David Adamo
description: Untitled

title: John Houck: A History of Graph Paper
description: On Stellar Rays

title: Jack Whitten
description: Alexander Gray Associates

title: Design Office With Kim  Gordon  Since 1980
description: White Columns

title: Raymond Pettibon: To Wit
description: David Zwirner

title: Unzipped
description: Ever since the 40th anniversary of my first novel, Fear of Flying, peeped over the horizon, Ive been thinking a lot about storytelling  why certain stories stick with us and others dont.

title: Lets Read About Sex
description: Writing about sex can be uniquely powerful  and perilous. A group of novelists, memoirists and poets tell us about working blue: what novels first inspired them, what nouns they strive to avoid and who they think writes sex best.

title: With Shutdown, Questions About Visiting National Forests
description: While closing gates around a national park or monument is relatively simple, closing a forest is not. Newspapers and radio and television news operations around the country are reporting that while offices and facilities within the national forests have been closed, the land is still open to outdoor enthusiasts.

title: New York City Opera Files for Bankruptcy
description: New York City Opera, which was founded 70 years ago to help bring opera to the masses, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Thursday after an urgent $7 million fund-raising appeal fell short last month.

title: Hes Back for More Blood
description: When insects are the best thing in your movie, its probably time to retire.

title: The Numbers Behind Twitter
description: Updated to include international revenue statistics.

title: Twitters Letter to Shareholders Is Short and Lightweight
description: Twitters ancestors, Google and Facebook, used their initial public offering filings to write long letters about the high-minded philosophies of their companies. But Twitters letter in its filing, which was made public on Thursday, was much more succinct  perhaps fitting for a company that has popularized short bursts of information.

title: A Painters Cut-and-Paste Prequel
description: Abstract Expressionism is overrated. And it wasnt initially a movement or style at all. It was a bunch of unalike artists, some great, some not, who shared a city, a war, some ideas and a bar, circa 1940. Pretty much everything else, including a fecund two-decade fad for soulful painting that grew from that moment, was largely a product of marketing and myth spinning.

title: Cuba in America, Onstage and Unbound
description: The pianist Michele Rosewomans long-running project New Yor-Uba, which she revived for a new album and two nights of performances at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola, still looks good on paper and sounds better in practice.

title: Cowboy With a Cause
description: People were telling me it couldnt be done, the craggy, white-haired man in the denim shirt says. And thats the wrong thing to say to a cowboy.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: baby smells, health insurance and food-borne illness. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Shots Fired Near the Capitol
description: Law enforcement officers shot a woman during a car chase from the White House.

title: Vigneault Still Learning About His Rangers as Season Opens
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Alain Vigneault is about to start his 12th season as an N.H.L. coach, but of course this time is different. After the morning skate ahead of the Rangers opener against the Phoenix Coyotes here Thursday, he talked about how he felt as he prepared to coach his first regular-season game with the Blueshirts.

title: Huddled Masses, Studiously Eyed
description: With so much contemporary art photography devoted to the slippery nature of photography itself, its a good corrective to regularly visit the International Center of Photography, an institution founded on faith in the medium as a window on empirical reality. Among the non-navel-gazing shows on view there are a pair devoted to the pioneering documentarian Lewis Hine (1874-1940), whose subjects included immigrants arriving at Ellis Island, children working in factories and coal mines, families living in Lower East Side tenements, black Americans and men building skyscrapers.

title: Car Chase and Gunshots in the Capital
description: Car Chase and Gunshots at Capitol Hill

title: Touching on Modern, Hip-Hop and Tap
description: Every Fall for Dance program  this year, especially  shows marvelously mind-widening diversity. Most dancegoers have relatively narrow tastes, but the festival ignores that. Each year, it keeps drawing our attention to things we hadnt seen, didnt know, might have missed, new and old; it loves to place dissimilar genres side by side. Its every performance sells out and is lustily cheered; I ardently hope that it leads people to see examples of dance theyve never visited before.

title: A Shooting Star Lights Up Manhattan
description: It was only 20 months ago, but seems far more distant: that stretch in February 2012 when Jeremy Lin, a relative unknown from the end of the bench, took over as a guard for the New York Knicks and promptly tore through the N.B.A. He scored more points in his first five starts than any other player in nearly 40 years, peaking with 38 against the Los Angeles Lakers (Kobe Bryant managed only 34 that night).

title: Back in the Blue Saddle, for a Gallop to Abstraction
description: New Yorkers might be forgiven for greeting Vasily Kandinsky: From Blaue Reiter to the Bauhaus, 1910-1925, at the Neue Galerie, with a shrug and a distinct feeling of dj vu. Wasnt it just three years ago now that the Guggenheim mounted a full retrospective, a delirium-inducing helix of Kandinskys?

title: Extreme Measures
description: Photos from the Chris Burden show at the New Museum.

title: The Intoxicating, Tradition-Steeped Charm of New Orleans
description: With its last-frontier appeal and magical mixed bag of culture, New Orleans is quietly luring a circle of expats, who find an evolving city thats just the right amount of undone.

title: Living and Killing in a Materialist China
description: A blistering fictionalized tale straight out of China, A Touch of Sin is at once monumental and human scale. A story of lives rocked by violence, it has the urgency of a screaming headline but one inscribed with visual lyricism, emotional weight and a belief in individual rights. You can feel the conviction of its director, Jia Zhang-ke  one of the few filmmakers of any nationality who weighs the impact of social and political shifts on people  in every shot. In A Touch of Sin, the world isnt an amorphous backdrop, pretty scenery for private dramas, it is a stage on which men and women struggle to fulfill basic moral obligations, including recognizing one anothers humanity.

title: Andy Warhol Schlepped Here
description: All the art in the photographer Christopher Makoss modest four-room apartment in a six-story walk-up building in the West Village is by friends or fellow scene-makers, a roll call of the New York art world of the 70s and 80s: Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman, Jeff Koons, Donald Baechler, Keith Haring. Mr. Makos lives much as he did in that era, a bohemian who brushes his teeth in the kitchen sink because his bathroom has only a toilet and a cast-iron tub.

title: What I Love | Christopher Makos
description: Mr. Makos West Village walk-up is hung with art by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman and others.

title: The Stuff of Building and Destroying
description: Chris Burden: Extreme Measures at the New Museum is a superb survey, but also a kind of transfiguration. It liberates the Los Angeles-based Mr. Burden from the clutches of history, expanding and rebalancing our understanding of his art.

title: One Holds the Cards, the Other Is Bluffing
description: In Runner Runner, directed by Brad Furman from a script by Brian Koppelman and David Levien, Ben Affleck and Justin Timberlake face off, cleft chin to cleft chin, in a battle for ... well, what, exactly? The attention of the audience? Of Gemma Arterton, who plays virtually the only female character in the movie not employed as a hooker or a stripper? Huge sums of money? All of the above, or whatever.

title: Plain or Painted? In Any Case, Unfaded
description: We now live in a culture in which everything must be original. We have to strip the paint off our oak paneling. Our architecture has to look as if it had always been there. Our jeans have to be faded. But original can turn around and bite you, as shown in the perplexing case of 90 Macdougal Street, a house in the Macdougal-Sullivan Gardens complex, between Houston and Bleecker Streets.

title: Comedy Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Leader of Cancer Center Works on Changes After Feedback
description: HOUSTON  Ronald DePinho, the president of the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, part of the University of Texas, becomes animated when he talks about his ambitious plans in leading the institutes efforts to combat the disease.

title: Theater Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Is There Really a Market for That?
description: Concussion, written and directed by Stacie Passon, deals with the age-old challenge of keeping that special spark alive. How do you find meaning in lives that seem to consist of routine, much less appreciate desire in its complexity and vividness?

title: Hurdles for Condo Buyers
description: In New York, buyers intent on getting a co-op know to brace themselves for the notoriously invasive approval process. But increasingly, condominium buyers are also being asked to fill out lengthy applications and provide detailed financial information to buildings governing boards.

title: Push for a Shift Could Affect Governors Race
description: Why would anyone want Debra Medina to run for governor as an independent?

title: A Japanese Welcome, and Korean-Style Barbecue
description: With close to 800 locations in Asia and the United States, and three outposts already in Manhattan, could Westchester County be far behind? Apparently not. Last June, Gyu-Kaku settled into White Plains, a bold move in an area jammed with restaurants offering every culinary variety  or so one would think. With its very Korean spin on Japanese barbecue, Gyu-Kaku has managed to bring new and different tastes to the city centers growing dining scene.

title: Game Firms Get Great Tax Deals, Maybe Too Great
description: In the lobby of the Twisted Pixel Games studio in Austin, a futuristic motorcycle welcomes visitors with an electric blue glow. The robotic motorcycle stars in LocoCycle, a new video game produced almost entirely in Texas.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Wedding? Uncork the Rancor
description: A.C.O.D., an unfunny comedy about a guy mooning over his parents divorce decades later, is so eager to please its hard to hate. But its sluggish even at 87 minutes, clichd and gives you nothing of interest to look at other than some familiar faces. Early on, during one of its inertly staged and shot conversations between two people  the kind that switches between over-the-shoulder shots, the performers frozen on their marks and drained of animation  one of the characters words didnt match his mouth. The words just kept coming, and so did the perfunctory rest of it.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Sell Them Trees, Then Steal Them Blind
description: The wry tone of All Is Bright, a sardonic, smart screwball comedy that teams Paul Giamatti and Paul Rudd as professional thieves trying to go straight by selling Christmas trees in New York City, is defined by its droll soundtrack of holiday favorites. Familiar carols are reduced to bouncy instrumental elevator music with a hint of jazz and a smirk on its face.

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Majority Disapprove of Shutting Down Government Over Health Law
description: A wide majority of Americans disapprove of shutting down the federal government over differences about the 2010 health care law, including a majority of those who oppose the law, according to the latest CBS News poll.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 4-10
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Fleeing Her Troubles for a Host of New Ones
description: A ballad of photographs, music and memories  both the old we savor and the new we consciously construct  I Used to Be Darker picks at the seams of an unraveling family and watches to see what will happen.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bulgaria. Italy, Nigeria and Myanmar.

title: The Pleasure of Crime
description: The question that I am most often asked about Ponzi schemes is Why? Didnt the person behind the scheme know that it was inevitable he would be caught? That he would be sent to prison?

title: Obama on Government Shutdown
description: The president addressed people at the M. Luis Construction Company in Rockville, Md.

title: Dallas, 1963, Redux
description: Parkland, Peter Landesmans taut but unsatisfying docudrama about the Kennedy assassination, is mercifully short. For the events depicted, no matter how familiar, still hurt. Watching the movie is like enduring dental surgery without anesthesia. You clench your fists, suck in your breath and remind yourself that the pain will end. And when it does, sooner than expected, you sigh with relief.

title: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 4-10
description: LIVE BAT ENCOUNTERS

title: Fighting School Bullies With a Camera
description: Remarkable as much for its insights as for its audacity, The Dirties approaches school violence with a comic veneer that slowly shades into deep darkness. Capturing the downward spiral of Matt (played by the director, Matt Johnson), an excitable high schooler terrorized by bullies and obsessed with bloodthirsty movies, this found-footage exercise unfolds with shocking credibility.

title: Twitters Biggest Risk? Losing You
description: Even though Twitters staff has ballooned to about 2,000 employees, having talented workers isnt nearly as crucial for the company as having quality users.

title: Her Huddled Masses? They Must Settle for a 47-Foot Imitation
description: A New York vacation is not a New York vacation without a visit to the Statue of Liberty, and so, on Thursday afternoon, a tourist from Kuwait strolled up to Lady Libertys plinth and turned toward the camera, smiling broadly. His wife took a photo with her iPhone, tilting it up to make sure she captured the entire statue, crown to toe.

title: A Feminists Daughter Finds Love in the Kitchen
description: On Mothers Day last spring, my 10-year-old daughter listed some things she loves about having me as her mother. The first two surprised me: You make my lunch most days, she began, and you make dinner. Other observations followed, including that I am huggy and smart. But first came the kitchen.

title: Telling Them Not to Take a Hike
description: We are planning a hiking trip with three other couples. One of them is now asking to bring their two adult children, who are in their early 20s. We would prefer the children not come; they would inevitably change the dynamic of the trip. So we exchanged e-mails on the subject with their parents. We wrote, We assumed this was an old geezers trip. Our friends replied, Assumed or preferred? How should we respond and still keep the peace?

title: Spare Times for Oct. 4-10
description: Literary Events (Friday through Sunday) The literary smorgasbord known as The New Yorker Festival is offering ample servings of readings, discussions and screenings with writers, actors and others, at several locations. Online sales are closed for many events, but tickets to some notable ones are still available.

title: Love Triangle, With Mom in the Middle
description: Set in a vibrant Puerto Rican community in the Bronx, Babygirl is a gently knowing coming-of-age tale about the dangers of combining intellectual precociousness with emotional immaturity.

title: Making Life, and Your Cat, Sit Still
description: When Mimi Vang Olsen is commissioned to paint a portrait of a home and its inhabitants, her goal is not simply to record the color of the walls and the style of the sofa. Her aim is to produce a small, richly textured domestic drama, studded with the tiny but telling details that reveal the true nature of those who call the setting home and the intricate emotional relationships that bind them.

title: Pet Portraitist
description: Mimi Vang Olsen, a painter of cats, dogs and domestic scenes, works out of a Hudson Street storefront.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Stress Brings Out a Real Monster in Him
description: The premise of Bad Milo!, Jacob Vaughans devilish comedy about a mild-mannered accountant with an angry critter lodged in his colon, is not nearly as gross as it sounds. For one thing, the anal intruder  which resembles a hairless troll doll  is rather cute. And for another, Mr. Vaughan is more eager to inspire giggles than gag reflexes.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Twitters Evolution From Side Project to Wall Street Hopeful
description: People are at the heart of Twitter.

title: A Heartbreaking Loss for One and All
description: Inspired by a viral YouTube video and deftly directed by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason (Designing Women), Bridegroom is about an unmarried gay couple in their 20s and what happens when one of them dies. Thats the simple summary of this simply told but exceptionally moving documentary.

title: Taking the Stigma Out of Dyslexia
description: Dislecksia: The Movie, directed by Harvey Hubbell V, is an informative, entertaining survey about what dyslexia is and how to treat it. A central theme is that the condition, estimated to affect up to 35 million Americans, is not a learning disability, but a learning difference.

title: Elvin R. Heiberg III, General Who Took Blame for Hurricane Katrina Failures, Dies at 81
description: Lt. Gen. Elvin R. Heiberg III, who rose to the top of the United States Army Corps of Engineers in the 1980s and decades later expressed regret for failing to fight hard enough to build floodgates that he believed might have protected New Orleans from Hurricane Katrina, died on Sept. 27 in Arlington, Va. He was 81.

title: Phantom Crises (Wonkish)
description: Simon Wren-Lewis is puzzled by a Ken Rogoff column that sorta-kinda defends Camerons austerity policies. His puzzlement, which I share, comes at several levels. But I want to focus on just one thing: Rogoffs assertion that Britain could have faced a southern Europe-style crisis, with a loss of investor confidence driving up interest rates and plunging the economy into a deep slump.

title: Newcomers Rite of Passage
description: Five people rehearsing in an otherwise vacant dance studio: That pitch may not appeal to everyone, but fans of the movement arts and ensemble acting will appreciate the possibilities. Yet few of those possibilities are explored with any depth in Five Dances, a promising though static new film that never leaves its taciturn shadows for a single emotionally gripping moment.

title: Breaking From Recent Tech Tradition, Twitter Forgoes Multiple Stock Classes
description: Twitters initial public offering highlights many of the social networks differences from rivals like Facebook. But the companys prospectus highlights one unexpected change: the lack of multiple classes of stock.

title: In Store | Old-World Luxury, For Sale Downtown
description: After doing everything from curation to publicity for design-world stars like Thom Mayne and Dror Benshetrit and luxury goods companies like LVMH, Melanie Courbet has ventured out on her own to indulge her passion for craftsmanship. At Atelier Courbet, her new SoHo gallery and shop in a 19th-century building on Mott Street, which opens Saturday, she will offer contemporary design by companies and workshops that use Old World techniques to produce everything from spoons to bicycles.

title: Friends Come Together for an Intervention
description: Cant a guy just get away for a few months at his familys old cabin upstate? Do his city friends have to show up unannounced, en masse, all concerned and overhelpful?

title: The Twitter Wealthy
description: Twitters public filing for an initial public offering says it has over 100 million daily users. It also has a few very lucky takers.

title: Something Creepy This Way Comes
description: A girl proves to be a pain to her relatives in Nothing Left to Fear, a horror trifle about a ministers family discovering that its new rural neighborhood is a passageway to a demonic petri dish  or something otherwise Hell-like. Dan Bramford (James Tupper of Revenge) and his wife, Wendy (Anne Heche), want only to assimilate into their congregation. But their adolescent daughters have boys on their minds, and that, of course, means jeopardy.

title: Board Battle Leads to Exit of Telecom Italia Chief
description: LONDON  Franco Bernab resigned as chief executive of Telecom Italia on Thursday after he clashed with some of the European telecommunications companys major investors.

title: Big Canadian Carrier Shuns New BlackBerry Phone
description: Rogers Communications, based in Toronto and one of the first carriers in the world to offer devices from BlackBerry, will not sell the ailing smartphone makers new flagship Z30 phone, the president of its wireless unit said on Thursday.

title: Wall Street Seeks to Soothe, While Preparing for Trouble
description: Wall Street is preparing for the government to bounce its first check.

title: Officials Big Salary in California City May Lead to Prison
description: LOS ANGELES  Robert Rizzo, the former city administrator of Bell, Calif., accused of looting millions from city coffers, pleaded no contest to all 69 charges against him on Thursday, prosecutors announced.

title: Armenian Church, Survivor of the Ages, Faces Modern Hurdles
description: ECHMIADZIN, Armenia  In this ancient city, tucked in a valley that has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, King Tiridates III converted to Christianity and declared Armenia to be the worlds first Christian state. The year was 301, more than a decade before the Emperor Constantine put Rome on a similar path.

title: Tunisian Ex-Soccer Player Extradited
description: A former Tunisian soccer player who was sentenced to a decade in prison in Belgium in 2003 for planning a suicide bombing for Al Qaeda against a military base there  which is also used by NATO  has been extradited to the United States to face similar charges in an American court, the Justice Department announced Thursday. The player, Nizar Trabelsi, 43, was indicted under seal in 2006 in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Prosecutors say he traveled to Afghanistan in the spring of 2001 and met with Osama bin Laden and, later, Muhammed Atef, a chief military planner for the terrorist group. The indictment accuses him of obtaining chemicals in Europe to build a 1,000-kilogram bomb and joining others to scout the military base, Kleine Brogel Air Base, as a potential target for a suicide attack.

title: Ballmers Bonus Shrinks on Weakness of Windows
description: SEATTLE  Microsofts board of directors has again penalized the companys chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, for the companys performance by giving him a smaller bonus than he was eligible for.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitters I.P.O. Filing, and Adobe Hacked
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: The Religious Dorm at the Public University
description: TROY, Ala.  There are many clues that life at the newest residence hall on the campus of Troy University is not centered on parties and beer.

title: FIFA Official Urges Worker Protections
description: ZURICH  A vice president of FIFA on Thursday called for global soccers governing body to insist on minimum standards of worker protection on World Cup projects amid allegations of abuse that have troubled construction projects for the 2022 finals in Qatar.

title: Furloughs Alter Routines for Presidents Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly before the federal government shut down at 12:01 a.m. Tuesday, a small group of top White House officials huddled in the West Wing for what turned out to be a discussion of critical importance: how to run the place.

title: Europe Threatens Gazprom With Antitrust Action
description: The European Unions top antitrust enforcer on Thursday threatened to formally charge the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom with restricting trade and price gouging, raising the stakes in a two-year investigation that has already created tensions with Russias president, Vladimir V. Putin.

title: The Moment a Photographer Became a Historian
description: Bill Eppridge, who was best known for his haunting photograph of a busboy kneeling beside the mortally wounded Senator Robert F. Kennedy, died Thursday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 75.

title: Campaigning Again, for Obama to Say No
description: WASHINGTON  Elijah Zarlin was handcuffed outside the White House two years ago for joining in weeks of protests against the Keystone XL pipeline. His arrest would have been an ordinary rite of Washington, except for one thing: Mr. Zarlin had been an aide at the headquarters of Barack Obamas first presidential campaign.

title: Garment District Isnt Just for Fashion Anymore
description: Manhattans garment district is undergoing a renaissance, with the recent sale and refurbishment of many office buildings and an influx of tenants from media, advertising, entertainment, technology and other, nonfashion industries.

title: Russia: A Legal Victory for Kasparov
description: Garry Kasparov, the chess champion and opposition politician, on Thursday won a ruling against the Russian government in the European Court of Human Rights for an illegal arrest at a rally in Moscow in 2007. In the past, Mr. Kasparov has been arrested on pretexts like an allegation that he bit a police officers finger while protesting last year against the conviction of members of the band Pussy Riot. The court found that the 2007 arrest was disproportionate to the aim of maintaining public order and ordered Russian authorities pay Mr. Kasparov about $13,500 in damages.

title: In Autumn, a Taste of the Season
description: Wanda Jacobson understands the appeal of fresh wood-pressed apple cider on a crisp autumn afternoon. What continually surprises her is what people will do to get it.

title: Russia: More Charges for Greenpeace
description: Russian prosecutors have now pressed charges of piracy against the entire crew of the Greenpeace International ship the Arctic Sunrise, including the captain, Peter Willcox; the ships cook and doctor; and two freelance journalists who were among the 30 people aboard last month when Russian authorities seized the vessel during a protest in the Arctic Ocean. The prosecutors charged 16 people on Thursday and 14 on Wednesday. The charges carry a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison upon conviction. The activists said their attempts to scale the side of a Russian oil platform were meant to call attention to the environmental hazards of drilling in icy northern waters.

title: U.S. Accuses 13 Hackers in Web Attacks
description: Thirteen members of a hacking collective that calls itself Anonymous were indicted on Thursday on charges that they conspired to coordinate attacks against prominent Web sites.

title: Weary but Spirited, the Well-Traveled Rays Roll Into Fenway
description: BOSTON  The Tampa Bay Rays arrived here just after 4 a.m. Thursday, their fourth city and second country in five days. They were exhausted but satisfied, having won three straight win-or-go-home games.

title: Britain: Online Surveillance Challenged
description: Three British organizations said Thursday that they had filed a legal challenge in the European Court of Human Rights to the online surveillance programs of the British spy agency the Government Communications Headquarters. The groups are seeking to have the court declare the collection of metadata, including e-mails and social media messages, in secret programs revealed by the American intelligence analyst Edward J. Snowden to be an illegal breach of the right to privacy. The case, financed through donations, has been brought by English PEN, the Open Rights Group and Big Brother Watch, as well as by a German activist. The government said that a similar challenge could not be brought in domestic courts, but that a complaint could be made only to the Investigatory Powers Tribunal, which does not act in public.

title: Jack Dorsey Gave Evan Williams His Voting Power at Twitter
description: Twitters financial filing on Thursday raised new questions about the strained relationship between two of its founders.

title: Boutique Winery Rises to Top Tier
description: Roanoke Vineyards, a boutique winery in its 13th year, has ascended to the top tier of Long Island estates. Its wines are consistently outstanding.

title: Potential New Leader for Trading Commission Under a Lens
description: As Gary Genslers tenure as a Wall Street regulator draws to a close, the White House has begun to vet a senior Treasury Department official as a potential replacement.

title: U.S. and Israel Share a Goal in Iran Talks, but Not a Strategy
description: JERUSALEM  Fearing that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was on the verge of ordering an airstrike on Irans nuclear plants, President Obama sent two emissaries here almost exactly a year ago to stop him. Warning that the White House could not abide an attack in the run-up to the November elections, the Americans persuaded the prime minister to give the newest sanctions time to bite, according to Americans and Israelis familiar with the tense exchanges.

title: Experts See Potential Ways Out for Obama in Debt Ceiling Maze
description: WASHINGTON  Even as President Obama insists that he would be powerless to save the economy from catastrophe should Congress fail to raise the nations debt ceiling, some law professors say he does have options. They may be politically unattractive, unpalatable to the financial markets and subject to legal challenges, these experts say, but these choices are better than failing to live up to the nations financial commitments.

title: Bats and Balls May Need an Introduction
description: The breeze whipping through the air last fall when the Oakland Athletics played the Detroit Tigers had nothing to do with the weather. It came from the Oakland bats, swinging and missing, over and over again.

title: At Cubans Trading Trial, Dispute Over Secrecy of Data
description: DALLAS  Mark Cuban sent out a series of e-mails saying that he had sold his shares in the search engine company Mamma.com because he had received information that the company was about to recruit private investors whose contributions would dilute the value of the public shares, a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer said on Thursday.

title: Amid Bloodshed in Pakistan, a Stock Exchange Soars
description: LONDON  If the best time to buy, as the old business adage says, is when there is blood on the streets, then Pakistans commercial capital, Karachi, offers the ideal investment opportunity.

title: Wrong Side of History
description: Sarah Palin finally got her death panels  a direct blow from the Republican House. In shutting down the government, leaving 800,000 people without a paycheck and draining the economy of $300 million a day, the Party of Madness also took away last-chance cancer trials for children at the National Institutes of Health.

title: Q. Which Night Is Trivia Night?
description: Morrisons seems to have struck a chord with Long Island diners. The restaurant, which opened in June in Plainview, was packed to overflowing on a recent Saturday and was nearly full on a Tuesday, usually one of the slowest nights of the week.

title: How a Debt Ceiling Crisis Could Do More Harm Than the Shutdown
description: The impasse in Congress this week has overshadowed the fact that the government is fast approaching its borrowing limit  or debt ceiling  later this month. Most economists and investors view the debt ceiling as a much more significant issue for the economy, with the potential to set off a global financial crisis. What is all the concern about? Here is an attempt to answer the basic questions.

title: Twitter Puts Numbers to Its I.P.O. Talk
description: Millions of users seem to believe that Twitter has value.

title: The Moderates Who Lighted the Fuse
description: WASHINGTON  THE government shutdown is the work of the so-called kamikaze caucus of about 40 Tea Party Republicans in the House of Representatives. But why is the body of the Republican Party in thrall to its erratic right foot? Maybe the real blame should go to the far more numerous non-Tea Party Republicans, from Speaker John A. Boehner down, who have been unable or unwilling to restrain the radicals.

title: Why Italians Love Francis
description: ROME  ONE day, as Pope Francis was leaving the Casa Santa Marta, a spartan guesthouse in Vatican City where he lives in preference to the lonely but luxurious papal apartments, he met a bishop waiting for his driver. Cant you walk? the pope smiled.

title: Reform Turns Real
description: At this point, the crisis in American governance has taken on a life of its own. Some Republicans are now saying openly that they want concessions in return for reopening the government and avoiding default, not because they have any specific policy goals in mind, but simply because they dont want to feel disrespected. And no endgame is in sight.

title: The Ad Campaign:  De Blasio Not Resting on Laurels
description: Bill de Blasio, New York Citys public advocate and the Democratic nominee for mayor, is running his first campaign commercial of the general election  a documentary-style excerpt from his lofty primary night victory speech. Titled Everyone, the 30-second ad began appearing on local network TV across New York City on Thursday.PRODUCER AKPD Message and Media

title: Frenzy Awaits an Opponent That Has Seen It Before
description: Alex Cobb went to high school in Vero Beach, Fla., but he was born in Boston and remembers enough to know what awaits the Tampa Bay Rays this weekend. Fenway Park has not hosted a playoff game in four years, and the atmosphere should be as charged as it was in Cleveland on Wednesday.

title: Wendy Davis Enters Race for Texas Governor With a Shorter Speech
description: HALTOM CITY, Tex.  Exactly 100 days after the legislative filibuster that defied the Republican establishment and turned her into a Democratic star, State Senator Wendy Davis announced Thursday that she would run for governor, opening an underdog campaign to lead a state that last sent a Democrat to the governors mansion nearly 23 years ago.

title: Unfair Business in College Sports
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is now the sole defendant in a lawsuit that could alter the college sports business model, under which everybody  the N.C.A.A., universities, media companies, coaches  makes money except the student athletes.

title: Silvio Berlusconi Undone
description: Silvio Berlusconis two-decade-long spell over Italian politics seems to have finally broken this week. His attempt to bring down Prime Minister Enrico Lettas coalition government by withdrawing his partys support collapsed when many of Mr. Berlusconis closest political allies refused to go along.

title: A Population Betrayed
description: It is outrageous that millions of the poorest people in the country will be denied health insurance because of decisions made mostly by Republican governors and legislators. These people will neither qualify for their states Medicaid program for the poor nor for subsidized coverage on new insurance exchanges that are being established in every state by the health care reform law.

title: Phony Self-Denial in Congress
description: As the government shutdown continues, more members of Congress are making a show of refusing their salaries or donating them to charities. With hundreds of thousands of idled federal workers unpaid and unsure if they might ever be paid, lawmakers are left to making gestures in lieu of doing a more effective job for their $174,000 annual salary, which the Constitution mandates regardless of the shutdown.

title: Stock Market Is a Bright Spot in Pakistan
description: The Karachi Stock Exchange has risen more than 44 percent in the past 12 months despite rampant violence nationwide.

title: G.O.P. Elders See Liabilities in Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  The hard-line stance of Republican House members on the government shutdown is generating increasing anger among senior Republican officials, who say the small bloc of conservatives is undermining the party and helping President Obama just as the American people appeared to be losing confidence in him.

title: The Ad Campaign: Lhota on the Common Ground
description: In his first television advertisement of the general campaign, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor of New York, takes pains to highlight his similarities with his Democratic opponent, Bill de Blasio, who is surging in the polls. The ad ends with a point of contrast that Mr. Lhota hopes will sway voters.

title: Pirates Break With Past by Playing; Cardinals Relive It by Winning
description: ST. LOUIS  If Tuesday night was a raucous party, with Pittsburgh hosting Cincinnati in the Pirates first playoff game in 21 years, the St. Louis Cardinals countered Thursday with stately tradition. Clydesdales clip-clopped around the warning track before the game, and Busch Stadium was awash in its familiar sea of red.

title: No Trends for Old Men?
Finance Panel Didnt Cave
description: To the Editor:

title: Scissors, Not a Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Only a New Penn Station Will Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Trials in Bangladesh
description: To the Editor:

title: Popes Model for the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Baseball Still the National Pastime?
Mario Montez, a Warhol Glamour Avatar, Dies at 78
description: Mario Montez, whose glamour and poise as a drag performer elevated him to the heights of avant-garde theater and cinema in the 1960s and made him a fixture in films by Andy Warhol, died on Sept. 26 in Key West, Fla.

title: Influence of Jackson Verdict Is Limited
description: After finding on Wednesday that the concert promoter A.E.G. Live was not liable in the death of Michael Jackson, members of the jury told reporters that despite their relatively short deliberations  about 13 hours, after a five-month trial  the job was not easy.

title: Can We See Philosophy? A Dialogue With Ernie Gehr
description: The common currency of philosophy is language. But does it have to be?

title: Goldman Banker With Years Top Tech Quarry
description: Anthony J. Noto, a former Army Ranger and pro-football executive, may seem an odd fit among the cerebral recluses and flashy moneymen of the tech world.

title: Car Fire a Test for High-Flying Tesla
description: DETROIT  Its an automakers worst nightmare: graphic video footage of one of its cars engulfed in flames after an accident.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 4, 2013
description: Thank God the research didnt find that novels increased tooth decay or blocked up your arteries.

title: In Leaked Video, Egyptian Army Officers Debate How to Sway News Media
description: CAIRO  A leaked video of senior Egyptian Army officers debating how to influence the news media during the months preceding the military takeover offers a rare glimpse of the anxiety within the institution at the prospect of civilian oversight.

title: From Left to Right, As Maximize Their Lineup
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  If the name had not been used for a film of an entirely different genre, the sequel to Moneyball might be called Platoon.

title: Fruit of the Loom Sees Workers in Their Underwear
description: LISTING a new job on LinkedIn typically prompts congratulations from friends and relatives, but 25,000 members of the professional networking platform who change their employment status also are about to get a change of underwear.

title: Jobs Report Becomes a Casualty of Shutdown
description: On the first Friday morning of almost any other month, from the trading floors of Wall Street to the hushed hallways of the Federal Reserve, all the attention would be focused on two numbers: the latest government estimates for unemployment and job creation.

title: Finally, It May Be Mattinglys Moment
description: ATLANTA  He is an oddity of history, a man who has spent 24 years in the storied uniforms of the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers without ever reaching the World Series. Don Mattingly was a superstar who has coached and managed for winning teams. Yet he has never appeared, in any capacity, on the brightest stage.

title: Decade of Dedication to an Urban Garden
description: Beside a parking lot in Harlem, there is a stash of sun-ripe tomatoes, okra, collard greens, sweet potatoes, strawberries and watermelons just for the asking.

title: Corrections: October 4, 2013
description: NEW YORK

title: Holier Than Thou? Oh, Shes Just Getting Started
description: Theres nothing like a death in the family to bring out the worst in people. This unhappy truth is displayed with delectably savage humor in Bad Jews, a zesty play by Joshua Harmon that opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater. Tracee Chimo, leading a flawless cast of four in the best comedy of the season to date, gives a ferocious performance as a young Jewish woman, Diana  she prefers to be called by her Hebrew name, Daphna  aggressively fighting to obtain a religious relic left behind by her grandfather.

title: Good Evening, Heartache, Sit Down
description: Hush now, dont explain.

title: Stand-Out Performances
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Now this is the way to end a fairly exciting solving week. No rebuses, no flying geese. Just a nice, Scrabbly 72-word themeless with some great entries and even better cluing. Nearly all the clues hit it out of the park today, in my opinion.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sergei Belov, Star Guard Who Led Soviet Upset of U.S., Dies at 69
description: Sergei Belov, a Russian basketball star who led the Soviet national team in its controversial gold medal victory over the United States at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, died on Thursday in Perm, Russia. He was 69.

title: A Pioneering AIDS Prevention Group Struggles to Stay Relevant
description: In 1981, before the virus that would eventually kill 35 million people around the world even had a name, a small group of men gathered in the West Village apartment of the playwright Larry Kramer to discuss something called the gay cancer.

title: New Trial Ordered for Man Who Helped a Long Island Motivational Speaker Kill Himself
description: The case started oddly enough in July 2009, when the body of a motivational speaker and father of three from Long Island was found tied up, with multiple stab wounds, in his black station wagon on a street in East Harlem.

title: In a First, Saudis Cancel a Speech at the U.N.
description: Saudi Arabia, frustrated by what it apparently regarded as policy setbacks over Syria, Iran and Palestinian statehood, abruptly canceled its turn to speak this week at the annual United Nations General Assembly meeting, diplomatic officials and Arab news agencies reported Thursday.

title: Levity Amid Competition as U.S. Takes a Slim Lead
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Jason Day stood over a 20-foot birdie attempt with a 2 -foot break Thursday, his confidence buoyed by having struck the same putt dozens of times in the scores of rounds he has played at Muirfield Village, his home course. What made the putt hard to read, for the fans gathered around the 18th hole, if not for Day, was that if it dropped, the visitors from the International team would earn their second point of the Presidents Cup.

title: Many Win in Offering, but Some Are Off List
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The list of newly minted millionaires from Twitters public offering will be longer than the average tweet. But the list of who stands to make into the hundreds of millions of dollars is tiny, and shows that sometimes when you roll the dice early in a companys life the payoff can be enormous.

title: Assessing the Impact of the 2011 Debt Ceiling Showdown
description: A Treasury Department report released Thursday cited a series of economic indicators to illustrate how the August 2011 Congressional impasse over raising the debt ceiling hurt the economy.

title: Outside Rodriguezs Arbitration
description: Supporters of Alex Rodriguez gather outside his arbitration at the headquarters of Major League Baseball where he is appealing a 211 game drug suspension.

title: Measuring a Tweets Worth
description: Twitters revenue has steadily grown since 2011 to more than $120 million in the second quarter. But the microblogging site has yet to turn a profit.

title: Rodriguez Thanks Supporters as Hearing Continues
description: Thursday, the fourth day of Alex Rodriguezs arbitration hearing at Major League Baseballs headquarters at Park Avenue and 46th Street in Manhattan, turned into an improvised day-night doubleheader for him.

title: Traveling With Obama to Maryland
description: Stephen Crowley, a Times photographer, offers a closer view of President Obama at a construction plant berating House Republicans.

title: Thievery Comes After Carnage at Kenya Mall
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Mannequins were stripped clean, jewelry cases smashed, racks of expensive suits carted off, dozens of cash registers cracked open and at least one member of the Kenyan security services arrested, caught with a bloody wallet.

title: Adobe Announces Security Breach
description: Hackers infiltrated the computer system of the software company Adobe, gaining access to credit card information and other personal data from 2.9 million of its customers, the company acknowledged on Thursday.

title: Obama Pulls Out of Asian Security and Economic Conferences
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday night canceled the last of his scheduled destinations in a trip he had planned for Asia, saying the government shutdown had made it impossible to travel to a Pacific Rim economic conference in Indonesia or an East Asian security conference in Brunei next week.

title: In Formula One, a Grip Not Easily Loosened
description: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium  The command center of the shimmering, multibillion-dollar road show that is Formula One Grand Prix racing is an unobtrusive, gray-walled motor home known colloquially as the Kremlin.

title: Paris Fashion Week Debrief
description: Cathy Horyn and Eric Wilson discuss the spring 2014 collections at Paris Fashion Week.

title: After Isles Big Step, Tavares Takes Pressure in Stride
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Casey Cizikas, a gritty 22-year-old center who excelled in 2012-13, his first full N.H.L. season, is all eyes and ears when near John Tavares, the teams new captain. That is wise, given what Tavares has achieved since the Islanders selected him first over all in the 2009 draft.

title: Reading Selections in the Empathy Study
description: A study published in the journal Science found that after reading literary fiction, as opposed to popular fiction or serious nonfiction, people performed better on tests measuring empathy, social perception and emotional intelligence  skills that come in especially handy when you are trying to read someones body language or gauge what they might be thinking. These were the reading selections used in one or more of the experiments in the study.

title: This Weeks Movies: Oct. 4, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on "Gravity," "A Touch of Sin" and "A.C.O.D."

title: New Diplomatic Avenue Emerges, in 140-Character Bursts
description: UNITED NATIONS  Countries all over the world, dictatorships and democracies alike, have in the last few years sought to tame  or plug entirely  that real-time fire hose of public opinion known as Twitter.

title: India: Ex-Official Is Jailed in Graft Case
description: An Indian court sentenced Lalu Prasad, a former chief minister of the state of Bihar, to five years in prison for corruption on Thursday after he was found guilty of participating in a scheme in which officials created false receipts and siphoned off $6 million worth of public funds earmarked for animal husbandry for more than a decade. The sentence effectively bars him from participating in the coming national and state elections. Mr. Prasad is the first major political figure affected by a Supreme Court order disqualifying politicians who are sentenced to prison terms of more than two years. More than 40 politicians, bureaucrats and suppliers were sentenced in the case, but Mr. Prasad is by far the most significant. His party controls four parliamentary seats allied with the national governing party, and he is a loyal supporter of Sonia Gandhi, the president of the Congress Party.

title: The Stunning, Sacred Retreats of California
description: Over the past half century, an odd mix of swamis, monks, Zen masters and utopians have secured thousands of acres of prime California real estate to make sanctuaries for those seeking to escape the world. Welcome to Gods country.

title: Marseille, the Secret Capital of France
description: Despite an ambitious face-lift with gleaming new architecture and a refurbished waterfront, Marseille remains a stubbornly glorious melting pot of seediness and sun  which is precisely why its so wonderful.

title: For Rodarte, a Santa Cruz State of Mind
description: A childhood immersed in the suburban ennui and really weird vibes of Santa Cruz has left its quirky imprint on the work of the sister team behind Rodarte, Kate and Laura Mulleavy.

title: Word of the Day | odorous
description: odorous \o-d-rs\ adjective

title: Kershaw Foils Braves as Dodgers Win Easily
description: ATLANTA  Clayton Kershaw was 7 months old the last time the Los Angeles Dodgers won a championship. All the members of the team know the year, Kershaw said, because every day, someone reminds them: the Dodgers won the World Series in 1988  and have never been back.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 10 P.M.
