(NBC) ELIZABETHS STORY: A MEREDITH VIEIRA SPECIAL Ms. Vieira interviews Elizabeth Smart, who, at the age of 14 in 2002, was kidnapped from the bedroom of her Salt Lake City home by Brian David Mitchell, a religious zealot, and his wife, Wanda Barzee, and subsequently chained up, dressed in disguise and raped before being rescued nine months later. Ms. Smart, left, who established the Elizabeth Smart Foundation to help prevent crimes against children, will discuss life with her captors as told in her memoir, My Story, to be released on Monday.

title: Rangers Stumble in Vigneaults Debut as Coach
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The Rangers looked awful on opening night of their 88th season, losing to the Phoenix Coyotes by 4-1 on Thursday and ruining the debut of Coach Alain Vigneault.

title: News Quiz | October 4, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Poll Finds Support for de Blasio, if Not All His Ideas
description: New York City voters want to keep Raymond W. Kelly as police commissioner. They want more charter schools. And nearly half of them support the Police Departments use of the stop-and-frisk tactic.

title: Indian, Chinese Passports Among Least Attractive for Global Visa Waivers
description: NEW DELHI A global index that ranks countries based on freedom of travel for their citizens has ranked India among the bottom few with its South Asian neighbors like Afghanistan and Pakistan. Indias citizens have visa-free access to only 52 countries, with India ranking in 74th place, along with Uzbekistan.

title: HTC Reports Its First Loss, but Samsung Shows Vigor
description: TOKYO  The diverging fortunes of two of the leading smartphone providers in Asia were demonstrated on Friday when Samsung Electronics of South Korea predicted better-than-expected quarterly earnings, while HTC of Taiwan reported its first loss.

title: The Latest New York Times/Siena College Poll
description: Bill de Blasio has a commanding lead over his Republican opponent for mayor, Joseph J. Lhota, the latest New York Times/Siena College poll finds.

title: The State of the Mayors Race
description: Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate, had a commanding advantage over his Republican opponent, Joseph J. Lhota.

title: Polling on the Mayors Race
description: Bill de Blasio is leading Joseph J. Lhota by wide margins in the early polls following their primary victories.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/Siena College Poll of New York City consisted of telephone interviews with 1,168 adult residents throughout the city conducted Sept. 28 through Oct. 2. Of these, 700 are considered likely to vote.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Oct. 4, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Boat Packed With Hundreds of Migrants Sinks Near Sicily
description: Jim Yardley and Elisabetta Povoledo write about a disaster on the Mediterranean Sea in the article Boat Packed With Migrants Sinks Near Sicily, Killing Dozens.

title: Is Miguel Cabrera the Hero of the Post-Steroid Era?
description: Miguel Cabrera looked as if he were wearing pajamas, untucked and mismatched, as he lumbered around the Detroit Tigers clubhouse in a sweaty gray T-shirt and a pair of Nike shower shoes. Known to his teammates as Miggy, Cabrera wore his hair dense down the middle and bare on the sides  in what he called a faux-hawk. In an era in which even baseball players have come to resemble souped-up Eastern bloc Olympians, Miggy packs more of a stonemason physique: he is 6-foot-4 with massive arms and torso, but also a noticeable paunch of fluctuating size and, God bless him, well-articulated man-boobs. Yet he is the reigning American League M.V.P. and quite possibly the best hitter of his generation. (One of the fun parts about writing about baseball is inviting a best of his generation debate before the first paragraph is even over.)

title: Should Video Games Be Considered a Sport?
description: Players compete in huge arenas, cheered on by thousands of screaming fans, with millions of dollars in prize money at stake. Top competitors must endure grueling training regimens, but also enjoy soaring salaries and corporate endorsement deals.

title: New York Today: Out of the Mothballs
description: Updated 12:21 p.m. | A check to the Girl Scouts signed by John Wayne. Hospital newsletters from the 1930s. Silverware pilfered from the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Ask Well: Relieving Sore Muscles
description: Question:

title: Daily Report: Twitter Makes Its I.P.O. Plans Known
description: Twitter has taken the cover off its initial public offering, making public its prospectus and setting the clock on one of the most anticipated stock sales of the year, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report.

title: Week 5 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Saints (4-0) at Bears (3-1)

title: Other Ways to Get Your Jobs Data
description: Heres one potential beneficiary of the government shutdown: all the alternative labor market indicators that are fighting for attention thanks to the data vacuum left by the shuttered Labor Department.

title: A 7 Up Series for Russia, With Soviet Roots
description: Born in the USSR is an award-winning documentary series that started out as the Soviet version of British director Michael Apteds 7 Up, the project that has followed a group of children starting at age 7 and checked in with them every seven years.

title: Barclays Has Strong Demand for Rights Issue
description: LONDON  Barclays said on Friday that investors had bought 94.6 percent of the shares the British bank was selling as part of a rights issue.

title: Pope Visits Assisi, Bearing the Message of a Favored Saint
description: ASSISI, Italy  It was clear from the moment that Pope Francis began his first visit to the town of the saint whose name he shares that he would use personal, intimate gestures to send a strong message.

title: Syrians Seeking Asylum End Standoff in France
description: PARIS  A three-day standoff between security forces in the French port of Calais and several dozen Syrians ended Friday evening when the Syrians backed down, a migrant association in northern France said.

title: Twitter Opens Up
description: TWITTER OPENS UP | Twitter on Thursday made public its prospectus for an initial public offering, providing a glimpse at the high-flying companys financial health. The filing showed just how central smartphones and tablets are to Twitters business, underscoring the technology industrys shift to a mobile world, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. But despite evidence that Twitter is increasing its revenue from mobile advertising, the company also showed that it has not yet turned a profit, and has been steadily losing money, and that its user growth has been slowing since the end of last year.

title: Today in Small Business: Becoming a Business Owner After a Bullet to the Spine
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Addressing Teenage Drinking
description: The topic this week for our third New Parent-Old Parent column is teenage drinking, which I found to be one of the very hardest parenting problems I faced. To be perfectly honest, I never felt I got it right. Several years back, when my twins were 17 and their older brother was 19, I described my frustrations in a parenting column:

title: New York Film Festival: Jia Zhang-ke on Contemporary China
description: Updated, 8:10 a.m. | The drama A Touch of Sin, from the director Jia Zhang-ke, tells four stories of contemporary China that follow working-class characters pushed to the brink of violence when treated with brutality at work and elsewhere. The events in the movie are fictionalized versions of incidents widely reported in the press. The film, which won best screenplay at Cannes in the spring, was shown this week at the New York Film Festival and opens Friday in New York. (See Manohla Dargiss review.) At Cannes, Mr. Jia spoke about how the films visuals and locations played into the stories. Speaking through an interpreter during an interview at the Paramount Hotel in New York, Mr. Jia discussed issues the movie raises. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

title: The Shutdowns Data Blackout
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Today, for the first time since 1996 and only the second time in modern memory, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will not issue its monthly jobs report, as a result of the shutdown of nonessential government services. This raises an important question: Are the B.L.S. report and other economic data that the government provides nonessential?

title: Teenagers in The Times | September 2013
description: In this monthly feature we collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson Teaching With Teenagers in The Times.

title: T FALL TRAVEL
description: A childhood immersed in the suburban ennui and really weird vibes of Santa Cruz has left its quirky imprint on the work of the sister team behind Rodarte, Kate and Laura Mulleavy.

title: Tea From Their Childs New Teacher
description: Dear Diary:

title: Skills Practice | Understanding and Making Analogies
description: Update: Oct. 8, 2013

title: Bankers and Business Leaders Concerned About Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  The prospect of a mid-October debt crisis on top of the government shutdown shapes up to be sort of a perfect storm for the economy that is rattling American bankers and businesses, a leading corporate executive said on Thursday.

title: After 30 Years, Theyre Still in Concert
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Behind the Poster: Romeo and Juliet
description: It wouldnt be a new theater season without Shakespeare, and it wouldnt be Shakespeare without riffs on gender. The Donmar Warehouses all-female production of Julius Caesar begins performances next week at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn. Later this month, a rouged Mark Rylance stars as Olivia in Twelfth Night on Broadway.

title: Popcast: Lorde, Cyrus and the Different Paths Into the Top 10
description: This week: New and old teenagers.

title: Merkels Conservative Bloc Sounds Out Possible Partners
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and representatives of her conservative bloc began the first in a series of exploratory talks with potential coalition partners on Friday, amid a growing sense of urgency from all sides about the danger of leaving Berlin rudderless for too long.

title: Twitters I.P.O. Plan Has an International Focus
description: LONDON  Twitter might have American roots, but the social-networking service is a truly international phenomenon, its filing for an initial public offering shows. And it is banking on growth overseas to fuel its continued expansion.

title: Burger Perk Ends for Furloughed Federal Workers
description: A Washington burger chain that offered free food to furloughed federal workers said it would end the deal on Thursday because it had become too costly.

title: Italy Suspends Search for Shipwreck Victims
description: Having floated for at least two days in the choppy Mediterranean Sea to reach Europe, a rickety trawler overstuffed with African migrants fleeing war and poverty was nearing a Sicilian island, not even a quarter-mile away. But it was still dark and no one had yet spotted them. So to signal their position, someone set a match to a blanket.

title: Goat Droppings and Real Democracy
description: ISTANBUL  Goat droppings is the polite translation for a graphic Turkish expression that describes something insipid: The idea is that goat pellets are relatively inoffensive, lacking the quality of real dung.

title: Sothebys Adopts Shareholder Rights Plan to Fend Off Loeb
description: Updated, 3:14 p.m. |

title: Company Is Scolded for Mistakes at Fukushima
description: TOKYO  In an unusually public scolding, Japans nuclear watchdog agency criticized the operator of the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant on Friday for making mistakes that allowed radioactive water to leak into the Pacific Ocean, and ordered it to fix the problems quickly.

title: Swiss Investigate Banks Over Currency Trading
description: FRANKFURT  The banking industry, already troubled by official inquiries that have badly damaged its reputation, got hit by another on Friday. Swiss authorities said they were investigating whether financial institutions had colluded to manipulate foreign exchange markets.

title: Mobile Payment Startups Face Reluctant Indian Consumers
description: When Mrugank S., 33, an information technology professional in Bangalore, Karnataka, ordered five teaming carts of produce from Big Basket, an online grocery store, he chose card-on-delivery as the mode of payment. But when the two deliverymen wheeled up to his flat on the 14th floor of a tower, he pulled out a wad of bills.

title: As Twitter Opens Up, Employees Do, Too
description: Twitter was largely silent last month about the details of its planned initial public offering, saying only that it had filed papers confidentially.

title: Rodriguez Sues, Targeting Baseball and Medical Treatment
description: Faced with baseballs longest doping suspension, Alex Rodriguez sued Major League Baseball late Thursday, accusing it of buying the cooperation of Anthony Bosch, the head of an anti-aging clinic at the center of a doping scandal, as part of a continuing witch hunt to force Rodriguez out of the sport.

title: We Dont Need No Education
description: The Republican shutdown of government is compounding what was already a disastrous year for Head Start, the federal program that prepares disadvantaged 3 and 4 year olds for school. This critically important program is already reeling from the sequester, the senseless across the board budget cuts that began last spring, which caused Head Start centers to scale back on transportation, basic learning materials and, in some cases, to even close their doors. According to the National Head Start Association, owing to the sequester cuts that began in March, 57,000 fewer children will have access to the program this year  with even deeper cuts to come if the mindless process of budget cutting continues.

title: Alex Rodriguezs Lawsuit Against Major League Baseball
description: Alex Rodriguez sued Major League Baseball, accusing it of buying the cooperation of Anthony Bosch, the head of an anti-aging clinic at the center of a doping scanda.

title: Accommodations | A Virgin Islands Getaway Where Richard Branson Is Your Landlord
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Dealing With Drafting Errors in the Health Care Law
description: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

title: The Short-Seller Stands Tall
description: Your fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, took a $500-million loss on its investment in J. C. Penney. How did that feel?  Im not emotional about investments. Investing is something where you have to be purely rational, and not let emotion affect your decision making  just the facts.

title: Drinking Like Hemingway
description: A critical assessment of Brooklyns authors; why youre gaining weight on Sundays.

title: Why I Silence Your Call, Even When Im Free
description: My cousin Stacey in San Francisco called recently. We hadnt spoken since she visited me the previous month, and I missed her. I was sitting in my office, catching up on e-mail while refreshing my Twitter feed every few minutes. Hardly too busy for a chat.

title: When Meta Met Data
description: Lost in all the anxiety and hand-wringing over revelations about big data, personal privacy and the National Security Agency is another unfortunate, and consequential, societal development: A transformation in the meaning of meta. This has happened specifically in relation to metadata  the transactional digital information that pinpoints the date and time you called someone, for example, or locates the spot from which you last accessed your e-mail account  but also to our larger understanding of the concept of meta; our metaunderstanding, as it were.

title: Dead Mans Burden
description: A family member died last winter and named me and my sister the heirs to his estate. In a letter accompanying the will (but not part of it), he asked us to donate several thousand dollars to certain organizations. Some of these are extremely right-wing groups, which we feel border on the fringe: paranoiac with no objectivity, with ties to militant political organizations. We feel conflicted about this  we want to honor our relatives wishes but really take offense to some of these groups. L.B.,CALIFORNIA

title: And Then Steve Said, Let There Be an iPhone
description: The 55 miles from Campbell to San Francisco make for one of the nicest commutes anywhere. The journey mostly zips along the Junipero Serra Freeway, a grand and remarkably empty highway that abuts the east side of the Santa Cruz Mountains. It is one of the best places in Silicon Valley to spot a start-up tycoon speed-testing his Ferrari and one of the worst places for cellphone reception. For Andy Grignon, it was therefore the perfect place for him to be alone with his thoughts early on Jan. 8, 2007.

title: The 9.22.13 Issue
description: INTO THE WILDFIRE

title: The Peculiar Beauty of Flotsam
description: Whats floating in the East River?

title: Who Made Movie Popcorn?
description: In the 1920s, movie palaces rose up around the country like so many portals into a glamorous world. After you bought a ticket, you might pass through gilded archways and ascend a grand staircase lighted by a crystal chandelier to find your velvet seat. Eating was not meant to be part of the experience, says Andrew F. Smith, author of Popped Culture: A Social History of Popcorn in America. Theater owners feared that audiences would strew popcorn and peanuts on those crimson carpets. They hung signs discouraging people from bringing in food from vendors parked outside and didnt sell it themselves.

title: Bridging the Gap Between High School and College, at a Price
description: MY older son is about a month into his freshman year at college, and like most of his classmates, is adjusting to new roommates, classes and doing his own laundry.

title: Potbelly Doubles in Market Debut Amid Strong Investor Appetite
description: Investors have an enormous hunger for shares of the Potbelly Corporation, it seems.

title: A Major Photography Museum in Marrakesh
description: The worlds largest photography museum is coming to Marrakesh: the Marrakech Museum for Photography and Visual Art is scheduled to open in 2016 near the Menara Gardens on the outskirts of the old city.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Lets Read About Sex
description: This week, Francine Prose and Anna Holmes talk about the most erotic books theyve ever read; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alison Wolf discusses The XX Factor; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Aaron Curry Unveils New Sculpture
description: In his most significant public sculpture to date, Aaron Curry will unveil a new work at Lincoln Centers Josie Robertson Plaza called Melt to Earth.

title: The Gun Report: October 4, 2013
description: For practical, common sense ideas regarding gun control, maybe we should look to Canada, Adam Gopnik wrote on The New Yorkers Web site on Tuesday. Gopniks parents live in Ontario, surrounded by crops, animals, and pestsand indeed by farmers who need and use rifles. In order to procure a gun for, say, culling a raccoon infestation, you need to fill out an application for a license and take a gun-safety courseand if your current or former spouse doesnt sign your application, the police have to inform them that youre applying for a firearms license.

title: Getting It Right: Lore Segal Talks About Half the Kingdom
description: Lore Segal published her first novel in 1964. Other Peoples Houses was a semi-autobiographical story about a young girl growing up in England after Hitler took control of Austria. When Ms. Segal was 10 years old, she left Vienna for England as part of the Kindertransport program. She moved to New York in 1951. In her new novel, Half the Kingdom, older hospital patients are mysteriously contracting Alzheimers disease at a rapid rate. In The New York Times Book Review, Patricia T. OConner wrote: Fans of Segals fiction should feel right at home in this darkly comic novel. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Segal, 85, discussed what the book says about aging, the recurring characters in her fiction, whether she ever thinks of retiring and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: A Call for Self-Restraint at the U.N.
description: PARIS  It has taken more than two years and 120,000 deaths in Syria for the United Nations Security Council to finally cease being paralyzed by vetoes and make a decision.

title: Sex Lives
description: SWINGLANDBetween the Sheets of the Secretive, Sometimes Messy, but Always Adventurous Swinging LifestyleBy Daniel Stern  Touchstone, $26.

title: 1912: Titanic Disaster
description: The Titanic, new White Star liner, founders off Newfoundland; reports are most contradictory, but appalling loss of life is feared, said The New York Herald, a forerunner of the International Herald Tribune, describing one of the worst maritime disasters in history.

title: Lets Do It
description: Birds do it, Ella Fitzgerald sang. Bees do it. Even educated fleas do it. Musicians have always had an easy time expressing lust. Without sex, most of Princes work would be a John Cage-like experiment in complete silence.

title: Love During Wartime
description: The big story is Lisbon in 1940: the last way out of Europe as the Nazis advance, a neutral port full of spies and desperate refugees. Thousands of them have struggled south from France, managed the almost impossible trick of getting the right papers with the right stamps at the right time in the right place, and now theyre waiting to see if they can arrange passage out. Lisbon in 1940 is famously melodramatic; its where Ingrid Bergman was heading at the end of Casablanca.

title: No Sex Please, Were Buddhist
description: Last summer my beloved, who is on a meditation kick that has reshaped the contours of his disposition in a most agreeable way, attended a weekend retreat at a Zen monastery. While there, he tucked his wallet under a mattress and returned from a serenity session to find it some $200 lighter. It was a small price to pay for a lesson in detachment, he later concluded, as I audibly gritted my teeth.

title: Acquired Tastes
description: The finding of an object, Sigmund Freud wrote a century ago in his Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, is in fact a refinding of it. The patterns and paths our lusts will take, what we will yearn to do and have done to us and whom we will wish to do these things with  to a great extent, our erotic longings are laid down early, beginning in childhood and even infancy. Freud has lost currency in recent decades, but few in the field of sex research, no matter how they qualify his premise or dismiss him as unscientific, would argue that our early experiences dont have the power to profoundly shape our later cravings, and two experiments described in Jesse Berings Perv: The Sexual Deviant in All of Us lend indirect proof.

title: What You Wish For
description: Discussing his classic noir tales of adultery and murder, The Postman Always Rings Twice and Double Indemnity, James M. Cain set forth a concept he called the love rack. For him, it meant finding a way to manipulate readers into caring about his criminal characters and their plight, and surrendering to the story. The terms connotations of torture were apt. In Cains novels, desire is a prison, a death trap. If the author can seduce the audience into investing in that desire, and the fate of the lovers in its thrall, the reader essentially joins them on that rack, with each plot twist proving another pull of the rope, another turn of the screw.

title: Cherry Bombshells
description: A girl can do what she wants to do, Joan Jett sings in her anthem Bad Reputation, and thats what Im gonna do. Similar sentiments drove the Runaways, Jetts first group and perhaps the first teenage, all-female hard-rock band signed to a major American label. Despite defiant assertions of independence like the classic Cherry Bomb, the band remains cruelly underrated, a perception Evelyn McDonnell seeks to rectify in her scrupulously researched Queens of Noise. Ambition and self-determination are prevailing themes: for these women, pursuing those aims in the 1970s could be brutal, especially when contending with adolescent hormones.

title: Rosedud
description: If you have not already done so, please see The Room. Certain films elicit so much joy they cannot be recommended highly enough. The Room is such a film. Not because it is good. No. The Room is not a good film. It is bad. Some call it the best bad movie ever made. But bad does not do it justice. In fact, no adjective I know fully conveys the comprehensive artistic disaster that is The Room. Perhaps some Amazonian tribe has a word that means something so terrible it achieves a certain kind of majesty, but in English we do not.

title: The Price of Equality
description: Earlier this year, Sheryl Sandberg asked the members of a mainly female audience of undergraduates at Harvard University to stand up if they thought one day they could be C.E.O. of their company or even president of the United States. Many stayed seated. For the chief operating officer of Facebook and the fledgling elite she was addressing, one crucial barrier on the road to gender equality may well be what Sandberg calls the leadership ambition gap  the lack of women with the self-confidence to lean in like men.

title: In Performance: Orlando Bloom
description: The actor performs a scene from the new Broadway production of Shakespeares Romeo and Juliet.

title: Yoga Has Limited Menopause Benefits
description: Many women seek natural alternatives to hormone replacement therapy to treat menopause symptoms. Some have turned to yoga, but a rigorous new trial shows that its benefits may be limited, at best.

title: The Devils Own
description: Many readers of Jeanette Wintersons new novel will already have traveled with her to 17th-century England in her 1990 novel Sexing the Cherry. Like most of Wintersons work, that early book is brief, copious and sometimes astonishing  Clarendons History of the Rebellion meets Naked Lunch. In The Daylight Gate, Winterson now puts her mind to the Pendle Hill witch trials of 1612, whose 400th anniversary has occasioned a small outpouring of fiction and poetry.

title: Hell Hath a Fury
description: I can tell you in just two words why ALEX (MacLehose, $24.95), a thriller by the fashionable French author Pierre Lemaitre, was such a sensation in Europe. Partisan politics. Just kidding! The two words are  sadistic sex.

title: Songs of Experience
description: When we first met Paul Chowder, the hyper-garrulous narrator of Nicholson Bakers 2009 novel The Anthologist, he was furiously blocked on writing the introduction to an anthology of rhyming poetry, and somewhat less furiously blocked on salvaging his relationship with his longtime girlfriend, Roz. What came seeping from around those blockages was a mordant and effervescently graceful disquisition on the nature of poetry, poets, failure and the interesting blind pain of wrongness: a riff-tastic essay masquerading as a novel, or vice versa. The voice of Paul Chowder  prickly, whimsical, genially pedagogic, opinion-stippled and often lavishly intelligent  supplied the vessel, yet poetry, the novels subject and in some sense its main character, provided the sustenance.

title: Now Screening | A Train Film to Celebrate Doug Aitkens Station to Station Tour
description: By now the resounding whistle of Doug Aitkens Station to Station art train has blown all the way across the country, from New York City to the Bay Area. The nomadic happening, as the artist called it, brought artists, musicians and other creative visionaries together for exhibitions and performances in cities like Pittsburgh, Kansas City and Santa Fe last month. What I really like about Doug is that he wants to communicate with the whole world, said the German photographer and sculptor Thomas Demand, one of the projects participants, who has known Aitken for nearly two decades.

title: Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, Who Ousted U.S. From Vietnam, Is Dead
description: Vo Nguyen Giap, the relentless and charismatic North Vietnamese general whose campaigns drove both France and the United States out of Vietnam, died on Friday in Hanoi. He was believed to be 102.

title: Image of the Day: October 4
Paperback Row
description: FROM THE RUINS OF EMPIRE: The Revolt Against the West and the Remaking of Asia,  by Pankaj Mishra. (Picador, $17.) This is a superb history of Asian intellectual responses to Western colonialism in the 19th and 20th centuries, from Ottoman Turkey to Meiji Japan. Mishra tells this story through the biographies of two independent thinkers: the itinerant Persian-born agitator Jamal al-Din al-Afghani and the Chinese reformer Liang Qichao.

title: Netanyahu Plans to Meet With European Leaders on Iranian Nuclear Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that he would meet with European leaders next week in hopes of influencing the negotiations scheduled to begin Oct. 15 over Irans nuclear program, part of what he described as a comprehensive international struggle.

title: Inside the List
description: Ocean State: Jhumpa Lahiri grew up in Rhode Island, right next to the state universitys main campus in Kingston, but youd never know it from her first three books. Outside of her brief authors biography, the state never makes an appearance in the story collections Interpreter of Maladies and Unaccustomed Earth, while in the novel The Namesake it earns just two passing mentions: once during a school field trip and once when the protagonists train is delayed by a suicide on the tracks somewhere in Rhode Island.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SIGNATURE OF ALL THINGS,  by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Viking, $28.95.) In this winning novel by the author of Eat, Pray, Love, a botanists hunger for explanations carries her through the better part of Darwins century, and to Tahiti.

title: Golden Boy With Silver Hair
description: CHICAGO  Claiming an ever-smaller slice of the cultural pie and with fewer media outlets to spread the word, orchestras and their conductors struggle for visibility these days. But there are signs that Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra since 2010, has solved the problem better than most.

title: No Comment Necessary: What If the Government Defaults?
description: In a Thursday report, the Treasury Department explained what would happen if Congress were to refuse to raise the federal debt limit.

title: When Converting a Roth I.R.A. Back to a Traditional One Makes Sense
description: WHEN it comes to making financial decisions to save on taxes, you dont usually get a do-over. Just ask all those people who rushed to make large tax-free gifts to family members at the end of last year before a historically high exemption was set to expire. Not only did the exemption not end, but it was increased for 2013. And there was no way to get those tax-driven gifts back.

title: Snowboarding at the Cardrona Halfpipe
description: Every August, the worlds best snowboarders come to work on big-air and physics-defying in Wanaka, New Zealand.

title: How Parents Handle Teenage Drinking
description: This weeks New Parent, Old Parent question really gets to the heart of why we created this collaboration between Booming and Motherlode. Back when he was in the thick of it, my colleague Mike Winerip wrote a column about how much he was struggling with how to handle the question of teenage drinking. Did he have to take a complete no drinking stance, he asked? Or should he assume that some drinking was inevitable, and try to teach moderation rather than abstinence? He was, he writes, assailed just for asking the questions  but whats truly interesting is who the parents who knew exactly what to do about teenage drinking turned out to be: the parents of younger children.

title: Company Man
description: Patrick Flanerys first novel, Absolution (2012), was a beautiful book of secrets, a multilayered tale of post-apartheid South Africa. His second, Fallen Land, is very different in style and substance, a dystopian story set on the outskirts of an unnamed Midwestern city that bears some resemblance to Omaha, where Flanery was raised.

title: A Snowboarding Wonderland
description: Snowboarders flock to New Zealands South Island in August to take advantage of the halfpipe at Cardrona Alpine Resort.

title: Icahn Gives Up Fight Over Dell Appraisal Rights
description: Carl C. Icahn is finally abandoning his battle against Dells sale to its founder.

title: Summer Camp for the Winter Olympics
description: WANAKA, New Zealand  From the bottom, they look like butterflies, dropping soundlessly into the halfpipe and soaring high above its walls, spinning and flipping, flashes of color cascading over the whiteness. Its only after they skid to a stop and lift their bug-eyed goggles that you see the dreadlocks and soul patches, the Rockstar and Monster energy-drink logos, the tie-dye slickers and the ubiquitous ear buds.

title: Nets Kidd Receives Two-Game Suspension
description: DURHAM, N.C.  The N.B.A. on Friday imposed a two-game suspension on Nets Coach Jason Kidd, who pleaded guilty in July to a drunken-driving charge.

title: Both Hero and Villain, and Irresistible
description: Before there was a documentary about WikiLeaks  before there was a major motion picture about its founder  Julian Assange was a star.

title: Another Missed Ritual: Jobs Numbers
description: Jobs Report Becomes a Casualty of Shutdown

title: Cancellation of Trip by Obama Plays to Doubts of Asia Allies
description: BEIJING  As President Obama made apologetic calls to Asia to cancel his planned trip to the region, Chinas leader, Xi Jinping, was taking a star turn in some of the same countries Mr. Obama would have visited.

title: With No New Plan, Boehner Makes Angry Plea on Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans emerged from a closed-door meeting on Friday with no new strategy to end the budget standoff and an angry plea to President Obama to negotiate over his health care law.

title: Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: New Fashion Runway: Wall Street
description: With his red-carpet gowns, lush cashmere sweaters and jet-set shoulder totes, Michael Kors has influenced fellow designers across the globe.

title: The First Illicit Thing You Read
description: In the Book Reviews Sex Issue, a select group of writers shared their memories of the first illicit thing they ever read. More than 200 readers also wrote on The New York Timess Web site about their experiences with books, poems and other works of literature that their parents or teachers might not have wanted them to read.

title: Delivering the News, All of It, in 2 Minutes
description: LOS ANGELES  The mission: re-create the history of the news media in two minutes or less.

title: Off the Charts: In Europe, Adult Unemployment Rises
description: The number of unemployed adults in the euro zone countries reached a record high in August, despite a continued decline in Germany.

title: In Performance: Orlando Bloom
description: In the new Broadway production of Romeo and Juliet, Orlando Bloom and Condola Rashad star as the doomed young lovers.

title: Q. & A. | Greg Lauren on His Foray Into Fragrance
description: With his fifth ready-to-wear collection behind him, the 43-year-old L.A. artist-turned-designer Greg Lauren will make his fragrance industry debut on Tuesday, when his namesake unisex fragrance hits shelves at the Barneys New York flagship on Madison Avenue. I thought this would have the same emotional themes that Id want to express in my collection, which never feels like a fragment is made for men and another for women, said Lauren, a nephew of Ralph Lauren. The exclusive scent is the second in the luxury department stores designer fragrance collection, which started in 2012 with a LWren Scott creation. Made by the New York perfumer Ralf Schwieger, whose work includes Lipstick Rose by Frdric Malle and Eau des Merveilles by Herms, the blends sweet aroma is built around tonka beans, vanilla and coconut, offset by a musky veil of sandalwood, amber and moss.

title: The Building Has 1,000 Eyes
description: Some of the wealthiest people in New York City live at 740 Park Avenue: the industrialist David Koch and the financier Stephen Schwarzman, among others. Its hard to pass the board inspection; its very hard to get past the vigilant doormen.

title: Carnegie Hall and Stagehands Settle Contract Dispute
description: The negotiations lasted more than a year and led to a strike that canceled Carnegie Halls planned opening night for the first time in the halls 122-year history. But after only two days, the dispute between Carnegies management and its stagehands was settled on Friday, and the hall announced that it was fully back in business.

title: T FALL TRAVEL
description: Can a modern family make a home among hordes of tourists under the watchful eye of Englands National Trust? The grandson of Vita Sackville-West and Harold Nicolson attempts to bring Sissinghurst, one of the most famous gardens in the world, into the 21st century.

title: Shutdowns Pinch Leaves Governors With Tough Calls
description: LOS ANGELES  With no end in sight to the federal government shutdown, governors across the nation are struggling with a cascade of tough decisions about when and whether to step in with state money to keep shuttered parks and programs operating until the deadlock is resolved.

title: Luxury Moves to Mulberry Street
description: The architecture and development company Flank set out years ago to prove what others are now discovering: there is a market in Lower Manhattan for oversize condominiums in boutique buildings, no matter the neighborhood.

title: Climbing to the Top of His Range
description: The resurgence of the countertenor voice  roughly equivalent to a male alto  in classical music began about 70 years ago in Britain, so its appropriate that one of the best of the emerging generation is Iestyn Davies, who hails from York, England.

title: A New Life, Furloughed
description: Katherine Buckingham, a furloughed FEMA employee, is counting the days of the federal government shutdown until she can get back to work.

title: Happy to Be Alive ... and Dancing
description: The choreographer David Dorfman drives a Saab convertible, which he bought in his early 50s. But dont call it a midlife crisis car.

title: De Blasio Focuses on Inequality as He Courts Business Elite
description: Bill de Blasio delivered on Friday his most detailed blueprint yet for how he would reimagine New York as a more equitable and populist metropolis, even as he works diligently behind the scenes to send a subtler message to the citys corporate titans: He is not their enemy.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Reykjavik; Adams County, Pa.; San Diego
description: Iceland Airwaves, ReykjavikSince beginning in an airplane hangar in 1999, this music festival, from Oct. 30 to Nov. 3, has showcased an eclectic mix of musical acts in a variety of locations, from neighborhood clubs to art museums to the new Harpa concert hall. This years lineup includes the British electronic musician Gold Panda, the Syrian folk-pop musician Omar Souleyman, above, and the Swedish experimental group Goat.

title: Trading an African Dashiki for Union Blue
description: We most heartily endorse the earnest and energetic efforts being put forth by Mr. Delaney, and John Jones of this city, towards the enlistment of volunteers for the Artillery Brigade, to be composed entirely of colored men, announced The Chicago Tribune on Oct. 2, 1863. The article focused on black Union recruitment in the city, a process that had been in full swing for months across the North and Union-occupied South. But the paper was burying the lede: by the fall of 1863 Mr. Delany  Martin Robison Delany, the nations foremost advocate for black migration out of the country  had become one of Uncle Sams best recruiters.

title: Unemployment of Adults Falls in Germany, but Not the Rest of Europe
description: THE euro zone can be separated into two groups, at least in terms of unemployment: Germany and the rest.

title: Video Reviews of Gravity, A Touch of Sin and A.C.O.D.
description: In this weeks video, Times film critics share their thoughts on the science fiction thriller Gravity, the Chinese drama A Touch of Sin and the comedy A.C.O.D. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: T FALL TRAVEL
description: Despite an ambitious face-lift with gleaming new architecture and a refurbished waterfront, Marseille remains a stubbornly glorious melting pot of seediness and sun  which is precisely why its so wonderful.

title: Recalling Blitzkrieg Bop on the Bowery
description: Nobody knows what punk rock truly is. Some have defined it well: Kurt Cobain simply said, Punk rock means freedom. Others not so well: A 1992 Subaru commercial insisted that the Imprezas were just like punk, except its cars. In Next Stop, Nowhere, a 1982 episode of the television procedural Quincy M.E., a murder has taken place in a club and a concerned parent describes punk to Jack Klugmans titular coroner as violence-oriented music that does nothing but reinforce all those bad feelings. The episode is now the go-to example for getting the punk spirit horribly wrong on screen.

title: Wheelies: The Rent More Cars Edition
description: Updated, 4:01 p.m. |

title: Modernizing an English Garden
description: Can a modern family make a home among hordes of tourists under the watchful eye of Englands National Trust? The grandson of Vita Sackville-West and Harold Nicolson attempts to bring Sissinghurst, one of the most famous gardens in the world, into the 21st century.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Lets Read About Sex
description: This week, Francine Prose, Anna Holmes and Alison Wolf.

title: In Mauis Upcountry, Where the Paniolo Roam
description: At the Oskie Rice Arena, the Friday night lights hung in the damp, mid-December Hawaiian air. Beaming through Mauis notorious red clay dust, the lights served as a backdrop to one of the Upcountrys biggest annual events. On the metal bleachers, families were bundled against their idea of the cold: a winter chill that sank just below 60 degrees. There were coats, blankets and hoodie strings pulled tight. There was Portuguese soup and Puerto Rican stew at the family-run concession stands, where the handwritten menus were scrawled in thick felt marker, crossed through as the onolicious fried ice cream or pork with tofu and macaroni ran out.

title: Cowboy Culture on Maui
description: Welcome to the Upcountry, home of ranches, rodeos and a rich cowboy tradition.

title: Long Before the Shutdown, Republicans Were Hurting National Parks
description: The closing of 401 national parks, monuments, waterways and memorials (plus 561 national wildlife refuges) as part of the broadergovernment shutdown has the public in an uproar and Republicans in (partial) retreat.On Tuesday, the House passed a bill to fund these facilities as one of several measures to open those parts of the government whose shuttering has drawn the most criticism  a truly cynical gesture that rightly found no traction whatever in the Senate.

title: Treasures of the Cinque Terre
description: It was a stroke of luck, really, that my luggage was lost when I flew to Italy this summer to visit the jewel box villages of the Cinque Terre  five heart-stoppingly picturesque hamlets on the Ligurian coast, dotted with pastel houses nestled amid terraced hills that drop to the jade and lapis waters of the Mediterranean. All I had with me were my eyes and feet. For the next few days, that would be all I needed. Unencumbered, I could leap lightly onto trains and trails, feeling sorry for the heavily laden travelers around me, even as I mourned the absence of my hiking sandals. And I saw at once that the Cinque Terre (pronounced CHING-kway TAY-ray) should not be reserved as a bucket-list destination: they are best seen pre-bucket, while you are still limber enough to hop on and off platforms and boats, scamper up winding medieval staircases and clamber onto slick sunning rocks in secluded coves and on friendly beaches.

title: In the Cinque Terre, Sun, Sea and Sweeping Scenes
description: Views from Italys Ligurian coast.

title: Terror That Melts From the Screen
description: As sexy as the technology may be, digital 3-D hasnt exactly conquered the entertainment landscape. ESPNs decision this summer to end its three-year-old stereoscopic sports channel strongly suggests the format will never be adopted as an across-the-board industry standard. But the format (or gimmick, depending on your point of view) does seem to have established a niche for itself. 3-D is now a more or less obligatory adornment for computer-animated family films and the high-end action franchises, although  despite rare exceptions like Ang Lees Life of Pi and Alfonso Cuarns Gravity  the process hasnt found a foothold in straight dramatic filmmaking. Depth, it seems, is appropriate only for shallow subjects.

title: Hapless and Hopeless
description: During the Bush years, I would often run into people mocking W for being stupid. I never thought he was  incurious, anti-intellectual, but not stupid. And the people around him certainly werent stupid  cynical, dishonest, but not stupid, especially regarding matters political.

title: During Shutdown, Many Agencies Are Offline
description: WASHINGTON  During the government shutdown, federal agencies are not just shutting their doors and sending their employees home. Some are choosing to shut down their Web sites as well.

title: Book Review Podcast: Lets Talk About Sex
description: In The New York Times Book Reviews Sex Issue, Francine Prose and Anna Holmes write about the most erotic books theyve ever read. Ms. Prose writes:

title: Armory Show to Highlight a Shanghai Artist
description: Each year the Armory Show, New Yorks largest art fair, commissions one artist to make his or her mark on the event, with tote bags and ephemera, an on-site installation and the production of an edition of prints to benefit the Museum of Modern Art. This year the fairs focus will be on China, and the organizers have chosen the Shanghai provocateur Xu Zhen (pronounced shoo jen), a 36-year-old conceptual artist and one of the most influential among the younger generation. Armory Focus: China will feature 20 galleries showing the works of young Chinese artists, organized by Philip Tinari, the director of the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art in Beijing.

title: The Virtues of Adding Hoc (Wonkish)
description: At an economics education event in Florida, so little posting today. But a quick note on some methodological thoughts.

title: Decades in Solitary Confinement, Then Death in Freedom
description: Herman Wallace, one of the so-called Angola 3 prisoners known for their decades of incarceration and solitary confinement in Louisiana, has died just a few days after being released from jail, his legal team said on Friday. He was 71. The cause was liver cancer, the team said.

title: FIFA Assigns Group to Study Winter Move for World Cup
description: ZURICH  Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, world soccers governing body, emerged Friday from two days of meetings to address serious questions about the 2022 World Cup with a concrete answer to one of them.

title: Twitters I.P.O. and the League Table Fight
description: Thanks to the social network Twitter, the league tables for initial public offerings for both banks and stock exchanges could shift significantly.

title: Whatll You Have, Mr. President?
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps it was the dearth of kitchen workers at the White House as the federal shutdown dragged on, but President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. strolled out, coatless, to a nearby sandwich shop on a sunny Friday  both for lunch and for another photo opportunity to press House Republicans to reopen the government.

title: Imported From France, a New Sitcom Set in Brooklyn
description: A 1998 action-comedy movie, Taxi, was set in a place with intriguing museums and galleries, appealing restaurants and a multicultural population  Marseille, on the southeastern coast of France.

title: Acoustic Version of Super Bon Bon
description: By Mike Doughty

title: Boehner: This Isnt Some Damned Game
description: With no new plan on the fourth day of the shutdown, House Speaker John A. Boehner made an angry plea to President Obama for a discussion on his health care law.

title: Acoustic Version of Circles
description: By Mike Doughty

title: Possible Clues in Fatal Chase, but No Motive
description: The woman who was shot to death after a taut, high-speed car chase through the streets between the White House and Capitol Hill was still in her car, snagged on the curb of a grass-covered median, when the police fired at her, a Senate official said on Friday.

title: After Killings, Tourists Are Told to Avoid Madagascar
description: JOHANNESBURG  Several Western countries issued travel warnings about the Indian Ocean island nation of Madagascar on Friday, citing mob attacks that killed two Europeans and a Madagascan accused of organ trafficking.

title: In Rural Iowa, Spending, Not the Shutdown, Raises Worry
description: The Republican Party has long claimed to be the champion of business, large and small, and an advocate for fiscal responsibility. Yet now Republicans in Congress have precipitated a shutdown of the federal government and are threatening to let the nation default on its once Triple-A-rated debt.

title: As Defense, a Handwritten Lesson on Senate Procedure
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Boozman, Republican of Arkansas, took the unusual step of publicly releasing a handwritten letter to constituents explaining his choice on a procedural vote on stopgap spending legislation last week. Mr. Boozman, first elected in 2010, was one of 25 Republican senators who joined all of the Senates Democrats in voting to cut off debate on the measure. After that cloture vote, the Senate removed language in the spending bill that would have defunded the new health care law on a party-line vote. Mr. Boozman voted against removing the House-passed defunding provision, and against final passage of the spending bill itself.

title: Pursuing a New Path Down the Aisle
description: Last Monday, Kathryn Ho received a text from her sister: Have you called the hotel to see what happens if the government shuts down?

title: Shhh. Silence Being Observed.
description: Theres been a lot of noise about silence lately. Last month, art and music lovers poured into an Upper East Side church to hear the first New York performance of Yves Kleins Monotone-Silence Symphony, a composition conceived around 1947, featuring a D chord followed by 20 minutes of silence. Around that time John Cage composed 433, first performed in August 1952, when the pianist David Tudor sat at a piano on a stage in Woodstock, N.Y., stopwatch in hand, without playing a single note. For 4 minutes 33 seconds, nothing but ambient sound could be heard.

title: How to Find Sugar Man
description: Maybe you are a person who is looking to feel good. Nothing wrong with that, inherently. Its not an aesthetic, per se, but it is a worldview. A person like that would find himself in good company at Barclays Center onWednesdayto see Rodriguez, owner of a feel-good story if eer there were one.

title: Still Duke, With Cracks
description: There was a time in the postwar era when John Wayne wasnt merely a brawny block of granite, when his men of action were pocked with character flaws. (James Stewart found his own dark shadows in the same period.) John Ford questioned Waynes imperious nobility with The Searchers (1956), but Howard Hawks got there first, with Red River (1948), playing at the Museum of the Moving Image on Friday as part of its Complete Howard Hawks series.

title: Video: A New Life, Furloughed
description: Katherine Buckingham, a furloughed FEMA employee, is counting the days of the federal government shutdown until she can get back to work.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Return of The Nose
description: Happily, the Metropolitan Opera has brought back its brilliant production The Nose, by Shostakovich, a hit of the 2010 season. Based on Gogols absurdist story, the production is by the South African artist William Kentridge, who incorporates his trademark films into his staging. The baritone Paulo Szot, who made a noteworthy house debut as the hapless, noseless bureaucrat Kovalyov, returns. Valery Gergiev conducts the sardonic score. (8 p.m. Tuesday and 1 p.m. Saturday, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, 212-362-6000, metoperafamily.org.)

title: Two People and the Darkness
description: Certainly October dance in New York features the heavyweights  American Ballet Theater, the Forsythe Company and San Francisco Ballet among them  but theres a potentially more elegant offering in the mix. The dazzling improvisation artists Lisa Nelson and Steve Paxton, who met in 1972 at Bennington College, reunite to present Night Stand, which opens at Dia:Chelsea on Thursday.

title: The U.S. Has Defaulted Before
description: When it comes to debt delinquency, Americans have short memories. But then so do many other countries.

title: Twitters R.&D. Spending Hits the Spot
description: Twitters research and development spending may be sky-high, but it hits the right spot. At 44 percent of revenue in the first half of the year, the microblogging site is spending far more as a proportion of its top line than Facebook. But with a lower number of users than its rival, Twitter needs to grow to make new investors happy.

title: Back to School, With New Teachers
description: Can the right teacher make the difference between failure and success? Imagine learning about civil rights from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, economics from the financial expert Suze Orman and music from the producer Swizz Beatz. Dream School, a series beginning Monday night at 10 on the Sundance Channel, offers 15 Los Angeles dropouts  17- and 18-year-olds whose educational trajectories were sidelined by pregnancy, bullying and neglect  a chance to start over by gleaning information, and not a little inspiration, from superstars.

title: Letterman to Stay at CBS Through 2015
description: CBS announced on Friday that it had extended the contract of David Letterman to continue as the networks late-night star through 2015.

title: Big Ticket | Gravity-Defying Vistas for $15 Million
description: A floor-through combination unit at the Trump Palace with six terraces and gravity-defying vistas of the cityscape and Central Park sold for $15 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The four-bedroom, three-bath residence, No. 47A/B, had an initial asking price of $16.95 million and has monthly carrying charges of $14,425.

title: T FALL TRAVEL
description: Over the past half century, an odd mix of swamis, monks, Zen masters and utopians have secured thousands of acres of prime California real estate to make sanctuaries for those seeking to escape the world. Welcome to Gods country.

title: Sense and Superstition
description: SUPERSTITIOUS people do all sorts of puzzling things. But its not just the superstitious who knock on wood. From time to time, we all rap our knuckles on a nearby table if we happen to let fate-tempting words slip out. The cancer is in remission, knock on wood, we might say.

title: Exclusive | 101 Central Park West
description: A gracious four-bedroom prewar duplex, owed by one family for 21 years, is about to enter the market at $12.25 million.

title: On the Upper West Side: Haute Yet Homey
description: A gracefully renovated Upper West Side duplex that retains its homey prewar charms  original beamed ceilings and crown moldings  while providing an elegant palette for entertaining, thanks to an exacting makeover by the architect Annabelle Selldorf and the interior designer Victoria Hagan, is poised to enter the market for the first time in more than two decades.

title: A Woman Whose Passion Made Her Dangerous
description: Lovers of Victorian literature who treasure George Eliot and her writing will find the novelist depicted with dignity and ample biographical detail in Cathy Tempelsmans A Most Dangerous Woman.

title: Beets, Raw and Cooked
description: This is one of those salads where the grain enhances texture and adds a nutritional punch, but isnt what the salad is about. Its about beets and spinach. I usually slice beets for salads, or cut them into wedges. But here I cut them into very small dice, so the quinoa/beets/walnuts/blue cheese mixture comes together in particularly appealing bites.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Green Heart Solved
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 76-year-old man with many medical problems who was found to have a green-colored heart during a routine bypass surgery. We asked our readers to look at all the patients recent medical problems in order to figure out why his heart was turning this odd color. In addition, we asked that you tell us how the surgeon proved the diagnosis. The correct diagnosis is

title: Across a Crowded Room
description: It took nothing less than an oil spill of monumental proportions to bring Philippe Cousteau Jr., an explorer and environmental activist, into contact with Ashlan Gorse, then a correspondent for the cable television show E! News.

title: Government Shutdown Changes  a T. Rexs Travel Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Even being 68 million years old isnt enough seniority to be spared from government furlough.

title: Sleepy Hollow on Fox Is First New Show to Be Renewed
description: Foxs Sleepy Hollow has become the first of this falls batch of new network television shows to be renewed for a second season.

title: To Stop the Craziness in Washington, Fund the Census
description: No one knows how the latest shutdown plus debt ceiling farce will end. But there is a way to try to stop the craziness from happening over and over again: Fund the census.

title: Pastas for Fall
description: This week, Martha Rose Shulman takes the last of her summer vegetables to make fast and delicious pasta for a healthful fall meal. She writes:

title: Screen Gems and Stars Aplenty
description: If the Academy Awards were a horse race, the Hamptons International Film Festival, taking place for the 21st time from Oct. 10 to 14, would be quite the handicapper.

title: National Parks Closed, Indian Lands Open
description: MOENKOPI, Ariz.  Keith Riddle and Merilyn Lassman had planned to celebrate their retirement with a visit to the Grand Canyon  a lifelong dream of ours, she said. But because of the government shutdown, and the closing of the entire national park system, they found themselves instead in this village on the Hopi Indian reservation, learning about a people they had known almost nothing about.

title: Toyotas Everycar, Straining to Get Noticed
description: The 2014 Corolla has emerged longer, lower, wider and just a little bit wilder. But it still risks getting lost in the crowded compact-sedan class.

title: Seven Days of Style | Saint Laurent Snubs Colette, Barneys Does Blowouts and Marc Jacobs Says Goodbye
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLESept. 28  Oct. 4

title: NASA to Proceed With Mars Mission
description: NASAs next Mars mission is getting to the launching pad, government shutdown or not.

title: Lockheed Martin Furloughs 3,000 Workers
description: Lockheed Martin, the nations largest military company, said it would furlough 3,000 workers on Monday, and it expected that number to increase.

title: Dealing a Blow to Berlusconi, an Italian Senate Panel Recommends His Expulsion
description: ROME  A special panel of the Italian Senate on Friday voted to strip Silvio Berlusconi of his current seat, a humiliating blow for a man who has dominated Italy for the past two decades but whose political career is now very much in jeopardy.

title: Riots in Kenya After Killing of Muslim Cleric
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Deadly riots broke out in the coastal city of Mombasa on Friday morning after a popular but controversial Muslim cleric was fatally shot in what his followers said they believed was an attack by the security services.

title: Dancing on the Edge of Default
description: Mr. Reinhart, former head of the Federal Reserves monetary division, is the managing director and chief United States economist for Morgan Stanley.

title: T-Rex Misses a Washington Premiere
description: WASHINGTON  One of historys greatest predators has fallen victim to Congressional gridlock.

title: Clinton Says Shell Probably Weigh 2016 Bid Sometime Next Year
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin to seriously consider a run for president sometime next year, she told a group of Long Island business people on Friday.

title: Ireland Votes on Shutting Its Senate
description: DUBLIN  Irelands voters had a chance on Friday to accomplish what some American voters, with their government partly shut down, can only dream of: abolishing one house of the nations legislature. And the Irish were expected to vote to do so.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Italy, Bahrain, Kenya and France.

title: Desperation Fuels Trips of Migrants to Spain
description: TARIFA, Spain  The southern tip of Spain is barely nine miles from the coast of Morocco, a distance so tantalizingly close that African migrants trying to reach Europe can see the Continent from the Moroccan shoreline.

title: Police Officer in Brazil Jokes on Facebook About Breaking Truncheon Over Protester
description: A police officer in Rio de Janeiro faces disciplinary measures after posting a self-portrait on Facebook in which he held a broken baton and suggested that he had snapped it on the body of a striking teacher during a crackdown on protesters this week.

title: What to Do When Asked to Accent Beethoven
description: Orchestra programs that pair a new work with a Beethoven symphony have become increasingly common. For the New York Philharmonics concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, the conductor Alan Gilbert took that idea to another level.

title: Richardss New Start as Rangers Left Wing Begins Well
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Brad Richards was annoyed at the question, which he has been asked repeatedly for the past few weeks.

title: A Stew in Touch With Its Wild Side
description: Suppose you are craving wild mushrooms. In a perfect world, if you actually did trek into a forest, and knew where to go and knew what to look for, you might happen upon an enclave of golden chanterelles just waiting to be picked. The yellow beauties would jump into your basket at the touch of a pocketknife blade.

title: Review: 2014 Toyota Corolla LE Premium
description: Known for reliability, not passion, the 2013 Toyota Corolla was past its prime. Tom Voelk and his neighbor Dick check out the 11th-generation 2014 model to find out if its back in fighting form.

title: In a Quick Parole, Some See an Unwelcome Message
description: Almost everything about this case makes me sad  and angry, wrote Nora OBrien-Suric, a senior program officer for The John A. Hartford Foundation, in a recent blog post entitled A Sordid Criminal Case Raises Important Geriatric Issues.

title: Faithful Companion, Hiding in Plain Sight
description: SAN DIEGO  If the previous 2013 Toyota Corolla were an actor, it would be the faithful sidekick: the average Joe who always comes through, no matter what scrapes his buddy  the flashy, daring, irresponsible star  gets them into.

title: Detroit Institute of Arts Mulls Transfer to State
description: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose collection has become a target of creditors in Detroits federal bankruptcy case, is formulating a proposal to protect the museum that might include asking Michigans governor, Rick Snyder, to consider state take-over of the city-owned museum, the Detroit Free Press reported.Many of the masterpieces in the museums collection are being appraised by Christies auction house at the behest of Kevyn Orr, Detroits emergency manager, who has said that he has no intention of selling the art but that none of the citys assets can be taken off the table as the bankruptcy case proceeds.The new proposal would ask the state to begin providing substantial funding to the museum that would allow the museum to provide money to the city that might otherwise be found only by selling art. At a business luncheon on Thursday in Detroit, Mr. Orr said that the museum might consider long-term leases of art works as another way of avoiding any sale. Im deferring to them to save themselves, he told business leaders, referring to the institute.

title: Spotlight on Godard
description: Images from select films in the Film Society of Lincoln Centers Jean-Luc Godard retrospective.

title: The First Time
description: For its Sex Issue, The New York Times Book Review spoke to several authors, including Sam Lipsyte and Alison Bechdel, about their first illicit reading experience. More than 200 readers then shared memories of their first times with us online. So I asked a few people at The Times if they would like to join the growing chorus, and heres what they said:

title: A Closer Look at Harvards Choice on Fossil Fuels
description: Updated, Oct. 15, 9:29 p.m. | The student effort to get universities and colleges to sell off their investments in companies hawking fossil fuels continues, as can be seen in the Twitter item and photo above from Bard College.

title: One More Time, Clawing Their Way to a Verdict
description: Here are two ways to tell that Twelve Angry Men is set in the 1950s: First, someone produces a pack of cigarettes in a jury room, and no one says it is against the law to light up. Later, in a discussion about going to the movies, a second feature is mentioned, as though the audience always got to watch two films for the price of one.

title: Pirates Rebound by Stifling the Cardinals Powerful Lineup
description: ST. LOUIS  Pittsburgh led St. Louis by 5-1 in the bottom of the sixth inning Friday, but Game 2 of their National League division series was far from decided. The Pirates starter, Gerrit Cole, had given up a flyout to the wall to start the inning, then walked Matt Carpenter. Fans at Busch Stadium  a red-clad capacity crowd announced at 45,999  stood, roared and waved white towels as the perennial postseason star Carlos Beltran strode to the plate.

title: De Blasio Speech Excerpt
description: Bill de Blasio spoke to a standing-room-only crowd on Friday, laying out his vision for making New York City more equitable. The following is a clip from that speech.

title: Economic Confidence Plummets
description: Economic confidence has taken a nosedive in the last few days, reaching its lowest three-day rolling average since December 2011.

title: Metro-North to Resume Full Service on Monday
description: The Metro-North Railroad is expected to return its New Haven line to full service by Monday, transit officials said, nearly two weeks after a power loss in Mount Vernon, N.Y., upended commutes for tens of thousands of travelers across the Northeast.

title: An Inaugural Solo Effort, and Plenty of Teamwork
description: William Winant

title: Yankees Make a Contract Offer to Girardi
description: With other teams peering in from the outside, the Yankees made a contract offer to Manager Joe Girardi on Friday, and expect to find out within a few days whether a deal is likely to be reached.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: After Hoping to Avoid It, Harvey Will Have Surgery
description: The Mets had promised: 2014 would be their year. They had the pitching. They had David Wright. They had Matt Harvey. They said they would spend money. It would all come together next year, they hoped, and they would be contenders again, at last.

title: Gathered Acts of an Auteur Provocateur
description: Plus a change, plus cest la mme chose. No filmmaker was more identified with the New York Film Festivals first decade than Jean-Luc Godard; now entering its second half-century with a new programming director, Kent Jones, the festival is poised to begin New Yorks first comprehensive retrospective devoted to ... Jean-Luc Godard.

title: Elbowing Aside Vampires and Zombies
description: BURNABY, British Columbia  Evidence of witchcraft was all over the house  actually a soundstage in suburban Vancouver. A wine glass full of feathers. Apothecary bottles filled with dried roots and herbs. The bodies of beetles and scorpions, neatly mounted under glass. A wooden light fixture whose frame, when viewed from a certain angle, suggested a pentagram.

title: Once More Into the Breeches
description: Is there a classic play more macho than Shakespeares Julius Caesar? A tragedy of mens frustrations, desires and actions, it offers just two small speaking roles for women. The word men occurs 54 times in the script, more than in any other Shakespeare play.

title: Squatters Paradise Lost
description: Ash Thayer photographed life in several buildings in the East Village area that were occupied by squatters in the 1990s.

title: A Soprano Braving the Shoals, Like a Stoical Isolde
description: The soprano Deborah Voigt is still wondering whether, during a crisis in confidence, she made the right decision last month to withdraw from the season-opening production of Wagners Tristan und Isolde at the Washington National Opera. She had sung Isolde to acclaim in important productions over the previous 10 years. But last month, she found the long, punishing role beyond her current vocal capacities.

title: Big Executive Moves Within Hispanic Media
description: The Hispanic media world was active on Friday with the announcement of executive changes at Telemundo, owned by NBCUniversal, and Fusion, the new English-language joint venture between the Disney-ABC Television Network and Univision Communications aimed at millennials.

title: Cuba in America, Unbound
description: The pianist Michele Rosewomans long-running project New Yor-Uba, which she revived for a new album and two nights of performances at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola, still looks good on paper and sounds better in practice.

title: Long, Strange Trip Ends for a Symbol of the 60s
description: For many Americans, they prompt images of hippies and surfers, or perhaps memories of wholesome camping holidays. Europeans may associate them more with the police or parcel delivery. As for their name, take your pick: Type 2, T2, Kombi, Transporter, Bulli, Micro Bus, Samba Minibus, Vanagon, Caravelle, Clipper L.

title: Adopted by Neighbors, a VW Camper Spreads Happiness
description: Sitting in the living room of her familys 19th-century colonial home, Lesley Fowks recalled the day in 2002 that her son, Ian Brady, burst in with an announcement: the rusting 1977 Volkswagen camper van sitting in the side yard of a nearby house could be his for free.

title: Expanding Family
description: With a little persistence, some elbow grease and a moms support, a young mans dream car  in this case a VW camper van  was brought back to life.

title: Bill Cunningham | Le Grand Orange
description: It's often asked why Paris is the center of creative fashion. Bill Cunningham weighs in.

title: Wash Me? Some Cars Want to Be Left Alone
description: PIERCE, NEB.  So your winning bid at the Lambrecht auction here last weekend put a treasure on your trailer, and youve brought it home. Now what?

title: In Nebraska, Rusty Chevys Turn to Gold
description: PIERCE, NEB.  It was early in the bidding, and the auctioneer was still warming her pitch  and trying to fire up the crowd of thousands around her mobile stage, a flatbed trailer in a soybean field in the middle of the country.

title: When Parisians Stormed Out, and the Earth Trembled
description: By this point in the centennial year of The Rite of Spring, youve probably heard the story about the riot.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Moving From a Stabilized Apartment

title: A Lantern to Show the Way
description: When the owners of the creative agency Fuzzco moved offices, they didnt want to let their old work space go to waste. So they transformed it into the Pretend Store, a pop-up shop at 85 Spring Street in Charleston, S.C., that will feature goods from a different design firm every month for the next three months. Each edition will also introduce a special collaborative product designed by Fuzzco and its guests.

title: Week in Pictures for Oct. 4
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include stabbings on the Upper West Side, a monument at Grand Army Plaza, and the effects of the government shutdown on city beaches.

title: Annotations on a Speech
description: Bill de Blasio on Friday delivered his most detailed blueprint yet for how he hopes to make New York a more equitable and inclusive city. Read the entire text of his speech here, as delivered, with annotations for context and clarity.

title: No News Is Good News
description: Five days a week, Pat Kiernan, the morning news anchor for NY1, is awake before dawn, rushing from his brownstone in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to his stations studios in Chelsea, where his broadcasts help the rest of us get ready for our day. Its no surprise, then, that on the weekends, Mr. Kiernan, 45, likes to relax close to home with his wife, Dawn, a client-service representative for Nielsen, the television research firm, and with their daughters, Lucy, 11, and Maeve, 9. On Sundays especially, I get to live on a more or less human schedule, he said. But the reprieve is short-lived, and work invariably returns early Monday.

title: Audrey Gelman, the Girl Most Likely
description: If you had to pick a low point for Scott Stringer in his recent David-versus-Goliath race against Eliot Spitzer for New York City comptroller, it would have been in early August. Mr. Spitzer, the scandal-plagued ex-governor, had a 15-point lead in the polls, coming off appearances on Jay Leno and Bill Maher.

title: The Wages of Pop Music
description: A J Michalka, the star of Grace Unplugged, used to record with her sister in the teen-pop duo Aly and A J. (They now perform as 78Violet.) The songs were sturdy, melodic and espoused wholesome self-reliance. Aly went on to embody female independence in the charming film Bandslam and the TV series Hellcats. A J, alas, has succumbed to Grace Unplugged, which feels like a religious tract more than a movie.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom colonial in Glen Cove and another in Rye with five bedrooms.

title: Loud, Brash, Raunchy: And Not Just the Clothes
description: Supermodels, drugs, clothes that emphasize a womans curves, a murder at the hands of a spree killer, a family riven by a spiteful will: the details of the Versace fashion empire have the makings of a fantastic HBO mini-series.

title: The Lure of the Savage, Deconstructed and Reassembled
description: Before we see a body, we are greeted with words. In rite riot, a new work by Nora Chipaumire performed Thursday at Le Skyroom at the French Institute-Alliance Franaise, Ms. Chipaumire is referred to as an exotic installation in the sarcastic text, which scrolls across a piece of fabric hanging from a wall and stretching across the floor. She is notoriously dangerous, savage and bares her teeth and other body parts while in performance.

title: Friday Night Music: More Lucius
description: Short on time, so something cheerful as I rush to the airport:

title: Aging, Coming of Age, and Vampires
description: With 13 main-slate features to go between now and next Sunday, the last week of the New York Film Festival reinforces the impression that this is an exceptionally wide-ranging, even sprawling event. You could say that the festival, in its 51st edition, has one foot in the high end of the American commercial mainstream, and another in the realm of international art cinema.

title: Questions Often Asked About Health Law
description: Millions of consumers rushed to the online health care exchanges on Tuesday only to be greeted with long waits and frustrating error messages.

title: Why Fashion Films Are Usually Cartoons
description: During the 1990s, when access to fashion designers and their families was fairly easy, I learned one or two things about these glamorous creatures that Ive tried to keep in mind.

title: Mobsters, Urban Design and Murals
description: Arguably, he was the biggest mob informer since Joseph Valachi testified before Congress in 1963. And in Mob Boss: The Life of Little Al DArco, the Man Who Brought Down the Mafia (Thomas Dunne Books, $27.99), the veteran crime reporters Jerry Capeci and Tom Robbins spin a gripping, novelistic biography of the diminutive man behind the big mouth.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Gramercy Park area co-op, a Turtle Bay loft and a Kensington apartment.

title: Better Sharpen Your Talons, Country Girl
description: If soap opera could be sold by the yard, The Paradise would be a bolt of beaded polyester chiffon. Its not silk, but if youre looking for something a little sexy on a budget, itll do.

title: Morrissey Autobiography on Its Way, Again
description: Morrissey once sang: You say that the day just never arrives/And its never seemed so far away/Still I know its gonna happen someday. His fans could apply those lyrics to the publication of the singers autobiography, which is to be published in Britain by Penguin Classics on Oct. 17.

title: Transnational Teams in Bali
