description: The Transnational Teams world championship in Bali, Indonesia, last month was for teams that had not qualified for the knockout stage of the Bermuda Bowl, Venice Cup or dOrsi Senior Trophy, and for anyone willing to travel to that beautiful island in the South Pacific.

title: Editors Letter | The Journey
description: IN OUR SIGN OF THE TIMES ESSAY this month, our columnist Andrew OHagan takes on the notion that good is often really good enough, particularly when it comes to travel. In this age of bucket lists and extreme travel, in which we seek the extraordinary, the unique, the rare  longing to rocket into space or plummet beneath the sea  OHagan wonders if weve forgotten that the real value of travel is simply pleasure and inspiration. He makes the case that the Ultimate Experience now poses a threat to the kind of small revelations that make us happy. These we often find if we are looking where we might not expect.

title: Daughters Inheriting the Practice
description: The latest additions to the witch infestation sweeping through the fall television season are delightful company, a welcome relief from the rather humorless witches and possible witches who have already turned up in shows like The White Queen, Sleepy Hollow and The Originals.

title: The Nodding Ladies-Tresses Orchid, Ever Young
description: Every autumn there are one or two perfect days when winds from the north sweep summer south, combing the seasons thick clouds into mares-tails and sending its insects, birds and milkweed seeds packing. Recently, on a day like this, I stood in a scruffy Bronx field. Summers last pink flowers and goldenrods chrome yellow blooms were intertwined with the brick-red leaves and frosty blue berries of Virginia creeper. There was a biting chill in the air that heightened the earthy, sour scent of leaves decomposing.

title: Man on Fire Is Hospitalized in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  A week in which the capital was first shaken by a shutdown of the federal government and then rattled by a car chase and shooting on Capitol Hill ended Friday with scenes of a medical helicopter evacuating a man who the police believed set himself on fire on the National Mall.

title: Gulf Coast Storm Pulls Federal Workers Off Furlough
description: NEW ORLEANS  Arriving in the waning weeks of a quiet hurricane season, Tropical Storm Karen chugged its way toward the Gulf Coast on Friday, prompting the usual preparations and drawing federal response workers out of furloughs.

title: What Asthma Drugs Cost Us
description: Robin Levis two daughters both have drug-controlled asthma, thanks to top tier insurance. The students she tutors also have asthma but lack the same insurance and medical care.

title: Minnesota Nice Infuses the Night Life in Minneapolis
description: Another installment of Tribes of Saturday Night, a look at mating rituals around the country.

title: What Was Past, and What Was Modern: Post-World War I Works
description: Carnegie Halls 2013-14 season kicked off Thursday evening with the American Symphony Orchestra and a program from an alternate universe.

title: How Twitters I.P.O. Filing Evolved to Contain New Details
description: Laying the groundwork for its initial public offering, Twitter on Thursday filed a regulatory document that contains important details about its business.

title: The Dating Scene? Hip, With a Bit of Minnesota Nice
description: MINNEAPOLIS  As night-life emissaries go, one could do worse than Robert John Wayne, a 31-year-old artist here who happily told a recent visitor about everything from an indigenous delicacy called the Juicy Lucy (a burger with cheese baked into the patty) to what women want, something Mr. Wayne should know, seeing as how hes dating four of them.

title: Asthma: The Hayes
description: Hannah and Abby Hayes discuss activities they can enjoy because of the drugs they take to manage their asthma.

title: Asthma: The Pitres
description: Donza and Kemmoni Petri discuss their allergies, asthma and the drugs they take to keep their diseases in check.

title: T Fall Travel Issue
description: The concept of leisurely travel has been in flux in recent times. As Andrew OHagan points out in his essay, the concept of fine, or perhaps good enough, has been lost in an age of awesome superlatives and extreme travel. In T Magazines Fall Travel issue, we discover a more contemplative mode of getting there, and being there, whether the destination is a place or something less defined. Whether with Michael Kimmelman finding Marseille, France, despite a slew of ambitious development projects, as gloriously scrappy as ever, or with the surreal and severe beauty of Craig McDeans portraits from Icelands wilderness, a sense of really being present, a sense of place, is more important than a contrived sense of adventure. We also explore the Restoration Hardware tycoon Gary Friedmans desire to become a force of disruption in the contemporary art world, a resurgence in appreciation for almost-forgotten Indian Modernist furniture and a familys attempt to reinvigorate one of Britains most famous gardens by restoring its traditional agriculture. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Novels Pillorying Black Church Find Readers in Pews
description: DECATUR, Ga.  Kimberla Lawson Roby stood near the pulpit of a Baptist church in this Atlanta suburb one Saturday in late August, giving her testimony. She spoke of infidelities, mistresses, blackmail, out-of-wedlock children and extravagant spending. She did so as neither minister or worshiper, but rather as a novelist telling scores of rapt fans about her fictional characters.

title: Chinny-Chin-Chins? Maybe Its the Software
description: The answer: six.

title: From Classic to Spiky, Earthy to Ethereal
description: Concert Artists Guild, which manages and promotes rising classical performers, is well aware of the challenges its musicians face as they embark on their careers. Stable, dependable engagements may well be a thing of the past, and it is necessary to think beyond the same traditional halls.

title: New Music Bonds With Vintage Images
description: At a time when we are awash in a constant deluge of digital images shared by friends and strangers through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Flickr, it can be hard to recall when we were less instantly and intimately connected. In the 1970s, though, the world was still analog. Most photographs needed developing, usually by specialists. You posted an image by sticking it in an envelope, then into a mailbox. Sharing photos meant passing prints from hand to hand, or maybe gathering in a darkened den to dutifully watch while a relative or neighbor showed vacation slides.

title: The Benefits of Intransigence
description: IF the government shutdown has shown us anything, its that the 80 or so House Republicans driving the crisis have emerged as the most unified force in politics: tightly organized, highly disciplined and ideologically firm.

title: Twitter Bios and What They Really Say
description: Wife, mom, lawyer, women & kids advocate, FLOAR, FLOTUS, US Senator, SecState, author, reads Hillary Clintons Twitter bio, before veering off: dog owner, hair icon, pantsuit aficionado, glass ceiling cracker, TBD ... Written after she joined the microblogging service in June, those descriptors earned raves.

title: Man on Fire on National Mall
description: Witnesses called emergency operators as bystanders tried to extinguish the flames using their own clothing.

title: Louis Vuitton Revives Travel for the Genteel
description: PARIS  When you walk into LAventure, Louis Vuittons pop-up store next to the luxury brands Rue de Montaigne boutique, you are supposed to feel as if you have entered a stylish travel agency from the golden age of the grand tour, when Thomas Cook was king and wealthy travelers would think nothing of dragging along a dozen trunks on their journey.

title: So Paulo Parties on the Hudson
description: To celebrate Arthur Medeiross third birthday last year, there was a three-course brunch for a dozen guests at the Hotel Plaza Athnes private dining room, which was expertly decorated to look like a scene from the movie The Lion King, complete with elaborate mini-jungle centerpieces. This was followed by another party at Dylans Candy Bar, and then the climax: a trip to see The Lion King on Broadway.

title: Which Type of Therapy Works Best?
Index of Happiness? Bhutans New Leader Prefers More Concrete Goals
description: THIMPHU, Bhutan  I think I can take President Obama one on one in basketball, Bhutans newly elected prime minister said recently in an interview. Ive got some special moves.

title: Making Over Clergy Fashion
description: Stephen Fendler, president of CM Almy, shows off a rack of samples from his brand-new womens collection, pointing out a piece hes particularly proud of: a black blouse in a stretchy jersey knit.

title: Guns and Children: A Dangerous Combination
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Group Moves to Develop Global Airline Emission Rules
description: BRUSSELS  Transportation officials from around the world on Friday reached a preliminary agreement to develop global rules by the end of the decade that would control airline emissions. The action by the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations body, represents the first major move toward industrywide rules to limit carbon pollution.

title: Saudi Arabia: New Infections Raise Virus Cases to 136
description: Saudi Arabia has confirmed six new infections from the potentially fatal MERS virus, the World Health Organization reported Friday, raising the total number of cases worldwide to 136. Most of the cases, which have resulted in 58 deaths, have been in Saudi Arabia. The latest cases, the W.H.O. said in a statement, afflicted three men and three women, all from the Riyadh region. MERS stands for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. It is believed to be spread by bats and possibly camels. The concentration of MERS cases in Saudi Arabia has raised concern about the possible spread of the infection during the annual pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina later this month, when millions of Muslims from around the world visit the kingdom.

title: How the Shutdown Hurts the Naval Academy
Data on Quality of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Trial of a Psychic, Its Awkward for Her Clients
description: It is one thing, after having forked over tens of thousands of dollars to a psychic who warned that you had evil spirits blocking your happiness, to become suspicious and demand a refund. And, when that does not happen, to go to the police and swear out a complaint.

title: On the Baseball Beat
description: Thats Andrew McCutchen  he has a sock fetish, he collects them, said Haley Smilow, pointing out the center fielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates as he batted Tuesday night in the National League wild-card game against the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. A recent F.Y.I. item mentioned that Batman was created by Bob Kane and Bill Finger, who worked out the character during an hour spent in Poe Park in the Bronx. Ive heard of Bob Kane, but not Bill Finger. Can you tell me about him?

title: The Netherlands: Greenpeace Activists Gain an Ally
description: Foreign Minister Frans Timmermans said Friday that the Netherlands intended to press a case against Russia in the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea for seizing a Greenpeace International ship, the Arctic Sunrise, which was sailing under a Dutch flag. Russian prosecutors this week filed piracy charges against all 28 members of the crew and 2 freelance journalists. The Dutch government called the detentions unlawful. Greenpeace issued a statement praising the decision as an important symbol of support for its activists, who are being held in a jail in the Arctic Ocean port city of Murmansk.

title: Biker Was Playing Peacemaker When S.U.V. Hit Him, Lawyer Says
description: The man most seriously injured in an encounter between a swarm of motorcyclists and a family in an S.U.V. on the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan on Sunday was playing the role of a peacemaker, his lawyer said on Friday.

title: Where Cowboys Roam
description: This sounds like the premise for a sitcom or a reality TV show: A straight couple opens a gay bar.

title: 6 Die in Egypt as Islamist Opposition Tries to Re-energize Movement
description: CAIRO  At least six people were killed in political violence in Egypt on Friday in the buildup to a much-anticipated day of protests on Sunday calling for a rollback of the recent military takeover.

title: Tardy Deliveries Keep New Books Out of Teachers Hands
description: Because all of the books associated with their new English curriculum have not yet arrived, teachers at Public School 125 in West Harlem have been pulling last years texts from storage, dusting them off and handing them out, even though they are not considered rigorous enough for the revised standards.

title: Amid Questions, Town Welcomes a New College
description: WINGDALE, N.Y.  For 20 years, the 80 brick buildings of what was once the Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center have lain fallow, their weathered faces hidden by untamed vines, their windows buckling, their emerald lawns turning to weeds.

title: Harry Macklowe Gambles Again
description: Harry Macklowe wanted to go higher. Another story up? he offered with a smile.

title: For Coach, Seizures Are Mere Distractions
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Immediately after Jerry Kill has a seizure on the sideline, one longtime assistant takes over the headset and communicates with officials. The defensive coordinator handles the postgame news conference and splits the remaining news media obligations with the offensive coordinator. Should Kill miss practice, they revert to their schedule from a week earlier, with adjustments based on their next opponent.

title: Hagels Week in Asia, Complete With Talk of Drones and Fiscal Standoff
description: ABOARD A U.S. MILITARY JET  Within the same hour that the White House announced that President Obama was scuttling the remainder of his long-planned trip to Asia because of the government shutdown, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was ending a weeklong trip to South Korea and Japan, as part of the administrations continuing  and vexed  attempt to refocus defense, economic and diplomatic interests in the region.

title: Upstart Abu Dhabi Airline Becomes Ally to European Carriers
description: PARIS  Just a few years ago, James Hogan, the chief executive of Etihad Airways, probably would have had trouble scoring a meeting with one of his European counterparts. These days, however, it seems hes never been so popular.

title: Boehner Urges G.O.P. Unity in Epic Battle
description: WASHINGTON  With his troops anxious for a way forward, Speaker John A. Boehner began a closed-door meeting of House Republicans on Friday morning with a recitation of letters from local schoolchildren on how they deal with stress.

title: Video of Nairobi Gunmen
description: Kenyan officials have used footage from the Westgate mall to identify four suspects.

title: Cutting the Lean From Food Stamps
description: Many years ago a Korean man named Francis An arrived in New York via Argentina and observed that many communities in the city lacked the sort of grocery stores that could supply immigrants with the foods they were accustomed to in their native countries. He would eventually open a chain of supermarkets under the corporate name Bogopa, which in Korean means yearning for you, in low-income neighborhoods.

title: A Terrible, Tragic Game
description: Speaker John Boehner barked Friday about the government shutdown: This isnt some damn game.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Rise of Wantrepreneurs, and a Penny Stock Jumps Because of Twitter
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Fund-Raising for de Blasio Soars, Aided by Big Lead in Polls
description: Ever since winning his partys primary on Sept. 10, Bill de Blasio, the Democratic nominee for New York City mayor, has reduced his public appearances significantly, in part because he has been busy raising money for the general election.

title: A Week of Hearings Ends With More Cheers for Rodriguez
description: Alex Rodriguez concluded the first week of his drug-suspension appeal as if he were a minor conquering hero.

title: Officer Held in Fatal Accident
description: A New York City police officer who struck and killed a pedestrian on Staten Island while off duty on Friday morning has been charged with manslaughter and driving while intoxicated, officials said.

title: Curtain Is Rising on a Tech Premiere With (as Usual) a Mostly Male Cast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitters financial filing for its Wall Street debut was chock-full of juicy tidbits, from the name of its richest founder to a list of its escalating losses. But one revelation was particularly startling: Just a single woman among its top officials.

title: Lawrence Goodwyn, Historian of Populism, Dies at 85
description: Lawrence Goodwyn, whose experience building cross-racial political coalitions in the 1960s led him to write an authoritative history of the rise of American populism in the 19th century, died Sunday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 85.

title: Maximilian in Mexico
description: On Oct. 3, 1863, a Mexican delegation arrived in the Austrian port city of Trieste to officially offer Mexicos imperial crown to the 31-year-old Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian, a scion of the Austrian branch of the Hapsburg royal family and the brother of the Austrian emperor, Franz Josef I.

title: United States Has Lead in Tournament Slowed by Rain
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  After two days, it would appear the greatest obstacle in the United States teams march to another Presidents Cup title might be the weather.

title: Frankenstein Goes to Congress
description: Our question for today is: Why dont the Republicans just throw in the towel? Really, this is not going well for anybody.

title: Supervisors of Navy Yard Gunman Were Told of Issues
description: The mother of Aaron Alexis, the military contractor who killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard last month, told his bosses one month before the shootings that he had a history of paranoid episodes and most likely needed therapy. But Mr. Alexis managers at the Experts Inc., an information technology firm, decided to keep him on the job and did not require him to seek treatment, an internal company investigation has found.

title: Minnesota Nice Infuses the Night Life in Minneapolis
description: Another installment of Tribes of Saturday Night, a look at mating rituals around the country.

title: Chinas Economy, Back on Track
description: CHICAGO  NEXT month, President Xi Jinping and Prime Minister Li Keqiang will use an important meeting  the so-called Third Plenum of the Communist Partys 18th National Congress  to unveil Chinas priorities for reforming economic policy for the next decade.

title: Rookies Mistake Opens Door for Red Sox
description: BOSTON  After several innings had passed and the raw emotion and taunting chants had subsided, Dave Martinez felt it was time to find out what had happened. Five innings earlier, Wil Myers, a 22-year-old rookie outfielder for the Tampa Bay Rays, had ducked under a fly ball, allowing what should have been an easy out to drop in for a ground-rule double  the key moment in an embarrassing afternoon.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: An insider trading trial opens in Dallas, an electric car catches fire in Washington and hotel building booms in Austin, Tex.

title: University of Mississippi Investigating Anti-Gay Heckling at Theater Performance
description: OXFORD, Miss.  Every seat in the house was sold out for Fridays performance of The Laramie Project, a play staged by the University of Mississippi theater department about an anti-gay hate crime.

title: Herman Wallace, Freed After 41 Years in Solitary, Dies at 71
description: Herman Wallaces world for much of the last 41 years had been a solitary prison cell, 6 feet by 9 feet, when he left a Louisiana prison on Tuesday, freed by a federal judge who ruled that his original indictment in the killing of a prison guard had been unconstitutional.

title: What Can Be Sold in 140 Characters? Thats Now the Challenge for Twitter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Once Twitter enters life as a publicly traded company, it will have to satisfy Wall Streets demands for constant growth.

title: Redemption Songs
description: I recently played a show where I did something I hadnt done in years: I performed songs by the band I founded, sang for and became quasi-famous in  Soul Coughing,

title: Speed of Eagles Gives Giants Pause
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Spencer Paysinger has flashbacks of sprinting and sweating and sprinting some more, the motif of practice at the University of Oregon.

title: Migrants Cast Their Lot on a Troubled Sea
description: A rising number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are daring the waters of the Mediterranean to reach Europe.

title: Umenyiora Urges Falcons Not to Panic
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Breaking slowly out of the gate, while inadvisable for a team aspiring to reach the playoffs, is hardly fatal. Atlanta Falcons players who are inclined to abandon postseason hopes after a discouraging September can be disabused of the notion by listening to their newly welcomed defensive end.

title: Shutdown Din Obscures Health Exchange Flaws
description: The shutdown of many federal operations and activities this week has obscured widespread problems in the opening of insurance exchanges under President Obamas health care law, giving the administration time to work out the kinks, members of both parties say.

title: Corrections: October 5, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Now Republicans Want a Dialogue
description: Republicans are now simply flailing. Because they lack any plausible explanation for their irresponsible conduct in creating and prolonging the government shutdown, they are inventing new demands by the hour.

title: Raffling Off Assault Rifles
description: The Republican Party of Rhode Island is attracting well-deserved scorn for its plan to raise money  Sunday by raffling an AR-15-style assault rifle  the same sort of modified military weapon used last December in the Newtown school massacre in neighboring Connecticut.

title: Pent-Up Demand for Health Insurance
description: There were plenty of computer glitches when millions of Americans went online to check out their options for affordable insurance policies on the new health care exchanges that opened for business this week. It was frustrating, but it was also an indication of overwhelming interest that exceeded all predictions.

title: A Second Chance in California
description: The California Legislature passed a bill last month that bars government agencies from asking job applicants about criminal convictions until the agency has determined that the applicant meets minimum qualifications for the job. This measure will help remove unfair barriers to employment that keep millions of qualified workers trapped at the margins of society. Gov. Jerry Brown should sign this sensible bill.

title: A Fracking Rorschach Test
description: A few weeks ago, a group of scientists led by David T. Allen of the University of Texas published an important, peer-reviewed paper in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The subject was our old friend hydraulic fracturing  a k a fracking  that infamous process that allows companies to drill for natural gas trapped in shale formations deep below the earths surface.

title: Hip Injury Ends Season of Giants Guard
description: During 10 seasons in which he missed just seven games, guard Chris Snee, the physical and spiritual anchor of the Giants offensive line, was always the guy who played through any infirmity, including many he never acknowledged.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 4, 2013
The Frenzied Last-Act Effort to Save City Opera
description: In the frenzied final days of New York City Opera, when it was becoming clear that an urgent drive to raise $7 million for its very survival was failing, the general manager, George Steel, found himself scrounging for money wherever he might find it.

title: The Shifting Fortunes of the Peoples Opera
description: New York City Opera, the 70-year-old company that made opera affordable to the masses, championed new work and fostered the careers of major singers, announced this week that it will close.

title: Dodgers Fall as Mattingly Follows Convention
description: ATLANTA  Follow the conventional wisdom, the thinking goes, and a manager can always sleep easily. Even if his moves backfire, the unwritten rules must be there for a reason. They are rooted mostly in logic.

title: Word Search Technique
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Lets talk about memory loss. There come, at certain times of life, points at which you are required to hold so much information in your brain that the absorption of additional material requires your brain to jettison other bits of trivia, such as where I put my car keys. Sometimes you have to really rack your brain just to remember your own childrens names, not that that has ever happened to me.

title: Booster Proud of His Largess and Game-Day Parties
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn.  Roy Adamss two-story brick home is tucked neatly into a middle-class residential street. In the driveway, University of Tennessee and Southeastern Conference flags fly at full staff. On the front door, a poster urges his guests to adhere to a five-drink limit.

title: Game Day for a Booster
description: Roy Adams, the well-known booster, opens his Memphis home each weekend for parties that attract one hundred or more people to watch college football.

title: Bill Eppridge, Who Captured Powerful 60s Images, Dies at 75
description: Bill Eppridge, an award-winning photojournalist who made his most enduring mark with a historic image of a mortally wounded Senator Robert F. Kennedy lying on the floor of a Los Angeles hotel in June 1968, died on Thursday in Danbury, Conn. He was 75.

title: Help at Running Back? Not Much Yet
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The return of Mike Goodson from a four-week suspension would seem like found money for the Jets, providing additional depth and skill to the running game, which already has shown it can be one of the teams strengths.

title: Impasse With Afghanistan Raises Prospect of Total U.S. Withdrawal in 2014
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United States and Afghanistan have reached an impasse in their talks over the role that American forces will play here beyond next year, officials from both countries say, raising the distinct possibility of a total withdrawal  an outcome that the Pentagons top military commanders dismissed just months ago.

title: To This Tycoon, Iran Sanctions Were Like Gold
description: TEHRAN  He called himself the economic basij, a reference to Irans hard-line paramilitary organization and defender of the Islamic Revolution. He drove a black Mercedes 500 SL and wore a $30,000 watch, as befits a man who put his self-worth at $13.5 billion.

title: Health Exchange Enrollment Improves, but Is Still Short of Target
description: A state-by-state look at enrollment in the Affordable Care Acts health coverage.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9:05 P.M. (Showtime) THE MASTER (2012) Philip Seymour Hoffman portrays Lancaster Dodd, the leader of the Cause, a therapeutic, religion-tinged cult built around using painful questions to delve into a subjects past and get at the root of negative emotion and destructive behavior. Joaquin Phoenix (above left, with Mr. Hoffman) plays Freddie Quell, a World War II Navy veteran and alcoholic wreck who seeks solace through Dodds method. And Amy Adams is Peggy Dodd, the latest of her husbands wives and the hidden hand that guides his empire. The Master is really more Freddies story than Dodds, and some of the films drama resides in the struggle between the two characters  and perhaps the two actors  for supremacy, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, which earned its three principals Oscar nominations. Youll be my protg and my guinea pig, Dodd says to Freddie shortly after their first meeting. There turns out to be a lot more to it than that. They are father and son, guru and disciple, passionate friends and bitter competitors locked in a relationship whose sexual undercurrents are as palpable and mysterious as the motion of water under the surface of the ocean. The film, he added, is wild and enormous, its scale almost commensurate with Lancaster Dodds hubris and its soul nearly as restless as Freddie Quells. It is a movie about the lure and folly of greatness that comes as close as anything Ive seen recently to being a great movie.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 5, 2013
description: I knew the N.C.A.A. rules. I just didnt care for them.

title: Departing Director Conducts Locked-Out Minnesota Orchestra
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It may have been the worst-kept secret in the city, early this week, that Osmo Vanska, who resigned as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra on Tuesday, would conduct the players, who have been locked out for more than a year in a labor dispute, in their self-produced concerts this weekend. Mr. Vanskas last hurrah was finally announced on Thursday, and he led the first concert on Friday evening at the Ted Mann Concert Hall on the campus of the University of Minnesota: piano concertos by Beethoven (No. 3) and Mozart (No. 27), with Emanuel Ax as soloist; Beethovens heroic Egmont Overture; and Stravinskys stirring Firebird Suite.

title: Scherzer Pitches Tigers Past As in Opener
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Max Scherzer, an easygoing Missourian with a cruel arsenal of pitches, cut down the Oakland Athletics on Friday, leading the Detroit Tigers to a 3-2 victory in the opening game of their American League division series.

title: Kerry, at Asia Summit, Warns of Damage to U.S. Standing
description: HONG KONG  Secretary of State John Kerry, standing in for President Obama at an economic summit in Asia, warned on Saturday that the United States reputation was endangered because of the government shutdown, which sends the message that we cant get our own act together.

title: House Approves Back Pay for Furloughed Workers
description: WASHINGTON  The House, in a rare Saturday session, voted unanimously to guarantee that federal workers will receive back pay once the government shutdown ends, offering a promise of relief if not an actual rescue to more than 1 million government employees either furloughed or working without pay.

title: From Iranian Ayatollah, Support for U.S. Outreach, but Also Criticism
description: TEHRAN  Irans supreme leader expressed support on Saturday for the recent diplomatic outreach to the West by President Hassan Rouhani and his aides, but criticized some actions by the president as inappropriate.

title: A Note to Readers
description: An After Deadline post was inadvertently published here. Next weeks post will appear as usual on Tuesday.

title: An App That Saved 10,000 Lives
description: While most start-ups feverishly track figures like the total number of users, Ron Gutman, the founder and chief executive of the health information start-up, HealthTap, is more interested in a different data point.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Oct. 4, 2013
description: Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar from Time magazine join Charlie Herman on WNYCs Money Talking to discuss why the stock market is holding steady despite the government shutdown. And Twitter finally opens the curtains to reveal just how much money its making (hint: its not making a profit) and how many people are using it. And in the fight for Sothebys, does hedge fund manager Dan Loeb have better artistic taste?

title: Still IS-LMing After All These Years (Wonkish)
description: Presentation from EconEd conference yesterday, here (pdf).

title: Governing the Worlds Greatest Nation
description: From the Times, on John Boehners position:

title: Richardson Takes Trade as Fuel for Improvement
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Members of Clevelands overhauled front office were not the only ones disappointed in Trent Richardson, the running back the Browns chose third over allin last years draft, when they dealt him to Indianapolis for what figures to be a late first-round selection in 2014.

title: You Cant Have One Without the Other
description: Why did you never fall in love, Sandra? the gentleman caller asks as he takes her in his arms.

title: Rodriguez, Citing Missed Opportunities, Rejected the Players Union
description: First, it was Alex Rodriguez against Major League Baseball. Next, it was Rodriguez versus the Yankees, his own team. Then Rodriguez found himself at odds with the players union that is supposed to be representing him.

title: Week 5 Matchup: Eagles (1-3) at Giants (0-4)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: In October, Showcasing a Thriving Sport Thats Not Football
description: ATLANTA  In a happy little coincidence for a team that deserves one, the Pittsburgh Pirates have this Sunday all to themselves. The Steelers, their N.F.L. neighbors on the citys North Shore, are off this weekend. A fall Sunday in Pittsburgh, with only baseball on the schedule? Imagine that.

title: Deciding Who Sees Students Data
description: WHEN Cynthia Stevenson, the superintendent of Jefferson County, Colo., public schools, heard about a data repository called inBloom, she thought it sounded like a technological fix for one of her bigger headaches. Over the years, the Jeffco school system, as it is known, which lies west of Denver, had invested in a couple of dozen student data systems, many of which were incompatible.

title: For the Nets Lone Rookie, Time for Relaxation Remains a Distant Luxury
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Mason Plumlee had curved his body and long limbs into a folding chair and was saying how cool it was having star teammates, when his eyelids began to droop and flutter.

title: Variety: An Entire Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I used to read the dictionary, although I never got all the way through. I did not, however, give up during the As (see Emily Coxs and Henry Rathvons funny note below), but I did skip around to read up on whatever caught my young fancy.

title: Twitters Main Characters, Not Counting the Usual 140
description: Twitter has gone from whimsical side project to a multi-billion dollar company, and a handful of people have been at the heart of the companys rise.

title: The Mets Promise of Cash Isnt a Promise to Spend
description: Sandy Aldersons comments last Monday about the Mets off-season spending could not have comforted fans whose patience and desire to buy tickets are understandably frayed after five consecutive years of losing.

title: From Charlie O. to O.co Coliseum, the As Have History
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Twenty-three framed Sports Illustrated covers line the left wall of the entrance to the cramped Oakland Athletics clubhouse at O.co Coliseum. Familiar names (Reggie Jackson to Rickey Henderson) and titles (Bash Brothers to Moneyball) belie the blandness of the concrete bowl sitting alongside Interstate 880.

title: Some in G.O.P. Try to Pick and Choose Amid Spending Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, a hard-core leader of House conservatives who helped force a government shutdown in a fight over the scope of federal health care spending, sent out a statement on Wednesday bragging that the House had voted to fully fund the National Institutes of Health.

title: Court Defers Imprisonment for Journalist Covering Sinai
description: CAIRO  A military court on Saturday convicted an Egyptian journalist of entering a military zone without authorization and sentenced him to six months in prison, but deferred his sentence indefinitely, a mixed decision in a closely watched test of news media freedom under the new government.

title: Women Shaping a New Path Among a Rich Baseball Tradition
description: Since the Detroit Tigers ended the regular season last Sunday, Heather Nabozny has had time to accomplish tasks normally considered a luxury.

title: Letters to the Editor: A Poignant Tribute to Rivera
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Outsider Looks at Life in America
description: NEW YORK  Al Jazeera wants to make its name as American as pizzaburgers.

title: A Killing by Sudanese Security Forces Stokes the Anger of a Protest Movement
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  The killing of a young pharmacist by Sudanese security forces during an antigovernment demonstration here has become a rallying cry for the protest movement that has rocked Sudan for the last two weeks, threatening the governments grip on power.

title: Urging Patience, Obama Says Problems With Health Care Sites Reflect Demand
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged Americans who have flocked to the new government-run Web marketplaces for health insurance policies not to give up because of the technical problems attributed to greater-than-anticipated demand. Fixes are under way, he said.

title: U.S. Raids in Libya and Somalia Strike Terror Targets
description: CAIRO  American commandos carried out raids on Saturday in two far-flung African countries in a powerful flex of military muscle aimed at capturing fugitive terrorist suspects. American troops assisted by F.B.I. and C.I.A. agents seized a suspected leader of Al Qaeda on the streets of Tripoli, Libya, while Navy SEALs raided the seaside villa of a militant leader in a predawn firefight on the coast of Somalia.

title: Assad Says He May Seek Re-election
description: ISTANBUL  President Bashar al-Assad says that he would run for another term if his people wished him to do so, but that he needs a few more months to decide, given the rapidly changing situation in his country.

title: At the S.E.C., a Question of Home-Court Edge
description: SINCE Mary Jo White settled in as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, lots of tough talk has emanated from the agency about enforcement priorities. Just last week, Andrew Ceresney, co-director of enforcement, told an audience in New York to expect bolder actions out of the agency, especially when it comes to penalizing individuals.

title: Thousands Rally Nationwide in Support of an Immigration Overhaul
description: Thousands of supporters of an immigration overhaul held rallies on Saturday at more than 150 sites in 40 states, trying to pressure Congress, despite the partisan turmoil in Washington, to focus on passing a pathway to citizenship for millions of immigrants here illegally.

title: Mugged by a Mug Shot Online
description: IN March last year, a college freshman named Maxwell Birnbaum was riding in a van filled with friends from Austin, Tex., to a spring-break rental house in Gulf Shores, Ala. As they neared their destination, the police pulled the van over, citing a faulty taillight. When an officer asked if he could search the vehicle, the driver  a fraternity brother of Mr. Birnbaums who quickly regretted his decision  said yes.

title: The Bernanke Market: Mixed Grades
description: HOW good a job has Ben S. Bernanke done as Fed chairman?

title: Financial Literacy, Beyond the Classroom
description: EVEN if we grade on a very generous curve, many Americans flunk when it comes to financial literacy. Consider this three-item quiz:

title: Using Anonymous Data to Pinpoint a User
description: By analyzing patterns in anonymous browsing data over time, Internet advertising firms like Drawbridge can determine whether multiple computing devices belong to the same person.

title: Fund That Looked Beyond Labels and Found Winners
description: WASHINGTON may have been paralyzed by partisanship, and European economies hampered by the hangover from a nasty recession. But the developed worlds stock markets hummed along in the third quarter, allowing the managers of three of the top-performing mutual funds to find winning investments in enterprises as varied as forklift makers and food retailers.

title: European Stocks Finally Showing Signs of Recovery
description: JUST last fall, Europe was sinking into a double-dip recession and many global investors were questioning whether the European Union would even survive. Now signs of recovery have emerged, and European stocks have been ticking higher.

title: In Emerging Markets, a Time to Be Especially Choosy
description: AFTER two difficult years, emerging-market stock funds posted solid gains in the third quarter, raising hope that this once-highflying asset class may be ready to rebound.

title: A Budget Distress Call  Please Pay Us  Hidden in a Federal Weather Forecast
description: Someone at the National Weather Service clearly had the Washington budget showdown in mind in writingthis weather forecast, which includesa not-so-hidden message (here highlighted in a red box).

title: The Cash Cushion, Making a Comeback in Mutual Funds
description: JITTERY investors see danger in every market thrust upward.

title: Craving Those Good Old Dot-Com Days
description: KOZMO.COM is back!

title: New Books Put Finances Atop Your To-Do List
description: MAYBE its because so many people find the subject boring. Maybe its because the language is so weird, saying basis point when you mean one-hundredth of 1 percent and beta instead of volatility. Or maybe its simply that so many people hate math.

title: Mutual Funds
description: Highlights of mutual fund performance in the third quarter

title: Fund Investors, Caught in Washingtons Circus
description: POLITICS and policy dominated the markets in the third quarter, especially during an eventful, nerve-racking and surprising final few weeks that left the markets in a state of heightened uncertainty.

title: Rich People Just Care Less
description: Turning a blind eye. Giving someone the cold shoulder. Looking down on people. Seeing right through them.

title: Active E.T.F.s, Still Trying to Make Waves
description: ACTIVELY managed exchange-traded funds are supposed to combine the professional investment acumen available from mutual funds with the low costs, tax advantages and ease of trading of regular E.T.F.s.

title: Our Sickly Political System
description: IN our journalism and our conversations, we tend to talk about things in isolation, focusing on whats happening right now and failing to connect the dots. The present outrage becomes our complete obsession; the countless frustrations that telegraphed it fade from view. So it is with the shutdown of the federal government, which we could and should have seen coming. Which we did see coming, more or less.

title: An Audience Without an Opera
description: Last week, the New York City Opera announced that it was closing its doors and filing for bankruptcy, ending its 70-year existence orphaned, homeless, broke and all but out on the street. It was a disappointing demise to what was once an enterprising and insouciant company, a kind of scrappy newsboy thrust among the citys elite, thanks to Fiorello La Guardia, who founded it in 1943. Its end was as au courant as it could be  a failed Kickstarter campaign and a final performance of Anna Nicole, just the kind of production unlikely to turn up at the Metropolitan Opera, just the kind you might use to explain why this city needs two major opera companies.

title: Great Betrayals
description: AS a psychiatrist I find that friends frequently seek me out to discuss problematic events in their lives; it comes with the territory and Im usually happy to do it. But I was surprised and shaken to hear from an old friend that her husband of nearly 25 years had long been accruing and hiding from her a huge credit card debt (in the six figures). Even after divulging his secret, the husband had lied about the amount, with the sum increasing every time it was discussed. And right from the start, he refused to document where the money was spent. He left it for his wife to ruminate on, trying to puzzle it out. The disclosure wreaked financial and emotional havoc on their family.

title: A Wolf, a Sheep, or What?
description: FOR anyone who enjoys a good metaphor, Iranian President Hassan Rouhanis visit to the United Nations has been a field day for sheep and wolves. Rouhani has been dubbed both a wolf in sheeps clothing and a sheep in wolfs clothing and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel called Irans previous president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, a wolf in wolfs clothing.

title: Why the Bad Rap on Generic Drugs?
description: IN an episode of Orange Is the New Black, the Netflix series set inside a federal prison, a journalist rattles off a series of budget cuts that are making life difficult for the inmates. Closing the running track. Canceling G.E.D. classes. And switching to generic drugs.

title: Doctors Bad Habits
description: RECENTLY I was talking with a patient about her glucose levels, which have been inching their way toward diabetes. She was honest that she was eating too much junk and knew perfectly well that her diet was not doing her health any favors.

title: High Tea for Two Tourists
description: A tradition is a habit whose logic has faded. A silly thing you keep doing even when you cant remember why, like bringing a tree inside in December, or continuing to visit family.

title: Sunday Dialogue: A Disillusioned Citizenry
description: Readers discuss what has bred public distrust of government.

title: Howard Stern, My Literary Idol
description: WHEN asked to name the influences on my fiction and nonfiction, its become fairly customary, and perhaps a little pretentious, for me to cite the literary gods Franz Kafka, Samuel Beckett and George Orwell. And while its not untrue to say that these three legends, who broke such fertile ground in portraying the struggle of the alienated Everyman, made me want to be a writer, I would be remiss if I didnt acknowledge a fourth artistic influence, one who might not come so readily to mind when thinking of literary inspiration but who is equally important to me: the radio host Howard Stern.

title: Lets Build a New Bridge. No Cars Allowed.
description: O HARP and altar, marveled the poet Hart Crane about the Brooklyn Bridge. But if you dont love it as he did, dont worry. With bridges, as with everything else in New York City, you are spoiled for choice. More than 2,000 bind this metropolis.

title: Governing by Blackmail
description: SUPPOSE President Obama announced:

title: The Promise and Peril of Pope Francis
description: TO understand Pope Francis  his purpose, his program and its potential pitfalls  its useful to think about whats been happening to New York Citys Jews.

title: Dirk Kramers
description: Dirk Kramers was the chief engineer of the catamaran that won this years Americas Cup. That makes four boats he has helped design and build that have won the race.

title: Welcome to Ted Cruzs Thunderdome
description: A PLACE ONCE CALLED WASHINGTON

title: Dogs Are People, Too
description: FOR the past two years, my colleagues and I have been training dogs to go in an M.R.I. scanner  completely awake and unrestrained. Our goal has been to determine how dogs brains work and, even more important, what they think of us humans.

title: The Cost of the Shutdown, by the Numbers
description: A look at the budget standoffs effects on Americas economy, institutions and government workers.

title: Video: The Cost of the Shutdown by the Numbers
description: A look at the budget standoffs effects on Americas economy, institutions and government workers.

title: Making a Deal With Murderers
description: SAN SALVADOR  THE president of El Salvador has helped save more than 2,000 lives in the past two years. Now if only he would admit it.

title: The Supreme Court Returns
description: The Supreme Court begins a new term on Monday, even as the landmark rulings of last term continue to reverberate. The court has agreed to hear more than 50 cases so far on disputes both familiar and fresh: from affirmative action and freedom of speech, to campaign finance and the presidents power to make recess appointments.

title: A Good War, a Bad Father
description: World War II had been over for more than a decade when Dale Maharidge was born, but he still sees himself as damaged by that war, in particular by the Battle of Okinawa, in 1945. His father, Steve, a Marine sergeant, brought that battle home with him, to a suburb south of Cleveland. It lived on, taking the shape of desolate anger, forever on the edge of violence, of pain that he parceled out to his wife and children over the rest of his life.

title: Getting Older, Growing Poorer
description: The basic outlines of poverty in America are sadly familiar. At last count, 46.5 million people were poor  15 percent of the population. Women and children, especially in single-mother families, were, as always, hit hardest.

title: Electronic Devices on Planes
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is considering relaxing restrictions on the use of electronic devices on airplanes. Since there is a lot of confusion among passengers about why restrictions apply, clarification is a sensible move. As it is, many passengers accidentally or deliberately violate the rules they dont like or understand. According to one private survey, as many as 30 percent of passengers left their devices on when they were not supposed to.

title: Hagel Recalls Most Defense Department Workers
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made a surprise announcement on Saturday that he would recall next week almost all of the 400,000 civilian employees of the Defense Department who had been sent home when the government shut down.

title: Municipal Bonds, Stung Again
description: SELL IN MAY, the stock-market adage, would have served municipal bond investors well this year. Those who stayed in the market faced sharp losses.

title: Michael Gould of Bloomingdales, on Passion and Compassion
description: This interview with  Michael Gould, chief executive of Bloomingdales, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Shorting Out The Wiring
description: For the moment, at least, the shutdown and the general scene of insanity in Congress is clearly hurting the Republican brand. And theres a whole small industry of crunching numbers on the 1995-6 shutdown, etc., to estimate the likely impact on next years elections. For now the conventional wisdom is that the impact will be small, not nearly enough to restore Democratic control.

title: Bible College Helps Some at Louisiana Prison Find Peace
description: ANGOLA, La.  Like most of his fellow inmates, Daryl Walters, 45, can expect to spend the rest of his days in the infamous prison on a former slave plantation here. He was sentenced to life without parole for a murder more than 20 years ago in a state where a life sentence means just that.

title: Having Fun at AccuWeather, Rain or Shine
description: I REMEMBER being fascinated by snow at age 3. When I was 7, my grandmother gave me a diary, which I used to keep track of the days when it snowed. At around 9, Id get up early and listen to weather forecasts on all the radio stations I could, so that I could track storms.

title: A Bad Workers Mad Mom
The View From Toronto
description: MY first Toronto apartment was in a 32-story midcentury modern tower in the citys midtown, a cluster of high- and midrise buildings with single-family homes scattered among them. The neighborhood is atop a mild escarpment, giving these buildings a height advantage on the city spreading south toward Lake Ontario.

title: The View From Bangkok
description: MY wife and I live in a building with 24 floors in downtown Bangkok, a dwarf compared to most of the ones around us.

title: Snap. Hold. Kick. All in the Blink of an Eye.
description: Field goals occur so swiftly and so regularly that they are often treated as afterthoughts. But a highly intricate three-part choreography is involved. The Giants field-goal unit breaks it down.

title: The View From Dubai
description: OUTSIDE our door, high up in the Burj Khalifa, we board one of the towers 57 elevators and are catapulted even higher, to the 123rd floor, as if we were weightless objects being effortlessly lifted through the air. Our ears adjust several times as we speed along at almost 60 feet a second.

title: In Surprise Announcement, Hagel Recalls Most Defense Department Workers
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made a surprise announcement on Saturday that he would reinstate almost all of the 350,000 civilian employees of the Defense Department who had been sent home when the government shut down last week.

title: Athletic Art: 3 Acts and 3 Points
description: N.F.L. kickers last season attempted 1,016 field goals, each a quick, odd, almost artistic intermezzo to footballs other acts of fury. The field goal  snap, hold and kick take about 1.2 seconds  happens so swiftly and with such regularity, it is often treated as an afterthought, both omnipresent and overlooked.

title: Cardinals Romp, Highlighting Challenges for New Conference
description: PHILADELPHIA  The royal blue A logo of the new American Athletic Conference is painted on the perimeter walls in the corners of Lincoln Financial Field, near the tunnels, the only indication of Temples new conference affiliation. The logos were hardly noticeable enough to be a target for the sharpshooting offense of No. 7 Louisville in its 30-7 romp over Temple on Saturday. The Cardinals (5-0, 1-0), the top team in the current A.A.C., flexed their muscles and demonstrated what they can do with a Heisman Trophy contender, Teddy Bridgewater, at quarterback, throwing for 348 yards and 2 touchdowns.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, October 6
description: Its like building a bridge from two sides of the river; you just hope it comes out in the middle.

title: The Long, Long Wait for Mental Health Care
description: The Long, Long Wait For Mental Health Care

title: Ahead of the Market
description: How three of the top performers of the third quarter of 2013 fared against the market  and against their peer groups of funds.

title: Obama Points to Legitimate Concerns Over Redskins Name
description: The long-simmering debate over the Washington Redskins name took a new turn when President Obama said that he would consider changing it if he were the teams owner.

title: Secrets of a Field-Goal Kick
description: The Giants kicker, holder and snapper share the details of how a field goal is executed.

title: In an Opera House, All the Office Is a Stage
description: Peter Gelb, 59, is general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

title: As Syrian Refugees Develop Roots, Jordan Grows Wary
description: MAFRAQ, Jordan  For Jordan, a small desert nation that is one of the worlds driest, the recent home improvement trends at its biggest camp for Syrian refugees may prove particularly unsettling.

title: For Syrian Refugees in Jordan, a New Sense of Home
description: Some refugees are seemingly settling in for the long haul by recreating fixtures of their past domestic lives.

title: Readers Comment on the Government Shutdown
description: My Sunday column lacerates the House Republicans for the government shutdown and the flirtation with a debt limit default. To me, this isnt politics as usual but a rare instance of a political party causing deliberate economic and national security damage in hopes of gaining leverage on another issue. The national security consequences havent garnered enough attention, and theyre compounded by something I didnt have space to mentionPresident Obamas cancellation of his Asia trip itinerary. At a time when there is broad agreement that we should recalibrate our diplomatic efforts to focus more on Asia, this is an instance when were backing away from Asia because of this domestic political crisis. And China is the winner. So read the column, please, and share your thoughts on it.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 6
description: As the government shutdown approaches the one-week mark, conversations about whether Congress can come to an agreement on raising the debt ceiling are cropping up on the Sunday talk shows.

title: Toe Tags
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  First things first: Hands up if you were ready to write a strongly-worded comment or letter about 37 Down. Dont be shy; I looked it up, too. I will bet that most people believe that the correct phrase is JUST DESSERTS instead of the correct JUST DESERTS, because the majority of people pronounce the second word with the accent on the allegedly wrong syl-AH-ble.

title: Scores Are Killed in Iraqi Violence
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber killed at least 51 Shiite pilgrims who were crossing a bridge in Baghdad in the deadliest of several attacks in Iraq on Saturday, the police said. All told, the attacks claimed at least 80 lives, officials said.

title: Treasury Secretary Says Size of Debt-Ceiling Rise Is Up to Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has declined to tell senior Senate Republicans how large an increase the Obama administration wants in the nations soon-to-be-breached $16.7 trillion debt limit, saying that is Congresss job to decide under the Constitution.

title: A Coded Plea in the Forecast
description: A Budget Distress Call  Please Pay Us  Hidden in a Federal Weather Forecast

title: Obama on Iran's Leadership
description: In an interview with The Associated Press, President Obama spoke about President Hassan Rouhani of Iran and of the estimated timetable for Iran to be able to produce nuclear weapons.

title: Obama Defends the Health Care Law
description: President Obama defended the health care law and discussed the government shutdown in an interview with The Associated Press on Oct. 4, 2013.

title: Conservative Georgia District Urges G.O.P. to Keep Up the Fight
description: FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga.  Just down the road from where Union troops suffered their worst defeat of the Civil War, Jeff Epperson sang the praises of his congressman, Representative Tom Graves, whose Defund Obamacare Act set the table for the partial government shutdown.

title: Hillary Clinton, Waxing Nostalgic, Accepts Award at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  Hillary Rodham Clinton accepted an award at her alma mater, Yale Law School, on Saturday. At her 40th reunion, Mrs. Clinton, the former secretary of state, delivered a speech that took the audience down memory lane, highlighted her passion for childrens welfare and largely avoided politics.

title: Giants Lose Ross and Add Two to Secondary
description: Weakened in the secondary by injuries as they headed into Sundays game with the Philadelphia Eagles, the Giants on Saturday added two defensive backs. In a surprise, Aaron Ross, the teams first-round draft pick in 2007, was placed on injured reserve to make room for one of the two players.

title: Plan for Ridding Syria of Chemical Arms Includes Brute Force and Chemistry
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and its partners are planning a series of rapid steps to dismantle Syrias chemical weapons program, a strategy that is intended to guard against backsliding by President Bashar al-Assad and limit the time that international experts need to work in the country, according to senior American officials.

title: By Cutting Rural Routes, Megabus Leaves a Void
description: Confused and frustrated South Texans in March began calling Sarah Hidalgo-Cook, the manager of the Southwest Area Regional Transit District, in March. They were learning through e-mails that bus tickets they had purchased through Megabus.com had been refunded, with no option to repurchase. Because her transit district oversees public transportation for eight rural counties, Ms. Hidalgo-Cook was the logical person to call.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: The Days Best

title: Minnesota Coach Misses Michigan Game After Seizure
description: Minnesota Coach Jerry Kill had a seizure Saturday morning and did not travel with the Golden Gophers, who fell to No. 19 Michigan, 42-13.

title: In Spending $180 Million on Tutoring Help, Much Misuse
description: A federal program that set aside millions of dollars to provide remedial help for struggling students from low-income families quietly came to an end in Texas last month.

title: A Top Mormon Leader Acknowledges the Church Made Mistakes
description: One of the top leaders in the Mormon Church acknowledged in an address to the churchs global membership on Saturday that past leaders had made mistakes that had caused some Mormons to have doubts, an admission that amounts to a significant change in tone in the leaderships approach to Mormons who question, dissent or defect from the church.

title: Finale of Elite Series Brings Its Own Excitement
description: The final tournament in the mens Grand Prix series, which ended last week, did not live up to its billing.

title: For Low Taxes, It All Depends on the Business
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Hammer Museum to Offer Free Admission
description: LOS ANGELES  While admission fees at major art museums across the country keep rising, the Hammer Museum here is joining a small group of institutions bucking the trend. The Hammer Museum has announced this weekend that all exhibitions will be free to the public starting in February.

title: One Talk Show That Will Never Book a Kardashian
description: On most talk shows with a comedian as host, whether Jimmy Kimmel Live or Late Show With David Letterman, the guests are usually celebrities, who pitch their latest movies and tell lighthearted stories before sliding down the couch to make room for the next A-lister. The few nonfamous people on hand are glimpsed waving from the studio audience or relegated to comic relief in man on the street segments.

title: Newcomer From Japan Turns Heads, but Woods Steers U.S. to Wider Lead
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  The International teams Australia-based yell squad, known as the Fanatics, serenaded the pairing of Adam Scott and Hideki Matsuyama on the first tee Saturday morning at Muirfield Village by singing, Weve got the best-looking golfer in the game, to the tune of Hes Got the Whole World in His Hands.

title: Sidney Lanier, 90, Experimental Stage Producer, Is Dead
description: The Rev. Sidney Lanier first tried to revive his dwindling congregation on the fringe of Manhattans Theater District by summoning actors to the pulpit to read stirring passages from the Bible and great literature. Then, in 1963, he dispensed with the pulpit  the altar and pews, too  to try something really dramatic.

title: Grand Jury Indictment of Abu Anas al-Libi
description: American forces captured a Libyan militant, known by his nom de guerre, Abu Anas al-Libi, who had been indicted in 2000 for his role in the 1998 bombings of the United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: Corrections: October 6, 2013
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Nicholas Oresko, 96, a Hero of the Battle of the Bulge, Dies
description: The hill ahead, outside the German town of Tettingen, had twice been assaulted by Sgt. Nicholas Oreskos platoon in the previous two days, but it remained in enemy hands. Darkness was arriving to accompany the snow and cold. It was late afternoon, Jan. 23, 1945, the final stages of the Battle of Bulge, Adolf Hitlers massive surprise attack inflicting heavy casualties as the Allies massed for a push toward Berlin.

title: Red Sox Chase Price and Take Command in Series
description: BOSTON  David Price knew this could be his last start with the Tampa Bay Rays. He had seen the others ushered in and out. The Rays had drafted and developed him to be their ace, even as Matt Moore, Alex Cobb and Chris Archer joined the rotation, and as James Shields and Wade Davis were traded last winter for younger, cheaper talent.

title: In Age of Anywhere Delivery, the Food Meets You for Lunch
description: Julio Diaz was hungry. The problem was that Mr. Diaz was sitting in his Mitsubishi S.U.V., had a great parking spot on the Upper West Side, and could not walk away from the car until the alternate-side parking period had passed.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 5, 2013
Irish Say No to No Senate in Blow to Prime Minister
description: DUBLIN  Irish voters have rejected a proposal to abolish the upper house of Parliament, delivering a blow to Prime Minister Enda Kenny, who had championed the measure, which had been widely expected to pass.

title: Gunfire Wounds Israeli Girl, 9, Playing in Yard in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  A 9-year-old girl was shot in the chest Saturday night while playing outside her home in a West Bank settlement, in what the Israeli authorities suspect was an attack by a Palestinian who had broken into the settlement from one of the surrounding villages. The girl was in stable condition at a Jerusalem hospital, officials said.

title: House Republican Efforts to Repeal or Weaken the Health Care Law
description: A chart showing House votes that Republican leaders identified as containing at least some provision weakening the health care law.

title: As Germans Push Austerity, Greeks Press Nazi-Era Claims
description: AMIRAS, Greece  As they moved through the isolated villages in this region in 1943, systematically killing men in a reprisal for an attack on a small outpost, German soldiers dragged Giannis Syngelakiss father from his home here and shot him in the head. Within two days, more than 400 men were dead and the women left behind struggled with the monstrous task of burying so many corpses.

title: Karzai Is Planning to Be There for a Successor. Right There.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With less than a year left in his final term, President Hamid Karzai insists that he is eager to leave the presidential palace and lead a quieter life. It turns out, though, he may just be moving next door, to a lavish new home yards from the complex that has been the seat of his power for more than a decade.

title: Selling Secrets of Phone Users to Advertisers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Once, only hairdressers and bartenders knew peoples secrets.

title: A Federal Budget Crisis Months in the Planning
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after President Obama started his second term, a loose-knit coalition of conservative activists led by former Attorney General Edwin Meese III gathered in the capital to plot strategy. Their push to repeal Mr. Obamas health care law was going nowhere, and they desperately needed a new plan.

title: Argentine Leader Has Head Injury
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, has been told by doctors to take a month off after recently suffering a head injury, her spokesman said Saturday.

title: With Gusto and a Few Hiccups, Rose Makes an Electric Return to the Court
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Minutes before Saturdays preseason game between the Chicago Bulls and the Indiana Pacers, Derrick Rose emerged from the tunnel at Bankers Life Fieldhouse to a rousing cheer. A large contingent of Chicago fans, many seated behind the Bulls bench, had made the three-hour drive to see Roses return to the court 526 days after he tore his anterior cruciate ligament in the first round of the 2012 playoffs.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 6, 2013
description: Maybe some of us have not paid our taxes. But that is nothing compared to what they did.

title: Melanie Lindner, Benjamin Robbins
description: Melanie Sara Lindner, a daughter of Dr. Rochelle Haller Lindner and Dr. Gary S. Lindner of Manchester, N.H., was married Saturday to Benjamin Robert Robbins, the son of Patricia Biederman Robbins and William J. Robbins of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Rabbi David B. Kudan officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

title: Jennifer Chudy and Nitin Walia
description: Jennifer Chudy and Nitin Kumar Walia were married Saturday morning in Groton, Conn. Pandit Vinayak Pathak performed a traditional Hindu ceremony at the Mystic Marriott Hotel and Spa.

title: Alice Grant, Benjamin Graham
description: Alice Kathryn Grant, a daughter of Dr. Patricia Kavanagh and James Grant of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to David Benjamin Graham Jr., a son of Rebecca Graham and Mr. Graham Sr. of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Stephen D. Muncie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn.

title: Elizabeth Shivener, Steven Czarnecki
description: Elizabeth Rae Shivener and Steven Richard Czarnecki were married Saturday. The Rev. Dion Frasier, a minister of the Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Jorgensen Farms in Westerville, Ohio.

title: Teresa Ghilarducci and Richard McGahey
description: Marion Teresa Ghilarducci and Richard Michael McGahey were married Saturday in Montclair, N.J., at the home of Marcia Marley and Peter Rappoport, friends of the couple. Mayor Robert D. Jackson of Montclair officiated.

title: Katherine DePaul and Eivind Brydoy
description: Katherine Lynn DePaul and Eivind Brydoy were married Saturday at Bragernes Church in Drammen, Norway. The Rev. Carl Petter Opsahl, a minister of the Church of Norway, officiated.

title: David Landau, Joshua Picker
description: David Adam Landau and Joshua Benjamin Picker were married Saturday evening at the Carey Conference Center in Rensselaerville, N.Y. Rabbi Beth S. Kalisch officiated, with Cantor David Frommer taking part.

title: Garth Bardsley, Michael Morgenfruh
description: Garth Ian Bardsley and Michael Robert Morgenfruh were married Saturday. David G. Schmidt, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: Amanda Armstrong, Samuel Wilson
description: Amanda Brooke Armstrong and Samuel Edens Wilson were married Saturday evening in anondenominational ceremonyperformed by the Rev. Lynne S. Kramer, a minister of the United Church of Christ, at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Maureen Boyle, John Brady
description: Maureen Eleise Boyle and John Jeffrey Brady were married Saturday at St. Augustins Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Richard Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emilie Keldie, Andrew Rosenfeld
description: Emilie Michelle Keldie and Andrew Skiles Rosenfeld were married Saturday evening at the Bedford Post Inn in Bedford, N.Y. The grooms father, Morton M. Rosenfeld, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Deborah Temkin, Bryan Cahill
description: Deborah Ashley Temkin and Bryan Jefferey Cahill were married Saturday evening at the Sixth and I Historic Synagogue in Washington. Rabbi Martin Beifield officiated.

title: Shana Marowitz, James Hechler
description: Shana Juli Marowitz and James Steven Hechler were married Saturday evening at the Belvedere Mansion in Rhinebeck, N.Y. William Sanchez, a village and town judge in Rhinebeck, officiated.

title: Rachel Adams, Nicholas Miller
description: Rachel Elizabeth Adams and Nicholas Conrad Miller were married Saturday in Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Hilary Milton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia Church, where he is pastor.

title: Rebecca Zylberman and Daniel Freeman
description: Rebecca Marlo Zylberman and Daniel Joshua Freeman were married Saturday evening at the Whittemore House, a historic home in Washington. Rabbi Rachel Shere officiated.

title: Natalie Ritchie, Adam Binderup
description: Natalie Dawn Ritchie and Adam Joseph Binderup are to be married Sunday at the Darlington House, a restaurant in San Diego. Deborah Young, a minister ordained through the American Holistic Church in San Diego, is to officiate.

title: Timothy Roberts, Christopher Taggart
description: Timothy Clifford Roberts and Christopher Donlon Taggart were married Saturday in Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Leigh Hofstetter, Chad Diacont
description: Leigh Ashley Hofstetter and Chad Andrew Diacont were married Saturday. The Rev. Justin J. Baker performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Rutland, Vt.

title: Kristin Faucher, Peter Sicher
description: Kristin Elizabeth Faucher and Peter William Sicher were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Glen Miles, aDisciplesofChristminister, at the Hobbs Building, a group of art studios, in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Coffee Leads to Courtship
description: April Karena Rinne and Gerald Phillip Michalski were married Saturday on Mount Tamalpais in Marin County, Calif. Charles Warren, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, with the assistance of Marti Spiegelman, a friend of the couple who is a shaman.

title: Kathryn Jones, Alexander Witten
description: Kathryn Marie Jones, the daughter of Patricia Furey Jones and Richard H. Jones of Jacksonville, Fla., was married Saturday to Alexander Hayes Witten, a son of Lisa Hayes Witten and Richard E. Witten of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Cody, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Thomas Cody, also a Roman Catholic priest, assisting, at St. Pauls Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: A Life Built on Common Ground
description: Erin Louisa Thompson, a daughter of Mary Kae Thompson of Tucson and the late William J. Thompson, was married Saturday to Noah Ashur Brick, the son of Richard Brick and the adopted son of Sara Bershtel of New York. Jack Bershtel, the grooms uncle who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the home of the grooms parents.

title: Morgan Galland, Max Rettig
description: Morgan Arielle Galland and Max Louis Rettig will be married Sunday in Sonoma, Calif. Rabbi Marvin J. Goodman is to officiate at Cornerstone, a showcase for the work of landscape architects and garden designers.

title: Brielle Kissel, Anne Meade
description: Brielle Amara Megan Kissel, the daughter of Kathleen V. Kissel and Richard J. C. Kissel of Lexington, Mass., was married Saturday to Anne Kinkelaar Meade, the daughter of Susan J. Kinkelaar of Kennebunk, Me., and Dr. William C. Meade III, of Islesboro, Me. Debora J. Marathon, a notary public and Ms. Meades mothers partner, officiated at the Ducktrap Retreat in Lincolnville, Me.

title: Carl Sciortino Jr. and Pem Brown
description: Carl Michael Sciortino Jr. and Francis Pemberton Brown were married Saturday evening at the Old South Meeting House, a museum in Boston. Marc Solomon, a friend of the couple who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, officiated.

title: Nora Oberfield, Michael Fruchter
description: Dr. Nora Catherine Oberfield and Michael Howard Fruchter were married Saturday at the boathouse at the Sedgewood Club in Kent, N.Y. Rabbi Ammiel Hirsch officiated.

title: Love at First Handshake
description: Sarah Rebecca Cirkiel and Daniel Evan Gladstone were married Saturday evening at the Gansett Green Manor in Amagansett, N.Y. Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court in New York, an uncle of the groom, officiated.

title: Whitney Weiler, Thomas Zipser
description: Whitney Ward Weiler, a daughter of Wendy Gould Weiler and Robert P. Weiler of Camden, Me., was married Saturday to Thomas Frederick Zipser, the son of Marsha S. Zipser and Howard A. Zipser of New York. The Rev. Jeffrey C. Lewis, an Episcopal priest officiated at Pascal Hall, an art gallery in Rockport, Me.

title: Beth Wexelman, Arash Dawoodi
description: Beth Paula Wexelman and Arash Dawoodi are to be married Sunday afternoon by Rabbi Jeremy Rosen at the Essex House hotel in Manhattan.

title: Kathleen Strand, Robert Kellman
description: Kathleen Joan Strand and Robert Arthur Kellman were married Saturday at the South Shore Cultural Center in Chicago. Sister Carol J. Crepeau, a Roman Catholic nun who was ordained as a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the ceremony, which incorporated Jewish and Roman Catholic traditions.

title: Kathryn Tanner, Cyrus Stahlberg
description: Kathryn Cavanaugh Tanner and Cyrus Melcher Stahlberg were married Saturday at the Groton Long Point Yacht Club and Casino in Groton, Conn. Mary Joy Leaper, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood, officiated.

title: Nancy Borowick, Kyle Grimm
description: Nancy Elizabeth Borowick and Kyle Gilbert Grimm were married Saturday at the Liberty View Farm in Highland, N.Y. Anne E. Thompson, a United States district judge for the District of New Jersey, for whom the groom was a law clerk, officiated with Rabbi Shir Yaakov Feit assisting.

title: Everything Changed at the Ball
description: Laura Marie Jenkins, a daughter of Mary R. Jenkins and Dr. Randall D. Jenkins of Portland, Ore., was married Saturday to Lt. John Stanley Plack, the son of Margaret M. Plack and Thomas P. Plack of Washington.

title: Amy Stein, Michael Luxenberg
description: Amy Beth Stein and Michael Daniel Luxenberg were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Joshua Plaut at Thalassa Restaurant in New York.

title: Lucy Emerson-Bell, Zane Kessler
description: Lucy Amelia Emerson-Bell, the daughter of Sara J. Emerson of Cambridge, Mass., and Donald H. Bell of San Diego, was married Saturday to Zane McGee Kessler, the son of Twylah Jenonne Kessler and Ned A. Kessler of Edmond, Okla. The Rev. Jane Keener-Quiat, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Hell Roaring Ranch in Redstone, Colo.

title: Samantha Levy, Ryan Alovis
description: Samantha Blake Levy, a daughter of Darcy Cohen Levy and Lawrence H. Levy, both of New York, was married Saturday evening to Ryan Paul Alovis, a son of Meryl H. Alovis and Kenneth D. Alovis of Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis Math officiated at the brides fathers vacation home in New Hope, Pa.

title: Kristilyn Whigham and Percy Lambert
description: Kristilyn Shaquell Whigham and Percy Lawrence Lambert III were married Friday by the Rev. Dr. Toussaint K. Hill Jr., a Baptist minister, at the Biltmore Ballrooms in Atlanta.

title: Allison Pennock, Matthew Danzig
description: Allison Tatnall Pennock and Matthew Isaac Danzig were married Saturday in New Castle, N.H. Vice Chancellor Donald F. Parsons Jr. of the Delaware Court of Chancery, who received permission from New Hampshire to perform this ceremony, officiated at the Great Island Common, a park.

title: Mary Clancy, Jamie Riches
description: Mary Elizabeth Clancy and Dr. Jamie Cathleen Riches were married Friday evening at the Kaaterskill, an inn in Catskill, N.Y. Francis Tabone, a friend of the couple who became an Open Ministry minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Aditi Sen, Sudhir Muralidhar
description: Aditi Priyadarshini Sen, the daughter of Jyoti Misra Sen and Ranjan Sen of Baltimore, is to be married there Sunday evening to Sudhir Sudarshan Muralidhar, the son of Veena Muralidhar and Narasimhan Muralidhar of Cary, N.C. Sam Rosenfeld, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, will officiate at the Howard Peters Rawlings Conservatory and Botanic Gardens. B.S. Varadaraja Bhattar, a Hindu priest, will perform a traditional Hindu ceremony at the brides parents home Sunday morning.

title: Tali Yahalom, Joshua Leinwand
