description: Tali Ravit Yahalom, a daughter of Marlene Warshawski Yahalom of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Dr. Joshua Caleb Leinwand, a son of Bethsheba Mandel and Robert M. Leinwand of Brooklyn. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Jessica Smith, Andrew Pugliese
description: Jessica Elaine Smith and Andrew Paul Pugliese were married Saturday at the Barn at Hillsprings Farm in Tuscarora, N.Y. Richard D. Sullivan, a former town justice in Addison, N.Y., officiated.

title: Result Favors As Even if Matchup Did Not
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  At first glance, it looked like a lopsided pitching matchup in favor of the Detroit Tigers. They had Justin Verlander, baseballs highest paid pitcher, going against a 23-year-old July call-up named Sonny.

title: Movie Review: 'Gravity'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Gravity."

title: Movie Review: 'A.C.O.D.'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews A.C.O.D.

title: Movie Review: 'A Touch of Sin'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews A Touch of Sin.

title: Bomb Kills 4 Soldiers In Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Four coalition soldiers were killed Sunday in southern Afghanistan, the American-led international military force said, in the coalitions worst loss of life in a single episode since June.

title: Libya Condemns U.S. for Seizing Terror Suspect
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Libyas fragile interim government condemned the United States on Sunday for what it called the kidnapping of a Libyan citizen from this capital city a day earlier, and Libyan lawmakers threatened to remove the prime minister if the government was involved.

title: The Shutdown Hurts the U.S. in Asia
description: With Obama hobbled, Xi can pursue his game plan.

title: Daniel Radcliffes Fantasy Football Dreams
description: Among the many delightful and unexpected tidbits that Susan Dominus tells us about Daniel Radcliffe in the magazine this weekend, theres the fact that he is nurturing a fairly recent obsession with fantasy football. I probably know every starting players name in the league, he told Dominus. Actually, I dont know why Im being modest; I definitely know every starting player.

title: A Dad Grows in the Bronx
description: My lessons in Bronx parenting began on my first night in our new apartment, about an hour after my wife and I went to bed. My wife had moved in about a week earlier, but she still hadnt adapted to the sounds of our new home.

title: Ailing Mayor, Absent From Strawberry Fields, Is Still Channeling Lennon
description: Outside a ninth-floor room in St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital on the West Side of Manhattan last week was a handwritten sign that said Mayor of Strawberry Fields.

title: Disruptions: How the F.A.A., Finally, Caught Up to an Always-On Society
description: You know the scene in a movie when a character trails off into the past and is reminded of the moment it all began? I had one of those last week.

title: Boehner Hews to Hard Line in Demanding Concessions From Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner stood his ground on Sunday alongside the most conservative Republicans in Congress, insisting that the House would not vote to finance and reopen the government or raise the nations borrowing limit without concessions from President Obama on the health care law.

title: Cruzs 21-Hour Speech Fueled a Ratings Jump at C-Span2
description: Given the meager approval ratings the public has consistently given Congress, it might seem surprising that anyone watches the unblinking live shots of the Senate and House on television. But government crises apparently have a way of ratcheting up interest in Washington procedural drama.

title: Cate Blanchett at the New York Film Festival
description: She has played Katharine Hepburn. She has played Bob Dylan. She has played an elf. And at the New York Film Festival, Cate Blanchett played host to accolades.

title: The Social Science Explaining Why More Climate Science Hasnt Led to Greenhouse Action
description: Earlier this year, I took part in a fast-paced tour of the science of climate change at the Seattle Science Festival. I posted on the event at the time, but the Pacific Science Center has uploaded better video versions.

title: Schoolboy's Face, Killer's Arsenal
description: LONDON  He has the face of a schoolboy, the wispy body of a youth, and a future that five different countries are hoping to claim for their national team.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 6:30 P.M. (13) MOYERS & COMPANY The novelist Wendell Berry, above, a farmer, environmentalist and literary agrarian voice, sits down with Bill Moyers to discuss a no-compromise plan to save the earth. The interview was taped at St. Catharine College in Kentucky  home to the new Berry Farming and Ecological Agrarianism Program  during a two-day celebration of the 35th anniversary of the publication of Mr. Berrys seminal book, The Unsettling of America. Its mighty hard right now to think of anything thats precious that isnt endangered, Mr. Berry says. There are no sacred and unsacred places; there are only sacred and desecrated places. My belief is that the world and our life in it are conditional gifts. We have the world to live in on the condition that we will take good care of it. And to take good care of it we have to know it. And to know it and to be willing to take care of it, we have to love it.

title: Dozens Are Killed in Street Violence Across Egypt
description: CAIRO  At least 51 people were killed and hundreds were injured as street clashes erupted in several Egyptian cities on Sunday, in a surge of violence that raised new questions about the ability of the interim government to secure the fractured country.

title: Fox Renews The Simpsons
description: The Simpsons has a quarter-century behind it and at least one more year ahead of it on Fox. The network has announced that it renewed this animated comedy for a 26th season, keeping new episodes on television through 2015 and dispelling speculation that the show might make its 25th season, the one that started last month, its last.

title: Twitter C.E.O. Defends Representation of Women at the Company  Sort Of
description: When I was writing the article that ran in Saturdays New York Times about the dearth of senior women at Twitter  and the total absence of women on its board  the company declined to comment.

title: Gravity Is Strongest at Box Office
description: Gravity, a space thriller starring Sandra Bullock, reasserted the drawing power of 3-D as it took in $55.6 million at the domestic box office and another $27.4 million in international markets for Warner Brothers. over the weekend. An overwhelming share of ticket sales came from 3-D screens and large-format Imax showings, in the United States and abroad. That reversed a trend that had seen 3-D falter, particularly in domestic theaters.

title: Keystone XL Pipeline Commercial
description: TransCanadas latest ad in support of its pipeline project contrasts Canada with other, more unstable, sources of United States oil imports.

title: Cahills Late Theatrics
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls snatched a point and a playoff berth Saturday night in a 2-2 tie against the New England Revolution at Red Bull Arena, but like so much else for this club, it did not come easily.

title: Bomber Kills 13 Children At Iraq School Playground
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber detonated a truck filled with explosives on the playground of an elementary school in northern Iraq on Sunday morning, killing 13 children and the headmaster, the police said. Shortly afterward, another suicide truck bomb struck a police station in the same village, killing three officers.

title: We Are Now At War With Eastasia, I Mean The Deficit
description: This morning, for my sins, I found myself involuntarily watching bits and piece of the morning talk shows, and it seemed clear that Republicans have been given a new talking point. Suddenly, the shutdown/debt ceiling confrontation isnt just about Obamacare; its about curbing runaway spending growth and exploding debt.

title: Hitting the Ceiling: Disastrous or Utterly Disastrous?
description: Obama wont, cant negotiate over the debt ceiling, and Republicans still havent figured that out. So you have to say that its pretty likely that we will indeed hit the ceiling. Suppose that Obamas lawyers tell him that extraordinary measures like just ignoring the ceiling or minting the coin are out. Then what?

title: The Return of Speaker Pelosi?
description: Its just one poll, but maybe the Republican lock on the House isnt that unbreakable after all.

title: Bryan Cranston Is Headed to Broadway
description: The Emmy Award winner Bryan Cranston, fresh off his popular run as the drug kingpin Walter White on the cable series Breaking Bad, will make his Broadway debut this season as Lyndon B. Johnson in the play All the Way, the producer Jeffrey Richards said on Sunday. The play, which wraps up a sold-out production on Saturday at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., received mixed-to-favorable reviews there; the notices for Mr. Cranstons performance were strong, and producers are counting on his star power to drive ticket sales in the move to Broadway.

title: Afghan Presidential Hopefuls Are Told to Leave Guns at Home
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The deadline for registering as a candidate in Afghanistans coming presidential election was Sunday, and the election commission had a request for contenders: When you come to declare your candidacy, do not bring your gunmen.

title: Abortion Vote Exposes Rift at a Catholic University
description: LOS ANGELES  Not three weeks have passed since Pope Francis said the church had grown obsessed with abortion, declaring, We have to find a new balance. But on the campus of Loyola Marymount University, overlooking this citys west side, a fight over abortion now threatens to rip the school asunder.

title: Mideast Unrest as Foil to Promote Keystone Pipeline
description: TransCanada, the company trying to build the Keystone XL pipeline, is distributing a new round of ads in support of its stalled project.

title: Instruments of Danger in Weapons Case Were Dogs, Authorities Say
description: James Austin stood in front of a two-story Brooklyn row house, watching his puppy, Dutchess, play with a pair of pants while, a few feet away, a friends dog, Stoney, was tethered to a fence. At that moment, they were companions  both to him and in the eyes of the law.

title: U.S. Said to Hold Qaeda Suspect on Navy Ship
description: An accused operative for Al Qaeda seized by United States commandos in Libya over the weekend is being interrogated while in military custody on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, officials said on Sunday. He is expected eventually to be sent to New York for criminal prosecution.

title: Despite Good Intentions, New Targeting Rule Creates Problems
description: The changes to college footballs targeting rule  and the subsequent backlash  speak to a quandary all football faces.

title: Zoos Try to Ward Off a Penguin Killer
description: Zoos all around the world love penguins. Theyre cute, they dont require much space, they never eat zookeepers. And children adore watching them, especially at feeding time.

title: Marketers Chase Evolving Consumer
description: PHOENIX  THE senior executives who spoke at a major marketing conference here seemed to be auditioning for a reality show called Extreme Makeover: Corporate Edition.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 7
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Netanyahu Dressed Down After Appeal to Iranians
description: TEHRAN  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel tried to take his campaign against the Iranian leadership to Irans young population last week, saying that if they were truly free, they would be able to wear jeans, listen to Western music and participate in free elections.

title: From Irving Berlin to Bon Jovi: An American Songbook Devotee Gives Rock Hits a Twist
description: Its all in the arrangement. If you take a rock song like the Bon Jovi hit You Give Love a Bad Name and perform it in a pop-jazz style, it becomes a latter-day standard in the American Songbook. Or does it?

title: U.S. Names Roster for World Cup Qualifiers
description: Injuries and inaction played a role when Jurgen Klinsmann, the United States national team coach, selected his 20-man roster for the two final matches in regional World Cup qualifying.

title: Strife Joins Minnesota Musicians in Concert
description: MINNEAPOLIS  By the end of a disastrous week, classical music fans in this city sorely needed something positive to hang onto, however fleetingly. And, happily, they got momentary relief over the weekend in three concerts by the players of the Minnesota Orchestra, conducted by Osmo Vanska.

title: Ivy League Home for a Cartoonists Vast Archive
description: Al Jaffee started out as a professional cartoonist in the early 1940s, and he has been at it ever since. Although best known for the three-panel fold-ins that Mad magazine has run since 1964, he has also produced work for Timely Comics, the forerunner of Marvel, for Playboy and Esquire, for the short-lived satirical magazine Humbug, and for The Moshiach Times, a Jewish family magazine that has carried his secret-agent strip The Shpy for the last 25 years.

title: Federal Reserve to Unveil a Redesigned $100 Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve will begin circulating a new $100 bill on Tuesday with some modern and colorful anti-counterfeiting features, after overcoming problems that postponed its debut for more than two and a half years.

title: A Multiplicity of Musicians With Many Traditions and Narratives
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The first striking thing about Open City, Vijay Iyers large-ensemble suite heard twice over the weekend at Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University here, wasnt sound but a kind of theory of possibility suggested by the sight of the 20 people onstage.

title: An Environmental Album Recaptured in a Concert
description: At a time when we are awash in a constant deluge of digital images shared by friends and strangers through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Flickr, it can be hard to recall when we were less instantly and intimately connected. In the 1970s, though, the world was still analog. Most photographs needed developing, usually by specialists. You posted an image by sticking it in an envelope, then into a mailbox. Sharing photos meant passing prints from hand to hand, or maybe gathering in a darkened den to watch dutifully while a relative or neighbor showed vacation slides.

title: Giants Follow a Losing Formula
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Flawed teams find ways to lose, and by now the Giants must recognize the pattern. Interceptions, fumbles, penalties, blown coverages, even poor coaching decisions  this years Giants are dexterous and resourceful architects of defeat.

title: Lamenting Slavery and Celebrating a Culture
description: There was no mistaking the African roots of Christine Salems new music  a tradition called maloya that has been honored by Unesco as part of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity  when she opened the World Music Institutes season on Friday night at Symphony Space. Ms. Salem (pronounced sah-LEM) sang in a robust contralto and, much of the time, shook a sugar-cane rattle called a kayamb that was a blur of motion as it pinpointed breakneck 6/8 rhythms. She was backed by only two other percussionists and harmony singers, David Abrousse and Harry Perigone.

title: Scratching a Muses Ears
description: Mary Oliver has spent most of her life with a mind ripe with poems  and with at least one steadfast dog by her side. It seems fitting then that her latest collection revels in the carrying on of dogs. Dog Songs, out from Penguin Press on Tuesday, is a sweet golden retriever of a book that curls up with the reader, with 35 poems and one essay about the dogs who have shared Ms. Olivers days.

title: Point-Blank Perspectives on a Fatal Bullying Case
description: Events that received widespread news coverage when they happened can be difficult to turn into documentaries, but Valentine Road does an impressive job of making a 2008 shooting at a junior high school in Oxnard, Calif., horrifying and disheartening all over again.

title: Survivor Among a Lifetime of Ghosts
description: One Saturday morning, as the heroine of Alice McDermotts quietly exquisite new novel is just developing a classic case of preteenage insolence, her mother summons her to the kitchen for a cooking lesson. Its all in a days work, but the girl, Marie, takes it for granted that her mother has already done the familys laundry and hung it out to dry. This is a book so deft that even the damp shirts and school blouses on the clothesline have some import. Marie sees them hung upside down by their hems, their arms waving in a way that made me grow dizzy in sympathy.

title: Swarm of Rivals Seeking Share of Social Media Pie
description: Twitter, poised to make its splashy entrance on Wall Street, has helped define modern social networking. But while seeking to establish itself as an Internet powerhouse, it must also prove it can fend off a rising threat from a younger generation of nimble social outlets that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share content.

title: U.S.-Polish Showdown at Bali Tournament
description: Following on from Saturdays column, we move to the diagramed deal, the penultimate board in one quarterfinal of the Transnational Teams world championship last month in Bali, Indonesia. The eventual winners, Mark Gordon, Pratap Rajadhyaksha, David Berkowitz, Alan Sontag, Jacek Pszczola (known as Pepsi) and Michael Seamon from the United States, were locked in a tense battle against Polish Students (Stanislaw Golebiowski, Piotr Tuczynski, Pawel Jassem, Jakub Wojcieszek, Michal Klukowski and Piotr Zatorski).

title: Supreme Court Precedents in Play
description: The new Supreme Court term, which starts Monday, is notable for the number of major precedents that may be overruled or revised.

title: Big Fish
description: Scenes from the new Broadway musical at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: What the Artists Are Doing
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Its always nice to start a brand new solving week with a debut. Today, Amy Johnsons byline appears in The New York Times, and I would like to welcome her by saying that I enjoyed her puzzle. Its great to see a debut puzzle thats relatively clean and has such nice long fill. I also liked her colorful theme.

title: Fall for Dance
description: Images of performances by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and other companies.

title: Hip-Hop in Mixed Company of Swans and Other Woodland Creatures
description: The fifth and final program of this years Fall for Dance Festival was like a day at the cinema: the dancing equivalent of a short film, two cartoons and, at long last, a movie. The program, presented on Friday at City Center, got off to a ponderous start with a work that had its origins as a Sadlers Wells London production. While that connection doesnt automatically mean clunker, there are trademarks to such imports: ever-torquing limbs and more than a dash of melodrama.

title: Divers Recover 83 More Bodies From Migrant Ship
description: ROME  Divers searching the underwater wreckage of a migrant ship that capsized last week in the Mediterranean Sea recovered another 83 bodies on Sunday, raising the death toll to 194, a figure that is likely to keep growing.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: E-CIGARETTES The European Parliament, meeting in Strasbourg, France, plans to vote on Tuesday on a broad set of proposed tobacco regulations  the most contentious of which is how to regulate electronic cigarettes. Advocates of e-cigarettes say they are less harmful than conventional cigarettes, because users inhale nicotine-infused vapors instead of smoke. Despite the products growing popularity, some European public health officials want them regulated as medical devices. Even if tobacco industry lobbyists prevail in getting the European Parliament to back a less stringent form of regulation, the vote would be only a step in a European rule-making process for e-cigarettes that could continue into next year or beyond.

title: World Bank, Rooted in Bureaucracy, Proposes a Sweeping Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON  Jim Yong Kim, the genial American physician who took over as the president of the World Bank last year, recently conducted a survey of its 10,000 employees. The survey revealed a culture of fear, pervasive fear of risk and a terrible environment for collaboration at the huge development institution, which lends more than $30 billion a year and works in more than 100 countries.

title: Without Health Insurance: Those Left Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex, Doubt and the Pope
description: Many liberal Catholics have been encouraged by Pope Franciss comments about sexual ethics in a recent interview. His general point was that these are lesser matters, not to be emphasized at the expense of the churchs essential message of healing and salvation. Asked about homosexuality, he simply evoked Gods love for all humans: when God looks at a gay person, does he endorse the existence of this person with love, or reject and condemn this person? . . . In life, God accompanies persons, and we must accompany them, starting from their situation. It is necessary to accompany them with mercy. More widely, he said: We cannot insist only on issues related to abortion, gay marriage and the use of contraceptive methods . . . . The dogmatic and moral teachings of the church are not all equivalent. The churchs pastoral ministry cannot be obsessed with the transmission of a disjointed multitude of doctrines to be imposed insistently.

title: N.S.A. Social Data Mining
description: To the Editor:

title: No Limit on Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Abolish Runoff Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghanistans Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Aims to Regulate the Cloud
description: LONDON  The words cloud computing never appeared in a 119-page digital privacy regulation introduced in Europe last year.

title: Its Not About Mona Lisa
description: To the Editor:

title: In a World of Social Media, Alternatives for Everyone
description: Each social networking platform has a different take on inventive ways of private messaging and creating content with a rich infusion of images and videos.

title: Nielsen to Measure Twitter Chatter About TV Shows
description: Only 98,600 people wrote messages on Twitter about the two-hour season premiere of Greys Anatomy last month. Thats a tiny fraction of the 9.3 million who, according to Nielsen, watched the show that night.

title: Being Mayor
description: IN electing their next mayor, New Yorkers have a choice between a man with impressive political gifts but limited management experience and a seasoned manager who seems politically tone deaf.

title: Abraham Nemeth, Creator of a Braille Code for Math, Is Dead at 94
description: Abraham Nemeth, whose frustrations in pursuing an academic career in math prompted him to develop the Nemeth Code, a form of Braille that greatly improved the ability of visually impaired people to study complex mathematics, died on Wednesday at his home in Southfield, Mich. He was 94.

title: The Boehner Bunglers
description: The federal government is shut down, were about to hit the debt ceiling (with disastrous economic consequences), and no resolution is in sight. How did this happen?

title: Pakistan Army Chief Says He Will Retire Next Month
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, confirmed Sunday that he would retire next month, laying to rest media speculation that he would extend his term or take a powerful new position in the military.

title: A. C. Lyles, Prolific Producer of Westerns, Dies at 95
description: A. C. Lyles, who rose from the mailroom to producer at Paramount Pictures and created a string of profitable low-budget westerns, died on Sept. 27 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

title: A Balancing Act Around Lake Tahoe
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif.  Protecting this natural wonder, set in a mountain-ringed bowl 6,225 feet atop the Sierra Nevada, would have been difficult enough. But its placement, straddling the California-Nevada border, brings the two states into play, with sometimes-competing visions for the lakes future.

title: 4 Held in Iran Nuclear Site Plot
description: TEHRAN  The Iranian authorities have arrested four people suspected of planning to sabotage one of the countrys nuclear sites, the chief of Irans nuclear program told reporters on Sunday.

title: When Wealth Disappears
description: LONDON  AS bad as things in Washington are  the federal government shutdown since Tuesday, the slim but real potential for a debt default, a political system that seems increasingly ungovernable  they are going to get much worse, for the United States and other advanced economies, in the years ahead.

title: At a Nissan Plant in Mississippi, a Battle to Shape the U.A.W.s Future
description: CANTON, Miss.  The United Automobile Workers  desperate to make inroads in the anti-union South where Toyota, Volkswagen and other foreign automakers have assembly plants  has never tried a unionization drive quite like the one at the Nissan plant here.

title: Aint That Peculiar
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The night before every Jets game, safety Jaiquawn Jarrett shuts off his cellphone, as he used to do in college. In a separate room at the team hotel, right guard Willie Colon has two hours of acupuncture treatment. As needles poke and prod Colon, linebacker Antwan Barnes takes a 45-minute shower while rhythm and blues music plays in the background.

title: Old Warhorse Is Having Trouble Finding His Stride
description: NEWARK  Like most everything in his career, Jaromir Jagrs three-week tenure with the Devils has been eventful.

title: Jets (2-2) at Falcons (1-3)
description: 8:40 p.m., Ch. 11, ESPN

title: Using Twitter to Move the Markets
description: Last week, while everyone was wondering what Twitter is worth after the unveiling of its I.P.O., I spent some time on a little different math. How much could a single post on Twitter be worth?

title: As DVRs Shift TV Habits, Ratings Calculations Follow
description: One day after Fox introduced the Headless Horseman drama Sleepy Hollow last month, the television world was impressed by its overnight rating, a 3.4 among adults age 18 to 49. Fox knew it would grow: based on last seasons viewing trends, Fox figured the premiere episode would finish between a 5.1 and a 5.4 rating once seven days of digital video recorder playback were added.

title: Despite Hazards, Street Skateboarding Thrives
description: They race through the streets of New York, cruising through the cityscape as they try to outmaneuver taxis and dodge car doors swinging open.

title: Rival Factions in Strike Underscore the Fissures in Post-Chvez Venezuela
description: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela  Rival union groups squared off outside this countrys biggest steel mill last week, arguing over whether to continue a lengthy strike at the government-run plant. Each faction blasted its message at top volume over loudspeakers, trying to drown the other out. Pushing and shoving ensued, along with dueling renditions of the national anthem.

title: Pirates Beat the Averages and the Cardinals in Game 3
description: PITTSBURGH  Kevin Siegrist had never pitched in the major leagues before early June. Five years ago, he was drafted in the 41st round. But pedigree hardly matters to the St. Louis Cardinals, who develop their prospects well and expect results when they reach the majors.

title: Popular Demand
description: Because of the shutdown, going to a government Web site was hit or miss: the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services was navigable but carried a disclaimer that information might not be up to date.

title: Giants Close-Up
description: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE

title: Booker Campaign Ad
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will start spending more than $1 million on Monday to broadcast this television commercial on Cory A. Bookers behalf.

title: Rays Fail to Control a Red Sox Pest
description: BOSTON  Six pitches into the bottom of the first inning Saturday night, as fans were still finding their seats to watch Game 2 of the American League division series between Boston and Tampa Bay, Jacoby Ellsbury stood on third base.

title: In the Midwest, Recovering With the Help of Immigrants
description: Dayton, Ohio, is among many struggling cities that have launched programs to attract newcomers and their work skills.

title: Target in U.S. Raid on Somalia Is Called Top Shabab Planner of Attacks Abroad
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The target of the American commando raid in the Horn of Africa, a Kenyan of Somali origin known as Ikrimah, is one of the Shabab militant groups top planners for attacks beyond its base in Somalia, an American official said Sunday.

title: Ailing Midwestern Cities Extend a Welcoming Hand to Immigrants
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Fighting back from the ravages of industrial decline, this city adopted a novel plan two years ago to revive its economy and its spirits: become a magnet for immigrants.

title: Necessity Is the Mother of Reinvention as Players Shift Roles During the Postseason
description: DETROIT  Need and comfort often clash in the postseason, when a manager places a player in an unfamiliar role or asks him to perform a seldom-required task.

title: Alabama Museum, in Area Where Stars Found Sound, Seeks an Audience: Tourists
description: TUSCUMBIA, Ala.  A tentative revival is under way in this rural nook of northwest Alabama, a holy place in the evolution of rock n roll and home to a museum noticeably light on tourists.

title: Braves Simmons Is Turning Heads and Double Plays
description: LOS ANGELES  Andrelton Simmons had just finished high school in his native Curaao and figured that baseball was finished with him. Major league scouts, the same ones who had taken to his former youth teammates Kenley Jansen and Didi Gregorius, had passed on him. Simmons loved the game, so maybe he would play in a local league. Or maybe he would play semipro soccer. In any case, he would surely have to get a job.

title: Corrections: October 7, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Fixing Immigration From the Ground Up
description: The immigration marches and vigils that took place across the country on Saturday, uniting tens of thousands of people in more than 40 states, were a plaintive reminder that immigration reform  remember immigration reform?  is among the many pieces of business that remain unfinished while Congress is in lockdown.

title: The Fight Against Al Shabab
description: The raid by Navy SEALs on a Somali villa in search of a senior Shabab commander (his fate is unknown) and the capture by American commandos of a key terrorist suspect in Libya on Saturday were signs of a more assertive, targeted American role in trying to curb rising militancy and terrorist enclaves in North Africa.

title: Mismanaging the Vote in New York City
description: Around the country, voting seems to be getting easier  not perfect, but certainly better. One glaring exception is New York City. Instead of leading the way to better, fairer, cleaner elections, the citys Board of Elections runs a slow, often loony system that cant seem to deal with voting in the computer age. New Yorkers who voted in a mayoral primary last month were forced to use ancient voting machines because the board couldnt figure out how to make sure the newer optical-scanning machines would work for a possible runoff three weeks later.

title: To Delight Stamp Collectors, Postal Service Turns a Famous Mistake Upside Down
description: In an effort to rekindle the publics excitement over stamp collecting and interest a new generation in the hobby, the United States Postal Service has created an instant stamp rarity  a twist on one of the worlds most famous and valuable stamps.

title: A Face-Off Short on Showdowns
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  As if on cue, the curtain of rain parted Sunday to reveal Tiger Woods on center stage. With a 1-up lead over his International team opponent, Woods stood on the 18th green at Muirfield Village with the decisive point in the Presidents Cup on his putter. He hit a long birdie putt to within concession range to clinch the 18th point, and the Cup, for the United States.

title: News of Argentine Presidents Latest Ailment Fuels Criticism and Speculation
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentinas political system was hit by uncertainty on Sunday after the disclosure that President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner had sustained a head injury more than seven weeks ago and was told by neurologists over the weekend to rest for a month while receiving treatment for chronic bleeding near her brain.

title: A Dads Tall Tales and a Down-to-Earth Son
description: For a show that celebrates tall tales, Big Fish feels curiously stunted. Granted, this movie-inspired musical about a whopper-spinning traveling salesman, which opened on Sunday night at the Neil Simon Theater, is certainly big by most conventional measurements.

title: Why Limit Political Donations?
Breaking Away in the Old West
description: A group of rural counties in Colorado will vote in November to secede and work to form their own state.

title: Fed Up on the Prairie, and Voting on Seceding From Colorado
description: CHEYENNE WELLS, Colo.  The Old West has decided it is fed up with the New West.

title: Senate Chaplain's Shutdown Prayers
description: In the first week of the government shutdown the Senate chaplain, Barry C. Black, urged lawmakers to admit their mistakes. He prayed to deliver members of Congress from hypocrisy and stubborn pride.

title: Give Us This Day, Our Daily Senate Scolding
description: WASHINGTON  The disapproval comes from angry constituents, baffled party elders and colleagues on the other side of the Capitol. But nowhere have senators found criticism more personal or immediate than right inside their own chamber every morning when the chaplain delivers the opening prayer.

title: Pirates, Willing to Be Stupid, Made Smart Midseason Moves
description: PITTSBURGH  It was one of the more memorable comments by a general manager in recent memory, and it said everything about the often conflicting goals of the job. When the Pittsburgh Pirates Neal Huntington failed to make a move at the July 31 trading deadline, he summarized his efforts this way: We were willing to do something stupid. We just didnt want to do something insane.

title: Syrian Officials Sound a Conciliatory Note Toward the Opposition
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Coming from a Syrian deputy prime minister, it was an unusual statement. The countrys crisis, he said, began in part with a popular movement of peaceful protesters angry over economic disparities, and descended into war in part because officials were slow to make changes and failed to realize that the repression of the popular movement would lead to disaster.

title: Anxious Allies Aiding Booker in Senate Bid
description: Cory A. Booker is an undisputed star of a new generation of African-American leaders, electrifying liberal audiences with his oratory and charming the social media set with his digital savvy.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 7, 2013
description: We acknowledge our transgressions, our shortcomings, our smugness, our selfishness and our pride. Deliver us from the hypocrisy of attempting to sound reasonable while being unreasonable.

title: Beaten and Booed
description: Fans at MetLife Stadium lost patience with the Giants, who fell to the Eagles and dropped to 0-5 for the first time since 1987.

title: Drug Testing in Schools Divides North Jersey District
description: DEMAREST, N.J.  Jason Baretz wore a striped convicts outfit as he addressed a group at Northern Valley Regional High School at Demarest on a recent Monday evening.

title: Raising Her Voice in Pursuit of a Quieter City
description: Dresners restaurant, on York Avenue at 78th Street, should be fine for lunch, Arline L. Bronzaft had said when the appointment was set up. It might be quiet, she said. Quiet was important.

title: Raids Show the Limits of U.S. Military Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  Four vans with tinted windows converged in a comfortable Tripoli neighborhood as a leader of Al Qaeda returned home on Saturday from early morning prayers. As his wife watched with alarm from a window, the men  armed with silencer-equipped weapons, some masked and some not  smashed his car window. Within moments, they were gone, taking with them one of Americas most wanted terror suspects.

title: S.U.V. Fatally Hits Girl, 3, in Queens
description: A 3-year-old Queens girl was killed Sunday evening when she was struck by a sport utility vehicle as she crossed a street with her grandmother, the police said.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Oct. 6
Third Biker Is Charged in Attack on S.U.V. Driver
description: A motorcyclist who smashed his helmet into a sport utility vehicle after a high-speed chase last week was arraigned Sunday on several charges as the Police Department moved to determine whether one or more of its officers were present at a subsequent attack on the S.U.V.s driver.

title: Quest to Honor a Veteran Spans Years and Continents
description: Johan Kinberg was at his home in Sweden, researching his family tree, when he came across an old newspaper article about a World War I veteran who jumped to his death in Manhattan in 1922. The veterans name was Kinberg, too.

title: The Color of Affordable Care
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Breakthroughs in Prenatal Screening
description: More than 30 years ago, a 37-year-old friend of mine with an unplanned fourth pregnancy was told by her obstetrician that an amniocentesis was too dangerous and could cause a miscarriage. She ultimately bore a child severely affected by Down syndrome, which could have been detected with the test.

title: Word of the Day | spasmodic
description: spasmodic \spaz-m-dik\ adjective

title: In Military City, Government Reassurances Are Little Comfort
description: LAKEWOOD, Wash.  The Pentagons announcement that thousands of civilian Defense Department employees would soon return to work, even as the federal government shutdown continued, was welcome news to this city, which generations ago hitched its star to the military. But the anxiety remains, as do the wounds already inflicted on lives and businesses, in some cases by months of spending cuts even before the shutdown began.

title: Chat Service Aims to Challenge Bloomberg
description: The largest banks on Wall Street are teaming up to join a network that could challenge an important part of Bloombergs terminal business.

title: Supreme Court Has Deep Docket in Its New Term
description: WASHINGTON  After back-to-back terms ending in historic rulings that riveted the nation, the Supreme Court might have been expected to return to its usual diet of routine cases that rarely engage the public.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (HBO2) SHAME (2011) A handsome Manhattanite named Brandon (Michael Fassbender, above) hooked on sex finds his routine disrupted by the arrival of his sister (Carey Mulligan), whose neediness threatens his detached self-control  and whose self-destructive tendencies fuel his own  in this drama from the director Steve McQueen. Were not bad people, she says in a teary message on his cellphone. We just come from a bad place. A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times: Is Shame the name of something Brandon does feel, or of something the filmmakers think he should feel? The movie, for all its displays of honesty (which is to say nudity), is also curiously coy. It presents Brandon for our titillation, our disapproval and perhaps our envy, but denies him access to our sympathy. I know, thats the point, that Mr. McQueen wants to show how the intensity of Brandons need shuts him off from real intimacy, but this seems to be a foregone conclusion, the result of an elegant experiment that was rigged from the start.

title: Police Question Brooklyn Woman in Death of 19-Month-Old Son
description: A Brooklyn woman was being questioned by detectives late Sunday night after her 19-month-old son was taken to a hospital, where he later died, according to the police.

title: Dodgers Bats Pound Questions Into Footnotes
description: LOS ANGELES  Returning home with a split of the first two games of a playoff series would buoy spirits in many cities. But when the Dodgers took the field Sunday night, the anxiety about the game that slipped through their grasp in Atlanta, which had stewed for 48 hours, seemed palpable among the capacity crowd. The cheers for the home team sounded more hopeful than assuring.

title: News Quiz | October 7, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: Return of the Guardian Angels
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pump for Reactor Stops in Japan
description: TOKYO  The operator of Japans wrecked nuclear plant said Monday that a pump used to cool one of the damaged reactors had stopped, possibly because of human error, in the latest problem at the facility.

title: Japan Airlines Deal With Airbus Is Blow in Boeing Stronghold
description: Stung by all the problems with its new 787 Dreamliner over the past decade, Boeing waited too long to start updating its larger 777 jets, giving Airbus an opening to break into the Japanese market that Boeing had dominated for decades, aviation analysts said Monday.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Oct. 7, 2013
description: Before Taking the Quiz

title: Bombing Near Polio Vaccination Site Kills 2 Pakistani Police Officers
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  At least two police officers were killed and a dozen people wounded on Monday when a bomb went off near a health care facility where polio vaccines were being dispensed outside this northwestern Pakistani city, officials said.

title: 6 Qs About the News | New Exhibition Features the Paintings and Re-Paintings of Vincent Van Gogh
description: In Seeing Double: Van Gogh the Tweaker, Henry Adams writes about world-renowned artist Vincent Van Goghs habit of copying his own original paintings, a practice that had long been something of a dirty secret and now, the subject of an exhibition.

title: Obamas Absence Leaves China as Dominant Force at Asia-Pacific Meeting
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  Secretary of State John Kerry replaced President Obama at the opening of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting on Monday, leaving Chinas president, Xi Jinping, as the dominant leader at a gathering devoted to achieving greater economic integration.

title: Anonymous Men, Made Real
description: We highly recommend viewing this slide show in full-screen mode.

title: Who Should Be Able to See Students Records?
description: Every day people share personal information about themselves online, using social media, blogs and even email messages. What happens when information collected about you from schools youve attended is added to a software program to track yourand your schoolsprogress, habits and behaviors?

title: Week 5 N.F.L. Quick Hits: The Woes of Romo
description: Andy Benoit takes a tour through Week 5, including high drama in Dallas with a familiar finish for Tony Romo; a rare Patriots game without a touchdown pass from Tom Brady; and a Philadelphia offense that finally reached its potential.

title: For 3 Nobel Winners, a Molecular Mystery Solved
description: Three Americans won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday for discovering the machinery that regulates how cells transport major molecules in a cargo system that delivers them to the right place at the right time.

title: New York Today: Mr. Lhotas Neighborhood
description: Updated 12:27 p.m. | Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor, likes to point out that he was raised in the Bronx. (A long way from Cambridge, Mass., where his opponent, Bill de Blasio, grew up).

title: Your Ideas for Revisiting the News
description: Which news stories from decades past would you like to see re-examined today? Our weekly online video series, Retro Report, revisits what are supposedly old stories  but they all have much to tell us about news today.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on Daniel Radcliffes Introspective Side
description: Susan Dominus, a staff writer for the magazine, profiled the actor Daniel Radcliffe for this weeks cover story. Her last article for the magazine was about college career-services counseling.

title: Richard Jewell: The Wrong Man
description: The 1996 Olympics in Atlanta were rocked by a bomb that killed one and injured more than 100. In the frenzy to find the perpetrator, an innocent man became a suspect.

title: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Regulations for Cloud Computing
description: The digital privacy regulation introduced in Europe last year, which did not initially address cloud computing, is expanding to cover this ascendant method of handling data, Danny Hakim reports.

title: A Bombing Suspect, and the Rush to Judgment
description: This weeks Retro Report video tells the story of Richard Jewell, an innocent man, who in the summer of 1996 was painted by some news media outlets as being a likely suspect in a bombing at the Atlanta Olympics, which killed one person and injured more than 100 others. Using archival footage and recent interviews with the lead players, the video explains how a good deal of the newspaper and television coverage relied on unidentified law enforcement sources to cast Mr. Jewell in the worst possible light. It was nearly three months before the federal government cleared him, and almost a decade before Eric Rudolph, a violent anti-abortionist, pleaded guilty to the bombing. Below, The Timess main reporter on the story recalls lessons learned.

title: Ex-Minister in Greece Is Found Guilty in Bribery Case
description: ATHENS  In a landmark verdict, a former Greek defense minister and co-founder of the countrys once-mighty Socialist Party, Akis Tsochatzopoulos, was found guilty on Monday of setting up a complex money-laundering network to cover the trail of millions of dollars in bribes that he is said to have pocketed from government weapons purchases.

title: World Bank Lowers East Asia Growth Forecasts
description: HONG KONG  The World Bank lowered its growth forecast for large parts of eastern Asia, saying on Monday that the rebalancing of the once red-hot Chinese economy, lower commodity prices and weaker-than-expected exports were holding back expansion in countries like Indonesia, Malaysia and China itself.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 7, 2013
description: Update: Oct. 8, 2013

title: Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, Spiritual Leader of Israels Sephardic Jews, Dies at 93
description: JERUSALEM  Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, who became a fiery figure in Israeli politics as the spiritual leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, championing the interests of Jews of Middle Eastern and North African origin, died here on Monday. He was 93.

title: Inside the Political Crisis
description: The government shutdown that began last week seemed to come out of nowhere. But the take-no-prisoners strategy among Republicans was planned months ago, as part of a long-running effort to undo the Affordable Care Act, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mike McIntire report in The New York Times.

title: Daily Report: Twitter Rivals Seek Share of Social Media Pie
description: Twitter, poised to make its splashy entrance on Wall Street, has helped define modern social networking. But while seeking to establish itself as an Internet powerhouse, it must also prove it can fend off a rising threat from a younger generation of nimble social outlets that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share content, Jenna Wortham and Vindu Goel report.

title: The Watery Tomb Europe Tolerates
description: COPENHAGEN  A FEW years ago, a young woman I met in a small fishing village in central Ghana told me that, after her husband left to try to get to Italy, she stepped out into the courtyard of their home and saw his ghost at the gate.

title: Weekend Gun Report: October 4-6, 2013
description: In an interview with Slate on Sunday, Garen Wintemute, a professor of emergency room medicine and director of the Violence Prevention Research Program at the University of California, Davis, revealed why gun research is such an uphill battle in the U.S. While guns claim 30,000 lives a year and injure 75,000, federal funding for research is less than $200,000 a year, he told Tiffany OCallaghan. In contrast, public health research on motor vehicle accidentswhich also claim 30,000 lives each yearreceives close to $4 million.

title: IndieCade Games Festival Celebrates Winners
description: IndieCade, the four-day festival known as the Sundance of games, announced the eclectic winners of three awards on Sunday night in Culver City, Calif.

title: Britain Sought European Permission for Possible R.B.S. Split
description: LONDON  The British government has filed for permission from the European Union to possibly split the Royal Bank of Scotland into two entities, a move that would essentially wall off troubled assets that crippled the bank and led to a government bailout five years ago, the European Commission confirmed on Monday.

title: All the Rage | Funny Sweaters
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Today in Small Business: No Backbone
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Doctor Who Star Takes a Stab at American Psycho Musical
description: An actor gives up the lead role he has played for nearly four years and the next thing you know, hes turned to murder. Matt Smith, who has traveled time and space on the science-fiction TV series Doctor Who, is putting down his sonic screwdriver and picking up some sharper, Earth-made implements to play the bloodthirsty Patrick Bateman in a London stage musical adaptation of American Psycho, its press representatives said on Monday.

title: Twitters Filing for I.P.O.
description: Twitter set the price of its initial public offering at $26 a share, valuing the company at $18.1 billion.

title: Credibility All The Way Down
description: Ken Rogoff has responded to Simon Wren-Lewis and yours truly, and Im glad to see that hes taking the analytical questions we raised seriously. I guess it wont surprise readers, however, to learn that I dont find the response adequate.

title: On Knowing What You Dont Know
description: Brad DeLong catches Niall Ferguson making another whoopsie. And while chasing NF isnt worth the effort for its own sake, I think there is a broader lesson here: namely, the importance of knowing what you dont know.

title: Karen Strauss Cook, Trader Who Helped Women on Wall Street, Dies at 61
description: Karen Strauss Cook, a trailblazing trader at Goldman Sachs who went on to help other working mothers find part-time jobs in finance, died on Wednesday in New York. She was 61.

title: With Reid Statement, Relationship With Boehner Grows More Acid
description: Senator Harry Reid on Monday morning blistered Speaker John A. Boehner in a statement, worsening the already tense atmosphere over the shutdown and debt ceiling negotiations.

title: Life in A Refugee Camp Near Muzaffarnagar
description: MALAKPUR, Uttar Pradesh Of the 42,000 people who fled their homes in Muzaffarnagar after violence broke out between Hindus and Muslims in early September, several thousand have settled near this village, about 60 miles north of New Delhi, staying in rows of colorful tarpaulin tents that are just wide enough for a cot and just high enough to allow one to sit upright.

title: A Magical Isle Loses the Last of Its Residents
description: It sounded like a nursery rhyme, but it was true.

title: G.M. Recalls 1,600 Sonics for Fuel Tank Defect
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is on a hiatus because of the federal government shutdown, but that doesnt mean automakers cannot initiate recalls on their own. General Motors said in a news release on Monday that it would recall about 1,558 Chevrolet Sonics from the 2013-14 model years in the United States because the strap holding the gas tank could break.

title: Top Court Will Not Hear Argentina Debt Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court refused on Monday to hear Argentinas appeal of a lower courts decision in favor of hedge funds that held bonds on which the country had defaulted.

title: Ruth Benerito, Who Made Cotton Cloth Behave, Dies at 97
description: Half a century ago, working quietly in a New Orleans laboratory, Ruth Benerito helped smooth the fabric of modern life. In so doing, she helped liberate people from hours of household drudgery.

title: Coping With Local Government Regulations
description: At the last She Owns It business group meeting, we talked about government regulations  especially at the state level (this was before the federal government shutdown). This post continues that conversation.

title: The Netherworld of What Constitutes Insider Trading
description: Identifying insider trading sometimes seems like a game of three-card monte: first you see it, then you dont.

title: After Years of Pain, Greece Expects a Budget Surplus
description: ATHENS  Offering the first real hope that Greece could emerge from a six-year recession, the government on Monday presented a draft budget for next year forecasting a tenuous return to growth.

title: Egyptian Attacks Are Escalating Amid Stalemate
description: CAIRO  The lethal conflict between Egypts military-backed government and its Islamist opponents escalated on Monday, with an expansion of attacks against government targets, signs that the authorities have failed to secure the streets and that both sides refuse to back down.

title: Stir-Fried Beet Greens, Tofu and Beets
description: I had lots of beet greens on hand during the week that I was testing all of these beet recipes, so I decided to combine them with julienned beets in a stir-fry. The greens should be crisp-tender.

title: Japanese Court Fines Rightist Group Over Protests at a School in Kyoto
description: TOKYO  In a widely watched decision, a court in Kyoto on Monday ordered a far-right group to pay $120,000 in damages to an elementary school for ethnic Koreans after the group staged demonstrations using slogans that the court characterized as racist.

title: Beet and Chia Pancakes
description: Ever since I read Kim Boyces recipe for quinoa and beet pancakes, a recipe that inspired her wonderful book Good to the Grain, Ive wanted to add pured beets to a pancake batter. I finally got around to it. I used two-thirds whole wheat flour and one-third all-purpose flour in this very pink batter. Ms. Boyce uses a mixture of quinoa flour and all-purpose, which shows off the bright color of the beets to a better effect. I think millet flour would be a good choice too. Its important to pure the roasted beets until theyre really smooth; I found using a powerful hand blender was more effective for this than my food processor.

title: The Anxiety of Exodus
description: TEL AVIV  Israelis are fretting about emigration after a recent series on Channel 10 News featured disillusioned Israelis who left the homeland. The migrs thought the country didnt pay enough attention to the needs of the young and the middle class.

title: Kobe Who? Showtime Has Moved to Dodger Stadium
description: LOS ANGELES  It is so loud inside Dodger Stadium these days that Tommy Lasorda cannot listen to himself talk, and Magic Johnson can hardly hear his own hyperbole. Not coincidentally, it is N.B.A.-arena loud  quite a feat for a building with the sky as its ceiling and a soothing outfield backdrop of rolling hills and mountains.

title: The Dashilar Pilot
description: This project to regenerate a historic area of Beijing was introduced at the recent Beijing Design Festival.

title: Solvay Pays Up to Get Into Fracking
description: Solvay is paying up to tap into fracking.

title: City Ballets Chase Finlay Is Recovering From Injury
description: The New York City Ballets principal dancer Chase Finlay is not expected back onstage until the winter season after breaking his foot during a performance of Swan Lake, said a company spokeswoman.

title: On the Verge | The Magical Mosaics of Yukiko Nagai
description: Yukiko Nagai was recently anointed one of designs bright young things by the renowned Milan-based gallery owner Rossana Orlandi, who became entranced by the 32-year-old Japanese artists work, like the Patchwork Chair (above), which has a cushion made of marble and glass tiles. Nagai, whose studies in landscape design led to her interest in mosaics, uses the same technique to mimic other unlikely materials  wood grain and boar hide  always creating a second-glance surprise that subverts the viewers expectations of comfort.

title: Image of the Day: October 7
Martin Gardners The Monkey and the Coconuts
description: For the next several weeks well be celebrating the life and interests of Martin Gardner, the American science and math writer who popularized the notion of recreational mathematics  math for fun. Many readers of this blog may be familiar with Mr. Gardner through his puzzles: we cant go very long here at Numberplay without featuring a puzzle that Martin Gardner either discovered, created or popularized.

title: From Todays Paper: Monster Truck Crash Kills 8 at Mexican Air Show
description: At least 79 spectators were wounded, officials said, after an out-of-control truck drove into a crowd in Chihuahua on Sunday. The driver has been detained on suspicion of manslaughter.

title: Legal Side Effect in Admission of Wrongdoing to the S.E.C.
description: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | When Philip A. Falcone admitted committing multiple acts of misconduct in a settlement this summer with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the hedge fund billionaire appeared to put his legal woes to rest.

title: Some Civilians Return to Military Academies
description: WASHINGTON  United States military academies got some relief from their government shutdown struggles over the weekend as the Pentagon reinstated most of its furloughed civilian employees, allowing professors and other staff members to return to workon Monday.

title: Should the President Negotiate?
description: For our polarized times, here are two polarized views of the debt ceiling debate, which is set to swallow up the unresolved government shutdown debate sometime late this week. First,Kevin Hassett and Abby McCloskey in the Wall Street Journal, attacking the president for his refusal to negotiate around a debt limit extension:

title: Zoellick to Join Goldman as International Adviser
description: Goldman Sachs said on Monday that it had hired Robert B. Zoellick, the former president of the World Bank, as the chairman of its international advisory board.

title: A Most Inquisitive Court? No Argument There
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court has what lawyers call a hot bench, and temperatures are rising.

title: The Day My War Ended
description: Standing shoulder to shoulder with hundreds of heavily armed paratroopers, I looked around at all of us, breathing heavily, angry and resentful, surrounding the Baya mosque in Baghdad. The previous morning, we had arrested the head imam because he was stockpiling weapons in the mosque. Now, under amber street lamps casting wicked shadows, his followers were gathered, demanding his release. My adrenaline was still pumping from the explosion minutes earlier, when one of them tossed a grenade at our line of troops, injuring more than a half-dozen soldiers and civilians. After that, order descended into a running street battle, soldiers wrestling protesters, bodies slamming into the hard concrete. Months of pent-up aggression were suddenly released in a cathartic, chaotic performance.

title: Expecting Not to Stay, but Now Right at Home
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Paul Worrilow and Joplo Bartu, who shared a room during the Atlanta Falcons off-season training in the spring, would read their playbooks or watch practice videos on their iPads at night, and then quiz each other about the fine art of playing linebacker.

title: The Making of Malala
description: The story of Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl, told by The Timess Adam B. Ellick, who made a 2009 documentary about her before she was an international star.

title: Feeling For | Backpackers and Businessmen Alike Check Into Hlemmur Square in Reykjavik
description: Klaus Ortlieb, a German-born hotelier who made his mark stateside with the Hotel Modern in New Orleans and two properties in New York City (the Gotham Hotel and the Standard East Village), proves once again that building a successful hotel is not unlike throwing a much-talked-about party. Its all about appealing to a wide range of guests. So for the new Hlemmur Square hotel in Reykjavik, he designed a high-low model to accommodate the discerning traveler at any budget. The 26 shared, hostel-style rooms are available for as little as $20 per night, while the 18 private rooms, on a separate, plusher floor, cost as much as $182. A far cry from the standard-issue budget digs of yore, the hostel suites offer duvet-covered beds, complimentary local telephone calls and optional room service. And the upgrade to a private room comes with the usual boutique hotel comforts: modern dcor (earth tones and oak parquet floors, gray walls dotted with black-and-white photographs of Old Reykjavik), extra-cozy beds (made with up with Lissadell linens) and stunning, top-floor views (of the citys boldly colored roofs).

title: An Educational Program for Graffiti Art
description: The institutionalization of graffiti culture continues apace: a program teaching the style and history of illegal tagging is set to begin this month.

title: Top Editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer Is Dismissed
description: In the latest example of management turmoil at The Philadelphia Inquirer, William K. Marimow was fired as the papers top editor on Monday.

title: After Years on Run, Libyan Was Found With Family
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  When Delta Force commandos homed in on Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai in a neighborhood of Tripoli this weekend, they found him settled with his wife and children in his familys traditional home after nearly three decades on the move.

title: How the Shutdown Is Affecting Cape Hatteras Seashore
description: Ocracoke Island, the southernmost barrier island of the Outer Banks in North Carolina, enjoys such a strong association with its one-square-mile historic village that some tourists here were surprised to learn the federal shutdown had affected their vacation plans.

title: Healthful Muffins, Moist and Sweet, for Anytime
description: Whats for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes for supper, or, in this case, lunch.

title: India Says It Has Killed 7 in Clashes Along Pakistan Border
description: NEW DELHI  India says it has killed seven fighters and is still fighting others in a Pakistan-backed force of several dozen who crossed a mountainous and thickly forested border area with the aim of killing Indian troops, ratcheting up tensions just as the two countries leaders agreed to work together to de-escalate the situation.

title: Street Style: Tie Dye
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Oct. 1.

title: Obama Challenges Boehner on Budget Vote
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday made an unscheduled visit to the Federal Emergency Management Agency in his latest bid to draw attention to the effects of the government shutdown and to challenge Speaker John A. Boehners claim that he does not have enough votes to pass a measure to finance the government.

title: Competition and Productive Off-Season Keep Jets Kicker Sharp
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For four springs, like clockwork, Nick Folk would be home in New York or training in California when the news finally floated his way: the Jets had brought in another kicker to take his job.

title: The Flight of the Fly
description: Michael Dickinson has spent his career studying how flies fly and researchers in his lab have invented new devices to investigate the complex feat of insect flight.

title: Focusing on Fruit Flies, Curiosity Takes Flight
description: SEATTLE  To hear Michael Dickinson tell it, there is nothing in the world quite as wonderful as a fruit fly.

title: 57th Street Reopened After Crane Malfunction in Midtown
description: A crane malfunctioned on Monday at the same Midtown Manhattan high-rise that was the scene of a crane accident during Hurricane Sandy.

title: Weighing Surgeries in Light of a Breast Cancer Gene
description: When Tracy Dunbrook, a bioethicist in Sherman, Conn., tested positive for the BRCA gene mutation, she was told she had a 40 to 60 percent chance of developing ovarian cancer in her lifetime. Doctors advised her to have her ovaries removed.

title: A St. Regis New York Face-Lift Spurs a Glamour Campaign
description: The St. Regis New York is showing off its $90 million renovation in a new multimedia ad campaign inspired by vintage advertising and fashion photography.

title: A Recent Flourish for Winton Capital
description: Winton Capital Management is showing some improvement in the art of investing.

title: Scalias Echo Chamber
description: Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia has seen the T.V. show Duck Dynasty. In an interview published on Sunday with New York Magazines Jennifer Senior, he said many people recommended it to him as a great show and he figured hed better look at it. He also said hed seen The Sopranos, plus a couple of episodes of Mad Men, and that he loved Seinfeld. Oh, boy, he said, The Nazi soup kitchen? No soup for you!

title: Monday Motorsports: IndyCar Crash Injures Franchitti and 13 Spectators in Houston
description: Three-time Indianapolis 500 winner Dario Franchitti broke his back and sustained other injuries in a huge last-lap crash Sunday at the Grand Prix of Houston. At least 13 spectators and one official were also injured by flying debris.

title: Documenting a Pakistani Girls Transformation
description: There is a story to Malala Yousafzais improbable transformation from a quiet, deferential 11-year-old living near Pakistans tribal areas to a teenage spokeswoman for girls education. Malala, shot in the head by the Taliban last year, has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, to be announced on Friday.

title: The Crazy, Intense Schedule of Competitive Youth Soccer? Bring It On
description: If my husband and I had to choose, we would live in Athens. While we were both athletes as children, as adults we make our home firmly in the world of content creation. Our daughter, however, lives much of her life in Sparta, by which I mean the world of highly competitive team sports.

title: A Few Controversies Amid a Record Number of Foreign-Language Oscar Entries
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has just announced its  official list of contenders for the 2014 Oscar for best foreign-language film, and, as usual, the movies that were submitted  or left out or disqualified  reflect a process that is rife with politics and intrigue.

title: Banksy Parodies Syrian Rebel Videos
description: Last Updated, 5:49 p.m. | The British street artist Banksy is apparently among the millions watching Syrias war from afar, through glimpses of the fighting recorded on video and posted on YouTube. His latest video work is a brief parody of one of those clips released on Sunday as part of a series of works produced during a monthlong residency in New York that started last week.

title: Losing Money on a Treasury Bill
description: Some investors in treasury bills  the safest, lowest-yielding assets around  are getting a little nervous.

title: Obama Challenges Boehner to Hold a Vote
description: During a visit to FEMA on Monday, the president said there were enough Republican and Democratic votes in Congress to pass a clean spending bill and pressured the House speaker to call for a vote.

title: Massacre at Baxter Springs
description: On the afternoon of Oct. 6, 1863, Maj. Gen. James G. Blunt lost 82 men when a Union baggage train making its way to Fort Blair near the southeastern Kansas town of Baxter Springs was attacked by Confederate guerrillas. The loss of the men was bad enough  but the Confederates also made off with Blunts clothing, sword, commissions, correspondence, official papers and a flag the ladies of Leavenworth, Kan., had presented to him four days earlier.

title: Unease in Hawaiis Cornfields
description: WAIMEA, Hawaii  The balmy tropical isles here seem worlds apart from the expansive cornfields of the Midwest, but Hawaii has become the latest battleground in the fight over genetically modified crops.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 1-7, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

title: Energy-Saving Secret of Jellyfish
description: The moon jelly, or common jellyfish, is often viewed as a problem, an ecological invader, a nuisance to swimmers, or worse. A moon jelly population explosion last month clogged the water intakes of a Swedish nuclear power plant, forcing it to shut down. The jellyfish, which can be 2 to 15 inches in diameter, is such a concern that engineers in South Korea designed seagoing, prowling robotic blenders to liquefy the offenders.

title: ScienceTake: The Jellyfish Engine
description: The moon jellyfish is slow, but there's a reason for that. Its undulating pace allows it to swim more efficiently than just about anything in the ocean.

title: Young People Are Not as Digitally Native as You Think
description: Everyone knows young people these days are born with smartphones in hand and will stay glued to the Internet from that time onward. Right?

title: The Age Suit and Talking to Older Drivers About Giving Up the Keys
description: Imagine you have arthritis in every joint. With a stiff neck, knees that wont bend past 40 degrees and arms that take great effort to hold up, driving would be a chore. Getting into the drivers seat would be a controlled fall of sorts, and after plopping down behind the wheel, turning your head to check the mirrors would be nearly impossible.

title: The New World of the Kolache
description: This soft pastry of yeasted dough, traditionally filled with sweetened cheese or fruit, is now straddling several constituencies.

title: The Kolache: Czech, Texan or All-American? (All Three)
description: HOUSTON  Morgan Weber grew up eating poppy-seed kolaches baked by his Czech grandmother, who honed her technique on a wood stove. Kolaches, soft pastries of yeasted dough with a divot in the center, traditionally filled with sweetened cheese or fruit, are a humble link to the Old World.

title: Readers Ask About Families Who Want Different Plans, and Rise in Costs
description: In the last two installments of the Your Money column, I answered questions about the new health insurance exchanges. The first column discussed many of the basics, and the second column answered reader questions. You can find more readers questions and answers on In Practice, with the latest series below. If youre still not sure how the law affects you and your family, please e-mail me your questions: tsbernard@nytimes.com.

title: The Amazing Fruit Fly, Millions Left Out of the New Health Law
description: The humble fruit fly turns out to be a lot more complicated than you might think; a sweeping national effort to extend health coverage to millions of Americans will leave out two-thirds of poor blacks and single mothers.

title: Photo Replay: Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: Shall we dance? The choreography of sports is seen in all manner of competition.

title: Collisions of Football Helmets and Money
description: The National Football League, so good at hyping its own games and stars, may have inadvertently sprinkled some of that promotional fairy dust on League of Denial: The NFLs Concussion Crisis, a Frontline installment about brain injuries among players.

title: A Magical, Flying Visit From a Magical, Flying Boy
description: In Peter Pan, at the New Victory Theater, Peter is played by a fit young man, Meyne Wyatt, rather than by a petite woman. And instead of tights and forest leaves, this Peter wears gym shorts, a T-shirt and sneakers.

title: Default Threat Generates Fear Around Globe
description: LONDON  The bitter fiscal stalemate in Washington is producing nervous ripples from London to Bali, with increasing anxiety that the United States might actually default on a portion of its government debt, set off global financial troubles and undercut fragile economic recoveries in many countries.

title: What Happened to Recreational Sports?
description: My children have no wish to live in Sparta, and I have no desire to change that.

title: French Judges Drop Investigation Into Charges Against Sarkozy
description: PARIS  French magistrates said Monday they were dropping an investigation into charges that former President Nicolas Sarkozy had manipulated a fragile heiress into financing his 2007 campaign, removing a potential obstacle to the political return that Mr. Sarkozy is widely assumed to be planning.

title: Trends in Interregional and International Trade
description: Well, Ive just paid my first personal price for the shutdown; Im trying to finish a paper for the Walter Isard memorial volume, and discovered that the International Trade Commissions invaluable Dataweb is shut down. I know, people are missing essential medical care and more, and Im complaining about a slight academic inconvenience. But its a symptom.

title: A Painting as Talisman, as Enduring as Loved Ones Are Not
description: The goldfinch referred to in the title of Donna Tartts dazzling new novel is a charming painting of a pet bird created in 1654 by the Dutch artist Carel Fabritius, who died that year at 32, when the gunpowder arsenal in Delft exploded, destroying part of the city. His Goldfinch is considered a small but priceless masterpiece of Dutch painting.

title: On Vieques, Destination Weddings for Gay Couples
description: With growing legalization of same-sex marriage it was just a matter of time before gay couples got the travel pitch for destination weddings. Now the W Retreat & Spa-Vieques Island has a partnership with the same-sex wedding specialist Bernadette Coveney Smith, founder of the planning service 14 Stories, to offer destination wedding ceremonies for same-sex couples at the oceanfront resort on the Puerto Rican island.

title: Cheatings Surprising Thrill
description: When was the last time you cheated?

title: Blame the Deficit Scolds
description: If we have a debt-ceiling crisis in a couple of weeks, with dire economic effects, dont just blame Boehners Bunglers; you should also blame the deficit scolds  the Committee for a Responsible Peterson Budget and so on, and all the Very Serious People who have lent them support. For as Jonathan Chait reminds us, these organizations all cheered the Republicans on in 2011, as they made the first-ever use of the debt ceiling to blackmail a sitting president.

title: Lessons of the Richard Jewell Case, False Balance, and More
description: For those who follow journalism and press rights issues, heres a roundup of some interesting pieces on those topics from the past few days:

title: Record Sales for Broadways Betrayal
description: The new Broadway revival of Harold Pinters marital drama Betrayal, starring Daniel Craig (the current James Bond) and his real-life wife, Oscar winner Rachel Weisz (The Constant Gardener), set a box-office record at the Barrymore Theater last week for its first week of performances, a spokesman for the production said on Monday.

title: In Performance: Norbert Leo Butz
description: Norbert Leo Butz, with Jim Hershman on guitar, sings "Fight the Dragons" from the new Broadway musical "Big Fish," at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: Do Most Flowers Have 5 Petals?
description: Q. Most flowers I see have five petals. Is this generally true, and if so, why?

title: Spicing Up a Spring Antiques Fair
description: The architect Rafael Violy has been enlisted to help spice up the Spring Show NYC at the Park Avenue Armory, organized and founded by the Art and Antique Dealers League of America and produced by the Art Fair Company.

title: SunTrust Analyst Explains His $50 a Share Price Target for Twitter
description: It has been only four days since Twitter first took the wraps off its initial public offering prospectus. But that hasnt stopped Robert Peck from setting a high $50-a-share price target on the still-private social network.

title: Sponges Recycle Food for Reefs
description: It is known as Darwins paradox: coral reefs are rife with animal and plant life, yet exist in clear, nutrient-free waters. Where is the food coming from?

title: Support for Breast-Feeding (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Aging Gracefully (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Banning Online Comments
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: How the U.S. Is Interrogating a Qaeda Suspect
description: The United States seized a leader of Al Qaeda  Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, better known as Abu Anas al-Libi  outside his three-story house in Tripoli, Libya, on Saturday and is reportedly interrogating him in the brig of the Navy ship the San Antonio, in the Mediterranean Sea. The following covers some basic questions about his interrogation.

title: Charting Success in Battling AIDS
description: About a dozen countries hit hard by AIDS have reached a tipping point that means they are winning their battles against the disease, according to a new analysis.

title: Gatess Future Fuels Speculation as Microsoft Seeks New Chief
description: SEATTLE  Theres a question being whispered around Microsofts sprawling suburban campus: What will Bill Gates do?

title: A Partnership Built on Fostering Change
description: Bill Gates met Melinda French in the 1980s, when he was Microsofts chief executive officer and she was a young associate product manager there. They married in 1994.

title: A Disconnect in Money, Logic and Emotion
description: Stop for a minute and think about how we show the value of money. Its in nice, neat columns on our financial statements. Its in specific dollars and cents. The value of money appears to be a very clear-cut and logical part of our lives, at least on paper.

title: Walkabout: Competing Visions for Lake Tahoe; AirBnB Subpoenaed for User Data
