description: Natural Rivals Protecting Lake Tahoe, which straddles the California-Nevada border, brings the two states into play, with sometimes competing visions for the lakes future. (The New York Times)

title: Seeking Clarity on Fees at the Metropolitan Museum
description: Seeking to reconcile two contradictory realities  a friend said admission was free, and a sign said admission might or might not be $25  Ingrid Opperman stood at the entrance desk to the Metropolitan Museum of Art on a recent morning and whipped out her English-German dictionary.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Israel, Iraq, Italy and Iran.

title: Tempers Flare in Ninth as Athletics Gain the Edge
description: DETROIT  Grant Balfour, the Australian-born Oakland Athletics closer, pitches with a maniacal streak. He fires himself up with screaming bursts of R-rated patter, a bizarre habit that can be unnerving even to teammates.

title: Union Action at Scottish Refinery Could Escalate
description: LONDON  A labor action that began Monday at the huge Grangemouth refinery and petrochemical complex in Scotland could threaten the future of the unprofitable plant, analysts said.

title: How Young Mice Tell Older Ones, Get Lost
description: As nocturnal animals, mice rely on the chemical substances called pheromones to share personal information with other rodents. Age, gender and general state of health are all determined by the sniff of a whiskery nose.

title: A Hero Just Wants to Frolic With Muses, but Whats With That Evil Gnome?
description: New York City Ballet, approaching the end of its fall season at the David H. Koch Theater, has just added two new triple bills. Though one of these is a marvelous group of Balanchine story ballets, the most newsworthy item occurs in the other: the first revival in three years of Alexei Ratmanskys Namouna, a Grand Divertissement, a fascinating and delicious if obviously frustrating work that demonstrates much of the nature of Mr. Ratmanskys talent.

title: When the Best-Laid Plans Still Arent Enough
description: IM a partner and chief creative officer at Puccini Group. We conceptualize, design and operate restaurants, mainly in the hotel industry. So most of my business travel involves pitching new clients or researching cities for business development purposes. Im an architect by training and I like seeing new places and how they are designed, so I dont really mind the travel.

title: Fast Food, Not Fine Dining, Tops Expense Account List
description: IN nearly 15 years of writing this column every week, the cold hammer of oppression has come down on me from New York just once, more than 10 years ago. On a trip to San Francisco, I was too tired to find a restaurant, so I stopped at a Walgreens near Union Square, bought a cheap little canned ham and some rolls and made a sandwich back in my hotel room.

title: Alex Drexler: A Personal Quest for the Perfect White Shirt
description: Alex Drexler was not happy with the sock arrangement. Mr. Drexler was standing at his recently opened clothing store, Alex Mill, staring intently down at the socks, which were displayed unrolled, in a windowless frame, laying flat on a counter. Maybe they should be moved a few inches to the left? Or to the right?

title: Tending to Colombias Disappeared and Their Final Homes
description: The double N in the title of Rquiem NN is no misprint: It stands for sadness and, very probably, suffering. In this brief documentary, the Colombian artist Juan Manuel Echavarra chronicles the stacked tombs of anonymous victims from his countrys decades of violent internecine conflict. Each is marked with the abbreviation for no name in Spanish, but as shown here, the unknown dead enter a kind of second life through the residents of Puerto Berro, where bodies found in the nearby Magdalena River are buried.

title: Fact-Checking Hyness Take on a Reversal
description: Charles J. Hynes, Brooklyns current and perhaps future district attorney, sat down to talk politics last week with a journalist who agreed to play pretend with him.

title: A Polish History Lesson Emerges Through Song
description: The Polish cleric who would later be named St. Adalbert of Prague died gruesomely while trying to convert Prussian pagans to Christianity in 997. He ventured too close to a sacred oak grove and was attacked by a mob bearing axes and lances.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Avoiding a Candy Crush Crash, and Airbnb Subpoenaed
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Sleigh Bells, Glasser and Matana Roberts Release New Albums
description: SLEIGH BELLS

title: Tiny Particle Looms Large on Eve of Top Physics Prize
description: Its that time of year again, when physicists of a certain age, even if they do not want to admit it, are afraid to step into their morning shower for fear of missing the call from Stockholm.

title: Do Republicans Believe in Their Own Crisis?
description: You would think Republicans would be the ones trying to scare the country about the imminent expiration of the Treasurys borrowing authority. After all, theyre the ones trying to use the debt ceiling (and the government shutdown) as leverage to get their way on policies that would be laughed out of Washington at any other moment.

title: Excerpts: Four New Books on Water
description: From its history to how we use it today, four new books tackle a subject that runs through all of our lives.

title: Plenty of Water, but Little to Drink
description: Earth, the blue planet, has a lot of water. Most of the planets surface is covered with it. But less than 5 percent of that water is fresh, and much of that is locked up in ice sheets or inconveniently far underground. And it is not always most abundant where it is most needed.

title: Cardinals Even Series Behind Gem by a Rookie
description: PITTSBURGH  In the opening game of the 1912 World Series, at the Polo Grounds, a 24-year-old rookie named Jeff Tesreau carried a no-hitter into the sixth inning for the New York Giants. Bostons Tris Speaker broke it up with a triple, and Tesreau lost the game.

title: Damien Hirst Sculptures Unveiled
description: On Monday, the British artist Damien Hirst unveiled 14 monumental bronze sculptures in Doha, Qatar. The installation is considered a bold move by the Qatar Museums Authority.

title: Art, From Conception to Birth in Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar  For weeks, 14 giant balloons had been mysteriously parked in front of the Sidra Medical and Research Center, a hulking steel, glass and white ceramic building devoted to womens and childrens health that is to open on the outskirts of this city in 2015.

title: How to Slice a Global Carbon Pie?
description: STOCKHOLM  It was the middle of the night. In a matter of hours, journalists from around the world would be showing up, expecting details about the latest big United Nations climate report. But behind closed doors here, as the final wording of that document was being worked out, things were not going well.

title: Percussion Goes Global
description: Pedrito Martnez is known for his residency at Guantanamera in Manhattan. With his first album coming out this week, the challenge was to bring the energy of his performances to the studio.

title: In a Safer Brooklyn, the End Nears for an Outbound Bus
description: Spider Duncan Christopher remembers when the bus to Manhattan was always full after a performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, or BAM. There was, he recalled, a simple reason that so many passengers once piled in.

title: Pushing Boundaries of Rumba Fervor
description: It has become a familiar question backstage at festivals, concert halls or anywhere else that musicians gather on the road: Have you heard that amazing Cuban percussionist in New York City? Pedrito Martnez may not yet be known to the public, but among his peers, he is firmly established as a source of rhythmic delight and inspiration.

title: Electric Water Droplets and a Secret to Long Life (in Rats, Anyway)
description: Thanks to the federal government shutdown, the big science news last week was a sudden halt to all manner of research projects. Scientists across the country found themselves locked out of their labs as any work deemed nonessential  a designation that could seem arbitrary at times  was stopped. Academic medicine is no day at the beach, said Ellen Beckjord, an assistant professor at the University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute, to The Huffington Post. It doesnt help matters when the rug gets torn out from under you like this.

title: Microsoft: The Cloud Cant Be Slave to the Past
description: Microsoft will soon have a range of products to beef up its cloud computing business. According to the guy running the show, however, the most important thing is not what Microsoft is selling, but how it was made.

title: Motion, Motion, Stillness, Stillness
description: Stamina. Thats what Molissa Fenley became most famous for, not long after she began performing her own works as a 22-year-old choreographer in 1977. Now a month shy of 59, shes still at it, dancing with no signs of fatigue in a premiere and two reconstructions that began a run at New York Live Arts on Wednesday.

title: Checking on Android Updates for Older Phones
description: Android Updates

title: Pakistani Girl Shot by Taliban Says Militants Only Helped Amplify Her Message
description: As my colleague Adam Ellick reports, Malala Yousafzai, the young girl who was shot in the head by the Taliban a year ago, has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, to be announced on Friday.

title: New Sculptures in Doha, Qatar
description: Images of the new sculptures by Damien Hirst unveiled this week.

title: Multiethnic Style in Rego Park
description: In the latest Intersection video, we visit Rego Park, Queens, where Jamilla Galloway modernizes the pin-up look.

title: Pals, Along for a Ride
description: Jack Kerouac doesnt figure into Cloud Gate 2s production of On the Road, even though this dance is about a journey, and it does strike an unmistakable note of male bonding. Performed by this Taiwanese company in a run that began on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, the work was inspired by a trip to Yunnan, a province in southwest China.

title: Will Treasury Pay?
description: Treasury bills normally become more expensive as they come closer to their due date, but investors are paying less for bills due right after the nation hits its projected borrowing limit on Oct. 17.

title: Hotels Go to Extra Lengths for the Repeat Customer
description: When Leslie Ciminello arrives at the Hotel 1000 in Seattle, she knows milk and cereal will be waiting in her rooms refrigerator. Lactose-free milk and gluten-free cereal, that is.

title: In Times Square, a Friendly Jab at Atheists
description: If the evangelical organization Answers in Genesis was looking to take its message to a secular audience, it would be hard to do better than the heart of Times Square at noon on Monday.

title: East Coast Calls It a Night for a West Coast Game
description: The San Diego-Oakland game Sunday night on NFL Network was a scheduling rarity: a major sports event shown live in prime time on the West Coast.

title: Cuban Says He Was Taken Aback by S.E.C. Charges
description: DALLAS Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, testified on Monday that he was cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission as early as 2004 in an inquiry into an Internet search engine company and was taken aback when he turned on the news one day in 2008 and heard that the agency was charging him with insider trading.

title: A New Investment Bank, Kimberlite, to Focus on Advice
description: Wall Streets big banks advertise themselves as full-service shops, boasting that they can offer a range of services to institutional clients. But one new investment bank is taking the opposite approach.

title: At Ad Conference, Ron Burgundy and Infobesity
description: PHOENIX  HERE is a look at some highlights, sidelights and lowlights from the 2013 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which took place here from Thursday through Sunday.

title: Meeting With Israelis, Palestinian Leader Strikes a Conciliatory Tone on Peace Talks
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  In a rare meeting with Israeli politicians, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority expressed optimism on Monday that a peace agreement could be reached in the nine months allotted to the current round of negotiations, and pointedly avoided questions that proved provocative in the past.

title: Britain Replaces Minister Responsible for Scotland
description: LONDON  Less than a year before Scots vote on independence, the British cabinet minister responsible for Scotland, Michael Moore, was dismissed on Monday, apparently to give a harder edge to the campaign against the breakup of Britain.

title: A Greek Tragedy With Elements of Danger. Carlos Danger.
description: Oedipus. Othello. Weiner?

title: Billions in Debt, Detroit Faces Millions in Bills for Bankruptcy
description: DETROIT  This city is learning that it is expensive to go broke.

title: Worsening Debt Crisis Threatens Puerto Rico
description: While Detroit has preoccupied Americans with its record-breaking municipal bankruptcy, another public finance crisis on a potentially greater scale has been developing off most Americans radar screens, in Puerto Rico.

title: Powerhouse to Punch Line, N.F.C. East Is in Free Fall
description: If the N.F.C. East were a state, city or county, the federal government would declare it a disaster area and provide millions of dollars to bulldoze the refuse and start over.

title: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 4
description: In the final episode of a four-part series, "Home" comprises images submitted by New York Times readers, who show their lives in high-rises around the world.

title: Little Fear on Wall St. of Default, at Moment
description: Wall Street is showing few signs so far that it is fearing the financial panic it has been predicting should the government default on its debt.

title: More Setbacks in Deal for U.S. Tire Maker
description: Updated, 12:47 a.m. | When Apollo Tyres of India announced a $2.5 billion plan to buy Cooper Tire and Rubber in June, deal watchers believed the subcontinents economic tiger was finally beginning to roar.

title: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 3
description: In the third episode of a four-part series, "Glass" examines the recent proliferation of luxury condos and the growing segregation between the rich and poor.

title: A Short History of the Highrise: Part 2
description: In the second episode of a four-part series, "Concrete" explores how, in New York City and globally, residential high-rises and public housing attempted to foster social equality in the 20th century.

title: When Clothes No Longer Make the Man
description: As I watched the coverage of Milans fall fashion week  the penultimate of a month of fashion shows that began in New York and ended in Paris last Wednesday  I thought of Giacomo Leopardi, the great Italian poet and moralist. Leopardi fancifully portrayed fashion as deaths sister. In a dialogue between the two, Fashion explains to Death what they have in common: We both equally profit by the incessant change and destruction of things here below I was struck by the special relevance of Leopardis statement to one earthly realm in particular: the writing of fiction, where the device of disclosing the nature of character through clothes seems to be all but destroyed.

title: Garcetti, New Los Angeles Mayor, Reflects Changing City
description: LOS ANGELES  He is Jewish. He is Latino. He can break dance and play jazz piano. He speaks nearly impeccable Spanish. He has talked longingly about growing his own vegetables and maybe even raising his own chickens. He lives on this citys hip east side.

title: No Way U.S. Would Allow Debt Default? Dont Bet on It
description: The United States government is not going to default, ever.

title: A Growing Race With Big Risks
description: MARTINSBURG, W.Va.  The simplest way for the authorities to identify a mud-stained Avishek Sengupta as he lay unconscious in a hospital here last April was by the series of numerals written in a black permanent marker on his forehead: 69989.

title: A Short History of the Highrise
description: At a time when Manhattan luxury condos can cost tens of millions of dollars, residential high-rise buildings made of glass have become symbols of gargantuan excess and privilege. But the history of vertical living goes far back in time and extends around the globe  from the biblical Tower of Babel, to Arizona cliff dwellings to the Soviet Khrushchyovka towers.

title: Argentina: Surgery for President
description: President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner will undergo surgery on Tuesday to drain an accumulation of blood near her brain resulting from a recent head injury, her doctors said Monday. The doctors, Facundo Manes and Gerardo Bozovich of Fundacin Favaloro, a private hospital in Buenos Aires, said they opted for the surgery after Mrs. Kirchner was found on Sunday to have a tingling sensation and a slight loss of muscular strength in her left arm. Mrs. Kirchners spokesman had revealed Saturday that she had sustained a previously undisclosed skull trauma in August, and that doctors had told her to rest for 30 days as a result of the injury, which involves chronic bleeding between the surface of her brain and her skull.

title: Obama and the Debt
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  THE Republicans in the House of Representatives who declare that they may refuse to raise the debt limit threaten to do more than plunge the government into default. They are proposing a blatant violation of the 14th Amendment, which states that the validity of the public debt of the United States, authorized by law is sacrosanct and shall not be questioned.

title: China: Big Energy Project Planned
description: China is planning to build its largest coal gasification energy project in the western region of Xinjiang, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The $30 billion project is in the Zhundong area of the Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture, and it is expected to produce 30 billion cubic meters of gas per year, Xinhua reported Sunday, citing Xinjiang officials. The project will need an input of 90 million tons of coal per year and is expected to create 18,000 jobs, Xinhua reported. The article said coal gasification is expected to be a key sector in the countrys clean energy initiative. The coal gasification process can result in severe discharge of pollutants if it is not properly controlled.

title: Nazis, Lynching and Obamacare
description: You might think that the methodical extermination of millions of Jews by a brutal regime intent on world domination would resist appropriation as an all-purpose metaphor. You might think that genocide, of all things, would be safe from conversion into sloppy simile.

title: Iraq: Outburst of Bombings Sweeps Through Baghdad Neighborhoods
description: Twelve explosions hit Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad within 40 minutes on Monday, killing at least 37 people and wounding more than 100, security and medical officials said. In one attack in the Husseiniya area in northern Baghdad, a homemade bomb exploded near a restaurant, followed by a car-bomb blast in a nearby parking garage. The two explosions killed eight people and wounded 22.

title: Why the Debt Ceiling Matters
description: The word we keep hearing is catastrophe.

title: Senate Leaders Mull Raising Debt Ceiling in Challenge to House
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democratic leaders will move forward this week on a measure to raise the governments legal borrowing limit without any policy strings attached, answering House Republicans taunts that Democrats would not force their politically vulnerable senators to cast that difficult vote.

title: Leading a Title Bid With a Lifted Spirit
description: ATLANTA  The most joy Angel McCoughtry derived from the 2012 season was not leading the W.N.B.A. in scoring or steering the Atlanta Dream to the playoffs, but simply that it ended.

title: Politicians for Sale
description: Nearly four years after its controversial ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court is once again taking up the issue of the regulation of money in politics. This time, the risk to the integrity of elected officials, and public confidence in government, may be even greater.

title: The International Fallout
description: The Republican-induced government shutdown and the partys threats to create another crisis next week over the debt ceiling are causing harm internationally as well as at home. They are undermining American leadership in Asia, impeding the functioning of the national security machinery, upsetting global markets and raising questions about the political dysfunction of a country that has long been the worlds democratic standard-bearer.

title: A Breakthrough on Iraqi Visas
description: Even as the shutdown of the federal government dragged on last week and it seemed bipartisan cooperation had become an obsolete relic, members of Congress managed to honor a moral obligation. They rescued an important program that extends visas to Iraqi translators who risked their lives to assist American troops during the Iraq war and now face threats of retribution.

title: Uighurs in China Say Bias Is Growing
description: KASHGAR, China  Job seekers looking for opportunities in this ancient oasis town in Chinas far western Xinjiang region would seem to have ample options, based on a quick glance at a local help-wanted Web site. The Kashgar Cultural Center has an opening for an experienced dance choreographer, the prefectural Communist Party office is hiring a driver and nearby Shule County needs an archivist.

title: Supreme Court Ponders Suits in Stanford Fraud Over Securities That Never Existed
description: WASHINGTON  On the first day of its new term, the Supreme Court heard arguments in a case arising from one of the most brazen frauds in recent history, the $7 billion Ponzi scheme orchestrated by R. Allen Stanford.

title: Veto Halts Bill for Jury Duty by Noncitizens in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Breaking with Democrats in the State Legislature, Gov. Jerry Brown vetoed a bill on Monday that would have made California the first state to allow immigrants who are not citizens to serve on juries, saying that the responsibility should come only with citizenship.

title: Governors Letter to the California Assembly
description: Gov. Jerry Brown of California told members of the California State Assembly that he was returning without his signature a bill on allowing noncitizens to serve on juries.

title: For a Skilled Fund-Raiser, Lhota Looks No Further Than Home
description: As his second bid for mayor swung into gear, Rudolph W. Giuliani had a familiar problem. A Republican in an overwhelmingly liberal-leaning city, facing a Democratic incumbent who had left him gasping for campaign dollars four years earlier, Mr. Giuliani needed to do more than just galvanize voters weary of crime, squeegee men and scandal at City Hall. He needed money.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 7
Health Exchange Delays Tied to Software Crash in Early Rush
description: WASHINGTON  The technical problems that have hampered enrollment in the online health insurance exchanges resulted from the failure of a major software component, designed by private contractors, that crashed under the weight of millions of users last week, federal officials said Monday.

title: Rescuing Citys Aging Blades, a Member of a Dying Trade
description: ROME  Carmine Mainellas calling card is his call. Arrotino, arrotino, he shouted on a warm September morning, strolling with an easy gait on a sidewalk in central Rome, announcing his trade: a sharpener of knives, scissors, meat-slicing blades and sundry metal items that have lost their edge.

title: Dull Knives? Dwindling Service in Rome
description: Romes knife sharpeners are becoming a dying breed as restaurants cast aside dull cutlery instead of repairing it, or rent knives instead of owning them.

title: Corrections: October 8, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bang For Your Buck
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Heres an interesting concept for aspiring puzzle constructors: the best way to cram as much theme material as possible into a grid is apparently to leave some of it out.

title: Shareholder Adviser Plans to Escalate Fight Over Oracle Chiefs Pay
description: A group that advises several union pension funds plans to ratchet up the fight against Oracle Corporations pay practices, especially for its founder, Lawrence J. Ellison.

title: Navajo Leader Drops His Support for Slaughter of Wild Horses on the Reservation
description: PHOENIX  Under pressure by animal welfare groups and many of his own people, the president of the Navajo Nation, Ben Shelly, has reversed his stance on horse slaughtering, saying he will no longer support it and will order the temporary suspension of the roundups of feral horses on the reservation.

title: Transit Agency Expands Real-Time Bus Information to Manhattan
description: New York Citys traffic can appear to be an ungovernable force  understood, perhaps, but never fully tamed.

title: Charges Filed Against Mother of Dead Boy in Brooklyn
description: Anna Thomas had no criminal history, no interactions with child protective services and no history of mental illness, the authorities said. There was nothing that might provide an immediate explanation of what the police said was the killing of her 19-month-old son.

title: Drinking on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Suicide and Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: The Plotting Before the Shutdown
description: To the Editor:

title: Berlusconi, Isolated
description: To the Editor:

title: Is There Any Hope for New York City Transit?
A Childs Fear Come True
description: To the Editor:

title: A New York Ad Campaign to Build Girls Self-Esteem
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazils Leader Asks Canada to Explain Its Spying
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils president, Dilma Rousseff, crisply demanded an explanation on Monday from Canada over revelations that a Canadian intelligence agency had spied on Brazils mining and energy ministry and a top Brazilian diplomat, a development contributing to festering resentment in Brazil over the targeting of the nation by foreign intelligence agencies.

title: Jesuit Campus to End Coverage for Elective Abortions
description: LOS ANGELES  The trustees of Loyola Marymount University, a Jesuit university in Los Angeles, voted Monday to eliminate coverage for elective abortions from the health care plans offered to faculty and staff members in 2014.

title: Mother of Baby Hope Is Identified, Police Say
description: More than two decades after the girl who would come to be known as Baby Hope was found dead in a cooler along a New York highway, a law enforcement official said on Monday that her mother had been identified.

title: A G.O.P. Moderate in the Middle ... of a Jam
description: WASHINGTON  As a moderate House Republican, Representative Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania by definition typically finds himself somewhere near the middle when the majority of his colleagues veer well to the right.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 8, 2013
description: When youre in this business of governing, sometimes you must step up and govern.

title: A Humbled Knick Tries to Fit In, Hoping to Avoid Moving on Yet Again
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Chris Douglas-Roberts was challenging his physical limits when he tried to draw a charge on Tyson Chandler at Mondays practice. Douglas-Roberts lost.

title: Patrice Chreau, Opera, Stage and Film Director, Dies at 68
description: Patrice Chreau, a director whose iconoclastic theater, opera and film productions sometimes offered broad social critiques that made them both provocative and influential, died on Monday in Paris. He was 68.

title: Robert C. Stebbins, Chronicler of Western Reptiles and Amphibians, Dies at 98
description: Robert C. Stebbins, who was considered by many to be the pre-eminent authority on the lungless salamander, the barking tree frog, the northern Pacific rattlesnake and hundreds of other amphibians and reptiles of the North American West, died on Sept. 23 in Eugene, Ore. He was 98.

title: 100 Specialists to Carry Out Tricky Syria Disarmament
description: One hundred specialists drawn from the United Nations and the organization that polices the global ban on chemical weapons will be sent to Syria over the next eight months to help dismantle and destroy its roughly 1,000-ton arsenal, an extremely hazardous task that has never been tried and that could fail without Syrias cooperation, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Monday.

title: United States Lagging in Skills
description: United States lags behind other countries in basic math skills and  working with technology.

title: Video Game Review, Beyond: Two Souls
description: Quantic Dream's newest cinematic game for Playstation 3 explores the action-packed emotional journey of a young woman with a mysterious gift.

title: A Bit of Mystery, a Bit of Hollywood
description: David Cage, the writer and director of Beyond: Two Souls, a thriller released on Tuesday for the PlayStation 3, starring Ellen Page and Willem Dafoe, is among the most divisive figures in video games. Thats partly because of his outlandish pronouncements about the future of the medium, like when he said last month during a lecture to the British Academy of Film and Television that developing an algorithmic Martin Scorsese  artificially intelligent software that imitated Mr. Scorseses camera style and recreated it on demand  would be an interesting way to improve video game storytelling.

title: Word of the Day | immolate
description: immolate \i-m-lat\ verb

title: When the Treasury Runs Out of Cash
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Fourth Motorcyclist Is Charged in Attack on Driver of S.U.V.
description: A fourth motorcyclist was chargedon Mondaynight in the recent attack on the driver of a sport utility vehicle after a high-speed chase that was caught on camera.

title: Smith Saves the Day and Comes of Age
description: ATLANTA  It was all there for the Jets, and then it almost wasnt. Their lead, which had grown to 13 points almost midway through the fourth quarter. Their discipline, which had improved after penalty-filled disasters the previous two weeks. Their sense of accomplishment, which comes from watching a rookie quarterback recover from the worst game of his brief career by delivering the best one.

title: For Shoppers, Next Level of Instant Gratification
description: All the worlds a shopping cart.

title: To Lift Hong Kong Park, Disney Deploys Iron Man
description: HONG KONG  Iron Man has proved his might at the Chinese box office. Now Disney is betting that the Marvel superhero has enough muscle to complete a turnaround at its underperforming theme park here  a task of crucial importance as the company hurtles toward the opening of a mega-resort in Shanghai.

title: With a Ninth-Inning Home Run, the Rays Stave Off Elimination Again
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Boston Red Sox had thoroughly dominated their American League division series with the Tampa Bay Rays, standing a victory from a sweep on Monday night at Tropicana Field. The Rays, meanwhile, were trying to avoid a third early postseason exit since their run to the World Series in 2008.

title: Share Your Advice for Young Women in the Workplace
description: Adam Bryant has interviewed hundreds of executives during more than four years of writing Corner Office, his semiweekly Q. & A. feature on leadership and management. This week, in a special installment of Corner Office in the Sunday Business section, Mr. Bryant interviews four executives about being a woman in a position of power. In these conversations, the executives explore the idea of gender and leadership in the workplace.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 7:45 P.M. (Cinemax) THE LOVELY BONES (2009) Mark Wahlberg, above, and Rachel Weisz play the grieving parents of Susie Salmon (Saoirse Ronan), a 14-year-old who has gone missing in 1970s suburbia, in this adaptation of the best seller by Alice Sebold, directed by Peter Jackson. Stanley Tucci is the neighbor who knows what happened. As a pictorial artifact The Lovely Bones is gorgeous, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. It pulses and blooms and swells with bright hues and strange vistas. But in the end, he added, the film  which focuses on Susie as she hovers in the in-between and tries to bring her killer to justice  shows less audacity than the novel and too much art.

title: Moving Back to (Their) Town
description: I was having a drink one afternoon recently at the sunny end of the bar at the Kettle of Fish celebrating my recent move to New York after a 30-year absence, telling the story of how that bar, in its incarnation as the Lions Head, had become my regular haunt years ago.

title: News Quiz | October 8, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Dodgers Eliminate Braves With a Two-Run Shot in the Eighth
description: LOS ANGELES  As if the $235 million payroll, and the decision to refrain from fully investing in Manager Don Mattingly, left any questions about the Steinbrenner-like expectations of the Los Angeles Dodgers, they issued another proclamation Monday.

title: Cuomos Office Is Said to Rein In Ethics Board He Created
description: ALBANY  When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo created the Commission to Investigate Public Corruption in early July, he promised a muscular response to bad behavior by legislators that included allegations of bribe taking, favor trading and embezzlement.

title: 2 Companies in Web Video Are Expected to Merge
description: In another sign that the world of digital video production may be entering an era of consolidation, two significant participants in the market, Alloy Digital and Break Media, are expected to announce on Tuesday that they will merge.

title: U.S. Adults Fare Poorly in a Study of Skills
description: American adults lag well behind their counterparts in most other developed countries in the mathematical and technical skills needed for a modern workplace, according to a study released Tuesday.

title: In Berlin, Musical Support for Rights in Russia
description: BERLIN  After weeks of insisting that the star-studded To Russia With Love concert he organized in Berlin was not aimed against any individual, government or law, the violinist Gidon Kremer allowed the music to speak.

title: Record-Setting Diamond Sale Shows Appetite for Luxury in Asia
description: HONG KONG  As investors fret about the budget standoff in the United States and slowing growth in Asia, the confidence of the worlds superrich to splurge on top gems and works of art appears intact, judging by a string of Sothebys auctions in Hong Kong in the past five days.

title: Test Yourself | History, Oct. 8, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Summer Camp for Olympic Snowboarders
description: In Summer Camp for the Winter Olympics, Joe Drape writes about summer training for the Winter Olympics.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Gives Details on Plan to Cut 10,000 Jobs
description: PARIS  The French-American telecommunications equipment maker announced on Tuesday details of a major restructuring plan that includes 10,000 job cuts worldwide over the next two years.

title: Putting a Speed Limit on the Stock Market
description: When Brad Katsuyama was running the U.S. trading desk for the Royal Bank of Canada, his clients would send in orders every day, but every day, when Katsuyama went to buy or sell, something would go wrong. When he wanted to buy, offers to sell shares would suddenly vanish, and the price of the stock would shoot up. When he wanted to sell, the same thing would happen in reverse. I started to realize that, day in and day out, I was getting screwed, Katsuyama told me recently.

title: Photographing by Santas Rules
description: Its 80 degrees in New York and not yet Columbus Day, but walk into some convenience stores and you will already find plastic mistletoe and reindeer competing for shelf space with skeletons and Halloween candy.

title: Is It Offensive for Sports Teams to Use Native American Names and Mascots?
description: Native American names and symbols have long been popular for all types of American sports teams at the professional, college and high school levels. Think of the Cleveland Indians, Atlanta Braves and Washington Redskins.

title: Lucks Effect on Colts Transcends His Statistics
description: As a rookie, Andrew Luck led one of the great N.F.L. turnarounds, taking a Colts team that was 2-14 without him in 2011 to 11-5 with him in 2012. This year, Luck has been even better, and Indianapolis, with a 13-3 record in its last 16 games and with recent victories over San Francisco and Seattle, has become a serious Super Bowl contender.

title: New York Today: Turned Away
description: Updated 12:03 p.m. | And on the seventh day, Horst and Kristine Sahlmann of Hamburg, Germany, attempted to visit Grants Tomb.

title: Daily Report: As Microsoft Seeks a Chief, Speculation on Gatess Future
description: There is a question being whispered around Microsofts sprawling suburban Seattle campus, Nick Wingfield reports: What will Bill Gates do?

title: Pacific Rim Leaders Urge New Focus on Global Trade Talks
description: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  Leaders at the Pacific Rim economic summit meeting declared at the end of their two-day meeting here Tuesday that the global trade talks known as the Doha round were at an impasse and urged trade ministers, due to meet here in December, to get negotiations back on track.

title: What Is the Higgs?
description: Two physicists, Peter Higgs of Britain and Franois Englert of Belgium, on Tuesday won the Nobel Prize in Physics. But just what is the Higgs Boson?

title: Still Crazy After All These Years, Two Ways
description: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: For Nobel, They Can Thank the God Particle
description: The God particle became the prize particle on Tuesday.

title: Study Suggests Fact-Checking Influences Political Behavior
description: The rise of professional fact-checking in recent years has brought both praise and criticism. One of the more common laments, even from fans of fact-checking, is that it has little effect  that politicians judged to be untruthful ignore the judgment against them and pay little price from voters.

title: Close but Not Quite
description: Its commendable to add nuance or texture to our prose with a word thats slightly out of the ordinary. Just be sure the word you pick is the right one, used the right way. Its not enough to be in the general vicinity. And a misstep is all the more glaring if the word is unusual.

title: In Performance: Norbert Leo Butz of Big Fish
description: In the new Broadway musical Big Fish, a stage adaptation of the 2003 Tim Burton film, Norbert Leo Butz plays Edward Bloom, a father whose wildly inventive tales about meeting witches and befriending giants come to life on stage. In this video, Mr. Butz, with Jim Hershman on guitar, sings the number Fight the Dragons, in which he explains his love of storytelling to his son. The show, with music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa and book by John August, is at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: A Woman to Serve on Twitters Board? Here Are 25
description: There has been quite a kerfuffle over Twitters lack of gender diversity at the top, including my Saturday New York Times story about the issue and a stream of tweets in response from Dick Costolo, its chief executive.

title: A Debutante With Lesbian Moms: How Does She Come Out?
description: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Britain Expands Program to Spur Home Purchases
description: LONDON  The British government on Tuesday began the second phase of a new program aimed at igniting home buying, in part by guaranteeing up to 15 percent of a mortgage loan.

title: Today in Small Business: The Enormous Benefits of Obamacare
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: A Worrisome Calm on Wall Street
description: Wall Street has predicted financial panic should the government default on its debt, but markets so far are showing few signs of fear, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. We all tell ourselves, This is something that is not going to happen, said David Coard, the head of fixed-income trading at the Williams Capital Group.

title: Take Me to the Bad Old Bronx
description: Dear Diary:

title: Default Deniers
description: You knew this would happen, didnt you? As we close in on the debt limit, with Obama insistent that he will not give in to hostage-taking, there is a growing chorus of voices on the right insisting that the whole debt limit thing is scare tactics from the administration, and that hitting the limit will be no big deal.

title: Nest Labs Reinvents the Smoke Alarm
description: The loud, sensitive smoke alarm is probably the least-loved electronic device in your household, but it is also an appliance that could get you killed if its not working properly. That is why Nest Labs, a start-up led by former Apple engineers, saw an opportunity to reinvent it.

title: I.M.F. Cuts Forecasts for Global Expansion, and Warns U.S. on Its Stalemate
description: WASHINGTON  Emerging economies have cooled off. Europe remains in the doldrums. The United States is facing fiscal uncertainty, and its powerful central bank is contemplating easing its extraordinary stimulus efforts, with potentially global ramifications.

title: Karzai Lashes Out at the U.S. for Its Role and Focus in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With the United States weighing a complete withdrawal from Afghanistan by the end of next year, President Hamid Karzai offered a stinging critique of the American-led campaign here, saying that coalition forces had inflicted needless suffering on Afghans.

title: The Midterms: Sam Wang Weighs In
description: My Princeton colleague Sam Wang, one of the best poll aggregators out there  and one of the people who, if you were reading him, made you smarter than any of Romneys advisors  takes on the PPP poll of selected Congressional districts. His conclusion:

title: European Lawmakers Reject Tight Restrictions on E-Cigarettes
description: STRASBOURG, France  The European Parliament on Tuesday scrapped proposals by health officials that electronic cigarettes be tightly regulated as medical devices, setting the stage for a debate in the United States over the extent of regulation.

title: De Keersmaekers Famous Rosas Dance Gets the Fan Treatment
description: The movements may be simple, but dance fans still cant get enough. Now, a part of Anne Teresa de Keersmaekers seminal Rosas Danst Rosas, which she created in 1983 for her new four-woman company, has been replicated by more than 1,500 people all over the world, as part of a project to celebrate the works 30th anniversary.

title: Inquiry Into Illicit Online Marketplace Extends to Britain
description: LONDON  Four men arrested in Britain on drug charges are being investigated over their suspected ties to Silk Road, an online marketplace that has been linked to narcotics sales and other illegal activity, British officials said on Tuesday.

title: Concert for the Opposition
description: BERLIN  At the end of the evening, Daniel Barenboim and Martha Argerich sat down at the piano together and played Grand Rondeau in A-minor. The crowd in the chamber hall of the Berlin Philharmonic went wild. One does not see this kind of thing often: two world-famous pianists laughing playfully as they jostle over access to the pedals and then launching into an intimate, almost sentimental, rendition of a piece. Nor will anyone else see this performance again: The two times Barenboim performed during the Monday evening concert, the video operators in the room shut off their cameras.

title: 1931: Leading Paris Couturiers
description: Offering a rare insight into the life of leading Parisian couturiers, The New York Herald from May 3, 1931 published gravures of Jean Patou enjoying a windy ride in a speed boat (with his beret surprisingly in place) and Lucien Lelong, schussing down a slope.

title: Icahn Secures Seats on Nuances Board
description: Strike another victory for activist investors, and the billionaire Carl C. Icahn in particular.

title: Citys Charter Schools Fear Having de Blasio for a Landlord
description: Charter schools in New York City have flourished over the past decade, attracting donations from Wall Street, praise from leaders in business and government, and free real estate from the city.

title: South Korea Says North Restarted Nuclear Reactor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas main intelligence agency confirmed on Tuesday that North Korea has restarted a Soviet-era nuclear reactor that has been used to obtain plutonium for bombs, according to South Korean legislators.

title: Nuclear Power and the Shutdown
description: Try as they may, Tea Party Republicans who triggered the shutdown cannot disguise the fact that it is disrupting important government activities.

title: Eric Garcetti Takes the Stage
description: The new mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, connected with Mexican-Americans at a recent celebration in the city.

title: Genes Suggest European Women at Root of Ashkenazi Family Tree
description: Over the last 15 years geneticists have identified links between the worlds Jewish communities that point to a common ancestry as well as a common religion. Still, the origin of one of the most important Jewish populations, the Ashkenazim of Central and Eastern Europe, has remained a mystery.

title: After the I.V.F., the Wait
description: I feel a twinge on my right side. Am I pregnant, or is it just gas? Two weeks of thinking about whether the embryo inside of me has implanted is driving me crazy.

title: Back-to-Work Day at H.P.
description: Memo to Hewlett-Packard employees: Its o.k. to come back in.

title: The Journey to Europe
description: African migrants, trying to reach Europe, flood the tiny island of Lampedusa.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Dont Teach to the Test
By Design | At Christies, the Legacy of a 70s Decorator Hits the Auction Block
description: As the estate of a favorite client of the 70s American decorator Michael Taylor comes up for auction, a former protge recalls her boss.

title: Dead 22 Years, Baby Hope Has a Name Again
description: As the officers tacked up posters and handed out fliers last July, a van with loudspeakers inched through Washington Heights, announcing yet another attempt by the police to dredge up anything resembling a clue in an emotionally wrenching case from 1991: the little girl whose emaciated and bound body had been left in a cooler by a highway in Upper Manhattan.

title: The Iditarod Trail by Snowmobile
description: The fourth checkpoint on the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, Alaskas remote Winterlake Lodge will offer visitors a chance to follow the historic trail for 35 miles, this time by snowmobile.

title: After Having Sloppy Start, Smith and the Jets Look Sharper
description: ATLANTA  As midnight approached, Geno Smith buttoned his blue dress shirt, knotted a red tie and slipped into dark slacks. Before reaching for the blue sport coat in his locker, Smith, the Jets first-year quarterback, sat on a stool and covered his feet with sweat socks and white athletic shoes.

title: Debt Ceiling Blackmail, Then and Now
description: Just to follow up on my post yesterday, in which I argued that whats unprecedented about the looming debt-ceiling stand-off is the implausibility-cum-unknowability of the House Republican ask, not the idea of a debt ceiling ask itself, heres Townhalls Kevin Glass with an account of how the ceiling was raised during Ronald Reagans second term:

title: Soundtrack for a Debt Showdown  In the Red, Got No Green and Im Feeling So Blue
description: Expanded slightly, 12:14 p.m. | As some readers know, Im a performing songwriter in spare moments. While going through a rough patch a couple of decades ago, I wrote a tune that could, sadly, serve as a soundtrack to the disgraceful Washington gridlock over the budget, the debt ceiling, and Americas fiscal future. Its called Bills, Bills, Bills and heres a new video built around the version that will be on my first album, coming later this fall:

title: A Guide to Affordable Dental Care
description: Finding affordable dental services can be daunting for aging parents and a headache for family members coordinating their care. Retirees, after all, often lose dental insurance after leaving the workplace, and Medicare does not cover cleanings, fillings or dentures. Dental coverage for adults on Medicaid varies broadly, depending on the state.

title: World Monuments Fund Lists Vista of the New Jersey Palisades as Endangered
description: The World Monuments Fund has listed the Cloisters in Manhattan and the Palisades in New Jersey on its annual list of endangered cultural sites, citing the construction of a new corporate headquarters in Englewood Cliffs that is to rise above the tree line as a threat to the view from the museum across the Hudson.

title: Supreme Court Again Weighs Spending Limits in Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed prepared to strike down a part of federal campaign finance law left intact by its decision in Citizens United in 2010: overall limits on direct contributions from individuals to candidates.

title: Recent Deals Show Freer Capitalism Is Taking Hold in Japan
description: Japan Inc. is breaking some deep-rooted taboos.

title: School Bus Drivers in Boston Stop Work, Surprising the City
description: BOSTON  School bus drivers infuriated parents and city officials on Tuesday morning with a surprise work stoppage that left thousands of the citys 57,000 schoolchildren stranded at home or at bus stops.

title: The Gun Report: October 8, 2013
description: After years of sponsorship, NBC Sports has decided it will not be a sponsor of the nations largest gun trade show in January, Media Matters has reported. At the Shooting Hunting and Outdoor Trade Show, or theSHOT Show, as it is known, gun manufacturers showcase their latest products, including an array of assault rifles, tactical shotguns and pistols with high-capacity magazines. Its organizer, the National Shooting Sports Foundation, calls it a powerful display of industry unity and its resolve to meet any challenge affecting the right to make, sell and own firearms.

title: An Indians Maiden Visit to Pakistan
description: I traveled to Pakistan two weeks ago as one of five Indians who were invited to meet with six Pakistani leaders from various walks of life as part of an effort by the Asia Society and the Jinnah Institute in Pakistan to continue cross-border dialogue. Meanwhile, the Indian and Pakistani governments had, once again, been engaged in their characteristic rhetoric on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Image of the Day: October 8
U.S. Warned by Japanese Over Perils of a Default
description: TOKYO  Japans finance minister urged the United States on Tuesday to avoid a default that could cast the global economy into turmoil and hurt the value of Japans enormous holdings of United States Treasury bonds, a day after similar warnings from China, which has an even larger stake in American debt.

title: How Googles Search Changes Affect Small Businesses
description: Google recently switched to something known as secure search, limiting the data that can be seen using its analytics. This means Web site owners and managers can no longer see the string of words used by an individual to find their site in a search, which could have a profound effect on marketing efforts. Knowing how customers found them helps business owners optimize their sites so that they rank higher in search results.

title: What Do You Look for in Modern Translation?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Dana Stevens write about what they look for in modern translation.

title: Lift Threats, Obama Insists, Spurning Talks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama intensified his pressure on House Republicans on Tuesday, calling on them to lift these threats from our families and our businesses as the federal government remained shuttered into a second week and the possibility that the United States would default on its debts grew closer.

title: Indian Workers Strike Over Plan to Split State
description: NEW DELHI  Striking workers shut off electricity and cellphone service to a large section of the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh on Tuesday, as hundreds of thousands of government employees protested a decision to divide the state into two parts.

title: U.S. Upholds Ban on Some Samsung Products
description: In another blow to Samsung Electronics in its continuing patent disputes with Apple, the Obama administration has decided to uphold a ban requested by Apple of some of Samsungs mobile products.

title: No Offense to Tourists: Taxi Jeopardy! Is Easier
description: For three years, Jeopardy!, the popular game show, has been running quiz-like advertisements in New York Citys yellow taxis, offering passengers clues and prompting them to answer in the form of a question the way contestants on television do. Much like the experience of watching Jeopardy! from home, theres no buzzer to ring or jackpot to win. Whether or not you know the answer, it will appear on-screen a few seconds after each clue.

title: European Officials Consulted Business Leaders on Trade Pact
description: LONDON  Long before trade negotiations began with the United States this summer, European officials were consulting with business leaders from both sides of the Atlantic on how to structure a free-trade pact.

title: Imperfect Intelligence Said to Hinder U.S. Raid on Militant in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The reinforcements have already started arriving, armed extremists posted along the coastline and the rest of town, guarding against any more attacks on their stronghold, witnesses say. People suspected of spying for the enemy have been rounded up and arrested, residents say, adding to a sense that the worst is far from over.

title: In Store | Sleek, Seductive Italian Furniture Makes Its Way Stateside
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Opinion Section Is Expanding
description: Were very happy to announce an important expansion of the Editorial Departments opinion offerings, to coincide with the IHTs reincarnation as the International New York Times next week.

title: Mementos of James Coburn Up for Auction
description: On Tuesday, Paddle8 began an auction of 59 items from the home of the actor James Coburn, who died in 2002, and his first wife, Beverly.

title: Boehner Calls for Spending Negotiations
description: John A. Boehner, the Republican speaker of the House, and members of the House majority urge Democrats to negotiate to end a spending standoff that has shuttered the government for eight days.

title: A Nuisance Can Be Tasty, Too
description: Foraging for weeds, and cooking with those forgotten or unloved specimens, has grown in popularity in recent years.

title: New Ingredients Sprout From the Cracks
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Chicory is best known to suburbanites as a destroyer of lawns and gardens. But when Linda Hezel, a former nurse practitioner, spotted the enormous weed growing inside one of her large raised garden beds, she chose not to uproot it.

title: Turkey Lifts Longtime Ban on Head Scarves in State Offices
description: ISTANBUL  The government on Tuesday lifted a ban on head scarves for female workers in state offices, ending a longstanding restriction that has polarized Turkish society.

title: Waiting for the Markets Call to Reason
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: A Transcendence Grounded in Austere Contemplation
description: The New Ecstatic, Sarah Skaggss latest evening of work and newest piece, seen at Danspace Project on Saturday, is a change for this choreographer. Known for creating dances with high-energy explosiveness, Ms. Skaggs has become more contemplative, more deliberate. She has slowed things down.

title: Lhota, Speaking to Corporate Leaders, Harshly Criticizes de Blasio
description: Joseph J. Lhota unleashed a full-throated attack on his chief rival for the New York City mayoralty on Tuesday, deriding Bill de Blasio as an inexperienced and smooth-talking naf with little understanding of what it takes to run a government.

title: Passing the Time Until He Arrives
description: You think Waiting for Godot is depressing? Wait till you hear it in Yiddish.

title: Walking on Sydneys Wild Side
description: The blue-tongued lizard eyed me suspiciously but remained still long enough for photographs, while a kookaburra laughed and a diminutive wallaby rustled in the brush. Rock engravings of fish and kangaroos marked ceremonial sites of Aboriginal ancestors. Scented forests of eucalyptus and gum trees shaded our path over sandstone and thin topsoil, classic Outback topography surprisingly concealed on the outskirts of Sydney.

title: The Meaning of Mountains
description: Pemba Gyalje Sherpa was part of the group of climbers who, in early August 2008, began the last leg of their summit of K2, a mountain in the heart of the Karakoram Range in northern Pakistan. At 28,251 feet, K2 is second in height only to Everest, but its peak is even steeper, colder and more desolate than its Himalayan sister.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Ghosts of Amsterdam

title: They Put Art in the Game
description: The story of the Bucks old basketball floor, which was created by the Pop artist Robert Indiana and is currently an installation of 260 eight-foot panels at the Milwaukee City Hall.

title: Hecklers Greet Hynes Effort to Renew Bid for Re-election
description: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, officially kicked off his reinvigorated bid for a seventh term on Tuesday morning amid questions about the viability of his campaign, which he is running as the Republican and Conservative nominee after losing the Democratic nomination last month.

title: The Non-Paparazzi View of Daniel Radcliffe
description: The Italian photographer Luca Locatelli, whose images of Daniel Radcliffe appeared in this past weekends magazine, describes the experience of being part of what the paparazzi are focused on.

title: Rules of Style | Ferragamos New Leading Lady on Flying in Style and Dressing Like a Star
description: Hollywoods leading ladies and men have been wearing shoes by Salvatore Ferragamo since before the invention of talkies. In 1954, Audrey Hepburn famously wore suede Ferragamo ballet flats in Sabrina, and more recently, Drew Barrymore and Nicole Kidman have appeared in films wearing Ferragamo footwear. The latest ingenue to be associated with the brand, Kaya Scodelario, was cast by Ferragamo itself. The 21-year-old actress, best known for her role in the British TV series Skins, recently embarked on a whirlwind adventure, traveling from her hometown of London to Florence, Los Angeles and Shanghai to shoot Walking Stories, an online-only romantic comedy that Ferragamo will release in eight parts this month, every Tuesday and Thursday beginning today, at ferragamo.com. We literally went around the world in two weeks, she said.

title: Obamacare  With or Without Quotation Marks
description: A Times reader, Tom Bird, of East Lansing, Mich., raised a timely issue, given all thats happening in Washington. He wrote that other news organizations, including The Associated Press, are putting the expression Obamacare in quotation marks, signifying that it is not a neutral expression, but instead is political rhetoric that is being used in a partisan way. And he added, When will The Times wake up?

title: Key Moments From the Hearing on Campaign Contributions
description: The Supreme Court seemed prepared to strike down a part of federal campaign finance law setting overall limits on direct contributions from individuals to candidates. The Timess Adam Liptak offered analysis of the arguments.

title: Obama on Raising the Debt Ceiling
description: A week into the government shutdown, President Obama argued to raise the debt ceiling and said health care shouldnt have anything to do with keeping the government open.

title: Butter Tasting
description: Melissa Clark and a panel of dining connoisseurs, including Frank Bruni and Florence Fabricant, sample 13 different kinds of cultured butter.

title: The N.F.L.'s Endangered Species
description: The pass-happy N.F.L. has a problem. Its quarterbacks are taking a beating.

title: Spreading Culture
description: Diane St. Clair started making her extraordinary butter  the butter that Thomas Keller serves at Per Se and the French Laundry  after breaking her leg in an accident with a team of draft horses on her farm in Vermont.

title: Video Sports of The Times: The N.F.L.s Endangered Species
Shutdown Denies Death and Burial Benefits to Families of 4 Dead Soldiers
description: WASHINGTON  The families of four soldiers killed in Afghanistan last weekend will not receive death benefits or the money to pay for their funerals because of the government shutdown.

title: NewsHour Ex-Anchors to Cede Ownership
description: Jim Lehrer and Robert MacNeil have been closely linked with the PBS NewsHour since the shows beginnings in 1975, for many years as its co-anchors and, since 1981, as the shows owners and co-producers through MacNeil/Lehrer Productions.

title: David vs. Goliath
description: Shortly after 9 p.m. on a dark October night in 1863, four intrepid Confederates launched one of the most daring attacks of the Civil War. Nestled into the David, a cigarshaped vessel 50 feet long and barely 5 feet in diameter, they steamed toward one of the Union Navys mightiest warships, the New Ironsides, on blockade duty in Charleston harbor. Each member of the crew  Capt. William T. Glassell, the pilot Walker Cannon, the assistant engineer J. H. Toombs and the seaman James Sullivan  carried a shotgun and revolver. But the real damage they intended was to come from a 134-pound explosive charge of at the end of a 30-foot spar extended from the prow of their vessel.

title: $4 Million Grant to Help Rebrand Lincoln Center Institute
description: The Lincoln Center Institute, Lincoln Centers educational arm since 1975, has received a $4 million grant from the Sherman Fairchild Foundation to support a rebranding effort and new programs.

title: Beyond the Rhetoric: Researching and Writing About the Health Care Law
Mourning Syrian Soldier, but Not Doubting a War
description: DAQAQA, Syria  Under a silvery canopy of olive trees, men and women crowded around the grave of a 24-year-old lieutenant in the Syrian Army. As a commander handed the dead mans mother a Syrian flag folded into a neat triangle, the scrape of branches shifting in the wind could be heard over quiet sobs and prayers.

title: Second Team of Weapons Experts to Head to Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The organization responsible for ensuring the destruction of Syrias arsenal of chemical weapons said Tuesday that it was sending a second team of experts to the country, as the forces of President Bashar al-Assad and rebels seeking his ouster battled over strategic swaths of territory.

title: The Elm
description: Inside Paul Liebrandts restaurant in the King & Grove hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Living in Canarsie, Brooklyn
description: This southern Brooklyn neighborhood is still recovering from the twin blows of the mortgage crisis and Hurricane Sandy.

title: A Fearless Palate for the Drop-In Crowd
description: There were more luxurious fine-dining restaurants in New York than Corton, which closed this summer after nearly five years in TriBeCa, but very few that could deliver as many high-wire thrills. Paul Liebrandts cooking challenged you to pay attention. The precisely calibrated flavors might be contained in a single mouthful, or might unscroll themselves as you ate your way across several plates. The harmonies were multilayered, and so were the rewards.

title: In Canarsie, a Coalition of the Tried-and-True
description: To walk or drive around Canarsie, a quiet suburblike peninsula on Brooklyns south shore, you might not immediately guess at the recent struggles its residents have endured. The streets are relatively clean, the rows of one- and two-family homes often well maintained, the living-room-carpet-size lawns conscientiously mowed.

title: The Shadow of the Sequester
description: A final point on the debt ceiling, before I turn to less exasperating subjects: One of the underappreciated dynamics making the current mess worse is the fact that both left and right, for somewhat different reasons, have embraced the idea that the outcome of the last debt ceiling deal  sequestration, with its butcher-knife cuts to domestic programs and defense was a straightforward win for Republicans, and a huge concession by the Democrats. For liberals, this idea has fed into the widespread never again attitude where debt ceiling negotiations are concerned. (We cant get blackmailed like that a second time!) For conservatives, its encouraged deeply implausible ideas about what they can expect the White House to offer them this time. (We basically won outright in 2011, so why not try to go for Obamacare repeal this time around?)

title: Court Blocks Citys Plan for Taxis of Tomorrow
description: A judge on Tuesday blocked New York Citys plan for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow taxis, dealing a potentially decisive blow to one of the Bloomberg administrations signature transportation initiatives.

title: In Twitters I.P.O. Filing, Signs of a Start-Up That Has Matured
description: Twitters prospectus for an initial public offering was disclosed last week, showing that the brouhaha about its confidential filing was much ado about very little.

title: Encouraging the Reviewers, Honestly
description: The credibility of online reviews has come under attack so many times that it is hard to know which, if any, to believe.

title: Villard Michel Richard Opening at the New York Palace
description: Headliner

title: Fantasy Football Week 6: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
description: As this topsy-turvy fantasy football season rolls along, the waiver wire options have become as plentiful as an ice cube in the Sahara.

title: Nazisms Feminine Side, Brutal and Murderous
description: German women and girls, under the Third Reich, were dissuaded from wearing makeup. They should glow from fresh air and exercise, Hitler thought, or better yet, from pregnancy.

title: The ioSafe N2 Is a Disaster-Resistant Backup Drive
description: The simple argument for cloud backup services is that if your house burns down, all your physical backup drives burn with it. The argument against cloud backup services is that they are expensive and slow  it can take days to upload the contents of a modest computer.

title: Meringue-Based Cakes, Fried Turkey Tails and More
description: To Indulge: An Ode to Belgium, Made of Meringue

title: Each One Witchier Than the Next
description: You have to admire the versatility of school-age witches as television characters. You can use them to make a kid-friendly animated show, as Hub has done with Sabrina: Secrets of a Teenage Witch, which begins on Saturday. Or you can use them as pivotal figures in a not-remotely-kid-friendly show whose premiere features torture, rape, drug use and death by intercourse.

title: Pentagon Says Shutdown Affects Military Death Benefits
description: Shutdown Denies Death and Burial Benefits to Families of 4 Dead Soldiers

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Israel, Pakistan, South Korea and China.

title: Hi-Fi Accessories for Your Headphones
description: Because the headphone market is so competitive, electronics companies are turning their focus more and more to hi-fi accessories.

title: An App to Create Your Movie-Star Photo
description: One reason celebrities look so polished in photos is that there are Photoshop artists to smooth every wrinkle, minimize every pore and erase every blemish. The rest of us? We have to live with poorly lighted mobile phone selfies.

title: Filipino Opera, Informed by Oppression
description: Noli Me Tangere, billed as the first Filipino opera composed in the Western operatic tradition, has rarely been staged in its entirety since it received its premiere in 1957 in the Philippines.

title: A Little Monster in Need of a Hug
description: When Tickle Me Elmo was released in 1996, demand for the toy created such hysteria that its name became insider shorthand for a hot holiday seller. Every year, analysts guess which toy will be the next Elmo. Hasbro is hoping that this year, that toy will again be Elmo.

title: A Showcase for Sustainable Food
description: TerraVITAs focus on sustainability has made it one of the Souths most progressive food and beverage festivals. Now in its fourth year, the multiday event in Chapel Hill, N.C., this year running Thursday to Saturday, includes special dinners, workshops and the Grand Tasting on the Green, highlighting dozens of chefs and food and beverage producers focusing on local or earth-friendly sourcing.

title: Disembodied Voices Hold Forth, Uttering the Question on Your Lips
description: The stage is strewn with lighting poles, some upright, some toppled. Two clothed men treat an inert, naked man as if he were another stage prop, slowly tipped end over end and carried. They stick him horizontally against the back wall, pressing him high above their heads. The man seems to thaw, to develop a will, as he is dragged around.

title: Obama on the Supreme Court
description: During a press conference a week into the government shutdown, President Obama discussed the consequences of the Citizens United case on financing elections.

title: Face to Face With Time, No Blinking
description: It is impossible not to root for Clint Holmes, the longtime Las Vegas headliner whose determined campaign to establish himself as a New York cabaret star has brought him to the Caf Carlyle for three consecutive years. His first two engagements were ambitious tributes to Bobby Short in 2011 and to Paul Simon and Cole Porter the year after.

title: Wilson Out as Giants Woes Continue
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants starting running back David Wilson will not play Thursday against the Chicago Bears because of a neck injury sustained in a 36-21 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday. The Giants were not more specific about the injury to Wilson, who attended practice and was occasionally seen running but did not participate in any drills.

title: Pleasing Deities, and the Eyes, With Storytelling Steps From India
description: The citys dance world at this time of year offers no shortage of festivals, from the something-for-everyone programming at Fall for Dance to the genre-blurring lineup at Crossing the Line. While dancegoers flocked to those last week, a kind of inadvertent festival, the product of serendipitous timing, unfolded with less fanfare.

title: Hotel Review: Topping Rose House in Bridgehampton, N.Y.
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: The Blackanese Sushi & Wine Bar in Johannesburg
description: On a stretch of the eastern fringe of downtown Johannesburg, the Maboneng Precinct (maboneng is Sotho for place of light) materializes like a hipster mirage. This once-gritty enclave has been transformed into a creative haven with galleries, a popular weekly market and, of course, restaurants. Last winter the Blackanese, a pocket-size Afro-Asian spot, joined the fray with a brick-and-mortar avatar of a successful mobile stall.

title: Starbucks Aims to Move Beyond Beans
description: SEATTLE  In a suburb due east of Los Angeles, Starbucks is opening a $70 million, state-of-the-art plant that will produce cold-pressed juices.

title: The Guarantee That Banks May Fear to Invoke
description: The mortgage orgy that banks entered into before the financial crisis has caused them  and their borrowers  immense pain since then. I have lost track of all the settlements and payments.

title: Learning to Live With the Family Secret
description: Among American pop cultures most profitable analogies continues to be the one between teenage angst and latent paranormal ability (magical, alien, vampiric). The latest television show to feed at this trough is The Tomorrow People on CW. And its title is perfect for the genre: Today were teenagers, but tomorrow well be people!

title: Oil Shocks Ahead? Probably Not
description: HOUSTON  OVER the last few months, as an Egyptian government fell in a coup, the United States considered an attack on Syria and disgruntled Libyan terminal guards blocked oil exports, the only predictable news was the rise in oil prices to levels not seen in more than two years.

title: They, Like, Know the Lines
description: Along with a love of Lisa Frank Trapper Keepers and slap bracelets, Gen Y-ers share an almost aggressive nostalgia for the harebrained sitcom Saved by the Bell.

title: Surfs Up, and So Is the Curtain at This Festival
description: SAN DIEGO  Sitting silently in a seat was pretty much off limits at the Without Walls festival, a weekend of theater set in, near and around La Jolla Playhouse here. Instead, one play seesawed the audience up and down in an elevator (Dramamine recommended). Another put attendees to work in a power plant.

title: The Me Generation Would Struggle Here
description: For a play that celebrates the individual, Anthem sure doesnt trust its audience. Instead of illustrating ideas, this sporadically interesting show too often delivers exposition, desperate to overexplain rather than risk a moment of misunderstanding.

title: The Long Shadow of Citizens United
description: Technically speaking, the Supreme Courts controversial 2010 ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission was not up for reconsideration on Tuesday, when the court heard oral arguments in the first major case of its new term.

title: The Mets Commissioning Program Is Starting to Bear Operas
description: When Nico Muhlys opera Two Boys has its American premiere at the Metropolitan Opera this month, it will be the first work to make it to the stage of the Met from a commissioning program that the company began seven years ago with Lincoln Center Theater.

title: New Corporate Tax Shelter: A Merger Abroad
description: Executives at a California chip maker, Applied Materials, highlighted a number of advantages in announcing a merger recently with a smaller Japanese rival, but an important one was barely mentioned: lower taxes.

title: Classical Musicians, Too, Make Berlin Their Capital
description: BERLIN  When Cameron Carpenter first came here, Berlin was covered in snow and looked as if spies might be lurking in the shadows. A year later, in 2010, Mr. Carpenter  the enfant terrible of the concert organ world  moved from the East Village to a loft in what was once a bombed-out neighborhood in the East German side of the city and is now the trendy district of Mitte.

title: Obama on China
description: President Obama said at a news conference that it was important for U.S.-China relations to resume and that cooperation between the countries is not a zero-sum game.

title: The 12 Best Restaurants in New York for Wine
description: Simply put, New York City offers the worlds greatest concentration of wonderful wine. Situated centrally among the worlds wine regions, it is free of the provincial tradition of drinking only the local wine. With an unparalleled variety

title: Obama on Terrorism
description: During a news conference, President Obama discussed the recent attacks in Kenya and American foreign policy in Africa.

title: Robert Redford in Pictures
description: Images of the actor and his work.

title: Bessies Are Presented to Dancers in Ceremony at the Apollo
description: In their 29th year, the Bessies, known formally as the New York Dance and Performance Awards, remain a work in progress.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,269 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Moving to the Cadence of an Elizabethan Text
description: William Forsythes first work, Urlicht, was a lyrical, on-point pas de deux, set to a vocal section of Mahlers Second Symphony, full of sustained tension and sculptural fluidity. One of his more recent pieces, Sider, is a large-scale ensemble work in which his dancers  some wearing Elizabethan ruffs, others hoods  manipulate large cardboard panels, scrambling and weaving through an unsettling, rule-bound universe, occasionally speaking in a mysterious language of familiar rhythms.

title: Simona de Silvestro, the IndyCar Driver, Says the Future of Racing Is Electric
description: A woman has yet to win the Indianapolis 500, but Simona de Silvestro, the Swiss-born driver, could be the first. In last Saturdays race at the Shell and Pennzoil Grand Prix of Houston, she came in second to Scott Dixon, her best finish ever (and first podium) in the Izod IndyCar Series.

title: Higgs Boson Particle Theory Wins Nobel
description: Dennis Overbye, a Times science reporter, discusses the Higgs boson particles significance  and insignificance  in understanding our universe.

title: These Donors Will Take Anything but Manhattan
description: Few major cultural donors are excited by the notion of contributing to an arts organization on a former landfill near a Costco warehouse in Queens.

title: European Union Official Calls for More Surveillance of Migrant Routes
description: BRUSSELS  A senior European Union official called on Tuesday for vastly expanded patrols of Mediterranean waters, as horror mounted over the deaths of hundreds of African migrants near Sicily last week.

title: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Fashion Week Take Their Bows
