description: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 14 fashion visionaries.

title: The Handwriting Is on the Purse
description: G TRAIN STATION, on the way to J.F.K., rush hour on a Friday. Im writhing about in search of my smartphone. Is it in your suitcase? my patient husband asks.

title: Boehner Disappointed by Obamas News Conference
description: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, responded to President Obamas lengthy news conference on Monday afternoon by reiterating that he was disappointed that the president refuses to negotiate.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Curtain Call
description: To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of 14 of its visionary designers.

title: Survey Says: Parents Are Happy, but Tired
description: Remember the research suggesting that mothers preferred housework to child care? The Daniel Kahneman study of almost 1,000 employed mothers in which the women reported feeling more negative emotions while caring for children than while doing almost anything else contributed to recriminations all over the Internet as parents wrestled with whether raising children was, indeed, All Joy and No Fun, as Jennifer Senior put it in a 2010 New York magazine article subtitled Why Parents Hate Parenting.

title: Airport Noise Linked to Heart Risk
description: Older people living near noisy airports may have an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, a new study reports.

title: Comfortable in the Contemporary, While Honoring the Venerable
description: The real thing: you know it when you see it. And on Monday evening at the opening-night show of the revitalized New York Cabaret Convention, now in its 24th year, at Frederick P. Rose Hall, the singer Carole J. Bufford showed the way forward. This brash cutie-pie belter with a pixie haircut triumphantly ended the show with renditions of House of the Rising Sun and Cant Help Lovin Dat Man in which hard-shelled resilience and determination with deep emotional undercurrents crushed any tendencies toward self-pity or empty showboating.

title: Argentine President Undergoes Surgery for Blood Clot
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, underwent surgery on Tuesday to drain a blood clot near her brain resulting from a head injury she sustained nearly two months ago, her spokesman said.

title: India Increases Effort to Harness Biomass Energy
description: GHANAUR, India  THE hulking power plant set against the green countryside of Punjab state in northwest India does not look like a source of renewable energy. Yet filling its stockyard, instead of mounds of coal, are bales of rice straw. Machines break up the heavy straw cubes as men with pitchforks hoist fibrous mounds onto a conveyor belt leading to the power plant. Handkerchiefs cover their faces to protect them from dust swirling in the air.

title: For Klinsmann, All Roads Lead to Brazil
description: Tuesday was the second anniversary of the first victory by a United States mens national team under the direction of Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.

title: Envoys Near Deal to Free Ex-Premier of Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  European diplomats appear close to negotiating the release of Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former prime minister of Ukraine, whose imprisonment by the government under her political rival has strained ties with the West and threatened to derail a trade agreement with Europe scheduled for signing in November.

title: Irans Foreign Minister Discusses Twitter, Netanyahu and Kerry on State Television
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, 10:51 a.m. | While restrictions on the use of social networks by Iranians remain in place, the countrys new foreign minister openly discussed the Happy Rosh Hashanah message he posted on his official Twitter account last month on state television Saturday.

title: Broadway Soul Doctor to Close on Sunday
description: Soul Doctor, the Broadway bio-musical about the singing rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, will close on Sunday after 32 preview performances and 66 regular performances, the producers announced on Tuesday. The show received mixed reviews during its initial Off Broadway production last year, and had roughly the same reception when it re-opened on Broadway in August at Circle in the Square Theater.

title: Undercover Detective Is Arrested in Attack on S.U.V.
description: An undercover New York City police detective who was among a group of motorcyclists chasing a sport utility vehicle on the West Side of Manhattan last month was arrested on Tuesday evening for his role in the episode, in which the vehicle was damaged and the driver was beaten, the police said.

title: Falling Behind
description: Most jobs in our globalized economy require ever increasing skills. But the skill set of the American work force has improved little. In math ability, not only are American workers less skilled than those from most other rich nations, but the young are even less skilled than the rest.

title: Obama to Pick Yellen as Leader of Fed, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate Janet L. Yellen as chairwoman of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday, White House officials said Tuesday night, ending an unusually prolonged and public search to fill one of the most important economic policy-making jobs in the world.

title: Annotations on a Speech
description: Joseph J. Lhota on Tuesday delivered a speech criticizing Bill de Blasio and offered a forceful argument in favor of aggressive policing tactics and the expansion of charter schools. Read the entire text of his speech to the Association for a Better New York, with annotations for context and clarity.

title: A History of Fed Appointments
description: Janet L. Yellen will be the first Democratic nominee to run the Fed since President Jimmy Carter named Paul Volcker as chairman in 1979.

title: The Economy Under Recent Fed Leaders
description: How effective the most recent Federal Reserve chairmen have been at fulfilling the systems dual mandate  controlling inflation while maximizing employment.

title: Surgery Ends Season for Sanchez
description: Finding Mark Sanchez on the Jets victorious sideline Monday night in Atlanta was not difficult. He was the one standing beside Coach Rex Ryan pumping his fist and sticking his tongue out with joy.

title: Boehner on Negotiations
description: John Boehner, the House speaker, discussed the need for talks on Tuesday.

title: Modern Updates to Old-School Building Materials
description: THERE was a time, long before Home Depot and cement mixers, when people had to build their homes from nearby materials. Centuries ago, the Indians of the Southwest used a mix of sand, clay, straw and water to make adobe homes. The Chinese constructed houses out of bamboo, and the English used a combination of straw and moist earth known as cob.

title: Off Scottish Coast, Harnessing Motion of Ocean Waves
description: STROMNESS, Scotland

title: Sports Beginning to See the Energy-Efficient Light
description: ALAIN GAUTHIER, who runs the Bell Centre, home of the Montreal Canadiens, wrestled with a problem confronting arena and stadium operators all over: large arrays of energy-sapping light bulbs.

title: In a Hot, Thirsty Energy Business, Water Is Prized
description: WITH so much focus on carbon emitted from the nations power plants, another environmental challenge related to electricity generation is sometimes overlooked: the enormous amount of water needed to cool the power-producing equipment.

title: Nuclear Plants Vexed at Prices That Shift as Demand Does
description: WASHINGTON  AS costs and competition from cheap natural gas force more old nuclear plants to shut down, their owners have a new complaint: the electricity market is rigged against them.

title: Unplugging Bottlenecks in Oil and Gas Deliveries
description: THE North American shale boom has brought with it many benefits, including new jobs, cheaper electricity and the potential for energy independence.

title: In Return to Vancouver, Schneider Duels Old Team
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  When former Canucks goaltender Cory Schneider returned here for the first time as a member of the Devils on Tuesday, it was billed as a duel with his old partner in the nets, Roberto Luongo. With Vancouvers 3-2 overtime win, Luongo earned bragging rights and his 350th career victory. Schneider is still looking for his first win in a Devils uniform.

title: Yellens Path to the Pinnacle
description: Milestones in the career of Janet L. Yellen, President Obamas choice to be chief of the Federal Reserve, including video recollections from friends and colleagues.

title: Another Unlikely Moment for an Unlikely Star
description: LOS ANGELES  When Juan Uribe, soaked in beer and Champagne and partially undressed, rose from his seat behind the microphone late Monday night, ready to return to a celebrating clubhouse after a brief news conference, the moderator thanked him.

title: At the Gravestone of Baby Hope, Investigators Who Never Let Go
description: The headstone is like no other in St. Raymonds Cemetery in the Bronx, both for what it is missing  a name  and what is there instead. A toll-free number.

title: Pentagon Names Envoy for Guantnamos Closing
description: The Pentagon announced Tuesday that Paul M. Lewis, the top lawyer on the Democratic staff of the House Armed Services Committee, will fill the new position of military envoy for the closing of the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. Mr. Lewis joins Cliff Sloan, who was appointed in June to be the State Departments envoy. The appointment of Mr. Lewis, who had worked in the office of the Pentagon general counsel earlier in the Obama administration, is part of a larger turnover of staff on detention issues. In July, William Lietzau, who had been the Pentagons top policy official on detainee matters, announced that he was stepping down to take a private sector job.

title: Stubborn Skills Gap in Americas Work Force
description: One of the few things that nearly everyone in Washington agrees on is that American workers are the best.

title: Renovated Tenement Awaits the Return of One of Its Carpenters, Jimmy Carter
description: Don Kao vividly recalls his first day of work as an urban homesteader in the East Village. I was standing in front of the building and I could see the sky right through it, he said. There was no roof. And I said, Oh my God, what did I get myself into?

title: Power Grid Is Attacked in Arkansas
description: ATLANTA  The federal authorities are investigating whether three recent attacks against the power grid in Arkansas are linked, and utility officials have asked residents to remain alert to the threat of more trouble.

title: Jody L. Kriss
description: Mr. Kriss, 38, is a founder and principal of East River Partners, a company based in New York that acquires and redevelops brownstone properties in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Issues Warning on Salmonella Believed to Be Linked to a Poultry Farm
description: The Agriculture Department issued a public health alert this week, saying that a strain of salmonella may have sickened 278 people who reported becoming ill after they ate poultry produced by Foster Farms.

title: My Afro, Myself
description: LIKE many Americans, Im a white person. But I am one of the select few who can make this boast: I once had quite a substantial Afro. Not a phony, permed, modest little Afro like the kind Mr. Brady sported in later seasons of The Brady Bunch, but a genuine, all-natural, Angela Davis-worthy fro with a radius of nearly a foot and a half (though thats including skull as well as hair). My Afro was so large that it bounced when I walked. I was a life-size bobblehead, with a feather-light boulder of dead protein suspended over my shoulders.

title: Janet Yellen: An Updated Reading List
description: Much of the recent coverage of Janet Yellen, President Obamas choice to head the Federal Reserve, has focused on her personal style, portraying her as a consensus builder and referring to her quiet demeanor  offering a contrast with the sometimes abrasive image of the previous front-runner for the job, Lawrence H. Summers. But wider reading offers a more detailed picture of Ms. Yellen as an obsessive student of economics who chooses her battles carefully.

title: Kansas Legislature Threatens Showdown With Court Over School Financing
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  As advocates of increased school funding brought their request to the Kansas Supreme Court on Tuesday, the staunchly conservative Legislature vowed to defy any court orders that it felt trampled on its sovereignty.

title: China: Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters, Report Says
description: A Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia said Tuesday that Chinese security forces had fired on a protest in an eastern town in the Tibetan Autonomous Region, wounding at least 60 people, two of them critically. The violence took place on Sunday in Driru County, known as Biru in Chinese. Radio Free Asia said security forces were confronted by a crowd that had gathered to prevent the police from searching the home of Dorje Draktsel, who was detained last week after taking part in protests against orders that Tibetans fly the Chinese flag during the October national holiday period. The Tibet advocacy group, Free Tibet, said thousands of officials had flooded into the area in September to impose a political re-education campaign on the locals.

title: SAC Is Said to Weigh Plea Deal in Insider Trading Case
description: After months of fighting the governments insider trading case tooth and nail, the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is leaning toward admitting criminal wrongdoing and agreeing to pay a record financial penalty to resolve the charges, according to two people briefed on the deliberations.

title: Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Uninsured Find More Success via Health Exchanges Run by States
description: WASHINGTON  Robyn J. Skrebes of Minneapolis said she was able to sign up for health insurance in about two hours on Monday using the Web site of the state-run insurance exchange in Minnesota, known as MNsure. Ms. Skrebes, who is 32 and uninsured, said she had selected a policy costing $179 a month, before tax credit subsidies, and also had obtained Medicaid coverage for her 2-year-old daughter, Emma.

title: Atlantic 10 Hoping Edginess of Barclays and Brooklyn Will Rub Off on Conference
description: Virginia Commonwealth Coach Shaka Smart took a cab to Barclays Center for the Atlantic 10 Conference mens basketball media day Tuesday, and before he entered, he snapped a picture of the arena. He sent the photograph as a text message to his six returning players. Immediately his phone began buzzing in response.

title: China: Decision in Bo Xilai Appeal Expected Soon
description: Bo Xilai, a former senior Communist Party official who was sentenced to life in prison last month, expects a court in eastern China to make a decision soon on his appeal, a family associate said Tuesday. Mr. Bo was convicted of bribetaking, embezzlement and abuse of power in an effort to head off murder charges against his wife. His wife, Gu Kailai, was sentenced to life in prison last year for the murder of a British businessman. The family associate said that Mr. Bos lawyer had filed the appealed soon after the sentencing. The higher court judges are likely to review the appeal on paper rather than hear arguments in court, the family associate said. Political analysts said the higher court is unlikely to overturn the verdict, since party leaders were almost certainly the ones who had determined the verdict.

title: Why Wont McDonalds Really Lead?
description: Every McDonalds executive Ive met who happens to be a parent says something like this: I dont let my kids eat at McDonalds all the time. Its a treat; we know that. Yet these same executives, in literature and in public, say that theyre championing childrens well-being.

title: Deadlock Worry Jolts the Market for T-Bills
description: The political impasse over the debt ceiling roiled a closely watched corner of the bond market on Tuesday, pushing up the price the government paid to borrow money for a month to its highest level since 2008, more than doubling from just a day earlier.

title: Hes Over 80, but a Convict Gets No Parole
description: It began with a parking ticket dispute on a street in Manhattan more than 35 years ago, then lots of stupidity, shots fired, everyone lived.

title: No Physicist Is an Island
description: LOS ANGELES  THE physicist Richard Feynman liked to gripe about what he called Alfred Nobels Other Mistake. The first mistake was the invention of dynamite. The second was creating the Nobel Prizes. Mr. Feynman thought it was ridiculous that something as material as a cash prize should be awarded to something as grand and open-ended as scientific research. (The griping wasnt a matter of sour grapes; Mr. Feynman shared a well-deserved prize for physics in 1965.) This years physics Nobel has just been awarded to Franois Englert and Peter Higgs, for what is simply called the Higgs mechanism. But while Mr. Englert and Mr. Higgs undoubtedly deserve acclaim, bestowing an award on them alone distorts the nature of modern physics research.

title: 8 Lawmakers Arrested at Immigration Protest
description: WASHINGTON  As several thousand demonstrators rallied around them, eight members of the House of Representatives were arrested on Tuesday outside the Capitol in a protest to push Congress to pass broad immigration legislation that includes a path to citizenship for immigrants in the country illegally.

title: Cuomo Denounces Con Eds Proposed Rate Increase
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who has been a stern critic of utility companies since Hurricane Sandy struck a year ago, said on Tuesday that Consolidated Edison should be denied the $450 million rate increase it is seeking. Indeed, Mr. Cuomo said, Con Edisons rates should not go up at all next year.

title: Brazils Next Steps
description: After a decade of fast growth and rising incomes, Brazil has hit a rough patch that is testing its governments ability to manage the economy and satisfy the growing aspirations of its people. President Dilma Rousseff, who faces elections next year, needs to push through policy reforms and public investment projects to revive growth and bring inflation under control.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 8
Broken Military Justice
description: The abusive grilling last month of a female midshipman in a case involving three former United States Naval Academy football players provided further evidence that the militarys handling of sexual assault complaints is seriously flawed.

title: Lets Build a More Secure Internet
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  CAN we ever trust the Internet again?

title: Regaining Swagger, Tigers Force a Game 5
description: DETROIT  The Detroit Tigers slug, period. Manager Jim Leyland never asks his power-laden team to manufacture runs, because it is not its nature. So when the Tigers collectively slump, like the spell that began the final week of the regular season, they look listless. And there is not much Leyland can do about it.

title: First End the Crisis, Then Talk
description: The demand from House Republicans on Tuesday morning  theres a new one every day  was recycled from the last fiscal crisis they created: a bipartisan supercommittee of 20 lawmakers to negotiate a way out of the two crises (the government shutdown and debt-ceiling deadline) the House has now merged together. It was a particularly cynical flourish, given the Republican sabotage of the last supercommittee, and Democrats were right to dismiss it.

title: A Study in Scarcity: Women at Central Banks
description: If confirmed by the Senate as the next chief of the Federal Reserve, Janet L. Yellen would be the highest-ranking woman ever in an economic policy-making position in the United States  and one of the most powerful women to serve in American government. No woman has led the Fed in the century since it was established, or the Treasury Department in its 224-year history.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Demise of Lavabit, and an Interview With John McAfee
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Drivers Defense: Too Drunk to Be Guilty
description: Martin Heidgen went on a drinking binge for 10 hours in Manhattan and Nassau County, then drove his pickup the wrong way down the Meadowbrook State Parkway for miles, killing a limousine driver and a 7-year-old girl.

title: U.S. Fringe Festival
description: There is one group of people with an even greater interest than Democrats in President Obama prevailing over Tea Party Republicans in this shutdown showdown, and that is mainstream Republicans.

title: Britain and Iran Move to Repair Diplomatic Relations
description: LONDON  In an effort to repair long-strained relations, Britain and Iran announced Tuesday that each would appoint a charg daffaires, a rank below ambassador, to work toward resuming full diplomatic ties. The diplomats will remain in their own countries, but will discuss reopening embassies in London and Tehran.

title: Call an Audible, Dan
description: WASHINGTON  Whenever I want to be called a detestable, insidious proselytizer of political correctness, I just bring up the idea of changing the name of the Redskins at a family dinner. What if our football teams name werent a slur, I ask brightly. Wouldnt that be nice?

title: City Council to Decide Fate of Mecca for Graffiti Artists
description: The New York City Council is expected on Wednesday to decide the fate of 5Pointz, the brick warehouses slathered in oversized graffiti that became a cultural institution in a once-working-class neighborhood of Queens.

title: Cardinals Know How to Raise Young Arms
description: ST. LOUIS  Adam Wainwright was hungry. Happy, but hungry, and maybe also a little weary. Wainwright, the ace of the St. Louis Cardinals, had spoken for a while in the visitors clubhouse at PNC Park on Monday, trying to explain the spectacular emergence of another protg, Michael Wacha, on the national stage.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 9, 2013
description: You may imagine that this is not unpleasant.

title: Lawyer Sought for Terror Suspect Held on Navy Ship
description: A terror suspect captured in Libya over the weekend, and now said to be undergoing interrogation on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, should be appointed a lawyer, the chief federal public defender in Manhattan wrote on Tuesday.

title: Many in G.O.P. Offer Theory: Default Wouldnt Be That Bad
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Richard Burr, Republican of North Carolina, a reliable friend of business on Capitol Hill and no ones idea of a bomb thrower, isnt buying the apocalyptic warnings that a default on United States government debt would lead to a global economic cataclysm.

title: A Rays Home Run Is a Sweet Splash of Drama
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Boston Red Sox and the Tampa Bay Rays were tied at 4-4 on Monday, with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning, when Jose Lobaton came to bat. What happened next exceeded even a childs wildest imagination. Lobaton crushed a game-winning home run that landed in a tank of cownose rays in right-center field.

title: SFX Entertainment Prices Its I.P.O. at $13 a Share
description: The electronic dance music craze will face a referendum of sorts on Wall Street this week.

title: Corrections: October 9, 2013
description: NEW YORK

title: One Ringy-Dingy
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Heres a new idea: not one, but two 30-letter theme entries in a 15 x 15 puzzle. Its an innovative concept. Its also a fascinating debut by Jason Flinn, and well meet him after the jump.

title: Rights Advocates Suing U.N. Over the Spread of Cholera in Haiti
description: Advocates for Haitian victims of the deadly cholera epidemic that first afflicted their country three years ago said they were taking the extraordinary step on Wednesday of suing the United Nations, asserting that the organizations peacekeeping force in Haiti was responsible for introducing the disease through sewage contamination from its barracks.

title: $10 Million Gift to Help Head Start Through Shutdown
description: A wealthy Houston couple have donated $10 million to Head Start to keep its programs running through this month despite the government shutdown.

title: Steinbrenner, With His Teams Season Over, Talks About 2014
description: Eight days into October, with the Yankees not playing postseason baseball for just the second time in 19 seasons, Hal Steinbrenner spoke up.

title: What Federal Spending Are We Better Off Without?
College in Prison: Were Treated Like People
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Debt Deadline Approaches
description: To the Editor:

title: South Sudan: Signs of Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: City Operas Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Fed Does, and Can Do
description: With the prospective nomination of Janet L. Yellen to head the Federal Reserve, here is a look at the fundamentals of the organization she would be taking over.

title: Report Says a Shortage of Nuclear Ingredient Looms
description: WASHINGTON  Most nuclear reactors in the United States rely on a type of lithium that is produced only by China and Russia, and the supply may be drying up, according to a study to be released on Wednesday.

title: Start-Up Chic Goes Corporate, as Couches Replace Desks
description: Small start-up tech companies have become known for renting tiny offices in expensive loft areas, and providing employees a less structured work space  often without even a traditional desk.

title: A Leaders Admission of Mistakes Heartens Some Doubting Mormons
description: Mormons hoping for change were buoyed when one of their churchs top leaders gave an address last weekend offering an outstretched hand to those who struggle with doubts about the churchs history and doctrines.

title: Megyn Kelly Draws a Large, Older Audience on Fox News Show
description: On her first night as a central player in the Fox News prime-time lineup, Megyn Kelly scored impressively with the networks core audience of older viewers, but did not register much improvement in attracting additional viewers in the category that makes money for cable news networks, viewers between the ages of 25 and 54.

title: London Game Added; 3 Cities Will Vie for 18 Super Bowl
description: WASHINGTON  The N.F.L. said it would add a third game in London next year and narrowed the list of candidates to host the Super Bowl in 2018 to Indianapolis, Minneapolis and New Orleans.

title: In a Healthy Apartment Market, Pockets of Worry
description: Over the last year, the apartment developer Arnie Gregory has opened 236 units in two early 1900s warehouses in the trendy downtown Minneapolis North Loop neighborhood. All are full and fetching higher-than-expected rents by about 25 cents a square foot.

title: March in Support of Charter Schools
description: Thousands marched across the Brooklyn Bridge in support of New York Citys charter schools Tuesday, protesting plans by Bill de Blasio to charge such schools rent.

title: Snacks for Soccer Stars, and Their Fans
description: IN what Mondelez International says is its largest investment ever in a multibrand marketing effort, the snack-food giant on Wednesday will announce an expansive sponsorship deal with American soccer teams and players.

title: In Unlikely Turn, Bloomberg Convenes the Mayoral Rivals
description: He was the gracious host of would-be successors he has refused to endorse, praising one for his wisdom in a crisis, the other for his love of New York City.

title: Nets Initial Trial Run Shows a Few Flashes but Little Familiarity
description: WASHINGTON  This was the first glimpse, a tantalizing but precursory peek, at what a $183 million team looks like.

title: In New Jersey Debate, a State Senator Tries to Deflate a Confident Christie
description: With less than a month before Election Day, it was a rare sign that, in fact, there is a race for governor in New Jersey this year.

title: Obama Expected to Reduce Military Aid to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to suspend a substantial portion of American military aid to Egypt, several administration officials said Tuesday, after last summers deadly crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood and the recent surge in violence there.

title: Candidates Spar Over Souls and Pensions in Comptroller Debate
description: Scott M. Stringer, after defeating Eliot Spitzer, the former governor, in a closely fought Democratic primary for New York City comptroller, faced off on Tuesday evening with a much less well-known, but no less determined, rival.

title: Norman Rockwell Painting Disappears From Storage
description: A Norman Rockwell painting that sold for more than $1 million at an auction in May disappeared from a storage warehouse in Queens last month, the police said on Tuesday.

title: Anger Can Be Power
description: These are extraordinary times. The depth and strength of voters conviction that their opponents are determined to destroy their way of life has rarely been matched, perhaps only by the mood of the South in the years leading up to the Civil War.

title: Ralph A. Dungan, Aide in Kennedy White House, Dies at 90
description: Ralph A. Dungan, a prominent aide in the Kennedy White House who was later caught up in tumultuous Chilean politics as an ambassador and bitter university politics as New Jerseys first chancellor of higher education, died on Oct. 5 at his home in St. John Parish, Barbados. He was 90.

title: The Scent of the Wild in Williamsburg
description: A bearded, flannel-shirt-wearing backpacker from the Cascade Mountains of Portland, Ore., is not your typical perfumer. But in the case of Hall Newbegin, an obsessive love for the outdoors inspired him to create Juniper Ridge, a wild-crafted line of handmade colognes, soaps and incense, based in Oakland, Calif. First introduced at farmers markets in the Bay Area in 1998 and now carried in thoughtfully curated shops like Shelter Half in Los Angeles and Steven Alan Home in New York, Newbegins artisanal goods have a hyper-local focus. He forages aromatic plants, mushrooms, tree trimmings and moss on the trails around the West Coast, then distills everything using an old-fashioned enfleurage process to create essential oils that smell like the Mojave Desert after the rain or a dusky summer evening along the Timberline Trail on Mount Hood. People say the scents remind them of camping, said Newbegin, who currently lives by Mount Tamalpais in Northern California and trained in herbal medicine before becoming what he calls a wildness nose. The latest additions to his forest-centric range are two addition to his line of backpackers colognes: Big Sur, which is infused with wild sage, and Yuba River, a blend redolent of cedar log cabins and the richness of hiking-boot leather. Like all Juniper Ridge products, theyre made without petrochemicals or synthetic ingredients  just real stuff from real places, Newbegin explained.

title: How Walking May Lower Breast Cancer Risk
description: Physical activity, even including walking, can substantially reduce a womans risk of developing breast cancer, encouraging new science shows, in part, it seems, by changing how her body deals with estrogen.

title: Public Policy and Wages
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Word of the Day | concentric
description: concentric \kn-sen-trik, kn-\ adjective

title: Gunfire Report Closes a Princeton Hall
description: A report of gunshots prompted the police to cordon off the historic central building on the Princeton University campus in New Jersey for about three hours Tuesday night.

title: Red Sox Grind Rays Down and Out of the Playoffs
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Red Sox have bonded over their beards, of course, but another charm has been with them since August: a cigar-store Indian, owned by Jake Peavy.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 10 P.M. (Ovation) A YOUNG DOCTORS NOTEBOOK A morphine-addicted Russian doctor (Jon Hamm), accompanied by his younger self (Daniel Radcliffe, above right, with Mr. Hamm), relives stories of being dispatched in 1916 to a country hospital, where he performs surgeries in primitive conditions, longs for Moscow and lives in fear of killing his patients in this adaptation of Mikhail Bulgakovs autobiographical short stories. The two actors are wonderful in their scenes together (their half-foot difference in height can be excused as a metaphor for growth), and Mr. Hamm, especially, displays bountiful intelligence, depth of feeling and mordant humor, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. He gives an admirable delicacy even to a postoperative, postamputation line like, You just might have to settle for saving the world three-quarters of a peasant at a time. In this second episode, the young doctor tries to appear more imposing as he lives in the shadows of his predecessor. Episode 1 will be rebroadcast at 1 p.m. and 2:30 a.m.

title: News Quiz | October 9, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: U.S. Officials Say Libya Approved Commando Raids
description: WASHINGTON  The Libyan government in recent weeks tacitly approved two American commando operations in its country, according to senior American officials, one to capture a senior militant from Al Qaeda and another to seize a militia leader suspected of carrying out the Sept. 11, 2012, attacks on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi.

title: Why Woody Allens Blue Jasmine Wasnt Released in India
description: Indias tough censorship policy has cost its people a wide range of visual pleasures, but even so, its latest blow would have been difficult to anticipate. Last Thursday, film fans in India woke up to the news that the next days planned release of Blue Jasmine, the latest film from the writer and director Woody Allen, had been canceled. Apparently, Mr. Allen was unwilling to follow the local guidelines for showing people smoking on film.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 9, 2013
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The God Particle and the Nobel Prize
description: In Higgs and Englert Are Awarded Nobel Prize in Physics, Dennis Overbye writes about the discovery of the God particle.

title: Stuff Yourself
description: D.I.Y. dolmas are not only doable but come with a significant advantage: choice.

title: All Is Fair in Love and Twitter
description: Right in the center of South Park, a large, grassy oval near San Franciscos financial district, there is a rinky-dink playground with slides, ladders and firefighter poles, all dented and dinged, connected by gritty brown pylons. Yet for many in Silicon Valley, this playground is hallowed ground. It was here, one breezy day in 2006, according to legend, that Jack Dorsey ordered burritos with two co-workers, scaled a slide and, in a black sweater and green beanie, like a geeked-out Moses on Mount Sinai, presented his idea for an Internet service that would allow users to update their current status and share what they were doing. That playground right up there is where I first brought up the idea, Dorsey, whose present-day uniform is a white Dior dress shirt and tailored dark blazer, told CNBC earlier this year.

title: The First Tweet Aint the Deepest
description: The creation of Twitter was a sloppy, nasty thing, as Nick Bilton describes in his cover article for Sundays magazine. Bilton unearths the collusion and deception behind the scenes in Twitters early days. But even on the surface, right there in the Twitter stream, there was something ugly and confused going on. Nobody  founders included  really knew what Twitter was or how to use it. Take a look at the first tweets from the four men who could reasonably claim to have founded Twitter:

title: Documenting the Delta, Then and Now
description: Eugene Richards is a documentary photographer who has published 16 books, including Dorchester Days, a personal view of the working-class neighborhood in Boston where he grew up; Cocaine True, Cocaine Blue, on the ravages of drug abuse; and War Is Personal, about Iraq war veterans returning to the United States.

title: What Would You Do With a Gap Year?
description: Taking a gap year between high school and college is an idea that is gaining popularity, according to The Timess Business section. Would you be interested in taking one? Why or why not? If you could do anything that year, what would it be?

title: The Oaxaca Teachers Union
description: MEXICO CITY  On Sunday the teachers union from Oaxaca, one of Mexicos poorest states, decided that all 70,000 of the states teachers should go back to class  some seven weeks after the rest of the country resumed school.

title: Wal-Mart Drops Ambitious Expansion Plan for India
description: MUMBAI, India  Wal-Mart Stores gave up on Indias huge market on Wednesday, announcing that it had indefinitely delayed its once-ambitious plans to open hundreds of superstores across the country.

title: New York Today: Empty Chair
description: Updated 12:00 p.m. | What if they had a mayoral debate and the man most likely to become mayor didnt show?

title: Wheelies: The Mans Best Friend Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Healthy Obese and Their Healthy Fat Cells
description: They are a mystery to researchers: people who are significantly overweight and yet show none of the usual metabolic red flags. Despite their obesity, they have normal cholesterol levels, healthy blood pressure levels and no apparent signs of impending diabetes.

title: Without Test Tubes, 3 Win Nobel in Chemistry
description: Chemistry, meet computer science.

title: India Trade Deficit Narrowed in September
description: HONG KONG  Indias trade deficit dropped to its lowest level since early 2011, data released Wednesday showed, providing a rare piece of good news from an economy that has been weighed down by inadequate infrastructure, a gaping current account deficit and a currency that has plummeted in recent months.

title: Mens Wearhouse Rejects $2.3 Billion Offer by Jos. A. Bank
description: Updated, 8:12 p.m. | Mens Wearhouse rejected an unsolicited $2.3 billion takeover bid by Jos. A. Bank Clothiers on Wednesday, calling the proposed deal highly opportunistic and saying it would be likely to draw antitrust scrutiny.

title: Daily Report: Ban Upheld in U.S. on Some Samsung Phones and Tablets
description: In another blow to Samsung Electronics in its continuing patent disputes with Apple, the Obama administration has decided to uphold a ban requested by Apple of some of Samsungs mobile products, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: In Crackdown Response, U.S. Temporarily Freezes Some Military Aid to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday announced a modest and temporary freeze on military assistance to Egypt, even as American officials emphasized their desire to avoid rupturing a security relationship that stretches back more than three decades.

title: Advice About Sleep Deficiency in Midlife, Part 3
description: Orfeu Marcello Buxton, a neuroscientist in the Division of Sleep Medicine in the Department of Medicine at Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston, has been answering reader questions about sleep deficiency. More than 300 people sent questions (most can be read here). Part 1 of his answers is here; part 2 of his answers is here.

title: Taking Questions About When Its Time for Assisted Living
description: This weeks Ask an Expert features Debra Drelich, a specialist in geriatric care who will answer questions about assisted living and other special living arrangements for aging relatives. [Update: Part 1 of her answers is here. Part 2 is here. Part 3 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

title: The Sun-Dried Kid
description: SUNDANCE, Utah  Maybe when you play Death on The Twilight Zone at the start of your career, mortality doesnt faze you.

title: Today in Small Business: Shutdown Beards
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Washington Heights Remembers a Child It Mourned
description: The people of Washington Heights claimed her when her own family didnt. They said prayers for her, and told their children about her, and wondered what she would have been like if she had lived.

title: Taliban and Pakistan Argue Over Fate of Islamist Detainee
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban on Wednesday publicly disputed claims that the Pakistani government had released a senior militant detainee, drawing a firm rebuttal from the government and plunging efforts to start peace talks in Afghanistan into new confusion.

title: SAC Considers Deal With Prosecutors
description: SAC IS SAID TO WEIGH PLEA DEAL | The hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, after months of fighting the governments insider trading case, is leaning toward admitting criminal wrongdoing and agreeing to pay a record financial penalty to resolve the charges, DealBooks Peter Lattman reports. Federal prosecutors have taken an aggressive stance in settlement talks with SAC, according to two people briefed on the deliberations.

title: Im Calling About a Barking Dog
description: Dear Diary:

title: G.E.s Industrial Internet Goes Big
description: The more General Electric gets into its plan for an Industrial Internet, the bigger it seems.

title: By Design | The Fanciful World of Fornasetti
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Turkish Court Upholds Many Convictions in Coup Case
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys highest appeals court on Wednesday upheld the convictions of 237 military officers accused of plotting to overthrow the government a decade ago. The case, which has riveted the nation, highlights the power struggle between Turkeys pro-Islamic government and the once powerful military, which sees itself as the defender of Turkeys historically secular state.

title: Yellens Path From Liberal Theorist to Fed Voice for Jobs
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  When the economists Janet L. Yellen and George A. Akerlof hired a baby sitter for their son in the early 1980s, they decided to pay more than the going wage. They reasoned that a happier baby sitter would provide better care.

title: Yellens Exclusive Interview, With Yellen
description: Janet Yellen, whom President Obama plans to nominate Wednesday to lead the Federal Reserve, was the editor in chief of the student newspaper at Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn. She was also valedictorian of the class of 1963. So in keeping with a school tradition for the editor to interview the valedictorian, she interviewed herself.

title: Europe Looks Ahead to Fed Choice
description: FRANKFURT  For a world increasingly nervous about events in Washington, President Obamas choice Wednesday of Janet L. Yellen to be chairwoman of the Federal Reserve meant there was one less thing for global economists and investors to worry about.

title: Seeking to Preserve a Plain Brick Firehouse With a Painful History
description: There is an old red brick, neo-Georgian building in Elmhurst, Queens, that looks like a firehouse from a movie studio lot: two truck bays with roll-down red doors  side by side, for engine and ladder  under four tall windows and an entablature embossed with the city seal.

title: What the Latest Consumer Credit Report Tells Us
description: With the government shut down, reliable data is in short supply. Labor statistics? Retail sales? Business inventories? Trade balance? Health updates? The list of what we dont know goes on.

title: The Gun Report: October 9, 2013
description: The pro-gun movement is scared. Despite recent victories at the federal and state level, theres a demographic drop-off on the horizon, writes Alexander Zaitchik, who covered this years Gun Rights Policy Conference in Houston for Media Matters. Indeed, gun industry veterans joke that N.R.A. now stands for Normal Retirement Age.

title: Europe Votes to Tighten Rules on Drilling Method
description: European Union lawmakers voted narrowly on Wednesday to force energy companies to carry out in-depth environmental audits before they deploy a technique known as fracking to recover natural gas from shale rock.

title: Janet L. Yellen, on the Economys Twists and Turns
description: The Federal Reserve is said to have a dual mandate: keeping inflation in check and the unemployment rate low. These metrics are charted for every year since 1941.

title: Real Estate in West Vancouver
description: There has been a resurgence in the Vancouver market over the summer, spurred in part by concern about rising interest rates.

title: House Hunting in ... West Vancouver
description: A THREE-BEDROOM WATERFRONT HOUSE IN WEST VANCOUVER

title: Homes for $850,000
description: This weeks properties include a 1912 house near San Antonio and midcentury moderns in Florida and Missouri.

title: What You Get for... $850,000
description: ALAMO HEIGHTS, TEX.

title: Are Treasuries Terrifying?
description: Neil Irwin says yes. Felix Salmon says no. I say, yes and no.

title: A Clever Solution to an Olympic Problem
description: For athletes and others going to the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, its a much-discussed riddle: how to take a stand against the host countrys reprehensible anti-gay laws, which have rightly caused international outrage, without running afoul of them or of the International Olympic Committees prohibition against political statements and protests.

title: A Creative Renaissance in Philadelphias Fishtown
description: The scruffy neighborhood of Fishtown in Philadelphia is having a creative renaissance, coming on the heels of Stephen Starr and Joe Carrolls recent opening of the barbecue restaurant Fette Sau. The southwest end of Frankford Avenue is becoming an artisanal avenue, with design shops, a small publishing press, restaurants and coffeehouses moving in to this former manufacturing district. Neighborhood pride is palpable; graceful metal sculptures line one stretch of sidewalk, and a wooden sign in a community garden reads Welcome to Fishtown: Stop and smell the roses. First Fridays, the free open gallery nights along Frankford Avenue, are also drawing newcomers.

title: In California, Diving for an Elusive Delicacy
description: The abalone did not want to come off the rock. Fifteen feet underwater, I had jabbed my abalone iron (basically a hard metal spatula) underneath the shell, between the mollusks muscular foot and the rock, hoping for the pop I had been promised by our instructor. Nothing.

title: CreatureCast: Royalty Sapped From Snails
description: Tyrian purple was one of the only bright dyes available to ancient civilizations. The sought-after pigment, whose color often worn by royalty, was created from the extracts of marine snails.

title: They Cant Handle the Truth
description: Its remarkable and scary to watch Republican leaders trying to extract themselves from the box theyre in. They have now figured out that Obama wont eviscerate health reform under threat  although their base refuses to believe it. They still cant face the reality that Obama wont offer any concessions, of any kind, under threat. In an odd way, their attempts to get something by repeating over and over the same old lies and misdirections  were not practicing extortion, hes just refusing to negotiate!  makes me think of the classic tourist, believing that locals will understand English if only you talk loud enough.

title: Maybe WE Should Buy That Old General Store!
description: The start-up was not a new software company, a new cupcake store, or even a new idea. It was actually a remake of a very old idea.

title: The Color of Royalty, Bestowed by Science and Snails
description: We now take brightly colored fabric for granted. There were far fewer pigments available to the people of antiquity, and most of them were somewhat drab by todays standards. Throughout the Mediterranean, the dye Tyrian purple was prized above all others. In ancient Rome, fabric dyed with Tyrian purple was worth its weight in gold. Its intense color, as well as its expense, made it a favorite of royalty and nobility and it was coveted as a status symbol. The association between purple and royalty that persists in many cultures today originated with this ancient pigment.

title: Comcast Hopes to Promote TV Shows in Twitter Deal
description: Comcast customers will soon be able to reach some television shows from Twitter messages about those shows, the two companies announced on Wednesday, in what they hope will become an industrywide practice.

title: Poems to Read by Jack-O-Lantern Light
description: Most of the fun of Halloween is in the planning: choosing a costume, negotiating accessories (But Dad, a real scythe would look so much scarier!), decorating the house, dreaming about how much candy you could possibly amass, and where to hide it from your parents. Its also, perhaps surprisingly, a fine time for poetry. For children who are squeamish about verse, poems about dark magic, graves, goblins and monsters are  no disrespect intended  a far cry from Now We Are Six: unabashedly fun, unsentimental and occasionally wicked.

title: Kochs Deny Pushing for Shutdown Over Health Law
description: Updated, 12:43 p.m. | WASHINGTON  Koch Industries, whose co-founders, Charles and David Koch, are major donors to Tea Party-inspired conservative causes, accused Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, on Wednesday of spreading false information about the brothers by suggesting they are behind the move to end financing for President Obamas healthcare law and the partial shutdown of the federal government.

title: With New Abortion Restrictions, Ohio Walks a Narrow Legal Line
description: CLEVELAND  Angela H., married with two children, became pregnant accidentally and, after medical complications during her last pregnancy and severe postpartum depression, said neither she nor her family was ready for another child.

title: 3 Arrested in Death of Tibetan Religious Leader in China
description: BEIJING  Three men have been arrested in the stabbing death of a prominent Tibetan religious leader and British citizen who founded a monastery and Buddhist center in Scotland, Chinese state news media reported Wednesday. The religious leaders nephew and driver were also killed in the attack, which took place on Tuesday in the western provincial capital of Chengdu.

title: Turning Education Upside Down
description: Three years ago, Clintondale High School, just north of Detroit, became a flipped school  one where students watch teachers lectures at home and do what wed otherwise call homework in class. Teachers record video lessons, which students watch on their smartphones, home computers or at lunch in the schools tech lab. In class, they do projects, exercises or lab experiments in small groups while the teacher circulates.

title: Complacency on Wall Street Could Be Worse Than a Panic
description: Dont look to a market panic to save us.

title: Three Things the Development World Could Do Better
description: The notion that all foreign aid is a waste of money is dead wrong. In my last post, I wrote about the incredible success stories that I witnessed firsthand working on the ground in Africa on development for 25 years. But that doesnt mean that everything went according to plan.

title: Tepid Opening for Promoter of Electronic Dance Music
description: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | Investors didnt seem to be in the mood to dance on Wednesday.

title: Unrest Over Telangana Brings Andhra Pradesh to Standstill
description: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh Over 80,000 state power workers protesting a plan to carve a new state out of Andhra Pradesh refused to go back to work on Wednesday despite the state governments efforts at negotiations, raising concerns among government officials that a prolonged power outage could destabilize the entire southern Indian grid.

title: Stanley Kauffmann, Critic, Dies at 97; Spent a Half-Century at the Movies
description: Stanley Kauffmann, whose literate, tightly constructed movie reviews appeared in The New Republic for more than a half-century and set a standard for critical ease and erudition, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 97.

title: App Smart: Nature Apps
description: Kit Eaton reviews Audubon Trees, iBird Plus and RockHound, three apps that aim to deepen knowledge of the natural world around us.

title: Cheat Sheets for Your Walk in the Woods
description: A family friend has an amazing ability to casually identify most, if not all, of the flora we encounter when were walking in the countryside. Her skill is based on experience and knowledge gained from a lot of reading. But now, thanks to my smartphones high-tech trickery, I can almost begin to rival her powers. As you take long autumn strolls in the wild, apps can be excellent nature guides.

title: Up Next: Haley Wollens, Getting Mileage From Miley Cyrus
description: AGE 27

title: Obama to Meet With Congressional Democrats and Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is bringing Democrats and Republicans from the House and Senate separately to the White House before weeks end to try to resolve the continuing impasse over funding the government and raising the nations borrowing ceiling.

title: O.E.C.D. Head Calls for Global Effort Against Climate Change
description: LONDON  The head of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development sought to make climate change a higher priority on the global agenda, urging the world on Wednesday to eliminate all emissions from burning fossil fuels sometime in the second half of this century.

title: Andy Pafko, Who Watched Thomsons Shot, Dies at 92
description: Andy Pafko, the All-Star outfielder who played on four teams that won the National League pennant but who also watched a once-sure Brooklyn Dodgers pennant disappear over a Polo Grounds wall in one of baseballs most memorable moments, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Stevensville, Mich. He was 92.

title: Image of the Day: October 9
The Evolution of Verizons Higher Bid for Its Wireless Unit
description: It was never a secret that Verizon Communications wanted to buy back Vodafones 45 percent stake in their enormous wireless joint venture.

title: Space, the Ultimate Destination
description: Those who have seen Sandra Bullocks harrowing adventure in Gravity and still want to travel to space will have the opportunity to win a suborbital flight through a new NBC reality series being developed by Mark Burnetts One Three Media, the company that made The Voice and Survivor, in partnership with Virgin Galactic, the commercial space venture founded by Richard Branson, the owner of the Virgin Group.

title: High-End Art, a Way to Stand Out
description: Luxury hotels have been increasingly adorning their public spaces with high-end art, but now, some are going a step further by decorating their suites with museum-quality works. The Regina Hotel Baglioni in Rome recently introduced an art exhibition in its new Roman Penthouse called Luxury Is Not a Waste, which includes 26 limited-edition pieces by contemporary Italian designers and architects like Michele de Lucchi, who have had their works displayed in museums including the Museum of Modern Art in New York and La Triennale di Milano in Milan. Also in Rome, the Rome Cavalieri has a suite with Andy Warhols Dollar Signs from 1981.

title: Downsizing a Play (as Well as Its Wigs)
description: The three-foot-tall wigs were among the first things to go, followed quickly by the collapsing wall of dirt.

title: Redskins Name Change Remains Activists Unfinished Business
description: WASHINGTON  Suzan Shown Harjo still becomes tense when she recalls the only Washington Redskins home game she attended, nearly 40 years ago.

title: Without Services, Small Businesses Feel the Pinch
description: Chris Leh, the owner of a fledgling manufacturing company in Ephrata, Pa., recently landed the kind of deal that growing companies dream about, with a major client whose order volume will triple his annual sales to around $1.5 million.

title: Shutdown Is Affecting Energy and Environmental Programs
description: As the government shutdown goes on, parts of the government related to energy and the environment are losing steam.

title: Exercise as Preventive Medicine
description: A structured exercise program may be as good or better than frequently prescribed drugs for some common cardiovascular ailments, a large meta-analysis has found.

title: A Glimpse of Yellens Career, Chronicled in Her High School Newspaper
description: She was valedictorian of the class of 1963, newspaper editor in chief, honor society inductee, psychology club member, budding scientist and rock collector. She won scholarships and prizes and studied math on Saturday mornings. She was bound for Brown University, where, she said, she would study math, anthropology or economics.

title: A Breast-Feeding Latina Mother Looking for Support
description: This summer, the British poet Hollie McNish posted a video to YouTube in which she reads one of her poems, Embarrassed. With a voice full of emotion, she speaks about nursing her infant daughter in public bathroom stalls after being shamed out of breast-feeding whenever she went out.

title: What If Theres Another Chemical Disaster?
description: The explosion at a fertilizer plant in West, Texas in April that killed 14 people and injured nearly 200 others had the force of a 2.1-magnitude earthquake. It leveled homes to ruble in a five-block radius and left a crater 93 feet wide and 10 feet deep.

title: A New Way to Pay for Long-Term Care
description: I was visiting an assisted living facility recently with my sister, whose disability made that a prudent choice, when the marketing manager handed us a brochure. It asked, Did you know a life insurance policy can pay for long-term care expenses?

title: As Pressure Mounts, House G.O.P. Weighs Short-Term Debt Deal
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans, increasingly isolated from even some of their strongest supporters more than a week into a government shutdown, began on Wednesday to consider a path out of the fiscal impasse that would raise the debt ceiling for a few weeks as they press for a broader deficit reduction deal.

title: The Wonderful and Somewhat Ugly World of Parquet Courts
description: I came to Parquet Courts late.

title: Date Is Set for 2014 Tony Awards Ceremony
description: The 2014 Tony Awards ceremony, the biggest night of the year for the Broadway theater industry, will be held on June 8 at Radio City Music Hall, organizers of the Tonys announced on Wednesday. A host for the show wasnt named; usually the host is announced in the spring. The organizers also disclosed that nominations for Tonys, which recognize actors, directors and designers as well as new musicals and plays and revivals, will be announced on April 29; to be eligible for nominations, shows will have to open by Thursday night, April 24.

title: By 2047, Coldest Years May Be Warmer Than Hottest in Past, Scientists Say
description: If greenhouse emissions continue their steady escalation, temperatures across most of the earth will rise to levels with no recorded precedent by the middle of this century, researchers said Wednesday.

title: Bill Young, Floridas Master Appropriator, to Retire
description: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, currently the longest-serving Republican in Congress, will retire in 2014, he announced Wednesday.

title: Your Dot: On Walking Dogs and Warming Trends
description: Kip Hansen, a longtime reader, and sometime critic, of Dot Earth, sent this closer look at one animated graphic I pointed to in my recent post about innovative ways to communicate about climate change. I think hes downplaying the scientific case, built on basic climate principles (everything we do know), for long-term warming, but his general point is worth exploring. Heres his Your Dot contribution:

title: Australias New Creative Commune
description: A factory space on Sydneys fringe has become a surprising center for forward-thinking local artisans.

title: Out of Position: Changing Cast in Heart of Giants Defense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants visit Chicago on Thursday night to play the Bears, a team with a rich heritage at linebacker, from Dick Butkus to Mike Singletary to Brian Urlacher.

title: Is the Shutdown Affecting Your Business?
description: As Stacy Cowley writes in an article just published in The Times, Chris Leh, the owner of a fledgling manufacturing company in Ephrata, Pa., thought he was about to triple his annual sales to around $1.5 million.

title: Further Thoughts From Paris
description: The Paris Fashion Week schedule is beginning to look as overcrowded as the New York Fashion Week schedule. With just over 100 officially sanctioned shows over nine days, the Paris collections, which ended last week, included so many designers that it became impossible for most publications to include coverage of them all.

title: Fears for Economy Kept Stimulus Intact
description: WASHINGTON  The decision by Federal Reserve officials last month to continue the stimulus campaign came down to this: their anxiety that the economy might falter outweighed their anxiety that waiting to pull back would surprise and confuse investors.

title: Nestle Is Said to Seek Buyer for Jenny Craig
description: LONDON Nestl, the Swiss food giant, is looking to sell its Jenny Craig brand, just seven years after spending $600 million to buy the weight-loss company from two private equity firms, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Clinical Trials Continue, but Only at a Crawl
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government has continued to enroll critically ill people in clinical trials at the National Institutes of Health since the government shutdown began last week, but the pace has slowed drastically, and many other sick people are having to wait for treatment.

title: A Spin in the 2014 Cadillac CTS Sedan
description: Although Cadillacs XTS  the brands flagship  gave me the impression of, say, a really, really well-appointed Toyota Camry, the CTS sedan had the opposite effect. Id heard all the hype, as well as breathy admiration from my colleagues about what a grand car the CTS-V was. And I have to say, the CTS Vsport is as they described the V: fantastic.

title: Watchdog Says Syria Has Been Cooperative on Weapons
description: GENEVA  The head of the international watchdog overseeing the destruction of Syrias chemical weapons arsenal said Wednesday that a team of 15 inspectors had begun to visit sites and that the Syrian authorities had been quite constructive and cooperative.

title: Silver Screen and LEDs Join at Last
description: The world is discovering LED lights, and for good reason. They last 25 times as long as regular bulbs, they use a fraction of the power, they dont get as hot and theyre very rugged. Theyre cropping up everywhere: in homes, flashlights, car headlights, flat-panel TV screens, movie lights and Christmas lights.

title: Good Populism, Bad Populism and the Shutdown
description: The big D.C. news today, of sorts, is Paul Ryans op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, sketching out what might be the G.O.P.s leaderships hoped-for path out of this mess: Negotiations to trade relief from the discretionary spending levels in the Budget Control Act in exchange for structural reforms to entitlement programs, presumably tied to some sort of short-term continuing resolution/debt limit lift. Notably, the piece does not mention Obamacare, which prompted much snark from pro-shutdown voices on Twitter last night, and then this broadside from Ben Domenech, prince of the libertarian populists, in this mornings edition of The Transom:

title: Israel Expresses Dismay at Cutback of U.S. Aid to Egypt
description: JERUSALEM  Officials and experts in Israel responded on Wednesday with a mixture of disappointment and alarm to the news that the United States planned to reduce its  military aid to Egypt in response to this summers brutal crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood and the continuing violence it has spawned.

title: A Deal That Needs Some Special Tailoring
description: Jos. A. Banks $2.3 billion attempt to stitch up Mens Wearhouse will be no cinch.

title: Going Contract-Free: Finding a Phone and Plan That Fit
description: Just a few years ago, buying a cellphone without a contract was both unfashionable and largely unfeasible. No-contract options were available but getting your hands on the latest phones and the best data plans usually required a two-year contract.

title: Join Us on Oct. 16 for TimesOpen: Performance
description: Youve probably heard that performance matters on the web. Youve heard that Google saw a 20% decrease in page views after increasing page load time by half a second. Youve seen studies claiming e-commerce sites can see reduced performance and revenue due to one second of latency loading a site. You know the drill: gzip, concatenate, minify, reduce page size.

title: Greenpeace Leader Offers Himself to Aid Detainees
description: MOSCOW  The executive director of Greenpeace International offered on Wednesday to travel to Russia and risk his own freedom with a possibly lengthy prison sentence, if it would help win the release on bail of the Greenpeace activists who are being held by Russia on piracy charges.

title: On Cells and Nobels: Understanding and Modeling Prize-Winning Work on Vesicles
description: Overview | What are the Nobel Prizes, why did three American biologists win this years award in Physiology or Medicine, and how can students understand and illustrate their findings? In this lesson, students study these scientists discovery of cellular transportation systems  the compartments, called vesicles, that cells use to ferry compounds from one cell to another, or to carry materials within the cell  then build models of cells, showing how these vesicles work.

title: Who Is Janet Yellen?
description: Janet L. Yellen, President Obamas pick to head the Federal Reserve, is favored by Democrats and economists alike.

title: A Conversation With Lavabits Founder
description: Ladar Levison, the founder of the secure e-mail service, spoke to The Times about his confrontation with law enforcement officials who demanded full access to his customers accounts.

title: Dinner With Friends Revival Boasts Weighty Names
description: An Off Broadway revival of Dinner With Friends, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2000 for the playwright Donald Margulies, will star four highly regarded New York stage actors, Roundabout Theater Company announced on Wednesday.

title: Skin Deep: The Fishtail Crown Braid
description: Follow these easy steps to recreate a popular runway look.

title: Boston School-Bus Drivers Return to Work Amid Uncertainty
description: BOSTON  School-bus drivers returned to work Wednesday after a surprise daylong work stoppage that left thousands of schoolchildren stranded at home and at bus stops.

title: Braids 2.0
description: Braids have returned to the runways and are showing their staying power.

title: Cosmetics Sending Some Money Toward Breast Cancer Causes
description: It is National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and the disease is a major cause of the cosmetics industry. Here are some products intended to raise awareness and some money.

title: Braids Woven to Each Personality
description: Rihanna with a cascading fishtail side braid. Eva Chen, the editor in chief of Lucky magazine, on Instagram with her purple locks woven into a slightly tousled crown braid. Allison Williams at an Emmys weekend party in a complicated French braid.

title: For Girardi, Its 4 More Seasons in Pinstripes
description: When he was a third grader in Illinois in the 1970s, Joe Girardi said, he wrote a school paper about how he would one day play for the Chicago Cubs. Years later, after Girardi had achieved that goal, many people wondered whether the team of his boyhood dreams might lure him from the Yankees to be the manager on Chicagos North Side.

title: Maverick and Scavenger
description: A Mike Kelley retrospective completely fills MoMA PS1.

title: From the Screen, Quirks and All
description: Am I wrong to find it slightly unfortunate (and utterly inevitable) that William Finn, a brilliant composer and lyricist who specializes in gently funny and heartfelt small-scale musicals, is doing a movie adaptation? Probably. After all, there are many great movies turned into musicals, and such cultural borrowing and translating has been part of the art form since the start. And the 2006 indie hit Little Miss Sunshine does seem like a nice fit for Mr. Finn. Who better than the creator of Falsettoland to reinvent for the stage an intimate, quirky film about family and misfits that proves that a little sweet sentimentality can be a wonderful thing?

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Escape From Tomorrow
description: Randy Moore, the writer and director of Escape From Tomorrow, narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Keeping Score: It Was All Hands (and Arms) on Deck for Ousted Rays
description: The Tampa Bay Rays were facing elimination from the playoffs for the fourth time in nine days, but Manager Joe Maddon was not going to go out quietly. If it meant using his entire pitching staff and a kitchen sink or two, he was more than willing.

title: Announcing Fed Nomination, Obama Praises Yellen
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday announced what he called perhaps his most important economic decision, nominating Janet L. Yellen to lead the Federal Reserve system and be his independent co-steward of the economy, calling her one of the nations foremost economists and policy makers.

title: Republicans Using Shutdown to Stake Positions for Potential 2016 Bids
description: During the federal government shutdown, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has appeared guided by one goal: sticking as close as possible to Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

title: Prepaid Debit Cards Shed Some Fees, but Face Scrutiny
description: Prepaid debit cards continue to grow more popular and offer more services that mimic traditional debit cards, even as the federal government weighs new rules for the cards.

title: Financial Times to Consolidate Print Editions
description: LONDON  The Financial Times, signaling a tighter focus on digital publishing, plans to stop printing regional editions and produce only a single global daily newspaper.

title: Timberlake Nets Second No. 1 Album This Year
description: The final installment of Justin Timberlakes two-part 20/20 Experience (RCA) has jumped onto Billboards album chart at No. 1, displacing Drakes Nothing Was the Same (Young Money/Cash Money/Republic) and giving Mr. Timberlake his second chart-topping album of the year.

title: Better Access to Contraceptives for Parents Means Better Outcomes for Children
description: Whats the long-term impact of access to birth control and family planning? The economist Martha J. Bailey pulled together decades of data and research on families surrounding two major policy changes in the United States: laws banning the sale of contraceptives and their repeal, and the expansion of federal funding for local family-planning clinics during the Johnson and Nixon administrations. She writes:

title: $60 Million Gift to Establish Fellowships at Juilliard
description: Time was when a conservatory students main worry was about finding a job, either as a soloist or in a chamber group or an orchestra, after graduation. These days, many of them fear that even if they do, they will be unable to repay the student loans that helped finance their training.

title: Bail for Pakistani Ex-Leader Paves Way for His Exit
description: A Pakistani court granted bail on Wednesday to Pervez Musharraf, the countrys former military ruler, clearing the way for him to leave the country as early as Thursday, his lawyers said.

title: Giambattista Valli: Looking Beyond the Clothes
description: Giambattista Vallis career is a little young to be the subject of a coffee-table book. He started his signature label only in 2005 and became a couturier two years ago, so how to fill the nearly 400-page book ($100) being published this month from Rizzoli?

title: Man Trades Elmo Costume for a Jail Suit
description: Elmo bad. Elmo go to jail.

title: A Conversation With Lavabits Founder
description: For nearly a decade, Ladar Levison ran Lavabit, a secure e-mail service that served as an alternative for a tech-savvy crowd that cared about privacy. Then, last July, after two months of haggling with the F.B.I., Mr. Levison shuttered the service rather than give the government untrammeled access to his users communications and everything he had built.

title: Chicago Symphony to Stream Performance of Verdis Requiem Online
description: Lots of people love the Verdi Requiem.

title: The Hurdles Ahead for a Cooper Tire Deal
description: Cooper Tire and Rubber is heading perilously close to a collision in its just-commenced legal battle with Apollo Tyres.

title: Madoff Trustee Asks Supreme Court to Let Him Sue Banks
description: Updated, 7:27 p.m. | The trustee seeking to recover money for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to review a ruling that prohibits him from suing several of the worlds largest banks that he contends aided the fraud.

title: Trash Bags You Wont Throw Out
description: Derelicte is really happening.

title: Death Benefits for Soldiers to Continue
description: WASHINGTON  Pentagon officials said Wednesday that they would contract with a charity group, the Fisher House Foundation, to restore death benefits to families of service members killed in action, including a $100,000 payment, that have been stopped by the government shutdown. The officials said the Pentagon would reimburse the group after the shutdown ended.

title: Pictures of the Day: Delaware and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Delaware, Syria, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: Manufacture New York Provides Production Facilities to Independent Designers
description: Almost a year to the day since she began pitching the idea for Manufacture New York, a work hive for independent designers with outposts in Brooklyn and Manhattan, Bob Bland was on the verge of opening the doors to the first iteration of her vision. We gut-renovated this space with our bare hands, she said one afternoon last month, casting her gaze over a 2,000-square-foot space at 23 West 36th Street that she is branding the Garment Center Pilot Program. Although now I hear theyre rebranding as the garment district, which means well have to redo all our branding.

title: Megyn Kelly Draws a Bigger, Younger Audience on Night 2 in Prime Time
description: In an impressive turnaround, Megyn Kelly, Fox News new prime-time host, reversed a somewhat disappointing performance on her first night at the center of the networks lineup, scoring a smashing win across the board on Night 2.

title: Dressed to Celebrate a Night for Nudity
description: Perhaps predictably, there was a lot of nudity at the Take Home a Nude benefit Tuesday night at Sothebys, where art was being auctioned to raise funds for the New York Academy of Art. Still, it took Sophie Portale a minute to figure out what was going on in a work by Lola Montes Schnabel.

title: Scene City: Getting Undressed for Art
description: The New York Academy of Art held its annual Take Home a Nude benefit.

title: G.M. to Recall Some 2014 Full-Size Pickups for Seat Problem
description: General Motors will recall almost 19,000 of its new 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra pickups because some front seats may not meet a federal safety standard, the automaker said in a news release Wednesday.

title: Ford, Playing Catch-Up in China, Sees Sales Jump 51 Percent
description: Even as the Ford Motor Company has rebounded from the recession to become the most profitable of the big three American automakers, it has lagged in China, the worlds biggest car market.

title: A New Danger for Democrats: Boehners Delegation
description: Speaker John Boehner isnt taking the House Tea Party coalition with him to the White House on Thursday. Though President Obama invited the entire Republican caucus to discuss the budget crisis, Mr. Boehner is only bringing 17 others along. Perhaps he was worried about misbehavior, or maybe some on the hard right  deathly afraid of being branded a collaborator with a man they call a socialist  wouldnt be caught dead in Mr. Obamas home.

title: Director of British Domestic Intelligence Agency Defends Spying Policies
description: LONDON  Warning that there are thousands of Islamic extremists who view British citizens as legitimate targets, the chief of Britains domestic intelligence agency, MI5, said this week that recent leaks about government spying capabilities had caused enormous damage, handing the advantage to the terrorists.

title: Kerry, in Asia, Urges Focus on Law in China Disputes
description: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei  Secretary of State John Kerry encouraged Southeast Asian leaders on Wednesday in their efforts to resolve maritime disputes with China based on international legal principles, rather than by making individual deals as China would prefer.

title: 36 Hours in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina
description: At midday in Sarajevo, muezzins call from minarets as church bells echo through the Dinaric Alps. Street cars rumble past hookah smokers and cafegoers. Chic women click-clack down cobbled alleyways. The citys charisma is intoxicating, but the hustle and bustle belies a tragic past. In 1992, Bosnia-Herzegovinas capital went from a beacon of diversity, with Yugoslav Muslims, Christians and Jews worshiping within feet of one other, to the site of a nearly four-year siege claiming more than 11,000 lives. But much has changed over the last decade or so. The creative spirit that Sarajevans fought to preserve is very much in evidence these days. Neighborhoods, cradled in this valley and ringing the foothills, are fertile entrepreneurial grounds and a testament to the epochs that came before. Cafes, theaters, boutiques and restaurants have sprouted among buildings in myriad styles, including Ottoman, Secessionist, Communist and modern. And locals and visitors alike are rediscovering the surrounding mountains on the slopes that hosted the 1984 Winter Olympic Games.

title: Sarajevo Scenes
description: Eat, drink and shop during a tour of the capital.

title: Trips to Ancient Iraq
description: Steppes Travel, a London-based company specializing in high-end cultural and archaeological tours, recently announced that it is offering two trips next year to the Kurdish city of Erbil in northern Iraq.
