title: Emma Thompson to Join Philharmonics Sweeney Todd
description: Following a year-end movie season in which she will play P. L. Travers, the surprisingly tough creator of Mary Poppins, Emma Thompson will pick up her umbrella and alight on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall, where she will play a murderous London shop proprietor who serves up surprisingly tough meat pies.

title: The Soulful High-Tech Wizard
description: Alone onstage Tuesday evening at the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Jorge Drexler sang in Spanish, There are so many things/I only need two: My guitar and you. The song was Guitarra y Vos (Guitar and You). Vos can double as a pun on voz, or voice. When he stepped to the front of the stage to sing other songs, away from the microphones, his guitar and voice were indeed all Mr. Drexler needed in the intimate hall. He didnt even need the guitar when he sang his Academy Award-winning song from The Motorcycle Diaries, Al Otro Lado del Rio, a cappella.

title: Want to Meet Influential New Yorkers? Invite Them to Dinner
description: Jonathan Levy was standing on the coffee table in his spacious Upper West Side apartment, holding up a bottle of Lagavulin 16 like a trophy. It was after midnight on a Wednesday last month and the living room was packed with chief executives, designers, philanthropists and TV personalities.

title: Rainbows Im Inclined to Pursue
description: Swaggering across the stage of Frederick P. Rose Hall toting bottles of Jack Daniels and cracking dirty jokes, the Rat Pack commandeered the second night of the 2013 New York Cabaret Convention on Tuesday evening. Chasing away Nol Coward, Cole Porter and their fancy society friends, they ring-a-ding-dinged until daylight.

title: Feeling For | The Warm, Rough Comforts of Wool
description: Nubby, fleecy or boucl, creamy textured wool is cozier and more durable than the beige Belgian linen that designers have grown so fond of. Ideal for furniture, these fabrics nod to vintage Chanel suits and childhood teddy bears but still feel luxuriously modern.

title: House Republicans Argue for Delay in Health Law Penalties
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans said Wednesday that chaos in the first nine days of open enrollment under President Obamas health care law would justify a delay in major provisions of the law, including tax penalties for people who go without insurance in 2014.

title: Pakistani Taliban Leader Talks Peace and Frolics on Camera
description: The BBC journalist who traveled to Pakistans northwestern tribal areas this month to interview the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, as drones hovered overhead, made it back to Islamabad with the sound bites he was after, but something unexpected too  footage of the militant at play, frolicking on a riverbank.

title: Shopping Events in New York Beginning Oct. 10
description: Openings

title: Jennifer Rubell: Two Legacies, Now Home to Roost
description: The first time Jennifer Rubell gave a dinner party, at age 9, a guest (a friend of her parents who was a diamond dealer) followed up the next morning with a thank-you gift: a heart-shaped diamond ring. Since then, Ms. Rubell, now 43, has worked as a hotelier, a food writer and an artist, but at heart she has remained a hostess.

title: Catastrophe by the Spoonful
description: As a book about a cinematic comedy of errors, The Disaster Artist is much better than the mess of a movie it describes. That movie is The Room, which has gone all but unnoticed on the East Coast until lately but developed a West Coast following after its sickly 2003 release.

title: PC Shipments: It Could Have Been Worse (and Probably Will Be)
description: The new personal computer sales numbers are out from the analysis firm IDC. Which bad news/good news would you like first?

title: Shutdown or No, Shes Still Busy Fixing Washington
description: The scolding, cadenced admonitions rolling out of Olivia Pope  crisis handler, presidential girlfriend and major buzzkill  were a sign of continuity in last Thursdays Season 3 premiere of ABCs Scandal, an episode that was patchy and transitional but drew a series-record 10.5 million viewers.

title: What Economists Think About a Possible Debt Default
description: As my colleague Jonathan Weisman wrote on the front page of Wednesdays editions, some Republican leaders are arguing that a debt default would not be so terrible. Economists do not agree.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Escape From Tomorrow
description: The Magic Kingdom isnt always magical in Randy Moores comedy Escape From Tomorrow. The film, which had its debut in January at Sundance and is being released in theaters and on-demand Friday, was shot partially in the Disneyland and Walt Disney World parks. In this video, Mr. Moore narrates a scene where the ride Space Mountain causes some family problems.

title: TV Talk: The DVR Dilemma
description: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss how viewers using DVRs make it difficult to judge a shows success.

title: Canadians Stuck in Egyptian Legal Limbo Thank Supporters via YouTube
description: Two Canadians who were detained in Cairo during the deadly security crackdown in August and are still barred from leaving the country despite their release last week posted a message of thanks to their supporters on YouTube on Wednesday.

title: For City Ballet, Future Is Now
description: The usual rule is that a ballets original cast is never surpassed. Though its first dancers may grow better over the years, as they understand the choreography more completely, it was tailor-made to display their particular gifts. Yet there are a number of cases with todays New York City Ballet where older audience members have been asking: Was it really this good back then?

title: U.S. vs. Poles at Transnational Teams Quarterfinal
description: We have reached the last board of the Transnational Teams world championship quarterfinal between Mark Gordon, Pratap Rajadhyaksha, David Berkowitz, Alan Sontag, Jacek Pszczola and Michael Seamon from the United States and the Polish Students team: Stanislaw Golebiowski, Piotr Tuczynski, Pawel Jassem, Jakub Wojcieszek, Michal Klukowski and Piotr Zatorski. The Saturday and Monday columns described other boards from this exciting set, in which more than 5 international match points per board were exchanged.

title: Barclays Names Head of Americas Banking
description: Barclays has reshuffled the leadership of its investment banking team in the Americas, including giving a top industrial and private equity banker a new prominent role.

title: Oh Boy, Looks Like Reggie and Billy Are at It Again
description: Great theater can make an audience feel new things, perhaps reassess long-held beliefs. It turns out that bad theater can achieve that, too. As a lifelong Mets fan, I never thought I could pity the Yankees. But thanks to Bronx Bombers, I do.

title: Yellen Named as Obama's Choice for Fed
description: Janet L. Yellen, 67, would be the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve if the Senate confirms her nomination for a four-year term.

title: Obama Announces Pick to Lead the Fed
description: President Obama said Wednesday that his choice to head the Federal Reserve was its current vice chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen.

title: Loss of 22 World Cup Bid Still Rankles Head of U.S. Soccer
description: It has been three years, but FIFAs decision to award the 2022 World Cup to Qatar still smarts for Sunil Gulati.

title: Like Vines, Reaching, Twining, Curling
description: The veteran choreographer Lar Lubovitch, an art major before he discovered modern dance, has spoken about how he sees the stage as a canvas. Instead of using brush strokes to give a painting a sense of momentum, he relies on bodies that ripple through space, pause to crest and then sweep lushly in another direction. When they succeed, Mr. Lubovitchs dances are visceral paintings come to life.

title: Listen Up | An Avant-Garde Artist Makes a Bid for Pop Stardom
description: Alexis Georgopoulos took the moniker under which he makes music, Arp, from a defunct manufacturer of analog synthesizers. It was a fitting name for the kind of music the 39-year-old, New York-based artist made on the albums In Light (2007) and The Soft Wave (2010): instrumental outings with minimalist repetition and exploratory electronics that owed more to minimalist composers like Steve Reich and Philip Glass than anything resembling pop music. But on his new album, More, it becomes clear from the opening strains of the first track, High-Heeled Clouds a dreamy ballad featuring breathy vocals, melodic keyboard lines and a hooky chorus  that Georgopoulos is taking the music in a more tuneful direction.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Googles Anti-Aging Start-Up, and the Man Tied to Silk Road
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Alice Lives Between Fantasy and Reality
description: If I get high enough, I can see the Hatters house, Alice says in the premiere on Thursday night of ABCs Once Upon a Time in Wonderland. If we could get high enough, maybe we could see some reason to sit through this Disneyfied pastiche of Lewis Carroll and 1,001 Nights. Or maybe not.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Park Delicatessen
description: In Crown Heights, a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop attracts a varied customer base.

title: Blurring Boundaries, Sharpening Ideas
description: The term transdisciplinary is heard a great deal. But what does it actually mean? Does it go beyond using text in your dance piece, or video in your play? Does its very nature ask artists to question our understanding of genre, or to destabilize what it is that audiences think they are seeing?

title: Investigating a Grudge During a Day in Berkeley
description: Ive long held a grudge against graduates of the University of California, Berkeley. As the graduate of a pricey private university in the wintry northeast, Ive never been able to shake the uneasy feeling that they got a similar education at a fraction of the cost in far nicer weather.

title: So I Told Hitler and Other Film Re-Enactments
description: A film festival that includes a pair of Weimar-influenced pre-code Hollywood musicals, three classic cartoons by John and Faith Hubley and a 1936 docudrama in which an American re-enacts her imprisonment in Nazi Germany might fairly be called eclectic. Or it might be called To Save and Project, as the Museum of Modern Art titles its annual survey of recently restored movies, which returned this week for its 11th edition. Organized by Joshua Siegel, an associate curator in the museums film department, the festival has a sweeping nature that suggests how much work is being done to reclaim film history  and how much more needs to be done. This years program contains some 75 feature films and shorts from archives around the world.

title: Not a Teachable Moment, but a Respectful One
description: Glee isnt just another comedy about the horrors of high school. Now in its fifth season, this cheeky Fox show has become a cabaret-meets-after-school-special that sneaks in as many life lessons as it does pop songs. In a recent episode, there was even a reminder about the importance of meningitis vaccines.

title: Reincarnation of Treasured Instrument
description: This was a sound no musician should have to suffer: the destruction of her longtime instrument. In Wu Mans case, in June, it was a loud crack, heard from her seat as a flight attendant, trying to stow her pipa in a coat closet up front, dropped it, breaking its neck.

title: After an Introduction by de Blasio, a Brooklyn Hospital Hired His Wife
description: Sometime around 2005, a Brooklyn city councilman introduced his wife, who was looking for a new job, to the head of a hospital in his district.

title: Meredith Whitney Appears to Be Trading Brokerage Firm for Investment Fund
description: Meredith A. Whitney appears poised to leave the industry that lifted her to fame.

title: Wu Man Plays the Pipa
description: The musician performs a piece on her pipa, a traditional Chinese instrument.

title: Polls Show Growing Concerns About Shutdown
description: More than a week into the government shutdown, a number of new polls have found rising exasperation with a dysfunctional government and economic concern, as well as disagreement about the debt limit and how Congress should handle it.

title: Video Offers Glimpse of Russias Ban on Gay Propaganda in Action on a Moscow Street
description: Video recorded this week during the arrest of gay rights activists in Moscow shows what Russias legal ban on propaganda for nontraditional sexual relationships looks like in practice.

title: No Pastrami, but Skateboards and Zinnias
description: Michael J. Sclafani and Valentine Leung didnt exactly set out to open a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop.

title: Artisanal Housewares
description: Conscientious shoppers may prefer to buy socially responsible design  objects produced in a way that promotes the well-being of the artisans in Third World countries who make them  but the products have not always been easy to find or sophisticated enough to satisfy the tastes of some consumers. In recent years, however, that has begun to change, as collaborations between designers and artisans have flourished.

title: Start Spreadin the News
description: The Viceroy New York, a 29-story brick hotel at 120 West 57th Street, is the latest and largest building designed by the architectural studio Roman & Williams. And it is filled with its signature touches, like shiny black fluted Italian glass block, crown molding, ultra-veined marble and a strategic use of brass. Rooms are well-appointed modernist cabins in the sky, said Robin Standefer, a founder of the firm. Over all, the hotel reflects a narrative that is artistic, refined and glamorous  a way of looking at Uptown, and 57th Street in particular, that seems to have been lost in the last 20 years, she said.

title: If Its All About Location, Does the Sky Count?
description: For many, a treehouse signifies questionable construction and freedom from adult supervision. But the projects in Tree Houses (Skyhorse Publishing, $50) show how a childs hideaway has experienced a renaissance in material, sophistication and design. The Copper Cube, for instance, a metal-clad guesthouse in Germany, sits on stilts and has electricity and even a full bath. In Sweden, a saucer-shaped enclosure tied to trees with cables and aptly called the UFO is accessible via a retractable take-me-to-your-leader staircase. But traditionalists, fear not: there are plenty of fairytale-like cottages, too.

title: Not Built in a Day
description: When David Nosanchuk wandered around Rome with a camera a couple of years ago, he didnt realize he was making wallpaper. But Mr. Nosanchuk, a New York designer, had been invited to contribute ideas to Flavor Paper, a Brooklyn producer of avant-garde wallcoverings. And at some point he saw potential in his luminous prints of the Pantheon and Berninis Colonnade at St. Peters Basilica.

title: A One-of-a-Kind, From Sketch to Auction
description: On Nov. 23, Sothebys New York will host an auction of items selected by the designer Marc Newson and Apples senior vice president for design, Jonathan Ive, to benefit (RED), the charity founded by Bono and Bobby Shriver. Mr. Newson described the 40-odd lots as stuff we ourselves would kill to have, including an anodized aluminum desk that he designed with Mr. Ive for the occasion.

title: Discounts at Vermont Woods, DwellStudio, De La Espada and Lumens
description: Vermont Woods furniture is 15 percent off, Friday to Tuesday (a queen-size Modern Incline bed, regularly $2,394, will be about $2,035); (888) 390-5571, vermontwoodsstudios.com.

title: Light up the Cigars: Its a Chair
description: The Museum of Arts and Design, known as MAD, takes another leap beyond its origins in traditional craft with Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital, an exhibition of new technologies that dominate many of todays conversations about design. The show, which opens on Wednesday and runs through July 6, will present objects created through 3-D printing, digital weaving and computer-controlled milling. Included alongside the forward-thinking work of well-known designers like Ron Arad, Zaha Hadid and Maya Lin is a project by the Dutch-born designer Jan Habraken that represents his attempt to breed the ultimate chair. Mr. Habraken, is the founder of FormNation, a New York company. Recently he met a reporter in his Manhattan studio to discuss the concept of chair eugenics, or chairgenics. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: A Bit Tori and Dean
description: A Park Slope Victorian goes Hollywood mod.

title: The Circuitous Route Home
description: Even for Park Slope, the house is a showstopper, blooming with intricate mahogany paneling inlaid with mother-of-pearl, and nestled into a block just a few streets away from P.S. 321, the much-coveted elementary school.

title: The Architecture of Autism
description: SONOMA, Calif.  Here is a truth about children with autism: they grow up to become adults with autism. Advocates estimate that over the next decade some 500,000 such individuals will come of age in the United States.

title: Peace, Purpose and a Pool
description: Sweetwater Spectrum, a California residence for autistic adults, hopes to become a model for like-minded experiments across the country.

title: T-Mobile to Make It Cheaper to Make Calls While Abroad
description: Cellphone plans are a little like languages: they dont always translate well in foreign countries.

title: Europe Pledges Aid to Italy for Refugees
description: ROME  The European Unions top official on Wednesday visited the Italian island of Lampedusa, where a crowded boat capsized last week, killing hundreds of migrants, and announced that Italy would receive an additional 30 million euros, or $40.5 million, from the union to help deal with refugees.

title: Longtime Florida Congressman to Retire
description: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the longest-serving Republican in Congress, said Wednesday that he would retire in 2014. Its my time, Mr. Young, 82, told The Tampa Bay Times. He has long served on the Appropriations Committee, including a stint as chairman from 1999 to 2005, and is known for bringing millions of dollars to his district. A moderate Republican, Mr. Young came to Congress in 1971, at a time when most Southern conservatives were still Democrats. He said that he admires the spirit of Tea Party Republicans, but is a little disappointed with the current gridlock.

title: Big-Money Manipulators
description: The dysfunction in Washington is incredibly dispiriting.

title: For Journalists Who Seek Out Hidden Things, a More Visible Brand
description: A leading nonprofit organization in the field of investigative journalism is getting a free branding and advertising campaign, courtesy of a leading creative agency.

title: Paul McCartney Makes Surprise Stop in Queens
description: A half-century after Beatlemania swept Britain, Paul McCartney faced squealing teenage girls once again when he performed on Wednesday afternoon in the Tony Bennett Concert Hall at the Frank Sinatra School of the Arts in Astoria, Queens. They didnt scream all the way through the songs, as their grandparents might have, but they stayed on their feet  clapping, waving their arms, singing along  through oldies like Eight Days a Week, Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da, We Can Work It Out and Blackbird.

title: Cutbacks in U.N. Food Assistance Set Off Outcry in Gaza
description: GAZA  Hundreds of women and children protested cutbacks in a United Nations food-assistance program on Wednesday, the latest in a growing backlash by Palestinian refugees and their offspring in this forlorn coastal strip against the agency that for decades has provided them with nutrition, education and health services.

title: Struck by the Wish to Own
description: Alison Ehrmann lived in the quintessential brownstone on a quiet block on far West 100th Street. Her one-bedroom rental had high ceilings, exposed brick and a tiny kitchen. Her rent was $2,000 a month, just $200 more than when she moved in nine years ago. I had great landlords, and they really valued good tenants, she said.

title: Risk to Food Safety Seen in Furloughs
description: WASHINGTON  The government shutdown is endangering what America eats, food safety experts said this week, as all inspections of domestic food except meat and poultry have halted and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recalled furloughed workers to handle a salmonella outbreak that sickened hundreds of people in 18 states.

title: A Winner, to Get You There
description: I was a bit disappointed when I saw that  Citymapper had won the 2013 Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys App Quest competition when the results came out a couple of weeks back. Judging by its name, I figured it was just another piece of utilitarian software to help people figure out the city. I was hoping that the winner of the competition, held for apps that complement the transit experience, would be imaginative, like the runner-up, Subculture.FM. Not something so brusque, so practical, so obvious as a map.

title: Giants (0-5) at Bears (3-2)
description: Thursday, 8:25 p.m.

title: A Russian Region Neither at War Nor at Peace, but Facing a Crackdown
description: MAKHACHKALA, Russia  The race lasted only a few seconds and ended with the sound of a gunshot. Shamil Abdulayev, who was 24 years old at the time, had tried to run away from a group of men he knew were bent on abducting him. They wore ski masks and traveled in a white Lada sedan with tinted windows.

title: Real Estate Boom in Phoenix Brings Its Own Problems
description: PHOENIX  Here, where the housing market endured one of the hardest crashes anywhere during the recession, the rebound has come faster than in most parts of the country, fueled by a vigorous job market, a sturdy rise in home values and an all-around sense that the worst of times is in the distant past.

title: Future Look of Citys Cab Fleet Uncertain
description: If there is a heaven for iconic taxicabs, with a sneering Travis Bickle at the pearly gates, New York City is almost certainly its top feeder market.

title: California Expands Availability of Abortions
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday expanded access to abortion in California, signing a bill to allow nurse practitioners, midwives and physician assistants to perform a common type of the procedure, an aspiration abortion, during the first trimester.

title: Blitzer Causes Stir With Comments on Health Care
description: The CNN anchor Wolf Blitzer put himself into the middle of the political warfare over the Affordable Care Act onWednesday when he said on the air that the Obama administration should accept the advice that a lot of Republicans are giving them and delay the start of the program for a year.

title: Government Standoff Shakes Trust in U.S. Debt
description: In good times and bad, the worlds financial system has long been able to rely on one thing: that the United States government would pay back its debt on time.

title: Researchers Press for Broad Ban on Hockey Fights
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  Researchers at a Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey called Wednesday for a ban on fighting at all levels of the sport, eight days after a Montreal Canadiens enforcer was hospitalized because of a fight on opening night of the N.H.L. season.

title: The Yellen Fed? Precise and Predictable
description: There are no fast rules for running the Federal Reserve, but Janet L. Yellen has a few.

title: A Cupboard of My Own
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  At the start of the 1960s, my parents bought a corner shop and moved into the house above it with their five children. Ten years later, I, the accidental sixth, was born. By the time I was 9, my brother and sisters had grown up and either temporarily or permanently moved out, leaving behind them a museum of abandoned items. Cluttering every shelf and corner were forgotten cardigans, orphaned dolls, discarded purses and grayscale strips of pouting photo-booth faces.

title: In a Polluted Stream, a Pathway to Peace
description: MORRO BAY, Calif.  PEACE talks are under way again in Jerusalem. If the past is any guide, the two sides are stymied over difficult issues like settlements and borders. The negotiators badly need a new approach, and one is right beneath their feet, in the Kidron Valley, the deep ravine that runs from the Old City through the West Bank toward the Dead Sea.

title: First, the Good News
description: Good news: The people who track killer asteroids for NASA are still on the case, despite the government shutdown.

title: Gang of 40
description: In the 1970s, in its days of hard-line Communist isolation, China was ruled by the extremist Gang of Four. Drivers then were sometimes encouraged to proceed at red lights because red was the revolutionary color signifying advance  resulting in a chaos that was emblematic of the times.

title: Protecting the Speech We Hate
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  SHOULD one-on-one advice and counseling be protected as free speech? It sounds like a no-brainer. Of course it should be. But a recent decision by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit says otherwise.

title: For America, Life Was Cheap in Vietnam
description: OBITUARIES of Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese general who helped drive the American military from his country, noted, as The New York Times put it, that his critics said that his victories had been rooted in a profligate disregard for the lives of his soldiers.

description: Once home to Benjamin Franklin and Betsy Ross, Philadelphias Old City now hosts an assortment of design and fashion boutiques.

title: As Drilling Practice Takes Off in U.S., Europe Proves Hesitant
description: LONDON  France and Bulgaria have already banned it, and in Britain the governments attempts to promote it have led to heated demonstrations in the countryside. It is complicating Germanys attempts to wean itself from fossil fuels and forcing Russia to recalibrate the energy-export strategy that sustains its economy.

title: Charges Upgraded Against Police Detective in Motorcyclists Attack on S.U.V.
description: Prosecutors on Wednesday upgraded the charges against an undercover New York City police detective, saying he terrorized a family when he punched and kicked their sport utility vehicle as a group of motorcyclists he was with assaulted the driver after chasing the vehicle down.

title: Chairwoman Janet Yellen
description: President Obama was wise to nominate Janet Yellen, vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, to be the Feds next leader. As a deeply respected economist, she will bring two vital attributes to that role as a steward of the economy.

title: Cory Booker for the U.S. Senate in New Jersey
description: On Wednesday, New Jersey voters will go to the polls to choose a United States senator, replacing the late Frank Lautenberg. Mayor Cory Booker of Newark, a moderate Democrat, is running against an extremely conservative Republican, Steven Lonegan. Mr. Booker is far and away the better candidate to serve the needs of his entire state and to provide a national voice for the less fortunate across America.

title: Monitoring Your Every Move
description: You may have even less privacy than you thought.

title: Four Square Blocks: Philadelphia
description: Design shops and galleries enliven Philadelphias Old City, whose Colonial roots are just one part of the story.

title: Ex-Director of Charity Is Charged in Theft
description: The daughter of a founder of a South Bronx housing and social service organization was arrested on Wednesday on charges that she stole nearly $900,000 from the group to pay for personal expenses, including a new $29,000 Toyota Sienna and trips to department stores, jewelry stores, nail salons and movie theaters.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 9, 2013
Penny Harvest Charitable Group to Stay Afloat With City Money
description: New York Citys penny harvest will live to see another year of children collecting a small fortune in stray pennies and then discussing how to dispense it to help the sick and the bereft.

title: The Curious Curse of the Oakland As
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The line was buried deep in Moneyball: The Art of Winning an Unfair Game, but it still taunts the Oakland Athletics, 10 years after Michael Lewiss best seller was published.

title: To Neighboring Restaurants, Shutdown Rules Are Nothing if Not Arbitrary
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Perched on an ocean bluff just up the street from the historic Cliff House, Louis diner has always taken a back seat to its neighbor.

title: In Dugout, a Grinder Who Never Gave In
description: ST. LOUIS  Jeff Banister sat alone in the Pirates dugout after batting practice Monday in Pittsburgh. He is always at home there, in the hours before a game, basking in the silence and the scenery of a life he was never supposed to live.

title: In Another Early Cancellation, CBS Sheds We Are Men
description: The CBS comedy We Are Men late Wednesday became the second new-season entry to get a quick hook as CBS announced it was canceling the show.

title: Rodriguez at Center of a Different Kind of Postseason Drama
description: October is traditionally a month of clarity for baseball fans as a long season gives way to the sports high point, the World Series.

title: Are Casinos Too Much of a Gamble?
Polish Plan on Pensions Arouses Sharp Criticism
description: The Polish government is expected to release details of its plan to transfer back to the state $47.6 billion worth of government bonds held by privately managed funds that invest retirement money on behalf of Poles.

title: Florida Defends New Effort to Clean Up Voter Rolls
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla.  Paving the way for a new attempt to remove noncitizens from voter rolls, Floridas election chief tried to stoke confidence on Wednesday in the revamped plan before a largely skeptical crowd in immigrant-heavy South Florida.

title: Corrections: October 10, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: All the Time
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Jeffrey Wechsler is slowly establishing himself as a midweek constructor, and today he has a very timely puzzle for us in the sense that it deals with the days of the week. More specifically, its a representation of how people recorded their appointments prior to the invention of smartphones. (Yes, I know there are some people out there who dont own smartphones. Please dont send angry e-mails.)

title: Business Groups See Loss of Sway Over House G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  As the government shutdown grinds toward a potential debt default, some of the countrys most influential business executives have come to a conclusion all but unthinkable a few years ago: Their voices are carrying little weight with the House majority that their millions of dollars in campaign contributions helped build and sustain.

title: Friends, Romans, Countrywomen
description: A womans touch has not softened the hard and mighty Julius Caesar. On the contrary, the gripping, all-female, London-born production that opened on Wednesday night at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn has a muscular strength and ferocity guaranteed to keep everyone in the theater in sustained fight-or-flight mode.

title: A Novel Prompts a Conversation About How We Use Technology
description: Has Dave Eggers written a parable of our time, an eviscerating takedown of Silicon Valley and its privacy-invading technology companies?

title: Partly by Shunning Documentary, ESPN Lifts It
description: In August, ESPN pulled its name and logo from League of Denial, a Frontline documentary about how the N.F.L. handled  or, more appropriately, mishandled  the concussion crisis among its players. ESPNs decision came seven weeks before the documentary was scheduled to run and ended a 15-month collaboration with Frontline that had already produced nine separate reports.

title: Searching for the Father of Baby Hope
description: The detectives searching for Baby Hopes killer have been tracking down her fathers relatives for about a week and are hopeful the family members can provide more leads, a person with knowledge of the matter said Wednesday.

title: Extremist Group Gains Foothold Among Kenyans
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  When the United States tried to capture a powerful militant in Somalia last weekend, it did not go after the leader of the Shabab extremist group, but a Kenyan national whose ties were as much in his native country as in the Horn of Africa.

title: Paul Desmarais, Canadian Magnate, Dies at 86
description: Paul Desmarais, who transformed a bankrupt bus line in a Canadian mining center into an international conglomerate with $527 billion in assets and, in the process, became one of his countrys most powerful businessmen, died on Tuesday at his country estate in the Charlevoix region of Quebec. He was 86.

title: The Treasurys Dwindling Cash Supply
description: Since May, the Treasury has been employing a set of extraordinary measures, to free up cash to pay its bills. Once these measures are exhausted, the Treasury will have to rely on revenues and its cash on hand until they are also exhausted.

title: Tracing the Calendar Down to the Last Cent
description: WASHINGTON  Oct. 17 is the day the Treasury Department expects to exhaust its so-called extraordinary measures to keep paying the countrys bills, putting it on the precipice of default. But officials in Washington and traders on Wall Street have a second, yet more dire deadline in mind: Nov. 1.

title: Shumpert Looks Sharp in Bid as Shooting Guard
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  There was intrigue on the court, if not exactly tightrope theatrics.

title: Fairness an Issue, Even After Azerbaijan Votes
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  The slogan of Jamil Hasanlis long-shot campaign to unseat Azerbaijans longtime president, Ilham Aliyev, in elections on Wednesday was Enough! Or, more specifically, as the red and white stickers plastered all over his headquarters and around this capital city made clear: enough corruption, enough monarchy, enough unemployment, enough stolen oil money, enough low-quality education and health services, enough disrespectful officials, and enough war over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh.

title: More Malala Malaise
description: LONDON  This is a big week for Malala Yousafzai. It has been exactly a year since the Pakistani Taliban tried to assassinate her for championing education for girls. On Tuesday her memoir was released worldwide. And she is a favorite for this years Nobel Peace Prize, which is to be announced Friday.

title: Peacekeeping by U.N. Faces New Scrutiny on 2 Fronts
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations was hit with a double dose of scrutiny over its accountability practices on Wednesday, charged in a lawsuit with gross negligence in Haitis deadly cholera epidemic, and accused by an anticorruption organization of oversight lapses in its own peacekeeping operations around the world.

title: Week 6 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
description: The Denver Broncos are on their way to breaking records this season, having scored 230 points in five games. Thats 51 percent more points than the second-highest-scoring team and over twice as many points as the average N.F.L. team.

title: Israel: Soldier Hurt by Mortar Shells From Syria
description: An Israeli soldier was lightly wounded by shrapnel on Wednesday when two mortar shells fired from Syria hit a military post in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights. A spokeswoman for the Israeli military said the strike was probably the result of errant fire, given the heightened fighting between Syrian government forces and rebels across the frontier in recent days. There have been numerous instances of fire from the Syrian civil war spilling into the Israeli-held territory, but injuries on the Israeli side have been rare.

title: Japan: Workers Doused With Radioactive Water
description: Six workers at Japans wrecked Fukushima nuclear plant were sprayed with highly radioactive water on Wednesday after they accidentally disconnected a pipe in the reactors makeshift cooling system, the plants operator said. The operator, Tokyo Electric Power Company, or Tepco, said the workers took off their protective clothing after the incident and showered, and that there was no apparent risk to their health. Tepco said about 10 tons of tainted water also spilled onto the ground, though it was prevented from reaching the sea.

title: Chinese Leader Concerned About Debt Ceiling Issue
description: HONG KONG  In his meeting Wednesday night with Secretary of State John Kerry, Li Keqiang, Chinas prime minister, raised the issue of Congresss failure to extend the debt limit, underscoring Chinese concerns about the trillion dollars of U.S. government debt Beijing holds.

title: Christian Conservatives to Meet Cruz and Rand Paul
description: A group of longtime Christian conservative activists are holding a private meeting Thursday in Washington to hear informal presentations from two of the most talked-about potential Republican presidential candidates: Senators Ted Cruz of Texas, and Rand Paul of Kentucky.

title: The Big-Bank Subsidy
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Fat and Thin Find Common Ground
description: When binge eating disorder gained legitimacy as a full-fledged mental condition in the latest edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders in May, many people in the eating disorders and obesity communities wondered: Will this inspire us to finally get along?

title: Cardinals Wainwright Cuts Down Upstart Pirates
description: ST. LOUIS  When it was over  the decades of losing, the revival of a proud baseball town, the exhilarating playoff run  the Pittsburgh Pirates best player found a simple reason to be satisfied.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 10, 2013
description: There clearly are people in the Republican Party at the moment for whom the business community and the interests of the business community  the jobs and members they represent  dont seem to be their top priority.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 9 P.M. (Fox) GLEE The show bids farewell to its onetime star quarterback, Finn Hudson, portrayed by Cory Monteith, left, who died July 13. The playlist includes Season of Love, Ill Stand by You, Fire and Rain, If I Die Young, The Surrender and Make You Feel My Love, performed by Lea Michele, Mr. Monteiths on- and off-screen girlfriend.

title: Yo-Yo Ma and the Mind Game of Music
description: Yo-Yo Ma began playing the cello at the age of 4. Now 57, he has received numerous Grammy Awards, the National Medal of Arts and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. In 1998 Mr. Ma founded the Silk Road Project, a nonprofit organization that brings together musicians from around the world. Last month, Sony Masterworks released his Silk Road Ensembles Playlist Without Borders CD and Live From Tanglewood concert DVD. Mr. Ma recently called from his home in Cambridge, Mass. A condensed and edited version of our conversation follows:

title: Show of Power by Libya Militia in Kidnapping
description: TUNIS  Libyas prime minister, Ali Zeidan, was hauled from his bed at 2:30 a.m. Thursday by a group of militiamen who stormed into the luxury hotel where he lives in downtown Tripoli, a kidnapping that would be extraordinary by almost any standard.

title: News Quiz | October 10, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Snowdens Father Arrives in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  After fleeing his home in Hawaii for Hong Kong, then spending a month as resident of an airport transit zone in Moscow before winning temporary asylum in Russia, Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American intelligence contractor, is getting a visit from his father.

title: Airbus Predicts Growth in Air Cargo Market
description: HONG KONG  The air cargo market is showing signs of life after years of pain following the global financial crisis, senior executives of the European plane maker Airbus said in a news media briefing on Thursday. The officials forecast solid growth powered by demand for freighters from emerging markets over the next 20 years.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 10, 2013

title: 6 Qs About the News | President Obama Nominates New Fed Leader
description: The questions below relate to two articles on President Obamas pick to head the Federal Reserve: Announcing Fed Nomination, Obama Praises Yellen and Obama to Pick Yellen as Leader of Fed, Officials Say.

title: What Does Your Hairstyle Say About You?
description: You might wear it long, straight, curly or braided. Maybe you obsess over it every morning  blow drying, brushing, combing or gelling. Or perhaps you sport a crew cut and dont worry much at all. No matter how we wear it, our hair can be an important way in which we express ourselves.

title: Women on the Front Lines and Behind the Lens
description: Stephanie Sinclair has mostly happy memories of her childhood in Miami, where she grew up encouraged by her parents to be carefree, confident and defiant. It was there, in an elementary school broadcast arts program, that she requested to be a camera operator, offering the first inkling of what she would do with her life.

title: Despite Climate Concern, Global Study Finds Fewer Carbon Capture Projects
description: WASHINGTON  The number of large-scale projects to capture and bury carbon dioxide has fallen to 65 from 75 over the last year, a worldwide survey has found, despite a consensus among scientists and engineers that such projects are essential to meet international goals for slowing the buildup of climate-changing gases.

title: The Final Insult in the Bush-Cheney Marriage
description: In the final days of his presidency, George W. Bush sat behind his desk in the Oval Office, chewing gum and staring into the distance as two White House lawyers briefed him on the possible last-minute pardon of I. Lewis Libby.

title: New York Today: Tornado Tracking
description: Updated 12:03 p.m. | They looked at radar maps. They studied tree-fall patterns. They tallied eyewitness accounts.

title: Sinking of Migrant Boat Off Italy Complicates Politics in Germany
description: BERLIN  The deaths of about 300 migrants whose boat caught fire and sank off the Italian island of Lampedusa added complexity to the search for a new German government on Thursday, when major figures in Chancellor Angela Merkels conservative party demanded a change in European policies toward asylum seekers.

title: Daily Report: Novel Prompts Reflections on Our Technological Lives
description: Book critics are divided over the quality of Dave Eggerss highly anticipated novel The Circle, which went on sale Tuesday. Is it an eviscerating takedown of the tech industry? Or is it a sanctimonious screed that fails to understand its subject? But in Silicon Valley and beyond, the books theme promises to spark an even bigger debate over the 21st-century hyperconnected world that Mr. Eggers describes, Julie Bosman and Claire Cain Miller report.

title: Alice Munro Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
description: Alice Munro, the renowned Canadian short-story writer whose visceral work explores the tangled relationships between men and women, small-town existence and the fallibility of memory, won the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday.

title: North Korean Leader Tightens Grip With Removal of His Top General
description: SEOUL, South Korea  State news media on Thursday confirmed the removal of a hard-line general as North Koreas military chief, the latest sign of an overhaul by the countrys leader, Kim Jong-un, who South Korean officials say has replaced nearly half of his top officials in the past two years.

title: Britain Weighs Creating System to Reward Whistle-Blowers
description: LONDON  The British government is considering creating a reward system, similar to ones in the United States, to encourage whistle-blowers to come forward to root out fraud and other white-collar crime.

title: Bank of England Retains Low Interest Rate
description: LONDON  Britains central bank decided on Thursday to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low in the face of more evidence that the countrys economic recovery was gaining speed.

title: U.S. Reduces Military Aid to Egypt
description: Obama tries to slow down the Egyptian army.

title: Stun Guns and Video Generate a Surprising Match
description: Taser International, a manufacturer of electronic stun guns, is not the company most people would expect to be bumping elbows with the likes of Twitter, Facebook and Dropbox as it looks for acquisitions.

title: Weill Invests in Silicon Valley Finance Start-Up
description: Updated, 1:13 p.m. | With investments by other former Wall Street chieftains.

title: European Trade Chief Proposes Trans-Atlantic Working Group
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions top trade official, in one of the first concrete proposals in the trade negotiations with the United States, called on Thursday for a new trans-Atlantic group that would coordinate the work of United States and European regulatory agencies.

title: Experience as It Once Was
description: WORLITZ, Germany  I was going 115 miles per hour on a German autobahn when it occurred to me that one reason the German economy is doing so well is that people can get from one place to another so fast. With most of the rest of Europe confined to a limit of about 80 miles per hour, Germany has a clear competitive advantage.

title: Pakistani Student Wins Top European Rights Award
description: LONDON  Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl who was shot in the head by the Taliban for her advocacy of girls education, was awarded the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought on Thursday by the European Parliament.

title: Faith in U.S. Debt Is Rattled
description: The fiscal impasse in Congress has been testing investors confidence that the United States  considered the most reliable borrower in the world  will be able to pay back its debt on time, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Investors in recent days have shifted money out of the $1.7 trillion market for the short-term government debt known as Treasury bills. It now costs more for the United States to borrow money for a month than it does for the average highly rated American company to do so, Mr. Popper writes.

description: Logistics note | Im traveling in Asia through Monday, October 14th, so posting and comment moderation may be limited.

title: Wilfried Martens, Belgian Statesman, Dies at 77
description: Wilfried Martens, a grand statesman of Belgian politics who led nine Belgian governments and helped shape what became the European Union, the worlds biggest trading bloc, died on Wednesday at his home in Lokeren, in East Flanders. He was 77.

title: Today in Small Business: Does Our Logo Look Like Underpants?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Treasury Chief Warns of Severe Debt-Limit Fallout
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew implored Congress on Thursday to raise the debt ceiling, warning of potentially severe market and economic repercussions if it did not.

title: Observers Differ on Fairness of Election in Azerbaijan
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  A prominent delegation of international election observers on Thursday sharply criticized Azerbaijans presidential election as unfair and rife with fraud, amid aggressive efforts by the Azerbaijani government and its allies to portray the vote as legitimate.

title: On Beauty | Eyeliner, the Time-Honored Makeup Choice of Bad Girls Everywhere
description: Demure makeup has defined the eye for the past few years, but now a bold new line is being drawn. Here, a testament to the power of eyeliner.

title: Baby Hope Identified as Angelica, but Questions Remain
description: After 22 years of being known as Baby Hope, the slain child found in a cooler on the side of a highway can now be called by her name: Angelica.

title: Cities Report Better Finances, but Worries Persist
description: Fiscal conditions are slowly improving for American cities, aided by increases in sales tax and income tax revenue, but rapidly rising pension and health costs for city workers continue to pose a potentially crippling threat, according to an annual study released Thursday by the National League of Cities.

title: Kwame M. Kilpatrick, Former Detroit Mayor, Sentenced to 28 Years in Corruption Case
description: DETROIT  Kwame M. Kilpatrick, the former mayor of Detroit, stood before a federal judge on Thursday and apologized for putting the people of his city through a corruption scandal so vast that prosecutors say it helped accelerate Detroits march toward bankruptcy.

title: How Democracy Works Now
description: Americans who find politics and political reporting glib, unsatisfying and depressingnow have an antidote for all time.

title: A Maverick as Student and Teacher
description: Only a few days after the artist Mike Kelley committed suicide last year by sealing himself inside his bathroom in South Pasadena, Calif., and asphyxiating himself with fumes from a barbecue grill, an impromptu memorial sprouted near his studio in Los Angeles.

title: At Risk: Currency Privilege of the Dollar
description: Not all government debt is created equal. Some governments get a much better deal than others, and no one gets a better deal than the United States.

title: When Sports Defeat Homework
description: Dear Mrs. Lahey,My child is coming home after school and sports practices exhausted. He is reduced to tears when facing his homework. I do not want to take sports out of his life as there are so many wonderful things he gains, but he is not getting his homework done. Advice?

title: Scott Turow: By the Book
description: The author of Identical ranted about Patti Smiths National Book Award. Then he read her book  a perfectly wrought account of what it means to give your life to art and to another person.

title: No Quick Deal, but Offer by G.O.P. on Debt Shifts the Tone
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and House Republicans failed to reach agreement on a six-week extension of the nations borrowing authority during a meeting Thursday at the White House, but the two sides kept talking, and the offer from politically besieged Republicans was seen as an initial step toward ending the budget standoff.

title: A Mighty Honor for Munro, a Humble Writer
description: Most of us are lucky to get a gold pen when we retire. Alice Munro got the Nobel Prize.

title: Oil Spills Becoming Frequent Hazard for Fishermen Near Mumbai
description: MUMBAINaushad Qureshi, 26, who belongs to an indigenous fishing community in the Uran region of Maharashtra, felt his eyes burning and feet tingling when he settled into his dinghy Tuesday morning. He was looking for crabs, lobsters and prawns in the Arabian Sea to sell in Mumbai, which is almost 30 miles southwest from his village, Peerwadi.

title: Kimmel and West Share the Screen but Thats About It
description: Is any celebrity alive better at hijacking television shows than Kanye West?

title: Automatic Destabilizers
description: The debt ceiling situation remains extremely foggy. Republican leaders seem, slowly, to be coming to the realization that Obama is serious about this business of not engaging in hostage negotiations  but theyre still trying to bargain (kill your main achievement? No? OK, how about killing Social Security instead?). Will they realize that this just isnt going to work before the money runs out? Nobody knows.

title: Following Up on Our Sales Training, Profit-Sharing, Health Insurance and the Shutdown
description: I usually pick one thing that has happened to me recently to write about, but the reality of life as a boss is that a typical day, week, or month consists of a series of unrelated events. They dont always fit together into a neat narrative with a clear theme.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 6 Matchup Breakdown
description: After five weeks of play, the owners who drafted a top-15 wide receiver before the season have learned the hard way that there is no such thing as a safe pick in fantasy football.

title: Poetry Pairing | A Small Story about the Sky
description: In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, this Poetry Pairing features A Small Story about the Sky, a poem by Alberto Ros, and the article Water, Now Fire, and Shore Nightmare Goes On, by Kate Zernike.

title: T-Mobile Hands Consumers a Pleasant Shocker
description: Back in March, T-Mobile burned every possible bridge it had with the other cellphone carriers. As I wrote then, it eliminated the two-year contract; you can now quit T-Mobile whenever you like.

title: Trusting the Doctor
description: We drove along the dirt and gravel roads of western Massachusetts, on our way to the Umpachene Falls.

title: Myanmar in Lead Role at a Regional Meeting
description: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei  Myanmar, until two years ago a pariah, on Thursday formally accepted the top post of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, an affirmation of the countrys new position on the international stage.

title: S.E.C. Wont Pursue Action Against Rebecca Producers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to pursue any action against the Broadway producers of Rebecca, the Gothic musical that was derailed last fall before performances began because of a fraud scheme involving phantom investors.

title: U.S. Accuses 2 Rabbis of Kidnapping Husbands for a Fee
description: In Brooklyns ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods, Mendel Epstein made a name for himself as the rabbi to see for women struggling to divorce their husbands. Among the Orthodox, a divorce requires the husbands permission, known as a get, and tales abound of women whose husbands refuse to consent.

title: Standoff on Debt Default Fails to Rattle Asia, Yet
description: HONG KONG  When the United States government was borrowing heavily four years ago to cover costs related to the global financial crisis, Wen Jiabao, then the prime minister of China, strongly and publicly warned Washington to make sure that Chinese investments in Treasury securities were safe.

title: The Gun Report: October 10, 2013
description: Next week, Oakland, Calif., could be the only city in California with the right to make its own rules governing gun licensing and registration. A bill called AB180, sponsored by Assemblyman Rob Bonta, is on Gov. Jerry Browns desk. For the bill to become law, it must be signed by midnight on Sunday.

title: T FALL DESIGN
description: The seasons strongest designs are anything but two-dimensional  with a sculptural consideration of form, these are clothes to be viewed from all sides.

title: 2 Face Court-Martial in Naval Academy Assault Case
description: WASHINGTON  Two former Naval Academy football players accused of sexually assaulting a female midshipman at an off-campus party will face court-martial proceedings, the latest in a string of high-profile cases in the military that are drawing increased scrutiny from the Pentagon and Congress.

title: A Timeless Thirst for Power
description: A country is thrown into chaos when its leaders descend into conflict in Shakespeares Julius Caesar. Does this sound slightly familiar?

title: Testing an Elephant's Attention
description: It's known that elephants are social creatures, but scientists have now discovered that they appear to understand human pointing.

title: Elephants Get the Point of Pointing, Study Shows
description: We point to things without giving much thought to what a sophisticated act it really is. By simply extending a finger, we can let other people know we want to draw their attention to an object, and indicate which object it is.

title: When Talking Makes the Art Happen
description: On a chilly fall day, the artist Suzanne Lacy stood fretting about the cold amid curators and production designers on a tree-lined stretch of Park Place, in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.

title: The Expulsion of the Consuls
description: By Oct. 8, 1863, Britain had crossed the line  at least in the eyes of Judah P. Benjamin, the Confederate secretary of state. Benjamins frustration rang out loud and clear from a letter he wrote that day to Allan Fullarton, Britains acting consul in Savannah, Ga. Fullartons offense? Like other consuls, he was helping British subjects in the Confederacy avoid conscription, which Confederate officials were increasingly applying to citizens and noncitizens alike. Britain allowed that foreign-born men could be required to take part in emergency local defense but denied the Confederacys right to draft them into regular military service. But to Benjamin, every time a foreign consul took it upon himself to determine the reach of Confederate conscription, he made an unacceptable assault upon the Confederacys sovereignty.

title: Excerpt: 'A Night With Janis Joplin'
description: Mary Bridget Davies and Allison Blackwell sing Spirit in the Dark from the new Broadway musical. (An earlier summary misspelled the surname of the actress Allison Blackwell as Rockwell.)

title: Transformations
description: The transformation of fashion has been told over the years through the pages of the International Herald Tribune. The following slides feature some of the Suzy Menkess most important looks.

title: Return of Here Lies Love Delayed Until 2014
description: The Public Theaters plans to remount the critically acclaimed musical Here Lies Love have been delayed until next year due to difficulties finding a new home as well as scheduling considerations, according to two executives involved with the production.

title: In Fashion | Wardrobe Pieces That Feel Like Sculpture
description: The seasons strongest designs are anything but two-dimensional  with a sculptural consideration of form, these are clothes to be viewed from all sides.

title: Letters
description: A Call to Battle

title: Snowdens Father Speaks About His Son
description: Lon Snowden, left, the father of Edward J. Snowden, said he did not expect his son to return to the United States. With him is his sons Russian lawyer, Anatoly G. Kucherena.

title: Adding New Holidays to the Outlook.com Calendar
description: Q. My Outlook.com calendar has United States holidays listed, but can I add Canadian holidays too?

title: A Thriller Armed With Thought
description: Captain Phillips, a movie that insistently closes the distance between us and them, has a vital moral immediacy. It was directed by Paul Greengrass, the British filmmaker who quickened the pulse of contemporary action cinema with the second and third installments in the Bourne franchise, features that proved yet again that big-screen thrills and thought need not be mutually exclusive. Kinetic action and intelligence are similarly the driving forces in Captain Phillips, which, like Mr. Greengrasss Bourne movies, shakes you up first with its style and then with its ideas.

title: Jason Collins, Openly Gay and Still Unsigned, Waits and Wonders
description: LOS ANGELES  Since making the announcement last spring that he is a gay professional basketball player, Jason Collins has been widely praised, received much support and made many new friends. But with training camp for a new season under way, he has been waiting for a call from an N.B.A. team. Any N.B.A. team.

title: Detroit Film Festival Will Focus on the City
description: Detroit may be ailing, but a new film festival there intends to give it a good dose of positive attention. The Freep Film Festival, presented by the Detroit Free Press and the Detroit Media Partnership, which manages the newspapers business operations, will screen around a dozen documentaries in four days, all of which focus on Detroit and its surrounding regions.

title: Five Ways to Teach the Shutdown
description: Update: Oct. 17, 2013: Now that the shutdown is over, use our 6 Qs About the News to answer questions about the results.

title: The Many Front Pages of New York, Past and Present
description: Youre probably more likely to have read about it online than in print, but this is National Newspaper Week. And if you cant take a reporter to lunch, at least pause and reflect on the fact that while New York remains that rare, robust daily newspaper town, thats nothing compared to the choices available in the city a century ago.

title: Jonas Brother Against Brother (Against Brother); Tour Canceled
description: The Jonas Brothers were to have played the first of 19 concerts in a North American tour on Friday in Upper Darby, Pa., but they may break up instead. At the very least, the tour, which was to include a concert at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan on Oct. 23, has been scuttled because of what the groups spokesman, Jesse Derris, described to People magazine as a deep rift within the band and a big disagreement over their musical direction.

title: G.O.P. Leaders on Debt Limit Increase
description: Republican members of the House announced their proposal for a short-term debt ceiling increase.

title: Delaware Court Lifts Injunction on Activision Blizzards Deal With Vivendi
description: The Delaware Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously reversed a lower court ruling on Activision Blizzards move to buy back most of Vivendis stake in the video game maker for $8.2 billion, letting the transaction move forward.

title: Image of the Day: October 10
What Were Reading Now
description: Nicholas Kristof brings some promising news from the developing world: Illiteracy and AIDS are receding, ancient diseases such as Guinea worm and polio are on the way out, and child mortality is dropping.

title: Norwegian Investigated in Deadly Mall Siege in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Norwegian police said on Thursday that they were investigating whether a Norwegian citizen was involved in the deadly siege of the Westgate shopping mall here in late September.

title: The Debt Ceiling and the Housing Bust
description: Suppose that we hit the debt ceiling, and that the Treasury manages to engage in prioritization  paying interest on bonds, so that all the burden falls on other kinds of spending. How should we think about the economic impact?

title: Former Liu Associates Are Sentenced
description: Two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, managed to avoid lengthy prison sentences on Thursday for their roles in attempting to funnel money to Mr. Lius mayoral campaign through an illegal fund-raising scheme.

title: After High Demand, Royal Mail Shares Are Priced at High End
description: Royal Mail, whose roots date back to the court of Henry VIII in the 16th century, is so deeply woven into the public fabric of Britain that even former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher did not push to sell it. Three attempts over the last two decades to privatize the postal service failed in the face of overwhelming objection.

title: Mobile Banking Players Are Shaking Up Chinas Cozy Oligopoly
description: The biggest threat to Chinese banks cozy oligopoly may be in the hands of the nations consumers. Two online companies, Alibaba and Tencent, are making incursions into the countrys financial services market, providing an alternative to the capped deposit rates and sluggish service offered by the countrys big lenders. The disrupters are taking on risks, and savers should be glad.

title: Ghost Hunting
description: The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in Weston, West Virginia, rumored to be haunted, is the site of Saturday night ghost hunting tours.

title: Getting Into the Spirit
description: Everyone has a ghost story, or at least thats how it has always seemed to me. My mothers best friend used to tell a doozy about a soldier she met when she was a bookkeeper in the Air Force. He claimed to be a ghost, then proved it by walking into the middle of a moonlit airfield and disappearing before her eyes. Another friend of my mothers used to bring over a Ouija board when she baby-sat for me. As that plastic pointer whizzed around the board (with seemingly little help from her fingers), she spoke of the messages that the spirit world sent to her on a regular basis.

title: 3rd Ward, Brooklyn Art and Design Space, to Close
description: Updated, Oct. 11 | 3rd Ward, the Brooklyn art, design and educational work space, where for seven years students and artisans have built wood furniture, learned about photography and pursued other creative endeavors, in Bushwick and at an outpost in Philadelphia, is closing, an owner, Jason Goodman, announced on Thursday.

title: 2 Founders of BlackBerry Weighing a Takeover Offer
description: OTTAWA  The two men who founded the company that became BlackBerry may now try to save it.

title: World Leaders Urge U.S. to End Its Debt Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  The exhortations have come from China, Singapore, Switzerland, Mexico, Japan and South Africa, from heads of government, bankers and business leaders: Raise your debt ceiling and reopen your government, for the good of the American economy and the worlds.

title: Snowdens Father Meets the Press in Moscow
description: As my colleague Andrew Roth reports, Lon Snowden, the father of the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, arrived in Moscow on Thursday to visit his son, and was met at the airport by a scrum of Russian journalists, including camera crews from the main state television channel and the governments English-language network, RT.

title: Wheelies: The J.F.K. Lincoln Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Suit Revives Goldman Conflict Issue
description: At a March 2012 meeting, a group of examiners at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York agreed that Goldman Sachs had inadequate procedures to guard against conflicts of interest  guidelines aimed at stopping firms from putting their pursuit of profit ahead of their clients best interests.

title: Video of the Libyan Prime Minister Speaking After His Release
description: The Libyan government released video footage showing the prime minister, Ali Zeidan, speaking to fellow cabinet members and officials after his release on Thursday from a kidnapping that took place before dawn at a hotel in the capital, Tripoli.

title: Koons Work to Be Auctioned for Brooklyn School
description: Benefit auctions for scrappy public schools in New York sometimes feature an item or two  a designer handbag, lunch with a minor celebrity  arranged by parents with connections. But when a list of art works was circulated recently among parents for an Oct. 23 auction to benefit P.S. 130, a school in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn serving a significant number of students from poor families, one art donors name fairly leapt off the page: Jeff Koons.

title: U.N. Backs Peace Effort for Central African Republic
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved a resolution on Thursday aimed at stabilizing the Central African Republic, a dangerous and dysfunctional country that has descended into near-total chaos over the last half year.

title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts
description: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm find natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

title: For Silicon Valley Novels, Blurring Fiction and Nonfiction
description: Mark Twain once said: Its no wonder that truth is stranger than fiction. Fiction has to make sense. It seems thatDave Eggers has people questioning which of those two types of storytelling he wrote about in his new book, The Circle.

title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Running Backs
description: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

title: Modern Love | Lost and Found
description: A 17-year-old girl, put up for adoption at birth, finds her biological mother on Facebook.

title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Wide Receivers
description: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

title: A Husband Lost, a Daughter Found
description: Four years ago, when people asked if I was married or had children, my answers were easy: Yes to the first and no to the second, because my husband was alive and the newborn I had placed in an open adoption when I was a teenager hadnt yet found me on Facebook.

title: Scott Carpenter, One of the Original Seven Astronauts, Is Dead at 88
description: M. Scott Carpenter, whose flight into space in 1962 as the second American to orbit the Earth was marred by technical problems and ended with the nation waiting anxiously to see if he had survived a landing far from the target site, died on Thursday in Denver. He was 88 and one of the last two surviving astronauts of Americas original space program, Project Mercury.

title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Tight Ends
description: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

title: Antitrust Fine for Supplier of Seat Belts
description: A Japanese seat belt supplier said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay a $71.3 million fine to settle antitrust charges, less than a month after one of its executives was sentenced to prison for fixing the price of auto parts sold in the United States and abroad.

title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Kickers
description: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

title: Safety Agency Cites Texas Plant in Explosion
description: The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited the owners of a fertilizer plant in West, Tex., that blew up in April, killing 15 people, with 24 serious violations, Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, said on Thursday. But the agency has not announced the action because its public affairs staff has been furloughed by the government shutdown, Ms. Boxer said.

title: Fantasy Football: Tiered Player Ranking Charts, Team Defenses and Special Teams
description: Charts resulting from a statistical algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within fantasy football player ranking data.

title: Market Report | Warming Up Cold-Weather Looks With Houndstooth
description: Nothing says cold-weather dressing quite like houndstooth, and the classic broken-check Scottish pattern is everywhere you look right now. Mulberry made the already bold style even more so by introducing a pop of red in a statement wool coat. Roger Vivier printed differently sized squares of it onto a pair of calf hair booties that will liven up any outfit. And Thom Browne, Tommy Hilfiger and Azzurra have also incorporated the time-tested pattern into clothing and accessories.

title: After Injury, Craig Bierko Takes Leave from Broadways Matilda
description: Craig Bierko, the Tony Award-nominated stage and film actor who recently joined the Broadway cast of Matilda the Musical as the villainous Miss Trunchbull, has taken a leave from the production following an injury.

title: A Sleeping Giant in African Soccer Is Starting to Stir
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Less than a week before the most important match in its history, Ethiopias national soccer team trained on a wet, uneven field on the outskirts of the capital. Nearby, a woman hung her wash on a clothesline. Birds of prey circled overhead, and sometimes a plane flew past at low altitude, coming from the capitals busy airport, which a few months ago added a connection to Rio de Janeiro.

title: Umami Burger
description: Inside the burger chains new restaurant in Greenwich Village.

title: The Meat Is Only the Start
description: Umami is sometimes defined as the flavor beyond all flavors, the flavor that cannot be described, but my waitress at Umami Burger in Greenwich Village has no time for such reveries.

title: Jeff Fluhr of Spreecast, on Finding Employees Who Fit
description: This interview with Jeff Fluhr, chief executive of Spreecast, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Living With Cancer: Hospital City
description: When you travel to cancer central, you may find yourself more perplexed by the currency, language, customs, costumes, cuisine and time zone than you would have been if you had landed in Timbuktu. In Hospital City, you can lose your way as well as your confidence in everything you took for granted.

title: Growing Up With a Disabled Sibling
description: Mom, when are you going to write a book about me? my 7-year-old son, Noah, asked as we sat on the floor of his room, surrounded by packing materials from the box that had arrived earlier that day. Inside were copies of my new book, each with a picture of me holding Noahs brother, Henry, on the cover. Henry has Down syndrome, and the book is about the first three years of his life. Noah had come home to find Henry admiring it while I danced around taking photos for our Facebook page. Noah stood by watching the commotion patiently enough. He understood that Henry was having his turn. He just wanted to know whether the next book would be about him.

title: Crawford Rediscovers Himself With Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Of all the indicators suggesting the return to form of Carl Crawford, a player once thought to be worth $142 million, the biggest was not the three home runs he hit in the last two playoff games for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the diving catch he made over the railing near the left-field stands or a comfortably stolen base.

title: MARKET REPORT
description: Spruce up cold-weather dressing with a little something inspired by the bold, classic mens-wear pattern.

title: From 'Weeds' To Broadway
description: Returning to Broadway after a long, successful run in Hollywood, Mary Louise Parker is set to take the leading role in the play The Snow Geese.

title: Stage Scenes: Mary-Louise Parker
description: A look at some of the actresss past stage performances.

title: Never Neutral, and Proud of It
description: As her Showtime series Weeds was nearing its eighth and final season last year, Mary-Louise Parker kept haranguing her agents to send new plays her way. But while she was itchy to find a vehicle back to her first love, theater, a part of her also felt that she would never act onstage again.

title: In Uganda, a Chance to Work With Gorilla Researchers
description: In addition to staring in awe at a rare African species, safari-goers can give an assist to science by working with gorilla researchers. Uganda-based Premier Safaris has partnered with the renowned gorilla expert Dr. Gladys Kalema-Zikusoka to offer research-focused itineraries to see mountain gorillas in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park.

title: When Bird Was a Fledgling
description: The ideal way to ingest Stanley Crouchs new book is probably on audio, late at night, while driving between the major cities of the Midwest, your headlights pushing past truck stops and dying cornfields. Youve got to be willing to submit to the spell Mr. Crouch is working to cast.

title: Danish Arts Subtler Sides at Scandinavia House
description: The Miser has a soft spot  if you can call it that  for Denmarks arch-brooders. Given their outsize influence on contemporary culture, you might be tempted to associate the likes of Kierkegaard and Lars von Trier with a distinctly Danish sensibility. But the Danish contribution to Western art isnt limited to histrionic bursts of angst, irony and the absurd. Danish Paintings From the Golden Age to the Modern Breakthrough, an exhibition opening this weekend at Scandinavia House, brings together a selection of masterpieces from the late 18th to the 20th centuries that make use of subtler, more austere aesthetics.

title: A Turnabout From Manga to Zen
description: Its been a full decade since Mariko Moris last New York museum show, and viewers who remember that exhibition might not even recognize the artist in Rebirth: Recent Work by Mariko Mori, at Japan Society. The futuristic fashion plate of Ms. Moris earlier photographs and videos  the artist herself, in Manga-inspired get-ups  seems to have vanished, and so has her contemporary Japanese landscape of malls, airports and business districts.

title: Holding Court in All Their Petaled Glory
description: THE stately chrysanthemum, one of natures noblest flowers, harbors a dark secret. It enjoys pain.

title: Bjarne Melgaard: Ignorant Transparencies
description: Gavin Browns Enterprise

title: Weeklong Search Continues for a Boy With Autism
description: It has been a week since Avonte Oquendo, a 14-year-old from Queens, was last seen, captured on surveillance video darting down the hallway of his school and then running out onto the street in Long Island City.

title: Josh Smith
description: Luhring Augustine Gallery

title: Whoa, Are Snow White and Mulan Really Working the Street?
description: Jim (Roy Abramsohn) is a doughy dad on a Disney vacation with a pair of cute towheaded kids and a nagging wife (Elena Schuber). Shortly after Jim receives an unwelcome call from his boss  firing him without warning or explanation  things turn weird. The theme park that promises magic for the masses takes on a decidedly sinister cast. Is it all in Jims head, or does evil stalk the happiest place on earth?

title: Edmund de Waal: Atemwende
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: Kuni Sugiura: Photographic Collages: 1977-1981
description: Leslie Tonkonow Artworks + Projects

title: Death of a Cameraman
description: Apexart

title: Are Disasters Lurking in European Banks? Who Knows?
description: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, gave a generally upbeat speech on Thursday. We have seen much progress in the banking sector of the euro area, he told the Economics Club of New York.

title: Judge Says New Jersey Can Begin Allowing Same-Sex Marriages in Two Weeks
description: A judge on Thursday cleared the way for same-sex marriages to start in New Jersey in two weeks, dismissing the states request to prevent the weddings until after an appeal of the court decision allowing them is completed.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, Northern Ireland, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

title: Toughing It Out, Against All Odds
description: There are times in The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete when the emotions it stirs up are so naked and unembarrassed that it feels as if youve entered a cinematic time machine back to the silent era, to when child actors like Jackie Coogan gutted you with sentiment. Coogan played the title character in Charles Chaplins glorious 1921 weepie The Kid, the urchin with the tight grip around the Tramps neck and lock on the audiences affections.
