The heartbreakers in Mister & Pete, a melodrama about two children slipping through the cracks, shed fewer tears than the Kid did  poverty can toughen even the most tender bodies  but their hold on you is as fierce.

title: Sally Field, Ken Burns and Philip Roth Honored by Scholarly Society
description: Updated, 11:02 a.m. Friday | Last year, Sally Field won an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Mary Todd Lincoln. This weekend, shell be making a turn as another first lady, Abigail Adams.

title: T FALL DESIGN
description: Two generations of one of Englands most celebrated families  Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant  make beautiful, unusual and deeply personal art that draws from the natural world.

title: Lamentation for a Home of Punk Rock
description: Because of the cruel accidents of age and geography, I never set foot in CBGB during its 1970s punk heyday. So I cant look at CBGB  Randall Millers sweet and nostalgic elegy to that defunct club and its owner and presiding spirit, Hillel Kristal, known to all, whether they actually knew him or not, as Hilly  and say, with the authority of experience, It wasnt like that. I will leave it to others to point out the films lapses of chronology, taste and historical detail. But on the other hand, I would swear on a stack of Dead Boys T-shirts and a first pressing of Richard Hell and the Voidoids Blank Generation that it could not possibly have been like that: so silly, so trivial, so boring.

title: Mixing and Matching Many Tastes of Japan
description: Takahiro Okada, a manager of the TriBeCa bar Shigure, said there were two ways customers could enjoy the distilled spirit shochu, a specialty of the house.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Winter Weather Advisory

title: Turning Advanced Statistics Into Fantasy Football Analysis
description: What can machine learning and statistics do for fantasy football? It turns out, quite a bit.

title: Why Alice Munro Is Canadas First Nobel Prize Winner for Literature (With an Asterisk)
description: Alice Munro, the Canadian writer whos widely acknowledged as the greatest living short-story writer (and, according to Jonathan Franzen, the best living North American fiction writer, period), was named the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature this morning.

title: For Finger Lakes Rieslings, Smashed Potatoes Inspired by Costata
description: On my first visit to Costata, Michael Whites SoHo steakhouse, I was bowled over by the crisp, deeply burnished smashed potatoes. I got the recipe, and then I waited for a wine inspiration. Of course, with a robust bottle of red and a slab of grilled meat, Id have been done with it. But I wanted to give the potatoes marquee billing.

title: A Life Ravels Out, and a Brooding Family Sets Forth
description: William Faulkners novel As I Lay Dying, published in 1930, is about a family hauling the dead body of one of its members on a journey of several days over rough terrain in a mule-drawn cart. That might be one definition of a fools errand, the primary fool being Anse Bundren, a stubborn, suspicious and toothless Mississippi farmer who insists on burying his wife, Addie, in her hometown. Another definition might be the attempt to turn Faulkners splintered, lyrical book into a movie. In this case the fool would be James Franco, who directed and stars in the first film adaptation of a book that has long been considered unfilmable.

title: Janet Joy
description: Ive been remiss in not writing anything about Janet Yellens nomination to head the Fed; partly that was because I wasnt sure exactly what to say, and how to explain why I and so many other economists are really happy with her selection.

title: In New Case, Former Leader of Pakistan Is Arrested
description: LONDON  The Pakistani police arrested Pervez Musharraf, the nations former military ruler, on Thursday, opening a new criminal prosecution against him that frustrated plans by his supporters to fly him out of Pakistan.

title: Peering Past New Yorks Locked Doors
description: THE New York fall cultural calendar is a busy one. The fashion world has September all sewn up, and between auctions and openings, the art world has November all nailed down. The holidays hold December hostage. That leaves October.

title: Jilted, and Communing With a Serial-Killing Cannibal
description: There are probably a good number of you out there who would never see a play that trades on the portrayal of a creepily charming Jeffrey Dahmer character. Who can say if this number is higher or lower than the number of you who would be persuaded to attend for precisely that same reason?

title: Oh, Hey, Romeo, Whats Up?
description: Passions and nostrils flare in the latest screen version of Romeo & Juliet, a sufficiently entertaining, adamantly old-fashioned adaptation that follows the plays general outline without ever rising to the passionate intensity of its star-crossd crazy kids. Adapted by Julian Fellowes, whos taken liberties with the original text, and dutifully directed by Carlo Carlei, it deploys the familiar emotional beats  if not all the lines  along with the usual mixture of comedy, romance and tragedy. Shot in the actual Verona and at other Italian attractions, it looks pretty, feels light and moves fast, with a 118-minute running time thats in keeping with the originals two hours traffic of our stage.

title: Taking Off to Find Yourself? Be Sure a Self Is There
description: Those of us who have rolled our eyes at the narcissistic entitlement of millennials   come on, you know youve done it  are gently scolded in Mike Lews bumpy road comedy, Bike America, for failing to recognize the genuine desperation beneath their whiny self-absorption.

title: Strong Start for American Horror Story
description: Cable television demonstrated again Wednesday night that it can produce powerhouse drama that can match or exceed anything on network television  the latest example being the new season of the FX drama American Horror Story.

title: All Hes Got to Do Is Save the World
description: Until your eyes glaze over after about a half-hour, Machete Kills might put a twisted smirk of guilty amusement on your face. The high point of those opening minutes is a fantastically gaudy fake trailer for a sequel, Machete Kills Again ... In Space, which embodies the director Robert Rodriguezs nostalgia for trashy B-movie exploitation flicks.

title: Reliving the Show That Dropped Like a Bomb
description: The International Exhibition of Modern Art, otherwise known as the Armory Show, woke American art from its provincial slumbers 100 years ago. Was it a good thing or a bad thing, and is there any reason to care about it now? With more than 100 works from the original exhibition and a big, richly illuminating catalog, The Armory Show at 100: Modern Art and Revolution at the New-York Historical Society offers an excellent opportunity to ponder such questions.

title: A Room Is Tense as African Rhythms Meet Jazz
description: Behind the drums at Iridium on Wednesday night, Ginger Baker leaned back, his chin drawn in toward his Adams apple, holding his sticks toward the bottom, his time as far back as his posture, head fixed within a narrow swiveling perimeter, wide eyes on amber alert.

title: 2013 Carnegie International
description: Images from the exhibition at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh.

title: Global Extravaganza, but on a Human Scale
description: PITTSBURGH  The 2013 Carnegie International is a welcome shock to the system of one of the art worlds more entrenched rituals. This lean, seemingly modest, thought-out exhibition takes the big global survey of contemporary art off steroids.

title: Josh Sapans Big Picture, on Group Photos as Collectibles
description: OUT OF STORAGE,

title: BBC and Discovery Cut Back on Collaborations
description: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s and delivered natural history programs like Blue Planet, Planet Earth and Life to American viewers. Some of the BBCs wildlife documentaries and films will be co-produced by its cable channel BBC America instead of Discovery in the future, the British broadcaster said Wednesday. Discovery will continue to work with the BBC on some programs, but will also strike deals with other producers for science and natural history programs. The two collaborators have become more like competitors over the years. Discovery is increasingly an international brand, and it wants to have worldwide rights to its programming; meanwhile, the BBC wants to bolster its own branded channel in America. The two companies said they had mutually agreed to go their separate ways.

title: Mixed Up Quote
description: Happy 11/11, everyone! Ill be filling in on the blog again this week, playing SIDE B to Deb Amlen while shes off on vacation.

title: Airline Extras at a Package Rate
description: Are airlines taking a cue from magazines, Netflix, even Internet and cable packages?

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: clinical trials, the Nobel prize and noisy airports. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Starting a Vapor Trail
description: I was recently at a dinner party at a friends house. In the middle of the meal, a young woman pulled out an electronic cigarette, took two puffs, then put it away. A few guests clearly wondered about the white smoke she exhaled. Shouldnt people excuse themselves to indulge their addictions in private? This bothered me because she was among friends and shouldnt have needed the security mechanism of a cigarette. What do you make of this?

title: A Fantastic Journey
description: Images from the Wangechi Mutu show at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: A Window, Not a Mirror
description: How much does the cash-drunk New York art industry care about racism, neocolonialism, wanton consumption, persistent sexism, environmental spoilage or any other global realities? Next to not at all. How much does the same industry care about big, superbly made objects that pleasure the eye? Hugely.

title: Paper Gallery: Mirth, Mayhem, Manga and More
description: Readers who lack tickets to this weekends New York Comic Con gathering may want to savor some hard-bound alternatives. Heres a sampling.

title: State Agency Appeals After Judge Calls Air a Natural Resource
description: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality is appealing a lawsuit that it has already won  one that was filed by children. Environmental advocates say the appeal shows that the state will go to any lengths to fight the suggestion that it address climate change.

title: In the Finger Lakes, Devotion to Riesling Shows
description: Ive consumed rieslings from all over the United States. Smith-Madrone, Trefethen and Stony Hill make fine rieslings in Napa Valley, but these are legacy vines.

title: Democracy Is Instrumental to a Maestro-Free Ensemble
description: What the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which opened its 41st season on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, has always done best is to reanimate war horses. The concentration, intensity and hair-trigger responsiveness it takes for 35 or 40 musicians to play without a conductor can translate into excitement and volatility, as it did here in Beethovens Eroica Symphony.

title: The Melancholy Effects of Growing Older in Gay Culture
description: The current reconstruction of Miguel Gutierrezs myendlesslove, which opened on Wednesday at the Abrons Arts Center at Henry Street Settlement, dates to 2006, when the original piece received its first and last performance. But its roots are actually older. In 2005, Mr. Gutierrez choreographed Retrospective Exhibitionist, a piercing solo that explored the plight of a performer with fearlessness, innocence and humor. It was raw in a way that only New Yorkers can pull off; his tools, other than his own body, included a television and a boom box.

title: A Photographer With Problems
description: Theres a moment when the thriller Forgetting the Girl leaves behind the twitches of its characters psychological troubles and moves headlong into the full-bodied shivers. Directed with unerring atmospherics by Nate Taylor, this dark tale  in which Jungian shadows eventually get their close-ups  reminds us of a simple truth: Some people are flat messed up.

title: Comedy Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Amazon as The Everything Store, and Twitters Ambassador
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Libidinous Specters in the House
description: The Paranormal Activity concept spawns yet another comic variation (after A Haunted House and Scary Movie V) with Ghost Team One, a rude and somewhat crude effort in which typewriter-font intertitles, a mobile camera and staccato surveillance video intersect with a stream of slacker potty talk. A drunken Sergio (Carlos Santos) is lurching around a boisterous house party hes hosting with his sex-obsessed roommate Brad (J. R. Villarreal) when he stumbles upon what seem to be spectral lovers canoodling in a closet. Their house, it turns out, might be haunted by a long-dead brothel madam. An investigation kicks into high gear after Brad inadvertently copulates with a ghostly visitor.

title: What I Love | William Wegman
description: The artist and author William Wegman lives and works in Chelsea with his family and quartet of Weimaraners.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: GTT
description: DALLAS

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Flights of Fancy
description: Let us consider the problems of the long novel, in which the heft is apt to come in for almost as much critical examination as the content. There is, for instance, Jack Beattys famous critique of James A. Micheners Chesapeake (865 pages): My best advice is dont read it; my second best is dont drop it on your foot. Presumably, Beatty read it  or at least skimmed it  before offering these helpful hints, but you get the idea. In this hurry-scurry age, big books are viewed with suspicion, and sometimes disdain.

title: Wegmans Weimaraner Republic
description: Visit William Wegmans home and studio  a pair of connected buildings in Chelsea  and youll get a nice warm greeting from the visual artist, filmmaker and author best known for his images of dogs in assorted get-ups and poses.

title: Deadline Friday for New Yorkers to Register to Vote
description: Friday is the deadline to register to vote in the Nov. 5 general election, which in New York City will include the election of the next mayor.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Madame Restells Other Profession
description: In July, the Streetscapes column looked at the claim that the 1870 Stuyvesant was the first New York apartment house, and decided in the affirmative. But no one is on solid ground in declaring a first unless he can also propose a second, and it turns out that runner-up is a lot harder to find than the winner. Whereas the Stuyvesant was built by an old New York family, the likeliest No. 2 is the work of a woman shunned by society.

title: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 11-17
description: Raptor Festivals

title: Alice Munro: Excerpts From Her Work
description: Below are selections from the work of Alice Munro, who was awarded the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday. They are reprinted with the permission of Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Rewarding Stellar Credit
description: Lending terms are easing up for borrowers who have superior credit. But mortgages are no easier to come by for applicants with unexceptional FICO scores.

title: Spare Times for Oct. 11-17
description: The Next Level: East Side Access Photographs by Hiroyuki Suzuki (through Oct. 27) Sometimes you have to dig deep to discover something beautiful. For the Japanese photographer Hiroyuki Suzuki  who has drawn inspiration from the scope and energy of major construction projects in Tokyo, Shanghai and Dubai  that meant descending 18 stories below Grand Central Terminal to capture images of the work now under way for the nearly $8.3 billion East Side Access Project, which will connect Long Island Rail Road trains in Queens to the Terminal in Manhattan. He started photographing in 2011, the year work began; it is expected to be completed in 2019.

title: Canadian Carrier Backtracks on BlackBerry Snub
description: OTTAWA  BlackBerry has received a bit of good news. Rogers Communications, Canadas largest wireless carrier, has backtracked on its earlier decision not to sell BlackBerrys new flagship smartphone.

title: Afterlife? What Afterlife?
description: Good for nothing besides the employment of insipid young actresses, films like I Will Follow You Into the Dark believe that romance is best dealt with in hurried montage and that a crisis of faith is an acceptable substitution for a personality.

title: Insufficiently Conservative? Take That!
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: For Girls, Their Own Way to Reach the Heavens
description: Lyn Pentecost settled into a plush, comfortable seat in a planetarium in Manhattan. No, not that planetarium. This one is for only girls.

title: Happenings | Mexican Summer, the Little Indie Label That Could, Throws an Anniversary Bash
description: For certain indie rock aficionados, a release put out by the Greenpoint, Brooklyn, record label Mexican Summer carries as much weight as a 10.0 review on the review site Pitchfork. Founded in 2008 by Andrs Santo Domingo, Keith Abrahamsson and Tom Clapp as the more tuneful offshoot of their rock-oriented imprint Kemado Records, Mexican Summer has since become a bastion for experimental pop, not to mention a model for successful music publishing in the 21st century. The label, which took its name from a track by the folk singer Marissa Nadler, one of its artists, has enjoyed one success after another. The first LP by the scrappy guitar-pop band Best Coast moved more than 100,000 copies (and subsequently landed in a Windows ad), a sizable number even for a major these days. The garage rocker Kurt Vile, the lo-fi experimental weirdo Ariel Pink and the chillwave act Washed Out have also experienced success with Mexican Summer. A considerable percentage of the labels sales are on vinyl, according to Abrahamsson.

title: This Week's Movies: Oct. 11, 2013
description: The New York Times movie critics on Captain Phillips, CBGB, and Romeo & Juliet.

title: Boxers Tale, Fashioned by a Fighter
description: WHEN the experimental composer Fred Ho answered the door of his apartment on a quiet, leafy street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn recently, he seemed much as he always has: beefy and muscular, with a warm smile that, over the next hour, would return to accompany some robustly expressed views about music and politics. If he had not mentioned that he felt too weak to sit, and preferred to speak while lying on his living room sofa, you probably would not guess that he is seriously ill  that, in fact, he is in the final stage of colorectal cancer, which he has been fighting since 2006.

title: Where Sances Go Badly
description: Cassadaga, Fla., has been called the Psychic Capital of the World. With its dilapidated Queen Anne mansions and its oak trees dripping with Spanish moss, this ghostly hub seems like the perfect setting for a horror story about an obsessed spirit harassing a lonely artist.

title: Building for the Sake of Deconstruction
description: Do you like to solve puzzles? William Forsythes Sider, which had its United States premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, offers puzzles upon puzzles, and analogies, too. Yet where most puzzles tantalize with intriguing pieces of a larger picture that make you want to put together, the surface of Sider is as enticing as a sheet of cardboard.

title: You Only Live Forever
description: Discussing one of his countrys most famous exports during a visit to the Soviet Union in the 1980s, John le Carr described James Bond as a sort of licensed criminal who, in the name of false patriotism, approves of nasty crimes. One has the sense, he told Radio Times in 2010, that Bond would have gone through the same antics for any country really, if the girls had been so pretty and the martinis so dry. Its an accusation that has existed in various forms ever since the publication of Casino Royale in 1953. Bonds creator also suffered doubts, as any reader of Andrew Lycetts expansive 1995 biography, Ian Fleming (recently republished by St. Martins Press), will know. While working on Moonraker, the third of his 14 Bond books, Fleming complained that Bonds future was nothing but a vista of fantastic adventures on more or less the same pattern, but losing freshness with each volume.

title: On the Market in Aspen, Colo.
description: Homes in ski country offering from one to five bedrooms and priced from $1,150,000 to $15,500,000.

title: Shes Where the Work Is
description: As Irving Berlin names alternative occupations to the theater in Theres No Business Like Show Business, a butcher and a baker lead the list. To those you might add the Bakers Wife, from the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical Into the Woods. Joanna Gleason portrayed that character so movingly that I fell in love with her when I first saw the show in 1987.

title: Russia: Shake-Up at Space Agency
description: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev fired the general director of Russias beleaguered space agency on Thursday as part of a shake-up that had been expected after a series of embarrassing rocket failures. The dismissed official, Vladimir A. Popovkin, was appointed to lead the agency, Roscosmos, in 2011 after a failed rocket launching destroyed three satellites needed for a Russian global navigation system. Mr. Medvedev said that Oleg Ostapenko, a deputy defense minister with long experience in space operations, would be the agencys new chief. A leadership change at Roscosmos was widely expected after the failed launching of an unmanned Proton-M rocket in July. It was the fourth failed Proton launching in three years.

title: The Joys of Being Wendish, Festival and All
description: SERBIN  In a light-filled 19th-century Lutheran church with red stenciling above the blue and white balcony, worshipers prayed and sang in German. It was the closest the visitors to this Central Texas community could come to honoring their heritage now that almost no one in Texas knows Wendish, the Slavic language their ancestors spoke in Germany.

title: A Piece of Italy for Everyone
description: Leaving Fortina on a Friday night this autumn, a tiny patron in a pink tutu clasped hands with her parents and happily chirped her newfound word: Ciao! Ciao! Ciao! Passing them on the way in, a young woman in a black sequined shift and very high heels texted as she teetered toward the door. I have never in my dining experience witnessed such a seamless transition from kiddie hour to singles scene.

title: Prison Oversight Faulted in Ariel Castros Death
description: Prison guards in Ohio falsified records and failed to properly complete their rounds on the day Ariel Castro, the man convicted of holding three women captive in his Cleveland home for a decade, hanged himself in his cell last month, according to a state report released Thursday. The report suggested that Mr. Castro may have asphyxiated himself during a sexual act.

title: Boeing 787, Grounded in Norway, Nearly Fixed
description: Boeing is almost finished repairing several balky systems on a new 787 Dreamliner operated by Norwegian Air Shuttle, the latest airline to complain about annoying malfunctions, the airlines chief executive said Thursday.

title: Pentagons Top Weapons Expert to Retire
description: Ashton B. Carter, who built upon academic specialties in medieval history and theoretical physics to become the Pentagons top expert on budgets and weapons, announced Thursday that he was retiring as deputy defense secretary. Mr. Carter, 59, was central to an emergency effort under former Secretary Robert M. Gates to rush heavily armored transport vehicles to Iraq. The initiative was hailed by troops as a lifesaving defense against roadside bombs. He was promoted to deputy secretary in 2011 and oversaw the complex task of devising strategy in a time of declining budgets, and he was said to have been under consideration when Mr. Obama picked Chuck Hagel to follow Leon E. Panetta as secretary.

title: Columbus Day Closings in New York City
description: NEW YORK

title: He Died as He Loved to Live, on the Edge
description: Shane McConkey took huge risks in pursuit of his dreams, pulling off feats that most people can hardly fathom (and some dismiss as foolish): big-mountain skiing, base jumping from glaciers, skiing off cliffs  la the chase scene in The Spy Who Loved Me. In 2009, he died the way he lived  doing what he loved  and a new documentary, McConkey, serves as a rousing testament to that freewheeling spirit.

title: Pentagon Drops Backup Helmet for F-35 Pilots
description: The Pentagon said on Thursday that it had decided to stop working on a conventional backup helmet for pilots of the new F-35 fighter jet and stick with a troubled, but improving, higher-tech model.

title: A Senator Raises Privacy Questions About Cross-Device Tracking
description: A lawmaker has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate online ad companies that track consumers across devices, like showing them ads on their phones based on Web sites they visit on a computer.

title: From Rock Album to Stage Musical
description: Broadway Idiot, a documentary by Doug Hamilton about the making of the Broadway show American Idiot, never feels as if it were delving too deeply into the creative process, which turned a best-selling Green Day album into a stage musical. But as a chronicle of how one rock star slowly fell victim to the Broadway bug, its kind of amusing.

title: A Glass, Maybe a Bottle, and a Few Plates
description: Francescas Wine Bar and Bistro, in Collinsville, is more than just an intimate place in which to enjoy a glass of merlot or pinot noir. It is also the nearest thing this former mill town has to a fine-dining establishment.

title: Two Are Charged in Plan to Send Goods to Taliban
description: Two New York City men have been arrested on charges that they sought to supply the Taliban and other terrorist fighters with warm clothes and equipment for use in wintertime battle with United States forces in Afghanistan, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: Hitting Pay Dirt
description: Unlike many recent documentaries about our careless stewardship of the planet, Deborah Koons Garcias Symphony of the Soil doesnt feel like a rap on the knuckles. Unfolding with gentle joy and an unexpected beauty, this ode to the miracle of the Earths topmost layer gives us a newfound respect for the ground beneath our feet.

title: Health Act Embraced in California
description: LOS ANGELES  There are radio and television commercials galore, along with Twitter and Facebook posts and scores of highway billboards. There are armies of outreach workers who speak Spanish, Tagalog, Cambodian, Mandarin and Cantonese, all flocking to county fairs, farmers markets, street festivals and back-to-school nights across the state. There are even dinner parties in Latino neighborhoods designed to reach one family at a time.

title: A Bizarre Scavenger Hunt in San Francisco
description: Spencer McCalls puzzling documentary The Institute wades into the mysteries of an experiment in alternate-reality gaming that took place a few years ago in San Francisco. Curious gamers loved the scavenger hunt/ sub-Pynchon intrigues, engineered by benevolent creators representing a supposed organization; we learn about it, a little, which is not quite the same as playing along.

title: In Florida, Opposition by the State and Snags in Signing Up on the Web
description: MIAMI  Be it gold, silver or bronze level, there are two ironclad requirements for buying health insurance in Florida on the federal online exchange: patience and persistence.

title: Court the Soul, Pummel the Sexuality
description: A searing look at the role of American evangelical missionaries in the persecution of gay Africans, Roger Ross Williamss God Loves Uganda approaches this intersection of faith and politics with some fairness and a good deal of outrage.

title: Suit Filed Against Warner Bros. in Screenplay Theft
description: LOS ANGELES  Warner Brothers responded harshly on Thursday to a legal complaint over the authorship of its Clint Eastwood baseball movie, Trouble With the Curve. But its opponents did not back down.

title: VW Plant Opens Door to Union and Dispute
description: FRANKFURT  The face-off between Volkswagen and the United Automobile Workers over organizing the companys new plant in Tennessee is rapidly becoming a global clash of cultures.

title: Serenity, and a Few Sly Smiles, for the U.S.
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  At its core, soccer is a game of rhythm and flow. But the international version is fundamentally stunted.

title: Stocks Rally, Talks Stall, Then Skepticism Returns
description: Investors embraced signs of a political compromise that could avert a default on government debt, sending stocks surging on Thursday.

title: Wheelchair Racer Could Be First to Win 3 Major Marathons in a Season
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.  On a recent afternoon, Tatyana McFadden wheeled her racing chair onto a quiet street to begin a training session. She rolled through the University of Illinois campus here, past the football stadium, by a cemetery and then a residential street lined with bungalows. Cornfields were in the distance. Her legs, which she has never used to walk, were tucked beneath her torso.

title: Blue Cross Plans Jump to an Early Lead
description: Color the new online insurance marketplaces Blue.

title: Outside National Parks, Feeling Squeezed by the Shutdown
description: SPRINGDALE, Utah  In the 10 days since Zion National Park closed its gates, the community on its doorstep has become a shutdown ghost town. Hotel rooms are dark, and housecleaners are working half-shifts. Herds of campers and sightseers have streamed away along the only highway out of town, and canceled reservations from New Zealand, California and Germany are piling up every day.

title: Gay Rights Protests Follow Gergiev to Carnegie Hall
description: The furor in the West over Russias new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality continues to dog the conductor Valery Gergiev, who is one of Russias most important cultural exports these days. Mr. Gergiev, a prominent supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who signed the law, drew protests Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, just as he did last month at the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Lapsed, but Listening
description: Just days before he got the diagnosis of the cancer that would kill him in 2011, Christopher Hitchens was flinging word bolts at pilgrims while promoting his book God Is Not Great. After his presentation, I asked him why, given that so few Americans self-identify as atheists, his book had found such a large audience.

title: Fed Up With Fund-Raising for My Kids School
description: AMID the flurry of school notices coming home in my kids backpacks, the PTA donation envelope carries a nostalgic pang. I remember thinking, only four years ago as my first child entered school, that a modest contribution to the PTA was my only cash obligation to New York Citys public schools  beyond being a dutiful taxpayer, of course.

title: Two Brazilian Brothers to Pay Nearly $5 Million in Insider Trading Case
description: The bullish bet on H. J. Heinz flashed all the telltale signs of insider trading.

title: Dealing With Default
description: So Republicans may have decided to raise the debt ceiling without conditions attached  the details still arent clear. Maybe thats the end of that particular extortion tactic, but maybe not, because, at best, were only looking at a very short-term extension. The threat of hitting the ceiling remains, especially if the politics of the shutdown continue to go against the G.O.P.

title: Libyas Security Crisis
description: The American commando operation that snatched a suspected leader of Al Qaeda from his neighborhood in Tripoli, while successful, does not offer a permanent strategy to the threat from extremists in Libya. That point was reinforced on Thursday when the countrys prime minister, Ali Zeidan, was briefly kidnapped by militia members in apparent retaliation for his consenting to the raid.

title: An Inadequate Offer From the House
description: Speaker John Boehner on Thursday said he was willing to delay briefly a disastrous default of the countrys financial obligations but was not willing to reopen the government. I would hope that the president would look at this as an opportunity and a good-faith effort on our part to move halfway  halfway to what hes demanded, he said.

title: Gambling on Loaded Language
description: New York voters will decide in November whether to allow seven new casinos to open across the state. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and most members of the Legislature are strongly in favor of these casinos. But they do not have the right to skew the language on the ballot, as they have contrived to do, in a way that tips the scales in favor of a pro-gambling outcome.

title: A Nobel Prize for Alice Munro
description: Over a long career, Alice Munros work has deepened and widened, so that coming new to one of her stories, you find all the others in your mind, mapping in some vestigial way a Canadian geography that feels continuous, no matter how much the stories shift in time and place.

title: Jerry Kill Makes a Difficult, but Prudent, Call
description: Those who knew Jerry Kill best, who watched him go through seizures in packed stadiums and return to work as if nothing happened, dreaded the situation that unfolded Thursday. They dreaded the day that Kill, an epileptic who inspired thousands of fellow epileptics, would step away from coaching.

title: In Africa, Seeking a License to Kill
description: CAPE TOWN  MEMBERS of the African Union will meet in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, today to discuss recent calls by some African leaders to withdraw from the International Criminal Court. These calls must be resisted. The continent has suffered the consequences of unaccountable governance for too long to disown the protections offered by the I.C.C.

title: For CVS Regulars, Ads Tailored Just to Them
description: ONCE, the letters in the name of the CVS drugstore chain stood for Consumer Value Store. Now, they could also stand for Customized Virtual Shopping.

title: Saudi Women Drive, Despite Ban, and Find Some Support on the Kingdoms Roads
description: Last Updated, Friday, 11:30 a.m. | A brief flurry of civil disobedience on the roads of Saudi Arabia this week, by women who flouted the conservative kingdoms ban on female drivers and documented it on Twitter and YouTube, ended on Thursday in a predictable manner  with an image of officers pulling alongside one car, captioned simply, Police stopped us.

title: After Tragic Loss During Hurricane Sandy, a Woman Chooses Not to Return
description: Patricia Dresch and her husband, George, lived in their home in Tottenville, Staten Island, for about 30 years, a wood-frame house where they raised two daughters.

title: Can Playing Ball Be Bad for Children?
Tutoring Help in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarcasm in the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Rearview Cameras on Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics and Art
description: To the Editor:

title: The G.O.P. Role in the Fiscal Crisis
Refuge From the Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. Warning on Snowden in 09 Said to Slip Through the Cracks
description: WASHINGTON  Just as Edward J. Snowden was preparing to leave Geneva and a job as a C.I.A. technician in 2009, his supervisor wrote a derogatory report in his personnel file, noting a distinct change in the young mans behavior and work habits, as well as a troubling suspicion.

title: Kochs and Other Conservatives Split Over Strategy on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Under attack for the government shutdown, some of the most vocal elements of the conservative wing of the Republican Party are publicly splintering, a sign of growing concerns among even hard-core conservatives that the defeat-health-care-at-any-cost strategy may have backfired.

title: Undercover Police, Just About Everywhere
description: It may not have occurred to people that New York City needed to deploy an undercover detective to spy on Occupy Sandy, a relief operation run by activists that delivered food and supplies to parts of the city ruined by the hurricane. But Detective Wojciech Braszczok, who embedded with the Occupy Wall Street forces under the nom de activist Albert, was putting posts on Twitter last November about the Sandy operation, which, by the way, received consistently high grades from people for its nimble, effective work.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 10, 2013
Ryan Is Again in the Forefront for the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Paul D. Ryan may have temporarily receded into the Capitol shadows after his stinging vice-presidential defeat in November, but he remains a powerful presence among House Republicans, earning the respect of hard-line conservatives for his budget blueprint and the trust of anxious moderates for his pragmatism.

title: The Alphabet Soup of Health Spending Plans
description: H.S.A.S, F.S.A.s  theres an alphabet soup of health spending plans out there. Last month, when I mentioned health savings accounts in an article, some readers seemed to confuse them with flexible-spending arrangements, which function quite differently.

title: U.N. Questions Criticism of Its Peacekeepers
description: The United Nations responded on Thursday with a mix of diplomatic decorum and criticism to a report asserting systemic flaws in the way that it selects and trains peacekeeping troops. The conclusions of the report, undertaken by Transparency International UK, a prominent corruption monitoring group, appeared to have surprised and angered some United Nations officials.

title: U.S. Offer Would Let Some States Open Parks
description: The governors of at least four states expressed initial interest in an offer on Thursday from Interior Secretary Sally Jewell to allow them to reopen national parks in their states, though it remained unclear whether any such deals could be reached soon.

title: The Quashing of a Case Against a Christie Ally
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J.  Prosecutors sent tremors through rural Hunterdon County when they announced a sweeping indictment of the local Republican sheriff and her two deputies in 2010.

title: Fifth Suspect Is Indicted in 2005 Killing of Ex-Lebanese Premier
description: PARIS  An international court has indicted a fifth suspect in the 2005 killing of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanon prime minister, describing the suspect, like the other four indictees, as a member of Hezbollah.

title: No Clues in Deaths of Brooklyn Mother and Infant
description: A woman and her 11-day-old son were found unconscious in their Brooklyn home on Thursday morning and were later pronounced dead, but the authorities could provide no immediate explanation for what had killed them.

title: N.L.C.S. Preview: For the Dodgers, a Model in the Opposite Dugout
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers get a lot of attention for their payroll, which was $216 million on opening day, a full $100 million more than the payroll of the St. Louis Cardinals, their opponents in the National League Championship Series.

title: Master of the Intricacies of the Human Heart
description: Alice Munro, named on Thursday as the winner of the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature, once observed: The complexity of things  the things within things  just seems to be endless. I mean nothing is easy, nothing is simple.

title: Theater Listings for Oct. 11-17
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Not Wasting Time, PGA Starts New Season With a Crowd
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  Before sunrise, the Argentine Miguel ngel Carballo was on the practice range waiting to see whether the new PGA Tour season would take flight with or without him. He would spend the next six and a half hours hoping to hear his name called.

title: Mercury Astronaut Scott Carpenter Dies at 88
description: Mr. Carpenter was the second American to orbit the Earth, following John Glenn, now the only surviving member of Americas original space program.

title: Corrections: October 11, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Little Girl Blue Howls Again, but Talks Sensibly, Too
description: The party onstage at the Lyceum Theater, where A Night With Janis Joplin opened on Thursday night, turns out to be more crowded than you might expect. This latest in Broadways endless stream of boomer-bait musical tributes isnt just a matter of a big-voiced singer, her backup band and a bottle of Southern Comfort.

title: The Dangers of Pseudoscience
description: Philosophers of science have been preoccupied for a while with what they call the demarcation problem, the issue of what separates good science from bad science and pseudoscience (and everything in between). The problem is relevant for at least three reasons.

title: Response to a Threat
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  As far as I know, Peter A. Collins is a lovely guy, but he seems a bit grumpy today. Lets see if we can cheer him up by saying nice things about his puzzle.

title: City Council Moves to Stall Land Leases at Public Housing
description: The New York City Council and a group of tenants sued the Bloomberg administration on Thursday over plans to lease land in public housing developments for the creation of market-rate apartments.

title: Inconvenient Uncertainties
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  THE headline in The New York Times yesterday was succinct. By 2047, Coldest Years May Be Warmer Than Hottest in Past, Scientists Say. Not, say, around 2050 or within our lifetime. The specificity makes the crisis feel real, imminent and terrible. Call it a convenient truth. The story was about a new study published this week in the journal Nature that calculated that by 2047, the average temperature will be hotter across most parts of the planet than it had been at those locations in any year between 1860 and 2005.

title: Jury Finds Toyota Not Liable in Death of California Driver
description: A jury in Los Angeles cleared Toyota Motor of fault on Thursday in a fatal 2009 accident in which a 66-year-old woman crashed her Camry.

title: Bookers Father Dies After Long Illness
description: The final stretch of the United States Senate campaign in New Jersey, already more unpredictable than expected, was jolted again on Thursday by the death of the father of the Democratic candidate, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark.

title: Lhota Continues to Trail de Blasio by Wide Margin, Poll Finds
description: At least it is not a 50-point lead anymore.

title: Grand Jury Cites Deaths of Children in Inquiry
description: A Brooklyn grand jury found that 19 children in New York City died of abuse and neglect because the citys child protective agency had failed to rigorously investigate cases even after a city report recommended new practices in 2007.

title: Mother to Visit American Held in North Korea
description: The mother of Kenneth Bae, an American of Korean descent who has been held in North Korea for nearly a year and is in failing health, has been granted permission by the North Korean authorities to visit him and arrived in Pyongyang on Thursday, his family reported.

title: Imero Fiorentino, Lighting Designer Who Mastered Television, Dies at 85
description: He made drinks sparkle, desserts shimmer and Richard M. Nixon look less shadowy  all with meticulous tricks of the light.

title: Off the Couch and Back With the Jets for Garrard
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It was not really the jogging, the weight training or the physical therapy that told David Garrard his chronic left knee troubles had healed enough for him to come out of retirement. It was playing wide receiver for his wife, a quarterback on a flag football team in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Coop and Papa, Manning Up in Good Times and Bad
description: Gary Cooper and Ernest Hemingway, two models of American virility, had similarities, not least as outdoorsmen: Cooper grew up on a farm in Montana, and Hemingway was a big-game hunter and deep-sea fisherman. But they were also a study in contrasts: Cooper worked with movie crews; Hemingway labored alone. Cooper was understated and conservative, Hemingway volatile and a liberal. The mix, as John Mulhollands exhaustive documentary Cooper & Hemingway: The True Gen demonstrates, made for a friendship spanning decades.

title: Shirley Chisholm Gets a Stamp of Approval
description: A stamp honoring Shirley A. Chisholm, the former congresswoman from New York, may soon grace your mail.

title: Jealousy and Spite as Game Figurines
description: Theres a new nerd in town, and hes causing all kinds of problems for Scott (Sam Eidson), the loathsome role-playing gamer whose downward spiral fuels Zero Charisma.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,270 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Ah, Those Giddy Teenage Pool Parties
description: A horror movie rises from the dead with All the Boys Love Mandy Lane, a theatrical release seven years in coming. Though it had its premiere at the 2006 Toronto International Film Festival, this feature-length debut from Jonathan Levine has a timeless premise: Horny teenagers are picked off by a bloodthirsty killer in an isolated location. The delay is marginally more an injustice than a condemnation.

title: Linear Genius, Bold and Transformative
description: Every time we take the subway in New York, were in Vignelli-land, says Paola Antonelli, senior curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, in the new documentary Design Is One. Ms. Antonelli is referring to the Italian couple Lella and Massimo Vignelli, whose firm designed many graphic elements for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Mr. Vignelli created a 1972 subway map that the designer Milton Glaser refers to in the film as a conceptual breakthrough.

title: Calm Before the Storm
description: Henri Coles lyric verse about watching a hurricane from afar reminds the artist Hernan Bas of visiting a cemetery in New Orleans before Katrina.

title: One of Englands Most Renowned Clans, in Its Native Habitat
description: Two generations of one of Englands most celebrated families  Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant  make beautiful, unusual and deeply personal art that draws from the natural world.

title: The Dubious Case for Professional Licensing
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Syrian Civilians Bore Brunt of Rebels Fury, Report Says
description: LATAKIA, Syria  Before dawn on Aug. 4, Raed Shakouhi, an olive and walnut farmer in a government-held hilltop village near the Syrian coast, just across a valley from rebel territory, was woken by gunshots and cries of God is great.

title: Ask Well: Leaving Nail Fungus Untreated
description: Question:

title: The Mystery Man Behind the Monsters
description: Escalators that eat people; a human sacrifice amid backyard barbeques. In any pantheon of cartoonists, Gahan Wilson and his uniquely mordant sense of humor fit somewhere between Charles Addams and Gary Larson. Armed with a perverse comedic view of the monsters behind every corner and an illustration style that hits with the thwack of a nightmare, Mr. Wilson has been reassuring his readers for more than 50 years that things really are as bad as they seem, probably worse.

title: Word of the Day | wanderlust
description: wanderlust \wn-dr-lst\ noun

title: The Human Rights Watch Report
description: Human Rights Watch said it had documented for the first time that Syrian rebel groups targeted civilians in Latakia for executions and hostage-taking. More than 200 people were still being held, the agency said.

title: Verlanders Mastery Extends Athletics Misery as Tigers Advance
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Detroit Tigers celebrated in a haze of smoke, pitcher Justin Verlander among those puffing on cigars between smiles and hugs. The ceiling dripped the spent remains of 15 cases of sparkling wine. A stereo thumped.

title: For Giants, a Familiar Start With Another Ugly Ending
description: CHICAGO  In the Giants season-opening game, Eli Manning threw an interception on the first play from scrimmage. Demonstrating improvement in the sixth game of the season Thursday night, Manning did not throw an interception until the third play of the game.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 11, 2013
description: We cannot be compared to other countries where they had strong institutions of army and police. In Libya we did not have institutions.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) UNBREAKABLE: ONE GIRL CHANGING THE WORLD On Oct. 9, 2012, Malala Yousafzai, a teenage spokeswoman for girls education in Pakistan, was shot in the head by Taliban attackers. Her story of courage and determination captured the publics imagination and inspired a global movement, resulting in her nomination for the 2013 Nobel Peace Prize. If she wins on Friday, she will be the youngest recipient ever. In this special edition of 20/20, Ms. Yousafzai, above, speaks with Diane Sawyer about her passion for learning amid threats, the moments leading up to the assassination attempt, her recovery and her new memoir, I Am Malala. Margaret Warner will also interview Ms. Yousafzai on PBS NewsHour, at 7 on Channels 13 and 49.

title: News Quiz | October 11, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: The Faces of Carrie
description: A look at some of the many versions of the picked-on heroines signature look.

title: A Conversation With: Human Rights Activist Rikke Nhrlind
description: On Thursday, the European Parliament, which consists of elected representatives from the 28 member countries of the European Union, passed a resolution that condemned caste-based discrimination as a human rights violation.

title: On Iran Talks, Congress Could Play Bad Cop
description: WASHINGTON  When Iranian diplomats sit down in Geneva next Tuesday with the United States and five other world powers for a new round of talks about Irans nuclear program, Congress will not have a seat at the table. But that does not mean it will not have a voice.

title: Test Yourself | Editing, Oct. 11, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: Bay Area Averts a Transit System Strike, for Now
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Minutes before a state-ordered 60-day cooling off period was set to expire on Thursday night, negotiators for employees of the Bay Areas main commuter railroad said they would stay at the bargaining table, temporarily averting a major transit strike.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Alice Munro Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
description: In the article Alice Munro Wins Nobel Prize in Literature, Julie Bosman writes about the announcement of the winner of this prestigious prize.

title: W. Eugene Smiths Big Book, His Way
description: W. Eugene Smith won renown for perfecting the modern photo essay during his years at Life magazine. But he was also well known for being the most difficult photojournalist an editor would ever encounter.

title: Are Some Youth Sports Too Intense?
description: Do you know children or preteenagers who are on sports teams so competitive that they spend several days a week nearly every week of the year playing? Whose families have organized their whole lives around getting these students to and from games and practices?

title: Chemical Weapons Watchdog Wins Nobel Peace Prize
description: LONDON  Urging the destruction of an entire category of unconventional weapons, the Norwegian Nobel Committee awarded its 2013 Peace Prize on Friday to a modest and little-known United Nations-backed organization that has drawn sudden attention with a mission to ensure that Syrias stocks of chemical arms are eradicated.

title: Alitalia Board Approves $676 Million Rescue Plan
description: Scrambling to stave off an imminent collapse of Alitalia, the airlines board voted unanimously late Friday to approve a rescue package of 500 million euros, or $676 million, for the carrier that was likely to result in its partial renationalization five years after it was rescued from bankruptcy.

title: New York Today: Winging It
description: Updated 12:03 p.m. | It is an annual fall migration  via FedEx.

title: Police Are Getting the Militarys Leftover Armored Trucks
description: The Sept. 11 attacks and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have had a broad impact on American society. It could be argued that one of its vestiges has been a keen interest in armored vehicles by many police departments.

title: Del Monte Foods Sells Consumer Products Division for $1.68 Billion
description: Del Monte Foods is finally shedding its long-held canned fruits and vegetables business.

title: Taking the Path of Profits Over Growth
description: In the Innovators Solution: Creating and Sustaining Successful Growth, Clayton Christensen and Michael Raynor suggest impatience for profits and patience for growth. This means that when starting a new venture, profits are most important. Without them your venture will have a hard time reaching sustainability.

title: JPMorgans Loss Is Corporate Law Firms Gain
description: Updated, 8:38 p.m. | The calls started flooding into JPMorgan Chase last month.

title: Gay People Have Children, Too
description: LONDON Daniel Vais, an Israeli Londoner with no connection to Russia, got in touch with me last week. We need someone to talk about what its like in Russia now, because we dont really know, said Vais, who runs the local TEDx event in Hackney, the part of east London where I live. He was organizing a small gathering at a theater near the Olympic Park to support Russias beleaguered gay community and wanted me to talk about my own experience living in Russia and the history of gay rights there.

title: JPMorgan Swings to Loss
description: JPMorgan Chase reported a third-quarter net loss on Friday of $380 million, or 17 cents a share, as regulatory and legal woes dragged down the banks results. Excluding the one-time costs, JPMorgans earnings were $1.42 a share, or $5.8 billion, beating analysts expectations of $4.65 billion, or $1.21 a share. The banks earnings were weighed down by a legal expense of $9.2 billion.

title: Each Generation Gets a Carrie It Deserves
description: Carrie White has been remarkably resilient. Getting pelted with tampons for decades will do that to a girl.

title: Career Builders and Now Doting Parents
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: The ICT Revolution Isnt Over
description: We have a Griswold Center event tonight in which Bob Gordon and I will discuss  debate is too strong a word  his pessimism about future growth. Ill post more about all that after the event; dont want to give away my (weak) punchlines. But I thought I would make one casual observation about technology.

title: France Upholds Ban on Hydraulic Fracturing
description: PARIS  Frances highest court on Friday upheld a government ban on a controversial drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing, in a defeat for a method that has revolutionized the oil and natural gas industry in the United States.

title: Divide Narrows as Talks to Resolve Fiscal Crisis Go On
description: WASHINGTON  Political divisions over the nations finances appeared to narrow on Friday as President Obama and Congressional Republicans showed greater flexibility in their negotiations. But officials headed into the weekend without a deal to end the shutdown and avert what could be a devastating default after the government reaches the current borrowing limit on Thursday.

title: Wells Fargo Quarterly Earnings Jump 13%
description: For Wells Fargos investors, it is hard to argue with 15 consecutive jumps in quarterly profit. And that trend continued on Friday, when the bank announced a 13 percent rise in third-quarter profit to a record $5.6 billion, or 99 cents a share, beating the expectations of analysts.

title: Christina Romer on Janet Yellen
description: Janet Yellens longtime friend and colleague, Christina D. Romer, discusses Ms. Yellens relationship with her husband, George A. Akerlof, a Nobel prize holder in economic science.

title: Kerry Visits Afghan Leader, Seeking End to an Impasse
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Last Saturday, Secretary of State John Kerry called President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan with a simple question: If Mr. Kerry came to Kabul, would it help break a deadlock in negotiations to keep American forces in Afghanistan beyond next year?

title: Israeli Man Fatally Bludgeoned in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli man who was a colonel in the reserves was fatally bludgeoned in the Jordan Valley area of the West Bank on Friday, according to the Israeli military, and security forces detained five Palestinians in connection with the attack.

title: Google to Sell Users Endorsements
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Those long-forgotten posts on social networks, from the pasta someone photographed to the rant about her dentist, are forgotten no more. Social networks want to make them easier to find, and in some cases, to show them in ads.

title: A Rescue on the Subway Tracks
description: Dear Diary:

title: Poland Moves Forward on Bill That Would Transfer Private Pensions to State
description: Ignoring warnings that it could deter foreign investment, the Polish government has announced a draft bill that would require private pension funds to transfer about 35.2 billion euros, or $47.6 billion, in government bonds to the state in February.

title: Daily Report: Google to Sell Users Endorsements
description: Google, following in Facebooks footsteps, wants to sell users endorsements to marketers to help them hawk their wares, Claire Cain Miller and Vindu Goel report.

title: Royal Mail Shares Surge in Debut
description: Updated, 12:39 p.m. |

title: Toyota Recalls 10,000 Models for Windshield Wiper Problem
description: Toyota will recall about 10,000 of its newest and most popular models to fix a problem with the windshield wiper switch, the automaker said Thursday. The action covers 2013-14 Camry and Camry Hybrid models, the 2013 Avalon and Avalon Hybrid and the 2014 Corolla.

title: Off the Charts: And the Last Shall Be First
description: Oct. 9 has twice been a turning point for stocks in this century. After the 2001 recession, the American market hit bottom on Oct. 9, 2002, and then peaked exactly five years later, on Oct. 9, 2007. American stocks underperformed most of the world during that five-year period, but have outperformed in the six years from 2007 to now. Within the United States, sectors that lagged in the earlier period have been strong more recently.

title: A Tale of Two Recessions and World Markets, Turned on Their Heads
description: WHATS in a date?

title: Small Businesses in Mumbai Bear Brunt of High Inflation
description: MUMBAI Nayan Lapsia spent much of a humid Wednesday afternoon looking despairingly at the idle cash register at his store in Crawford Market, a colonial-era open-air market in the heart of Mumbai, Indias financial capital. Though customers have stopped by fleetingly to glance at goods, things were unusually quiet at his shop, Shah Bhavanji Kunvarji & Company, which is stacked with all manner of spices and dry fruit.

title: Amber Teething Necklaces Pose Choking Hazard
description: When model Gisele Bndchen posted a photo of herself and her young child on Instagram this summer, the snapshot, which showed her infant daughter wearing tiny earrings, ignited debate on blogs about the appropriate age for ear piercing. But a more serious concern, missed in many of the discussions, was the delicate necklace of amber beads looped around the babys neck.

title: The Costs of Fantasy Politics
description: As of this morning, theres reason to hope that some time next week the government shutdown will end, the debt ceiling will be temporarily raised, and Ill be able to write a follow-up tomy column on Pope Francis, or something about whatshouldbe the political story of the moment the dont-call-it-trainwreck debut of Healthcare.gov  or even (who knows?) something more esoteric and random and fun. But for today, let me go one more round withBen Domenech, whowrote yesterday in defense of a Republican strategythat would lift the debt ceiling while keeping the government shutdown going, and going, and going a move that I likened on CNN to postponing a murder-suicide in order to just concentrate on slitting your own wrists, but which Domenech regards in a more favorable light. Tomy previous suggestionthat the shutdown is ratifying the publics pre-existing distrust of G.O.P. governance, he writes:

title: The War On The Poor Is A War On You-Know-Who
description: Lots of people have been referencing this Democracy Corps report on focus-group meetings with Republicans, and with good reason: Greenberg has basically provided a unified theory of the craziness that has enveloped American politics in the last few years.

title: Dont Feed the Trolls
description: Some readers have been asking when Im going to reply to certain rants aimed my way. The answer is, never.

title: Skills Practice | Concise Writing
description: This week, the third in our new Skills lesson series, Sarah Gross, an enthusiastic Twitter user and connected educator, suggests using an article on the art of the Twitter bio to teach lessons about concise writing and word choice.

title: Five Fillings for Stuffed Peppers
description: These roasted yellow peppers are filled with a savory mix of quinoa seasoned with garlic and parsley and tossed with Manchego or Parmesan cheese. The roasted peppers make a nice contrast in color and flavor to the sweet tomato sauce. Youll get plenty of Vitamin C and lycopene from both the peppers and the sauce in this dish.

title: Week 6 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Saints (5-0) at Patriots (4-1)

title: Notes on Interregional and International Trade
description: My brief paper (pdf) for a Walter Isard memorial volume.

title: The Feds Downward Trend at the Top
description: Since Paul Volcker, who stands 6 foot 7, left the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve in 1987, each successive Fed leader has stood at least a bit closer to the ground. Interest rates, coincidentally, have followed a similar path. With Janet Yellen poised to take over, the federal funds rate  a benchmark that sets the overnight cost of borrowing for banks  is effectively zero.

title: An Academic Home
description: Andrew K. Rose, a colleague of Janet Yellen at the University of California, Berkeley, discusses Ms. Yellen's role as a professor.

title: My Fake Levantine Romance
description: Our first date was at the best hummusia in Israel. We sat hillside in a white stone building, while the hummus, soaked with olive oil and topped with pine nuts and Egyptian brown beans, melted in our mouths like clotted cream. We were a few miles from Jerusalem on a scorching desert afternoon, in the Arab village of Abu Ghosh, a town known not only for its hummus but also for its peaceful relationship with nearby Jewish settlements.

title: Parts and Labor (and Luck)
description: I recently took my car to a mechanic because it had suddenly started making an alarmingly loud noise when the brakes were applied. He removed and cleaned the brake pads, but the noise persisted. After three more hours, he finally declared it a mystery. He didnt charge me anything, and I didnt offer to pay. But the following day, the brakes made significantly less noise, and now they are barely audible. Am I obligated to return to his shop and offer payment? ANAT CHEMERINSKI,BALTIMORE

title: Whos Winning the Architecture Arms Race?
description: Answer: Baku, Azerbaijan, where the government is spending an estimated $6 billion a year on architecture projects. As we wrote in February, Azerbaijans leaders want to make their capital city a destination for the rich and fabulous. The latest example: the Heydar Aliyev Center designed by Zaha Hadid, for whom it offered the rare opportunity of nearly total design freedom. Every roof and ceiling panel is different, Hadid says. Though the center does not officially open until Nov. 1, people are already climbing on its base, says the photographer Iwan Baan. But I havent seen any skateboarders yet. Maya Lau

title: Catie Marron: Blame Pastis, Not the High Line
description: Your book, City Parks: Public Places, Private Thoughts, is an anthology of writers musing about their favorite public parks. What was the genesis of the idea?  I went to Paris for the first time when I was 23. We went to the Luxembourg Gardens one morning, and I was nearly moved to tears. It became my favorite place in the world. Whenever I was in Paris, I would insist on going there, even on the way to the airport.

title: Why Dont We Dance Anymore?
description: When a dance move is born, the air is heavy with promise. Think of Chubby Checker, doing the twist with casual grace on American Bandstand. Think of that first surreal nightclub scene in Sweet Charity, in which Shirley MacLaines young dancehall hostess is mesmerized by a troop of dancers serving Bob Fosses unique style of ber-mod gesticulation. Think of Jennifer Bealss solo audition in Flashdance, the movie that led to a million ripped sweatshirts. Think of Michael Jacksons first moonwalk.

title: Smoking Is for the Birds
description: The secret to making it in the N.F.L.; Mario Batalis wine of the season; who is an essential employee anyway?

title: Nicolas Jaar Tests the Limits of Dance Music
description: When Nicolas Jaar was 17, he e-mailed a piece of electronic music, which he made on his laptop, to a record label in Brooklyn. Hed heard an interview with the owner of the label, Wolf + Lamb, who was going on about house music and elasticity. Jaar felt he knew exactly what the guy was talking about. Wolf + Lamb agreed to put out Jaars first E.P. and invited him to perform at a somewhat sketchy space called the Marcy Hotel in Williamsburg. At the time, Jaar was a senior at the Lyce Franais on Manhattans Upper East Side.

title: The 9.29.13 Issue
description: WE LIKE YOU SO MUCH AND WANT TO KNOW YOU BETTER

title: Whos Winning the Architecture Arms Race?
description: Hint: Its the place spending an estimated $6 billion a year on it.

title: Autumn of the Jackass
description: At first glance, the old man in the cardigan and the backpack-toting boy sitting on an outdoor bench in a Los Angeles suburb were an image of harmless innocence: just a drowsy octogenarian being looked after by his fidgety grandson. When the old man leaned back, closed his eyes and appeared to nod off, the cherubic child took out a permanent marker and pulled off its cap. With painstaking precision, the boy proceeded to write the word fart in thick capital letters on his grandfathers forehead.

title: Who Made That Android Logo?
description: Irina Blok may have drawn one of the most recognized logos in the world, but her association with the green Android has not made her famous. Blok can think of only one incident when she garnered the publics attention for designing it. In 2010, she and her 6-year-old daughter were in a movie theater waiting for Alice in Wonderland to begin when an Android logo flashed on the screen. Her daughter, Blok recalls, suddenly stood up and yelled, My mommy invented that! Everyone in the row in front of them turned around to stare. Blok was so embarrassed, she says, that she sank down behind her tub of popcorn.

title: Ahab, Huck and Walt
description: Norman Mailer once said of The Sopranos that the wide canvas associated with the Great American Novel was moving to television. The Wire has been compared to the work of Dickens. So it makes sense that literary types were following along on Twitter when Breaking Bad wrapped up on Sept. 29.

title: Sports
description: AMERICAN PASTIMESThe Very Best of Red SmithEdited by Daniel Okrent  Library of America, $29.95.

title: Inside the List
description: Ode to Meat: As Ron Swanson, the gruff parks director on NBCs sitcom Parks and Recreation, Nick Offerman plays Americas cuddliest libertarian outside Rand Paul. (Inside Rand Paul its too dark, Groucho Marx never said.) How much overlap exists between Offerman and his character? Its a question the actor  who grew up on an Illinois farm, loves woodworking and deplores the increasingly soft temperament of his hometown  invites in his autobiography, Paddle Your Own Canoe, new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8.

title: Paperback Row
description: SAN MIGUEL,  by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Penguin, $16.) In Boyles mesmerizing 14th novel, two utopians from different eras  Will Waters, a veteran of the Civil War, and later, Herbie Lester, a World War I veteran  establish private idylls on the desolate Channel Islands off the California coast. As these men pursue dreams of freedom and self-reliance, their wives grapple with the hardships of raising a family in brutal isolation.

title: Its Not Just Political Districts. Our News Is Gerrymandered, Too.
description: I read an interview this last week with someone who gets his news from a narrow band of information providers.

title: Editors Choice
description: PERV: The Sexual Deviant in All of Us,  by Jesse Bering. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Melissophilia, climacophilia, titillagnia: Bering provocatively examines notions of deviance and the wide- ranging triggers of human desire.

title: International Arrivals
description: Whether theyre arriving by boat, plane or a great gust of wind, characters in three new picture books find themselves in unknown territory. Their stories focus not on the voyage over but on the complex journey that begins upon arrival, as they learn how to navigate a puzzling new world until it gradually turns into a place that feels like home. While many childrens books about the experience of immigration are rooted in particular cultures and histories, all three of these books emphasize the universal aspects of acclimating to the unfamiliar.

title: Thrills and Chills
description: Where would teenage mysteries be without idiotic antics like going down to the docks alone late at night or opening haunted lockets? And where would Victorian London be without Undead motifs like fog and Scotland Yard? In two new middle-grade novels, Colleen Gleason and Jonathan Stroud have vamped up the familiar world of Holmes and Watson  and Scooby-Doo and Nancy Drew  to paranormally exhilarating effect.

title: Views of the Rebellion
description: The slow crackup of Chinas last imperial dynasty during its century of humiliation was so fantastical it could have been made up by a comic book artist: an aspiring civil servant failed his entrance exam, fell into a delirium, dreamed he was the younger brother of Jesus Christ sent to deliver China from the Qing dynasty and ignited the Taiping Rebellion in 1850. Twenty million people died in the ensuing chaos. In the late 1890s, peasants from the north, affronted by Western influence in the empire, formed a secret society to practice the martial and spiritual disciplines of Chinese folk religion, which some believed made them invulnerable to European bullets and cannon fire. The belief did not survive the test of experience, but did earn the Boxer Rebellion an enduring place in popular memory.

title: Selling a Hoarders Home: The Trouble With Stuff
description: The one-bedroom condo on Park Avenue was described by the broker, Jeffrey Tanenbaum of Halstead Property, as a hoarders paradise, with seven cats, one dog and 12 armoires packed to the brim.

title: Catsaway
description: Even for two cats lucky enough to be born in the fishing port of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, in its 19th-century heyday, the usual rules of sibling rivalry apply. Dont be a chicken, be a cat! Be adventurous! Cecil, hearty and omnivorous, taunts his brother Anton, who would rather doze off to sea chanteys than chase rodents. But when Anton is pressed into service as a mouser on the bark Mary Anne, hes forced to exert himself as never before. Cecil, hoping to catch up with his brother, stows away aboard another ship and finds he is not always as popular at sea as he was at home.

title: The Killer Went Postal
description: Jayne Anne Phillips is not sentimental. From her debut story collection, Black Tickets, right through to the extraordinary novel Lark and Termite, her fiction teems with missed chances and tough luck, and her characters  even the children  are resilient hard cases. So about 50 pages into Quiet Dell, Phillipss latest novel, any reader familiar with her work might wonder if theres some trick afoot, maybe even a case of identity theft.

title: Pride, Prejudice and Drudgery
description: Beloved books like Pride and Prejudice or Gone With the Wind, or books left unfinished like The Mystery of Edwin Drood, have always prompted efforts to imagine a continuing life for their characters. We cling to them in hopes that some of the qualities of Austen or Mitchell or Dickens can be recaptured, restoring our sense of delight, maintaining the mysterious bond that returns us to Mrs. Bennet declaring that Netherfield Park is let at last or Scarlett OHara deciding to wait until tomorrow to think about her problems. Alas, with few exceptions, these efforts rarely satisfy.

title: Today in Small Business: An Entrepreneur for Halloween
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Talk of the Townies
description: In his 2004 introduction to Barry Hannahs story collection Airships, Richard Ford noted that writers like Donald Barthelme and Gertrude Stein banged themselves and their sentences against conventional and intransigent American prose syntax, grammar and diction, with often unsustained results  failing most often to express the matter at hand. The distinguishing mark of literary greatness, Ford suggested, remains the combination of the two: a fresh sentence-level flair and a rigorous focus on the story at hand. Yet he mentioned only a handful of writers who have managed it: William Faulkner, Alice Munro, Raymond Carver and of course Hannah himself.

title: Foreign Indiscretions
description: I cant believe she did a cartwheel, Lily Hayess mother laments almost halfway through Jennifer DuBoiss psychologically astute second novel, which takes not only its title but its controlling metaphor from this gymnastic feat. The cartwheel in question  performed during an interrogation in a Buenos Aires police station  is so amazingly tone-deaf it ends up casting Lily as the killer of her beautiful American roommate, Katy Kellers, stabbed to death while Lily was navel-gazing in the night without a solid alibi.

title: No Faith in Progress
description: The name Karl Kraus means little to German speakers anymore, and less to most Americans. So why has a celebrated contemporary American novelist brought out an annotated translation of two literary essays by this Viennese satirist who was born when Ulysses Grant was in the White House and died before Franklin Roosevelt completed his first presidential term? The full answer comes only toward the end of Jonathan Franzens engrossing, highly original volume. But that slow burn is part of his purpose. As a declared enemy of the easy response in an instant-access culture, Franzen finds in the unduly neglected Kraus a model of how to provoke readers while at the same time getting them to do some work.

title: Killing Giants
description: To judge by David and Goliath, Malcolm Gladwells favorite word is we. In fact, its been his favorite word since his first book, The Tipping Point, launched his enormously successful career writing about how the world doesnt necessarily work the way we think it does.

title: Earth Control
description: If we wanted to bring about the extinction of the human race as quickly as possible, how might we proceed? We could begin by destroying the planets atmosphere, making it incapable of supporting human life. We could invent bombs capable of obliterating the entire planet, and place them in the hands of those desperate enough to detonate them. We could bioengineer our main food sources  rice, wheat and corn  in such a way that a single disease could bring about catastrophic famine. But the most effective measure, counterintuitive as it may be, would be to increase our numbers. Population is what economists call a multiplier. The more people, the greater the likelihood of ecological collapse, nuclear war, plague.

title: Spies Like Us
description: In the aftermath of 9/11, the New York Police Department began regarding Islamic houses of worship  and everyone who prayed there  as possible criminal organizations, Matt Apuzzo and Adam Goldman tell us in Enemies Within. For that reason, those houses of worship get special attention from officers in the departments intelligence unit.

title: Special Forces
description: Particular military strategies become identified with particular wars, often giving rise to confusion about whether the wars outcome is due to the strategy or to something else.
