Debates persist, for example, about how much credit David Petraeuss counterinsurgency strategy should get for the temporary de-escalation of violence in Iraq several years ago. Now the United States is out of Iraq, and the war in Afghanistan has come to be seen as the embodiment of counterinsurgency.

title: The Gun Report: October 11, 2013
description: A man charged with killing a bystander in Columbia, S.C., has been granted immunity from prosecution after citing the states Stand Your Ground Act. In the early morning hours of April 17, 2010, an S.U.V. filled with teenage boys had been threatening Shannon Scotts 15-year-old daughter, driving by their home and firing a gun. Shortly after, Darrel Niles, 17, a high school basketball player, drove by, and mistakenly believing Niles was involved with the earlier menacing, Scott, 33, shot him in the head with a .380 bullet, killing him instantly.

title: New Chapter, Old Story
description: In The Devil That Never Dies, Daniel Jonah Goldhagen reports that there has been a worldwide rise in lethal anti-Semitism. If he had to pick a role model for the new generation of Jew-haters, he might settle on an elderly Sunni cleric named Yusuf al-Qaradawi.

title: Bookshelf: Meow
description: New picture books about cats, including David Wiesners Mr. Wuffles!, in which a house cats silly name belies his predatory nature.

title: Bookshelf: Meow
description: BITS AND PIECES  Written and illustrated by Judy Schachner.  32 pp. Dial. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

title: Bookshelf: Trunk Show
description: New picture books about elephants, including Michael Slacks Elecopter.

title: The Fox Says, I Can Make You Famous
description: Studio 6A, the Rockefeller Plaza home of NBCs Late Night With Jimmy Fallon, was filled with artificial smoke and laser lights when Bard and Vegard Ylvisaker arrived. These Norwegian brothers, who had spent the previous days traveling from Oslo to London to New York, did not seem to be particularly fazed as they surveyed their surroundings, which included a squad of dancers in fox masks and makeup, two long rows of full-length mirrors and a man dressed in a head-to-toe horse costume.

title: Bookshelf: Trunk Show
description: ELECOPTER  Written and illustrated by Michael Slack.  32 pp. Christy Ottaviano Books/Henry Holt & Company. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

title: Mass Evacuations as Cyclone Phailin Nears Indias East Coast
description: Officials in Orissa and the northern part of the adjoining Andhra Pradesh state, scrambled Friday to evacuate thousands of people from the coastline as a major cyclone headed for landfall from the Bay of Bengal.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jonathan Franzens Kraus Project
description: This week, Jonathan Franzen discusses his Kraus Project; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alan Weisman talks about Countdown; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review
description: This week, Jonathan Franzen and Alan Weisman.

title: Ylvis and the New Clout of Novelty Pop
description: Dave Itzkoff and Ben Ratliff discuss the YouTube explosion of The Fox.

title: Concerto for Piano and YouTube
description: Visitors browsing through the YouTube channel of the pianist Valentina Lisitsa can watch her in hundreds of videos. There are live webcams of her practicing at her home in North Carolina, long blonde hair tossing and brow furrowed in concentration as she reads through new works. There she is in a red gown playing Schumanns Traumerei at a concert in Seoul, and recording Rachmaninoffs Concerto No. 3 at the Abbey Road Studios in London.

title: Its No Longer the Economy, Stupid
description: Its no longer the economy, stupid  its the government.

title: Popcast: Ylvis and the New Clout of Novelty Pop
description: This week: the chart semiotics of a novelty hit.

title: A Bridge Between Western Science and Eastern Faith
description: ATLANTA  Quantum theory tells us that the world is a product of an infinite number of random events. Buddhism teaches us that nothing happens without a cause, trapping the universe in an unending karmic cycle.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jonathan Franzens Kraus Project
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Edmund Fawcett reviews Jonathan Franzens Kraus Project, in which Mr. Franzen translates and annotates the work of Karl Kraus, the Viennese satirist of technology and modernity. Mr. Fawcett writes:

title: Video Reviews of Captain Phillips, CBGB and Romeo & Juliet
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Captain Phillips, CBGB and Romeo & Juliet. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Parents Offer Best Advice to Steer Clear of Teenage Drinking
description: This past weeks topic for New Parent/Old Parent was teenage drinking and how to deal with it as a parent (and there were comments). The first thing that struck me was that in all my time moderating reader comments, I cant remember so many as lengthy and nuanced  an indication, I think, on how complex and difficult the issue is and how much it can vary from child to child and from family to family. I was also touched by how many of the responses conveyed a sense of parental humility. I have worked hard to be a very good parent, but boy, did I fail on this front  a lot.

title: In a Bid for Mens Wearhouse, a Merger Battle With Modern Strategies
description: On Wednesday, the first volleys of a war started when Mens Wearhouse issued a news release rejecting a $2.3 billion takeover offer from Jos. A. Bank Clothiers. For spectators, it is not only a battle to watch for its outcome but also for how hostile takeovers have evolved.

title: A Bash Brother Returns to St. Louis, Wearing Dodger Blue
description: ST. LOUIS  During a team workout Thursday afternoon at Busch Stadium, Mark McGwire, the Los Angeles Dodgers hitting coach, stood near the batting cage surrounded by reporters eager to gauge his feelings about his return here to face the Cardinals in the National League Championship Series, which begins Friday night.

title: Spain to Proceed With Indictment of Chinas Ex-President
description: MADRID  Spains national court has approved the indictment of Hu Jintao, the former Chinese president, as part of an investigation into whether the Chinese government tortured and repressed the people of Tibet as part of an attempted genocide.

title: No Comment Necessary: Limbaugh Reads the Polls
description: Via The Atlantic

title: Detained Americans Mother Visits Him in North Korea
description: The mother of Kenneth Bae, an American Christian missionary serving a 15-year term of hard labor in North Koreas penal system, visited him for 90 minutes in a very emotional reunion on Friday at a Pyongyang hospital where he has been convalescing since the summer because of poor health and severe weight loss, Mr. Baes sister reported on Friday.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Montreal; Key West, Fla.; California
description: Beat Nation: Art, Hip Hop andAboriginal Culture, MontrealAn exhibition of contemporary aboriginal art, above, will be at the Muse dArt Contemporain de Montral fromOct. 17 to Jan. 5.Beat Nationwill feature painting, sculpture, installation, performance and video works that reflect the juxtaposition of urban culture with traditional identity, according to the shows organizers. Performances, tours, gallery talks and workshops planned in collaboration with aboriginal artists are scheduled.

title: Tributes for Seamus Heaney Are Planned
description: The poet Seamus Heaney, who died in August at age 74, will be honored next month at several free public events in New York.

title: When Having a Nanny Cam Isnt Enough
description: HAVING recently hired a new nanny, I received a refresher course in running a miniature human resources department. Its a costly process filled with terror to varying degrees  from being sure youve picked the right person to complying with labor, wage and tax laws that are easy to run afoul of.

title: Are Competing Bankruptcy Plans a Good Thing?
description: As LightSquareds creditors get prepared to consider which of four reorganization plans to vote for, it bears noting how much Chapter 11 has been changed by the 2005 amendments to the bankruptcy code.

title: Many Tune In to a Sad Night on Glee
description: Though it was hardly what the show or the Fox network would ever have wanted, Thursdays episode of Glee  which dealt with the death of the character played by Cory Monteith, the star who died of a drug overdose in July  lifted that series to its best ratings in a year.

title: A Familiar Look From 2(x)ist
description: In an article in the Thursday Styles section several months ago, headlined Less Ab. More Flab, my colleague Eric Wilson wrote of how increasing numbers of underwear companies were toning down their advertising  flashing less flesh and featuring more realistically shaped models than the god-like specimens who flaunt their startling good looks from any number of billboards and bus shelters around the city.

title: Movie Review: 'Romeo & Juliet'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Romeo & Juliet.

title: Movie Review: 'CBGB'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "CBGB."

title: Bed and a Chair Finds Its Leading Men
description: A jazz-inflected celebration of the songs of Stephen Sondheim has signed its leading men: the Tony nominees Norm Lewis (The Gershwins Porgy and Bess) and Jeremy Jordan (Newsies).

title: Image of the Day: October 11
A Theologians Influence, and Stained Past, Live On
description: Can a bad person be a good theologian?

title: Up Is Down: Republicans Defend D.C.
description: In their strategy of cherry picking popular programs to exclude from the federal government shutdown, House Republicans were particularly gleeful in approving a proposal to make an exception so that the District of Columbia city government can fund its budget.

title: Strong Demand for Royal Mail Stock May Not Translate to Lloyds Shares
description: The Lloyds Banking Group shouldnt get too cocky after the sharp rise in Royal Mails shares. Lloyds, a state-backed British bank, may be tempted to focus its next share sale entirely on retail customers after strong demand sent the postal services shares up 36 percent in their first few hours of trading. But the differences between a secondary offering from Lloyds and Royal Mails primary one warrant a different approach.

title: Movie Review: 'Captain Phillips'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Captain Phillips."

title: Follow the Tracks of the Crime Drama
description: It says a lot about the current cultural pre-eminence of television that the Museum of Modern Art is promoting Mikko Niskanens Eight Deadly Shots  a five-and-a-quarter-hour film made as a mini-series for Finnish TV in 1972  as a forerunner of The Wire, Breaking Bad and The Killing.

title: At Citi, Pandit Is Gone but Is Still Serving the Banks Shareholders
description: Michael L. Corbat is approaching his first anniversary as chief executive of Citigroup. The banks chairman, Michael E. ONeill, installed him after organizing a putsch to oust Vikram Pandit as C.E.O. The new boss has accelerated some cost cuts and clarified strategy around the edges, but the broad direction is still Mr. Pandits. Either way, it is serving shareholders well.

title: Making Tracks With a New Old Sound
description: There are very few pop musicians under the age of Dolly Parton who wouldnt bristle at being called old-fashioned, and yet the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter Diane Birch understands that her biography and music could lead someone to believe that she may possess such qualities.

title: United Has a High-Minded New Magazine
description: United Airlines latest attempt to polish its first-class service doesnt involve flat-bed seats or on-demand television. Instead, United is appealing to the intellectual senses of its elite travelers, with Rhapsody, a monthly literary and luxury lifestyle magazine edited by Ink Publishing, the in-flight media company.

title: A Sun Rises on a Plunge Into Abstraction
description: BOCHUM, Germany  The audience members had gathered in the darkness at 4.30 a.m. in the Cour dHonneur of the Palais des Papes in Avignon, France. When Anne Teresa De Keersmaekers Cesena began, with a screaming man running in a circle, they couldnt at first see anything. Then, as dancers and singers arrived onstage, and the unearthly sounds of the polyphonic medieval music known as ars subtilior filled the air, the sun rose, slowly revealing the performers. By the end, everyone was bathed in the morning light.

title: Darkness Falls; Still, She Sings
description: When it comes to musicals, Selma, the heroine of Dancer in the Dark (2000), prefers Hollywood to Vladivostok  or so were told when shes on trial for murder. This may not be true of Lars von Trier, whose movie seems to reference, in its song-and-dance sequences, Soviet films as much as American ones.

title: High School Classmate Reflects on Yellen
description: Charles Saydeh reflects on his junior high and high school classmate, Janet Yellen.

title: What Has All This Done to Us?
description: This week brings an ambitious show that should be required viewing for anyone who is curious  and that should be everyone  about the ways digitalization affects, facilitates, improves, inspires and sometimes ruins various forms of visual culture. Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital which opens on Tuesday at the Museum of Arts and Design, will present the efforts of some 80 architects, designers and artists from 20 countries, with the designers in the majority. Presenting digital-dependent work from the last decade, displays will run the gamut from life-changing (if not saving) to frivolous, among them dinnerware, sports shoes, furnishings, clothing, buildings and various forms of three-dimensional art. Those represented include Bathsheba Grossman, Greg Lynn, Marc Newson, Magnus Larsson, Roxy Paine, Frank Stella, Zaha Hadid and J. Mayer H. Architects (whose seemingly astounding Metropol Parasol, completed in 2011, spans a plaza in the old quarter of Seville, Spain). The show may harbor a bit much in the way of jewelry and bad art, and most of the buildings will be represented by photographs, but new and useful information should compensate. (Through July 6, 2 Columbus Circle, 212-299-7777, madmuseum.org)

title: Some Stones Shine Brighter
description: A jewelry store is generally a staid, rather somber place, reminiscent of a museum or library. But a jewels journey to reach a glass case can have a considerably livelier start.

title: Prizewinner, and So Much More
description: I dont really call myself a composer, Caroline Shaw told Zachary Woolfe in an interview in The New York Times in April. Earlier in the week, a Pulitzer Prize jury had begged to differ, making Ms. Shaw, at the age of 30, the youngest-ever winner of the music prize, for her Partita for Eight Voices. Ms. Shaw, for her part, prefers to think of herself as a musician: She sings as a soprano in Roomful of Teeth, the dynamic a cappella ensemble for which she wrote Partita, and plays violin in the American Contemporary Music Ensemble, also known as ACME.

title: Theres Beauty in All This Mess
description: David Dorfman Dance is plunging with abandon into themes of time, memory and fear in Come, and Back Again, which comments on matters like the eccentricities of family life, the resilience of the human spirit and what Mr. Dorfman calls the beauty of our personal messes. For the elaborate production, the Brooklyn sculptor Jonah Emerson Bell has designed a large wall, built from refuse, personal mementos and found objects, on which portraits by Caledonia Curry will be projected.

title: Activity Does Not Always Equal Productivity
description: In all likelihood, you get more done today than you ever have before. Thats mostly because you can do so much more, so much faster, wherever you are, through e-mail, texting, instant-messaging, Twitter and posting.

title: Combine Sounds; Hear What Happens
description: Ben Vida played acoustic guitar and trumpet in the Chicago minimalist quartet Town & Country, which for nearly 10 years used repetition, drones and delicate, drumless sonorities to get to intense places carefully, like post-prog chamber music, or a Slint-Morton Feldman collaboration.

title: A Headstand Without a Helmet? The Postal Service Halts Just Move Stamps
description: Lets Move!

title: Peas in a Vintage-Soul-Style Pod
description: Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig are not sisters, or even related in any way, but they have been merrily twinned as the frontwomen of the indie band Lucius for nearly a decade. Both 28, they met as students at the Berklee College of Music and then, post-graduation, moved to Brooklyn in 2007 to forge a musical career. We knew we wanted to work together and sing together and write together, Ms. Laessig said. But we were just kind of experimental, and thats why it took so long to come into what we are now. After assembling a band through friends and neighbors, their first album as a five-piece, Wildewoman, is due Tuesday from Mom + Pop Music. But their act  with Andrew Burri, Peter Lalish and Ms. Wolfes husband, Dan Molad, on drums, guitars and bass  has already earned fans for its girl-group harmonies and resourceful rhythms; for their Tiny Desk concert on NPR, they turned an empty cashew container into a drum. Theyve performed with Wilco, and worked as jingle writers and in commercials. (Those were their voices in the Mercedes ad with Willem Dafoe broadcast during the Breaking Bad finale.)

title: T FALL DESIGN
description: After years of struggle and strife, the citizens of Serbias war-torn capital are recasting their home into a burgeoning hub for design, culture and creativity.

title: On the Verge | Belgrade, Europes Latest Urban Success Story
description: After years of struggle and strife, the citizens of Serbias war-torn capital are recasting their home into a burgeoning hub for design, culture and creativity.

title: On View: No It Is by William Kentridge
description: Kentridge presents a triptych of films: Workshop Receipts, The Anatomy of Melancholy, and Practical Enquiries, all of which feature animated images on top of flipbooks.

title: Big Ticket | River Views for $9.495 Million
description: A glass aerie with 10-foot ceilings, ebony floors and sweeping views of the Hudson River, the Statue of Liberty and the George Washington Bridge from its 14th-story perch on the southwest corner of the Superior Ink building sold for $9.495 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Hulu Is Said to Pick a New Chief Executive
description: The owners of the online streaming service Hulu are preparing to appoint Mike Hopkins, a veteran of Fox Networks, to be the next chief executive.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Video Report Bolsters Claims of Summary Executions of Civilians by Syrian Rebels
description: As my colleague Anne Barnard reports, an investigation from Human Rights Watch released on Friday bolsters claims that Syrian rebels conducted a massacre of civilians in August in Latakia, the heartland of President Bashar al-Assads ruling Alawite sect.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Schools Fear Shutdowns Threat to Lunch Programs
description: WASHINGTON  The National School Lunch and Breakfast Program could soon be a casualty of the partial government shutdown, leaving millions of children without an important source of nutrition, a group representing school nutrition workers warned Congress on Friday.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Completely Ready or Not, Steve Mills Takes Charge of Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  In September 2009, only months after leaving a high-ranking post at Madison Square Garden, Steve Mills returned to Princeton, his alma mater, to teach a freshman seminar with Harold A. Feiveson, a professor who specializes in nuclear weapons and energy policy.

title: Pakistani Girl, a Global Heroine After an Attack, Has Critics at Home
description: SWAT VALLEY, Pakistan  The question for the class of 10th graders at an all-girls school here in this picturesque mountain valley was a simple one: How many of them, a district official wanted to know, had heard of Malala Yousafzai?

title: Portuguese, Right Down to the Olives
description: Fado is a treat: a charming restaurant with the best Portuguese food Ive ever had (including during recent meals in Portugal). On my first visit to this three-year-old Huntington restaurant, I spent the night kicking myself for not having come sooner.

title: Bill Weir Leaving ABC for CNN
description: The former Nightline anchor Bill Weir will join CNN next month in an as-yet- undefined anchor role as well being as the networks chief innovation correspondent, covering developments in the technology world.

title: United Nations Human Rights Chief Condemns Mass Executions in Iraq
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, on Friday condemned Iraqs execution of 42 prisoners over two days this week, denouncing such mass executions as obscene and inhuman and warning that they undermine efforts to reduce violence and achieve a more stable society.

title: Homage to the Vegetable and the Local
description: Dennis Foy, the onetime lord of Tarragon Tree, the 70s and 80s destination restaurant in Chatham that helped give birth to the farm-to-fine-dining aesthetic, celebrates the vegetable and the local at his year-old restaurant in Lambertville.

title: Jets Willie Colon Attends to His South Bronx Roots
description: The quarter-mile strip of asphalt and concrete connects the pillars of Willie Colons life in the South Bronx. It does not have an official name. It is an access road that branches off Concourse Village East, a road that is now paved, not covered in dirt and dust and gravel as it was more than a decade ago, when it bridged the chaos of Colons neighborhood and the structure of his school.

title: Honeymoon in Vegas
description: Tony Danza stars in this new musical at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

title: G.O.P. Helps Americans Like Government
description: Theres a lot of terrible news for Republicans inside the new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, but one of the worst bulletins is this: Americans are becoming more appreciative of government.

title: Cruz Is Heckled During Speech
description: While speaking at the Voter Values Summit, an annual gathering of social conservatives, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was repeatedly interrupted by protesters.

title: Doughboy in Love and Battle
description: At this moment, theres probably no better way of dispelling the tiresome myth that silent films were technically and dramatically crude than by directing skeptics to the radiant new Blu-ray of The Big Parade from Warner Home Video. Directed by King Vidor, and originally released by MGM in November 1925, this tale of three buddies caught up in what then was called the Great War was one of the most financially successful films of the silent era. It played for almost two years at the Astor Theater in New York and enjoyed similar success worldwide.

title: From Ring-a-Ding Swagger to Swooning Romanticism
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  Many a tut has been tutted in recent years over the contamination of Broadway by the spirit of Las Vegas, the world capital of the flashy, boozy floor show. So I am happy to report that you can score one for Team Broadway. The delightfully unexpected Honeymoon in Vegas, which opened this week at the Paper Mill Playhouse here, has wrestled the neon mirage of its title into the solid, satisfying shape of a classic Broadway musical.

title: Days After Disaster, Another Migrant Ship Sinks Near Italian Island
description: ROME  A ship filled with migrants apparently trying to reach Europe capsized in the Mediterranean Sea on Friday about 100 nautical miles southwest of the island nation of Malta, sending rescue boats and helicopters racing to the scene, officials said. At least 206 passengers were rescued, and 27 bodies were recovered.

title: Assured That Its Just Meant to Be
description: When she met a schoolmate, Alejandro de Castro, in 1992, Carly Brien instantly thought, wow, was he handsome  well, as third graders go.

title: Glaad Sees Improvement in Depictions of Gays and Lesbians on TV
description: No television network is excellent when it comes to representations of gays and lesbians, but most of the nations biggest networks earn a grade of good, Glaad, formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, said in a study released on Friday.

title: The Culture Paradox of 21st-Century New York
description: Last week The Guardian  published an essay by the singer-songwriter David Byrne, which received a fair amount of attention online, arriving under the headline If the 1% Stifles New Yorks Creative Talent, Im Out of Here.

title: Artists on Artists | William Kentridge on the Subtle Drama of the Indian Minimalist Nasreen Mohamedi
description: The South African artist William Kentridge is best known for creating low-tech animated films, often based on charcoal drawings, that explore the painful effects of apartheid. He describes his current show (Second-hand Reading, at Marian Goodman Gallery through Oct. 26) as being about the excess of making. Filled with drawings of trees, people and text made on the pages of old encyclopedias, the show also includes several animated videos and sculptural sound pieces, including one built from drums and percussion instruments and another that transforms old sewing machines into a hand-cranked phonograph.

title: A Ransacked Endowment at New York City Opera
description: A fundamental premise of successful investing is sell high, buy low. So what explains the New York City Opera boards decision to do the opposite?

title: Michael Shvo Is Back, and as Brash as Ever
description: At the height of the real estate boom, the broker Michael Shvo brashly coined the phrase Lets Shvo to define his style of marketing. That meant 24-hour sales offices, parties featuring red carpets and leggy models, and aggressive selling tactics that some considered questionable.

title: A Healthy Relationship All Around
description: There are many ways to measure the heart of Shelley Yeffet Wininger.

title: Weekend Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: An Unusual Coalition Presses for End to Shutdown
description: Shutdowns make strange bedfellows. Case in point: A letter released Friday from the Chamber of Commerce, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United Way urging Congress to reach a budget deal.

title: Activision Closes Deal for Most of Vivendis Stake
description: Thanks to a courts timely intervention, the video game maker Activision Blizzard closed its deal on Friday to buy a majority of Vivendis stake in the company for $8.2 billion.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 11
description: Pictures include the filming of a new sitcom, Brooklyn Taxi; a march over the Brooklyn Bridge; and a real estate developer at the top of his newest tower.

title: Netanyahu Takes a Lonely Stance Denouncing Iran
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the son of a historian, often complains to his inner circle that people have a historical memory that goes back to breakfast.

title: A Tale of Two Sport Sedans
description: The IS 250 and IS 350, redesigned for 2014, take the Lexus performance sedan back toward its sporty origins  with different degrees of success.

title: A Novel Way to Sidle Up to the High Line
description: There are apartment buildings near, along and even touching the High Line. And now there will be one, underneath, at least partly.

title: Making Portraits Together
description: Harvey Stein, whose latest book is Harlem Street Portraits, has been photographing Harlem for more than two decades and has witnessed its evolutions.

title: Following Kerouac Through Mexico
description: The writer visited Mexico in the 1950s and 60s to experience greater freedom.

title: Concern Grows for Jailed Pussy Riot Member
description: Updated, 6:43 p.m. | Lawyers have been granted access to Ms. Tolokonnikova, a spokesperson for the Voice Project said on Friday afternoon. The family are still being restricted, but Nadya is O.K., Hunter Heaney said by e-mail, expressing relief that Ms. Tolokonnikova had been able to visit with her lawyers in Mordovia.

title: Finance Class on the Web, for Students of All Ages
description: In an ideal world, a master class available to everyone would reveal all the secrets to retirement planning, telling you how much to save, where to invest and what to do when the stock market crashes.

title: Kerouacs Mexico
description: I found Jack Kerouacs Mexico on a strip of beach that separated the old hotels from the heaving Pacific, at a bar near where he sat on the sea wall and watched the sunset 61 years ago.

title: Weekend Reading: Wall Streets View of the Fiscal Crisis
description: As the budget shutdown in Washington continued, investors on Wall Street faced criticism that calm markets were encouraging House Republicans and making a default more likely. Heres a look at what some of the experts are saying about the fiscal crisis.

title: Coins Celebrating Pope Misspell Name Above All Names
description: ROME  It seems absurd that any official Vatican memorabilia would misspell the name Jesus. Or that the Italian institute that mints coins, passports and postage stamps would make such an error. And yet the fact remains: a new series of special commemorative coins honoring Pope Francis got it wrong.

title: Review: 2014 Lexus IS 350 AWD
description: Lexus is known for coddling, not sport sedans. The 2014 IS 350 is designed to change that. Can it lure buyers away from Audi, BMW, Cadillac and Mercedes? Tom Voelk checks out an AWD model to find out.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Bulgaria, the West Bank and Pakistan.

title: Green Goddess Roasted Chicken
description: Green Goddess dressing is good for salad but can be even better as a marinade for the mildness of roast chicken.

title: Whos on Line First?
description: October baseball is known to be extremely competitive, especially for fans who have vied for good World Series tickets through the years.

title: Back to the Bronx With Willie Colon
description: Willie Colon, the Jets right guard who was raised in the South Bronx and recently revisited his old neighborhood, is intensely proud of where he grew up.

title: Chicken Offered to the Green Goddess
description: My mother learned how to marinate chicken in spiced yogurt from Madhur Jaffreys famous tandoori recipe.

title: 2010 Yellen Senate Confirmation Hearing
description: Excerpts from the 2010 Senate confirmation hearing of Janet L. Yellen, after her nomination as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Whos on Line First?
description: Major League Baseballs semifinals, otherwise known as the League Championship Series, begin Friday night in St. Louis, with the Cardinals hosting the Los Angeles Dodgers. The other side of the bracket, the Boston Red Sox versus the Detroit Tigers, will begin Saturday. Do you have tickets to any of the games?

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Fending Off Foreclosure With Rock n Roll
description: A 40-year-old man sings I slept with your mother to a horrified buddy from high school. A rabbi break-dances in an exhilarating hip-hop version of Hava Nagila. A Welcome to Sayreville, N.J. sign gets entrance applause when it is rolled onstage.

title: Living in the Wild Wild Northeast
description: From the Princeton Town Topics, which used to be all about (a) parking (b) deer:

title: A Two-Level Approach to Protecting Riders Head in Impacts
description: There are mishaps that no rider, regardless of how skilled, could avoid. But if that rider knew exactly what kind of accident it was going to be, an engineer could build the ideal helmet to withstand it.

title: Dodge Fires Off a Retro Rocket
description: TESTED Dodge Charger SRT8 Super Bee.

title: An Early American, Ready to Try Again
description: BRIAN HEAD, UTAH  On Sept. 17, 2003, an all-new model from the Indian Motorcycle Company of America was delivered to me for a review.

title: Kaleidoscope of Chords
description: During an onstage interview halfway through a concert on Thursday night at the Miller Theater at Columbia University, the conductor Brad Lubman asked the composer Georg Friedrich Haas how he had become interested in writing microtonal music. It was a simple question that might have occurred to anyone in the hall. Mr. Haass works, some of which have become staples of the contemporary repertory, make striking use of sounds that lurk between the semitone steps of the conventional Western scale.

title: A Redesign That Hits or Misses
description: Lexus knows its audience.

title: 20 Years Later at the New York Film Festival, Still Dazed and Confused
description: It may make some members of Generation X feel that much less youthful to know that Richard Linklaters high school comedy Dazed and Confused is celebrating its 20th anniversary. But the film, set in 1976, always felt a little like a movie from another era. On Thursday night, Mr. Linklater shared his own 35-millimeter print with a New York Film Festival audience that ranged from longtime fans to those new to the film.

title: Friday Night Music: Shovels and Rope
description: People have been recommending this couple, and they are indeed a joy:

title: Every Time a Postman Rings ...
description: There was Touched by an Angel, and now comes Signed, Sealed, Delivered, so named, presumably, because someone realized that Touched by a Postal Carrier might send the wrong message.

title: They Like the Cars, but Love the Engines
description: REDWOOD CITY, CALIF.  No doubt there are devoted followers of most any automotive make or model, no matter how obscure. But now that like-minded enthusiasts can connect so easily online, the clubs dedicated to those long-gone marques find it easier to assemble their congregations of the faithful.

title: Evolution and Bad Boyfriends
description: THROUGHOUT history and in societies all over the world, parents have tried to influence the love lives of their children  with mixed success. Parents and children frequently dont see eye to eye on what makes a suitable partner, as studies across cultures have confirmed.

title: Six Pack
description: The unlikely object of affection at the center of one club of enthusiasts is an obsolete 6-cylinder engine that Chrysler stopped using in the 1980s.

title: Ethiopia: Land of Dust, Eucalyptus and Hope
description: I had already spent the last few hours watching Haftay hopscotch up the gravel path toward whatever it was that lay on the other side of the ridge. My guide, Mulualem Gebremedhin, and I had spent most of the day  the first of three we would spend hiking together in eastern Tigray on Ethiopias northern border  lagging several steps behind Haftay, a local villager accompanying us on the first leg of our trip.

title: Moving Into a New MacBook Air
description: Q. I have a MacBook Air running Snow Leopard (Mac OS X 10.6.8) and I am considering buying a new MacBook Air with the Mountain Lion (OS X 10.8) operating system. I have accumulated a large number of files over the years in various applications (notably Microsoft Word and Excel, Pages, Keynote and Keychain) on my current machine. Will I be able to readily move these to the new Mac?

title: A TV Show That Isnt Made of Whole Cloth
description: ON TELEVISION, the fashion world rarely shows itself. Instead, with most programs and Webcasts, you get a checklist of compulsory scenes: the nervous, befuddled designer; the delayed fabric order; the world-weary youre toast looks from the pros; a meltdown or two; and, inevitably, a blast of Pump Up the Jam, the 1989 hit.

title: In Trinidad and Tobago, Wheelchairs for the Water
description: Beachgoers with mobility issues visiting Trinidad and Tobago can now use amphibious wheelchairs at a flagship beach that allow people with disabilities to safely enter the water.

title: How to Know if Youre a Banana Republic
description: An excerpt from an e-mail to clients from Jonathan Lewis, chief investment officer at Samson Capital Advisors:

title: An Essentially American Narrative
description: Amid comic book epics, bromantic comedies and sequels of sequels, films about Americas tortured racial history have recently emerged as a surprisingly lucrative Hollywood staple. In the last two years, The Help, Lincoln,""Django Unchained,""42 and Lee Daniels The Butler have performed well at the box office, gathering awards in some cases and drawing varying degrees of critical acclaim.

title: A Slower Pace for Walkers and Survivors
description: In the short life of AMCs zombie-apocalypse series, The Walking Dead, the shows band of survivors has started each season in extremis, on the run and looking for a safe haven. In Season 2 they found it on a farm; in Season 3, driven off the farm, they locked themselves inside a prison.

title: Seven Days of Style | Miley Cyrus Explains Her Fashion Sense, Nicky Hilton Writes a Book, and Kate Moss Makes Another Comeback
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREOct. 5  11

title: Los Angeles, the City of Dancing Angels
description: Los Angeles is a city that values its beauty sleep. Cocktails clink as early as 5 p.m. Dinner parties start at 7 p.m. And unlike in Miami or New York, bars and clubs peak around 1 a.m., in part because state law bans alcohol from being sold after 2.

title: Italy vs. Monaco at the Bermuda Bowl in Bali
description: The Bermuda Bowl was the premier event at the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, last month.

title: A Former Fed Colleague Reminisces
description: Kevin Hassett, now an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, remembers Janet Yellens outreach to junior economists at the Federal Reserve.

title: The Pick of the Apple Orchard
description: Once, I slept in a blooming apple orchard under a full April moon, surrounded by fragrant blossoms as big as saucers.

title: From Flying Bows to Intent Faces, Verdi Via a Laptop
description: At one moment during the Chicago Symphony Orchestras performance of the Verdi Requiem on Thursday evening, conducted by Riccardo Muti and streamed live from Orchestra Hall in Chicago, viewers could see the rosin glistening on a bow during close-up shots of the violinists.

title: Investigation Moves Slowly in Kenyan Mall Siege
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The crater of rubble where the mall collapsed is still so hot that investigators are having a hard time examining it for clues. None of the bodies of the militants killed in the deadly siege have been clearly identified. Even the four attackers captured on security cameras are being called pink shirt, white shirt, black shirt, blue shirt, because investigators are not sure of their real names, said an official who had been briefed on the investigation.

title: Tim Gunn, a Lucky Guy
description: Mr. Gunn, a recent Emmy Award recipient, has emerged as a breakout star of Project Runway.

title: Weak Bank Revenues Show the Tough Road Back for the Economy
description: Anyone looking for reasons the economy is not growing faster should contemplate the bank earnings that have started to roll in.

title: Tim Gunn: A Lifetime of Making It Work
description: At Lincoln Center on the second day of New York Fashion Week, Tim Gunn quietly encouraged with a quick hug, a kiss on the cheek or a last-minute word of praise the four contestants who were about to show their final collections to a gathering audience of nearly a thousand invited guests. In turn, the designers smiled back at him, grateful for their mentors presence on the day that would determine the Season 12 winner of Project Runway.

title: An Alliance in Media Petitions Justices
description: The nations biggest television broadcasters are collectively asking for the Supreme Courts support in their quest to stop Aereo, a small Internet start-up that threatens some of the underpinnings of the TV business.

title: A Vigorous Macbeth, Swept Up in the Darkness
description: Given all the blood, gore and spookery that Shakespeare crammed into his shortest tragedy, its easy to overproduce Macbeth. But the current rendition at Hartford Stage unleashes the plays terrifying energy by pointedly rejecting theatrical furbelows.

title: Overscheduled Children: How Big a Problem?
description: Now that the school year is under way, my wife and I are busy managing our childrens after-school schedules, mixing sports practices, music lessons, homework and play dates. It can be a complicated balancing act for our elementary-age daughters, as some days end up overstuffed, some logistically impossible, some wide open. Still, compared to when we were children, the opportunities they get to sample on a weekly basis is mind-blowing.

title: Psychic Found Guilty of Stealing $138,000 From Clients
description: A jury found a Manhattan psychic guilty on Friday of swindling two women out of $138,000 in a case that probed the fine distinction between providing an unusual service and running a confidence scheme.

title: 10 Signs Your Parent Is Overscheduled
description: I would like to say Im calling this the year of no.  My iPad screen saver is a big, glorious NO, emblazoned and encircled in the middle of the screen. No is supposed to be my default response to any additional activities for our family, for the children, for me: no to the camp open house, no to taking gymnastics even if you can car pool there lots of the time, no to the speaking engagement, the coffee, the committee. No, no and no.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebooks No. 2 and Instagrams Man of Vision
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: New Arrest in Inquiry on Art Looting
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office and federal authorities have expanded their investigation into antiquities smuggling by Subhash Kapoor, a longtime Upper East Side art dealer who is accused of selling looted items from India that have ended up in private collections and museums around the world.

title: Pinstripes, Onstage
description: The costume designer David C. Woolard created Yankee home game uniforms from different eras for Eric Simonsons new play Bronx Bombers.

title: Diplomacy, Free of Gravity
description: DanceMotion USA, a State Department program produced by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, sends American companies to perform abroad for cultural diplomacy but also arranges collaborations between American troupes and foreign ones.

title: With Money Tight, Museums Embrace Nudes
description: PARIS  Over the last few weeks, the hottest cultural ticket in this city has been a museum exhibition that confronts viewers with images of a nude man on a cold morgue slab and the rapper Eminem, staring down from the walls of the Muse dOrsay, naked and brandishing a firecracker in front of his crotch.

title: The Leaning Tower of Power: Chryslers Venerable Slant Six
description: In the Sunday Automobiles section, Dave Wallace writes about an event that he and his wife attended with her red Dodge Dart convertible. Heres the story behind one of Chryslers most famous power plants: the Slant Six.

title: An Extended Addams Family
description: Gomez, Pugsley, Wednesday and three other members of the Addams Family, represented by heads once worn by circus clowns, greet visitors to the Southampton Center, a new cultural space in the former home of the Parrish Art Museum. Looming in the distance, past freshly painted white walls hung with 66 original drawings by Charles Addams, is a huge banner with a likeness of the mischievous Uncle Fester, a prime member of the whimsically ghoulish family made famous in cartoons in The New Yorker, a recent Broadway musical and television series, movies and books.

title: Beets for Breakfast, or Dinner
description: Beets are a fall favorite on Well. Weve put them in smoothies, lasagna and spring rolls. Weve tried to convert beet skeptics and even let our readers eat beet cake.

title: At Ralphs Restaurant, an All-American in Paris
description: On the afternoon of Sept. 23, a few hours after the Giorgio Armani show had signaled the end of Milan Fashion Week, a planeload of very important editors experienced a terrifying moment aboard an Air France flight destined for Paris. According to an item in Page Six that appeared the next morning, the plane was forced to abort its landing feet from the ground, and one passenger described the event as a near-death experience.

title: Another Spring, and Another Storm to Weather
description: The riot that erupted at the 1913 premiere of Stravinskys Rite of Spring is legendary. One of the less-well-known details is the performance of the conductor, Pierre Monteux. In Stravinskys recollection, Monteux kept his back turned to the brawl and guided the orchestra through this groundbreaking and difficult score impervious and as nerveless as a crocodile.

title: Bookshelf | A Grand Tour of Brooklynized Design
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: New Rule Affects Home Businesses

title: Economists to Watch for the Nobel Prize
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science will be awarded early Monday morning New York time (1 p.m. Swedish time, at the earliest). Every year predictions are made, and the actual winners are not always among the betting pool favorites. (And besides, there are also fewer prominent betting pools available this year.)

title: Q & A: Medicare and the Insurance Exchanges
description: Shirley Mierzejewski was very upset when she found out her Medicare health insurance premiums will nearly double next year.

title: Sean MacPherson: A Hotelier Recalibrates the Mood
description: The Waverly Inn was a lie, but it was a good lie, Sean MacPherson, the restaurateur, hotelier and tastemaker, said recently. He was referring to what is probably his best-known local production, the durably successful and clubby West Village restaurant and celebrity petting zoo where Harvey Weinstein, Sting or Mariah Carey can be spotted tucking into a $55 plate of truffled macaroni and cheese.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Janet L. Yellen is nominated to lead the Federal Reserve, Alcatel-Lucent announces job cuts and shares of Britains main postal service start trading in London.

title: Erich Priebke, Nazi Who Carried Out Massacre of 335 Italians, Dies at 100
description: Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who was sentenced to life in prison for helping to organize the execution of 335 men and boys at the Ardeatine Caves in Italy in 1944, died on Friday under house arrest at his home in Rome. He was 100 and the oldest surviving convicted Nazi war criminal.

title: The High-End Matchmaking Service for Tycoons
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a characteristically foggy evening here, a group of predominantly single venture capitalists, tech executives, hedge-fund managers and philanthropists gathered for a cocktail party in a penultimate-floor suite at the St. Regis apartment complex.

title: Berlusconi Aiding War Victims? Italy Speculates on His Penance
description: ROME  Perhaps he will clean toilets, or sweep streets, or collect trash. There is no shortage of graffiti to be scrubbed off the palazzo walls of Rome. Or maybe Silvio Berlusconi, the powerful former prime minister, could pay his debt to Italian society by working in a soup kitchen.

title: A Designer Defends Futility as a Noble and Useless Pursuit
description: No one seems to know when or where Ludwig Mies van der Rohe uttered the now-clichd assertion that less is more. What we do know is that in 1981, another great design mind described it, if memory serves, as the silliest thing Ive ever heard.

title: New, Young Help for Poor in Infamous Bronx Courts
description: On a recent afternoon in the South Bronx, Cordice Smith, a 79-year-old Korean War veteran wearing a Yankees hat, was standing in the tiled lobby of his apartment building  something he no longer takes for granted. Earlier this year, he almost lost his home after receiving a letter from his landlords lawyer: an eviction notice.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 11
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the filming of a new sitcom, Brooklyn Taxi; a march over the Brooklyn Bridge; and a real estate developer at the top of his newest tower.

title: Bill Cunningham | Netted
description: Fashion Week in Paris is full of ideas, both on the runway and from the public attending the shows.

title: A Throwback to the 1960s, and to the Bible
description: Clearly, Tamar was going for the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Its All Been Done Before
description: Im not a concept, Joel, says Clementine in the final scene ofEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.

title: With More Glitz, a Club Is Reborn
description: Phil Ciganer is not given to hyperbole. So when he expresses strong feelings  as he did watching music fans stream into his club, the Towne Crier Cafe, on Oct. 4  he can be taken literally.

title: Copland, Beyond the Fanfare
description: Amid the awards crowding the walls of Aaron Coplands former home in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., hangs a neatly framed movie advertisement with a modest distinction of its own: The ad, from a 1961 issue of Variety, focuses its sales pitch on the composer, Copland, not the star or the director. The novel approach suggests the centrality of the score and its creator to the enterprise.

title: Judge to Decide Next Week in Casino Referendum Suit
description: ALBANY  The State Board of Elections urged a judge in Albany on Friday to dismiss a lawsuit challenging a statewide casino referendum, saying the case had been filed too late and too close to Election Day.

title: Schottenfreude
description: The Germans languages ability to express the inexpressible explains why so many words have been embraced into English.

title: Winslow Is Suspended for Four Games
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Kellen Winslow, the Jets leading receiver, will miss the next four games after being suspended for violating the N.F.L.s policy on performance-enhancing substances. Winslow is eligible to return to the active roster on Nov. 4, but because of a bye week for the Jets, he will next be available for their Nov. 17 game at Buffalo.

title: Declared Legally Dead, as He Sat Before the Judge
description: Donald E. Miller Jr. is legally dead, an Ohio judge explained to Donald E. Miller Jr. this week in court.

title: The Leading Men (and Woman) of Physics
Fond Recollections of Dictators, Colored Later by the Lessons of History
description: SEOUL, South Korea  MONICA MACAS calls herself the daughter of dictators. Two of them.

title: Nothing Certain as England Chases World Cup Dreams
description: England, the country that gives so many of the worlds top players employment and huge salaries in its Premier League, remains tenuously on the brink of the World Cup.

title: Dining at a Star in Queens
description: When Michelin, the French publisher of travel books, issued its 2014 New York City dining guide this month, it gave stars to 58 restaurants in Manhattan, six in Brooklyn  and one in the entire borough of Queens. That Queens restaurant was the Danny Brown Wine Bar & Kitchen, a cozy Continental on Metropolitan Avenue and 71st Drive in Forest Hills. Owned by Mr. Brown, who runs the kitchen, and his wife, Audrey, who manages the front of the house, the restaurant, which attracts a crowd of stylish locals, was, for the fourth time, awarded a single star.

title: Teeth, Art and Iguanas
description: Caroline Sterns dental office on West 57th Street seems like an attempt to cure toothaches by distraction.

title: Anger Lingers in Sudan After a Crackdown
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  On the first Friday after the protests began, Samar Ibnoaf, 23, said, she stepped outside her grandmothers house to take a look at the growing demonstration nearby.

title: Raising the G.E.D. Bar Stirs Concern for Students
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The high school equivalency exams taken by people who dropped out of school and immigrants seeking a foothold in the American education system are about to get harder and potentially more expensive, causing concern that fewer will take and pass the exams.

title: Texas: Company Sets Aside Payment for Visa Fraud
description: Infosys, an Indian outsourcing company based in Bangalore, said in an earnings report that it had set aside $35 million for a possible settlement in a visa fraud inquiry in Texas. For more than two years, federal authorities have been examining whether Infosys misused visas to bring temporary technology workers from India. In its report, the company said the Department of Homeland Security had found errors in a significant percentage of its hiring records.

title: In Sickness and in Health, Long After the Bike Is Due Back
description: For years, the rise of cycling in New York City has sown disharmony.

title: She Doesnt Just Play a Mother on TV
description: Betsy Brandt says she did not learn much about how to cook methamphetamine during her five seasons on Breaking Bad. But she did get hooked on the show. Speaking three days before its finale last month, she said she still had not accepted that it was ending. Youll probably hear me screaming out the window, she said. Nevertheless, she has moved away from the dark side to a comedic role on The Michael J. Fox Show, in which, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, she harks back to Suzanne Pleshette on The Bob Newhart Show.'  Since moving to New York in June, Ms. Brandt, 40, has been living in an apartment on the Upper West Side with her husband, Grady Olsen, 40, who works for OpenText, a software company, and their two children, ages 4 and 8.

title: James A. Emanuel, Poet Who Wrote of Racism, Dies at 92
description: James A. Emanuel, a poet, educator and critic who published more than a dozen volumes of his poetry, much of it after his frustration with racism in the United States helped motivate him to move to France, died on Sept. 28 in Paris. He was 92.

title: In California, New Package of Gun Laws but One Snag
description: LOS ANGELES  Democrats in the California Legislature passed a sweeping package of gun control bills after a string of mass shootings across the country, cracking down on assault rifles, high-capacity magazines and lead ammunition. But on Friday, Gov. Jerry Brown, also a Democrat, vetoed several key pieces, including a ban on semiautomatic weapons that many had considered the toughest restriction on gun ownership in the country.

title: Picnic Over, Missouri Seeks to Build Its SEC Credentials
description: Missouris schedule in September looked as if it had been generously arranged at a neighborhood cookout by Coach Gary Pinkels friends and neighbors, eager to see him rebound after a 5-7 campaign in 2012, his first losing season since 2004.

title: Strapped In, but Still at Risk
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md.  For more than two hours, Xiaopeng Li struggled to securely install two rear-facing car seats for his young children in his Toyota Sienna minivan.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. Is Bowery a street or an avenue?

title: The Mystery Behind the Model for a Vanished Rockwell Painting
description: Norman Rockwell painted Sport, a cover for The Saturday Evening Post that was published in 1939. It is instantly recognizable, one of his scenes of iconic Americana, and yet a discerning eye may see hints of some personal turbulence behind its placid facade, said the author of a forthcoming biography.

title: India Braces for Cyclone Expected on East Coast
description: NEW DELHI  A monstrous cyclone that may be among the most powerful storms ever recorded in the Bay of Bengal was expected to hit the eastern coast of India by Saturday night.

title: At Drone Conference, Talk of Morals and Toys
description: The people came for the technology, certainly, and for the flying demonstrations they were promised. They came to find the hobbyists and dreamers who shared their vision of drones as a force of good  or at least good business.

title: A Private Artist Goes Public
description: Janet K. Ruttenberg hovered over a 15-foot-long piece of paper that was spread across the grass in Central Park. It was an unusually balmy October afternoon and she was painting one of her favorite subjects: the Sheep Meadow. Wielding a 40-inch-long brush, she dabbed some yellow paint and described the curious pull of the vast lawn, with its tableaux of couples, families and single New Yorkers, all set beneath the elegant skyline of Central Park South.

title: Britain: Rules for Press Proposed
description: Britains three main political parties on Friday agreed on a plan to regulate the countrys newspapers, but the proposal faced heavy criticism from the press, casting doubt over its future. Because of worries about press freedom, the government wants newspapers to agree voluntarily to be governed by a new regulatory body and whatever rules it sets up, and has suggested some incentives to win their cooperation. The move to tighten regulations follows a phone-hacking scandal that emerged in 2011 and led to the closing of a newspaper in Rupert Murdochs media empire. Under the plan agreed to Friday, the new regulator could impose fines of up to $1.3 million for violations of its code of conduct. Several prominent newspaper groups argue that any regulatory body set up by politicians could be used to control the news media. It is unclear if the parties will now press ahead with their plan or try again to win more media support.

title: Request to Appoint Lawyer for Terror Suspect Is Denied
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday rejected a request that he appoint a lawyer to represent a terror suspect who was captured last weekend in Libya and was said to be undergoing interrogation while in military custody on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Anger and Indifference After a School Ends a Full-Contact Tradition
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  Lawrenceville School students trickled out of the brick buildings of the campus on a recent afternoon to begin their activities of dance, soccer and community service.

title: Venezuela Intercepts Ship With 5 Americans Aboard
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Maps of Venezuela hanging on the walls of schoolrooms and in government offices show a large striped area to the east of the countrys border with Guyana marked Zone in Reclamation. For more than a century, Venezuela has claimed that it is the rightful owner of this zone, which consists of about three-quarters of Guyanas national territory. The longstanding feud has often darkened relations between the two nations.

title: More Sex, Anyone?
description: You made me laugh. You, the reader who wrote that, on the subject of sex before marriage, your mother asked your father the farthest he had gone with his before-marriage girlfriend. Poughkeepsie, he replied.

title: Midnight Scavengers
description: Three hundred people gathered in the parking lot of a shuttered Lower Manhattan supermarket on Oct. 5 for the start of Midnight Madness.

title: Hollywood Ponders Movie on Book About Snowden
description: LOS ANGELES  For more than a week, Hollywood has been exploring what could be one of the most difficult nonfiction projects it has ever tried: a proposed film based on the journalist Glenn Greenwalds planned book about Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive whistle-blower.

title: Airlines Cash In on Every Inch, Even the Jammed Bins Overhead
description: A frosted cake. A 10-gallon hat. A car muffler.

title: Wooing Hometown Industry, de Blasio Meets Wary Wall St.
description: It was an unadvertised stop on Bill de Blasios schedule. In a corporate boardroom high above Midtown Manhattan, the populist insurgent and sudden mayoral front-runner was courting an unlikely constituency: New York Citys plutocratic class.

title: C.I.A. Disputes Early Suspicions on Snowden
description: WASHINGTON  The C.I.A. said Friday that it did not suspect Edward J. Snowden of gaining access to computer files without authorization when he was working as a technician for the agency in Geneva in 2009, and did not send him home as a result.

title: And Now, Ted Cruz Cloned
description: Our question for today is: What does next Wednesdays Senate election in New Jersey mean to those of us who dont live in New Jersey?

title: One Long Night in Puzzle City
description: Along 11th Avenue, women in tight dresses and stiletto heels wobbled home in the misty hours after midnight.

title: Tackling, at the Turn of the Century
description: WASHINGTON  THE public was increasingly upset over the physical toll wrought by football. University faculties were in an uproar over funds diverted from education to the sport. The president called the leaders of the football establishment to the White House to demand change  and they responded.

title: For Safety in Reactors, Company Thinks Small
description: CORVALLIS, Ore.  Jose N. Reyes has a surefire way to make certain that in case of accident, his nuclear reactor is surrounded by plenty of cold water: install it at the bottom of a giant swimming pool.

title: An Island of Designer Toys and Dueling Artists Within New York Comic Con
description: After eight years of catering to fans in capes and masks, New York Comic Con is hoping to expand its audience.

title: Rolling the Dice on Food-Borne Illnesses
description: The government shutdown has caused staff reductions at two important federal health agencies, increasing the risk of serious harm to American consumers from food-borne illnesses. The two agencies  the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention  have decided to focus their remaining resources on imminent threats. But they have shut down very important work that allows them to spot potentially serious problems in advance and take steps to head them off. The longer Congressional Republicans allow the shutdown to continue, the greater the danger of harm.

title: The Villain in Gravity Is Real
description: The new movie Gravity, in which George Clooney and Sandra Bullock play astronauts adrift in space, has been variously praised as a riveting drama and criticized for scientific inaccuracies. But the phenomenon that sets the plot in motion is not a Hollywood fantasy. It is space junk, a very real villain. While Mr. Clooney and Ms. Bullock are out completing repairs, they hear that a Russian missile strike on a satellite has caused a chain reaction, with the debris taking out other satellites, and that flying bits of metal are coming their way. They survive the initial collision, but the junk ruins their shuttle.

title: Neighborhood Watch Fantasists
description: After George Zimmerman decided to shadow Trayvon Martin and then shot the unarmed teenager to death, accounts described him rather innocuously as a neighborhood watch volunteer. Mr. Zimmerman, who was ultimately acquitted, could have been described more accurately as a self-appointed sentinel, legally armed and fully protected against the full consequences for homicide under the states notorious Stand Your Ground law.

title: U.S. Team Shifts Focus to Sizing Up Its Players
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  As World Cup qualifying matches go, there was little to see here Friday night. The United States had already clinched its place in Brazil next summer, and its opponent, Jamaica, was all but eliminated from contention.

title: Dont Blame the Norwegians
description: HAMBURG, Germany  AFTER Santa Claus, Geir Lundestad has what may be the most joyful job in the world. Every year, on the second Friday of October at around 10:30 a.m., the suave, gray-haired Norwegian historian picks up his phone to inform a lucky earthling that he or she has just won the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Resolving Disputes in Asia
The Pope and Conservative Catholics
A Call for Privacy Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Prescribing Generic Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Devices in Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: Louder Voice for the Rich?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Arts, Under Threat
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Unequal Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: A Familys Need to Know
description: When you drive into Bloomington, Ind., a classic college town of 82,000 dominated by Indiana University, one of the first things you see is a large, handmade billboard with the picture of a pretty young woman. Next to her picture is her name, Lauren Spierer, and, in bold red letters, the word MISSING. More than two years ago, Lauren, who was finishing her sophomore year, disappeared.

title: In Libya, Premier Calls Kidnapping Failed Coup
description: TUNIS  Prime Minister Ali Zeidan of Libya said on Friday that his kidnapping the day before by militia members was no different than a coup and had been orchestrated by opponents in the legislature who want to force him from office.

title: A Warning to Egypts Generals
description: President Obamas decision to reduce but not terminate military aid to Egypt is a measured attempt to protect American interests in a tumultuous region while affirming the presidents support for democracy. One message is that the relationship between the two countries remains crucial to regional stability. The other is that America cannot sit by while the Egyptian Army tramples on Egypts political opposition, foments violence and turns increasingly authoritarian, thus ensuring further turmoil.

title: Shutdowns Quiet Toll, From Idled Research to Closed Wallets
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency has stopped monitoring mercury contamination in the Everglades and testing water after the recent floods in Colorado.

title: 3rd Buccaneer Found With Infection
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers said Friday that a third player had a MRSA infection, a thorny strain that has been a concern in N.F.L. locker rooms over the past decade.

title: 2 States Plan 2-Tier System for Balloting
description: PHOENIX  Barred by the Supreme Court from requiring proof of citizenship for federal elections, Arizona is complying  but setting up a separate registration system for local and state elections that will demand such proof.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 11
Teacher Leaves Yeshiva Amid Abuse Scandal
description: Yeshiva University said Friday that a Yeshiva College teacher was no longer employed by the university following news reports that he had been previously convicted of lewdness with minors.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 12, 2013
description: Netanyahu is most comfortable predicting disaster, scaring people into doing something. The problem is now hes lost momentum. His message is clear, his message is the same, the situation is the same, but everyone elses perspective has changed. Its like youre the only one in a dark room with a flashlight.

title: Share Your Citi Bike Wedding Story
description: They have been used as resting places and makeshift gyms. They have also helped inebriated people get home and helped a mayoral candidate navigate the city.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: 2 Oregon at 16 Washington

title: Corrections: October 12, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Vacancy Clause
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  The first thing were going to do is skip over discussing the northwest sector of this puzzle, because we are all adults here. And the answer is no, no one  including the constructor  noticed it. Instead, were going to focus our attention on the rest of John Farmers lovely, Scrabbly grid.

title: Giants Manning Shoulders Blame for Turnovers, but Problems Run Deeply
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Coughlin, who led the Giants to two Super Bowl triumphs, three N.F.C. East titles and five playoff berths in his first nine years as their coach, insists he and his staff have not lost their way after a devastating 0-6 start.

title: Detroit Arms Facing Test From Boston Bats
description: BOSTON  When Quintin Berry talks about the Boston Red Sox hitters, he does not include himself in the group. Berry has batted only nine times in 14 games for the Red Sox, who have included him on their American League Championship Series roster for his speed, not his bat.

title: For a Night, a Convicted Donor Can Stay Late at the Opera
description: Alberto Vilar, a longtime major donor to the Metropolitan Opera before his conviction for financial crimes, will be able to attend a sold-out performance on Saturday night  thanks to a federal judges agreement to extend his 11 p.m. curfew.

title: Spanish Formula One Driver Found Dead
description: Maria de Villota, a 33-year-old Spanish racing driver, was found dead in her hotel room in Seville, 15 months after she sustained multiple skull fractures  and lost an eye  in a Formula One testing accident in England.

title: Wolf Hall Mini-Series With Mark Rylance Is Coming to PBSs Masterpiece
description: A big British costume drama, adapted from big British literary works with a big British star, is coming to PBSs Masterpiece? Well, of course it is. But in this case, its still a big deal, because the literary works are Wolf Hall, Hilary Mantels Booker Prize-winning novel about the ascent of Thomas Cromwell, and its similarly decorated sequel, Bring Up the Bodies. And the star is Mark Rylance, the Tony and Olivier Award-winning actor, who will portray Cromwell, the powerful minister to Henry VIII, in this television drama.

title: With a Huge Line to Cover, the Jaguars Can Still Hope
description: Gamblers everywhere have an adage: there is no such thing as a bad game if you have money on it. The Denver Broncos and the Jacksonville Jaguars will demonstrate that again Sunday in what will be, by all indications, a brutal mismatch, one that has become the talk of the N.F.L.

title: After Steady Presence for Years, Kenseth Is Driver to Beat in Chase
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The last time Matt Kenseth dominated a Nascar season was 2003, when he took the points lead in early March and never relinquished it on the way to one of the more uneventful championship runs in the sports history.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY (2012) Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman, above) sets out with the wizard Gandalf (Ian McKellen) and a posse of dwarfs to battle a dragon in Peter Jacksons adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkiens first Middle-earth fantasy novel, part of a planned trilogy. Richard Armitage plays the exiled dwarf king Thorin, who leads the expedition through a series of encounters with orcs, elves, trolls and other beings. Andy Serkis returns, with the assistance of computer generation, as Gollum. The meeting between Bilbo and Gollum, which takes place in a vast, watery subterranean cavern, is the one fully enchanted piece of An Unexpected Journey, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Its a funny, haunting and curiously touching moment that summons the audience to a state of quiet, eager attentiveness. Even if you arent aware of the apocalyptic importance of Gollums precious ring, you feel that a lot is at stake here: Bilbos life and integrity; Gollums corroded soul; the fate of Middle-earth itself. He added, If only some of that feeling animated the rest of the movie.

title: Returning Home
description: Willie Colon, an offensive lineman with the Jets, has maintained a special bond to his South Bronx neighborhood.

title: Beltran Lifts Cardinals Past Dodgers in a Taut Game 1
description: ST. LOUIS  The voices of the Cardinals fans at Busch Stadium had turned raspy, harsh and a little desperate by the eighth inning Friday night. St. Louis had not managed much against the Los Angeles Dodgers starter, Zack Greinke, an old antagonist, in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series, and the score remained tied going into the ninth.

title: 800,000 Evacuated as Powerful Cyclone Hits India
description: NEW DELHI  A powerful cyclone whose spinning arms engulfed much of the Bay of Bengal weakened Sunday morning as it crashed into Indias eastern coast, flooding homes and roads throughout the region and disrupting electricity and communications.

title: Senate Takes Lead as House Republicans Talks With White House Fail
description: WASHINGTON  Senators Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell on Saturday began last-ditch negotiations on reopening the government and raising the debt ceiling as talks between House Republicans and the White House collapsed, dashing hopes for a quick resolution to the political crisis that has paralyzed the government.

title: Mother and 3 Young Children Are Killed in a House Fire on Long Island
description: A Long Island woman and her three young children were killed in a fast-moving house fire in Suffolk County late Friday night, the police said.

title: From the Archive Come Brides of The Times
description: Into the Lively Morgue they descend, rich and richer alike, the well born and the even more well off. Cue the organ music: here come the brides. These women marched down the aisle during the 1920s and 1930s, as the countrys economy and marriage rates were plunging  and they marched into The New York Timess portrait studio in the days before or after their weddings, defying the adage that women wear their wedding gowns one time only.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Oct. 11, 2013
description: The federal government could default on its debt if it does not increase the amount of money it can borrow by October 17. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine what will happen to the economy and Wall Street if Washington doesnt raise the debt ceiling. Domestic and foreign investors are closely watching and making decisions that could affect the nations economy for years to come.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (2) vs. Jamaica (0)
description: With a spot in Brazil next year already assured, the United States national team defeated Jamaica in its final home World Cup qualifier to lock down first place in the final round  the hexagonal  of qualifying in the Concacaf region.

title: Stephanopoulizing
description: On tomorrow morning, with David Plouffe, Dan Senor, and Peggy Noonan. I believe were going to be doing movie criticism, focusing on the new film in which Tom Hanks and his crew are taken hostage by Tea Party Republicans Somali pirates. But I might be wrong about that.

title: Business and the GOP
description: Still no resolution on the debt ceiling, and I think people are still too optimistic here. Republicans still arent willing to walk away from this without some kind of trophy, so they can claim victory; the whole point of Obamas position is that you dont get anything, not even something trivial, as a reward for threatening disaster.

title: Dodgers Top Hitters Havent Been Getting Chances in Key Situations
description: ST. LOUIS  Once again on Saturday, during Game 2 of their National League Championship Series against the Cardinals, when the Los Angeles Dodgers could have used a big hit from Adrian Gonzalez or Hanley Ramirez, neither had the chance to deliver.

title: Like Pirates, Steelers Having a Rare Season
description: PITTSBURGH  They came wearing jerseys of their newest heroes, McCutchen, Alvarez and Liriano. They set up chairs, huddled in blankets and waved Jolly Roger flags. Hundreds of Pittsburghers gathered here on a chilly night, in front of a giant projection screen at the foot of the Roberto Clemente Bridge, to watch their Pirates in Game 5 of the National League division series.

title: Variety: Diagramless Puzzle
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Fred Piscop appears to be on a very specific diet of sorts. Todays diagramless puzzle is a tasty SCHMEAR of various salads, with a sprinkling of crunchy Xs as croutons.

title: Kirilenko, Nets Versatile New Veteran, Plays With a Revived Hunger
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Andrei Kirilenko hid out this off-season in St.-Tropez, France, away from civilization, he said, as he has for the better part of a decade. But this summer, for the first time since he can remember, he did not touch a basketball.

title: N.S.A. Director Firmly Defends Surveillance Efforts
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The director of the National Security Agency, Gen. Keith B. Alexander, said in an interview that to prevent terrorist attacks he saw no effective alternative to the N.S.A.s bulk collection of telephone and other electronic metadata from Americans. But he acknowledged that his agency now faced an entirely new reality, and the possibility of Congressional restrictions, after revelations about its operations at home and abroad.

title: African Union Urges International Court to Delay Kenyan Presidents Trial
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The members of the African Union said Saturday that no sitting head of state should be prosecuted by an international tribunal and that the trial of Kenyas president at the International Criminal Court should be postponed, according to the groups chairman, who spoke after the closed-door session.

title: Cost of Flood Insurance Rises, Along With Worries
description: MIAMI  Sharp increases in federal flood insurance rates are distressing coastal homeowners from Hawaii to New England and are starting to hurt property values and housing sales in areas just beginning to recover from the recession, according to residents and legislators.

title: Four Executives on Succeeding in Business as a Woman
description: The executives, ranging from the president of a beauty products company to the general counsel at Pfizer, shared their stories about headwinds they have navigated over the years and advice to women wanting to succeed at work.

title: Readers Advice for Young Women in the Workplace
description: Before Adam Bryants special installment of Corner Office on women and leadership, The Times asked readers to give their own advice to women who are early in their careers. Here are excerpts from the more than 500 responses.

title: The Secrets of the Shenandoah
