description: South Pacific tropical islanders, boreal dawns, perilous ice floes and distressed whaling ships hardly belong to our usual mental inventory of American Civil War images. They evoke Herman Melville more than Stephen Crane. But they were all part of the long, strange global odyssey of a Confederate ship called the Shenandoah.

title: Talks Clear Path for U.S.-Afghan Deal on Troops
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After more than a week of hard-line posturing by Afghan and American officials, Secretary of State John Kerry and President Hamid Karzai defied expectations and agreed on key elements of a deal that, if completed, would keep American troops in Afghanistan beyond next year.

title: When the Stock Price Hides Trouble
description: WHEN a company receives criticism about its executive pay practices, a typical defense is to cite a rising stock price as justification of its pay. If total shareholder return is up, the theory goes, stockholders have no right to complain about what might otherwise look like outsize pay at their companies.

title: Tigers Torii Hunter Seeks Elusive Title
description: BOSTON  The next time a player says he has not even thought about his pending free agency, understand that he is lying. Or, at least, that he is not like the Detroit Tigers Torii Hunter, who enjoyed last season in Anaheim but knew he might not play there forever.

title: Sports Legends Selling Relics? Hey, That Glove Really Is Gold
description: There comes a time when a sports legend must decide whether to hang on to this championship ring and that game-worn jersey, or to cash in on the memorabilia market, which can fetch stunning sums for rare and historic artifacts.

title: Packing a Punch on the Bases, Too
description: In 1950, Dom DiMaggio led the American League in stolen bases with 15. It is the lowest total that has led either league, and if DiMaggio was to be believed, it was hardly on purpose.

title: Student Datas Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Mug Shots, Forever or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chatter for Sunday, October 13
description: Too many Americans still cant find a job, and worry how theyll pay their bills. The Federal Reserve can help.

title: Stuck on Usual Quarrel: Raising New Revenue
description: WASHINGTON  Be skeptical. Be very, very skeptical.

title: And Now, From the Woman Poised to Run the Fed ...
description: Last week, after President Obama nominated Janet L. Yellen, the Brooklyn-born, Brown-and-Yale-educated economist, to lead the Federal Reserve, commentators praised her intellect and expertise. But they were also quick to celebrate the fact that she would be the first woman to hold the top job at the 100-year-old central bank. Fairly typical was the sentiment expressed by Justin Wolfers, a University of Michigan economist, who wrote on Bloomberg View: Tonight, I feel reassured that my daughters economic future is in good hands. I also plan to tell her that she, too, can grow up to become the most powerful economist in the world. Its a potent stimulus. Ms. Yellen seems more at ease speechifying in the realm of monetary policy and inflationary models than discussing her gender. But over the years, she has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her own rise in a male-dominated field.

title: German Outrage Swells Over a Bishops Spending
description: BERLIN  Since being elected in March, Pope Francis has quickly made a mark with his displays of modesty, eschewing lavish papal apartments for a spartan guesthouse in Vatican City, wearing simple vestments, carrying his own bag and preaching against a Roman Catholic Church hierarchy that he said was overly insular and too often led by narcissists.

title: The Soaring Cost of a Simple Breath
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The kitchen counter in the home of the Hayes family is scattered with the inhalers, sprays and bottles of pills that have allowed Hannah, 13, and her sister, Abby, 10, to excel at dance and gymnastics despite a horrific pollen season that has set off asthma attacks, leaving the girls struggling to breathe.

title: The Science Behind a Call for Safer Hockey
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  The message from researchers last week for a Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey was clear: the game as it is played now causes too much brain trauma, and it must change fundamentally.

title: Penn State Opens Ice Arena Fit for a Division I Team
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  Penn State christened its $90 million Pegula Ice Arena with a 4-1 victory over Army on Friday night before an overflow crowd announced at 6,370. And Coach Guy Gadowskys first words were a salute to the fans who had ushered in a new era for the hockey program.

title: Staring Into the Abyss
description: No deal. And for a very good reason: the president has made it a matter of principle that he will not make concessions that reward hostage-taking, and Republican leaders refuse to release the hostages without getting something that will let them claim victory.

title: Riding Out the Political Storm
description: The stock market began the week in a funk and ended in subdued celebration as apparent progress in the debt-ceiling impasse seemed to confirm the Wall Street consensus that dysfunction in Washington wont lead to a debt default or set off a global cataclysm.

title: A Striking Absence of Women
description: Twitter, the popular social networking company, recently drew unwelcome attention to itself and the technology industry when it revealed in the filing for its initial public offering that none of the seven people on its board was a woman. One academic accused it of male chauvinist thinking; Twitters chief executive, Dick Costolo, seemed to only make matters worse by referring to that critic, Vivek Wadhwa, as the Carrot Top of academic sources, alluding to the over-the-top standup comedian Carrot Top.

title: Haitis Imported Disaster
description: Haitis cholera epidemic, now entering its fourth year, has killed more than 8,300 people and sickened more than 650,000. It is a calamity, though one fundamentally different from the earthquake, hurricanes and floods that have beset the fragile country since 2010.

title: Fighting Back Against Revenge Porn
description: Revenge porn is one of those things that sounds as if it must be illegal but actually isnt. Its the term of art for publishing sexual photos of someone without his or her  usually her  permission, often after a breakup.

title: Its Not Only Mothers and Children
description: For impoverished Americans, the biggest obstacle to health insurance remains the refusal of 26 mostly Republican-led states to expand their Medicaid programs as called for under the health reform law. As a result, up to an estimated eight million people will get no help at all because they earn too little to buy subsidized coverage on the new insurance exchanges and too much to qualify for Medicaid in states that wont expand their programs.

title: Monarchs Fight for Their Lives
description: The more you know about monarch butterflies, the more extraordinary they seem. Their life cycle  the adaptive web of behaviors they have evolved  is almost unbelievably complex. They migrate en masse (this month, as a rule) from all across the Midwest and Northeast to just a few high altitude sites in Mexico, where they winter, sheltering in profusion beneath a canopy of fir trees, from whose trunks they draw the residual heat they need to stay alive. Winter past, they migrate thousands of miles northward, where they lay their eggs on milkweed plants, the only plant a monarch caterpillar can eat.

title: Your Vintage Wedding Photos
description: A selection of readers heirloom wedding photos from around the world.

title: The Death of Willie Sherman
description: It was no secret that 9-year-old Willie was the favorite child of William Tecumseh Sherman. In fact, his wife, Ellen, reproved him repeatedly for making his preference for Willie uncomfortably obvious to their other children. But on the evening of Oct. 3, 1863, the boy lay dead in a Memphis hotel room. Sherman would write the next day to Ulysses S. Grant that Willie was the one I most prised [sic] on earth. But Willies death was the tragic consequence of a series of decisions for which Sherman would blame himself the rest of his own life.

title: Alex Gibney
description: Alex Gibney is an Academy Award-winning documentary filmmaker. His latest projects are Mea Maxima Culpa about the Roman Catholic Church and The Armstrong Lie about Lance Armstrong.

title: The End of the Nation-State?
description: SINGAPORE  EVERY five years, the United States National Intelligence Council, which advises the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, publishes a report forecasting the long-term implications of global trends. Earlier this year it released its latest report, Alternative Worlds, which included scenarios for how the world would look a generation from now.

title: The Kurtz Republicans
description: THEY told me, Martin Sheens Willard says to Marlon Brandos Kurtz in Apocalypse Now, at the end of a long journey up the river, that you had gone totally insane, and that your methods were unsound.

title: A Mad Tea Party
description: WASHINGTON  HOW awful are Ted Cruz and his Cruzettes?

title: The Disconnect on Anonymous Sources
description: ERIC Schmitt remembers being surprised when, as a member of a Times newsroom committee on reporting practices, he was given information about what bothered readers of The Times most. It wasnt political bias, or factual errors, or delivery problems.

title: Is Music the Key to Success?
description: CONDOLEEZZA RICE trained to be a concert pianist. Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, was a professional clarinet and saxophone player. The hedge fund billionaire Bruce Kovner is a pianist who took classes at Juilliard.

title: Shrinking Hours
description: ONCE, an hour with your therapist ran for about 60 minutes. But theres been a steady time deflation: first there was the 50-minute hour and now we have 45-minute hours.

title: Londons Great Exodus
description: LONDON  OUR neighbors Lauren and Matt and their kids moved out of London to Cambridge the other week. Bibi, Andy and their two left for Bristol in June. Another of my 8-year-olds classmates and her family are heading out after Christmas.

title: From the Streets to the Worlds Best Mom
description: NASHVILLE  WHEN men paid Shelia Faye Simpkins for sex, they presumably thought she was just a happy hooker engaging in a transaction among consenting adults.

title: How to Save Your Local Opera
description: Take a cue from New York City Operas demise and dont use your endowment to make ends meet; never let your operating costs exceed your basso profundos calorie count.

title: Colleges Identity Crisis
description: IS a college degrees worth best measured by the income its recipient makes 5 or 10 years down the road? Is college primarily a catapult to wealth? These were questions implicitly raised by President Obamas recent proposal that the federal government look at graduates earnings when rating schools in an effort to steer students toward the best ones.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Too Tethered to Tests?
description: Readers debate the influential role of SAT and A.P. exams.

title: Stuck in a Dispute Between PayPal and Itself
description: If PayPal isnt the most reviled online company in the country, which is? The Haggler invites reader suggestions for this unhappy title, but before you write in, consider the sheer quantity of animosity that PayPal inspires. There are anti-PayPal Facebook sites, anti-PayPal YouTube tirades, PayPal-loathing Twitter accounts and more than 550 complaints about PayPal on ConsumerAffairs.com.

title: City of Water
description: ONE of the great things about New York used to be how easy it was to ignore the natural world. With a public transportation system that never closes, moving from climate-controlled apartment to office to entertainment, and living high above the earth itself, New Yorkers never had to worry much about anything as mundane as the weather.

title: When Debate Stalls, Try Your Paintbrush
description: I LEAD a team of scientists that is designing a cognitive computing chip and software ecosystem inspired by the human brain. It will help computers sense, perceive, act and reason more like humans. In the face of much skepticism and tremendous technical unknowns, our goal is finally within reach.

title: Out of Network, Out of Luck
description: For several hundred patients at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, it started with a certified letter informing them that they were no longer allowed to see their physicians. The reason? They were unlucky enough to have insurance called Community Blue, which is offered by a rival hospital system. Astoundingly, they were barred even if they could pay for the care themselves.

title: Ebb and Flow on the Supreme Court
description: By two measures, the Roberts court has upended the existing legal order fewer times than any predecessor since the early 1950s.

title: How Activist Is the Supreme Court?
description: WASHINGTON  JUSTICES Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg are ideological antagonists on the Supreme Court, but they agree on one thing. Their court is guilty of judicial activism.

title: Redskins Owner Stubbornly Clings to Wrong Side of History
description: On Jan. 14, 1963, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama delivered an inaugural address in which he declared his unwavering allegiance to segregation now, segregation tomorrow and segregation forever.

title: Youd Better Have a Plan
description: MY parents emigrated from South Korea to the United States when my father enrolled in graduate school here for a Ph.D. in physical chemistry. My mother makes the woman who wrote Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother look like a kitten. She had strong ideas on how to raise children and pushed my older sister, Lydia, and me.

title: A Surprising Case Against Foreign Aid
description: IN his new book, Angus Deaton, an experts expert on global poverty and foreign aid, puts his considerable reputation on the line and declares that foreign aid does more harm than good. It corrupts governments and rarely reaches the poor, he argues, and it is high time for the paternalistic West to step away and allow the developing world to solve its own problems.

title: Missy Franklin Finds New World on Campus
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The strain showed on Missy Franklins face as she lay on her back, scissoring her straight legs a few inches off the ground as painstakingly as a seamstress cutting a pattern. Franklins strong core was obvious on Friday well before she joined a dozen of her University of California swimming teammates in the afternoon for their weekly hourlong dance class, which, to their dismay, featured more segmental rotations than hip gyrations.

title: As China Vows Austerity, Giant Brass Fish Devours $11 Million
description: HONG KONG  Chinese Communist Party leaders vows of a new era of humble austerity in government may have met their most exotic adversary yet: an $11 million, 2,300-ton, 295-foot-long puffer fish.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sticky Wages and the Macro Wars
description: Simon Wren-Lewis, following up on Bryan Caplan, makes the case that downward nominal rigidity of wages is simply a fact, attested to by overwhelming evidence. Furthermore, its a fact that we understand fairly well in terms of behavioral economics. So he suggests that the unwillingness of many macroeconomists to incorporate this fact in their models  because it doesnt have microfoundations  says something disturbing about the state of the field.

title: From Summer Camp, a Parable for Washington
description: FOR all Americans who want their government to work  and I presume that is most of us  the recent discord in Washington over the government shutdown and debt limit has been painful to watch. But for me, the high-stakes squabbling among Democrats and Republicans is also a reminder of a dissonance with which I have lived throughout my life.

title: At Least for One Game, Texas and Its Embattled Coach Return to Glory
description: DALLAS  These were the Longhorns that Texas Coach Mack Brown had lauded, the recruits he had molded and sold as championship contenders this season, heaping expectations that they had not come close to meeting.

title: Seeking a Staredown With Google Glass
description: SOON, many people will be seeing the world through computerized glasses, and not just those made by Google.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 13
description: With fiscal negotiations between House Republicans and the Obama administration crumbling on Saturday,all eyes turned to the Senate just days before the United States faces the possibility of a devastating financial default on Thursday. Key senators from both parties will take to the political talk shows on Sunday to discuss the prospects for a deal.

title: In a Mood? Call Center Agents Can Tell
description: IN a YouTube clip from one of Steve Jobss last interviews, he appears to be enjoying reminiscing about how he first hit upon the idea for the keyboardless tablet that eventually became the iPad.

title: Chipping Away at Sex Trafficking in America
description: Ive written a good deal about sex trafficking in other countries over the years, from Cambodia to India, Pakistan to Philippines. But I probably havent written enough about the problem right here in America, and in the last few years Ive tried to remedy that. My first aim is to remind people that this is a major problem at home, and that a lot of prostitution is less voluntary than people usually assume. The second aim is to show that the problem isnt hopeless, and that there are things we can do about it.

title: Duets, Messages, Crowds and the Country-Pop Blend
description: Growing up in the San Felipe Courts housing projects of Houstons Fourth Ward, Kenny Rogers used to walk to elementary school through better neighborhoods, admiring what he came to recognize as the mark of success: automatic water sprinklers. In the 1980s, in the middle of a run that earned him 12 Billboard-chart-topping albums and 24 No. 1 hits, Mr. Rogers built an 18-hole golf course at his home near Athens, Ga., and covered it in automatic sprinklers. Id spend hours sitting on a golf cart admiring them, Mr. Rogers says. I like to joke I have them inside my house now.

title: For Aid Insuring Latinos, Groups Look Close to Home
description: Though they make up roughly a third of the states population, Latinos account for nearly two-thirds of the more than six million Texans without health insurance. But in the 13 days since a federal insurance marketplace aimed at helping the uninsured find coverage opened, health care advocates across the state have encountered common obstacles in getting Latinos registered, including limited access to computers and the lack of an e-mail address.

title: The Last Person Did Everything Just Right
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Tutoring Company in Texas Draws Fire as State Pulls Back Services
description: When two of Marcos Sifuentess children received free laptops from a tutoring program through their San Antonio middle school, the family signed up for wireless access at home for the first time. Mr. Sifuentes added an Internet hot spot to his cellphone plan so they could continue their lessons.

title: Taken to Task
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Jeff Chen has set himself a Sisyphean task today in more ways than one. SISYPHUS didnt have any help rolling his BOULDER up the hill, but because resources here are limited and the Across Lite (and possibly the New York Times game play) version of the puzzle does not display the way Mr. Chen had planned, Im going to help him out. That what friends are for, right?

title: Cousin Arrested in Baby Hope Killing After 22 Years
description: It was a cold case that had eluded investigators for more than two decades. A little girl with no name had been stuffed into a cooler and left beside a Manhattan highway. On Saturday, however, the mystery seemed to have been lifted with the arrest of a cousin of the girl, known as Baby Hope, the police said.

title: Online Application Woes Make Students Anxious and Put Colleges Behind Schedule
description: With early admission deadlines looming for hundreds of thousands of students, the new version of the online Common Application shared by more than 500 colleges and universities has been plagued by numerous malfunctions, alarming students and parents and putting admissions offices weeks behind schedule.

title: What $250 of Prescriptions Looks Like
description: Comparing the costs of five medications between the United States and other countries.

title: Senate Democrats on Shutdown Talks
description: Top Senate Democrats led by the majority leader Harry Reid lamented the failure to end a 12-day-old government shutdown at a news conference in Washington on Saturday.

title: Vows: Kerry and Chris
description: Kerry Whichello and Chris Belair met while working behind the scenes on Late Show With David Letterman. They plan to spend the rest of their lives laughing together.

title: A Rookie Remains on a Roll and Extends the Cardinals Edge
description: ST. LOUIS  Only once, in the sixth inning, did Michael Wacha of the St. Louis Cardinals act like a giddy 22-year-old rookie pitching in his first postseason. And it happened in the tensest moment of Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Three Up-and-Comers Share Secrets of Success
description: Three Americans on the rise. Three ideas about their success.

title: Week 6 Matchup: Steelers (0-4) at Jets (3-2)
description: 1 p.m., CBS

title: Washington Cannot Keep Up, and Oregon Keeps Rivalry One-Sided
description: SEATTLE  Marcus Mariota was finally contained Saturday. He was trapped, boxed in. It took two concrete walls, a narrow walkway in between and a few dozen reporters in his path, but finally Mariota was stopped.

title: Governor Vetoes Bill to Limit Use of Generic Drugs in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Jerry Brown has vetoed a bill that critics said would have hindered the use of cheaper versions of high-priced biotechnology drugs, providing a victory for health plans and generic drug companies over brand-name pharmaceutical manufacturers.

title: 30 Seconds With Lou Holtz
description: Lou Holtz prepared for his job as ESPNs wise and witty college football analyst by serving as a head coach at six colleges over 33 years.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: TERRY BAGGETT The Army back, right, ran for a team-record 304 yards and had four touchdowns in a 50-25 home win over Eastern Michigan. It was the first 300-yard rushing game in the Football Bowl Subdivision this season.

title: G.O.P.s Hopes to Take Senate Are Dimming
description: WASHINGTON  Next year was supposed to be a prime opportunity for Republicans to retake the Senate. And for a while, everything seemed to be breaking their way: a wave of Democratic retirements, a fluke in the electoral map that put a large number of races in states that President Obama lost, a strong farm team of conservative Senate hopefuls from the House.

title: How HealthCare.gov Was Supposed to Work and How It Didnt
description: A look at what went wrong with the new federal health exchange.

title: From the Start, Signs of Trouble at Health Portal
description: WASHINGTON  In March, Henry Chao, the chief digital architect for the Obama administrations new online insurance marketplace, told industry executives that he was deeply worried about the Web sites debut. Lets just make sure its not a third-world experience, he told them.

title: Palin Endorses Lonegan in New Jersey Senate Race
description: NEW EGYPT, N.J.  With polls suggesting a tightening race and only a few days remaining in the United States Senate contest in New Jersey, thousands of people gathered at a racetrack here to watch Sarah Palin endorse the Republican candidate, Steve Lonegan.

title: Corrections: October 13, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Behind Flurry of Killing, Potency of Hate
description: LONDON  From a comfortable couch in his London living room, Sean OCallaghan had been watching the shaky televised images of terrified people running from militants in an upscale mall in Kenya. Some of those inside had been asked their religion. Muslims were spared, non-Muslims executed.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 13, 2013
description: We dont give any reason for drug makers to charge less.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 12, 2013
Family Man One Day, Rebel Fighter the Next
description: RAMTHA, Jordan  The Syrian rebel leader was sitting comfortably on a cushion at his home here recently, his wife and children filling the rooms with conversation and laughter. Then one day he shaved off his beard and slipped back into Syria, where he leads a rebel brigade.

title: Donald Cabana, Warden Who Loathed Death Penalty, Dies at 67
description: The first time Donald A. Cabana saw the gas chamber at the Mississippi State Penitentiary, in 1971, he was invited to sit inside it. He was 25 years old, had only brief experience as a corrections officer and was on a tour of the place  better known as Parchman Farm  hoping to work there one day. Certainly he did not envision himself as its future warden.

title: Krista Saunders, David Scenna
description: Krista Nicole Saunders and David Paul Scenna were married Saturday in Philadelphia. Naila L. Francis, a minister of the Journeys of the Heart nondenominational ministry, officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.

title: Rebecca Metz, Christopher Fiore
description: Rebecca Delahanty Metz and Christopher Fiore were married Saturday by the Rt. Rev. Andrew R. St. John, an Episcopal bishop, at the Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: Emily Jones, Jed Bonner
description: Emily Elizabeth Jones, the daughter of Cynthia Lance-Jones and Paul M. Jones Jr. of Pittsburgh, is to be married Sunday to Jed Wang Bonner, a son of Echo Wang Bonner and Sebastian P. Bonner, both of New York. The Rev. C. Anderson James, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate at the home of the grooms father.

title: Saying Yes to a Helicopter Ride
description: Sarah Lisette Pearse, a daughter of Gloria and Carl A. Pearse of Sarasota, Fla., is to be married Sunday evening to Maj. Zachariah George Morford, a son of Dorothy B. Morford and the Rev. G. Robert Morford of Keystone Heights, Fla. The grooms father, a Pentecostal minister, will officiate on the grounds of the Bay Preserve at Osprey, a historic home in Osprey, Fla.

title: David Sokosh, Robert Goldstrom
description: David John Sokosh and Robert Alan Goldstrom were married Tuesday at their town house in Brooklyn. Judge Richard J. Montelione of Brooklyn Criminal Court officiated.

title: Laura Merritt, Christopher Satti
description: Laura Jane Merritt and Christopher Stephen Satti were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Chris Sherwood, an evangelical Christian minister, at the Commanders Mansion, an event space in Watertown, Mass.

title: Rebecca DiLiberto, Gregory Adkins
description: Rebecca Dancer DiLiberto and Gregory Burrell Adkins were married Saturday evening at Cliffs Edge, a restaurant in Los Angeles. Wesley R. Morris, who became a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism for the event, officiated.

title: Jenni Schaefer, Eric Fluhr
description: Jenni Schaefer and Eric Jason Fluhr were married Saturday at St. Marys Catholic Church in Fredericksburg, Tex. Msgr. Enda McKenna, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Catherine Kast, Benjamin Stickney
description: Catherine Gill Kast, the daughter of Julie Gill Kast and Peter A. Kast of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday to Benjamin Ridgway Stickney, the son of Florence Macy Stickney and John T. Stickney of New York. The Rev. Joan T. Osgood, a Congregationalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: Deborah Lintz, Max Sank
description: Deborah Eileen Lintz and Max Steven Sank were married Saturday evening at Shutters on the Beach, a hotel in Santa Monica, Calif. The officiant was Daniel Brook, a friend of the couple and a rabbinical intern who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by Los Angeles County.

title: Emily Ross and Mark Hatch-Miller
description: Emily Robert Ross and Mark Howard Hatch-Miller were married Saturday evening at the Roundhouse at Beacon Falls, a hotel in Beacon, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated, with Cantor Angela Buchdahl assisting.

title: Joel Bauer, Michael Robotti
description: Joel Thomas Bauer and Michael Patrick Robotti are to be married Sunday at the Inn at West Settlement in Roxbury, N.Y. Allyne R. Ross, a judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, will officiate.

title: Kerry Whichello, Christopher Belair
description: Kerry Anne Whichello and Christopher Mark Belair were married Saturday by Canon Juan A. Quevedo-Bosch, an Episcopal priest, at Studio Square, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Kellie Miller, Michael La Mastra
description: Kellie Catherine Miller and Michael Armando La Mastra were married Saturday by the Rev. Gilbert Martinez at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Manhattan.

title: Meredith Horn, Avi Gelboim
description: Meredith Leigh Horn and Avi Joseph Gelboim are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi David Novak at the Hermitage Inn in West Dover, Vt.

title: Jessica Freeman-Slade, Nicholas Carbone
description: Jessica Ashley Freeman-Slade and Nicholas Dennis Carbone were married Saturday in Larz Anderson Park in Brookline, Mass.. by Daniel Gavin, a friend who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Jenny Rossman, Carlton Patrick
description: Jenny Rebecca Rossman and Carlton Justin Patrick were married Saturday at the M Building in Miami. Russell J. Mohrbach, a notary public, officiated in a ceremony that was led by Jacob W. S. Schneider, a friend of the couple, who incorporated Jewish traditions.

title: Elianora Palitz and Theodore Herbstman
description: Elianora Michele Palitz, a daughter of Gabrielle and Michael Palitz of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Theodore Andrew Herbstman, the son of Janet and David Herbstman of Flossmoor, Ill. Rabbi Shalom Podwol is to officiate at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: Katrina Pape, Whitney Rothe
description: Katrina Maria Vitagliano Pape, a daughter of Maria Teresa Ness Vitagliano of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Harry Charles Pape, who also lived in Palm Beach, was married in Greenwich, Conn., Saturday to Whitney Knowlton Rothe, a son of Nancy Louise Eberhart Rothe and Ernst Rothe of New York. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Greenwich

title: Jennifer Chu, Michael Kramer
description: Jennifer Lei-yee Chu and Michael Alan Kramer were married Saturday in San Diego. The Rev. Steven C. Siu, a minister of the Chinese Evangelical Church of San Diego, officiated at the San Diego Museum of Art.

title: The Wedding That Led to the Wedding
description: Georgia Nell Blume and William Donald Sugerman are to be married Sunday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in Brooklyn. Rabbi Geoffrey Basik will officiate.

title: Trisha Pfister, Eric Siegelstein
description: Trisha Ann Pfister and Eric Lee Siegelstein are to be married Sunday in Louisville, Ky. Kevin L. Garvey, who retired as a judge in the family division of the Jefferson County Circuit Court in Louisville, will officiate at the Hyatt Regency.

title: Christine Paquin, Nathaniel Wells
description: Christine Marie Paquin, the daughter of Theresa and Robert Paquin of Shelburne, Vt., was married there Saturday at the All Souls Interfaith Gathering to Nathaniel Emerson Wells, a son of Bonnie and Kim Wells of Lawrence, Kan. Judge J. Paul Oetken of the Federal District Court in New York officiated with permission from Vermont.

title: Ayla Pamuku, Andrew Leslie
description: Ayla Susan Pamuku, the daughter of Lisa E. Brown and Dr. Rifat Pamuku of Spring House, Pa., is to be married there Sunday to Andrew Burgess Leslie, a son of Marsha Kay Leslie and Dr. Bruce W. Leslie of Petersburg, W. Va. The couple will be joined under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute at the home of the brides parents.

title: Hunter Armstrong and Jay Meisel
description: Hunter Franklin Armstrong and Jay Desider Meisel are to be married Sunday at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan, an Episcopal priest, will officiate.

title: Kelly OConnor, Walter ODonnell
description: Kelly Marie OConnor and Lt. j.g. Walter Edward ODonnell were married Saturday by the Rev. Robert Schlageter, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. John Neumann Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Aditi Prabhu and Brian Wong
description: Aditi Ashok Prabhu, the daughter of Vimala A. Prabhu and Ashok N. Prabhu of East Windsor, N.J., was married Saturday to Brian James Wong, the son of Doris Yim-Lin Wong and Alfred Sik-Kin Wong of Chantilly, Va. Pandit Srinivas Bhattar, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Westin Hotel at Forrestal Village shopping center in Princeton, N.J.

title: Abra Lyons-Warren, Jonathan Fischer
description: Abra Elysia Lyons-Warren and Jonathan Lewis Fischer are to be married Sunday in St. Louis. Rabbi Mark J. Fasman will officiate at the Contemporary Art Museum.

title: Tamar Raviv, Jonathan Reiner
description: Tamar Lauren Raviv and Jonathan Seth Reiner are to be married Sunday evening at the Green Brook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J., by Rabbi Joshua Goldstein, with Rabbi Paul Plotkin participating.

title: Jaclyn Buzgo, Michael Filanowski
description: Jaclyn Christie Buzgo and Maj. Michael Elliot Filanowski are to be married Sunday at St. Lawrence Roman Catholic Church in Shelton, Conn. The Rev. Michael K. Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, will perform the ceremony.

title: Stacy Sadove, Richard Zbeda
description: Stacy Miriam Sadove, a daughter of Sandra Rozenberg Sadove of Bedford, N.Y., and Stephen I. Sadove of Purchase, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Richard Sason Zbeda, a son of Ety and George Zbeda of New York. Rabbi S. Martin Rozenberg, who is the brides maternal grandfather, officiated at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Anna Marie Wagner and Robert Sinnott
description: Anna Marie Updike Wagner, the daughter of Katherine L. Updike and Robert E. Wagner of El Paso, was married there Saturday to Robert Wyatt McCallum Sinnott, the son of Mary Faye Harned Sinnott and John Sinnott III of Barrington, Ill. The Rev. Charles D. Drew, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the groom, performed a nondenominational ceremony at St. Francis on the Hill Episcopal Church.

title: Emily Winograd, Alex Leonard
description: Emily Rose Winograd, a daughter of Sandra Slaton Winograd and Dr. Mark Winograd of Paradise Valley, Ariz., was married Saturday evening to Alex Gregory Leonard, a son of Dr. Debra A. Spicehandler and Dr. Daniel A. Leonard of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Maynard Bell officiated at the Montelucia Resort and Spa in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Sibyl Fenwick, Wixon Greenwood
description: Sibyl Stevens Fenwick and Wixon Adler Greenwood were married Saturday at the home of the brides uncle, Peter S.H. Grubstein, in Montecito, Calif. The Rev. Richard B. Tobin, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Cicily Daniels and Brett Macias
description: Cicily Daniels and Brett Macias were married Saturday at the Bolger Center, an event venue in Potomac, Md. The Rev. William D. Fields Jr., a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Seeing Yogi Bear Was No Boo-Boo
description: Frances Belzer Reid and Gary David Bixhorn were married Saturday evening at Hempstead House in the Sands Point Preserve in Port Washington, N.Y. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated.

title: Knicks, Without Anthony, Struggle in Preseason Loss to Celtics
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Carmelo Anthony interrupted an otherwise uneventful trip to New England by disclosing that he had taken a huge risk by opting against off-season surgery on his left shoulder.

title: Tigers Lose No-Hit Bid but Not Game
description: BOSTON  Anibal Sanchez was once a prospect blazing a path toward Fenway Park, toward postseason glory, toward the spoils that eventually went to Jon Lester, his teammate in 2005 on the Class AA Portland Sea Dogs, a Red Sox affiliate.

title: Having Starters Can Finish Off an Opponent
description: BOSTON  The prevailing theory before the American League Championship Series was that the Boston Red Sox approach at the plate could wear down the Detroit Tigers starters and force them to use their vulnerable bullpen. That is exactly what happened in Game 1.

title: Hotel Relax by the Runway
description: Hotel Relax by the Runway

title: Spending Dispute Leaves a Senate Deal Elusive
description: WASHINGTON  With a possible default on government obligations just days away, Senate Democratic leaders  believing they have a political advantage in the continuing fiscal impasse  refused Sunday to sign on to any deal that reopens the government but locks in budget cuts for next year.

title: Quick Evacuation Efforts Help India Minimize Deaths From Cyclone
description: NEW DELHI  The powerful cyclone that struck Indias eastern coast this weekend washed away thousands of mud homes, knocked down power lines, blocked many of the regions roads and damaged crops and fishing boats. But reports from the region on Sunday showed the success of one of the biggest and most rapid evacuations in Indias history, an operation that moved more than 800,000 people to safety.

title: Flim Flam Forever
description: Aha. Paul Ryan, the Serious, Honest Conservative (the media myth)  as opposed to Paul Ryan the unserious, dishonest partisan (always the reality)  made a brief reappearance over the past couple of days. Needless to say, his initiative was completely useless, and the debt talks were in breakdown.

title: Wage Flexibility in Doctrine and Policy (Wonkish)
description: I probably should have made clear in my post on sticky wages that I was arguing for stickiness as a central issue in the history of macroeconomic thought, not as a central issue in current policy. Ive been arguing for years that when youre in a liquidity trap wage flexibility actually hurts rather than helps; this is the paradox of flexibility, which arises, roughly speaking, because under current conditions the aggregate demand curve is upward-sloping thanks to debt and balance sheet effects.

title: U.S. impasse threatens to roil Asian economies
description: The U.S. shutdown battle is heading straight for Asia.

title: From One Child to Two
description: The first time I told my mother I was pregnant, she shrieked with glee. She had been praying for the arrival of her first grandchild since my wedding.

title: The Life of a Newspaper
description: This is the last time you will be reading The International Herald Tribune; as oftomorrow, it is The International New York Times. But weep not:

title: Ingmar Bergman and His Unfinished Business
description: Alan Ridings article from May 2, 1995.

title: The Interview | Ingmar Bergman
description: With Ingmar Bergman, Listen to the Silences

title: Are Hotels the New Handbags?
description: Suzy Menkess article from Mar. 3, 2002.

title: The Trends | Gucci and Prada
description: When Fashion Designers Moved Far Beyond Clothes

title: Death of a Jazzman: Last Notes on Chet Bakers Final Days
description: Mike Zwerins article from May 23, 1988.

title: The Talent | Chet Baker
description: Finding Meaning in a Trumpeters Jagged Life and Death

title: The Tastemakers
description: Patricia Wellss column from Oct. 17, 1994.

title: In Pursuit of the Worlds Finest Restaurants
description: In Pursuit of the Worlds Finest Restaurants

title: Buchwald Attends Wedding at Kelly Familys Invitation
description: Published on April 20, 1956

title: Why Do They Dislike Americans?
description: Published on August 19, 1957

title: Paris After Dark: The Life and Times of the Escargot
description: Published on October 20, 1950

title: Europes Lighter Side: Tax Deductions Made Easy
description: Published on July 3, 1954

title: Asias Lands of Charm and Cruelty
description: BANGKOK  Not long after landing in New Delhi for a two-month motorcycle trip across India, I was given some specific advice.

title: On Smaller Stage, Broadway Stars Show Appreciation for Stagehands
description: Katie OToole, a cast member of Jersey Boys, walked onstage on a recent Saturday night and wowed the audience with a sultry rendition of Lesley Gores 1964 hit song You Dont Own Me.

title: Disruptions: Bit by Bit, Virtual Reality Heads for the Holodeck
description: While sitting in a stuffy Hollywood hotel conference room recently, I plotted my next move outside a snow-covered, ancient castle. I raised an arm to block the falling snow as I peered up. As I looked from side to side, white drifts extended into the distance.

title: How the Cartoonists Called It
description: A selection of editorial cartoons from the Views pages of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Tunnel Found From Gaza Into Israel, Military Says
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military announced on Sunday that it had discovered a tunnel leading from Gaza into Israel that it said could have been used for an attack against Israeli soldiers or civilians.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (AMC) THE WALKING DEAD Season 4 of this zombie-apocalypse series finds Rick (Andrew Lincoln, above) and his band of heroes settled into prison, where Hershel (Scott Wilson) provides farming lessons; a decision-making council sets rules for the growing population; meals are cooked in a communal kitchen; children are going to school; and new romances are blossoming  though not all will survive. The challenge with any extended zombie narrative is striking the right balance between gut-munching action and undergraduate philosophy seminar, and the first two episodes this season are pretty talky, Mike Hale wrote about this latest round in The New York Times. Of course, he added, The Walking Dead has become one of the most popular shows on television by consistently getting the balance right. In Talking Dead, at 10, Chris Hardwick, the shows host, discusses the evenings Walking Dead episode with Nathan Fillion. And in Comic Book Men, at midnight, Lou Ferrigno visits the filmmaker Kevin Smiths New Jersey comic-book store, Jay and Silent Bobs Secret Stash.

title: American Soldier Is Shot and Killed by Attacker in Afghan Uniform
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American soldier was killed Sunday afternoon when a man wearing an Afghan security force uniform opened fire on a group of foreign trainers in eastern Afghanistan, officials with the international military coalition said. It was the third such attack in less than a month.

title: Suspect in Custody in Baby Hope Case
description: After two decades, the New York police arrested a cousin, Conrado Juarez, in the cold case of a girl whose body was found in a cooler beside a highway in 1991.

title: Op-Ed and You
description: I often go out and talk to people who are interested in getting Op-Eds published in The Times. I do it because we need you, the reader, the writer. People certainly dont write for us for the money; the payment, frankly, is peanuts. They write for the influence, for the chance to reach an audience, to say something thats been bothering them, driving them crazy, something that no one else seems to be saying.

title: In Washington State, Home of Highest Minimum Wage, a City Aims Higher
description: SEATAC, Wash.  Washington already has the highest state minimum wage in the country, at $9.19 an hour. Soon, voters in this tiny city south of Seattle will decide whether to push the local minimum even higher.

title: Whats Your Favorite Punk Film?
description: CBGB, a fiction feature on the legendary club where so many punk bands got their start, hit theaters this weekend. A.O. Scott had this to say about the film. Whether you agree with him or not, one thing is certain: its hard to get punk right on film. Last week, Marc Spitz surveyed a few people who know a thing or two about punk, and they offered their own ideas about the ultimate punk movie. Their candidates included:

title: World Leaders Press the U.S. on Fiscal Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders at World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings on Sunday pleaded, warned and cajoled: the United States must raise its debt ceiling and reopen its government or risk massive disruption the world over, as Christine Lagarde, the funds managing director, put it.

title: Gravity Still the Heavyweight to Beat at the Box Office
description: Near-perfect reviews helped Captain Phillips sail to very solid ticket sales over the weekend, but the pirate thriller still got a bit lost in the wake of the phenomenon that is Gravity, which continued to perform at summer levels. Gravity (Warner Brothers) repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America, taking in an estimated $44.3 million, for an astounding two-week total of $123.4 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box office data. Imax ticket sales for the 3-D space drama, which stars Sandra Bullock as a stranded astronaut and was backed by a flawlessly executed marketing campaign, have been particularly strong.

title: Europes Lighter Side: For Whom the Bloody Marys Toll
description: Published on August 5, 1953

title: American Held in Egypt Killed Himself, Officials Say
description: CAIRO  An American citizen who had been detained by the Egyptian authorities for more than six weeks was found dead in a police station on Sunday in what some American officials said appeared to be a suicide.

title: Dozens of Pilgrims Die in Stampede on Bridge in India
description: NEW DELHI  Thousands of pilgrims in northern India panicked on Sunday when they thought the narrow bridge they were crossing was collapsing, Indian officials said. The resulting stampede left at least 89 people dead and about a hundred more injured.

title: They Have No Idea
description: At the end of todays This Week, Peggy Noonan said something to the effect that Republicans, for all their turmoil, are brimming with new ideas, while Democrats arent. And then time was up. Which was too bad, because I really wanted to ask, what new ideas are you talking about?

title: Steve Bartman Remains Invisible, 10 Years Later
description: CHICAGO  Steve Bartman sat in the first row down the left-field line for Game 6 of the National League Championship Series between the Chicago Cubs and the Florida Marlins at Wrigley Field on Oct. 14, 2003. He wore a green turtleneck and had headphones over his Cubs cap. By the end of the night, he was the most infamous fan, perhaps, in the history of American sports.

title: Group Presses for Safeguards on the Personal Data of Schoolchildren
description: A leading childrens advocacy group is challenging the educational technology software industry, an estimated $8 billion market, to develop national safeguards for the personal data collected about students from kindergarten through high school.

title: Google Jousts With Wired South Korea Over Quirky Internet Rules
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea is one of the worlds most digitally advanced countries. It has ubiquitous broadband, running at speeds that many Americans can only envy. Its Internet is also one of the most quirky in the world.

title: Oscar Hijuelos, Who Won Pulitzer for Tale of Cuban-American Life, Dies at 62
description: Oscar Hijuelos, a Cuban-American novelist who wrote about the lives of immigrants adapting to a new culture and became the first Latino to win the Pulitzer Prize for fiction for his 1989 book, The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 62.

title: Bombings Kill at Least 34 in Iraq, Mostly in Southern Provinces and Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Attacks across Iraq killed at least 34 people on Sunday, security and medical officials said.

title: Jets Remain Consistently Inconsistent and Fall to the Steelers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets feel disrespected and discounted. They also feel embarrassed and frustrated. Week to week, their mood changes. It changes because they have moonwalked through their first six games, shuffling forward at the same time that they are drifting backward.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: 17th World Computer Championship
description: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, last month, there was a fifth title decided: the 17th World Computer Championship.

title: An Actor Is Revealing in a Role Thats No Act
description: That was not Jack Donaghy of 30 Rock talking to the Democratic candidate for New York mayor, Bill de Blasio, on MSNBC, nor was it the slimy businessman in Blue Jasmine. It wasnt even the daffy salesman from those Capital One credit card ads. (Whats in your wallet?)

title: A Slimmed-Down Newsroom
description: A slimmed down newsroom

title: With Oregons Offense, Even the Lows Are High
description: SEATTLE  Scott Frost became Oregons offensive coordinator before this season. Nice gig, if you can get it, the college football equivalent of a hefty inheritance, when an embarrassment of offense basically falls into ones lap.

title: Shifting Moods, From Brash to Lyrical
description: The only time it was obvious that it was Joshua Weilersteins subscription debut with the New York Philharmonic was at the start of the orchestras concert on Saturday evening, after he had jogged past the players and skipped onto the podium.

title: Contemporary Group Tries a Wagner Foray
description: The idea of the adventurous contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound including a work by Wagner on a program seemed like a vegetarian restaurant featuring a steak tartare appetizer. But on Friday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, the group opened its yearlong residency there with Wagners Siegfried Idyll.

title: Leavening TV Reality With Jolts of Hardship
description: Sometimes television accidentally presents illuminating, dismaying contrasts, and Lifetime and HBO have inadvertently combined to serve up a doozy.

title: Nothing Daring
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Zhouqin Burnikel is rapidly becoming one of my favorite early week constructors. Her puzzles are smooth and enjoyable, just the right way to kick off our solving week.

title: A Singleton Once More, Now at 51 With Kids
description: Bridget Jones, R.I.P. Youre not dead yet, but you might as well be. In Mad About the Boy, Helen Fieldings latest installment in this once-lovable series, there is a page that lists the things that have mattered to Bridget, now 51 and struggling mightily to take an interest in her two young children. They are: her weight, her number of Twitter followers, the number of texts she has exchanged, her difficulties writing a screenplay, a household infestation of lice and a head count of her boyfriends. The only conceivable reason to read about all this is that old habits die hard.

title: A World of Childhood Innocence Intersects With a Grown-Up Reality
description: Its no surprise that Brittens 100th birthday, arriving on Nov. 22, has been overshadowed all year by the two titans of opera, Verdi and Wagner, who turned 200. Even the Metropolitan Opera, which has long been kind to the British master, unveiled gleaming new productions of Verdis Rigoletto and Wagners Parsifal but is celebrating Britten with just a revival: A Midsummer Nights Dream, which opened on Friday evening.

title: Making a Serious Point With Eggshells
description: The Walls and Bridges festival continued on Friday with another round of minilectures  speakers focused on gender identity and female representation  and a performance by the French choreographer Jeanne Mordoj. In the program, held at New York Live Arts, the highlight was La Pome, a dance that drew on Ms. Mordojs circus training to explore the feminine body. By the end, she had morphed into an otherworldly creature, but she had to crack a lot of eggs to get there.

title: Mixing Fairy Dust With Urban Grit
description: Video-game players are the original binge viewers. Long before Netflixs House of Cards and Orange Is the New Black dispensed with the notion that television needed to be rationed and served in single helpings once a week, video games allowed their gluttonous players to feast at an array of all-you-can-eat buffets.

title: Dancing to His Tune, After the Music Stops
description: One obvious idea behind Walls and Bridges, a French-American festival now running in New York, has to do with making connections  or building bridges  between ideas and art. On Thursday at New York Live Arts, the topic was the link between music and the body. As the writer and documentary filmmaker Elena Mannes, one of the evenings speakers, said, Scientists believe that we came into the world prepared to respond to music.

title: Keeping It Real in a Time of Tumult
description: You may not remember the mid-2000s, so heres a quick refresher. It was the dawn of the rap Internet as it looks now: the one that led to stars like Drake; the one that, thanks to ease of access, started to sustain global fan bases for even the most regional rap heroes.

title: The Gangs All There, Talking Art in Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar  The art-world equivalent of McDonalds golden arches, Damien Hirsts candy-colored spots, now covering the exterior of the exhibition space Al Riwaq, glaringly mark this Persian Gulf city as a player in the increasingly branded art world. And the exhibition inside, which includes all the touch points in the career of Mr. Hirst, 48, is just one of a constellation of openings organized to attract a whos who in the art world (or at least a whos afraid of being left out).

title: Playing Cat and Mouse With Searing History
description: LOS ANGELES  What lessons do we learn from Anne Frank? Since her diary is the chronicle of an education, we learn what she learns: the lessons of daily life and early adolescence, acquired during a horrific time. We watch a meticulously observant girl, age 13, evolve into a self-consciously observant young woman, age 15. We watch  as one of Philip Roths characters pungently remarked  a fetus growing a face.

title: Well, One Thing Led to Another and Eventually to Beckett
description: Its one thing to see plays by Samuel Beckett with their intimations of mortality; its quite another to see a 77-year-old performing in them. Lelia Goldoni, a dancer and actor who appeared in John Cassavetess seminal 1959 independent film, Shadows, attended the Hoi Polloi theater troupes 2011 adaptation of that film and struck up a working relationship with the companys artistic director, Alec Duffy. The result of their creative pairing is Beckett Solos, a program of three short plays, two of which Beckett wrote for his longtime muse Billie Whitelaw. Its a splendid convergence of actor, director and playwright.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 14
description: EUROPEAN CURRENCY The Eurogroup of finance ministers from the 17-member euro currency union will meet Monday in Luxembourg. On Tuesday, the ministers will be joined by their counterparts from the other 11 members of the European Union that do not use the euro. Compared with such meetings in the recent past, there is no crisis to address. But the members will be concerned about whether the United States can avoid a credit default, the repercussions of which could upset Europes incipient economic recovery.

title: Male Lead Drops Out of 50 Shades of Grey
description: Fifty Shades of Grey is in search of a new male lead. The British actor Charlie Hunnam has dropped out of the film adaptation of E. L. Jamess best-selling novel because of a scheduling conflict, according to a statement by Universal Pictures. Mr. Hunnam was cast as the wealthy entrepreneur Christian Grey in September alongside the actress Dakota Johnson, who is to play Anastasia Steele.

title: Names, Names, Names. News, News, News.
description: On October 4, 1887, James Gordon Bennett Jr., an affluent and autocratic American, launched The New York Heralds European edition in Paris.

title: Arrest in Attacks on Power Grid
description: The federal authorities arrested an Arkansas man over the weekend in connection with a series of attacks on the power grid east of Little Rock.

title: Turning the Page  The International Herald Tribune
description: The International Herald Tribune, the global edition of The New York Times, has become The International New York Times. A look at its journey.

title: Stars of David to Return in Concert Form
description: A new production of Stars of David, which transforms interviews with Jewish figures like Gloria Steinem, Aaron Sorkin and Joan Rivers into songs, will begin a five-week New York run next month at the DR2 Theater, the producers announced Sunday. Based on Abigail Pogrebins 2005 book Stars of David: Prominent Jews Talk About Being Jewish  and directed by Gordon Greenberg (Working), the Off Broadway production will be different from the world premiere engagement presented by the Philadelphia Theater Company at the Suzanne Roberts Theater last year. Instead of a musical, it will be a concert presentation.

title: Royal Opera House Plans Simulcasts in U.S.
description: The Royal Opera House in London has announced that part of its lineup from the 2013-14 season will be simulcast for the first time in more than 500 movie theaters in the United States. The series begins with Puccinis Turandot on Oct. 24 and 27. The other works scheduled for 2013 are Puccinis Tosca on Nov. 7 and 10 and Verdis Vpres Siciliennes on Dec. 5 and 8. Also planned are Wagners Parisfal (Jan. 9 and 12); Puccinis Bohme (Feb. 6 and 9) and Manon Lescaut (July 17 and 20); Mozarts Don Giovanni (March 13 and 16); Verdis Nabucco (April 3 and 6) and La Traviata (May 8 and 11). Tickets are at screenvision.com/roh.

title: What Do We Owe the Future?
description: SAN SEBASTIN, Spain

title: Iran to Offer Proposal and Speak of Peaceful Aims at Nuclear Talks in Geneva
description: TEHRAN  Iranian nuclear negotiators will offer a new proposal on Tuesday that is intended to persuade world powers that the countrys nuclear program has only peaceful aims, a top official said on Sunday.

title: Philadelphia Newspapers Owners at War
description: When a group of wealthy, politically connected local businessmen bought The Philadelphia Inquirer in April 2012, there were concerns that they would use its influence to further their own interests, ruining what was left of a once remarkable American newspaper.

title: Gov. Brown of California Vetoes Biotech Drug Bill
description: LOS ANGELES  The first year of skirmishes in state legislatures over bills that would govern the use of cheaper versions of expensive biotechnology drugs is nearly over. Health insurers and generic drug companies have prevailed in most states over brand-name pharmaceutical companies.

title: For a Master of Sound, the Beat Goes On
description: Akili Walker made a living controlling sound. An Oz of audio, he could tweak a song working behind a huge mixing board in a recording studio for perfectionists like Prince, or get 30,000 people at an LL Cool J concert to throw their hands in the air. He worked hard and partied even harder.

title: After Downtown Fire, a Historic South Carolina City Ponders Its Next Steps
description: GEORGETOWN, S.C.  John Witzl Walters is not entirely sure how he survived the fire last month that gutted seven waterfront commercial buildings and destroyed the painting studio and apartment he rented above a 140-year-old store on Georgetowns Front Street.

title: Prompted by Injury, a League Will Review Rules on Fighting
description: The commissioner of a junior hockey league said he would review its rules governing fights after a player had a seizure and was hospitalized following a fight Saturday.

title: Setting Pace, Ireland Predicts December Exit From Bailout
description: LONDON  Declaring the imminent end of an economic emergency, Prime Minister Enda Kenny predicted over the weekend that Ireland would emerge from an international bailout program in December, the latest sign that the euro debt crisis may be past its bleakest phase.

title: Pulling Aid Away, Shutdown Deepens Indians Distress
description: CROW AGENCY, Mont.  Worlds away from Washington, Audrey Costa wondered aloud about keeping her family warm. A mother of three, she relies on lease payments from the Bureau of Indian Affairs on land owned by her family, which can run up to a few hundred dollars a year, to pay for food and electricity. But since the partial shutdown of the federal government began on Oct. 1, Ms. Costa, 41, has not received a check.

title: Bolstering a Phones Defenses Against Breaches
description: SAN FRANCISCO  From Lookouts headquarters here, the view extends west from the Bay Bridge to the Golden Gate, but its employees  mostly 20-something engineers in T-shirts and jeans  seem too preoccupied with the worlds nastiest new threats to take it in.

title: Tigers Find a Place on the Field for Peralta, and His Bat Answers Questions
description: BOSTON  A skinny ladder dangles about halfway down the Green Monster in left field at Fenway Park, looking like a thin teardrop streaking along the walls blank face. It is a subtle strip on the 231-foot-wide expanse, and Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland hopes it remains a nonfactor during the American League Championship Series here.

title: P.R. Agency Begins a Push to Modernize
description: ANOTHER public relations giant is reassessing how it presents itself to current and potential clients and employees, in an effort that reflects how all types of agencies are rethinking their offerings to keep up with the continuous changes in technology and consumer behavior.

title: Jets Close-Up
description: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Heath Miller emerged as a vital element of the Steelers passing game Sunday, in large part because the Jets could not figure out how to stop him. Miller caught six passes for 84 yards, and three of his receptions  including a 31-yarder on second-and-18  went for first downs.

title: Viral Content With a Liberal Bent
description: There is conventional wisdom about what kind of material will go viral on the Internet: celebrity slide shows, lists like 10 tips for losing belly fat, and quirky kitten antics.

title: Statue of Liberty Reopens as Other Sites Stay Closed
description: Some tourists said they had held out hope that the federal government would get its act together in time. Others admitted they had all but given up. After traveling to New York City from far-flung places, they feared they would be resigned to squinting from afar at one of its most famous landmarks.

title: Looser Rules on Illegal Housing Sought
description: Rakha and Mahbub Sarkar spent more than $4,000 upgrading the cellar apartment of their Queens home. They put in new floors and kitchen cabinets, and in the boroughs tight market for rentals under $1,000 a month, they had no problem finding new tenants.

title: Fall TV Season Delivers a Mixed Bag in Prime Time
description: Three weeks into the new television season, network executives have drawn some initial conclusions.

title: Bostons Only Option: Exploiting Bullpen
description: BOSTON  The Boston Red Sox did what they had to do on Sunday, the only way they could have done it. They evened the American League Championship Series with a 6-5 comeback victory over the Detroit Tigers bullpen. They cannot solve the Tigers rotation.

title: Out of Ammunition at Sulphur Springs
description: A lone Union cavalryman sped away from the front lines through the Virginia countryside towards Warrenton on the afternoon of Oct. 12, 1863. He soon encountered federal provost guards, who ordered him to halt. The cavalryman relayed an urgent request: He and his fellow troopers had come under heavy attack by the enemy and, low on ammunition, they needed help immediately.

title: Purple Boots, Silver Stars ... and White Parents
description: WHEN I wear my cap backwards, dont copy me, our 8-year-old son says to his 7-year-old sister. O.K., she answers, I will put it on sideways.

title: The Dixiecrat Solution
description: So you have this neighbor who has been making your life hell. First he tied you up with a spurious lawsuit; youre both suffering from huge legal bills. Then he threatened bodily harm to your family. Now, however, he says hes willing to compromise: Hell call off the lawsuit, which is to his advantage as well as yours. But in return you must give him your car. Oh, and hell stop threatening your family  but only for a week, after which the threats will resume.

title: The Bay of Bengal, in Peril From Climate Change
description: LONDON  NEARLY one in four people on earth live in the countries that border the Bay of Bengal. The region is strategically vital to Asias rising powers. Its low-lying littoral  including coastal regions of eastern India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, Malaysia and Sumatra  is home to over half a billion people who are now acutely vulnerable to rising sea levels. Storms are a constant threat; over the weekend, a cyclone, Phailin, swept in from the bay to strike the coastal Indian state of Odisha, leading to the evacuation of some 800,000 people.

title: Inequality Is a Choice
description: Its well known by now that income and wealth inequality in most rich countries, especially the United States, have soared in recent decades and, tragically, worsened even more since the Great Recession. But what about the rest of the world? Is the gap between countries narrowing, as rising economic powers like China and India have lifted hundreds of millions of people from poverty? And within poor and middle-income countries, is inequality getting worse or better? Are we moving toward a more fair world, or a more unjust one?

title: Surveillance Cameras in Downtown Oakland
description: Locations for the 272 surveillance cameras on the streets of downtown Oakland.

title: Privacy Fears Grow as Cities Increase Surveillance
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Federal grants of $7 million awarded to this city were meant largely to help thwart terror attacks at its bustling port. But instead, the money is going to a police initiative that will collect and analyze reams of surveillance data from around town  from gunshot-detection sensors in the barrios of East Oakland to license plate readers mounted on police cars patrolling the citys upscale hills.

title: VandeHei, Politico Editor, Is Made Chief Executive
description: Jim VandeHei, a co-founder of Politico who recently took charge of its new sibling Web site Capital New York, has a new title that is highly unusual for a journalist: chief executive.

title: Will New Yorks Political Watchdog Pass the Test?
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo had the right idea when he formed a commission to help end the scandal epidemic in New York State. He appointed a respected group of experts, asked them to come up with ways to cut the sleaze, promised them independence and asked for a preliminary report by Dec. 1. As that deadline nears, however, there is growing concern that the Commission to Investigate Public Corruption, also known as the Moreland Commission, could become little more than a branch of the governors political network. If so, it will be another Potemkin committee, issuing another report.

title: False Equality in Michigan
description: Can a states citizens amend the state constitution to ban affirmative action programs in public universities, even if the Supreme Court has approved those programs? That is the question the court is facing this week in the case of Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action.

title: Hope for a Malaria Vaccine
description: The most ambitious clinical trial of a malaria vaccine has shown some effectiveness in children over an 18-month period. While its efficacy is modest, it is nonetheless a significant advance in the long struggle to control a disease that kills some 600,000 people a year, mostly children under the age of 5.

title: Shortchanging Kansas Schoolchildren
description: The underfunding of Kansas public schools has been a long-running problem made worse by both parties in budget pinches over the years. But the schools fiscal agony took a precipitous turn last year when statehouse Republicans decided that an encouraging postrecession increase in revenues was the perfect moment for a huge tax cut, rather than for the overdue restoration of school aid to levels mandated under the State Constitution.

title: Broncos Beat Jaguars but Not the Spread
description: DENVER  In the end, just as had been the case all week, it was never a question of whether the undefeated Denver Broncos would beat the winless Jacksonville Jaguars on Sunday, but rather a more intriguing calculation: by how much would they win?

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Chuck Smith, Minister Who Preached to Flower Children, Dies at 86
description: The Rev. Chuck Smith, a Southern California minister who shepherded flower children and rock n roll into the conservative wing of the evangelical movement while building a religious organization that grew to encompass 700 congregations and hundreds of radio stations, died on Oct. 3 at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 86.

title: Lottery Numbers
When the Davis Cup Came in From the Cold
description: Rain pelting its windows, an Air France jet arrived in Bucharest, Romania, in early October 1972. Two dozen men waited below. They wore leather jackets and shouldered machine guns, and some had knives strapped to their ankles.

title: Global Finance Leaders Look at a Shift in Rates of Growth
description: WASHINGTON  Short-term concerns once again dominated talks at the World Bank and International Monetary Funds annual meetings, this time over the fiscal impasse in the United States. But with hopes high that Congress would end the standoff in the coming days, leaders also negotiated the longer-term issue of how the world should prepare for an economic rebalancing, with growth in rich economies speeding up and growth in middle-income economies slowing down.

title: Obamacare: The Rest of the Story
description: Unless youve been bamboozled by the frantic fictions of the right wing, you know that the Affordable Care Act, familiarly known as Obamacare, has begun to accomplish its first goal: enrolling millions of uninsured Americans, many of whom have been living one medical emergency away from the poorhouse. You realize those computer failures that have hampered sign-ups in the early days  to the smug delight of the critics  confirm that there is enormous popular demand. You have probably figured out that the real mission of the Republican extortionists and their big-money backers was to scuttle the law before most Americans recognized it as a godsend and rendered it politically untouchable.

title: As Police Chased Leads About Baby Hope, Those Who Knew Her Kept Quiet
description: Before she came to be known as Baby Hope, Anjelica Castillo lived with seven people in the Queens apartment where she was killed. None of them spoke up when she vanished one summer day.

title: From His Fathers Decline, de Blasio Learned What Not to Do
description: For a few fleeting years, Bill de Blasio had, in his words, a classic American family life with his father. He went with him to Little League and Boston Red Sox games, watched him grill steaks on the barbecue, joined him on evening rowboat rides.

title: Patients Mired in Costly Credit From Doctors
description: The dentist set to work, tapping and probing, then put down his tools and delivered the news. His patient, Patricia Gannon, needed a partial denture. The cost: more than $5,700.

title: Free Speech, and Counseling to Convert Gay Youths
description: To the Editor:

title: Head Scarves in Turkey
Is Fido a Person Under the Fur?
Changing Doctors Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: School Fund-Raising
description: To the Editor:

title: In Rare Cease-Fire, Hundreds Evacuate Rebel-Held Syrian Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hundreds of people were allowed to leave a besieged, rebel-held suburb of Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Sunday in a rare cease-fire, according to the government and its opponents. But aid workers said they were still unable to enter the town, Moadhamiyeh, which international organizations have been trying to reach for months and where six people have reportedly died of malnutrition.

title: A Leaner Times Aims for Global Growth
description: While some newspaper companies have spent recent years shifting their emphasis to other types of investments like television, The New York Times Company has taken a different path. It has been selling off its peripheral assets and concentrating on its flagship newspaper and Web site.

title: Is the G.O.P. Giving Independents an Opening?
A Russian Original With Irish Spin
description: The Russian gentry, fretting and fuming at a country estate in the late 19th century, have been transformed into Anglo-Irish aristocrats of the same period, feeling the ground beneath them shifting unsettlingly, in the Irish writer Thomas Kilroys stylish adaptation of The Seagull, Chekhovs play about misfired loves and misbegotten lives.

title: Legal Bills Rising, Cohen Is Said to Plan Art Sales
description: In recent months, as his legal troubles have deepened, the billionaire hedge-fund manager Steven A. Cohen has sold stocks to meet withdrawal requests from skittish investors.

title: Bankruptcy for Ailing Detroit, but Prosperity for Its Teams
description: DETROIT  In this bankrupt city where even keeping the streetlights on has proved a struggle, one industry has continued humming along at a multibillion-dollar clip: professional sports.

title: In Indias Politics, Jail Time Is a Badge of Honor
description: DALTENGANJ, India  When he decided to run for a parliamentary seat from this impoverished, and mainly low-caste constituency in northeast India, Kameshwar Baitha made no effort to sugarcoat his criminal record.

title: In Syria, Motorists Press on, Yielding for War
description: NORTH OF DAMASCUS, Syria  Along the road that winds over Mount Qasioun on the way out of Damascus, concrete archways lead to gated military bases, and sentry posts perch atop the slopes and rises of the dry, scrabbly hills. From behind sand berms at army checkpoints, tanks point their heavy guns into traffic.

title: Popular Demand
description: Once you get past the staggering success of Amazon.com as an online shopping destination, what stands out is how many people visit their favorite stores from a computer along with their smartphone or tablet.

title: Jets Replay: Week 6
description: Action from the Jets 19-6 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers at MetLife Stadium that dropped the Jets to 3-3.

title: Content With Their City, but Warming to Candidate Who Is Pledging Change
description: Paula Rossetti finally found work after 14 months of not having it, so she celebrated the best way she knew how  dinner out with four of her best girlfriends. They went to Joe Abbracciamento Restaurant, a home away from home fronted by a cursive neon sign and an old marquee in the heart of Rego Park, Queens.

title: Suit Could Determine Protections for Police Department Whistle-Blowers
description: When Officer Craig Matthews complained to his precinct commander about a quota system that he believed was resulting in illegal street stops and arrests, it did not take long, he said, for him to see a response: he was given undesirable assignments, a mediocre performance review and the cold shoulder from his immediate supervisors.

title: To Ousted Boss, Arms Watchdog Was Seen as an Obstacle in Iraq
description: PARIS  More than a decade before the international agency that monitors chemical weapons won the Nobel Peace Prize, John R. Bolton marched into the office of its boss to inform him that he would be fired.

title: Sale of a Landmark Building Reflects the Changing Needs of Lower Manhattan
description: With Lower Manhattan in a deep slump during the 1950s, David Rockefeller made a pivotal but risky decision to build a massive new headquarters, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, in the heart of the citys historic financial district.

title: Dodgers Place Their Hopes on Puigs Shaky Shoulders
description: LOS ANGELES  In his brief, mercurial career, Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder Yasiel Puig has handled any obstacle thrown in front of him in much the same manner. If he is on the bases, he will try harder to run home. If he is in the field, he will throw the ball farther. If he is at the plate, he will swing with more might.

title: After 187 Attempts and No Wins on the PGA Tour, a Golfer Finally Has His Day
description: SAN MARTIN, Calif.  Jimmy Walker, a slow cooker in a microwave sport, required 13 years of seasoning before his game was ready to be celebrated. Winless in his first 187 PGA Tour starts, Walker rallied on Sunday for a victory worth savoring, finishing two strokes ahead of the Hall of Famer Vijay Singh at the Frys.com Open at CordeValle Golf Club.

title: Regular Bedtimes Tied to Better Behavior
description: A regular bedtime schedule is unquestionably helpful for parents, but a new study has found it that it may be even more beneficial for their children.

title: Envy, Scorn and Shutdown
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: The Tests That Babies Need
description: Fifty years ago, a revolution began in neonatal care that has preserved the physical and mental health, and often the lives, of thousands of babies: screening of newborns for inherited and congenital disorders.

title: Photo Replay: Oct.  7-13
description: The intensity of competition is written on athletes game faces.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) 56 UP (2013) In 1964, the director Michael Apted interviewed 14 British 7-year-olds for a television documentary, returning to film the same children every seven years as they progressed into adulthood. This latest installment finds the subjects, like Tony, left, settling into middle age. As in the earlier movies, Mr. Apted again folds in older material from the ages of 7, 14 and so on, to set the scene and jog memories, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The abrupt juxtapositions of epochs can be jarring, unnerving or touching  sometimes all three  as bright-faced children bloom and sometimes fade within seconds. An analogous project in print or even still photographs wouldnt be as powerful, because what gives the Up series its punch is not so much its longevity or the human spectacle it offers, but that these are moving images of touchingly vibrant lives at certain moments in time and space. The more you watch, the more the movies transform from mirrors into memory machines, ones that inevitably summon reflections of your own life.
