description: KIROV, Russia  An appellate judge on Wednesday suspended a five-year sentence handed down over the summer to Aleksei A. Navalny, the anticorruption crusader and blogger whose role as Russias leading opposition politician was highlighted by an unexpectedly strong showing in Moscows mayoral election last month.

title: To Be a Syrian Refugee in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Of the two million Syrians who have fled the conflict in their country, 200,000 to 300,000 have ended up in Egypt. They were welcome at first, but lately they have become scapegoats in Egypts latest political crisis, accused of being allies of the ousted Muslim Brotherhood.

title: New York Today: Unwanted Vacation
description: Updated 12:13 p.m. | How do you spend an unscheduled and possibly unpaid autumn break?

title: Slim Gain in Car Sales Leads to Optimism, and Skepticism, in Europe
description: FRANKFURT  Europe suffered another month of dismal car sales in September. But the numbers were a little less grim than a year ago, nurturing hopes that the market had finally hit bottom. And a sales rebound in Spain showed the effects of a United States-style cash for clunkers government stimulus program.

title: Debt Ceiling Deadline Clear, but Implications Are Not
description: WASHINGTON  Ask officials at the White House to pinpoint the debt ceiling deadline and they will give you a fairly precise answer: Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Sharp Rise in Revenue for Twitter
description: As Twitter prepares to hit the road to begin peddling its stock to the public, the company disclosed new revenue numbers on Tuesday that may help it persuade investors to buy the shares, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report.

title: Merkel Lists Policy Goals, as Coalition Options Narrow
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel laid out her priorities on Wednesday for the next German government, as her options for a coalition partner to form that new government narrowed to one: her partys main rival, the center-left Social Democrats.

title: Death Toll in Philippines Earthquake Rises to 144
description: MANILA  The death toll from a powerful earthquake that shook the Philippines rose to 144 on Wednesday, with nearly 300 people injured in the quake, which caused widespread damage and smashed one of the countrys oldest churches, officials said.

title: The Faces of Statehood Supporters in Indias Northeast
description: It was late July, and the monsoons had finally arrived in Delhi. The month of July had been particularly good for me: my work from the northeast was finally getting some recognition and I had been awarded a prestigious global grant to continue my project on ethnic conflict related displacement in western Assam, India.

title: Irelands Government Says It Will Curb a Tax Strategy That Faced U.S. Scrutiny
description: LONDON  Irelands government on Tuesday promised to clamp down on a controversial tax strategy used by multinational corporations, but it was unclear what effect the move would have on Apple, Google and other companies that currently use the maneuver.

title: Cinema Heavyweights Open German Film Festival
description: Last Sunday, in a movie theater in central Beijing, a reunion took place of three men who had made possible one of the defining works of Chinese cinema.

title: T FALL DESIGN
description: If you cant find a design book that interests you this fall, you have only yourself to blame.

title: The Elusive British Artist Banksy Joins the Social Web
description: If you live in New York City, be sure to smile as you wander the streets during the month of October. Theres a good chance youre part of an elaborate art installation by theelusive British artist,Banksy.

title: Despite Loss in Mortgages, Bank of Americas Profit Surges
description: Bank of America on Wednesday reported a sharp rise in third-quarter earnings, but the banks mortgage operations faltered, underscoring that home loans remain a challenging business for the nations banks.

title: Illness and Power
description: EVERYONE knows the president fell, but nobody knows how, or when, or where. There are several theories in circulation about what happened to the Argentine president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner: some say she tripped on the stairway of her plane, others say it was a lumpy rug, and still others say she fainted. People are also split on when it happened: either just before or just after the August primary for the midterm elections, when her party saw its lowest support in a decade.

title: Berkshire Buys 2 Units From Industrial Manufacturing Firm
description: Warren E. Buffett is continuing his shopping spree.

title: Advance Auto Parts to Buy Rival for $2 Billion
description: Advance Auto Parts agreed on Wednesday to buy General Parts International, a privately held parts maker, for $2.04 billion in cash.

description: Sensing a business opportunity in the opaque marketplace of the art world, a fledgling company wants to offer the due diligence services common in corporate America to the buyers and sellers of Picassos, Warhols and Gerard Richters.

title: Today in Small Business: An E-Mail Curfew
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Ubisofts Delay of Watch Dogs Sends Shares Crashing
description: LONDON  A delay in any product can hurt a companys bottom line. But for a video game maker, the pain of delaying a potential blockbuster is even more acute.

title: Glaxo Executive Returns to China
description: HONG KONG  The former general manager of China operations for the pharmaceutical multinational GlaxoSmithKline has returned to China and remains there to help the authorities investigating corruption and bribery allegations, a spokesman for the company said Wednesday.

title: At a Cafe, a Hungry Little Outsider
description: Dear Diary:

title: BlackRocks Profit Rose 14% in Third Quarter
description: The giant money management firm BlackRock is now managing a record $4 trillion after customers put more money into its stock mutual funds and exchange-traded funds.

title: A Fishing Community Recounts Evacuation Experience During Phailin
description: SRIKAKULAM, Andhra Pradesh  When police and government officials came to his village on Friday, begging residents to evacuate before Cyclone Phailin hit, B. Appa said he didnt believe them at first. In fact, almost no one did.

title: Earnings Jump at Bank of America
description: Bank of America reported on Wednesday that third-quarter net income rose to $2.5 billion, or 20 cents a share, from $340 million in the period a year earlier, when the bank was hit by litigation expenses and other charges. Revenue, excluding a financial charge that investors often ignore, fell slightly, to $22.2 billion, from $22.5 billion in the period a year earlier. At the same time, the banks mortgage operations faltered, underscoring that home loans remain a challenging business for the industry. Bank of America is holding a conference call to discuss the results at 8:30 a.m.

title: Bookshelf | Where Design Comes First
description: If you cant find a design book that interests you this fall, you have only yourself to blame.

title: Republicans Back Down, Ending Crisis Over Shutdown and Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans conceded defeat on Wednesday in their bitter budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law as the House and Senate approved last-minute legislation ending a disruptive 16-day government shutdown and extending federal borrowing power to avert a financial default with potentially worldwide economic repercussions.

title: 2 Top Executives Are Ousted at Troubled Brazilian Oil Firm
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Eike Batista, the Brazilian businessman whose empire has fallen on hard times, fired the chief executive and chief legal officer of his petroleum company OGX on Tuesday night.

title: Its Not Easy Being Green
description: For parents, the scariest thing about Halloween is the lurking question: When kids choose their Halloween costumes, are they choosing their alter egos  or revealing their true selves? In two new picture books, Crankenstein, written by Samantha Berger and illustrated by Dan Santat, and Zombelina, by Kristyn Crow with pictures by Molly Idle, kids reallyaremonsters and zombies  and not just onOct. 31.

title: Vanishing Signs
description: Starting in the 1930s, corporations provided mom-and-pop stores with free signage that featured their product brand, but these privilege signs are now nearly extinct.

title: Finalists for National Book Awards Announced
description: The finalists for the National Book Awards were announced on Wednesday, one month before the winners will be named at a ceremony in Manhattan.

title: Tracking Privilege Signs as They Vanish
description: New Yorks ever-changing streetscape usually changes at a pace too slow to be discerned. All appears as it was the day before, until the day comes when you realize how long it has been since youve seen ...

title: A Regulator Cuts New Teeth on JPMorgan in London Whale Case
description: Updated, 8:49 p.m. | Lobbying groups for Wall Streets biggest banks cautioned that a new rule before the nations commodities trading regulator could have myriad unintended adverse consequences. A hedge fund trade group feared that the rule was overly aggressive. And the CME Group, one of the worlds largest futures exchanges, warned that the rule was susceptible to legal action.

title: Investors Cheer Deal to End Shutdown but Worry About Reruns
description: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | While investors were cheered on Wednesday by a last-minute agreement to raise the nations borrowing limit and end the government shutdown, their relief was tempered by the knowledge that the deal was far from a permanent solution. And they were tabulating what the long-term costs of the political turmoil could be.

title: A Web Site That Helps Shoppers Find Brick-and-Mortar Stores
description: Ruchika Kumar has a penchant for shopping at small boutiques. Generally, however, she finds them only randomly  by stumbling upon them or hearing about them from someone else. And that gave Ms. Kumar an idea.

title: The Gun Report: October 16, 2013
description: Last week, we reported that the Second Amendment Foundation and other gun advocacy groups were planning to lay claim to December 14, the one-year anniversary of the Newtown massacre, by organizing Guns Save Lives day,which gun activists hoped would include protests and meet-ups across the country. We are not going to let the gun prohibition lobby own December 14, the Foundationsfounder, Alan Gottlieb, said at the Gun Rights Policy Conference in Houston last month.

title: Former Hungarian Official Charged With War Crimes in 1956 Uprising
description: Prosecutors in Hungary charged a 92-year-old former interior minister on Wednesday with war crimes related to his suppression of civilians during the Hungarian uprising against Soviet rule in 1956.

title: Image of the Day: October 16
A Default Play Appears Too Risky for Hedge Funds
description: At a time when the hedge fund industrys many larger-than-life billionaires would normally be making bold bets, they are largely sitting on the sidelines.

title: After Talks on Irans Nuclear Program, Officials Highlight the Positive
description: GENEVA  Iran and a group of six world powers said Wednesday that they had engaged in substantive and forward-looking discussions on the disputed Iranian nuclear program and that they would meet again in early November.

title: Improving School Lunch by Design
description: What if the secret to getting kids to eat healthier is to stop focusing on food?

title: Sampling New Yorks Musical Buffet
description: After a New Orleans childhood in which he was weaned on jazz, the pianist Jonathan Batiste, now 26, moved to New York City and encountered its eclectic music scene, with clubs featuring rock, hip-hop, even bluegrass and jazz acts, sometimes all in the same night.

title: In a Florence Neighborhood, a Personal Touch
description: In a city like Florence where big-name labels like Gucci and Ferragamo are mainstays for international shoppers, its easy to overlook smaller, homegrown names. A number of these designers can be found in the Santo Spirito neighborhood. Situated in the Oltrarno quarter, south of the Arno River, this residential enclave is a collection of quiet and narrow streets gloriously free of the hordes of tourists that dominate the town center. Mostly housed in elegant Renaissance buildings, the shops especially stand out because many preserve the increasingly hard-to-find tradition of making everything by hand.

title: Amtrak: Not a Money Pit, After All
description: When Hurricane Sandy swept across railroad bedsin the Northeast last year, Amtrak went quiet.Officials at the nations railroad scrambled to repair the damage that stretched the length of the huge storm. Amtrak in the region was out for a week.And disruptions continued along the popular Boston to Washington corridor for almost a month.

title: Player Ratings: United States (3) vs. Panama (2)
description: In one of the most memorable nights in Concacaf World Cup qualifying, the United States rallied late on Tuesday to defeat Panama, 3-2, and toss a lifeline to its arch rival, Mexico.

title: Avalanche Kills Four Near Everest
description: BEIJING  A 60-year-old Australian and three Tibetan porters were killed by an avalanche in the Mount Everest area of Tibet this week, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported on Wednesday, citing local authorities.

title: Real Estate in Northern Ireland
description: A detailedlook at a six-acre property near Killinchy in County Down thats on the market for $2.06 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Northern Ireland
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM COTTAGE WITH AN 18TH-CENTURY FARMYARD IN NORTHERN IRELAND

title: Advice About Assisted Living for Aging Relatives, Part 1
description: Readers have sent more than 100  questions and suggestions to Debra Drelich, a specialist in geriatric care, about assisted living and other special living arrangements for aging relatives.

title: Tips on Talking to and Tapping Potential Investors
description: Debra Reisenthel, chief executive at Palo Alto Health Sciences, has been trying to raise money from investors for the last four months. The goal is to finance the development and production of a biofeedback device that measures carbon dioxide output and trains people to breathe in a way that helps them manage anxiety disorders.

title: Homes for $600,000
description: This weeks properties include a Colonial in New York State, a Craftsman in Oregon and a contemporary in North Carolina.

title: What You Get for... $600,000
description: SLATE HILL, N.Y.

title: Fallacies of Immaculate Causation
description: Brad DeLong reminds us of Eugene Famas remarkable (in the worst way) claim that stimulus cant work as a matter of logic. It was actually that claim, and its endorsement by John Cochrane , that led me to the realization that we were living in a dark age of macroeconomics.

title: Catching, and Releasing, Monarchs as They Flutter Down to Mexico
description: Tim Walsh, 67, saw the fluttering orange and black wings on Tuesday afternoon among the flowers near the Riverside Park tennis courts, around 96th Street on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Plane Crash in Laos Kills 49
description: BANGKOK  A Lao Airlines flight crashed into the Mekong River in southern Laos on Wednesday, killing all 49 people onboard, according to a statement from the Laotian government.

title: In Our Pages: October 17
description: 1913 Call for Arms to Cross Border

title: App Smart: Managing Your Passwords
description: Three apps to keep your passwords safe, as reviewed by The Timess Kit Eaton.

title: Britain Starts Formal Inquiry of Currency Trading
description: LONDON  Britains financial regulator said on Wednesday that it had started a formal investigation into whether a number of companies manipulated the foreign exchange market.

title: Prize-Laden Cast Is Set for Realistic Joneses on Broadway
description: Four actors known for biting performances  the Emmy Award winner Toni Collette (United States of Tara), Michael C. Hall (Dexter), the Tony Award winner Tracy Letts (Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf?), and the Oscar winner Marisa Tomei (My Cousin Vinny)  are set to star on Broadway this spring in Will Enos dark comedy The Realistic Joneses, the producers announced on Wednesday.

title: In the Senate, All Eyes on Cruz
description: WASHINGTON  As the Senate reached a deal on Wednesday that would end the government shutdown and increase the debt limit, all eyes were on the man many consider responsible for the current standoff  Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas.

title: The Backfire Effect
description: Im coming to this a bit late, but I see that theres now extensive evidence that facts not only dont win arguments, they make people on the wrong side dig in even deeper: When your deepest convictions are challenged by contradictory evidence, your beliefs get stronger.

title: Apps to Protect Your Array of Passwords
description: We all know that we need to use strong passwords on Web sites. In fact, a different password for every site you frequent is wise.

title: House Republicans Consider Their Options
description: WASHINGTON  As the Senate reached a deal Wednesday that would reopen the federal government and raise the debt ceiling, the House Republican leadership team continued to ponder whether taking up its own measure first was in the best interest of its members.

title: For South Carolina Senator, a House Vote Would Have Been Different
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Tim Scott, Republican of South Carolina, who was elevated to the Senate from the House earlier this year when Senator Jim DeMint retired, said he might vote differently on the proposed budget deal now than he would have as a representative.

title: Dutch Cable Company Rejects Liberty Globals Buyout Offer
description: LONDON  Ziggo, the largest provider of cable television services in the Netherlands, has rejected a buyout offer from Liberty Global, the media company controlled by John C. Malone, the company said on Wednesday.

title: Jazz & Colors Returns to Central Park
description: The sounds of jazz will waft throughout Central Park again this fall, as Jazz & Colors returns for a second year. The concert, free and open to the public, will take place on Nov. 9, according to a press announcement scheduled for release on Thursday.

title: CMJ, Day 1
description: The festival kicked off on Tuesday.

title: Observing Grizzlies at a Canadian Resort
description: The Orford Bay in British Columbias Bute Inlet is famous for an abundance of grizzly bears between September and November, and the Sonora Resort, 30 miles off the coast of Vancouver Island, gives its guests the chance to see these animals with daily four-hour tours.

title: CMJ: Seesawing Between the Past and a Forward-Looking Present
description: Ive seen it all before but I just didnt know, sang Matthew Paul of Ghost Wave on the first afternoon of the CMJ Music Marathon. The song was a measured, droney throwback to the Velvet Underground. Yet Ghost Wave, from New Zealand is a younger and larger band, with one guitarist devoted to distortion from a teardrop-shaped guitar and another band member  front and center  playing just tambourine or shaker.

title: Warren Buffett on Driving Violations, Baseball and Jamie Dimon
description: Warren E. Buffett offered an unusual defense of Jamie Dimon on Wednesday morning, comparing the billions of dollars that JPMorgan Chase has paid in fines to state troopers handing out a speeding ticket.

title: Cruz Wont Block Senate Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ted Cruz of Texas conceded defeat but did not express contrition as he emerged from a meeting of Senate Republicans called to ratify the agreement.

title: Senate Leaders Announce Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democratic and Republican leaders on Wednesday reached final agreement on a deal to reopen the government and extend its borrowing authority into February, with final passage looking increasingly possible by Wednesday evening.

title: Hunting the Perfect Logo
description: The many rejected designs for Tavern on the Greens new signage.

title: Share Your Emergency Room Experience
description: This year, in my series Paying Till it Hurts, I have been reporting on the high cost of medical care in the United States as the country endeavors to expand insurance coverage through the Affordable Care Act. Whether you are insured or uninsured, I would like to hear about your medical bills and your experiences with managing the costs of health care. Most of the patients featured in this series so far have been people who commented on previous articles or responded to a callout like this one and graciously shared their story with me.

title: Remaking Tavern on the Green, One Fork at a Time
description: The old restaurant is being remade by a couple of Philly guys who are making a big bet. It starts with getting the details right.

title: The Octopus That Almost Ate Seattle
description: In the months leading up to the hunt, Dylan Mayer trained twice a week in his parents swimming pool, asking friends to attack him, splay their arms and grab him, drag him to the surface and shove him below it, pull off his mask, snatch his regulator, time his recovery. By last Halloween, he was ready, and as the light began to fade that afternoon, the broad-shouldered 19-year-old jumped into a red Ford pickup truck with his buddy and drove some 40 minutes from Maple Valley, Wash., to West Seattle. They arrived at Alki Beach around 4 p.m., put on their wet suits and ambled into Cove 2. Then they slipped into Elliott Bay, the Space Needle punctuating the city line in the distance like an inverted exclamation point.

title: Some Republicans Question Cost of Outcome
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said the announcement of a deal to reopen the government and avert a default on government obligations would not be a time for finger pointing. But fingers are indeed being pointed, mainly at ardent conservatives who tied further government financing to the gutting of President Obamas health care law.

title: White House Supports Deal and Urges Quick Passage
description: WASHINGTON  Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said Wednesday that President Obama supported the compromise reached by the Senate leaders, and he urged lawmakers in both chambers to pass it quickly.

title: When Nets Salute Kidd, Thorn Should Receive an Assist
description: While the Nets are hoisting No. 5 to the Barclays Center rafters Thursday night for Jason Kidd, they might also consider raising a banner, or at least a toast, in honor of Rod Thorn.

title: Is the Right Winning?
description: While the press focuses, for understandable reasons, on the Republican Partys abject failure to accomplish anything remotely like its stated objectives in the shutdown/debt ceiling fight, Peter Beinart makes the case that the G.O.P.s mix of intransigence and internal chaos is successfully pushing the American political debate to the right:

title: Nazis, the American Revolution and 9/11
description: On her Facebook page on Monday, Sarah Palin said President Obama should be impeached if Congress did not raise the debt limit and the nation went into default  or if he tried to avoid that awful outcome by raising the debt limit without a Congressional vote of approval.

title: Mitch McConnell on Fiscal Deal
description: The Senate minority leader speaks about the bipartisan bill to reopen the government and avoid default.

title: Rowing With Esther Lofgren, Olympian
description: The gold medalist rower talks about her workout.

title: The Workout: Rowing With Esther Lofgren, Olympian
description: Members of the U.S. national rowing team follow an intense training regimen that combines rowing, weight lifting and aerobic training for 45 to 60 hours a week. We asked Esther Lofgren, an Olympic gold medalist, to take us through the rowers workout.

title: Gridlock Has Cost U.S. Billions, and the Meter Is Still Running
description: WASHINGTON  Containers of goods idling at ports. Reduced sales at sandwich shops in downtown Washington. Canceled vacations to national parks and to destinations abroad. Reduced corporate earnings forecasts. Higher interest payments on short-term debt.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | 12 Years a Slave
description: Steve McQueen, the director of 12 Years a Slave, narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Black Marks Routinely Expunged From Brokers Records, Report Finds
description: Updated, 5:11 p.m. |

title: Paper That Backed Cruz for Senate Now Wishes He Werent There
description: Updated, 3:13 p.m. | WASHINGTON  One year after endorsing Ted Cruz for Senate, The Houston Chronicle on Wednesday called the Texas senator part of the problem in Washington.

title: T FALL DESIGN
description: Once favored by the leading lights of Old Hollywood, the Trousdale section of Los Angeles fell out of fashion in the 70s  its trove of midcentury architecture tarted up or torn down  only to be rediscovered by a new wave of glamorous Angelenos devoted to preserving its unique style. Its ready for its close-up, again.

title: Private Stock, Paying Hard to Get
description: Do a not-all-that-deep Google dig on Jon Koon, the owner and designer of Private Stock, and youll happen upon pictures of him at the 2011 birthday party of the rapper Young Jeezy. Mr. Koon helped build Jeezys clothing line, 8732, and in the photos, in a room full of people skilled at flaunting their wealth, he looks like a man at peace with his success: gold sunglasses, cigar half-smoked, Champagne bottle uncorked and gripped by the neck.

title: Chris Kittrell, Frontman for the Band Baby Alpaca
description: AGE 28

title: Is It Harder to Pitch a Professional or a Family Member?
description: Debra Reisenthel, chief executive at Palo Alto Health Sciences, has been trying to raise money the past four months from investors. As we explain in a small-business guide we have just published about pitching investors, her goal is to finance the development and production of a biofeedback device that measures carbon dioxide output and trains people to breathe in a way that helps them manage anxiety disorders.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of 12 Years a Slave
description: The period drama 12 Years a Slave stars Chiwetel Ejiofor as Solomon Northup, a free man from the pre-Civil War American North who is abducted and sold into slavery in the South. In this video, the director Steve McQueen narrates a scene that takes place on the plantation where Mr. Northup serves, featuring Michael Fassbender as his owner Edwin Epps and Lupita Nyongo as Patsey, the slave Epps rapes.

title: Hill & Dale: Lounge on Lower East Side
description: By now, many New Yorkers have experienced the novelty of an $18 deconstructed Sazerac served by a sanctimonious mixologist in Prohibition-period dress at some spurious speakeasy. Though the old-timey trope continues at Hill & Dale, the Volstead Act is repealed in favor of an unpretentious cocktail lounge destined for midweek trysts and co-workers birthdays.

title: A Splashy Art Party at Philip Johnsons Glass House
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Suicide Bomber in Pakistan Kills a Provincial Official
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber killed a senior provincial official and at least nine guests at the officials home in northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday, in the most high-profile political assassination by the Islamist insurgency there this year.

title: Greeces Parliament Clears Way for More Charges Against 6 Right-Wing Lawmakers
description: ATHENS  As part of a widening effort to clamp down on violent extremism in Greece, the countrys Parliament moved on Wednesday to lift the immunity of six lawmakers of Golden Dawn, the neo-fascist anti-immigrant party prosecutors portray as a criminal organization involved in murder, attempted murder, blackmail and other crimes.

title: Reid Thanks GOP Leader for Cooperation
description: Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, announced an agreement on Friday with his Republican counterparts to reopen the federal government.

title: Acrostic
description: Acrostic puzzle for October20, 2013

title: Cruz Says He Wont Block Shutdown Deal
description: As both parties announced an agreement that would lead to the reopening of the government, Senator Ted Cruz, who had pushed the Republicans cause, said he would not try to delay a vote.

title: Sum Worth More Than the Parts in Advance Auto Deal
description: The sum is worth more than the parts  auto parts, that is. Advance Autos $2 billion takeover of rival General Parts International resulted in the acquirer gaining $1 billion in market cap. Thats bang in line with the net present value of promised cost savings. Nobel Prize winner Eugene Famas efficient markets hypothesis may be flawed, but when it comes to the nitty-gritty of corporate finance, it often seems to work just fine.

title: Awards
description: The truth is, nothing will ever top this:

title: Senate to Act First, Followed by House
description: With Senate Republican hard-liners promising not to delay a vote on the agreement to reopen the government and raise the debt limit, the Senate is expected to take up the bill first.

title: On E.U. Carbon Emissions Rule, First the Announcement, Then the Uproar
description: On Monday, the European Unions environmental ministers agreed to delay a plan to hold cars to tough new carbon emissions limits by 2020. On Tuesday they faced the music.

title: Dollhouse Made Them Do It
description: It was a blog about her old dollhouse that reunited Eden Cayen with Gerard Sambets. Ms. Cayen had restored her childhood dollhouse after it was unearthed in her mothers barn upstate. She had furnished it with vintage dollhouse furniture, posting photos of her miniature projects at eloisemoorehead.com.

title: Helpless and Contemptible
description: Matt Fink, a lawyer turned historian, sends this quotation:

title: Acrostic Answer
description: Acrostic answer for October 20, 2013

title: House Conservatives Blame Moderates, Not Boehner
description: WASHINGTON  Moments before the Senate deal was finalized on Wednesday, some House conservatives were alternately defiant and defeated, acknowledging they may have lost the current battle but vowing to fight on.

title: Judge Rejects Suit to Block Vote on Casinos
description: ALBANY  A judge dismissed a lawsuit on Wednesday that sought to stop a casino gambling referendum next month in New York State, saying the legal challenge over the measures wording was untimely and lacking in legal merit.

title: Wheelies: The Take a Deep Breath Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Christie Flips on an Immigration Bill
description: Immigrant advocates heard correctly over the weekend: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey really does support allowing unauthorized immigrants to pay in-state tuition at his states colleges and universities.

title: The Governments Coming Shortfall
description: If Congress does not raise the debt ceiling, the Treasury will have to rely on daily incoming revenues to pay its bills and will have to choose to delay certain payments or not pay for some programs altogether.

title: Amrica Mvil Drops Bid for KPN
description: LONDON  Amrica Mvil, the Latin American telecommunications giant owned by Carlos Slim Hel, said on Wednesday that it had dropped its 7.2 billion euro, or $9.7 billion, bid to acquire the Dutch telephone provider Royal KPN.

title: In Thailand, Redefining the Tastes of Childhood
description: I grew up on turkey and cheese sandwiches, Frosted Flakes and Capri Suns. In elementary school, I proudly traded my Fruit Roll-Up for Krafts cracker and cheese dip and my Cool Ranch Doritos for California Raisins. I was an all-American girl growing up in homogeneously backwater north Florida. This was the land of hamburger cookouts and pizza parties. Yoo-hoos after a long day of water skiing. A trip to IHOP for pancakes and eggs after a Sunday Southern Baptist revival.

title: The Art and Craft of Privilege Signs
description: The various fonts and options that make up a privilege e sign.

title: The Coca-Cola Goldline Program
description: The full details on the Coca-Cola Goldline Program.

title: Max Irons: Out of Character, but in His Element
description: On a recent Wednesday, the British actor Max Irons accompanied a reporter to the Cloisters, the museum devoted to the art of medieval Europe. It was a setting that may have felt familiar to King Edward IV, the character Mr. Irons plays on the Starz series The White Queen, a lusty take on the Wars of the Roses.

title: 'Can't Go Back'
description: The latest ad from the Lhota campaign claims that a de Blasio administration would return the city to its crime-ridden past.

title: Original Review: Fiddler on the Roof
description: Howard Taubmans 1964 review of the musical at the Imperial Theater.

title: Knight Capital to Pay $12 Million Fine on Trading Violations
description: On the morning of Aug. 1 2012, Knight Capital, Wall Streets biggest trading firm, sent out a wave of accidental stock orders  more than four million  that reverberated through the market and eventually resulted in a $460 million loss for the firm.

title: On the Verge | Trousdale, Los Angeless Forgotten Architectural Mecca, Makes a Comeback
description: Once favored by the leading lights of Old Hollywood, the Trousdale section of Los Angeles fell out of fashion in the 70s  its trove of midcentury architecture tarted up or torn down  only to be rediscovered by a new wave of glamorous Angelenos devoted to preserving its unique style. Its ready for its close-up, again. See the slide show.

title: New York Guitar Festival to Return in January
description: When David Spelman presented the last installment of the biennial New York Guitar Festival, in 2012, he mused, in a New York Times interview, about putting the festival on hiatus. But when he was asked whether that meant that there would be no 2014 festival, Mr. Spelman said, I always answer my cellphone. And I dont like to say no.

title: Boehner Supports Deal, but Says G.O.P. Fight Will Continue
description: WASHINGTON  House Speaker John A. Boehner threw his weight on Wednesday behind the Senate deal to reopen the government and avert a default. He pledged to continue fighting President Obamas health care law, but in a different manner.

title: Facebook Eases Privacy Rules for Teenagers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook has loosened its privacy rules for teenagers as a debate swirls over online threats to children from bullies and sexual predators.

title: Even a Doomed Queen Just Wants to Have Fun
description: Every new television season should have a camp classic, but its been hard to find one among the grindingly dull shows trotted out this fall. ABCs Betrayal had promise, with some risible plots and ripe performances (Henry Thomas as a brain-damaged scion and James Cromwell as his imperious dad are a hoot), but its just not enough fun.

title: The Golden Years of Tavern on the Green
Cyruss Bangerz Hits No. 1
description: With a blitz of media and constant online chatter, Miley Cyrus easily clinched the top spot on Billboards album chart this week. Bangerz (RCA), her latest, opened with 270,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, becoming Ms. Cyruss fifth No. 1 album, including three released under her Disney alter ego, Hannah Montana. Bangerz also tops the charts in Britain, Canada, Australia and Ireland this week. Ms. Cyrus, 20, has been perhaps the most unavoidable figure in pop culture since at least Aug. 25, when her hypersexed, tongue-wagging performance stole the show at the MTV Video Music Awards.

title: Jury Rules for Mark Cuban in Setback for S.E.C.
description: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | The government mocked Mark Cuban as a winner in his mind, claiming that the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team possessed a competitive edge that drove him to insider trading.

title: At the New York Premiere of Her, a Party Makes Do Without Its Voice
description: One important guest was missing from the New York premiere of Her, the new movie from Spike Jonze, which closed the New York Film Festival on Saturday night: the woman who plays the title character.

title: A Lesson in Time Management for a Wagner Coach
description: The first-grade students at Public School 80 entered Room 108 single file at 8:10 on a clear and blustery morning on Staten Island, placed their book bags in cubbyholes and waited. It was time for Bashir Mason to check their homework.

title: Gadgets to Help the Party Host
description: The stresses of hosting a party can pile up this time of year. Whether its for a holiday get-together or a tailgate extravaganza, drinks must be mixed and food must be cooked, preferably with a carefree attitude that puts your guests in awe of your party-throwing prowess.

title: Life on Ships That Make World Go Round
description: Rose George is a young British journalist who writes smart books about subjects we mostly prefer not to think about. Her last one, The Big Necessity (2008), about human waste and society, is among the best nonfiction books of the new millennium. Give the paperback edition to the person in your life who never puts down the toilet seat.

title: Times Reporter Plans to Take Fight to the Supreme Court
description: For James Risen, an investigative reporter for The Times, the bad news just keeps on coming. When I wrote about him in late July, a federal appeals panel had just ruled against him in a case related to a leak investigation.

title: How to Get Your Last Name Posted After You Win a Learning Network Student Contest
description: We like having student contests on The Learning Network, and we run them regularly.

title: On Glowing Pickles and Undiscovered Galaxies: Student STEM Contest Winners
description: A video sent in by  one of many students who entered our contest from a Project Lead the Way school.

title: An Assassin Abroad: Peter Savodnik Talks About The Interloper
description: For most of us, Lee Harvey Oswald exists most vividly in downtown Dallas, poised to make the worst kind of history. In his new book, The Interloper, Peter Savodnik recounts Oswalds time living and working in the Soviet Union. He went in 1960, with the hopes of building a permanent existence there after a childhood of frequent moves. He found his future wife, and became a father for the first time, but he returned to the United States in 1962, bitterly disappointed in his failure to start over in Russia. Mr. Savodnik argues that this time overseas reveals a great deal about Oswalds personality and his infamous crime. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Savodnik discussed Oswalds time in Minsk, the Russian view of conspiracy theories and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Robert Rauschenberg and Photography
description: A new show Pace/MacGill Gallery explores photographys role at the center of Rauschenbergs work.

title: Taking Flight Without Taking Off
description: Travelers who fancy themselves flyboys and girls can test their skills at Fly the Dream, a new virtual entertainment store where customers can navigate a simulated flight of an F-16 Falcon, a single-engine fighter aircraft developed by General Dynamics for the Air Force in the early 1970s.

title: Aggression Unleashed, and Moderated Too, in Pumped-Up Touring Return
description: Trent Reznors recent record with Nine Inch Nails, Hesitation Marks, represents a self-possessed next move for a band whose old meanings have been displaced, if not entirely eclipsed. The currents that it rose from in the late 80s  harsh and jabbering industrial music, creep-out cinema, roaring psychosexual anger  long ago became normalized; as elements of art, those things live and die on immediate response and dont get the kind the group desires anymore, especially from fans in their 40s.

title: A Wild Book Tour With a Soundtrack
description: As I dig out of a mountain of work built up after recent travels in Asia, Im enjoying listening to Jon Mooallem read excerpts from Wild Ones, his alternately amusing and unsettling book about the human species dysfunctional relationship with all manner of wild animals (he focuses on the American subspecies of humans).

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Washington, New Jersey, the Philippines and Pakistan.

title: Case Pits Freezing Assets Against Hiring Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON  Kerri and Brian Kaley, a New York couple, were unable to hire a lawyer to defend themselves against serious criminal charges because the government had frozen their assets. That seemed to trouble several justices at a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday.

title: 110 Seconds With Pogue: Windows 8.1
description: The Timess David Pogue weighed in on the updates to Microsofts Windows 8 operating systems, one of which is designed for desktops, the other for tablets.

title: Ronan Farrow to Host Show on MSNBC
description: The search for new hosts for cable news programs turned up a familiar name on Wednesday when MSNBC announced that it had hired Ronan Farrow, son of Mia Farrow and Woody Allen, to take over an hour of its weekday schedule starting early next year.

title: Reconciling 2 Worlds With Windows 8.1
description: Just about one year ago, Microsoft gave us two new operating systems.

title: House Republicans Gearing Up for Round 2
description: WASHINGTON  Coming out of a closed-door meeting Wednesday afternoon, in which Speaker John A. Boehner explained to his conference that he would be taking up the Senate deal and likely passing it with the help of Democratic votes, Republican lawmakers were already regrouping for the next fight.

title: Roundup at the Chelsea Hall, With Flinging, Stumbling, Collapsing
description: Forty-five years is a long time, as far as choreographic careers go  long enough, in Lar Lubovitchs case, to have created more than 100 works. That kind of experience might bring a certain comfort with trying new ideas. A dance about cowboys? Hey, why not?

title: Rhapsody in Deal to Expand in Latin America
description: Rhapsody, the subscription music service, is expanding to Latin America through a bundling deal with Telefnica, one of the worlds largest telecom providers.

title: Forget the Spoonful of Sugar: Its Uncle Walt, Uncensored
description: BURBANK, Calif.  In the coming movie Saving Mr. Banks, a comedic drama about the turbulent making of Mary Poppins in the 1960s, Walt Disney acts in a very un-Disney way. He slugs back Scotch. He uses a mild curse word. He wheezes because he smokes too much.

title: Be as Creative as a Kindergartner
description: Tom and David Kelley are brothers behind the design and consulting firm IDEO known for designing the first Apple mouse and an early laptop computer. David Kelley also founded the d.school Institute of Design at Stanford while Tom Kelley wrote the popular book The Art of Innovation, in 2001.

title: Milder Accounts of Hardships Under Mao Arise as His Birthday Nears
description: HONG KONG  The famine that gripped China from 1958 to 1962 is widely judged to be the deadliest in recorded history, killing 20 to 30 million people or more, and is one of the defining calamities of Mao Zedongs rule. Ever since, the party has shrouded that disaster in censorship and euphemisms, seeking to maintain an aura of reverence around the founding leader of the Communist state.

title: Muscle and Speed Win a Crowds Adulation
description: The Mariinsky Orchestras three-concert stand at Carnegie Hall, which ended on Tuesday evening, was billed as a 60th-birthday celebration for its music director, Valery Gergiev. And Mr. Gergiev was indeed the center of attention at the first concert, last Thursday (reviewed earlier), when he led a long program of Stravinsky ballet scores and was the target of protests by gay-rights activists for supporting the candidacy of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who is limiting dialogue on homosexuality in Russia.

title: Urban Living
description: The next mayor should keep architecture and planning front and center, a critic argues.

title: States Report Health Insurance Application Numbers
description: Minnesotas state-run health insurance exchange reported Wednesday that 5,569 households had completed applications for coverage in the first two weeks of operation, representing 11,684 people. The exchange portal has run relatively smoothly after struggling with technology problems for a few days after it opened on Oct. 1, said April Todd-Malmlov, the executive director.

title: Reflections on a Couple of Boston Homers
description: Before Torii Hunter even finished flipping over the wall at Fenway Park on Sunday night, before he even hit the ground, the image of his flailing legs juxtaposed against the raised arms of a triumphant Boston police officer had already become a baseball classic.

title: An Artist Who Gets a Lift From Gravity
description: John Knuth comes from a school of artists who allow nature to activate their works. But unlike some who let their pieces be entirely dictated by the whims of the elements, the Los Angeles-based artist remains involved with the process, exerting a measure of control over his science-based abstractions. His recent series of fly paintings  in which he fed the insects pigment, which they then regurgitated onto canvases  were ironically beautiful gradients of pointillist abstraction. For his next body of work, which he will create on site at Human Resources, an art space in Los Angeless Chinatown, the process is even messier.

title: Building a Better City
description: On Jan. 1, the next mayor  either Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate, or Joe Lhota, the Republican  will face a fiscal cliff of unpaid bills. Schools will need to be saved, union contracts negotiated  the future of New York envisioned.

title: A Computer Championship in Indonesia
description: How would you compare humans with computer programs when it comes to playing chess or bridge?

title: Making Opera of Art and Vice Versa
description: As a flickering projector beamed film fragments and India ink drawings into a dollhouse-size model of the Metropolitan Operas gold proscenium in a small workroom not far from the real stage, the artist William Kentridge was explaining how some of the embryonic images flitting by would be developed over the next two years into his new production of Alban Bergs Lulu.

title: One Met Isnt Enough
description: When The Refusal of Time, a multimedia installation and meditation on time by the South African artist William Kentridge had its premiere last summer at (d)ocumenta 13 in Kassel, Germany, Neal Benezra, director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, had his eye on acquiring it.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Shutdown Dysfunction, and Smile, Youre Being Tracked
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Thierry-Maxime Loriot, Curator of the Jean Paul Gaultier Exhibition
description: THE RUFFLE-AND-ROSETTE-FESTOONED corset that was being prepared for the Jean Paul Gaultier fashion exhibition making its long-awaited tour stop in New York at the Brooklyn Museum, beginning Oct. 25, had discreet panels of stretch fabric sewn into the sides. It was a spring 2011 sample created for Beth Ditto, the outspoken singer who once took Topshop to task for not offering larger sizes, who once pointed out that Karl Lagerfeld is a former fat kid, and who is not someone you would ever have expected to be found on a designer runway.

title: Kim Kardashians Ex Sells the Engagement Ring
description: Kris Humphries, the Boston Celtics player known formerly as Kim Kardashians husband, has sold the 20.5-carat engagement ring he gave to his former wife. The ring, which reportedly cost him $2 million, was auctioned on Tuesday by Christies in New York for $749,000 (including the commission). That topped the auction houses presale estimate of $300,000 to $500,000, but Twitter users were quick to point out the losing numbers.

title: New York Department Stores Revamp Cosmetics and Fragrance Sections
description: With increasing competition from specialized retailers like Sephora and Ulta, as well as the Internet, several New York City department stores have, perhaps necessarily, decided to give their areas dedicated to cosmetics, skin care and fragrances a makeover.

title: Furor Over Yahoo Mail Changes
description: It has become the online equivalent of a riot.

title: Columbia to House a Trove of Prokofievs Items
description: A foundation dedicated to Sergei Prokofiev will give a priceless trove of musical manuscripts, letters and other items belonging to the composer  including a suitcase  to the Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Columbia in an effort to make them more accessible to scholars. Most of the materials represent Prokofievs work from 1918 to 1938, the years he visited or lived in the West.

title: Two Longtime Gossip Columnists Share Their Secrets (Well, Some of Them)
description: When gossip columnists get a juicy tip but the sourcing is problematic, theres a tradition called the blind item, in which the subjects are described in detail but not named. As in: What married media duo could not stop bickering during a two-and-a-half-hour interview with a reporter?

title: A Line of Luxe Basics Made for Dancing
description: Nili Lotan, whose namesake line of luxe basics is a wardrobe staple for both celebrities and everyday, on-the-go women, introduced her spring 2014 collection last Thursday with a performance in her TriBeCa showroom. The Israeli-American designer said that the very minimal, clean, pure aesthetic of her 25 new pieces remained true to the vision of her very first collection a decade ago. To present the clothes, she commissioned LeeSaar the Company to incorporate them into an original modern dance, but because the spring looks werent designed specifically for dancers, she faced a few obstacles in preparing for the unusual show format. Its not models, so youre not dealing with size 2, she said. Theyre short and theyre big-muscled, and it was a challenge because most of the samples are a size 2, size 4. She wound up designing special briefs for the dancers to perform in.

title: Settlement Report Finds Banks Giving Timely Mortgage Relief
description: The $25 billion national mortgage settlement, intended to help homeowners affected by the housing crisis, appears to be running ahead of schedule, according to a new report by the monitor of the program.

title: Lifted From a Russian Lake, a Big, if Fragile, Space Rock
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials on Wednesday retrieved the largest fragment so far of a meteor that exploded in February over the city of Chelyabinsk, but as divers and a mechanical winch lifted it from the bottom of a lake, the rock broke into three pieces, and then broke the scale  literally  when all together it weighed in at more than 1,250 pounds.

title: After Decades, a Water Tunnel Can Now Serve All of Manhattan
description: Of all New York Citys sprawling mega-projects, the water tunnel snaking beneath the grid  connecting the Bronx to Upper Manhattan, Upper Manhattan to Central Park, Central Park to Queens, and, eventually, Queens to the western edge of Brooklyn  is perhaps the hardest to love.

title: Beauty Is Its Own Excuse
description: The novelist Allan Gurganus discovered the secret to happiness: collecting.

title: Wine Accessories
description: Well-designed wine accessories highlight any vintage, and maybe even that $6 bottle of merlot.

title: When the Saint Came Marching In
description: Collections collect collectors. It doesnt work the other way around.

title: Wine Accessories: Palette Pleasers
description: Brad Cloepfil, an architect known for designing buildings like the Seattle Art Museum and the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, developed his interest in wine in a roundabout way.

title: Discounts at Jonathan Adler, Garnet Hill and Others
description: Selected glassware is 30 percent off at Apartment 48 Thursday through Oct. 31 (the Mod hourglass, regularly $38, is about $27); (212) 807-1391, apartment48.com.

title: Waltzing With the Stars
description: Although Vienna was a birthplace of modernism, its contemporary designers get scant notice in the United States. At least, thats the view of Michael and Anna Trubrig, a Viennese couple who recently opened Stillfried Wien in TriBeCa to offer vintage and new items from Austria, Germany and Switzerland.

title: Dont Try This in Yoga Class
description: Pablo Pardo, a Venezuelan-born industrial designer who worked for Fisher-Price and DaimlerChrysler, started his own lighting company, Pablo, in San Francisco 20 years ago. The business has grown in prestige because of products like Circa, a new lamp that supplies balanced light via a flat-panel LED screen. A round shade-like element, which houses the LEDs, rotates a full 360 degrees and tilts 45 degrees to send the light were it is needed. The lamp also features a four-stage dimmer control and, on most of the models, a USB port for charging mobile gadgets.

title: If You Could Make It There, You Were Made
description: They were built as speculative housing in the last years of the 19th century, two blocks of elegant town houses in Harlem, divvied up between three architectural teams, including one led by Stanford White. When they were finished, ownership was restricted to whites only. But by the 1920s, the King Model Houses, named for their developer, David King, and known colloquially as Strivers Row, had become home to black artists, socialites and professionals like Scott Joplin, Eubie Blake and Dr. Louis T. Wright.

title: Bonnie Prints
description: Scotland has inspired schoolgirl uniforms, a New Years Eve song and a Mel Gibson epic, and now it must be credited for wallpaper patterns by Lake August, a Los Angeles company. Alexis Hartman, Lake Augusts founder and designer, resolved to start the business while traveling in Scotland a few years ago and realized her ambition earlier this year.

title: Chip Kidd: Start Making Sense
description: After 27 years of designing book covers for Knopf, Chip Kidd, the noted graphic artist, novelist and interpreter of superheroes in books like Batman: Death by Design, is passing on his wisdom to children. Go: A Kidds Guide to Graphic Design($17.95) came out this week from Workman Publishing. In 150 highly legible and humorous pages, it manages to teach the principles of form, content, color, type and even a bit of history.

title: The Renovation Was Overdue
description: Creating living quarters in a Craftsman-style cottage that once housed a library.

title: Putting Their Stamp on It
description: When Karen Gilliam and Sara Van Beckum began renovating their home in Portland, Ore., which once served as the local branch library, they werent planning to live there full time. The couple, who are voice-over artists, were based in New York City and intended to split their time between New York and Oregon.

title: China, Spitting and Global Tourism
description: Living in Beijing a long time, you learn to anticipate a spitter. The crackling crescendo may begin as he nears, leaving you wondering  is it a territorial thing? Then the finale: a terrific ptchoo! and an opalescent glob whirling like a tiny Frisbee into the gutter or onto the pavement near your feet. Or your eye, as happened to my companion standing downwind from a spitter at an open train window, in the western region of Xinjiang.

title: The Armani Experience
description: It was awkward, in more ways than one.

title: Scattered by War, Syrians Struggle to Start Over
description: MAFRAQ, Jordan  Watering the plants on her balcony back home in Syria this spring, Wedad Sarhan took delight in how they were stirring to life after the winter months. A jasmine tree filled the small balcony with its sweet scent. An apricot tree, planted eight springs earlier, was blossoming for the first time.

title: The Historic Scale of Syrias Refugee Crisis
description: Dramatic images from the Syrian refugee crisis, which exploded to encompass six million people by October 2013.

title: The Cost of Gridlock
description: Continued uncertainty over fiscal policy has eroded gross domestic product growth over the last several years, according to Macroeconomic Advisers, an independent economic research firm.

title: A Prairie of the Imagination
description: Federal Twist, a garden in New Jersey, serves no purpose  except an emotional one.

title: The Good-for-Nothing Garden
description: KINGWOOD TOWNSHIP, N.J.  The best kind of garden is a useless garden. James Goldens green parcel, in the quiet hummocks above the Delaware River, is literally good for nothing. He has made sure of it.

title: Designer Wine Accessories
description: While designer wine accessories might not be necessary says architect Brad Cloepfil, they are beautiful and that can be an important part of our surroundings.

title: To Get Through His Day, These Soothe His Ears
description: In times of stress and lots of work, I try to listen to the most soothing music possible. This usually happens first thing in the morning while Im performing the morning routine. Here are some things Ive been listening to recently. NICO MUHLY

title: Theater, Dance, Film, Pop: Dont Pin Him Down
description: His schedule crowded and his list of collaborators long, Nico Muhly has many other projects planned for this year and next in addition to Two Boys, opening on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera. His recent New York premieres have ranged from the melancholy score for the choreographer Benjamin Millepieds Neverwhere, which had its debut with New York City Ballet last month, to sensitive music for a new production of The Glass Menagerie, now on Broadway. Here is a look at nine other Muhly projects, from arrangements for an Icelandic pop artists lushly wistful new album to songs for an eminent mezzo-soprano and pianist.

title: Two Boys and One Composer
description: When Nico Muhlys opera Two Boys was first performed two years ago in London, Paul Cremo convened a small focus group.

title: In Performance: Nico Muhly
description: Nico Muhly performs an excerpt from Im Only Sixteen from his opera Two Boys. He is accompanied by the tenor Paul Appleby.

title: James Goldens Picks
description: Q. Where is the perfect spot to put a plant in the garden?

title: When the Gold Dust Settles
description: The Luminaries, Eleanor Cattons remarkable second novel  the winner of this years Man Booker Prize  is a lot of things, and I mean a lot, but above all, perhaps, it is a love story, one that takes all of 826 pages to truly arrive. And its not even a novel in the normal sense, but rather a mass confabulation that evaporates in front of us, an astrological divination waning like the moon, the first section 360 pages long (or are those degrees?), the last a mere sliver. But its a sliver that delivers.

title: Cameron Criticizes The Guardian for Publishing Secrets
description: LONDON  The battle lines hardened between the British authorities and The Guardian newspaper over its publication of material leaked by the fugitive American intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden, when Prime Minister David Cameron accused the newspaper on Wednesday of damaging national security.

title: Finally Back in the East, the Rangers Seem at Home
description: WASHINGTON  Playing a game in the East for the first time this season turned out to be just what the Rangers needed. They dominated the Washington Capitals, 2-0, on Wednesday, their most impressive outing of an otherwise dreadful start to the campaign.

title: Shopping Events in New York Beginning Oct. 17
description: Openings

title: Flying Close to the Law
description: Duke Riley, a Brooklyn artist, trained 50 homing pigeons to fly from Havana, Cuba, to the Florida Keys carrying illicit cigars and cameras to record the journey.

title: Avian Artistry, With Smuggled Cigars
description: Pablo Escobar was loose. He darted across a noisy warehouse, searching for a corner to loom in.

title: Massachusetts: Bomb Suspects Sister in Court
description: A sister of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev appeared in a South Boston district court on Wednesday to address an outstanding warrant for her arrest. The woman, Ailina Tsarnaeva, 23, was arraigned in January 2011 on a charge that she misled an investigator looking into the passing of a counterfeit bill at a Boston Applebees; the warrant was issued when she failed to appear later for a court date. Prosecutors say that she knew members of the group that allegedly used the bill, but that she lied to the police about the incident. On Wednesday, Judge Michael C. Bolden released Ms. Tsarnaeva, who now lives in New Jersey, on $1,500 personal recognizance and required her to check in weekly with probation officers. She could face up to 2.5 years in prison if convicted.

title: Iran's Nuclear Talks in Geneva
description: Two days of discussions between Iran and six world powers ended on Wednesday. They were the first talks on Irans nuclear program since Hassan Rouhanis election as president.

title: Massachusetts Schools Dial Back on Obesity Reports
description: The state Public Health Council voted Wednesday to stop automatically sending letters home with public school students about their weight. The state is one of 21 that collect data about students body mass index, but some parents say the letters with their childrens results can cause self-esteem problems and the risk of bullying. The testing will continue in Grades 1, 4, 7 and 10 with increased confidentiality protections; parents will receive results only if they ask for them.

title: Man Gets 30-Year Sentence for Raping Bird-Watcher in Central Park
description: A 74-year-old bird-watcher who was raped in Central Park confronted her attacker in court on Wednesday at his sentencing, describing in detail how he brutally assaulted her while she was photographing hummingbirds.

title: In Greece, the Banking Chief Draws Scrutiny
description: ATHENS  In an era when central bankers like Ben S. Bernanke dominate the global economic stage, few hold as much power within their own country as Georgios A. Provopoulos, the governor of the Bank of Greece, who has played a crucial role in keeping Greece out of bankruptcy and in the euro zone.

title: Body of Nazi War Criminal Moved to Airport in Rome After Clashes
description: As my colleague Elisabetta Povoledo reported, a funeral for Erich Priebke, a former Nazi officer who died under house arrest in Rome last week while serving a life sentence in Italy for the wartime massacre of more than 300 civilians, was called off on Tuesday, after angry protests and clashes at a church run by renegade Catholics.

title: British Police on Defensive Over Downing Street Clash
description: LONDON  As an experienced politician, Andrew Mitchell might well have known it was a bad idea to swear at the police officers who had just ordered him to get off his bicycle outside the prime ministers office on Downing Street in September 2012.

title: Senate Passes Measure to End Fiscal Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans conceded defeat Wednesday in their bitter budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law, agreeing to end a disruptive 16-day government shutdown and extend federal borrowing power to avert a financial default with potential worldwide economic repercussions.

title: Maxine Powell, Motowns Maven of Style, Dies at 98
description: Maxine Powell, the Miss Manners of Motown, who as the director of the labels in-house finishing school in the 1960s was considered in no small part responsible for its early success, died on Monday in Southfield, Mich. She was 98.

title: An Activist Investor Is Urging Darden to Break Itself Up
description: Over 45 years, Darden has grown from a single restaurant in a landlocked Florida city to a 2,100-outlet empire, with its Olive Garden and Red Lobster brands blanketing the country.

title: Ex-Coach Says Greatness Remains Within Federers Reach
description: If Paul Annacone is bitter about losing his roster spot on Team Roger Federer last week, he is doing an Oscar-worthy job of hiding it.

title: World Trade Center Contractor Is Said to Be Focus of Inquiry Into Misuse of Funds
description: The owner of a company that has done nearly $1 billion in work on the steel skeletons of two World Trade Center towers and a transit hub is expected to be implicated in a criminal fraud case that would be among the largest to involve the misuse of funds designated for minority- or women-owned businesses, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: In New Book, Cheney Recalls 5 Heart Attacks and His Brush With Death
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Dick Cheney was so close to death in 2010 that he said farewell to his family members and instructed them to have his body cremated and the ashes returned to Wyoming, he writes in a new book on his long battle with heart disease.

title: Thin at Running Back, the Giants Sign Hillis
description: The Giants on Wednesday signed the free-agent running back Peyton Hillis, who rushed for 1,177 yards for the Cleveland Browns three seasons ago. Hillis, a 6-foot-1, 245-pound, six-year veteran, has played for Denver, Cleveland and Kansas City. He was also with Tampa Bay during the preseason this year.

title: Larry Benoit, Babe Ruth for Hunters, Is Dead at 89
description: Larry Benoit, who tracked whitetail deer through the snowy woods of northern New England and southern Canada for more than seven decades, shooting at least 200 of the biggest and most prized specimens, known as trophy bucks, while becoming one of the nations most revered deer hunters, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Duxbury, Vt. He was 89.

title: Obama Addresses Deal to End Fiscal Dispute
description: President Obama made a public statement Wednesday night after the Senate voted to pass a bill that would end the government shutdown and increase the debt limit, allowing the nation to avert a default on its financial obligations.

title: Assault of Dutch Diplomat in Moscow Frays Ties Between Russia and the Netherlands
description: MOSCOW  The year 2013 was officially supposed to be one of cultural exchange to highlight the friendship between Russia and the Netherlands. But lately, the most common exchanges between officials have been threats and legal actions amid an intensifying quarrel over the arrest and prosecution of Dutch citizens detained by the Russian Coast Guard aboard a Greenpeace ship flagged in the Netherlands.

title: Hugh White on The China Choice
description: Australia has always been one of the United States most loyal allies, but now that the Australian economy depends mightily on the sale of iron ore to China, attitudes are a little more blurred. So perhaps it is not surprising that a provocative thesis  that the United States should share power with China in the Asia-Pacific region  should come from a former Australian government defense official.

title: Stumbling Blocks in Reducing Balance on a Student Loan
description: YOUVE been working hard and paying your student loans on time, and you find yourself with a bit of extra cash. So you decide that instead of spending it, youll make an extra loan payment, to whittle down your principal faster and save money on interest.

title: Ending the Shutdown
description: Congressional Republicans agreed to support plan to reopen the government about 24 hours before the Treasury was due to exhaust its borrowing authority.

title: Case Against Michigan Ban on Gay Unions Is Sent to Trial
description: DETROIT  A federal judge on Wednesday ruled that a case contesting Michigans ban on same-sex marriage would go to trial early next year, one among some 30 such challenges playing out in courthouses around the nation.

title: De Blasio Lashes Out at Lhota Over a Television Ad
description: The race for mayor of New York City entered a tenser and more incendiary phase on Wednesday, as the candidates clashed over a harsh and provocative television advertisement suggesting that the Democratic nominee, Bill de Blasio, would return the city to an era of crime, riots and graffiti-covered subway cars.

title: Dodgers Get Out of Jam and Back Into Series
description: LOS ANGELES  With the midday sun radiating warmth across Chavez Ravine and the palm trees beyond the outfield pavilions rippling slightly in the breeze as a late-arriving crowd trickled in, the ambience that typically accompanies taut playoff baseball was absent Wednesday at Dodger Stadium.

title: Sebelius Stands Firm Despite Calls to Resign
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, has no intention of bowing to Republican demands that she resign after the troubled rollout of President Obamas health care law, people close to her said Wednesday. And the White House expressed full confidence in her.

title: Second Thoughts on Voter ID
description: On Friday, Richard Posner, a highly respected federal judge, offered an unusual admission. He had made a mistake, he said, in voting to uphold one of the countrys first voter-ID laws. As courts in Texas, North Carolina and other states deal with litigation over ever-stricter versions of such laws  all enacted in the name of preventing nonexistent fraud  the question is what effect Judge Posners admirable candor could have.

title: The Disappearing Moose
description: For such large creatures, moose are a relatively hidden species. They are hard to count. They live where humans do not like to go, along the boggy fringes of northern lakes and rivers where the sound of summer mosquitoes fills the air. They thrive in cold weather, and their well-being depends on sharp, cold autumns and late springs, which protect them from their most important predator: not the wolf, but the winter tick.

title: Europe Cracks Down on Tobacco
description: The European Parliament voted last week to toughen regulations on the marketing and sale of tobacco that puts the Continent ahead of the United States in discouraging smoking, particularly among children.

title: The Republican Surrender
description: UPDATE: President Obama signed the bill reopening the government and lifting the debt ceiling early Thursday morning.

title: Photography in Service to Humanity
description: Robin Hammond just thought it was cool when he enrolled in a photography program in Wellington, New Zealand. But he soon found a serious calling as a photographer while paging through a copy of W. Eugene Smiths Minamata in his college library.

title: Effort to Evacuate Syrian Civilians Is Thwarted by Shelling
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  It seemed promising until the shelling started: under a brief cease-fire, 200 civilians were preparing to evacuate on Wednesday from a rebel-held town near Damascus that the government has blockaded for months. Their flight was arranged in a small-scale local deal that some aid workers and others hoped could become a blueprint for building trust and, perhaps, helping to end the war.

title: A Tree Grows in Canada
description: This Friday is Persons Day in Canada, a special day on the countrys calendar that commemorates, of all things, a judicial decision. It was on Oct. 18, 1929, that the Privy Council, a court in London that served then as the highest appeals court for Canada, declared women to come within the definition of persons in Canadas basic law, thus qualifying them for appointment to the national Senate. It was, Beverley McLachlin, the chief justice of Canada, said in a speech earlier this year, the beginning of a rights revolution that would transform Canadian society.

title: Republican Collapse
description: Congress has finally worked out a deal to end the government shutdown and dodge default, but not before the Republican Party demonstrated to Americans just how conflicted and dangerous it is.

title: This Is Your Brain on Toxins
description: Lead helps to guard your health.

title: At Brooklyns Domino Sugar Site, Waning Opposition to Prospect of Luxury Towers
description: It is the consummate landmark for 2013 Williamsburg: a monument of the Brooklyn neighborhoods industrial past that a developer has decided to transform into luxury high-rise buildings, knowing that people will pay to live in them for the unmatched views, the industrial-chic glamour and the neighborhood, the most up-and-coming of them all.

title: The Myth of the Medical-Device Tax
description: WASHINGTON  IN the last few days of negotiations in Congress, repeal of the Affordable Care Acts tax on medical devices emerged as a key Republican demand. The medical-device industry waged an intense lobbying campaign  even garnering the support of many Democrats who favored the law  arguing that the tax would stifle innovation and increase health care costs.

title: Search Tools Wanting on Many Exchanges
description: SHELBYVILLE, Ky.  As he was trying to sign up for health insurance through Kentuckys new online exchange this month, Kenny Wheeler hit a wall.

title: Most Regions Experienced Modest Growth
description: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserves 12 districts, according to survey results released by the Fed on Wednesday. The survey is based on information collected on or before Oct. 7.

title: Tigers May Catch Themselves by the Tail
description: DETROIT  With the Detroit Tigers leading by seven runs in the sixth inning on Wednesday, a fan in a Justin Verlander jersey tried to start a wave in the center field stands. It petered out within two or three sections, and after several attempts, the fan sat down.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 16, 2013
Snowden Journalists New Venture to Be Bankrolled by eBay Founder
description: For years, the tech billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar has been experimenting with ways to promote serious journalism, searching for the proper media platform to support with the fortune he earned as the founder of eBay. He has made grants to independent media outlets in Africa and government watchdog groups in the United States. In a more direct effort, he created a news Web site in Hawaii, his home state.

title: Lets Make a Deal
description: Well, um, yippee.

title: Door May Open for Challenge to Secret Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON  Five years after Congress authorized a sweeping warrantless surveillance program, the Justice Department is setting up a potential Supreme Court test of whether it is constitutional by notifying a criminal defendant  for the first time  that evidence against him derived from the eavesdropping, according to officials.

title: Latin America Brings Up Its Dead, Seeking Truth to Help Settle the Past
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In the aftermath of Chiles 1973 military coup, the Nobel Prize-winning poet and diplomat Pablo Neruda was found dead. Although he was long thought to have perished from prostate cancer, a judge recently ordered his remains exhumed from a grave overlooking the Pacific Ocean to investigate claims that he was poisoned.

title: Red, White and Blue Reprieve for Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  A month ago, when the United States mens soccer team handed Mexico a 2-0 defeat in Columbus, Ohio, and put Mexicos World Cup hopes in peril, the sports tabloid Esto took to English to scream shock and dismay on its front page: WHAT?

title: My Cloistered Teenage Soul
description: A few months ago, I found myself shifting nervously in the drivers seat of a parked rental car and avoiding the rearview mirror, afraid Id catch a disquieting glimpse of my adolescent self glaring back. Ive never come entirely to grips with him  or rather, Ive never entirely forgiven him his lies and his cowardice. And now that I was about to walk into my 20-year high school reunion, his ghost was unbearably palpable.

title: Jurors Gesture Livens CityTime Fraud Trial
description: There would be accusations about millions of dollars in illegal kickbacks and how fraud was at the heart of New York Citys scandal-ridden payroll modernization project. But before any of that could be heard came the matter of the juror and her middle finger.

title: Contract Employee Arrested After Dry-Ice Bombs Are Found at Los Angeles Airport
description: LOS ANGELES  For three days this week, the discovery of dry-ice bombs at Los Angeles International Airport rattled public confidence here.

title: Lhota Explains Role in Crime Data
description: There have been many disputes over who deserves credit for the steep drop in crime in New York City that began in the 1990s. There have been more than a few over who deserves credit for the creation of CompStat, the management system that was an important tool in bringing murder and mayhem under control.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 17, 2013
description: We fought the good fight. We just didnt win.

title: Booker, Winning Rocky Senate Bid, Gets a Job to Fit His Profile
description: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark easily won New Jerseys special Senate election on Wednesday, finally rising to an office that measures up to his national profile.

title: Rodriguezs Arbitration Case Resumes
description: New Yorks version of October baseball resumed on Wednesday as Alex Rodriguez returned to Park Avenue to continue his arbitration hearing on the 211-game drug suspension that Major League Baseball is trying to impose on him.

title: If the Scores Are So Low, Why Are the Games So Long?
description: DETROIT  The notion seemed contradictory, a nine-inning, 1-0 baseball game that could last almost four hours. It is a soccer score, after all, and in that sport, the game would be over in less than two hours.

title: What Kind of Senator Will Booker Be?
description: Cory Booker, the mayor of Newark and one of the best-known young politicians in America, will be the next United States senator from New Jersey.

title: Housing That's Not a Luxury
The New Look for The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Reform in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Start-Up Problems at the Health Exchanges
What Puts Young Women at Risk of Prostitution?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Loss of Privacy: The Fault Lies With Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Lessons From the Fiscal Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing a Lot to Get Little
description: WASHINGTON  For the Republicans who despise President Obamas health care law, the last few weeks should have been a singular moment to turn its problem-plagued rollout into an argument against it. Instead, in a futile campaign to strip the law of federal money, the party focused harsh scrutiny on its own divisions, hurt its national standing and undermined its ability to win concessions from Democrats. Then they surrendered almost unconditionally.

title: As Secession Talk Swells in Catalonia, Business Leaders Remain Wary of Costs
