description: SANT SADURN DANOIA, Spain  Sparkling Cava wine has become an emblem of Catalonia as one of the strongest exports from Spains northeastern region. Over the last decade, annual shipments of cava have climbed about 50 percent, to 161 million bottles.

title: Obama Speaks After Senate Passes Bill
description: President Obama thanked the leaders of both parties after the Senate voted to pass a bill that would end the government shutdown and increase the debt limit.

title: Corrections: October 17, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Those Star-Crossed Lovers, Caught Between Feuding Parents
description: Harken, all ye who have loved unwisely, to the woeful tale of Lady Capulet and her Tybalt. This little-known but intriguing tragedy, which opened on Wednesday night at Classic Stage Company, presents the devastating consequences of a Veronese noblewomans illicit passion for a younger kinsman who is called the Prince of Cats, a realm that evidently has room for cougars.

title: Can You Tell Me How to Get to Nezavisimosti Street?
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Coming up with a theme for a puzzle is the kind of thing that can happen anywhere, at any time. Most of my best ideas come to me just as Im falling asleep or waking up. Some people find that their creative juices flow best when theyre exercising. Sometimes a word or phrase gets stuck between the brain cells, and you happen to notice there is something fun and unusual about it. Thats what happened to Gary J. Whitehead. Well read more about that below.

title: Limits Approved for Genetically Modified Crops in Kauai, Hawaii
description: Legislators on the island of Kauai in Hawaii have approved a bill that would restrict the use of pesticides by companies developing genetically modified crops there.

title: Anthony Likes Idea of Becoming Free Agent
description: The Knicks have yet to start the regular season, but some of the focus is already beginning to drift toward next summer, when Carmelo Anthony is eligible to opt out of the final year of his contract. According to an article posted Wednesday on The New York Observer Web site, Anthony fully intends to do so.

title: 2 Officers Accused of Harassing Latinos Now Await Verdict
description: HARTFORD  The federal trial of two police officers accused of harassing Latinos in a Connecticut town concluded here on Wednesday with lawyers in the case presenting very different views of the officers and how they did their jobs.

title: Trial Opens for Imelda Marcoss Ex-Aide
description: When the former personal secretary to Imelda Marcos contacted a London gallery three years ago about selling a Monet masterpiece that Mrs. Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, had bought in the 1970s, the gallery was understandably leery.

title: Italy: No Solution on Burial of Ex-Nazi
description: After protests Tuesday evening halted the furtively organized funeral of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain associated with a World War II massacre, the former Nazis corpse lay Wednesday at a military airport near the capital, waiting for a resolution. Five days after Mr. Priebkes death at 100, the question of how to dispose of his remains was unresolved, after various cities in Italy, Germany and Argentina, where he lived for decades, declined to offer a final resting place. Discussions for alternative solutions continued Wednesday, a spokesman for the Rome prefecture said. The halted funeral was in the town of Albano Laziale, southeast of Rome.

title: House Votes to Approve Senate Plan
description: Hours after the Senate passed its measure, the House voted 285 to 144 to approve the Senate plan, which would fund the government through Jan. 15 and raise the debt limit through Feb. 7.

title: Odd Bedfellows in Realigned Big East Bond Over Basketball
description: Grant Gibbs is a senior point guard for Creighton, with neat brown hair and cornflower blue eyes. He was raised in Marion, a small city in eastern Iowa, where his mother was a home economics teacher at the local high school. His father works at the Quaker Oats cereal distribution factory in Cedar Rapids.

title: Central African Republic: Group Reports New Deadly Attacks
description: A new wave of attacks and killings has engulfed parts of the Central African Republic, Doctors Without Borders reported Wednesday. The organization is one of the few international aid providers that has remained in the country, which has descended into near-total chaos in the past half year. In a statement, Doctors Without Borders said more than 30,000 people had been displaced in the northwestern town of Bossangoa, and thousands more in surrounding areas.

title: Japan: Many Dead or Missing After Typhoon
description: A powerful typhoon struck eastern Japan on Wednesday, causing landslides and floods that left at least 17 people dead and 43 missing, the police said. Tokyo briefly ground to a halt as bullet trains and flights were suspended when the storm, Typhoon Wipha, swept through with strong winds and rain. At the wrecked Fukushima nuclear plant, workers released the Pacific rainwater that collected near storage tanks, but the company that operates the plant said the contamination was far below safe drinking water levels.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Seahawks (5-1) at Cardinals (3-3)
description: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

title: Hands Empty but Spirit Unbowed, House Republicans Take Stock
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner strolled into a late-afternoon meeting with House Republicans and gave them one key directive: go home after it was all over on Wednesday night and get some sleep. Their fight was done.

title: Disposal of Chemical Arms in Syria Progresses
description: Inspectors from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the agency based in The Hague that is responsible for policing a global ban, have reached 11 of Syrias 20 sites, the agency said Wednesday, and had verified their contents and begun destroying equipment at six. The work, part of a joint mission with the United Nations, advanced the process of dismantling Syrias toxic arsenal, under a Security Council resolution unanimously approved last month. President Obama had earlier threatened military strikes against Syria over theAug. 21chemical attacks near Damascus that killed hundreds of people.

title: First Task for Panel in New Playoff System: Easing Suspicions of Bias
description: IRVING, Tex.  On paper, the credentials of the 13-member college football selection committee announced Wednesday appear above reproach. Yet even as the mechanics of their mission  to seek a true Football Bowl Subdivision champion  were rolled out, officials acknowledged it would be hard for the members to be perceived as neutral enough to satisfy fans scrutiny.

title: The Ad Campaign: Far Behind, Lhota Takes a Risk
description: Confronting stagnant poll numbers and a lackluster debate performance, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor, is hoping an aggressive new advertisement can refocus the race on an issue that Republicans typically dominate: public safety.

title: Top Republicans Split on Fiscal Vote
description: The vote on the budget legislation split influential House Republicans.

title: A Teachable Moment
description: One of the themes running through my various government shutdown posts has been the importance of seeing the current wave of right-wing populism clearly and weighing its merits and demerits judiciously. That requiresunderstanding the strategic thinkingthat led to the shutdown in the first place  acknowledgingthe legitimate sense of political disappointment that underlies the rights inclination toward intransigence  and most importantly, recognizing that relative to the G.O.P. establishment (such as it is), todays right-wing populists often have better political instincts and better policy ideas.

title: Examining the Status of Irans Nuclear Program and Talks
description: Negotiators in Irans protracted nuclear dispute reported substantive and forward looking negotiations last month and said they would reconvene Nov. 7 to 8 for further talks. The following covers some questions about Irans nuclear program.

title: After Mayoral Debate, Back on the Trail
description: Bill de Blasio met Muslim supporters and Joseph J. Lhota served food at a Jewish soup kitchen on Wednesday, a day after the mayoral rivals sparred in a televised debate.

title: Bruno Metsu, 59, Dies; Led Senegal at World Cup
description: Bruno Metsu, a French soccer coach who led Senegals national team in an exhilarating and improbable run to the 2002 World Cup quarterfinals, died on Oct. 15. He was 59.

title: Week 7 N.F.L. Probabilities: Jets Over Patriots
description: What is often the most interesting thing about a statistical prediction model is discovering why the model disagrees with conventional opinion.

title: Raids to Free Minks Up Ante on Animal Rights
description: NEW HOLSTEIN, Wis.  Next to their white clapboard house on a rural road here, in long rows of cages set beneath the roofs of seven open-air sheds, Virginia and Gary Bonlander are raising 5,000 minks. Or were, anyway, until two Saturdays ago, when the police roused them from bed at 5 a.m. with a rap on their door.

title: A Syrian Refugee Familys New Life
description: Millions of Syrians have fled the civil war, scattering to neighboring countries like Jordan. Many have dreams of returning to a homeland long vanished.

title: In Chinas Campaign Against Bloggers, a Burst of Rumor-Mongering
description: The Chinese government has described its recent campaign to control online speech as an effort to stop unfounded rumors. In recent days, though, such rumors have only seemed to mushroom.

title: Disruption on the House Floor as Measure Passes
description: WASHINGTON  And just when it seemed as if things could not get any more bizarre in the Capitol, a House stenographer, shouting and protesting, was dragged off the House floor as the House voted to pass the Senate deal, 285 to 144, late Wednesday night.

title: Mayor of Chinese City Is Held by Communist Party Investigators
description: HONG KONG  Communist Party investigators have detained the mayor of Nanjing, a major city in eastern China, on allegations of grave disciplinary violations, a term that almost always refers to corruption and abuses of power, state-run news media reported on Wednesday.

title: When Renovation Means Erasing the Past
description: The fetish for destroying historic houses to feed the hunger for infinite white space has led to a global style of architectural homogeneity.

title: Everyday Jet Lag
description: This article appeared in the October 20, 2013 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Study Finds Gains From Teacher Evaluations
description: The education research of recent years has pointed overwhelmingly to the importance of teachers. Perhaps more than anything else  quality of principal, size of school, size of class  the strength or weakness of classroom teachers influences how much students learn and even how they fare later in life.

title: Brazils Protests, on and Off the Wall
description: Not long after 2 a.m. last Sunday, some 30 photographers and friends swept the downtown dust off two walls that closed in a small but busy street near So Paulos Luz subway station. They had just slathered glue onto several large photos and were about to paste them onto the walls when the police showed up and asked what they were doing.

title: Word of the Day | aristocracy
description: aristocracy \a-r-st-kr-se, er--\ noun

title: Tigers Change Their Lineup and Their Luck
description: DETROIT  Jim Leyland lay on his couch late Tuesday night, watching the Cardinals-Dodgers game, and thought about his team.

title: Hong Kong Rents Soar, Squeezing Out Small Shops
description: On a busy intersection in the crowded Hong Kong neighborhood of Sheung Wan  among dried-seafood traders, hardware stores and clothing shops  a trio of shops has been shuttered for the last few weeks: a tiny flower shop, a wine-and-tobacco store and a fruit vendor who mixed juices for passers-by to consume on the narrow sidewalk.

title: Following the Fiscal Crisis
description: Congressional Republican leaders conceded defeat in their budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law after the government shut down for 16 days.

title: President Signs Bill; Employees Told to Return to Work
description: About 12:30, President Obama signed the measure passed by the Senate and the House to reopen the government and extend federal borrowing power. Earlier, the Office of Management and Budget said federal employees should return to work on Thursday.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 9 P.M. (USA) WHITE COLLAR Season 5 opens with the F.B.I. agent Peter Burke (Tim DeKay) behind bars after being accused of murdering a senator  forcing Neal Caffrey (Matt Bomer, above left with Willie Garson) to return to his con man roots to set the record straight and overturn the charges. A new round of Covert Affairs, at 10, begins as Annie Walker (Piper Perabo) sheds the life she knew to operate off the grid in pursuit of Henry Wilcox (Gregory Itzin).

title: News Quiz | October 17, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: As China Mocks U.S. Debt Fight, Its Loyalty to Treasuries Remains
description: Updated, 7:00 a.m. | China reacted to Congress deal avoiding a debt default for now with welcomes, warnings and mockery on Thursday. It took a retired official to emphasize the awkward fact that China has little choice but to stay shackled to the dollar  for now.

title: Japanese Leader Rejects Appearance at War Shrine
description: TOKYO  For a third time this year, Japans prime minister, Shinzo Abe, refused supporters calls to visit a controversial Tokyo war shrine on Thursday, sending a ceremonial offering instead in what was apparently an effort to avoid angering Asian neighbors, including China.

title: Chinese Leader Gets a Cartoon Makeover
description: Chinas new leader, Xi Jinping, has brought a more down-to-earth style to the job than his famously formal predecessor, Hu Jintao. But a new animated video portrays Mr. Xi and the rest of Chinas ruling Politburo Standing Committee in a light far more playful than typically seen in China.

title: Chinas Anticorruption Czar: Its Lonely Being Honest
description: Another tiger falls.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 17, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: Are Women Better at Compromising and Collaborating?
description: Women make up less than 20 percent of Congress, yet they have emerged from the budget standoff as the real team players in Washington. According to a front-page article this week, a small group of female senators were the leaders in a bipartisan effort that paved the way to end the government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling.

title: The Long March of the American Right
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Chinese to Invest in British Nuclear Power
description: LONDON  Britain said on Thursday that it would allow Chinese firms to buy stakes in British nuclear power plants and eventually acquire majority holdings.

title: CMJ: Despite Frustrations, Guitars Impress on Day 2
description: At least I got my guitar blare. Day 2 of this years CMJ Music Marathon was full of frustrations: some to do with the inaccurate online schedule  really, phantom sets by bands I wanted to see? Doesnt anyone update these? Also frustrating were the travel times between the Lower East Side and Brooklyn. And then there were the baby bands who had decided  even before the release of a debut album  what their songwriting formula was and were determinedly playing sets of formula songs. I wont slam them here; may they remember when they considered themselves creative.

title: New York Today: The Ex-Mayors
description: Updated 12:01 p.m. | What do New York City mayors do after leaving office?

title: Wheres That Advance Care Directive?
description: Nancy Wagner, a social worker at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J., encounters this frustration at least once a week: A patient arrives in the emergency room and tells the inquiring staff that yes, she has indeed prepared and signed an advance directive. But, well, she doesnt have it with her.

title: Driving Through Manhattan in a Huge R.V.
description: Navigating New York City streets in a normal vehicle can be trying enough. When the roads arent an awful patchwork of lumpy asphalt and haphazard steel plates, thick clusters of pedestrians crowd into the right-of-way at intersections, making your path look like a canyon thats slowly closing in upon itself.

title: Divided We Stand
description: JERUSALEM Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, the Israeli spiritual and political leader whodied on Oct. 7at 93, was buried by an astonishing number of mourners. The official police tally at the day of the funeral estimated the figure at800,000;the number was then revised, by the police itself, to about 400,000.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Shifts Its Rules on Privacy for Teenagers
description: Facebook has loosened its privacy rules for teenagers as a rising debate swirls over online threats to children from online bullies and sexual predators, Vindu Goel reports.

title: If Not Now, When?
description: LONDON  It is possible to imagine a scenario more favorable to Israel than the current one, but it is not easy.

title: Africas Trauma Epidemic
description: LAGOS  It was dusk and I was on my way home from Abeokuta, a vibrant city in southwest Nigeria. My driver had switched off the cars air-conditioning so I could open the windows and feel the breeze. He was weaving between potholes in the road when suddenly, the scene ahead changed.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Government Shutdown Ends After 16 Days
description: In the article Republicans Back Down, Ending Crisis Over Shutdown and Debt Limit, Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker report on the final negotiations that ended the fiscal impasse in Washington.

title: Investors Fear the Next Political Battle
description: Investor relief on Wednesday at the last-minute agreement to raise the nations borrowing limit and end the government shutdown was tempered by the knowledge that the deal did not represent a permanent solution to the budget crises that have become more frequent in recent years, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Under the deal, the government will be financed through Jan. 15 and the Treasury will have borrowing powers until Feb. 7  at which point sharp political divisions could re-emerge.

title: What A Drag
description: As many people have been pointing out, the economic costs of GOP attempts to rule by extortion didnt begin with the shutdown/debt crisis, and havent ended with the (temporary?) resolution of that crisis. The now widely-cited Macroeconomic Advisers report estimated the cost of crisis-driven fiscal policy at 1 percentage point off the growth rate for three years, or roughly 3 percent now. More than half of this estimated cost comes from the fiscal drag of falling discretionary spending, with the rest coming from a (shaky) estimate of the impacts of fiscal uncertainty on borrowing costs.

title: Key to Ants Evolution May Have Started With a Wasp
description: How should we judge the success of an animal? Philip S. Ward, a biologist at the University of California, Davis, offers what could be called the Picnic Test. Have a picnic anywhere in the world, he suggests. Who would pick up the crumbs?

title: The Blood and Tears, Not the Magnolias
description: 12 Years a Slave isnt the first movie about slavery in the United States  but it may be the one that finally makes it impossible for American cinema to continue to sell the ugly lies its been hawking for more than a century. Written by John Ridley and directed by Steve McQueen, it tells the true story of Solomon Northup, an African-American freeman who, in 1841, was snatched off the streets of Washington, and sold. Its at once a familiar, utterly strange and deeply American story in which the period trappings long beloved by Hollywood  the paternalistic gentry with their pretty plantations, their genteel manners and all the fiddle-dee-dee rest  are the backdrop for an outrage.

title: Air Pollution Linked to Lower Birth Weights
description: Air pollution, even at relatively low levels, is associated with a significant increase in the risk for low-birth-weight babies, a new study has found.

title: Fall in Revenue at Goldman Sachs Raises Concerns
description: Updated, 5:53 p.m. | Among Goldman Sachs employees, the chatter started months ago that 2013 was going to be a good bonus year. The Wall Street bank began the year strong, and despite concerns about the economy, its profit doubled over year-ago levels in the second quarter.

title: Today in Small Business: A Restaurant Offers Congress a Special Price (Double)
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Man Group Reports First Net Inflows in 2 Years
description: LONDON  The Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund, reported its first quarterly net inflows of money in two years on Thursday, as clients became more confident about a global economic recovery.

title: Morning on the PATH Train
description: Dear Diary:

title: If You Like a Star Athlete, Now You Can Buy a Share
description: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | First, there was old-fashioned gambling on football. Then came the fantasy leagues. And now, thanks to Wall Street, fans can buy a stake in their favorite player.

title: Blackstone Earnings Rose 3% in Third Quarter
description: Real estate and investment banking helped propel the Blackstone Group to yet another profitable quarter.

title: Syrian Official Says Peace Talks Could Be Held in Late November
description: LONDON  A Syrian government official said on Thursday that long-postponed peace talks under international auspices  known in diplomatic shorthand as Geneva II  could be held in late November, raising speculation about who would attend and who would represent the fractured Syrian opposition, which is seeking to topple President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Government Gets Back to Business, but Effects of the Shutdown Linger
description: WASHINGTON  The United States government sputtered back to life Thursday after President Obama and Congress ended a 16-day shutdown, reopening tourist spots and clearing the way for federal agencies to deliver services and welcome back hundreds of thousands of furloughed workers.

title: Quality Preschool Is the Most Cost-Effective Educational Intervention
description: A decade or so ago, when it was time to send my children to preschool, it never occurred to me to do anything else. For an upper-middle-class family like mine, enrolling my kids in a half-day nursery school program with all of its benefits (socialization and school readiness, among them) was a no-brainer.

title: Donna Tartt: By the Book
description: The author of The Goldfinch and The Secret History says that personally, to paraphrase Nabokov: all I want from a book is the tingle down the spine, for my hairs to stand on end.

title: Transmuting Forms, Click by Click
description: Robert Rauschenberg, an artist of towering achievement, painted not only with the brush. He also employed, in his works on canvas, the photographs he took throughout his life, as well as found objects. Although the progression of his work aligns with Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism, Pop Art and Conceptual Art, no one movement can claim him. Rauschenberg said that when it came to photography, the camera is the transport for my eye and carries my seeing from place to place.

title: Why Dont More Owners Open Their Books?
description: This is something I have never understood. Why is it that we business owners are so reluctant to share financial information with employees? For more than 35 years Ive found that, when I share meaningful information with the people who work with me, our performance as a company improves. The process of sharing a companys financial performance is known as open-book management.

title: For Brian OKelley of AppNexus, Learning Never Stops
description: This interview with Brian OKelley, chief executive of AppNexus, an advertising technology company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: As Public Monuments Crumble, Private Aid Seen as Possible Savior
description: NEW DELHI  On a recent afternoon, Hari Om, a 25-year-old craftsman from Dholpur district in Rajasthan, was chiseling star-shaped patterns on blocks of red sandstone near the Humayuns Tomb, a 16th-century monument built by the Mughals in New Delhi. He is one among 1,500 craftsmen who worked on the restoration of the ancient structure.

title: Poetry Pairing | Raking Near the Great Works
description: As the autumn foliage reaches its peak in parts of the United States, we present this timely Poetry Pairing. It features Raking Near the Great Works, a poem by Megan Grumbling, and the article Pedal Peepers in Vermont by Katie Zezima.

title: A New Book, to Be Given Away, Documents the Wrath of Hurricane Sandy
description: After Hurricane Sandy swept through the region, people wandered the Rockaways like zombies, cloaked in blankets to protect against the mid-autumn chill. Families were left traumatized by homes reduced to skeletons. For weeks, the elderly and disabled, trapped in their apartments on high floors, waited for food and heat.

title: G.E. Smith and Jorma Kaukonen Not Enough? Bring Your Own Guitar
description: More than 150 guitarists  among them, Mark Stewart, G.E. Smith, David Broza, Captain Kirk Douglas and, by a Skype link, Jorma Kaukonen  will join forces at the City Winery on Nov. 17 for the Guitar Mash Benefit Concert and Jam. The ensemble will also include some high-profile amateur pickers like Tom Colicchio, the celebrated chef, and Chad Smith, who is better known as a drummer (for the Red Hot Chili Peppers). The concert, in its second year, will raise money for music education programs, including those run by the Church Street School for Music and Arts and Little Kids Rock, a program that offers music workshops in public schools.

First, Stepan returned to the game and said afterward that he was O.K., and second, the Rangers scrupulously followed concussion treatment protocol.

Why are the seats like this? she asked, turning this way and that. Is this a luxury theater?

The initial production played 3,242 performances, the longest-running show on Broadway for years. There have been four Broadway revivals and countless national tours; some 200 schools across the country put it on each year.

title: Going on a Burmese-Food Diet in the Bay Area
description: Burmese food has been an undeserved straggler in the American hierarchy of Asian cuisines; in New York City, as far as I can tell, we only have one dedicated Burmese restaurant. But things are slowly changing as Myanmar, the country formerly known as Burma, has finally opened to foreign tourists, and Burma: Rivers of Flavor, a deeply researched and sumptuously photographed cookbook by Naomi Duguid, has made the wider world more conscious of the cuisine, which mixes influences of China, India and Thailand with traditions from its own varied ethnic groups.

I had no interest in flying, she said. That was definitely something I didnt want to do.

That was the conclusion that many Republicans drew from the defeat of Mitt Romney in 2012. And now that Republicans in Congress have been forced to surrender in their fight with President Obama over the budget, health care and the nations credit, some are drawing the same conclusion.

title: Market Report | Whats Black and White and Swirled All Over?
description: Marble  the ho-hum black-and-white pattern, rather than the material  is getting a face-lift. Balenciaga printed icy variations onto the soft silk of a T-shirt and the structured leather of a pair of pumps, and Josh Goot used it on a silk skirt that looks like its made of actual stone. Other designers showcased the pattern in the precious materials of jewels and accessories. Lele Sadoughi created a classic bracelet with the timeless motif; Monique Pan encrusted rough, marbled agate with a showstopping design of shiny pav diamonds; Ralph Lauren used antique-looking shades of marble for a modern iteration of standby tortoiseshell sunglasses; and Stella McCartney contrasted the bold, geometric lines of a clutch with swirling lines of black and white.

title: Belgian Brewery Buys U.S. Maker of Craft Beers
description: As European interest in American craft beers begins to mirror the mania for them stateside, the Duvel Moortgat Brewery of Belgium on Thursday announced a deal to buy the Boulevard Brewing Company, a craft brewery in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Authorities Worry 3-D Printers May Undermine Europes Gun Laws
description: PARIS  The gun fired four shots into a gelatin block. Each nine-millimeter bullet punched deep into the substance, which was meant to mimic the density of a human body.

title: U.S. Judge Denies Bid by Lhota Supporters to Accept Unlimited Donations
description: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a bid by a conservative group supporting the mayoral candidacy of Joseph J. Lhota to accept unlimited contributions, saying it would be too disruptive to change New Yorks campaign fund-raising laws less than three weeks before Election Day.

title: Readers Ask How Insurance Subsidies Are Calculated for Students
description: In two recent installments of the Your Money column, I answered questions about the new health insurance exchanges. The first column discussed many of the basics, and the second column answered reader queries. You can find more readers questions and answers on In Practice, with the latest series below. If youre still not sure how the law affects you and your family, please e-mail me: tsbernard@nytimes.com.

description: Laurie Goodstein covers one of the most scrutinized beats at The Times. As national religion correspondent, her recent articles on Pope Francis have been the topic of plenty of conversation and discussion  and have had very heavy readership.

description: Cleopatras Needle draws a dedicated bunch to its Sunday afternoon jazz open mike.

title: The Challenge of Diabetes for Doctor and Patient
description: My patient was miserable  parched with thirst, exhausted and jumping up to go to the bathroom every few minutes. His vision was blurry and hed been losing weight the last few weeks, despite eating voraciously. Id only just met him, but I was able to diagnose diabetes in about a minute. What was unusual was that this was a scheduled office visit; usually, patients with such overwhelming symptoms are the provenance of emergency departments and urgent care centers.

title: Was It All Boehners Fault?
description: As a follow-up to my post on the lessons of the shutdown, and my insistence on the essentially indefensible folly of what weve just witnessed from House Republicans, let me say something aboutthe alternative interpretation thats come up in a number of mini-debates Ive had on Twitter over the last week or so, with conservative writers like the Weekly Standards Jay Cost and Sean Davis of the nascent webzine The Federalist. Against my indictment of the Republican caucus as a whole, theyve basically argued that the seeming irrationality of G.O.P. strategy across the last few weeks mostly just reflects the mistakes, shading into incompetence, of John Boehners negotiating strategy, rather the kind of deeper, essentially methodless dysfunction that I see when I look at the House Republicans.At bottom, these interlocutors think that the House Republicans are a fairly normal majority with a serious leadership problem, and they think Im a victim of what you might call the pundits limited-horizon problem, which fails to work in vitally-useful knowledge political science research in Costs case, business-school theory in Daviss case that would pin more of the responsibility on Boehner, and less on his backbenchers. (You can also read a more personalized version of this argument here, from the pseudonymous blogger Thomas Crown, which is based on a slight misreading of a tweet I wrote to Davis  such are the perils of Twitter! but which works off the entirely correct assumption that my analysis of internal House dynamics lacks the benefit of sustained personal experience with high-stakes negotiations in politics, law or the business world.)

title: Frites Show
description: The life of a Balthazar potato, from farm to fry.

title: James Franco, Chris ODowd Likely for Of Mice and Men on Broadway
description: The Oscar-nominated actor James Franco (127 Hours) is set to make his Broadway debut this spring as George in a revival of John Steinbecks Of Mice and Men, possibly opposite Chris ODowd (Bridesmaids, Girls) as Lennie, a person directly involved with the production said on Thursday. The 1937 play, like the classic novella by Steinbeck, depicts the friendship of the big-dreaming George and the mentally limited Lennie, migrant field workers in California during the Great Depression.

description: WUHAN, China  Chinese automakers are starting to ask some of the largest Western auto parts companies to supply parts that meet American and European regulatory standards, according to senior executives at the parts companies.

title: Chopsticks and Challah
description: Manischewitz and bubbly is the drink at hand, blushing darkly in a flute glass with a jag of lemon peel. It is a play on a kir royale, with the syrupy Sabbath dinner wine subbing for crme de cassis. It could be a gimmick, but it works: the sparkler, Palmer Brut from Long Island, is fruity and expansive, smoothing over Manischewitzs neurotic sweetness.

title: Standards, and Regulars

You start to notice the sheet music at the elbow of nearly everyone else at the long S-shaped bar  the slim blonde; the big guy with glasses; the man with the wide Harry Belafonte forehead. Youre at Cleopatras Needle, an Upper West Side fixture thats been serving Middle Eastern food and a daily helping of live music for more than 20 years at 2485 Broadway, at 92nd Street, and this is jazz open mike on Sunday afternoon.

title: An American in Paris Is Planned for Paris, and May Head West to Broadway

title: Decades Later, Condemnation for a Skid Row Cancer Study

title: Learning to Lean In Together

title: The Strong, Largely Silent Type
description: True solitude is a rarity at the movies, for those of us in the audience contending with yakkers and texters, and for the people on screen as well. The lonesome strangers of the old westerns almost always had a town to ride into or out of, a buzz of social life to contrast with their individualistic ways. Even movies that emphasize the isolation of their main characters tend to provide them with companions, human or otherwise. Piscine Patel in Life of Pi had his tiger, Richard Parker; Chuck Noland in Cast Away had Wilson the volleyball. Those guys did a lot of talking, even when nobody else was around.

title: Misleading Numbers on 401(k)s

title: Avoiding a Foul
description: A few years ago, my husband left me after I discovered his series of extramarital affairs. One of his trysts was with a local soccer mom. Her young son plays on the same team as mine; they live on the same block as us, and we travel in the same social circles. (She remains in her marriage; my ex is not present in our lives.) I feel great resentment about her role in the dissolution of my marriage. I think a confrontation is in order, but the soccer field does not seem right. Any ideas?

title: Seems This Anarchist Is a Laptop Hogger
description: At the very end of The Fifth Estate, the filmmakers offer their subject, the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, a chance at pre-emptive rebuttal. Not the actual Assange, of course, but the actor Benedict Cumberbatch, with platinum locks and an Aussie accent providing an uncanny simulacrum. Asked what he thinks of the WikiLeaks movie, Assange snorts that its more like the anti-WikiLeaks movie, bashes the books its based on and casts imperious doubt on its accuracy.

title: Google Tops Estimates, but Prices of Ads Slide
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For more than a decade, Googles search advertising business has seemed almost magical in its ability to mint money. But the magic is beginning to wear off as people spend more time on mobile devices, where the company makes less money on ads.

title: Old Informs New at Dual Frieze Fairs in London
description: LONDON  Minutes after the Frieze Art Fair opened here Wednesday morning for V.I.P. collectors, Mark Fisch, a New York real estate developer, paused in front of a table at the booth of a Berlin gallery called Contemporary Fine Arts. On display were 10 carefully arranged replicas of Greek and Roman objects  urns, vases and animals  each copied from works at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where Mr. Fisch happens to be on the board. Fashioned from Play-Doh, they were made this year by the Bruce High Quality Foundation, a Brooklyn artist collective, and were included in a recent retrospective of the collectives work at the Brooklyn Museum. Now the faux antiquities are priced at $6,500 to $38,000 each.

title: Throwaways, Put Together Just So
description: Almost anything, even the most banal object, can be beautiful if you see it in the right way. If youre not good at seeing that way, it helps to have someone present things to you in certain arrangements. Thats where the sculptor Tony Feher comes in. A much-admired but less-than-famous New York artist (born in Albuquerque in 1956), Mr. Feher organizes the kinds of things that most people throw away into simple but surprisingly exciting configurations.

title: Report That Turkey Exposed Spies Strains Its Relations With Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Persistently strained relations between Israel and Turkey have not been helped by a report that last year Turkey revealed to Iran the identities of up to 10 Iranians who had spied for Israel.

title: Protests After France Expels 2 Immigrant Students
description: PARIS  Shock over Frances recent expulsion of a 19-year-old Armenian student and a 15-year-old Kosovar girl, whom the police took off a school bus so that she and her family could be sent back to Kosovo, gathered momentum on Thursday with protests by students condemning the deportations and calling for the resignation of the interior minister.

title: Seafood, Without Going Overboard
description: The first time I visited Bistro 146, a one-year-old seafood restaurant in Pleasantville, I was with a friend whose wife has nicknamed him the Outraged Consumer. He is not easy to please, and sure enough, the evening did not start out well.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Washington, Malta, Afghanistan and Chile.

title: Its Not Nice to Fool the Bullied Daughter
description: The last time we saw Carrie White, she was looking a little, well, red around the gills. She had just taken a splashy blood bath in Brian De Palmas 1976 horror freakout Carrie, and then settled in for what looked like the big sleep. Stephen Kings tormented teenager proved a restless soul, though, and returned in a 2002 television movie and a short-lived 1988 Broadway musical that was revived off Broadway again in 2012. Now shes back, as they like to say in movie ads, in a fine, largely faithful screen remake, directed by Kimberly Peirce that stars Chlo Grace Moretz as its goddess of gore. Its hard to keep a franchise crazy down, especially one that can be retrofitted for todays fears.

title: 'Attention'
description: The latest ad from the de Blasio campaign features Mr. de Blasio's daughter, Chiara.

title: How It Felt to Be Caught in the Act
description: There was a time on Broadway when to be Hirschfelded meant youd earned the right to burst out the stage door and scream, I made it!  Al Hirschfeld, who died in 2003 at 99, was a master illustrator whose line drawings were highly coveted by performers who dreamed of being depicted in his signature squiggles and swoops. During a career that spanned over 80 years, his work appeared in the pages of The New York Times, on the walls of the Museum of Modern Art and on album covers, movie posters and postage stamps.

title: It Really Was All Germanys Fault
description: In 1962, when Barbara Tuchman published The Guns of August, her Pulitzer Prize-winning account of the opening of World War I, she found a ready reader in President John F. Kennedy. As the Cuban missile crisis unfolded, the book confirmed the presidents belief that war was more likely to break out by accident than by design, and in the folly of a brinkmanship that leaves no fallback position short of actually fighting.

title: On View | Where Diet Cola Is the New Paint
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Posters Lost to Nazis Are Recovered, and Up for Sale
description: Two poster collections that were lost to their owners under Nazi rule in the 1930s are now for sale in Manhattan. Each collection is made up of thousands of pieces, many of them bearing the signatures of designers as prominent as Alphonse Mucha or Gustav Klimt.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: TV Talk: The Walking Dead
description: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss The Walking Dead and the shows outstanding viewership.

title: The Pre-emptive Rate Lock
description: Fixed mortgage rates inched upward as the federal budget deadline loomed. Now that the budget stalemate is over, however, borrowers getting ready to apply for home loans shouldnt wait around for the still-reasonable rates to drop  lock in the best rate you can get, industry experts say.

title: After Cutting a Deal, McConnell Draws Criticism From All Sides
description: With Congress stuck in a bitter dispute over fiscal matters, there seemed to be no good solution for Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader up for re-election next year. Forge a compromise and risk attack from a primary opponent on the right. Block a deal and give fodder to a general election opponent on the left.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Nokias Moves to Wearable Tech, and Bezoss League of Shadows
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Following in the Wake of Oars and Paintbrush
description: PHILADELPHIA  WHEN rowers descend here next weekend for the Thomas Eakins Head of the Schuylkill Regatta, theyll be racing in a riverscape brought to life in Eakinss celebrated rowing paintings.

title: Two Boys Schooling, for 13 Years of It
description: Late in the documentary American Promise, one of its directors, Michle Stephenson, sits next to her adolescent son, Idris  one of the movies subjects  as he reads a disheartening e-mail. Theyve been opening college admissions notices and wading through some bad news. The two are shown separately and together, and at times in close-up. (Participants either talk directly to the camera  and sometimes to the various silent camera persons, who are introduced in the final credits  or avoid its gaze.) You can see every flicker in their faces, which allows you to notice and think about the glassiness in Idriss eyes. He never cries, but you may find yourself on the verge.

title: A Gala for Brass in Brooklyn
description: The Miser finds it curious that despite the wide diversity of its musical offerings, New York isnt especially known for its brass bands.

title: His Subject, Himself
description: American anti-Semitism, which was running high throughout the 1930s, steadily increased after the onset of war. During the entire period, polls showed, well over a third of the populace stood ready to back discriminatory laws. Nor was this a mere offshoot of the general xenophobia spawned by isolationism. Every synagogue in Washington Heights was desecrated (and some were smeared with swastikas); in Boston, beatings, wreckings and defilements had become near-daily occurrences by 1942. The disgraceful fever, which ruled out all but a trickle of immigration and so cost countless lives, reached its historic apogee in 1944  by which time the Holocaust was more or less complete.

title: Fame and Infamy
description: It could be said that Norman Mailer was a man and a writer halfway between fame and infamy and yet with little in the way of middle ground. He was, in varying combinations, a world-class drinker, feuder, provocateur, self-mythologizer and anti-feminist. He was a war protester, a mayoral candidate, a co-founder of The Village Voice, as well as a wife stabber, a serial husband (of six wives), and a father (of nine). He was a boxer, an actor, a filmmaker, a poet and a playwright. He was also a journalist and a novelist of enormous and singular narrative inventiveness and thrust, a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, and one of the least boring and most tireless and tiresome public figures of the last half of the 20th century.

title: With Mall Reopened, Tourists Return
description: WASHINGTON  The National Mall hummed back to life on Thursday as National Park Service employees carted away barricades, skimmed debris from fountains and passed lawnmowers over neglected grass.

title: The Dakotas Cousins and How They Grew
description: Oh, the Dakota this, the Dakota that. Sometimes its as if the Dakota were the only apartment building in New York!

title: Have I Got a Movie for You
description: For anyone interested in Hollywood deal-making, James Tobacks documentary Seduced and Abandoned provides the vicarious thrill of being at the table. You listen as financial movers and shakers coldly calculate the box-office potential of a project half-jokingly pitched by Mr. Toback and his sidekick, Alec Baldwin, as Last Tango in Tikrit.

title: After 15 Years, Still a Mix of Dance and Dare
description: During the first half of the Silk Road Ensembles concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, the audience behaved impeccably. Its members assumed what George Bernard Shaw would have called their churchiest expression and held back applause until the end of each work. Then came Shane Shanahans percussion solo in Giovanni Sollimas Taranta Project.

title: Jaded, Maybe, but Not Ready for Vegas
description: The problems with Paradise, Diablo Codys first directing effort and fourth produced screenplay, begin almost immediately as its damaged heroine, the ickily named Lamb (Julianne Hough), sits on a beach and  in singularly annoying voice-over  catches us up on her life so far. This cheap trick might help Ms. Cody avoid actually showing us things, but it doesnt bode well for whats to come.

title: Into a Galaxy of New Pieces, Jittery to Enigmatic
description: The San Francisco Ballet, led by the artistic director Helgi Tomasson, is a national treasure, prized for its dancers along with its fervent insistence on commissioning new ballets. For its first visit to New York in five years, the companys two-week season showcases four mixed-bill programs, a rarity in a time when story ballets sell. (There is one scheduled, but its not the same-old: the New York premiere of Christopher Wheeldons Cinderella is next week.)

title: New York Soda Ban to Go Before States Top Court
description: The battle over big sodas is not yet finished.

title: In Store | L.A.-Made Handbags That Feel Right at Home in New York
description: The leather goods designer and retailer Clare Vivier is one of the most prominent ambassadors of the new Los Angeles fashion scene. Yet her bags are especially well suited to the demands of life in New York. The line, recently rebranded as Clare V., is polished enough for a party, but not too precious for the subway  auxiliary pouches and pockets cleverly accommodate gadgets or spare pairs of shoes. New York is full of working women who want to look chic while being prepared for all sorts of situations, Vivier said. Those women can now find the entire Clare V. range at the brands second boutique and first East Coast outpost, which opens tonight in a former dressmakers shop on Elizabeth Street in NoLIta. Walking into the space feels like being transported to California, thanks to its airy, light-flooded interior (by the L.A.-based architect Barbara Bestor, who also designed Viviers Silver Lake flagship) and its mostly SoCal-sourced lifestyle goods (jewelry by Annie Costello Brown, hats by Westbrook Maker, scented candles from the Chateau Marmont). Monograms, a Vivier signature, can be embossed on the spot. Also on view, and worth a visit in its own right, is a colorful nine-foot-wide collage wall by the New York florist and artist Simone Shubuck, a close friend of Viviers for 20 years.

title: Reopening Is Hit-and-Miss in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  Government workers streamed into the John C. Kluczynski Federal Building in downtown Chicago on Thursday morning. Many of them, clutching takeout coffee, said they were late for their first day back and expected a daunting backlog of work.

title: Oil Companies Are Sued for Waste of Natural Gas
description: HOUSTON  In the sharpest challenge yet to the surge in flaring of natural gas in the Bakken shale oil field, North Dakota mineral owners this week filed 10 class-action lawsuits seeking millions of dollars in lost royalties from some of the nations largest oil companies.

title: A Boundless Appetite for a Universe of Sound
description: After a remarkable trilogy of concert films with Neil Young, the latest music documentary from Jonathan Demme, Enzo Avitabile Music Life, turns the spotlight on the mushier notion of world music. Not that the sounds of all nations gathered by the Neapolitan musician and groove ambassador Enzo Avitabile, the films focus, dont have soul. But the fuzziness of Mr. Avitabiles sentiments on boundary-blind unity is echoed in the movies slack, tag-along portraiture.

title: Where Even the Peaches Are Charred
description: Oak + Almond may be an offbeat name for a restaurant, but its location is familiar to many: next to the Department of Motor Vehicles in Norwalk, at the Wilton border. The owners, Jon Paul Pirraglia and his sister Johanna Gannon, worked at the Tuscan Oven, which their parents ran for years at the same site.

title: A Gene That Doesnt Recede
description: With a cocked eyebrow and a sly grin that with a slight curl of a lip can turn into a nasty scowl, Danny Huston portrays Jack Hussar, a reasonable facsimile of his father, the famed director John Huston, in 2 Jacks. Depending on your perspective, this satirical comedy about Hollywood nepotism and wheeling and dealing, adapted from Leo Tolstoys early short novel Two Hussars, is either a sons revenge or a tribute.

title: What I Love | Deepak Chopra
description: Deepak Chopras Midtown West apartment is as much a tribute to his cultural heritage as it is an expression of his spiritual beliefs.

title: Deepak Chopra: An Inner Stillness, Even on the Subway
description: Deepak Chopra, the controversial New Age guru and booster of alternative medicine, lives just below the penthouse on the 69th floor of a Midtown West condominium. The long elevator ride gives fellow residents like P. Diddy abundant opportunity to buttonhole the good doctor and seek guidance about their mantra and yoga issues. Sometimes, the encounter even results in a house call. They invite me for a cocktail or to teach them meditation and I go, said Dr. Chopra, an internist by training. What the heck.

title: A Zest for Peril and Playfulness
description: Whatever the economic challenges facing classical music, there is no shortage of superb young artists eager to enter the field. In recent years, the Ebne Quartet, comprising four young men based in Paris, emerged as the most exciting new string quartet to come out of France. Now another Paris-based ensemble, the Herms Quartet, is ready to take its place in the new generation.

title: Where Love Coexists With Death
description: Rocky Braat, a few years into his career as a graphic designer, quit to seek authenticity (his word) by traveling to India, as so many young Americans have done before him. But his jaunt is different. After a chance stop to visit a home for children with H.I.V., he decided to stay. What compels him to remain there, working at the home, today?

title: Nuggets of Frontier Greed and Justice
description: The Discovery Channel is teaching a pretty good lesson in moneys power to make human beings behave badly, with a four-part documentary about the California gold rush called Gold Fever. In recounting the story of that mid-1800s stampede westward in search of quick wealth, the program serves up one historical tidbit after another that seems like an allegory about the toll greed takes.

title: Europe Moves to Shield Citizens Data
description: BRUSSELS  Lawmakers here have introduced a measure in the European Parliament that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking private data.

title: Two Challengers to Chardonnay
description: Pinot blanc and viognier, grapes that flourish in Europe, play minor roles in Long Island vineyards. Both yield food-friendly, dry whites that harmonize especially well with fish and shellfish from the regions waters.

title: Boston Tourists Make Up for Lost Time
description: BOSTON  For the first time in 16 days, tourists on Thursday spilled into the Charlestown Navy Yard, the national historic park that contains the U.S.S. Constitution, the worlds oldest commissioned warship that is still afloat.

title: A Day in the Life of a Ghost
description: Call it one kind of hell on earth: In Haunter, 15-year-old Lisa is the only member of her Reagan-era suburban family who realizes that they are reliving the same day, over and over. Yet, unlike Bill Murrays weatherman in Groundhog Day, they are absolutely, positively dead. And the lingering menace in this serviceable ghost story from the director Vincenzo Natali and the screenwriter Brian King is that things could actually get worse.

title: Executing Italian Civilians Was Terrible for Executioners, Nazi Said Before Death
description: As officials in Italy continue to search for a solution to the problem of where to bury the body of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who died in Rome last week under house arrest, the voice of the unrepentant Nazi was heard in a video interview released on Thursday by his lawyer.

title: In Key Races, No Sure Thing on G.O.P. End
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Comedy Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Modern Art and the Metropolis
description: A look at an exhibition of works by the French modernist Fernand Lger, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: University of Illinois Acquires Gwendolyn Brooks Archives
description: The University of Illinois Rare Book and Manuscript Library has acquired the archives of the poet Gwendolyn Brooks.

title: Take It, and Run With It
description: The question isnt whether The Birthday Boys is funny. The question is whether you can stand any more sketch comedy with a white male sensibility.

title: The City as a Muse
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Fernand Lger show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art is not your typical single-star vehicle. Its title  Lger: Modern Art and the Metropolis  may feature only the big name of this French Modernist painter. But the show itself teems with so much work by other artists that it has the mood of a crowded, high-spirited, sometimes confusing reunion.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Only an Exterminator Can Save the World
description: Asking a bug, even a very large one, to carry your whole movie seems as if it ought to be against animal cruelty codes, but thats just what Big Ass Spider! does. The makers of this humorless horror comedy seemed to think that the mere existence of a gigantic, humanity-threatening spider would be enough.

title: Snowden Says He Took No Secret Files to Russia
description: WASHINGTON  Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, said in an extensive interview this month that he did not take any secret N.S.A. documents with him to Russia when he fled there in June, assuring that Russian intelligence officials could not get access to them.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: In New York, Looking Forward to a Paycheck
description: Office workers poured in and out of the imposing building at 26 Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan on Thursday morning. Some had been deemed essential and had worked through the shutdown, but others were eager to get back to the job  and start being paid again.

title: A Crushed Spirit, Healed by the Whispers of Angels
description: There.

title: A New Line | Whimsical Objects, Imported From the Island of Hydra Straight to Fifth Avenue
description: Beginning today, a 10-piece collection of jewelry by the Greek designer Elena Votsi, who has stores in Athens and Hydra (where the pieces are made), will be available for the first time stateside at Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue. In the short film above, A Day in Hydra with Elena Votsi, the artisan, who designed the medal for the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, discusses her own history and design inspiration for the rings, necklaces and earrings that she likens to objects, like toys, that can be as fun alone as they are on the body. Its no wonder, then, that included among her selection of work at Bergdorf Goodman is a gold ball ring that resembles a babys rattle and a gold-and-diamond ring that looks like a wound-up ribbon, which in Greek culture is a symbol for everything from athletics to marriage. Even from a very young age I loved Greek history, said Votsi, who discusses her Hydra roots in the video, which was produced by LoveGold, an online community dedicated to gold jewelry.

title: An American Adrift in Hong Kong
description: The conventions are trundled out in Stanley J. Orzels cross-cultural romance, Lost for Words, but not the tension or the chemistry. Sean Faris, resembling a very poor mans Ethan Hawke, plays Michael Vance, a former Marine who has been hired by the information technology department of a company in Hong Kong. Michael is despondent, having been dumped by his girlfriend stateside, until he meets a dancer, Anna Zhou (the gorgeous if opaque Grace Huang, assaying a woefully underdrawn character). How do they meet? He bumps into her as he arrives at the airport and as he jogs in a park.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Love, in Its Guises, Rebounding
description: One thing is certain about David Dorfmans Come, and Back Again: the show has heart. This hourlong dance production, which made its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater on Wednesday, features monologues about love and grandmothers. It has video projections of the heart shapes found on the stationery of young girls. Ive never seen a show with more hugging.

title: Theater Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Fiorano Wine Estate in Italy Making a Comeback
description: ROME  A fresh breeze was blowing in from the Mediterranean to the west, clearing the air here at the Fiorano estate on a brilliant day this month. The harvest was in, the grapes had been crushed and the juice was settling in concrete tanks in the newly constructed winery, beginning the slow process of fermentation.

title: Paint It Noir
description: Displaying a near-smothering fascination with 1940s noir, Cut to Black is a mildly engaging lowlife odyssey that struggles not to choke on its own style.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Two Mothers, Divided by Their Sons
description: Subdued in mood and palette, Torn sensitively explores the aftermath of a mall bombing through the eyes of two mothers who each lost a teenage son in the explosion.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 18-24
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 18-24
description: A Girl Without Wings

title: Nicky Nodjoumi: Chasing the Butterfly and Other Recent Paintings
description: Taymour Grahne Gallery

title: Nick Hornby: Sculpture (1504-2013)
description: Churner and Churner

title: Making Cities Work for People
description: It seems like youre at a tipping point between becoming L.A. or becoming Copenhagen, the narrator of The Human Scale says to an urban planner for Christchurch, New Zealand, a city rebuilding from an earthquake in 2011.

title: Burying the Lede: News as Art
description: Momenta Art

title: Lucas Blalock: Id, Ed, Ad, Od
description: Ramiken Crucible

title: Spare Times for Oct. 18-24
description: Harvest Fairs (Friday through Sunday) With Halloween less than two weeks away, pumpkin fever is high at the citys parks, gardens and farms. On Saturday a Halloween Harvest Festival at Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens will include costumed canines competing (at 1 p.m.) for the grand prize of a visit to a doggy spa. There will also be events for humans, including a performance of spooky tales by the Variations Theater Group. From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. (rain or shine), 32-01 Vernon Boulevard, at Broadway, Long Island City, (718) 956-1819, socratessculpturepark.org; free.

title: Karl Wirsum
description: Derek Eller

title: Paola Pivi: Ok, you are better than me, so what?; Audible Presence
description: Galerie Perrotin

title: Mike Kelley
description: Images from the new show at MoMA PS 1.

title: Trying to Keep Religion Out of the Charter School Classroom
description: SAN ANTONIO  At the Eleanor Kolitz Hebrew Language Academy, a fifth-grade foreign-language class is taught entirely in Hebrew, with students shifting into English only long enough to translate words like research and to overcome. In middle school, these charter school students will take a class on Israeli culture. Officials say the class is in line with the state mandate that public schools teach about the culture of the country where the instructed language is spoken.

title: This Shows as Big as His Career
description: Plainly put, the Mike Kelley retrospective, fresh from Europe to MoMA PS1, knocks everything else in New York this fall right out of the ring. Its immense, filling 40,000 square feet of gallery space, including a sub-basement boiler room. And its that extremely rare thing, a huge show that should be huge. Kelley earned this blowout; his work sustains it.

title: Academic Suggests an Entrance Test for Beijings Migrant Workers
description: A suggestion from a professor at a prestigious Beijing university that the Chinese capital begin an examination process to screen the quality of migrants has touched off criticism in blogs and in the Chinese press. The recommendation from Wen Guowei, a professor and urban planning expert at Tsinghua University, highlighted some of the difficulties faced by Chinas quickly growing cities and also the discrimination outsiders can face.

title: A Promoter Finds a New Cause: God
description: In Im in Love With a Church Girl, Jeff Atkins, the 37-year-old rapper better known as Ja Rule, plays Miles Montego, a drug dealer turned concert promoter. Hes smart, hes rich, and hes good-looking, audiences are instructed. Though not all of those qualities are obvious, Mr. Atkins plays the character with a perfunctory swagger.

title: Sinning a Little to Defeat the Demons
description: The title Hellbenders refers to a Brooklyn-based group of interfaith ministers whose peculiar practice involves racking up sins. These are debauched exorcists on a suicide mission: misbehave enough to invite possession, then commit suicide, dragging the demon with them to the underworld.

title: A Schizophrenics 15-Minute Fame
description: Every Monday, Marcelle Danan, a French art dealer in Los Angeles, picks up William Laga, an artist she represents. They buy canvases and paints, and then Mr. Laga creates: abstract maplike visions blending hues and textures. Since Mr. Laga is a schizophrenic whom Ms. Danan met on the street, Mondays With William, a spare, cleareyed documentary by Steve Beebe, starts out as a feel-good film about arts power to reclaim lives but becomes a commentary on the homeless and the mentally ill among them.

title: For Police Commissioner, the Next Mayor Will Have a Wide Array of Options
description: The topic came up late in the New York City mayoral debate, and the division could not have been clearer: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee, would seek to keep the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, if elected; his Democratic opponent, Bill de Blasio, would not.

title: Debate Shows Power of Cities to Limit Reach of Drilling
description: DALLAS  Claudia and Ed Meyer do not want natural gas drilling near their West Dallas home or anywhere else in the city, for that matter.

title: A Pizza Parlors Upscale Neighbor
description: Abeetza Next Door in Greenvale hews to a classic formula. Weve all been to one of these Italian spots that combines a pizza parlor with a more upscale dining room behind or alongside it.

title: Ah, Berlin, Home to Concerts With Phalluses
description: Based on stage shows in Berlin in 2010-11, Peaches Does Herself records a body-positive rock opera starring the happily raunchy, ditty-slinging singer of the title. The fan-friendly hit list spans electro thunks, guitar-riffing glam chants and even ballads as Peaches  an elfin figure at the center of yonic and phallic sets and costumes  moves from innocence to experience. Its a mix of brash celebration and sexual-wilderness heartbreak.

title: Remembering Pillars of Israels Past
description: This month is the 40th anniversary of the 1973 war between Egypt and Israel, and the analysis of that conflict continues to this day. The war is one of many challenges to the fledgling state of Israel examined in The Prime Ministers: The Pioneers, a vivid insiders perspective based on Yehuda Avners memoir.

title: The Last King of Ireland
description: DUBLIN  Oscar Wilde still lounges, louche-like, on a boulder in Merrion Square. As always, the Liffey, a river crossed by bridges named for playwrights and patriots, lumbers its way to the sea. Grafton Street is packed with moneyed pedestrians. But Irish ayes are missing.

title: Storing Solar Energy
description: A new solar thermal plant in Arizona, called the Solana Generating Station, can store solar energy so it is available whenever it is needed.

title: Behind Bars, Where Anything Goes
description: Is that political commentary lurking beneath the grunts and four-word sentences of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone?

title: Chopping, Flipping and Feinting in Search of Lost Art
description: There was an amusing Saturday morning cartoon series in the early 2000s, Jackie Chan Adventures, in which the title hero traveled around the globe tracking down 12 magic talismans representing the Chinese zodiac. Mr. Chans latest movie, Chinese Zodiac, also concerns a worldwide hunt for astrological symbols, but despite its bigger budget and scale, its hardly as entertaining.

title: Doubts Fall on Afghan Police as Kidnappers Exact Dire Price
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  The way Dr. Nisar Ahmed Barak sees it, he was robbed twice  and both times by law enforcement authorities.

title: Expatriates on the Road, With a Dead Body
description: Like someone using a thin smile to hide a heavy heart, The Taiwan Oyster employs a comic veneer to camouflage a deep sense of melancholy. This is a film that holds tight to its sorrow while trying not to scare you away.

title: Government Reopens After Shutdown
description: National parks, monuments, museums and federal agencies reopened on Thursday after a 16-day shutdown of the government.

title: Action, Comedy and the Brisk Snap of Breaking Bones
description: Everybody loves a character with absolute confidence, peerless skill and unshakable cool. The square-jawed gangster known as Boss (the undeniably appealing Akshay Kumar) is that kind of guy. He knows he can win any fight, and there are plenty for him in Anthony DSouzas Boss  in the marketplace, at the multiplex, in the desert. Between lethal kicks, as he easily dispatches 10 or 12 tough guys, Boss  whose agility is beyond Olympian  does a few dance steps and smiles. This is a man who prefers to fight to music, which is good, because sometimes that drowns out the sounds of all those necks being snapped.

title: Lingering Confusion in Debt Ceiling Deals Temporary Fix
description: WASHINGTON  DID Congress just kill the debt ceiling?

title: Those Hazardous Flying Birds
description: WHEN a US Airways jet leaving Reagan National for New York struck birds as it took off, it had to return to Washington. A JetBlue flight departing from Westchester County Airport was rerouted after colliding with birds. Ditto for another JetBlue flight leaving Kennedy Airport.

title: Security Council Elects 5 New Members
description: Chad, Chile, Lithuania, Nigeria and Saudi Arabia were elected Thursday to seats on the 15-member United Nations Security Council for two-year terms starting in January. It was the first time that Saudi Arabia had sought to gain one of the nonpermanent seats on the Council; its decision to vie for a seat appeared to reflect the kingdoms wish to be more assertive in resolving the Syria war and the Arab-Israeli conflict. The Saudis, who support the rebellion seeking the ouster of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, have criticized the Council over what they regard as its insufficient response to the turmoil in the Middle East. Last month the Saudi foreign minister canceled his General Assembly speech, apparently to show the Saudis displeasure. The new Council members replace Azerbaijan, Guatemala, Morocco, Pakistan and Togo.

title: Israel: Palestinian Is Killed at Army Base
description: Israeli soldiers on Thursday fatally shot a Palestinian man who drove a construction vehicle into an army base near Ramallah in the West Bank, barging through a gate and repeatedly trying to run over a soldier, the Israeli military said in a statement. The official Palestinian news agency Wafa identified the man as Yunis Radeideh, 30. In two attacks in July 2008, Palestinians driving construction vehicles in central Jerusalem were shot and killed after plowing into traffic and pedestrians, killing three Israelis. In March 2009, the Palestinian driver of an earthmover flipped over an Israeli police car, wounding two police officers before he was shot dead. According to initial reports, the driver in that episode, Marei al-Radeideh, was a brother of the driver killed at the army base on Thursday.

title: Riverss Move Brings Power, and Scrutiny
description: LOS ANGELES  On the wall of Doc Riverss new office inside the Los Angeles Clippers practice center are keepsakes more reflecting a diversity of interest than a tribute to his cherished vocation. For example: behind his desk hangs a signed picture of Muhammad Ali.

title: Small Plates, and a Taste of Many Cultures
description: Mistral, the restaurant that Scott Anderson and his business partner, Stephen Distler, opened in May, only solidifies the dazzling reputation that Mr. Anderson established at Elements, the other notable Princeton restaurant that he and Mr. Distler own. The new ingredient is Ben Nerenhausen, the talented chef they lured from the Restaurant at Meadowood in St. Helena, Calif., which has three Michelin stars.

title: Blood and Screams, Before the Show Starts
description: THE tone of Halloween marketing typically takes its cue from the national mood. The more scary the real world seems, for instance during and right after the financial crisis, the less scary Halloween ads are. Conversely, when consumers are upbeat, Madison Avenue produces ads that favor the frightful.

title: Court Rules on Stand Your Ground Costs
description: SEATTLE  A state appeals court here in Washington, in a major ruling on the stand your ground debate over personal safety, said Thursday that a defendant who successfully uses a self-defense claim is entitled to reimbursement for lost wages and other costs, as well as legal fees.

title: The Damage Done
description: The government is reopening, and we didnt default on our debt. Happy days are here again, right?

title: Rev. John Grange, Who Welcomed Bronxs Latinos, Dies at 73
description: The Rev. John Grange, a Spanish-speaking son of Irish-Americans who helped rebuild the impoverished South Bronx parish where he was raised into a more hospitable and promising place for Hispanic immigrants to New York City, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 73.

title: Crisis Over, Everyone Back to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: How God Is Real for Some, but Not for Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Charter Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: More American Jewish Students Take Up Study of the Arab World
description: Miriam Berger studied Arabic at Wesleyan University, lived twice as a student in Jordan, did thesis research in the West Bank and, after graduation, worked in Cairo. And like many of the Americans she has met each step of the way, she is Jewish.

title: Anger Across Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Haunted Houses in High Definition
description: Every year around this time it seems fitting to give thanks to horror-movie fans, whose willingness to support their genre of choice by actually laying cash on the line is substantially responsible for keeping a lot of studio library divisions and independent video companies in operation. This Halloween, the seasonal offerings include some big-ticket gift sets, like Chucky: The Complete Collection, an anthology of all six films in the Childs Play series (Universal; Blu-ray, $84.98; DVD, $59.88; not rated), and Friday the 13th: The Complete Collection, which offers Blu-ray editions of 12 films in that slasher franchise, from the original 1980 Friday the 13th directed by Sean S. Cunningham to its 2009 remake-reboot directed by Marcus Nispel  in effect, closing the circle (Warner Home Video; $129.95; R).

title: Erdogan, Syrian Rebels Leading Ally, Hesitates
description: ISTANBUL  From the start of Syrias civil war, rebels fighting President Bashar al-Assad have had no better ally than Turkeys prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. He has effectively kept Turkeys border with Syria open, allowing fighters a haven in the south of his country as weapons, cash and other supplies have flowed to the battlefield.

title: At 19, Jameis Winston is a Quick Learner and a Decisive Leader
description: First-year college quarterbacks typically hesitate with both their throws and their words. It is rookie indecision, the thing that holds them back for a moment from firing a ball through a closing window in the defense or makes them recoil before responding to questions about keeping their cool in front of a heckling crowd.

title: Settlement for a Shackled Pregnant Woman
description: A detained Mexican woman who had been shackled to her hospital bed while giving birth in Nashville will receive $490,000 in a settlement and also has the prospect of a resident visa.

title: Questions Surround Mt. Everest Tragedy
description: The deadly avalanche by Mount Everest hit around 5 a.m., when the trekkers were asleep at camp. It was Monday, near the end of the weeklong trek, and the four Australian tourists and the Tibetans accompanying them were on their way back to the trailhead village by the mountains east flank. Of the 10 people in the party, one Australian and three Tibetans died. A Chinese news report identified the dead Australian as Kenneth Dean Higgins, age 60, but did not name the Tibetans.

title: No One Wants to Be There
description: Nolan Conway photographs unlucky drivers whose cars have been towed to the Manhattan pound on Pier 76.

title: Common Interests, Not Confrontation
description: When a few dozen Republican pragmatists in the Senate finally roused themselves and stood up to the Tea Party this week, the budget crisis quickly came to an end. Now its time for them to lead their party to accept the challenge President Obama issued on Thursday and permanently change the way Congress does business. Confrontational tactics failed the Republicans when Mr. Obama stood up to their demands, but rational negotiations  on ways to promote the public interest, not the agenda of interest groups  can still succeed.

title: Suspect Recalls the Short Life of Baby Hope
description: Anjlica Castillo liked to ask questions. She was chatty and a little headstrong for a 4-year-old.

title: At Day Care for Dogs, a Surprise: Choke Collars That Can Kill
description: To begin with, the Bryants are not suing.

title: Many Ex-Players May Be Ineligible for Payment in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
description: When the N.F.L. agreed to pay $765 million to settle a lawsuit brought by 4,500 retired players who said the league hid from them the long-term impact of concussions, lawyers in the case said all retirees would be eligible for a share of the settlement.

title: White House Weighs Easing Iran Sanctions Bite With Slow Release of Assets
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, in the wake of a promising first round of nuclear diplomacy with Iran, is weighing a proposal to ease the pain of sanctions on Tehran by offering it access to billions of dollars in frozen funds if the Iranian government takes specific steps to curb its nuclear program, a senior administration official said Thursday.

title: A Thaw in Geneva?
