But this autumns crop of jewel-like beets has me thinking in an entirely different direction. These days when I make pasta, I think pink: pink beet sauce, that is.

title: Cavatelli with Brown Butter Beets
description: Beets add an earthy note to pasta, especially when they are both topped with brown butter.

title: A Beep in the Night
description: Mrs. Feld, you were confused!

title: The Last of the Sheiks?
description: DURHAM, England  THIS summer, disgruntled Saudis took their grievances online in droves, complaining of ever-growing inequality, rising poverty, corruption and unemployment. Their Twitter campaign became one of the worlds highest trending topics. It caused great alarm within elite circles in Saudi Arabia and sent ripples throughout the region. The rallying cry that salaries are not enough helped to prove that the monarchys social contract with its people is now publicly coming unstuck, and on a significant scale.

title: Same-Sex Marriages in New Jersey Can Begin, Court Rules
description: Same-sex couples can start marrying on Monday across New Jersey, after the states Supreme Court denied Gov. Chris Christies attempt to block the weddings and suggested that he would have a difficult time winning an appeal of a lower-court ruling that allowed them.

title: A 1930s Farce, but Not as Groucho Played It
description: The wallpaper in the hotel room is loud enough. But Gordon Miller, the struggling would-be Broadway producer who lives there in Room Service, often manages to outshout the dcor. He delivers the line My God, there must be somebody I can sue! at the top of his lungs while jumping up and down like a frustrated 3-year-old.

title: Revisiting a Revolution
description: In the third movement of Shostakovichs Symphony No. 11, The Year 1905, the violas play a melancholy theme over the subdued pizzicati of the lower strings. When Semyon Bychkov led the New York Philharmonic in a brilliant performance of the work on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the melody unfolded tenderly. It softly re-emerged with radiant introspection at the end of the third movement, called In Memoriam.

title: Audis V-8 Masterpiece
description: The S7 and S8 come with different versions of an impeccably engineered V-8 engine that sets Audi apart from its luxury performance-car competition.

title: Out of Network, Not by Choice, and Facing Huge Health Bills
description: Once the cardiologist figured out why Raquel and Michael DAndreas 9-week-old daughter was so frail and unable to eat, he immediately sent her to the hospital for heart surgery.

title: The Posh London Homes That Posh Londoners Covet
description: In 10th grade, my English class read Portrait of the Artist as a Young Dog, Dylan Thomass great book of autobiographical short stories, featuring examples of some early poetic attempts by the Thomas-ian protagonist. One day I gushed to the teacher, Mr. Weber, about the amazingness of those poems  how could anyone have been so talented so young? It was embarrassing because, as Mr. Weber gently explained, the author was making a joke at the expense of the character: the point was that the poems were not good at all.

title: Gwen Stefani Shimmies and Shakes in Metallic Fringe
description: The Girl: The singers fringed ensemble was full of movement at the black-tie opening-night gala for the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills last night.

title: A Painters Evolution in Abstract Landscapes
description: The style was so controlled! the artist Stan Brodsky said, not altogether admiringly, as he stood in front of one of his paintings at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

title: A Short History of the Fainting Couch
description: Recamier, mridienne, chaise longue, daybed  weve long needed a place to lounge.

title: Fox Gives Brooklyn Nine-Nine a Big Vote of Confidence
description: The Fox network is putting as much faith as it can muster behind the new comedy series Brooklyn Nine-Nine, announcing on Friday that the show would be renewed for the full television season and be introduced to the enormous audience that remains after a Super Bowl broadcast.

title: Is Kent the Westchester of London?
description: In Turner Contemporary, in Margate, the gallery workers were hanging a new exhibition: works by J. M. W. Turner, John Constable and their peers, a collection of rarely seen early-19th-century landscape sketches offset by the shark skin and whale spine of the Irish contemporary artist Dorothy Cross. The floor was littered with cables and vacuum-cleaner components, masking tape and Stanley knives. It was a scene that could have been straight out of a gallery on Cork Street, but instead the few visitors were able to look out over the water to where the North Sea meets the English Channel.

title: Big Sound in a Small House, Keen to Reach the Next Stage
description: But who will fill the arenas? Not with fans, with sound  anthemic rock has taken a beating in recent years. Or more accurately, its been pured into a softer, lighter version of its former self, be it the deep exhales of Coldplay or the turned-up muscle-folk of Mumford & Sons.

title: In Exploring Abuse, Encountering Tender Territory
description: The author and actor Martin Moran calls Two River Theaters decision to stage A Map of the Soul, a first-ever bundling of his one-man shows The Tricky Part and All the Rage, brave and ambitious.

title: Washington Reopens for Business
description: The capital comes back to life with tourists and federal workers after the end of the government shutdown Wednesday night.

title: Making Ballet Speak in Many Languages
description: The high and rising international reputation of the San Francisco Ballet derives from its deep bench of talent and its commitment to new work. The mixed-bill programs that the company is presenting during the first week of its visit to New York put forward both strengths at once. After an opening night on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater that offered three New York premieres of recently choreographed pieces, the troupe went one better on Thursday, with four.

title: Kenyan Leader Can Skip Parts of Hague Trial
description: PARIS  Kenyas president can be absent from parts of his trial on charges of crimes against humanity to fulfill his duties at home, but he will have to be present for a number of important hearings at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, the court announced Friday.

title: As Baseball Integrates, Satchel Throws Heat
description: In the pleasant parlor of a Kansas City boardinghouse, a young woman excitedly flips through the pages of a magazine. It is 1947, and change for black Americans seems enticingly close. She finds what she is looking for: an ad for Wheaties cereal. The spokesman-endorser is Jackie Robinson, who has recently become the first black player in modern major-league baseball.

title: Christopher Bailey: Burberrys Fitting Appointment
description: THIS WEEK INVESTORS weighed in on the news that Christopher Bailey would become the chief executive of Burberry, where he is already chief creative officer, and it wasnt pretty.

title: Video: G.M. Tries Diesel Again, This Time With an Efficient Chevy Cruze
description: Americans tend to think of hybrids when they want a car with high fuel economy. Europeans, on the other hand, turn to diesel-powered cars. The only manufacturers to offer diesel power to American car buyers with any regularity have been  Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz. So its only natural that Chevrolet is jumping into the game with the Cruze Turbo Diesel.

title: A Year After Sandy, Collectors Consider the Lessons
description: Scott Nadlers home in Oceanside, N.Y., was among the thousands severely damaged when Hurricane Sandys storm surge pummeled the South Shore of Long Island nearly a year ago. There was some relief, however, in finding that although saltwater had flooded his garage, the 1971 Chevrolet Chevelle SS 396 hed owned for 10 years was repairable.

title: A Fix for a Chirp Under the Hood
description: Honda Crosstours that foul spark plugs and Jeep Wranglers that run hot are among the vehicles with mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Mailer Gala Honors Diaz, Angelou and Its Divisive Namesake
description: At the fifth annual Norman Mailer Center Benefit Gala on Thursday at the New York Public Library, honored writers and even the M.C.s grappled with the legacy of the galas namesake.

title: Landlord vs. Tenant: When It All Began
description: Everybody loves a landlord, the Master of the House gustily sings in Les Misrables. At few times would that glibly insincere boast have rung less true than in New York City during and after World War I, when coal shortages, Socialist agitators and the scarcity of apartments conspired to bring about emergency rent regulation.

title: Problems of Growing Up Female
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Throughout Charlotte Vincents Motherland, which takes place on a white stage, several scenes repeat in exacting precision: Aurora Lubos walks onto the stage holding a bottle, unscrews its lid and flings its dark red contents onto a pristine wall. She then hikes up her dress, spreads her legs and leans against it with a hollow expression; it looks like menstrual blood. The stain sets.

title: On Late TV, Hosts Go From Snide to Sweet
description: In one of the signal moments of the greatest talk show in my lifetime, Late Night With David Letterman, on NBC, Cher called the host a big jerk.

title: Dirty Antebellum Secrets in Ivory Towers
description: When Craig Steven Wilder first began digging around in university archives in 2002 for material linking universities to slavery, he recalled recently, he was a little bashful about what he was looking for.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google and Facebook Partner on Ads, and Talk to Me, Siri
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: NBC Cancels Two Series and Will Bring Back Community
description: Cancellation news arrived again on Friday evening with NBC swinging the ax this time and removing both the comedy Welcome to the Family and the drama Ironside from the schedule.

title: Clarity at Yoga, Cheating at the Diner
description: With all the projects that the choreographer Larry Keigwin has going, his week could use four or five Sundays. This fall, Mr. Keigwin, 41, is choreographing a new musical, If/Then, to open in Washington next month and on Broadway in the spring, and preparing his own dance companys 10th-anniversary performances at the Joyce Theater from Oct. 29 to Nov. 3. In spare moments he is starting a magazine, ArtDesk, which just published its first issue. He lives with his partner, Christian Keesee, 51, a banker, and sometimes Mr. Keesees son, Blake, 16, in a town house in the East 70s, joined by their three dogs.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 18
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: politicians on the campaign trail, tourists at Liberty Island and crowds admiring Banksy graffiti.

title: An Elegant Little Soiree of String Players, Just Playing a Few Old Tunes
description: As a rule, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is all about intimacy. Its concerts often feel like conversations between a handful of players, the musical equivalent of confidences shared across a dinner table. But for the opening of its new season on Thursday, the society peopled the stage of Alice Tully Hall with a small crowd.

title: Forget Their Dad; Just Listen to Them
description: When Theo Spielberg decided it was time to get serious about starting a rock group, he only had to look across the hallway of his familys home to find a lead singer. Joined in his bedroom by his sister Sasha, he grabbed his guitar and started plunking out a chord progression hed been toying with since college, while she sang a pleading and melodic vocal about unspecified desires.

title: Old, but Not Off the Stage
description: They are out there nearly every afternoon in Balsley Park, a small plaza on Ninth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets.

title: Exotic Thrills for the Privileged, to a Jazz Score
description: In early-1930s London, behind endless clouds of cigarette smoke, society was being remade. Dancing on the Edge, a new Starz mini-series beginning Saturday, takes place in the swank hotels, garden parties and jazz clubs of that era to capture the moment when black music served as a social lubricant that brought together poor, itinerant musicians and the aristocracy, including members of the royal family, for a marriage that was tenuous by design.

title: The Charter School Fight
description: The mayors race, otherwise somnolently lacking in drama since the primaries retired the name Sydney Leathers to the history of grade-B scandal, received an infusion of heat recently over the dependably combustible issue of charter school education.

title: House Tour | Howard Slatkin
description: Howard Slatkin, an interior decorator, gave T Magazine's Sara Ruffin Costello a tour of his palatial Fifth Avenue apartment.

title: The New Nice Guys of Comedy
description: In an era when the most celebrated television dramas ask you to identify with often-repellent antiheroes, the new stars of late night are ingratiating nice guys.

title: Finding Your Flair, Pompadour Optional
description: Most nights around 8, you can catch Thelma & Louise on television at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn. As you may recall, that Ridley Scott 1991 film was a game changer in Hollywood, redefining the outlaw buddy movie by starring two women, instead of men, as partners in crime and self-discovery.

title: Logging Miles After Night Falls
description: In the developing scene of urban running crews, socializing and drinking are a large part of the draw.

title: Executive on Mayoral Races Fringes Says Goal Is to Offer Ideas
description: Jack Hidary had the gumption to start his first Internet company at a time when most people knew little of the Internet beyond e-mail. So when he looked earlier this year at the field of mayoral candidates, which included several career politicians and a former congressman best known for tweeting a picture of his underpants, he thought, Why not jump in?

title: Into These Woods, Suspect in a Killing Vanished a Year Ago
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y.  Last year about this time, Eugene Palmer, a 73-year-old retired truck driver with a love of the craggy backwoods, shot and killed his tempestuous daughter-in-law, Tammy Palmer, the police said, and vanished into the vast wilderness of Harriman State Park.

title: Miles, Then Margaritas
description: There are runners who get up early every morning to get in their miles and who meet up for weekend events in city parks sponsored by the New York Road Runners club, or the like.

title: When the E-Mail Is Not Quite Spam, but Not Quite Desired
description: Im opting out. Not of the workplace, but of newsletters I havent signed up for, business tips I never asked for, blog posts I wont read, events I cant attend, pet updates, recipes for organic vegan chocolate mousse that I will never make, and jokes that have been circulating on the Web since 2004 (but thanks, Mom).

title: Deal From the Venice Cup and Bermuda Bowl
description: One of the arts of declarer play is making life difficult for the defenders. And if you need a misdefense, usually the quicker you put your opponent on the spot, the better.

title: Seven Days of Style | Pradas Latest Desert Outpost, Karl Lagerfelds Class on Being Karl, and Gwyneth Paltrows Newest Crusade
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREOct. 12  18

title: A Risky Homecoming for White-Tailed Deer
description: Staring across Staten Islands West Shore Expressway, the buck struck a pose in the late light of an autumn day, antlers burnished like new bronze. His muddy feet described his journey from Old Place Creek, just below the roads shoulder, to a spot where he no doubt anticipated a better view, but instead found one of New York Citys busiest highways. The deers intent gaze was troubling. Suddenly driving 50 miles an hour seemed much too fast, and the roads shoulder, much too narrow.

title: Deadlines for Colleges Are Delayed
description: Several of the nations top colleges and universities have postponed their early application deadlines over the last few days, prompted by continued reports that students and high schools are stumbling over technical problems with the Common Application.

title: Bill Cunningham | Bigger, Bolder
description: Paris Fashion Week could easily be called the Greatest Show on Earth.

title: T FALL DESIGN
description: With a storied imagination, a collectors passion and an obsessive attention to detail, Howard Slatkin has created a one-of-a kind Fifth Avenue aerie in which every doorknob, tile and 19th-century silk lampshade was designed by him.

title: Nicholas Loeb: Forget All the Rest, Hes Mr. Condiment
description: On a recent afternoon, Nicholas M. Loeb walked into the Hillstone steakhouse on Park Avenue South, not far from his penthouse duplex apartment. Tall and handsome in a dress shirt, faded jeans and loafers, he sat down, ordered spinach and artichoke dip and lined up four bottles on the table. This is our company that I just launched, Onion Crunch, he said. And this year we launched three new flavors: chipotle, bacon and barbecue.

title: Q. and A.: Jia Zhangke on Violence, Censorship and His New Film A Touch of Sin
description: One afternoon, as a late summer thunderstorm rolled into Beijing, a small group of Chinese and foreign journalists sat in the Beijing office of Jia Zhangke, the Chinese director, watching his latest film, A Touch of Sin. Mr. Jia had finished one round of appearances at film festivals and was in Beijing for a spell, before heading to festivals in the fall in Toronto; New York; San Sebastin, Spain; and elsewhere. The film had made its world premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May, where it won a best screenplay award.

title: The Call of the Wild on the Pacific Crest Trail
description: The Pacific Crest Trail, a 2,650-mile hiking and equestrian trail that reaches from Mexico to Canada, has been called the Appalachian Trail of the West Coast. But that description does it a disservice, for the Pacific trail is longer, wilder, more punishing and also grander than its East Coast cousin.

title: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Turn It Around
description: Their album is just out  and its really, really good. (But wheres Genevieve?) I was worried that it would be overproduced, but while its different from the live performances, its different in a good way, with the voices even more gorgeous.

title: For Jewish Schools Football Team, Its Thursday Night Lights
description: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla.  Early Thursday morning at a Jewish high school here, Elan Kainen donned the prayer shawl that had been a gift from his maternal grandfather and recited the prayers of the Shacharit service. Nine hours later, he went through another ritual, one involving pads, cleats and a helmet, as he suited up for what might be the final game of his high school football career.

title: Online Happy Hours, From Corner Bar to Corner Office
description: A little after 4 p.m. on a recent Thursday, Eric Fleming, the head of strategy for Mash+Studio, a content marketing firm in SoHo, gathered his co-workers for happy hour.

title: When Celebrity Sex Videos Are Rated Y (for Yawn)
description: Rob Lowe in the hotel room.

title: Sports Ministry Fraud a Symptom of Venezuelas Race for Dollars
description: Venezuela is investigating athletes on its national motorsports teams for defrauding the government of tens of millions of dollars, Reuters reports.

title: Editors Letter | Life At Home
description: The homes featured in this issue are each wildly different and support wildly different ways of living. What unites them is the clear point of view each one possesses  each reflecting its inhabitant in the most basic, but profound, way.

title: Paying for Health Care on Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleges Need Metrics to Measure Student Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Dimensions of IndyCar
description: IndyCar is the only series that races on three types of courses: oval, street and road. Tony Kanaan, the 2013 Indianapolis 500 winner, and Simona DeSilvestro of KV Racing explain the differences in driving at Pocono Speedway, a high-speed oval, and at Mid-Ohios road course.

title: Book Bags for the Children, and Bags of Crack at Starbucks
description: A sign outside an 11th-floor apartment in the Jacob Riis Houses in Lower Manhattan reads: Warning: This Property Protected by Jesus Christ. But outside, in a nearby courtyard, that particular responsibility apparently fell to Dwayne Mitchell.

title: Activism in the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Zones and the State
description: To the Editor:

title: Let the Tea Party Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics in the Facebook Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Divorce for Jewish Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Company Buys Chase Manhattan Plaza
description: One Chase Manhattan Plaza, the 60-story office tower that has been home to one of New York Citys most important banks for half a century, has a new owner: Fosun International of China.

title: Russia: 2 Bomb Makers Die, Police Say
description: Two people suspected of being militants were killed Friday when an improvised bomb that the police said was being prepared for a terrorist attack exploded in a mosques cemetery in the North Caucasus region, where Russia is struggling to contain an insurgency. A police spokeswoman for the republic of Kabardino-Balkaria said officers responding to the blast in the village of Dugulubgey found the remains of two bodies, as well as two pistols and a Kalashnikov assault rifle stolen from a police officer in 2008. The device was estimated to have contained more than 20 pounds of explosives, and it shattered the windows of nearby homes when it went off, the police spokeswoman said. The region is close to Sochi, which will host the 2014 Winter Olympics.

title: T Fall Design Issue
description: In our latest issue, we explore distinct forms of design, whether theyre found in the asymmetrical forms of fashion, or in the 70s-style curvilinear lines of furniture, or in the architecture of midcentury homes in the Beverly Hills neighborhood of Trousdale. Design, like all forms of art, can be very personal; members of one of Englands most celebrated families, Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant, draw inspiration from nature, namely from the bucolic surroundings in Scotland to create their sculptures and paintings. It can also be very pared down and minimal, like in the home of two fashion designers in Tokyo, or in the distilled, spacious Antwerp residence of the Belgian architect Vincent Van Duysen. On a larger scale, we discover designers and artisans determined to reinvent neighborhoods and cities around the world. In Sydneys Rosebery neighborhood, three businesses celebrate the best of the citys agriculture, craftsmanship and furniture design. Meanwhile, in Belgrade, locals are turning their city into a world-class destination, with the emergence of design hotels, art museums and adventurous restaurants. We embrace those who break with convention in art and design; Not Vital, a Swiss artist obsessed with habitats, is the Picasso, the Dali, the Andy Warhol of today, claims Andrew OHagan. Howard Slatkins Fifth Avenue apartment is filled with custom-made items, from floor to ceiling; each room has a combination of textiles, lighting, objets dart from different eras and countries. Last but not least, we celebrate visionaries who are using technology to take design  and our imaginations  to the next level. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Mexico: Soda-Tax Bill Moves Forward
description: The lower house of Mexicos Congress has approved a tax on soda and other sugary drinks as part of the governments fight against the twin epidemics of obesity and diabetes. The legislators also added a junk food tax of 5 percent to most snacks and candy when they approved a broad overhaul of Mexicos tax system late Thursday. The beverage industry, along with sugar producers and the owners of small stores, has led a fierce lobbying campaign against the tax, but public health advocates have fought back. The Senate will take up the tax bill next week.

title: After Running Hot, Market for Used Cars Is Cooling
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  It was 9:30 on a recent Tuesday morning at Manheim Riverside, a wholesale auto auction, and more than a thousand used-car dealers were mulling in the desert heat. The bidders had gathered on the perimeters of Manheims 10 lanes of cars, watching the vehicles cycle through 10 different auction blocks, at no longer than 45 seconds a pop. Over a collective din that drowns out the auctioneers, the dealers wink, nod or, for the less stealthy, raise a hand to indicate their bid.

title: The Quarterbacks Share
description: The Giants quarterbacks, primarily Eli Manning, consume a larger portion of their teams salary cap than any other quarterbacks in the N.F.L. The chart shows the percentage of the $123 million cap used by each team for its quarterbacks.

title: Reasoning May Be Wrong, but No. 2 Spot Is for Best
description: Sometimes it seems the rift between baseballs traditionalists and its more statistically oriented enthusiasts will never be mended. Every time there is some progress, like players and pundits acknowledging the superiority of Mike Trouts well-rounded game, a situation arises like David Prices writing off questioning reporters as nerds.

title: Wave of High-Profile Crimes Has Put Malaysians on the Defensive
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysias population has tripled over the past four decades. Its largest city, Kuala Lumpur, a place once so sparsely populated that it looked like a botanical garden, has exploded into a cosmopolitan metropolis of shopping malls, luxury hotels and sprawling suburbs.

title: Democrats Aim to Restore Immigration to Agenda
description: As the fiscal crisis subsided and the government went back to work this week, President Obama and other leading Democrats were quick to say that an immigration overhaul should be back on the agenda in Congress.

title: Low-Cost B.A. Starting Slowly in Two States
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  With tuition, student loan debt and default rates all spiraling higher, whats not to love about a $10,000 bachelors degree?

title: Malaysia Confronts a Growing Crime Problem
description: Kuala Lumpur, the largest city in Malaysia, was once considered one of Asias safest cities. Now its fighting a rash of burglaries and other crimes.

title: A Ted Cruz on Every Corner
description: Have you noticed how many lawmakers from Texas were doing crazy things during the government shutdown debacle?

title: Shutdown to Cost U.S. Billions, Analysts Say, While Eroding Confidence
description: WASHINGTON  The government shutdown that ended this week will cost the United States economy several billion dollars, according to estimates by economic research firms.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: 5 FLORIDA STATE at 3 CLEMSON

title: The High Cost of Betrayal
description: The new Broadway revival of Harold Pinters Betrayal is setting box-office records at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, grossing $1,100,818 for the week ended Oct. 6 and $1,112,027 for the week ended Oct. 13. Thats roughly $45,000 more than the previous high mark set by Arthur Millers Death of a Salesman in the spring of 2012.

title: Canada and Europe Reach Tentative Trade Agreement
description: OTTAWA  Canada and the European Union tentatively agreed to a sweeping trade agreement on Friday. But while billed as a free-trade pact, the limited information released about its terms suggests that the details of any final deal may focus on adjusting import-export quotas and fine-tuning regulations as much as the easing of tariffs.

title: Mets Said to Be Near Radio Deal
description: The Mets are nearing a multiyear agreement to make WOR-AM (710) the new home for their games, according to a person in baseball. Howie Rose, the voice of the Mets, is expected to remain. The Mets had been searching for a new home after WFAN announced it would carry the Yankees next season. The Mets had been on WFAN since its inception in 1987.

title: A Sri Lankan Journalist Eagerly Toes the Line
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  He calls himself the Rush Limbaugh of Sri Lanka, except Im not as obnoxious. His critics say he should be hanged from a lamppost.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Handling Medical Errors
description: Readers discuss apologies, disciplinary actions and lawsuits.

title: N.S.A. Plan to Log Calls Is Renewed by Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court released a new legal opinion on Friday that reauthorized the once-secret National Security Agency program that keeps records of every Americans phone calls. The opinion also sought to plug a hole in a similar ruling made public last month.

title: As Iran Shifts, Hard-Liners See Threat to Battle Cry
description: TEHRAN  With the believers pouring out of the Friday Prayer site in Tehran, Ali Akbar and his friends sprang into action, hastily spreading posters of the American flag on the asphalt and switching on their megaphone.

title: World Series Seems Rodriguez-Proof
description: Alex Rodriguezs arbitration hearing recessed on Friday and will not resume until sometime in November, which apparently means this years World Series may be able to proceed without the Yankees third baseman creating a distinct distraction.

title: Cardinals Take Beltran to World Series
description: ST. LOUIS  Carlos Beltran was used to the scent. Seven times before Friday, he had sniffed the World Series, playing a game with a chance to win the pennant. Every time, his team had lost. Once, Beltran struck out looking to end the season.

title: Hit by Low Prices, Lobstermen Are at Odds in Maine and Canada
description: OTTAWA  Lobsters do not respect the lines on maps that define the Canada-United States border. They traverse the seabed contentedly munching on herring from New England to Newfoundland.

title: Corruption in Peru Aids Cutting of Rain Forest
description: PUCALLPA, Peru  Afraid the police would tip off suspects, Francisco Berrospi kept local officers in the dark when he headed into the rain forest as a prosecutor to investigate illegal logging. Sometimes it hardly seemed to matter, though.

title: White Sox Seek a Jolt of Power With a Cuban Slugger
description: CHICAGO  The White Sox finished 2013 with 99 losses, the most since they lost a franchise-worst 106 games in 1970. Less than three weeks after their season ended, they made the first big free-agent splash of the off-season by agreeing to a six-year, $68 million contract with the 26-year-old Cuban first baseman Jose Dariel Abreu.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: A deal is made to end the government shutdown, a Belgian company buys an American craft brewery and class-action lawsuits are filed against oil companies for burning off natural gas.

title: Illegal Logging Thrives in Peru, Environmentalists Say
description: An investigator goes to remote areas at the western end of the Amazon rain forest.

title: Texans Stick With Cruz Despite Defeat in Washington
description: HOUSTON  Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas and the face of the angry right, has been criticized, lambasted and lampooned for putting the nation through a 16-day government shutdown and the prospect of a financial default.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 19, 2013
description: You see Republicans voting for immigration reform, you see Democrats voting for streamlining environmental regulations. You never would have seen that before.

title: Kentuckys Case of the Missing Bourbon
description: FRANKFORT, Ky.  Americas decade-old romance with Kentucky bourbon, a drink formerly as plebeian as a Chevrolet, has come to this: high-end bar chefs and foodies everywhere have been abuzz since 65 cases of Pappy Van Winkle, one of the nations most expensive and sought-after bourbons, disappeared from a warehouse here.

title: Policing the Amazon
description: With vast territory to cover across Peru, government authorities are working hard to fight the illegal timber trade that often goes on deep in the jungle.

title: Continuing Salmonella Outbreaks
description: Months after salmonella-contaminated chicken distributed by a California company sickened people, the dangerous food is still being sold around the country. This disturbing situation is the result of weak federal regulatory powers and the companys irresponsibility.

title: Shortsighted Arms Deregulation
description: President Obama has rightly earned praise for signing the international Arms Trade Treaty, which seeks to keep many kinds of conventional weapons out of the hands of terrorists and other criminals who fuel conflicts around the globe. He now risks undercutting that treaty, as well as American laws and national security interests, by loosening regulatory controls on many of Americas own military exports.

title: No Vacancies
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg said on the radio on Friday that New Yorkers are lucky to live in a city where apartments are so hard to find. Somebody said that theres not enough housing, he said. Thats a good sign. As fast as we build, more people want to live here.

title: Detectives Working on Police Tips Line Must Sift and Coax
description: Dozens of times each day, someone reaches for the phone and dials 1-800-577-TIPS, the anonymous tips line of the New York Police Department. Callers may be motivated by a guilty conscience, a desire for reward money, a keen sense of justice or some less classifiable impulse.

title: Pirating Russias Hardwood
description: Hardwood timber from Russias Far East is being illegally cut and shipped to China to feed huge consumer demand for cheap wood products globally.

title: Fordham Enjoying Renaissance, on a Smaller Scale
description: Once a week, Gabrielle Cremone, a sophomore at Fordham, volunteers to lead prospective students on tours through the serene campus in the Rose Hill neighborhood of the Bronx, walking past the Gothic-style buildings and 19th-century chapels. This semester, Cremone has added a new destination on her tour: the home of the emergent Fordham Rams football team.

title: Long Island Man Faces Terrorism Charges After Failed Trip to Yemen
description: A Long Island man who the authorities say tried to fly to Yemen to join a branch of Al Qaeda was charged on Friday with conspiring to commit murder overseas and other terrorism counts.

title: Final Race Will Test The Luck of Castroneves
description: Helio Castroneves was boarding a flight out of Houston last week, eager to clear his head of the weekends great disappointment: a broken gearbox scuttled what looked to be a clean shot at his first IndyCar Series championship.

title: A Killing, a Puzzle: Self-Defense or Vigilantism
description: Nelson Acosta-Sanchez had proved surprisingly difficult to catch. Mr. Acosta-Sanchez, who was accused of the statutory rape of a 14-year-old girl, had already eluded capture, slipping out of the polices grasp and later swimming across a reservoir before disappearing.

title: Facebooks New Rules
description: No sooner had the ink dried on my last column  about the new Dave Eggerss novel The Circle, in which he imagines a world without privacy  than Facebook announced two changes to its privacy settings. In its short nine-year existence, Facebook has made many changes to its privacy policies, of course. More often than not, the changes have enabled the company to monetize the rich trove of data it collects from its users. When you get right down to it, thats really all it has to sell.

title: Juror in Tussle Over Taxi Is Taken Off Fraud Case
description: For two days, a defense lawyer sought to have a juror removed from a fraud case being tried in Federal District Court in Manhattan. And for two days the juror assured the judge that her impartiality had not been compromised and that she could carry on.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 18, 2013
Corrections: October 19, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Hows It Goin?
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I dont think Ive had this much fun with a Saturday puzzle in a long time. Theres a certain amount of loin-girding that goes with solving the Saturday crossword puzzle. I love the challenge, but I know Im going to have to really work for the answers. And work I do; I have always been honest about not being a speed solver or an expert, although I can tell you that my solving has certainly improved markedly with daily practice.

title: More Laser Pointers Aimed at Airplanes, F.B.I. Reports
description: Reports of people aiming laser pointers at airplanes landing in the New York City area are up 17 percent compared with last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation saidon Fridayas it sought information on a spate of recent incidents.

title: States Are Focus of Effort to Foil Health Care Law
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The federal government is again open for business, and Republicans in Washington are licking their wounds from the failed Tea Party attempt to derail President Obamas health care overhaul. But here in Virginias capital, conservative activists are pursuing a hardball campaign as they chart an alternative path to undoing Obamacare  through the states.

title: Giants, the Stalwarts of a City, Suddenly Cant Make It There
description: New York City is home to a noisy gaggle of professional sports teams shouting for attention.

title: The Presidents Pivot
description: Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory.

title: Giants Losing Streak, by the Numbers
description: The Giants have lost their first six games, the team's worst start to a season since 1976 (and other unflattering facts about a team that won the Super Bowl two seasons ago).

title: Lobbying Bonanza as Firms Try to Influence European Union
description: BRUSSELS  It was a show of force in keeping with the ambitions of American law firms that increasingly see the European Unions vast apparatus as a vital lobbying opportunity for themselves and their multinational corporate clients.

title: Against Jets, Patriots Can Do Without Thrills
description: BOSTON  Patriots and Red Sox fans are still celebrating Sundays back-to-back thrillers: a 30-27 victory with five seconds remaining against the previously undefeated New Orleans Saints and a series-changing 6-5 comeback victory against the Detroit Tigers in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series.

title: Red Sox Will Stay With Drew, for His Glove if Not His Bat
description: BOSTON  The last time the Red Sox played in a Game 6 at Fenway Park was 2007, and J. D. Drew was one of the teams heroes. Drew went 3 for 5 with a home run and 5 runs batted in, including a tone-setting, first-inning grand slam from which the Cleveland Indians never recovered.

title: Roger Richman, 69, Dies; Lobbied for Stars Heirs
description: Roger Richman, a celebrity agent who is widely credited with helping to invent the dead-celebrity industry, a multimillion-dollar realm built on licensing the rights to images of the prominent posthumously, died on Oct. 9 in Los Angeles. He was 69.

title: Cameras Found on L.I.R.R. Machines
description: Hidden cameras have been found attached to ticket vending machines on the Long Island Railroad, and the police are warning customers who have used the machines to check for any unauthorized activity on their credit or debit cards.

title: Anthony Hinds, Who Scared British Moviegoers, Dies at 91
description: Anthony Hinds, the producer who put the horror in Hammer horror, in the process turning a puny British film studio into a Goliath of cinematic gore, died in Oxford, England on Sept. 30. He was 91.

title: After Prison, Regret From Man Who Sold a Hoax to Try to Buy the Islanders
description: The man in the Islanders cap and sweatshirt partying with a dozen or so fans outside Nassau Coliseum last January was a specter from the teams weirdest and maybe darkest days. It was John Spano, the businessman-turned-felon from Dallas who had nearly bought the team 16 years earlier, even though he never had the money to pay for it.

title: Gloria Lynne, Singer of I Wish You Love, Dies at 83
description: Gloria Lynne, a jazz diva who climbed onto the pop charts with her recording of I Wish You Love in 1964 and continued singing for more than half a century even in the face of poverty, died on Oct. 15 in Newark. She was 83.

title: Giants Rush Hillis Onto Roster and Into Plans
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  If Peyton Hillis had reached the end of his professional football career, even at age 27, he was fine with that.

title: Clustering Near the Seat of Power
description: Hundreds of businesses, organizations or lobbying firms that seek to influence the European government have outposts near the European Parliament in Brussels.

title: Ralph Cook, a Pioneer of Off Off Broadway, Dies at 85
description: It was the kind of conversation that young restaurant employees in New York have surely had hundreds if not thousands of times since the early 1960s, when Ralph Cook was a waiter at the Village Gate, a nightclub in Greenwich Village.

title: More Trouble for Rangers: Callahan Is Out With Broken Thumb
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers and the Devils are limping into their meeting in Newark on Saturday, looking to break out of their early-season misery.

title: Restaurant Critics: Budget Squeeze
description: Part 14: The critics talk about how their work is affected by competitors and budget realities.

description: Part 2: The critics discuss how they avoid being recognized in restaurants.

title: David Bouley: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the chef and restauranteur David Bouley.

title: TimesTalks | Restaurant Critics: Preview
description: Ruth Reichl, William Grimes, Sam Sifton and Pete Wells discuss what its like to be a restaurant critic for the New York Times.

title: Restaurant Critics: Most Hated Reviews
description: Part 11: The critics reminisce about the most controversial reviews theyve written.

title: Restaurant Critics: No Notes
description: Part 13: The critics explain how they remember the details of a meal without obviously taking notes.

title: Restaurant Critics: Staying in Shape
description: Part 5: The critics discuss how they stay healthy in a profession that requires constant dining out.

title: David Bouley: Americans Dont Get Food
description: Part 8: The chef and restauranteur reflects on Americans relationship with food.

title: Restaurant Critics: Home Cooks
description: Part 10: The critics talk about their own skills in the kitchen.
