description: Part 7: The chef and restauranteur explains how better understanding our food can make us better cooks.

title: Restaurant Critics: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the current and former New York Times restaurant critics.

title: Restaurant Critics: Last Meal
description: Part 12: The critics reflect on what they would choose as their last meals in New York.

title: Restaurant Critics: A Changing Role
description: Part 7: The critics reflect on how restaurant criticism has evolved and changed from its early years.

title: David Bouley: Making It Better
description: Part 10: The chef and restauranteur reveals the process behind improving an already-loved dish.

title: Restaurant Critics: In Disguise
description: Part 3: The critics talk about the fake names and disguises theyve used to evade detection, and the special treatment theyve received when recognized.

title: David Bouley: Japanese Values
description: Part 6: The chef and restauranteur talks about what hes learned from Japanese cuisine and the Japanese approach to cooking.

title: Restaurant Critics: Stars
description: Part 9: The critics discuss the star system, and the freedoms of being a former restaurant critic.

title: David Bouley: A Living Pantry
description: Part 11: The chef and restauranteur talks about practical, home applications of his techniques.

title: David Bouley: A Cook and His Tools
description: Part 14: The chef and restauranteur discusses the importance of the right tools in the kitchen.

title: Restaurant Critics: Unlike Other Critics
description: Part 4: The critics explain how reviewing restaurants is different from reviewing art or performances.

title: David Bouley: Food Mysteries
description: Part 13: The chef and restauranteur reflects on the role of vegetables in the diet.

title: Restaurant Critics: Company of Others
description: Part 6: The critics talk about the potential ways that their dining partners can influence their reviews.

title: David Bouley: Famous Chicken
description: Part 9: The chef and restauranteur discusses cooking sous vide, and one of his famous dishes.

title: Restaurant Critics: Fast Food?
description: Part 8: The critics reveal whether they ever eat fast food.

title: Restaurant Critics: How You Tip
description: Part 15: The critics share their opinions on tipping.

title: David Bouley: No More Butter and Cream
description: Part 5: The chef and restauranteur discusses the evolving role of cream and butter in his cooking.

title: David Bouley: Science and Sous Vide
description: Part 4: The chef and restauranteur reflects on how science and medicine informs his ideas about food.

title: David Bouley: Lobster
description: Part 12: The chef and restauranteur explains his favorite lobster preparation and talks about his new kitchen.

title: Outspoken Chinese Professor Says He Was Dismissed
description: HONG KONG  A politically outspoken Chinese economist, Xia Yeliang, will lose his professorship at Peking University, one of Chinas most prestigious and internationally prominent schools, after a committee voted to dismiss him, Professor Xia said on Saturday. The decision came after months of contention over his future, which his supporters have said reflects the Communist Partys efforts to deter liberal political views on campuses.

title: Cardinals Win Pennant Once More, With Feeling
description: ST. LOUIS  By the end of the National League Championship Series, late Friday night, a cold, misty drizzle had settled over Busch Stadium. Nobody seemed to mind. The scoreboard read 9-0 in favor of the home team, just as it did last fall, when the Cardinals season slipped away in the San Francisco rain.

title: Bum Phillips, Homespun Coach Behind Oilers Rise, Dies at 90
description: Bum Phillips, the homespun Texan who was caricatured as a cowboy but possessed a keen football mind that built the Houston Oilers into one of the National Football Leagues leading teams of the late 1970s, died Friday at his ranch in Goliad, Tex. He was 90.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) MAMA (2013) In this modern fairy tale directed by Andy Muschietti, the uncle (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) of two feral sisters (Megan Charpentier, above, and Isabelle Nlisse), abandoned by their father in the woods, moves them into a home with his Goth girlfriend (Jessica Chastain). Then a grotesque figure the girls call Mama appears in the shadows and begins to wreak havoc on their lives. But is the monster simply a coping mechanism for dealing with tragedy? Or is Mama the essence of the girls dead mother? Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that dont often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you dont want anyone to take an ax to them, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while the director, Guillermo del Toro, the reigning godfather of motion picture horror, took only an executive producing credit on the film, it fits with the more successful movies hes signed onto. Mr. del Toro understands that nothing says terror like a home thats become a rattling cage.

title: Read!
description: The coolest library Ive ever been to is in a book. Its a literal labyrinth, made that way to scare off medieval monks from pursuing forbidden knowledge. There are 50-some seven-sided rooms and a few more square ones, and all of them have varying numbers of doors to the other rooms, and each is named after a Latin verse from the Apocalypse of John. Additional features include distorting mirrors, psychotropic herbs to induce visions and a ventilation system that whistles and feels like ghosts breathing on your face.

title: Swap Frees Lebanese Held by Syrian Rebels in Exchange for Turks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A flurry of back-room Middle East diplomacy led to an ambitious international prisoner swap on Saturday that freed Lebanese citizens held by Syrian rebels and Turkish pilots kidnapped by Lebanese gunmen.

title: Life in the Swamp
description: In early September 1863, a young Union soldier wrote a letter to his former professor back at Oberlin College, where he had studied before the war. The soldier, who identified himself only as G, had been tasked with taking a census of the freedmen on Craney Island, near Norfolk, Va. The African-American population of the area had been swelling since the arrival of Union forces the previous May, and soldiers like G were to provide the first step toward, among other things, organizing and recruiting black soldiers for the war effort.

title: Suicide Blast in Somalia Kills 15, Police Say
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than a dozen people, including at least four Ethiopian soldiers, were killed Saturday in a suicide attack on a cafe in western Somalia, near the border with Ethiopia. The Shabab, the militant Somali Islamist group, claimed responsibility.

title: ZLB Denial
description: Yes  if back in 2007 you denied the existence of liquidity traps, that is, denied that the zero lower bound on short-term interest rates places limits on monetary policy, you should long since have acknowledged that you were very, very wrong:

title: Invitation to Veterans, Their Friends and Families
description: The editors of Home Fires are requesting the participation of readers for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11, 2013. If you are a veteran, or friend or relative of someone who served in the military and would like to share a written message or recollection, or a photograph recalling a veteran or their service, you can send it to us via e-mail at opinionator@nytimes.com.

title: Do Currency Regimes Matter?
description: Antonio Fatas, citing new work by Andy Rose (pdf), suggests that currency regimes dont really matter  in particular that membership in the euro has not really been a special problem for peripheral countries.

title: Batali & Symon: Vegas
description: Part 10: The chefs describe how to make a restaurant in Las Vegas work, and talk about what makes them want to open new restaurants.

title: Batali & Symon: The Chew
description: Part 2: The chefs explain the host chemistry that makes The Chew a successful show.

title: Batali & Symon: Burger Joints
description: Part 9: The chefs explain why more and more chefs are opening casual concept restaurants.

title: Batali & Symon: Farmers and Chefs
description: Part 7: The chefs talk about the importance of farms and farmers in good food, and reflect on the future of collaboration between farmers and chefs.

title: Batali & Symon: Twitter
description: Part 12: The chefs discuss how social media has impacted the way they work.

title: Batali & Symon: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the chefs Mario Batali and Michael Symon.

title: Batali & Symon: Paula Deen
description: Part 8: The chefs discuss the responsibilities and pitfalls of being a food celebrity.

title: Batali & Symon: Authenticity
description: Part 5: The chefs explain what they think true authenticity in cooking means.

title: Batali & Symon: How to Win Iron Chef
description: Part 11: The chefs reveal the secret of how to win on Iron Chef.

title: Batali & Symon: Food Ethics
description: Part 13: The chefs describe their philosophy on GMOs and humanely raised animals.

title: Batali & Symon: Chef Heads
description: Part 3: The chefs talk about the challenges of reconciling the sensibilities of haute cuisine with those of daytime television.

title: TimesTalks | Batali & Symon: Preview
description: The award-winning chefs sit down with the Timess Julia Moskin to discuss their work as culinary celebrities and hosts of The Chew.

title: Batali & Symon: Over-Intellectualizing
description: Part 4: The chefs reflect on food cultures tendency to value faddishness over fundamentals.

title: Batali & Symon: Beef Cheek Pierogies
description: Part 6: The chefs discuss Symons technique and success in adapting coastal food culture for his Cleveland restaurants.

title: In Latest Snag, Police Block Maldives Vote for President
description: NEW DELHI  The police in the island nation of Maldives blocked a rescheduled presidential election on Saturday, setting the stage for a potential constitutional crisis if there is no replacement for the current president when his term runs out in November.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: High School Sexual Assault Case Is Revisited, Haunting Missouri Town
description: MARYVILLE, Mo.  The mayor of this small manufacturing town in northwest Missouri hardly blinks an eye these days when he gets an e-mail that calls him an unflattering name in the subject line. Those tend to be the tame ones. Others cut much deeper.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Wordplay, and indeed almost every other form of communication, would not exist without the subject of todays acrostic. Michel Eyquem de Montaigne was considered to be the creator of the written essay and, as such, we can count him as the first blogger.

title: Cardinals Strategy Replaces Big Names With Ingenuity
description: ST. LOUIS  Through the first five games of the National League Championship Series, one run separated the St. Louis Cardinals and the Los Angeles Dodgers. By the end of the series, the teams seemed worlds apart.

title: With Series Clincher, Red Sox Ensure Memories Are Lasting
description: BOSTON  The Game 2 home run by David Ortiz that turned around the American League Championship Series was indelibly memorable as soon as it was hit. But now the image of Detroits Torii Hunter going headfirst into the Boston bullpen has become absolutely symbolic after the Red Sox, by winning the American League pennant on Saturday night at Fenway Park with a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers, reached their third World Series in 10 years.

title: Seeing Things in Red and Blue After All
description: WASHINGTON  THE great irony of Barack Obamas political rise is that it depended on what turned out to be his single biggest political miscalculation. From the moment he appeared on a national stage  in his 2004 there is not a liberal America and a conservative America speech  he held himself out as the leader who could transcend the partisan divide and win over Republicans.

title: Val DiFebo of Deutsch NY, on Being Direct
description: This interview with  Val DiFebo, chief executive of Deutsch NY, the advertising agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Lies, Damned Lies, and Fox News
description: The other day Sean Hannity featured some Real Americans telling tales of how they have been hurt by Obamacare. So Eric Stern, who used to work for Brian Schweitzer, had a bright idea: he actually called Hannitys guests, to get the details.

title: Vows | Mr. Duckett and Dr. Jones
description: Together 46 years, Lewis Duckett and Billy Jones wrote coded letters to each other during Dr. Joness deployment in Vietnam. They adopted a baby, became grandfathers and then, finally, got married.

title: Cosmos Are Right Where They Want to Be
description: Around the North American Soccer League, a lament that rang true in the heyday of the league more than 30 years ago  the Cosmos are using their vast resources (Warner Communications then; an international group backed by the Saudi-based Sela Sports now) to buy championships  is again being heard from some less well-heeled clubs.

title: Policing Village Moral Codes as Women Stream to Indias Cities
description: ROHTAK, India  Meena, 20, was a village girl herself, so she can recognize the changes that come when girls from the village arrive in this city as students and take their first gulps of freedom.

title: How to Pay Millions and Lag Behind the Market
description: Todays low-interest-rate environment has made the hunt for investment income tougher than ever. Many overseers of public pension funds, desperate to bolster returns and meet ballooning retiree obligations, have turned from traditional investments like stocks and bonds to hedge funds and private equity.

title: Summer Camp at the Capitol? Hardly
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Fixing Scandal Hangs Over Nascars Playoff and a Racing Teams Future
description: CONCORD, N.C.  The cheating scandal at Richmond International Raceway that rocked Nascar more than a month ago continues to be felt in a sport whose credibility has been questioned by fans, the news media and even its drivers.

title: Foreign Aid, Refined
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: In St. Louis, Celebrating a Team Long Gone
description: In the corridor of a St. Louis-area hotel last month, Sam Cash waited in line for autographs from members of the long-departed major league team known as the Browns. The signatures secured, he then sat at an adjacent table with his own Browns display that featured team trivia, a team time line and photographs of his favorite Browns player, Bud Thomas. Fans and several former Browns took a look.

title: Driving a New Bargain on Health Care
description: The Affordable Care Act has gotten off to a rocky start. Federal and state online health insurance exchanges, which opened for business at the beginning of the month, have been bedeviled by technical snags. And opposition to the law from some House Republicans blocked funding for the entire federal government, leading to its partial shutdown.

title: CMJ: Arcade Fire Takes the Stage. No, Not That One.
description: It was not a secret for long. Last week posters, looking like advertisements for a cheesy lounge promotion from the 1970s, appeared in Brooklyn announcing: The Reflektors, 10/18 Brooklyn 10/19, Formal attire or costume mandatory. Prizes for best costumes!

title: Robert Shiller: A Skeptic and a Nobel Winner
description: Robert J. Shiller, a professor at Yale, learned on Monday that he had won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, along with Lars Peter Hansen and Eugene F. Fama of the University of Chicago. The Nobel committee described Professor Shiller as a founder of the field of behavioral finance, an innovator in incorporating psychology into economics and a pioneering analyst of speculative bubbles in the stock and real estate markets.

title: TimesTalks | David Bouley: Preview
description: The renowned chef and restauranteur discusses his cooking career and his ideas about food.

title: From a Bitter End to a Fresh Chance for Freeman
description: Josh Freeman may one day thank Greg Schiano for chasing him out of Tampa Bay. That concept might be difficult for Freeman to imagine today, while the hurtful emotions of the sudden end of their quarterback-coach relationship are fresh.

title: Alarming Abuses of Medical Credit Cards
description: Patients around the nation are being victimized by medical credit cards that can lead to financial calamity. These cards, issued by specialty finance companies as well as commercial banks, carry exorbitant interest rates after an initial period of zero interest expires  with heavy penalties for late payments. They are often pushed on patients with modest incomes by health care providers who want to make sure that they get paid, even if some of their patients end up with huge credit card bills they cant afford. Unless strong regulatory action is taken to curb the abuses, financial companies will continue to gouge consumers at their most vulnerable moments, when they are in pain and need medical attention.

title: World to Washington: Really?
description: PARIS  Not many Americans traveling abroad over the past three weeks could escape some fairly unpleasant reactions to the government shutdown in the United States.

title: The Writing on the Wall
description: Art will abide. Artists will be with us always. And the news will surely live on, as long as humans remain curious and communicative.

title: Europes Slow Progress on Banking Reform
description: The European Union last week moved one step closer to establishing a banking union that could help address problems in its financial system. But the Continents leaders need to act faster and do much more to end the long-running crisis.

title: The High Cost of Low Politics
description: Early this year, it was widely acknowledged that the economy was in for a tough patch. The fiscal cliff showdown at the end of 2012 had led to higher payroll taxes and had locked in earlier cuts to jobless benefits, while the sequester  deep and arbitrary federal spending cuts enacted to end a previous debt standoff  kicked in on March 1. The only consolation at the time was that several economic forecasters expected conditions to improve later in the year.

title: A Diaspora of 11 Million
description: Estimates of Roma populations vary. Figures on this map are from the Council of Europe, a human rights organization.

title: Dina Katabi
description: Syrian-born Dina Katabi is a professor of electrical engineering and computer science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was awarded a MacArthur genius grant last month for her work on improving the speed, reliability and security of data networks.

title: Here Comes the Neighborhood
description: SUBURBIA beckons many poor and working-class families with the promise of better schools, access to non-dead-end jobs and sanctuary from the looming threat of urban violence. But many suburbanites balk at the prospect of affordable housing in their midst.

title: The Lessons of Japans Economy
description: BY many measures, Japans economic fortunes have turned up. The Tokyo stock market has surged about 65 percent since last fall. In the second quarter, the economy expanded by 3.8 percent, which is faster than other developed economies. At last, prices are edging upward, a good thing for Japan. Yet, the mood in Tokyo among businessmen and economists remains precariously balanced between enthusiasm for the monetary and fiscal stimulus unleashed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and worry that promised structural reforms might not be implemented.

title: Cat on a Hot Stove
description: WASHINGTON  PRESIDENT OBAMA won big.

title: Are Chicks Brighter Than Babies?
description: SOME Americans are wondering whether to eat chicken in the aftermath of the latest salmonella outbreak.

title: Obamacare, Failing Ahead of Schedule
description: THIS is not the column about the Obamacare rollout I expected to write.

title: Color Me Blue
description: BLOOMBERG, love him or hate him? a friend asked.

title: Are the Roma Primitive, or Just Poor?
description: PARIS  THE cluster of Roma, handcuffed and caged-in behind glass walls, listened in silence as prosecutors accused them in court of selling child brides for up to about $270,000 in cash, valuing them based on their ability to steal. In a case that has riveted France, the prosecutors accused three family clans from Croatia of grooming girls and boys as young as 11 to steal as part of a gang that committed 100 robberies in France, Belgium and Germany in 2011.

title: The Middle Class Gets Wise
description: Perhaps we underestimate ourselves. Five years after the Lehman collapse triggered the deepest recession in eight decades, the middle class may be solving the vexing problems of income inequality and stalled wages on its own.

title: The Good Men of India
description: BANGALORE, India  IN India today, the rapes of women, from children to grandmothers, are daily news. Frothy television programs on sentimentalized family values are interrupted by advertisements for a new smartphone app: VithU, which allows women in danger, at a double press of a power button, to send an S O S alert with their location to predesignated friends and family members.

title: Maam, Your Burger Has Been Paid For
description: IF you place an order at the Chick-fil-A drive-through off Highway 46 in New Braunfels, Tex., its not unusual for the driver of the car in front of you to pay for your meal in the time it took you to holler into the intercom and pull around for pickup.

title: My Selfie, Myself
description: RECENTLY, I came across a great find in a Vermont antiques store: an old black-and-white photograph of a female pilot on a mountaintop, her aviator glasses pushed up on her forehead, revealing a satisfied, wind-burned face, the wings of her plane just visible behind her. But the best part of the discovery was the slow realization that she was holding the camera herself. It was, for lack of a better word, a selfie.

title: Why We Make Bad Decisions
description: LONDON  SIX years ago I was struck down with a mystery illness. My weight dropped by 30 pounds in three months. I experienced searing stomach pain, felt utterly exhausted and no matter how much I ate, I couldnt gain an ounce.

title: Hearing an Irresistible Beat
A Washington Football Fan Breaks With Tradition
description: I am a third-generation fan of the professional football team in Washington. When my family sat down for pancakes last weekend, with a big game against Washingtons archrival, Dallas, looming on the eve of Columbus Day, I had to tell my children why we were not going to use the teams nickname anymore.

title: An Invention That Marinated for 19 Years
description: Mary Hunter has always been happy to cook for her congregation at the Yes Lord Church in Gary, Ind. Her recipes, she told me, come directly from God. I dont have a cookbook, she said. God gives me my own. Prayer is where I get 99 percent of my recipes.

title: When the Bosses Are Whispering
description: Ive been in a new role at my company for three months, and Ive felt rather left out of my new team. Theres a new department head, and Ive been conveniently, or not so conveniently, forgotten in two meeting invitations when I should have been included.

title: To Jets Ryan, the Passer Rating Really Does Mean Something
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Before Rex Ryan addresses his players after games, he is handed an index card loaded with the numbers that matter most to him. He glances at each teams turnovers and combined total of runs and completions, and also a statistic that has long been derided and disparaged, mocked for its shortcomings in measuring the quarterbacks performance.

title: Starting the Wine
description: In the predawn chill of a September morning, Mario Bazn, his wife, Gloria, and their crew of about 10 workers arrived to harvest sauvignon blanc grapes grown on a plot near their Napa Valley home. Helping them in their work was a generator with bright lights attached, pulled by a tractor. On this morning, they harvested enough grapes to produce 220 cases of Mario Bazn Cellars wine. Picking the grapes in the early morning means that they are cooler when they go into the collection bins, which helps keep the sugars in ideal condition.

title: Tentative Deal Hands JPMorgan Chase a Record Penalty
description: Updated, 8:06 p.m. |

title: A Harvest Before Dawn
description: The first steps toward producing this years sauvignon blanc at Mario Bazn Cellars are taken under a night sky in the Napa Valley of California.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 20
description: Congress reached a deal late Wednesday to end the 16-day government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling before the nation ran out of money to pay its bills. On Sunday lawmakers will weigh in on that agreement and what comes next as Congress faces another set of deadlines early next year.

title: A Boy Who Played With Trains
description: My first job that mattered was on the Missouri Pacific Railroad, in 1963. I hired out  railroad lingo  as a locomotive fireman, working the switchyards in Little Rock, Ark. I was 19, and knew almost nothing about anything  certainly not about real work, and not about how work almost always affiliates you significantly with the lives of others.

title: France Says Deportation of Roma Girl Was Legal
description: PARIS  A 15-year-old girl who was ordered off a school bus by French police officers so that she and her family could be sent back to Kosovo was legally deported, but the operation could have been conducted with more sensitivity, the French government said Saturday after an investigation.

title: Seeking Online Refuge From Spying Eyes
description: Consider this scene in The Circle, Dave Eggerss new novel that imagines a dystopian future dominated by an omnipotent social networking company: Mae, the young protagonist, tries to unplug from her hypernetworked life to go on a covert, solitary kayaking trip. But when she returns to shore, she is greeted by police officers who have been alerted to her excursion by several hidden cameras. She quickly realizes that very little in her life isnt recorded, tracked and analyzed.

title: Aid to Pakistan to Resume as Tension With U.S. Eases
description: WASHINGTON  The United States plans to give more than $1.5 billion in assistance to Pakistan for programs that had been blocked because of tension between the two nations over events including the Navy SEAL raid that killed Osama bin Laden inside Pakistan, American officials said Saturday.

title: This Is War (for a Game Industrys Soul)
description: The Swedish Army drafted Patrick Bach in the early 1990s and tried to make a soldier out of him. No such luck. Mr. Bach couldnt see the point of pretending to protect a country at peace since the Napoleonic wars. The only part he liked was the shooting.

title: Betting on Battlefield
description: Despite shifts in gaming platforms and public relations issues, Swedens Digital Illusions CE is betting millions on the latest version of its first person shooter franchise, Battlefield.

title: In Sweden, a Breeding Ground for Video Games
description: The Scandinavian country has become a hotbed of video game development in recent years, and is home to the makers of several of the industrys most recognized titles, including Battlefield and Minecraft.

title: Hold the Drumstick! Thats an Intellectual Youre Eating!
description: My Sunday column looks at the ethical reasons to be wary of eating chicken, geese and other poultry produced in factory farms. My colleague Mark Bittman had an excellent column a few days ago about the health reasons to be wary, and in particular the salmonella risk. I agree with everything Mark said but want to go a step further. Even aside from the health issues, I think there are particular issues with the way poultry are raised, jammed in pens. Part of that is economics: its cheap to raise hens in cages, while cows and calves typically get pasture because thats cheaper. And part of it is, I think, that we have some natural sympathy and regard for fellow mammals like cattle or hogs, but we dismiss birds as lower animals less deserving of our moral concern.

title: Country Road
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  You might think that the solemn visage that looks down at us from the seated statue of Abraham Lincoln in Washington is the only memorial that exists for our SIXTEENTH U.S. PRESIDENT. And youd be wrong.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, October 20
description: Employees should expect to return to work in the morning.

title: The Sun Sets on a Symbol of Western-Themed Dining
description: SAUGUS, Mass.  The six-person booths in the Hilltop Steak House here were packed on a recent afternoon, and a line of customers stretched out the door. The wait for a table was two hours; by evening, it had grown to four.

title: To Catch Up, Walmart Moves to Amazon Turf
description: SAN BRUNO, Calif.  A plucky Silicon Valley company, forced to compete for talented engineers, is trying it all  recruiting billboards on Highway 101; workplace perks like treadmill workstations and foosball tables; and conference rooms named after celebrities like Rihanna and Justin Bieber.

title: Authors Accept Censors Rules to Sell in China
description: BEIJING  Chinese readers of Ezra F. Vogels sprawling biography of Chinas reformist leader Deng Xiaoping may have missed a few details that appeared in the original English edition.

title: Gun Sentiments and Guns on Display at Alamo Rally
description: SAN ANTONIO  Angela L. Pena brought her family to the Alamo on Saturday. She also brought her black assault rifle, a .223-caliber LWRC M4, and had it strapped across her back. Her daughter brought her M&P rifle; her son-in-law carried his .308-caliber Remington R-25; and her 8-year-old grandson, Sebastian Gonzalez, had his Ruger 10/22 rifle.

title: Best-Selling Foreign Books in China
description: The best-selling foreign titles in China in 2012.

title: Poised for I Do as Soon as New Jersey Allows
description: Romance and bureaucracy are rarely a good match. But this weekend, gay couples in New Jersey are hurrying to overcome administrative hurdles, and plan weddings, before a court ruling that allows same-sex marriage in the state officially takes effect early on Monday.

title: Six Killings in New York End a Lull in Murders
description: After a seven-day stretch in which no homicides were recorded in New York City, five occurred in 10 hours on Friday and Saturday, and another person was killedon Sunday morning.

title: With Its Flashy League Gaining Buzz, Stanford Relies on Brawn
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Stanford resides out West, out in the Pacific-12 Conference, where sunshine and technology and an abundance of speed beget offenses that play football on fast forward. Where the scores often match the temperature, 50s and 60s posted deep into the fall.

title: Two Russian Champions Capitalize on Mistakes
description: Peter Svidler won the national championship in Moscow last week by beating Ian Nepomniachtchi in a playoff. It was Svidlers seventh Russian title in 20 years  an unmatched record.

title: Lobbyists Ready for a New Fight on U.S. Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout the tense fiscal deadlock in recent weeks, some of the most powerful forces in Washington, including retirees and defense contractors, largely sat on the sidelines. Now they are preparing for a political fight with billions of federal dollars at stake.

title: The Factions in the House of Representatives
description: A look at alliances in the House, and how they voted on the compromise to end the government shutdown last week.

title: No Claytie and the Lady This Time
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: After Misuse, a Push for Tutoring
description: A decade after it became law as a part of the federal No Child Left Behind Act, a tutoring program heralded as an academic safety net for children from low-income families in struggling schools has earned few champions  and lost many supporters.

title: For Her Next Piece, a Performance Artist Will Build an Institute
description: In the name of art, she has hung naked on a wall and carved into her own stomach with a razor. She has masturbated in a museum; scrubbed at a pile of bloody, maggoty bones in a fetid basement; stood still while strangers put a gun to her head and stabbed her with thorns; and, in her best-known work, sat silently for seven hours a day, six days a week, as a succession of people lined up to bask in her aura at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Winning Lottery numbers for Oct. 19, 2013
At These Screenings, the Writers Get the Applause
description: If you call the offices of the Austin Film Festival and Conference and are placed on hold, take comfort: you will not be subjected to hummable pop Muzak or an automated voice repeatedly telling you that your party will be with you in a moment.

title: A Governors Last Campaign: To Prove Health Law Works
description: FRANKFORT, Ky.  In the windowless nerve center that resembles a campaign war room, Gov. Steven L. Beshear studied projections on a wall showing that 600 people were logged on to the states health insurance exchange.

title: 2 Bay Area Transit Workers Killed in Train Accident
description: Two transit workers died after being struck by a train near San Francisco on Saturday afternoon, transit officials said.

title: Remedy for Winless Devils: Listless Rangers
description: NEWARK  The loser of Saturday nights game between the winless Devils and the struggling Rangers was going to be embarrassed no matter what happened. But this was ridiculous.

title: Senate Minority Leader Faces Dual Battles in G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Few players in the Republican Partys internal melodrama better embody the tension between the partys establishment and anti-establishment factions than Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader.

title: Fiscal Crisis Sounds the Charge in G.O.P.s Civil War
description: After the budget standoff ended in crushing defeat last week and the political damage reports began to pile up for Republicans, one longtime party leader after another stepped forward to chastise their less seasoned, Tea Party-inspired colleagues who drove the losing strategy.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 20, 2013
description: To me the choice was easy. I thought it was better to have 90 percent of the book available here than zero.

title: Roseland Ballroom May Close in Six Months
description: The Roseland Ballroom, a club in Midtown where generations of bands have performed, is planning to close in April, according to a report on Friday from Billboard.com, which cited an internal e-mail it had obtained.

title: Erin Murphy, Ralph DeBiasi III
description: Dr. Erin Connolly Murphy and Dr. Ralph Michael DeBiasi III were married Saturday at St. Raymond of Penyafort Roman Catholic Church in East Rockaway, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas A. Cardone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Karen Selody, John Goldie
description: Karen Vanessa Selody and John Lawrence Goldie were married Saturday evening by Canon David Sinclair, an Anglican priest, at the St. Bernard Chapel in Mont-Tremblant, Quebec.

title: Gena Prastos, Zachary Linhart
description: Gena Prastos, the daughter of Marcy Orloff Prastos and Kosta Prastos of Edgewater, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Zachary Ernest Linhart, a son of Ellen Schneider Linhart and Dr. Jan Linhart of Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Howard J. Goldsmith officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York.

title: Barrett Brown, Stephen Fried
description: Barrett William Brown and Stephen Ernest Fried are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Donald B. Rossoff at the Yale Club in Manhattan. The ceremony will incorporate an Eastern Orthodox crowning ritual.

title: Jessica Manning, Matthew Mason
description: Dr. Jessica Elizabeth Manning and Maj. Matthew Thomas Mason were married Saturday by the Rev. Cleo Milano, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Michael the Archangel Catholic Church in Convent, La.

title: Erica White, Eric Grey
description: Erica Jill White, a daughter of Shelley F. White and Dr. Sanford F. White of East Brunswick, N.J., was married Saturday to Eric Zane Grey, a son of Elizabeth Grey-Fetherston of Avon, Conn., and the late Romer Zane Grey Jr. Jamie Brokowsky, who was authorized by Vermont, officiated at the Mountain Top Inn in Chittenden, Vt.

title: Nicole Vlez, Alec Templeton
description: Dr. Nicole Francesca Vlez and Alec Kron Templeton were married Saturday in Pittsburgh. The Very Rev. Drew Morgan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Heinz Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Daniel Schapira, Ethan Felson
description: Daniel Paul Schapira and Ethan Joseph Felson are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Steve Gutow at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Lindsey Hankes, Colin Jones
description: Lindsey Nicole Hankes and Colin Patrick Jones were married Saturday evening at Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in Manhattan. Matthew R. Breeden, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Tessa Crompton, Andrew Plaisted
description: Tessa Leigh Crompton, the daughter of Meg C. Winslow of San Carlos, Calif., and John P. Crompton of Pacific Grove, Calif., was married Saturday to Andrew Charles Plaisted, a son of Jane D. Plaisted and James A. Plaisted of Boonton, N.J. Ryan T. Kielty, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Holman Ranch in Carmel Valley, Calif.

title: Melissa Seligmann, Eugene Gokhvat
description: Melissa Kathryn Seligmann, a daughter of Peter O. A. Seligmann of Seattle and the late Susan Monaghan Seligmann, was married Saturday to Eugene Gokhvat, the son of Yelena Sokolov and Michael Gokhvat of Rockville, Md. Jody Gottfried Arnhold, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the vacation home of the Seligmann family in Teton Village, Wyo.

title: Gretchen Page, Sid Solomon
description: Gretchen Haskins Page and Sid Solomon were married Monday evening at the JW Marriott Essex House Hotel in Manhattan. Andrew S. Page, a brother of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Candice Cook and Harry Simmons III
description: Candice Sherrie Cook and Harry Simmons III were married Monday. The Rev. Kandace V. Simmons, the sister of the groom and an interfaith minister, officiated at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Meghan Gallagher, Roger Gill
description: Meghan Colleen Gallagher and Roger Brooke Gill were married Saturday. The Rev. Leonard J. Kempski performed the ceremony at Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Claymont, Del.

title: Melissa Davison, Frank Giovinazzo
description: Melissa Beth Davison, a daughter of Arlene P. Davison and Robert E. Davison of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Frank Thomas Giovinazzo, the son of Donna and Dr. Joseph A. Giovinazzo of New Springville, Staten Island. The Rev. Thomas Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marys Church in Ballston Spa, N.Y.

title: Sarah Kaplan, Zachary Evans
description: Sarah Christine Kaplan and Zachary Leslie Evans were married Saturday at the home of Carol and Michael Smith, an aunt and uncle of the bride, in Dorset, Vt. Judge Scott W. Nusbaum, a judge on the Ross County Court of Common Pleas in Chillicothe, Ohio, officiated.

title: Maura Judkis and Scott Gilmore
description: Maura Louise Judkis and Scott Allen Gilmore were married Saturday evening. The Rev. William R. Bovard, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Heinz Chapel in Pittsburgh, with Rabbi Deborah A. Reichmann taking part.

title: Leigh Harlan, David Perkins Jr.
description: Leigh Marie Harlan and David Joseph Perkins Jr. were married Saturday at Lowndes Grove Plantation in Charleston, S.C. The officiant was R. Christian Beatty, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Curtain Up on a New Production
description: Allen Charles Klein and Bliss Hebert were married Tuesday morning by James Mitchell, a marriage officiant at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York.

title: Richard Powell and Stephen Phillips
description: Richard John Powell and Stephen Christopher Phillips were married Saturday by the Rev. Caroline Stacey, an Episcopal priest, at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York.

title: Christina True and Daniel Pfeiffer
description: Capt. Christina Anne True and Capt. Daniel Rog Pfeiffer, who serve in the United States Air Force, were married Saturday. The Rev. Enrique J. Sera, a Roman Catholic priest and a former Navy chaplain, performed the ceremony at St. Joachim Church in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: Becky Forman, Ian Scott
description: Becky Cara Forman and Ian Michael Scott were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Fass at the Hilton Hotel in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Karen Wolf, Joshua Adland
description: Karen Wolf, a daughter of Yehudit Wolf and David B. Wolf of Skokie, Ill., is to be married in Chicago Sunday evening to Joshua Eliezer Adland, the son of Sandra Chapman Adland and Rabbi Jonathan F. Adland of Canton, Ohio. The grooms father will lead the ceremony, with Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein, the grooms godfather, participating, at the InterContinental Chicago Magnificent Mile hotel.

title: From Roommates to Romance
description: Vivian Sohee Lee and Cavan Hung-Jen Huang were married Saturday at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn. Shauna Kanter, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Elisa Lomnitz Climent and Adam Perlman
description: Elisa Lomnitz Climent and Adam Ross Perlman were married Saturday at 632 on Hudson, an event space in New York. Rabbi Naomi Levy officiated.

title: Girl Version of Him, Boy Version of Her
description: Chelsa Lynn Skees and Dennis Paul Crowley were married Saturday at Buttermilk Falls Inn in Milton, N.Y. Sarah Simmons, a Universal Life Church minister, officiated.

title: Electricity Leads to the Spark
description: Claire Antone Payton and Jonathan Myerson Katz were married Saturday by Rabbi David Ariel-Joel at the Athenaeum at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Yeng-Tse Wu, Edward Palmisano
description: Yeng-Tse Wu and Edward James Palmisano were married Saturday at Perry Street Restaurant in New York. The Rev. Laura V. Queen, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Kate Rinaldi, Timothy Kennedy
description: Kate Elizabeth Rinaldi and Dr. Timothy John Kennedy were married Saturday at the Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart on the campus of Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Dennis McManus, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Kanan Bhatt and Ravi Shah
description: Kanan Bhatt, the daughter of Yogini Bhatt and Bhargav Bhatt of South Brunswick, N.J., is to be married in Somerset, N.J., on Sunday morning to Ravi Shah, a son of Hemlata Shah and Dipak Shah, also of South Brunswick. Vimesh Thakar, a Hindu priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Palace at Somerset Park.

title: College Football Around the Country
description: DEVIN GARDNER AND JEREMY GALLON Gardner, right, threw for 503 yards and 2 touchdowns and ran for 81 yards and 3 scores in a 63-47 home win for Michigan over Indiana. Gallon had a Big Ten-record 369 receiving yards and scored twice.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Oct. 18, 2013
description: The federal government is up and running again after a last-minute deal that ended the shutdown and raised the debt ceiling so the government can pay its billsfor now. This week on Money Talking, WNYC contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine review the economic damage from the 16-day shutdown, what happens next, and how business leaders are considering getting involved in Republican primaries. Plus, whats in store at Apple after the company hired the C.E.O. of Burberry to run its stores.

title: Victorinos Slam Sends Red Sox to World Series
description: BOSTON  In 2004, they wore their hair long and projected a goofy, irreverent manner.

title: Winston Solidifies Stardom by Overwhelming Clemson
description: CLEMSON, S.C.  This was Jameis Winstons introduction to stardom: silencing Death Valley onSaturdaynight, quarterbacking Florida State to a signature win over Clemson and making a firm case for the Heisman Trophy.

title: Corrections: October 20 2013
description: OBITUARIES

title: Dispute Over Border Security Could Cause Delay for Bridge to Mexico
description: BROWNSVILLE  Lauded last year as a model of cooperation and a means to boost Texas robust trade relationship with Mexico, a rail project here in the Rio Grande Valley has hit a snag over the relocation of an X-ray machine.

title: Abes Burdens
description: Prime Minister Abe is constrained by his countrys past.

title: A Child With Autism Becomes a Teenager With Expectations
description: The night before his 13th birthday, Benj came to the door of my office and knocked in his typically abrupt way. Mommy, I need to talk to you, he said. Im really worried about tomorrow.

title: Bomber Tied to Al Qaeda Kills Dozens in Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A suicide bomber detonated a truck filled with propane tanks at a crowded military checkpoint in central Syria on Sunday, killing more than 30 people, most of them civilians, in the second such attack by fighters linked to Al Qaeda in two days.

title: Look Up to Notorious B.I.G.? No Way, Some Say. No Street or Avenue, Either.
description: It is hard to know what would come as the bigger surprise to the rapper Christopher Wallace, better known as the Notorious B.I.G., or Biggie Smalls, or Big Poppa.

title: Disruptions: Silicon Valleys Next Stop: The Kitchen
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Megan Miller knows that cockroaches are packed with protein and she says they can be made into a surprisingly tasty treat. But if that is a bit too avant-garde to believe, do you think you might like crickets if they were ground up into a powder so you cant see wings or legs?

title: The Worst Ex-Central Banker in the World
description: Steven Pearlstein reads Alan Greenspans new book, and discovers that Greenspan believes that he bears no responsibility for all the bad things that happened on his watch  and that the solution to financial crises is, you guessed it, less government.

title: A Very Un-British Fight for the English Title
description: LONDON  The Boleyn Ground is as British as Buckingham Palace. It is the place where West Ham United was formed more than a century ago. It is a stadium synonymous with Bobby Moore, Geoff Hurst and Martin Peters, all core players in Englands 1966 World Cup triumph.

title: The Man Wholl Do Triage on Europes Banks
description: FRANKFURT  All Ignazio Angeloni has to do is figure out Europes banking system.

title: Conflicting Signals From Senate G.O.P.  on Another Shutdown
description: In the wake of the spending deal last week that reopened the federal government through early 2014, Republicans tried to ease concerns Sunday about the possibility of another shutdown in just a few months.

title: Slow Ticket Sales for The Fifth Estate and Escape Plan
description: Anything positive at the weekend box office was obscured by the smoking wreckage of two movies that bombed. The Fifth Estate, an Oscar hopeful centered on the WikiLeaks organization and produced for about $26 million by DreamWorks Studios, took in $1.7 million in wide release, for eighth place at North American theaters. Escape Plan (Lionsgate), starring Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone, arrived in fifth place, selling about $9.8 million in tickets. The Los Angeles Times reported that Escape Plan cost about $70 million to make, but a person who worked on it, speaking on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss financial information, insisted that the final budget was closer to $50 million.

title: In Our Pages: October 21
description: 1938 Pax Hitler Not Eternal, English Fear

title: Jamalul Kiram III, Self-Proclaimed Sultan, Dies at 75
description: MANILA  Jamalul Kiram III, a descendant of the sultan of Sulu who led a quixotic military effort to regain part of the island of Borneo for his family this year, died on Sunday in Manila. He was 75.

title: Caribbean Nations to Seek Reparations, Putting Price on Damage of Slavery
description: LONDON  In his 2008 biography of an antislavery campaigner, Britains foreign secretary, William Hague, described the trade in human beings as an indefensible barbarity, brutal, mercenary and inhumane from its beginning to its end.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE REUNION: 10 YEARS LATER The Fab Five of Queer Eye for the Straight Guy  clockwise from top left, Kyan Douglas, Carson Kressley, Thom Filicia, Jai Rodriguez and Ted Allen  reminisce about the effect of the series on their lives and those of viewers. Andy Cohen moderates the discussion, which includes their favorite make-betters, their most challenging subjects and who came out as a result of the show.

title: An Echo of Rachmaninoff
description: For lovers of 20th-century Russian music in New York, the still-young season has offered a veritable banquet: great dollops of Shostakovich and savory side dishes of Stravinsky and Rachmaninoff. Amid this feast, alert listeners have undoubtedly turned up delicious little surprises and juxtapositions.

title: Liquidity Preference, Loanable Funds, and Erskine Bowles
description: Heres Erskine Bowles in March 2011:

title: An Opera Fights Hungarys Rising Anti-Semitism
description: BUDAPEST  Ivan Fischer is best known as a first-class conductor whose Budapest Festival Orchestra has entranced audiences worldwide. Last week, Mr. Fischer took on a new role  social critic  when the orchestra gave the premiere of an opera he had composed as a rebuke to what he and others see as growing tolerance for anti-Semitism in todays Hungary.

title: A Subway Car With Fewer Doors, but More Ways Out
description: For decades, the New York City subway car has been a predictable space. Some have seats; some have benches. Graspable pole options vary only slightly. Mariachi bands play, and self-appointed preachers preach.

title: Rice Approaches New Role With Diplomacy
description: STANFORD, Calif.  John Wesley Rice played football and coached football. He loved football. He was an offensive tackle, and he taught his daughter to appreciate line play and games called on the radio, and they religiously followed the Alabama Crimson Tide and the Cleveland Browns.

title: After Losing Rangers Spot, Biron Says He Will Retire
description: Goalie Martin Biron, who delighted teammates, fans and reporters during a 16-season N.H.L. career, announced his retirement Sunday, less than a week after being waived by the Rangers and assigned to their American Hockey League affiliate.

title: Humans Can Be Irrational, and Other Economic Insights
description: Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, writes in his new book, The Map and the Territory, that he has been thinking about bubbles since the financial crisis of 2008. Specifically, he has been trying to understand why he and so many other economic forecasters failed to see the housing bubble that caused the crisis.

title: After Nearly 90 Years, Ford Wants China to Give It a Second Chance
description: HONG KONG  General Motors now sells far more Buicks in China than in the United States, partly by playing on its history as the brand in which Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founder of modern China, was chauffeured around.

title: Cloudy Forecast for Holiday Spending Prompts More Promotion
description: THE 2013 holiday season was already challenging for retailers and marketers, with fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas and continued uncertainty over the economy. Now, after the government shutdown, as some analysts predict that consumers will trim holiday budgets by about 2 percent, efforts are being redoubled to woo reluctant shoppers.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Questions for Free-Market Moralists
description: In 1971 John Rawls published A Theory of Justice, the most significant articulation and defense of political liberalism of the 20th century. Rawls proposed that the structure of a just society was the one that a group of rational actors would come up with if they were operating behind a veil of ignorance  that is, provided they had no prior knowledge what their gender, age, wealth, talents, ethnicity and education would be in the imagined society. Since no one would know in advance where in society they would end up, rational agents would select a society in which everyone was guaranteed basic rights, including equality of opportunity. Since genuine (rather than on paper) equality of opportunity requires substantial access to resources  shelter, medical care, education  Rawlss rational actors would also make their society a redistributive one, ensuring a decent standard of life for everyone.

title: Lawyers Graphic Novels, Anything but Brief
description: LOS ANGELES  Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? Philip K. Dick asked in the title of a novel that became the basis of the movie Blade Runner.

title: Chinas Mountains of Construction Rubble
description: The demolition of old structures to clear way for urban development in China has some well-known consequences, notably the violence associated with forcibly removing people from their homes. But in recent years, the country has been increasingly faced with another unwelcome byproduct of the drive to tear down and rebuild: mountains of construction debris.

title: Spinning Horror Into Gold
description: LOS ANGELES  At first glance, there is nothing particularly special about Jason Blum. He makes low-cost horror films that sell a lot of tickets. Producers have been getting rich from that formula for decades: rinse (the fake blood) and repeat.

title: Horrors Head Honcho
description: The Hollywood producer Jason Blum has turned a decade of horror into more than a billion dollars at the box office.

title: Artwork on Foot Attracts New Vantage Points
description: At the Museum of Modern Art on Friday, I turned a corner and ran into a man well over six feet tall dressed as Martha Graham. This was the dancer Richard Move, celebrated for his impersonations of that modernist choreographer. For a while, he wandered like any other visitor, looking at the art. But Mr. Move also was the art. The Graham choreography he performed was an exhibit, yet so was he: a dancer as a living archive of dance.

title: Redemption, and Its Good, as Jets Foil Patriots
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When it was over, the Jets scurried off the field. They dashed through the tunnel, slapping hands with jubilant fans above, toward their locker room, toward relevance and respect and the promise of excitement still to come.

title: Standing Up for Muslims in Indias Courts
description: Shahid, a Hindi film directed by Hansal Mehta, is the story of a hero, though not in the typical Bollywood sense. Based on the life and death of Shahid Azmi, a Mumbai lawyer known for defending Muslims accused of terrorist acts, Mr. Mehtas movie is about one mans moral response to injustice.

title: Behind the Facade of a Carefree Hip-Hop Girl Group
description: In 1997, VH1 introduced Behind the Music, a docu-series that turned pop star biography into telenovela. The formula congealed quickly: bright spark, rapid ascendance, limitless potential, tragic flaw, rapid collapse, mild but needed redemption. Whether it was Judas Priest or Dr. Dre or Goo Goo Dolls, the message was clear: Drama doesnt discriminate.

title: Playing to the Classical Set and to the YouTube Crowd
description: The dynamic Ukrainian-born pianist Valentina Lisitsa fully acknowledges there was savvy reinvention in the way she jump-started her stalled career to become a YouTube sensation and a touring artist with a prestigious Decca recording contract. The combination of her fluid, impetuous playing and her glamorous persona proved ideal for the Internet. She has over 100,000 YouTube subscribers and has had more than 60 million views.

title: AT&T in $4.85 Billion Tower Deal With Crown Castle
description: AT&T agreed on Sunday to lease or sell 9,700 cellphone towers to Crown Castle International, a big wireless tower operator, for $4.85 billion in cash.

title: On Brooklyn Stoops, Artist Cultivates Debate
description: Suzanne Lacy has a long history of creating political performances that encourage dialogue. And on Saturday night her first major New York work, Between the Door and the Street, brought together close to 400 women  and a few good men, as Ms. Lacy likes to say  on the stoops and courtyards of a block in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, to discuss gender-related aspects of issues like poverty, violence and immigration.

title: Online Retailers Fear a Dreary Holiday Shopping Season
description: The government might be reopened, but online retailers are worried about whether the uncertainty the shutdown created, along with broader economic woes, could mean a dreary holiday season for online shoppers.

title: Vigilantes Defeat Boko Haram in Its Nigerian Base
description: BENISHEIK, Nigeria  The men from Boko Haram came tearing through this rural town, setting fire to houses, looting, shooting and yelling, God is great! residents and officials said. The gunmen shot motorists point-blank on the road, dragged young men out of homes for execution and ordered citizens to lie down for a fatal bullet.

title: As Downloads Dip, Music Executives Cast a Wary Eye on Streaming Services
description: As sales of CDs plunged over the last decade, the music industry clung to one comfort: downloads continued to sell briskly as people filled their computers and iPods with songs by the billions.

title: Just Before Going Airborne
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  You know, there is only so much commentary that one can take before one starts to get a bit paranoid about what the constructors are trying to say. Take the latest from Gary Cee, for example. In case you missed the mini theme that opens and closes the puzzle, Mr. Cee feels that we are both CATTY and SEEDY and he is trying to RUN AWAY, BREAK OUT, ESCAPE and TAKE OFF.

title: Writer Brings in the World While She Keeps It at Bay
description: Donna Tartt is the kind of writer who makes other writers, in the words of her fellow Southerner Scarlett OHara, pea green with envy.

title: That Head Turners Back, With an Old-School Posse
description: After almost 30 years, shes back in town, that gal with the turban, the Christmas-bulb gem, and the over-the-shoulder, did-you-say-something glance. Johannes Vermeers Girl With a Pearl Earring last visited New York in 1984, and much has happened since to burnish her allure.

title: Fighting for Customers
description: Chinese weapons manufacturers are pushing into new export territory, undercutting established companies in price as they gain the technology needed to compete at the high end of the arms market. Some examples of the high-profile weaponry China is offering:

title: Tablet Makers Gear Up for Latest Skirmish
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The race for the tablet market has become a full-blown sprint.

title: Married Couple Win Loeb Cup Tournament
description: The annual Arthur L. Loeb Cup Bridge Tournament raises money for the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. This years event, which attracted 200 players, including most of the top New York area experts, was held at the Neighborhood House on Oct. 8.

title: JPMorgans Legal Bill
description: The nations largest bank is paying billions of dollars to put its legal problems behind it.

title: Mayoral Race Threatens to Shake Up Tradition Where Jesus Grew Up
description: NAZARETH, Israel  Ramiz Jaraisi has been the mayor of this bustling Arab city in northern Israel for nearly 20 years. For 20 years before that, he served as deputy mayor. The local party slate he heads, the Nazareth Democratic Front, a coalition of the Communist Party and other groups, has been running the city since 1975.

title: Serving Skaters and Nature
description: A look at plans for Lakeside, a new $74 million redevelopment project in Prospect Park.

title: Restoring Brooklyns Pastoral Heart
description: For years, the Kate Wollman Memorial Rink in Prospect Park was a fenced-off, decrepit relic of the take-no-prisoners approach that New Yorks planning czar Robert Moses brought to urban renewal during the 1950s. Skaters suffered its musty lockers and dubious hot dogs until a couple of years ago, when the wrecking ball mercifully arrived to make room for a new skating and entertainment complex.

title: Marathon of the Formulaic and Eclectic
description: In 2004, Arcade Fire was the new band everyone wanted to see at the CMJ Music Marathon, the annual New York showcase that packs more than 1,300 club sets into five days. Arcade Fire became the decades quintessential CMJ success story, as glowing reviews and word of mouth from the bands independent-label debut album and small Lower East Side club shows propelled it onto radio and, eventually, to arena shows and an Album of the Year Grammy Award for its 2010 release, The Suburbs.

title: CMJ Music Marathon
description: A look at some of the performances from the festival.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Dozens Killed by Bombers at Baghdad Cafe
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber blew himself up inside a crowded cafe on Sunday, and moments later, as bystanders rushed to help the wounded, another suicide attacker detonated a car bomb at the scene, the Iraqi police said. Together, the explosions killed 54 people and wounded more than 70.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 21
description: EUROPEAN PRIVACY One of the most heavily lobbied pieces of European Union legislation in years, the Data Protection Regulation, could inch another step forward Monday evening when the justice committee of the European Parliament is expected to vote on whether to begin negotiating a final draft with bloc governments. Recent amendments to the law, which is aimed at expanding privacy rights, include a measure that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking to collect private data.

title: Wealth Fund Cautions Against Costs Exacted by High-Speed Trading
description: Despite being one of the largest single investors in the world, Norways sovereign wealth fund rarely makes waves.

title: Tech Wealth and Ideas Are Heading Into News
description: Producing serious news is an expensive enterprise with a beleaguered business model, one that remains tied to the tracks as a locomotive of splintered audiences and declining advertising hurtles toward it.

title: Yes, Economics Is a Science
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  THERES an old lament about my profession: if you ask three economists a question, youll get three different answers.

title: An Interview With Pierre Omidyar
description: Pierre M. Omidyar, the founder of eBay and now a philanthropist, has been much in the news after it was revealed last week that he would be backing a general-interest news site to the tune of $250 million.

title: A Marathon and Its Maestro, Getting Back on Track
description: Just about a year ago, Mary Wittenberg was treated in some quarters of New York almost as if she were no different from a stalker or a mob bag woman. Over-the-top words like evil and greedy were invoked by some scribblers on blogs and in newspapers to describe her. This for a woman whose sin, such as it was, had been a desire to stage a race.

title: Antonia Brenner, Prison Angel Who Took Inmates Under Her Wing, Is Dead at 86
description: Mother Antonia Brenner, who left a comfortable life in Beverly Hills to minister to inmates in a notorious Mexican prison, eventually becoming a nun and spending more than 30 years living in a cell to be closer to those she served, died on Thursday in Tijuana, Mexico. She was 86.

title: Inquiry of Ex-Charity Chief Sheds Light on Payments by 97 Council Campaign
description: Sixteen years ago, the longtime chief of staff to the speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, ran a campaign for City Council in Mr. Silvers home district that was unusually heavy on political firepower, especially when compared with its rather modest budget of $160,000.

title: Chinas Arms Industry Makes Global Inroads
description: BEIJING  From the moment Turkey announced plans two years ago to acquire a long-range missile defense system, the multibillion-dollar contract from a key NATO member appeared to be an American companys to lose.

title: Q. and A.: Jia Zhangke on His New Film A Touch of Sin, Part 2
description: In the second part of my interview with the Chinese director Jia Zhangke, he discusses censorship, industry financing and the need for films to reflect everyday life in China.

title: Mobs Reach Is on View in Florida Murder Trial
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  With a mix of swagger and candor, the witness airily acknowledged committing a fistful of felonies years ago as a member of New Yorks Gambino crime family.

title: Preseason Tries to Promote Global N.B.A.
description: Tim Hardaway Jr. experienced the less glamorous side of the N.B.A. this month when the Knicks went on a barnstorming tour of New England and beyond.

title: Gunmen Fire at Church in Egypt; At Least 3 Die
description: CAIRO  Gunmen on a motorcycle sprayed bullets at a church in a Cairo suburb late Sunday, killing at least three people. The attack appeared to be one of the deadliest in months against Egypts Christian minority, security officials said.

Families Separated by Deportation and Migration
description: To the Editor:
