description: To the Editor:

title: Rebel Raid in Oil-Rich South Sudan Leaves Scores Dead
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Rebel fighters mounted a raid in a restive, oil-rich part of South Sudan on Sunday that left 44 people dead and more than 60 wounded, according to a spokesman for the countrys military.

title: Its Safe to Eat Chicken
description: To the Editor:

title: Philadelphia Cedes Division Lead to Dallas
description: PHILADELPHIA  It seems that winning games in an N.F.C. East ruled by mediocrity has become more about doing just enough than playing well.

title: Whats That Smell? Exotic Scents Made From Re-engineered Yeast
description: EMERYVILLE, Calif.  Vanilla, saffron, patchouli. For centuries, spices and flavorings like these have come from exotic plants growing in remote places like the jungles of Mexico or the terraced hillsides of Madagascar. Some were highly prized along ancient trading routes like the Silk Road.

title: Making a Stand for Reform at Grambling, and at the N.C.A.A.
description: The players rights movement in intercollegiate athletics escalated beyond talk last week when football players from Grambling boycotted practice and forced the forfeit of a road game against Jackson State.

title: Widows Bankruptcy Case Poses Risk to Rent-Stabilized Tenants
description: After her husband died, Mary Veronica Santiago fell behind on her bills, and the creditors began to call.

title: An Industry of Mediocrity
description: Those who can, do. Those who cant, teach. And those who cant teach, teach teaching.

title: Some Wary as Lobstermen Unite
description: VINALHAVEN, Me.  Late last year, Magnus Lane, a lobsterman with the propensity for wearing pirate-themed pajama pants around this rocky island town, found himself at the end of his rope. A glut of lobsters during the previous summer had pushed lobster prices to a 40-year low, while the cost of bait, fuel and complying with state and federal regulations seemed to creep ever upward.

title: Despite Legal Tempests, Dimon Appears Solid as Ever Atop JPMorgan
description: To Wall Street, Jamie Dimon looks like the Teflon C.E.O.

title: Last Scheduled Case of Brooklyn Bridge Arrests, Like Most Others, Is Dismissed
description: Two years after more than 700 people were arrested on the Brooklyn Bridge roadway for participating in an Occupy Wall Street march, the last scheduled criminal case found its way to a courtroom in Manhattan this month.

title: Popular Demand
description: Moviegoers spent almost $8 billion at the box office through Sunday, and thats just on films that opened in 2013.

title: Beardless in Boston: Uehara Stands Out
description: BOSTON  Long, bushy beards have become the unifying trademark of the 2013 Boston Red Sox, but the most valuable player of their American League Championship Series victory stands out for more than his pitching.

title: Contractors See Weeks of Work on Health Site
description: Federal contractors have identified most of the main problems crippling President Obamas online health insurance marketplace, but the administration has been slow to issue orders for fixing those flaws, and some contractors worry that the system may be weeks away from operating smoothly, people close to the project say.

title: Questions Surround Death of 2 Bay Area Transit Workers as Strike Continues
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Federal authorities on Sunday said they were investigating an accident that killed two workers for the Bay Area Rapid Transit system on Saturday, less than 48 hours after employees of the commuter railroad went on strike.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 20, 2013
The National Guards Defiance on Civil Rights
description: In August, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel announced that the Defense Department would begin offering full spousal and family benefits, including health care coverage, housing allowances and survivor benefits, to the same-sex spouses of military personnel. In doing so he swiftly aligned the military with the Supreme Courts ruling in June striking down the Defense of Marriage Acts denial of federal marriage benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples.

title: A Way to Salvage Global Trade Talks
description: After more than a decade of fruitless talks to lower trade barriers, officials from more than 150 countries are back at the negotiating table. This time, they are hoping to reach a much more modest agreement by the end of the year that could provide a needed economic boost to the global economy.

title: An Exit Strategy From Afghanistan
description: As it winds down its 12-year-old military commitment in Afghanistan, the United States is still looking for a face-saving way out of a conflict that seems headed, at best, for a stalemate. The new bilateral security agreement between the two nations is part of that exit strategy. So is a hoped-for political settlement with the Taliban, on which there has been no progress, and a 2014 presidential election process that is also having problems.

title: Lousy Medicaid Arguments
description: For now, the big news about Obamacare is the debacle of HealthCare.gov, the Web portal through which Americans are supposed to buy insurance on the new health care exchanges. For now, at least, HealthCare.gov isnt working for many users.

title: Corrections: October 21, 2013
description: NEW YORK

title: Bloomberg Is First to Receive a $1 Million Jewish Award
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be honored on Monday as the first recipient of a $1 million award that organizers are calling the Jewish Nobel Prize.

title: Another Backside Debacle, This Time at Patriots Expense
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  About 11 months ago, the Jets lost a game against the New England Patriots, at least in part because of a butt fumble. On Sunday, they won a game against the Patriots, at least in part because of a butt push.

title: 0-6 Giants Will Be Tested at the One Thing Theyve Done Well
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There are not many things the winless Giants have done well this season. There is probably only one significant, measurable category in which they have had modest success: stopping the opposing teams featured running back.

title: The Doomed Queen of France, Stripped Bare
description: One of historys most fabled material girls is having to do without these days. Her wardrobe has been reduced to one red strapless number  kind of divine, but not all-occasion wear  and, for her final days, a stained chemise. As for all those towering wigs, they have been shrunk to the dimensions of a Park Avenue bouffant.

title: Grishams Tale Retold Onstage
description: The ceiling fans keep twirling away up there on the stage of the John Golden Theater on Broadway, as if to dispel all the heat and tension gathering in the courtroom where much of A Time to Kill, a stage adaptation of the John Grisham novel, takes place. But the producers might have saved a little on the electricity bill.

title: Manning Receives a Warm Welcome Back, but Luck Gets the Victory
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Sunday evening at Lucas Oil Stadium was like a bobblehead doll promotion in reverse. The occasion was Peyton Mannings first game here since he was let go by the Colts and found the Fountain of Youth in Denver. Instead of Colts fans receiving a ceramic reproduction of Manning, they gave Manning roughly 60,000 flesh-and-blood facsimiles of himself.

title: Writing a Budget to Prevent Another Shutdown
For the Vikings Peterson, the Death of a Young Son Is Another Devastating Turn
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Several of Adrian Petersons teammates created such a commotion Thursday, whooping and laughing as they entered the Minnesota Vikings locker room, that Peterson had to repeat his explanation for missing practice the day before.

title: U.S. Deal With JPMorgan Followed a Crucial Call
description: At a museum on Fifth Avenue, in a sparkling reception hall overlooking Central Park, Jamie Dimon convened his top executives and their spouses last month for the Wall Street equivalent of a pep rally.

title: Crash Course on Speaking in Tongues, All 22 of Them
description: It is, no doubt, a noble goal to be fluent in a foreign language or three, but sometimes what one really needs to get by in New York is a handy snippet, like Ill have the shrimp dumplings, or Please, sir, your Speedo is scaring the children.

title: Jets Close-Up
description: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Antonio Allen played linebacker at South Carolina before moving to safety in the N.F.L., and the Jets are fond of his physical style. That is why they put him on the Patriots hulking tight end, Rob Gronkowski, who caught eight passes for 117 yards in his season debut but was also stymied a number of times. This happened most notably on the Patriots opening drive of the second half, when Allen slipped underneath Gronkowski and returned Tom Bradys pass 23 yards for a touchdown.

title: At 12:01, Same-Sex Couples in New Jersey Say I Do
description: In Lambertville, N.J., the marriage certificate of Beth Asaro and Joanne Schailey allowed only for a bride and a groom, so Ms. Asaro  in a pink suit  was listed as the groom, and Ms. Schailey  in a black suit  as the bride.

title: Red Sox and Cardinals Meet Again
description: The Boston Red Sox have made it to the World Series seven times since World War II and, often enough, when they arrive, the St. Louis Cardinals are waiting for them.

title: Clashing Views of Chinas Human Rights Record at U.N. Hearing
description: Examining the hundreds of pages of submissions to the latest United Nations hearing on human rights in China, a reader might almost think that two very different countries face scrutiny in Geneva on Tuesday.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 14-20
description: Unique perspectives can give us pause and make us question what we see.

title: The Inefficient Market Hypothesis
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Scoliosis Can Hit Well Past Adolescence
description: On a family trip to the Grand Canyon three summers ago, my son Erik, who was hiking behind me, remarked, Mom, your right hip is higher than your left.

title: Breast Milk Donated or Sold Online Is Often Tainted, Study Says
description: A cottage industry has sprung up facilitating the sale and donation of human breast milk on the Internet, but a study published Monday in the journal Pediatrics confirms the concerns of health professionals over this unregulated marketplace.

title: Letter from Dr. Sun Yat-sen to Henry Ford and Fords response
description: Dr. Sun, a medical doctor and revolutionary who briefly became the first president of China in 1912, wrote to Henry Ford in 1924, in an exchange of letters released in Hong Kong by Ford Motor on Sunday night.

title: A Broadway Run for Bronx Bombers
description: Bronx Bombers, a play centered around the Yankees and some their biggest stars from the last century, completed a short Off Broadway run on Saturday. But the producers are to announce on Monday that a move to Broadway is set for January with the actors Peter Scolari (Lucky Guy) and his wife, Tracy Shayne (Chicago), taking over the roles of Yogi and Carmen Berra from Richard Topol and Wendy Makkena. The rest of the cast from the Off Broadway production  which included Christopher Jackson as Derek Jeter, Francois Battiste as Reggie Jackson, and Chris Henry Coffey as Joe DiMaggio  will return. Previews of the play, written and directed by Eric Simonson, are set to begin on Jan. 10 at Circle in the Square Theater, with an opening night on Feb. 6.

title: Jets Replay: Week 7
description: Action from the Jets 30-27 win over the Patriots at MetLife Stadium, a victory against a fierce rival for the Jets to savor.

title: Spankings Link to Bad Behavior
description: Spare the rod and spoil the child? A new study suggests that the opposite may be true: spanking could increase the risk of bad behavior.

title: Word of the Day | onomatopoeia
description: onomatopoeia \-n-m-t-pe-, -ma-\ noun

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) LIFE ACCORDING TO SAM (2013) In 1998, Dr. Leslie Gordon and Dr. Scott Berns discovered that their 2-year-old son, Sam, above, had progeria, a rare and untreatable progressive aging disorder that leads the children afflicted with it  at the time, fewer than 250 in the world  eventually to die of a heart attack or stroke at an average age of 13. But the couple werent about to give up on finding a cure, or empowering their son to enjoy life. Sam is now 17, a high school junior and an avid sports fan who excels at his studies, music and friendships. I didnt put myself in front of you to have you feel bad for me, Sam says at the beginning of this documentary, directed by Sean Fine and Andrea Nix Fine. I put myself in front of you to let you know you dont need to feel bad for me. His mother responds: You are handed something, and what you do with it is what matters, and thats what Sam is doing. Im impressed continually by him.

title: Globalfest Acts Are Announced
description: Globalfest, an annual festival designed to showcase a variety of international musicians, has announced the lineup that will perform at Webster Hall in January. The one-night event is to feature a dozen acts, including Fanfare Ciocarlia, a Romanian brass band; Hassan Hakmoun,  a Moroccan artist who focuses on Gnawa trance music; and Wu-Force, a folk group that features Abigail Washburn, Kai Welch and Wu Fei. Now in its 11th year, Globalfest is scheduled for Jan. 12 and will take place on three separate stages. Among the other artists to perform are Baloji, an Afropop rapper, and Como Mamas, a gospel a cappella trio from Mississippi.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday October 21, 2013
description: If you get milk from an unscreened sharer, you put your child at risk. I hate to say this to an informal sharer, because they are trying to do good. But they are playing a game of Russian roulette.

title: Beijing Marathoners Offend With Wetting the Red Walls
description: Wetting the red walls, its being dubbed. After participants in the Beijing Marathon on Sunday stood in rows to urinate against some of the high vermilion walls of the imperial palaces and gardens of the Forbidden City complex in the center of the city, people are asking: Has public peeing become an unfortunate and unhygienic tradition of the event?

title: News Quiz | October 21, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Using Bedbugs to Get a Love Seat
description: Dear Diary:

title: State Media Call Starbucks Too Pricey
description: The Chinese state news media have begun an attack on Starbucks, calling the coffee chain wildly expensive. Chinese consumers so far have responded with a yawn, and perhaps another latte.

title: Airpocalypse Hits Harbin, Closing Schools
description: Updated, 8:22 a.m. | School was canceled, traffic was nearly paralyzed and the airport was shut down in the northeast Chinese city of Harbin on Monday as off-the-charts pollution dropped visibility to less than 10 meters in parts of the provincial capital.

title: A Conversation With: Historian Ramachandra Guha
description: Ramachandra Guha is one of Indias foremost public intellectuals and historians. Gandhi Before India, his first volume of a two-part biography of Mohandas K. Gandhi, was published in India earlier this month. India Ink spoke to Mr. Guha about his decision to work on a biography of Mr. Gandhi, his choice to make Mr. Gandhis years in South Africa as the first volume of the biography, and Mr. Gandhis journey from a boy in the western state of Gujarat to his return to India as a major political figure.

title: China Arrests Prominent Businessman Who Backed Rights Causes
description: HONG KONG  The police in Beijing have formally arrested a prominent Chinese businessman who turned his energies and wealth to supporting human rights causes, his lawyer said on Monday. The arrest of the businessman, Wang Gongquan, was another step in the Communist Partys drive to deter dissent, supporters said. Notice of the decision comes a day before China is scheduled to defend its human rights record at a United Nations hearing.

title: Chinese Billionaire May Privatize Hong Kong Developer
description: HONG KONG  Zhang Zhirong, a mainland Chinese billionaire who was involved in an insider trading case in the United States last year, may make a privatization bid for his property development company in Hong Kong.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Oct. 21, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: Deal to Build a British Nuclear Plant Assumes a Role for Government
description: LONDON  In a back-to-the-future bet on its energy policy, the British government announced a long-elusive $26 billion deal on Monday to build the first new nuclear power station in Britain since 1995.

title: 6 Qs About the News | World Series Matchup Set
description: In Victorinos Slam Sends Red Sox to World Series, David Waldstein writes about the baseball teams that will face one another in this years World Series.

title: High in Nepal, a Lowly Status for Women
description: A woman crouches in a doorway, hay at her sandaled feet and a cow to her left. She looks ahead, a pained stare on her face. This is where she lives, for now.

title: When Is the Last Time You Did Something Nice for a Stranger?
description: Doing nice things for strangers isnt something that just came about, but in recent years, paying it forward has become a trend.

title: New York Today: Gay Marriage Crosses the River
description: Updated 1:10 p.m. | On the day that gay marriages were first performed in New York in 2011, supporters in New Jersey gathered on a pier in Hoboken.

title: Chasing Cars: Its Ultimately About the Bottom Line
description: The Car Chasers, an auto-themed reality show on CNBC, comes back for a second season of wheeling and dealing on Tuesday. Jeff Allen, the owner of Flat 12 Gallery in Lubbock, Tex., roams the countryside looking for bargains that he and his team  including his bottom-line-oriented wife, Meg Bailey; his fixer, Perry Brandt; and a master mechanic, Eric Ables  can flip for a profit.

title: The Umbilical Link of Man to Robot
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  Atlas doesnt shrug. But he teeters, loses his grip, stutters and staggers.

title: In Russia, Even Good News Is Bad
description: MOSCOW  I was about to turn off my computer late Friday night when a letter arrived saying that the bill that would take parental rights away from Russias gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender parents had been recalled from the Duma. And then I could not sleep.

title: Fear vs. Radiation: The Mismatch
description: CAMBRIDGE, Massachusetts  It has been more than two and a half years since the Fukushima nuclear disaster began to unfold, and still the world watches events closely, fearfully. The drumbeat of danger seems never ending: Earlier this month, to take just one example, international news reports spread word that six workers at the plant had been accidentally doused with radioactive water.

title: A Woman for All Seasons
description: BERLIN  When an 8-year-old girl on the Berlin subway asks her mother if its possible to have a male chancellor, you know something profound has changed in Germany. A woman ruling the country is not just the new normal; for millions of German children  including my daughters, ages 7 and 10  it is the only normal they have ever known.

title: Scalded by Coffee, Then News Media
description: In 1992, Stella Liebeck spilled scalding McDonalds coffee in her lap and later sued the company, attracting a flood of negative attention. It turns out there was more to the story.

title: Not Just a Hot Cup Anymore
description: More than 20 years ago, 79-year-old Stella Liebeck ordered coffee at a McDonalds drive-through in Albuquerque, N.M. She spilled the coffee, was burned, and one year later, sued McDonalds. The jury awarded her $2.9 million. Her story became a media sensation and fodder for talk-show hosts, late-night comedians, sitcom writers and even political pundits. But cleverness may have come at the expense of context, as this Retro Report video illustrates. And below, a consumer affairs reporter for The Times reflects on how the world has changed since the lawsuit.

title: A Start-Ups Documentary Series Tells Stories of Start-Ups
description: Gary Bredow has always been curious about how the businesses he patronizes started, whether its a local bakery, a pizza place or a hardware store. I always wondered about how they got their inventory, how they leased the store or where they got the idea in the first place, Mr. Bredow said.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 21, 2013
description: Updated: Oct. 22, 2013

title: Daily Report: New Bids for Dominating the Tablet Market
description: The race for the tablet market has become a full-blown sprint, and the intense competition will be highlighted on Tuesday, as Apple, Nokia and Microsoft each introduce new tablets, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: Week 7 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Inexcusable Broncos Blunder
description: Andy Benoit takes a quick tour through Week 7, from the Chiefs 7-0 start to a scary neck injury for the Packers Jermichael Finley.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Starts Spending His Billion-Dollar Charitable Fund
description: Last December, Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, and his wife, Priscilla Chan, donated 18 million shares of the companys stock to the Silicon Valley Community Foundation. At the time, the billionaire couple said they would direct money from their foundation fund, then valued at nearly $500 million, to unspecified education and health causes.

title: A Crucial Call From JPMorgans Chief
description: In late September, four hours before the Justice Department planned to hold a news conference to announce civil charges against JPMorgan Chase over its sale of troubled mortgage securities, Jamie Dimon, the banks chief executive, personally called one of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.s top lieutenants to reopen settlement talks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The call scuttled the news conference and set in motion weeks of negotiations that have led to a tentative $13 billion deal, people briefed on the talks said.

title: History in Jewels
description: A Parisian house marks 400 years of work with sparkling stones.

title: The Lackluster Reviews That Lawyers Love to Hate
description: WASHINGTON  Would you want The New England Journal of Medicine to be edited by medical students? asked Richard A. Wise, who teaches psychology at the University of North Dakota.

title: Ruling on Katyn Killings Highlights Russia-Poland Rift
description: LONDON  In the long-simmering and emotional debate over a notorious mass killing during World War II, the European Court of Human Rights ruled Monday that Russia had failed to comply with its obligations to adequately investigate the massacre of more than 20,000 Polish prisoners of war by the Soviet secret police in 1940.

title: Madame Tussauds and an Energy Company Seek to Go Public
description: The parent of Madame Tussauds and a clean energy business backed by the financier Guy Hands each said on Monday that they planned to go public on the London Stock Exchange, as their private equity owners seek to begin cashing out of their investments.

title: Gaming the Future With EAs Frank Gibeau
description: Frank Gibeau is a veteran gaming executive who until recently was in charge of console and PC game development at Electronic Arts, a gaming colossus that has had some misfires and queasy moments in recent years.

title: Chinese Court Says It Will Rule on Bo Xilais Appeal
description: HONG KONG  A provincial court in eastern China said Monday that it would deliver its decision on Friday on an appeal against the prison sentence for the former politician Bo Xilai.

title: U.S. Exchanges Set to Compete for Alibaba I.P.O.
description: The two big stock exchanges in the United States are ready to fight for the right to host the initial public offering of the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant.

title: European Court Rules Spain Must Free Terrorist
description: MADRID  The European Court of Human Rights ruled Monday against a Spanish law that has allowed the Madrid government to extend the imprisonment of convicted terrorists and members of ETA, the Basque separatist group.

title: For Star Athlete I.P.O., a Stumble on the Field
description: The road show for the Arian Foster initial public offering has gotten off to a disappointing start.

title: Today in Small Business: Drywall Contractors
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: As Gays Wed in New Jersey, Christie Ends Court Fight
description: As couples across New Jersey began marrying on Monday after the stroke of midnight, Gov. Chris Christie abandoned his long fight against same-sex marriage, concluding that signals from the court and the march of history were against him.

title: In Performance: Frances Barber
description: Frances Barber performs a scene as the title character in the Donmar Warehouse production of Shakespeares Julius Caesar, at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: In Performance: Frances Barber
description: The Donmar Warehouses all-female production of Julius Caesar, directed by Phyllida Lloyd, is set in a high-security womens prison. In this scene, Caesar, played by the actress Frances Barber, addresses the senate right before he is assasinated by conspirators (or in the case of this version, fellow prisoners), including his close friend Brutus.

title: Carol Burnett Cracks Up Washington
description: Decades after Carol Burnett made a place for women in sketch comedy with her namesake variety show, she stood onstage at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Sunday night to be recognized for her contributions to American society and to accept the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor.

title: French Condemn Surveillance by N.S.A.
description: PARIS  The French government castigated the United States on Monday for carrying out extensive electronic eavesdropping within France, the latest diplomatic backlash against the National Security Agencys wide surveillance net and another example of how disclosures about the program have strained relations  at least temporarily  with even the closest of Washingtons allies.

title: Matchups Set for Europes Last Cup Spots
description: Portugal will play Sweden and France will face a tough November home-and-home against Ukraine when eight teams from Europe square off for the continents final four places in next summers World Cup in Brazil.

title: Potential Silver Lining for S.E.C. in the Cuban Case
description: No one likes to lose, so the Securities and Exchange Commission is surely smarting from a jurys decision absolving Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, of insider trading charges. Although the case garnered headlines, it is unlikely to have much effect on other investigations, and even has a potential silver lining for the S.E.C.

title: A Landmark Building With a Fraught History
description: The Belnord is a powerfully built limestone rental building that occupies an entire city block on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Many windows are the width of a grown womans wingspan. The outer walls, as if built for a fortress, are nearly a foot thick. And the building has a 22,000-square-foot interior courtyard sprouting with well-manicured trees. Some of its apartments ask for $35,000, even $45,000, a month.

title: Biopic on Life of Lawyer Murdered in Mumbai
description: On Feb. 11, 2010, I returned to Mumbai after a reporting assignment in Hyderabad. A rare weekend off with family, it was also my nieces birthday. I switched my phone to silent mode to avoid work-related phone calls and tried to play host to a bunch of kids who were home.

title: By Design | Paul Smith Reintroduces Himself
description: Known for bringing a warm, whimsical touch to classic mens wear, Paul Smith may be one of fashions savviest eccentrics. Beginning next month, the Design Museum in London honors his nearly 45 years as a designer with Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith, a landmark retrospective of his smartly tailored, impeccably British ensembles for men and women, his charming collaborations  everything from Mini Coopers to Leica cameras  and his voluminous collection of oddball curios from around the world, quirky bits of inspiration that helped the designer bring his trademark twist to the venerable pinstripe. Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith, at the Design Museum in London, Nov. 15 to March 9; designmuseum.org.

title: Weekend Gun Report: October 18-20, 2013
description: The severely mentally ill have easy access to guns in Oklahoma, The Oklahoman reported yesterday. Gerald David Hume, a diagnosed schizophrenic, was able to purchase rifles and a handgun at Walmart and Gun World in Oklahoma City in November, which he used to shoot his 77-year-old mother to death. He then dismembered her body.

title: Cahills Goal: Its the Fizz
description: There are no photographs of Tim Cahills lightning fast goal at Houston on Sunday, probably because the photographers assigned to cover the game were as stunned and surprised as the Dynamo and Cahills Red Bulls teammates.

title: After Storm, Toxic Water Overflows in Japan
description: TOKYO  The operator of Japans wrecked nuclear plant said Monday that rainwater from a weekend storm became contaminated as it collected behind barriers meant to stop radiation leaks. The toxic water overflowed those barriers at several locations, with some of it possibly spilling into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Tim Griffin of Arkansas Will Not Seek Third Congressional Term
description: Representative Tim Griffin, a two-term Republican who represents a politically competitive district in Arkansas, said Monday that he will not seek a third term.

title: Rihanna Asked to Leave Mosque in Abu Dhabi
description: Rihanna was asked to leave the site of the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi after posing for photographs there over the weekend that the shrines overseers said had violated the sanctity of the site.

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes Bus in Southern Russia
description: MOSCOW  It was impossible not to notice her, one witness said. The young Muslim woman, her head covered by a light green scarf, boarded the No. 29 bus in the city of Volgograd and took a seat near the back. She rode for two stops, quietly looking out the window as the bus zipped along Azure Street. Then she blew herself up.

title: A Colorado Hotel With Plenty of Paleontology
description: Visitors to the Denver area can now spend a night in the museum or at least at a dinosaur-themed hotel that is also part natural history museum.

title: Martin Gardners Big Surprise
description: This week well be continuing our celebration of the life and many interests of the popular math and science writer Martin Gardner with a special birthday post  the third in our four-week series featuring Mr. Gardner, who was born on Oct. 21, 1914. Mr. Gardner was a prolific and attentive correspondent; he devoted a day each week to maintaining an ongoing written conversation with mathematicians and readers worldwide.

title: A Chain of Real Estate Envy From Across the Pond
description: Wishing a friends house or apartment were yours isnt only an American trait.

title: Obama Admits Web Site Flaws on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama offered an impassioned defense of the Affordable Care Act on Monday, acknowledging the technical failures of the HealthCare.gov Web site, but providing little new information about the problems with the online portal or the efforts by government contractors to fix it.

title: Image of the Day: October 21
The Forgotten Preacher
description: Henry McNeal Turner, the first black chaplain in the Union Army and one of the most prominent religious and political leaders of Civil War era black America, was born a free black on Feb. 1, 1834, in New Berry Court House, S.C. Turner was the oldest child of Hardy Turner and Sarah Greer Turner, and while we do not know much about Turners other siblings, we do know that Turners father died while he was still young.

title: In Our Pages: October 22
description: 1913 Crystal Palace Goes to the Dogs

title: Championship Slipped Away, but Leyland Recalls the Thrills as He Retires
description: DETROIT  Jim Leyland said he thought he would know when it was time to step down as manager of the Detroit Tigers, to finally retire after more than two decades of calling the shots in major league dugouts.

title: Saoirse Ronans Plum Benefits
description: The Girl: The actress contrasted the masculine silhouette of a plum pantsuit with a feminine lace top in a complementary berry hue at the 57th BFI London Film Festival Awards on Saturday night.The Details: The Kooples suit and shirt, Nicholas Kirkwood shoes.

title: Is Breast Still Best When Its Another Mothers Milk?
description: When parents cannot breast-feed an infant (when a child is adopted, when a mothers health or medical history precludes nursing or when a mother cant produce enough milk), most parents turn to formula. Donated breast milk  milk pumped by another mother and then donated personally, via a milk bank, or through informal sharing network  is still an option pursued by a relatively small group of parents, although many neonatal intensive-care units are increasingly seeking donor milk for premature infants to reduce the risk of a potentially fatal condition called necrotizing enterocolitis.

title: Greek Abduction Case Highlights Roma Tensions
description: ATHENS  A Roma couple were ordered jailed on Monday over the alleged abduction of a child who was found during a police raid on an encampment in central Greece last week. The case has fueled speculation about human trafficking and illegal adoption rackets, and heightened scrutiny of Roma populations across Europe.

title: Pogue, Times Technology Columnist, Is Leaving for Yahoo
description: David Pogue, the technology writer for The New York Times, whose columns were among the most popular at the paper, said on Monday that he was leaving for Yahoo to start a consumer-focused technology site.

title: A Closer Look at Factors Curbing Chinas Appetite for Shark Fins
description: Over the weekend, the Washington Post published an invaluable story offering a deeper look at the factors contributing to declining demand for shark fins in China. The piece adds some fascinating context on how the WildAid shark campaign that I posted on last week created social and governmental ripples.

title: 22 Under Investigation in Libor Case in Britain
description: Updated, 1:56 p.m. |

title: In Small-Business Lending, the Devil Is Often in the Lien
description: When small-business owners consider a loan, their primary concerns are generally what you would expect: What is the interest rate? How big is the loan? What will the monthly payments be?

title: Longtime Goldman Executive Is Departing
description: J. Michael Evans, a Goldman Sachs executive once seen as a possible candidate to succeed Lloyd C. Blankfein as chief executive, is leaving the Wall Street firm.

title: Bowlesonomics Versus Abenomics
description: As some readers may have guessed, a number of my recent blog posts have in effect been notes on the way toward my paper and presentation here. I have gotten somewhat obsessed with the question of whether a Greek-style crisis is possible for a country like the United States, and with the amazing way that the conviction that it is has taken root among policy elites without, as far as I can tell, any attempt to explain the actual mechanism.

title: Anti-Doping Agency Exposed Armstrong, but What About Others?
description: Some were cyclists who injected themselves with banned endurance boosters and popped testosterone pills. Some lay side by side with teammates while blood dripped from chilled IV bags and into their swelling veins. Others were doctors who helped cyclists dope or middlemen who ferried drugs for Lance Armstrongs United States Postal Service team.

title: Alan Greenspan Sees Inflation
description: Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has largely avoided public comment on the Feds efforts to stimulate the economy, but he has said enough to make it clear that he is not a fan.

title: Obama on Health Site Glitches
description: President Obama said the technical problems on HealthCare.gov did not indicate a failure of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Justices Return to a Death Penalty Issue
description: WASHINGTON  More than a decade after the Supreme Court banned the execution of the mentally retarded in 2002 in Atkins v. Virginia, the justices agreed on Monday to clarify how states should determine who qualifies.

title: New Technique Holds Promise for Hair Growth
description: Scientists have found a new way to grow hair, one that they say may lead to better treatments for baldness.

title: Ratmansky, Eliasson and  Irritu Among Rolex Mentors
description: VENICE  At a presentation at La Fenice opera house here on Monday, the Rolex Mentor and Protg Arts Initiative announced the artists who will serve as the 2014-15 mentors in dance, visual arts, film, theater, literature, music and architecture. The lineup comprises illustrious international names: the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the artist Olafur Eliasson, the film director Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu, the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, the author Michael Ondaatje, the composer Kaija Saariaho and the architect Peter Zumthor.

title: A New Hotel in L.A. Celebrates its Koreatown Surroundings
description: A stately yet unstuffy hotel injects style into the vibrant Los Angeles neighborhood.

title: Maybe Economics Is A Science, But Many Economists Are Not Scientists
description: Raj Chetty stands up valiantly for the honor of his and my profession, arguing that economics is too a science in which careful research is used to falsify some hypotheses and lend credibility to others. And in many ways I agree: there is a lot of good research in economics, maybe more than ever as the focus has shifted somewhat from theoretical models loosely inspired by observation  which, as he suggests, was my forte  to nitty-gritty empirical work.

title: Walkabout: Record Numbers for American Tourism in Cuba; TripAdvisor Plans Expansion
description: Bienvenidos Americans are visiting Cuba in record numbers despite strict travel restrictions, joining the hundreds of thousands of Cuban-Americans who travel there each year. (Reuters)

title: Better (and More) Congressional Member Information
description: Over the summer, as lawmakers in Washington, D.C., haggled about the budget, energy, immigration and other issues, weve been at work upgrading the information about members contained in the Congress API.

title: Soaring to the Stratosphere
description: The Perlan Project is building a carbon-fiber glider to carry two pilots to 90,000 feet. Its mission is to set an altitude record and to explore the high reaches of atmosphere.

title: Student Kills Math Teacher, Then Himself, at a Middle School in Nevada
description: A Nevada middle school student shot and killed a math teacher on Monday, then fatally shot himself in front of children who were gathering for class at the beginning of the school day, the authorities said.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Hayley Berlent joined Siegelvision, New York, in a new post, managing director and chief strategy officer. She had been senior strategy director at Siegel & Gale, New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

title: Sorting Out the New Yahoo Mail
description: Sorting Out

title: Hong Kong Tycoon Still Has Options for Supermarket Chain
description: Li Ka-shings sale of the Hong Kong supermarket chain ParknShop has flopped, but he still has other options.

title: Some Republicans Change Course on Health Care
description: Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, never misses a chance to accuse President Obama of being a terrible leader. So it was inevitable that he would pronounce Mr. Obamas Rose Garden speech today about problems with the federal health insurance Web site a sign of a fundamental breakdown in leadership.

title: Qaeda-Linked Group Is Seen Complicating the Drive for Peace in Syria
description: PARIS  Even as planning intensifies for a Geneva peace conference on the war in Syria, the emergence of a group affiliated with Al Qaeda has undermined the chances of negotiating an end to the conflict, a senior State Department official said on Monday.

title: The Scale of the Budget Divide
description: How the vastly different budgets passed by the House and Senate earlier this year as a share of the economy compare to the one proposed by President Obama in April and to historical averages.

title: Carve the Turkey and Pass the Latkes, as Holidays Converge
description: This year, in an extremely unusual coincidence of the calendar, the chants of Gobble, gobble, gobble for Thanksgiving will be interspersed with the singing of Dreidel, dreidel, dreidel for Hanukkah. The Manischewitz Company, the nations leading maker of kosher foods, is hoping to have fun  and sell its mainstay products like broth  by combining the holidays.

title: A Quiet Trip to the Ozone Hole
description: BEND, Ore.  It might be the weirdest part of the atmosphere, 15 miles above the polar regions, where vast stratospheric clouds of nitric acid and water vapor shimmer in iridescent pink while human-made chemicals play havoc with the ozone layer.

title: Economic Data Starts Flowing Again
description: The government economic data train is getting back on track.

title: Serena Williams Leads WTA Championships Field
description: ISTANBUL  Wearing a gray tank top and leather skirt that made her look every bit the conqueror she has become in womens tennis, Serena Williams took to the podium for the media day at the year-end WTA Championships with an air of caution.

title: Museum of Modern Art to Add Dave Kehr as a Curator
description: Dave Kehr, a columnist and critic whose writings about film and filmmakers have appeared in The New York Times since 1999, will become an adjunct curator in the film department of the Museum of Modern Art. Glenn D. Lowry, the museums director, announced the appointment on Monday.

title: BuzzFeed Hires Pulitzer Winner to Head Investigative Unit
description: BuzzFeed, the media Web site focused on viral content, announced on Monday that it was again expanding its reporting staff, this time to introduce an investigative unit. A new team of about half a dozen reporters will be led by Mark Schoofs, who was hired away from the nonprofit investigative service ProPublica.

title: A Look Toward the Future at National Design Awards
description: At the fourteenth annual National Design Awards event last Thursday, which drew more than 600 people to Chelsea Piers in Manhattan (including Al Gore), the talk was of recent dark days in Washington and a brighter future for design.

title: The Allergen-Free Cake That Wasnt
description: Nearly one-third of food-allergic children are bullied because of their allergies, according to a study published earlier this year in Pediatrics. Rather than blame the bully, what if we spun the discussion and asked: What does it take to create truly inclusive environments?

title: Visiting China, Pentagon Officers Step Up Dialogue
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Defense Department officials have been accelerating a dialogue with China, carried out through personal visits with Chinese counterparts to establish and strengthen military-to-military relationships.

title: A Start to Saving Lives: Treating Sore Throats
The Sweet Life
description: Q. WHY DONT SUGAR, MOLASSES AND HONEY EVER ROT?

title: In Video, Student Describes Nevada School Shooting
description: A student at Sparks Middle School in Reno, Nev., described witnessing a shooting that police said left two people dead and two others critically injured around 7:15 a.m. on Monday.

title: A Worldwide Fight Against Street Harassment
description: THE reality of street harassment against women who are traveling dawned on me some years ago in Rabat, Morocco, when my wife rushed back into our hotel room looking uncharacteristically shaken. She had ventured out alone on an errand, and had been accosted on a street near the Kasbah by a group of men, several of whom barked and made lewd comments, one of whom exposed himself. In broad daylight.

title: Pace-Setting Cells Linked to Slower Heartbeat
description: Getting older means getting slower, and the heart is no exception. A decreased maximum heart rate later in life reduces our capacity for strenuous work and can make it difficult to live alone. But why, exactly, does the heart slow down?

title: Answer to the Old Teeth-and-Scales Question
description: Its not quite a chicken-and-egg paradox, but scientists have long wondered which came first, teeth or scales. A new analysis of some toothlike fossils suggests the answer may be scales, contradicting decades of conventional wisdom.

title: How Safe Is Cycling? Its Hard to Say
description: Until his bike slid out of control while he was going 35 miles an hour downhill around a sharp turn, Dr. Harold Schwartz thought cycling accidents were something that happened to other people. Now, after recovering from a fractured pelvis, Dr. Schwartz, 65, the vice president for behavioral health at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut, has changed his mind.

title: Megan Cunningham of Magnet Media, on Judging Other Travelers
description: AS C.E.O. of a fast-growing company, Magnet Media, Im really committed to maintaining close relationships with clients. I think thats key to quality service. Even though we are proponents about the power of digital marketing, theres still nothing like being in a face-to-face meeting with a client and developing a relationship.

title: Gliders, Syrias Doctors and Bicycle Safety
description: A team of is hoping to send a glider 17 miles high for a closer look at what ails the atmosphere; how safe is your bicycle?

title: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 16-21, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

title: Mullally and Offerman to Star Off Broadway
description: The real-life husband and wife duo Megan Mullally (Will & Grace) and Nick Offerman (Parks and Recreation) will play a long-separated couple reunited by the husbands illness in Annapurna, which the New Group added to its season on Monday.

title: Rules Shielding Online Data From N.S.A. and Other Prying Eyes Advance in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  A panel of European Union lawmakers on Monday night backed a measure that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking private data.

title: Awareness Grows of Online Insurance Exchanges, and Their Problems, Survey Finds
description: Public awareness of the new health insurance exchanges has risen substantially in the weeks since they opened, but only a small percentage of consumers have visited the sites. Most of those already have insurance and are simply trying to learn more about the program, according to a survey released on Monday by the Pew Research Center.

title: Bud Adams, Founding Owner of N.F.L.s Titans, Dies at 90
description: Bud Adams, a pro football presence for more than half a century as a founder of the American Football League and the owner of the Houston Oilers and their successors, the Tennessee Titans, died on Monday at his home in Houston. He was 90.

title: An Eye for Bargains Can Be Bigger Than the Stomach
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

title: Keystone Pipeline Opponents Plan Widespread Civil Disobedience
description: PITTSBURGH  Opponents of the Keystone XL oil pipeline outlined new plans for persuading President Obama to reject the project at a conference for young climate activists here over the weekend. And while most organizers continued to express optimism that the administration would not allow TransCanada to complete the 1,700-mile pipeline from Albertas oil sands to Gulf Coast refineries, they are preparing for the likelihood that the project will win approval.

title: Poll Shows de Blasio Maintaining Huge Lead
description: Time is running out for Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor of New York City.

title: Twitter to End Its Music App, Which Never Made Much Noise
description: Twitter will close its music app, which was introduced with great fanfare six months ago but has failed to gain traction in the marketplace. The company is expected to rethink its music strategy, according to a person with knowledge of its plans.

title: Clinton Defender Takes On Fox News Over Benghazi Attack
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton says she has not decided whether she will run for president in 2016, but the battle over her public record is already being fought on television.

title: The Collections
description: Designers introduced shorter hems and jewel-toned gowns as whimsical options alongside timeless,white silhouettes.

title: Lawrence R. Klein, Economic Theorist, Dies at 93
description: Lawrence R. Klein, who predicted Americas economic boom after World War II and was awarded the 1980 Nobel in economic science for developing statistical models that are used to analyze and predict global economic trends, died on Sunday at his home in Gladwyne, Pa. He was 93.

title: The Improbable French Buddies
description: These days, science and philosophy dont seem to be the best of friends. Some prominent scientists dismiss philosophers as chasing vague concepts into murky and inconsequential rabbit holes, as the physicist Steven Weinberg once put it. And philosophers accuse scientists of imperial overreach in their attempts to claim ultimate authority on questions like consciousness, free will and the existence of God.

title: How the Rights Responding to the JP Morgan Deal
description: A few hours before the Justice Department was to announce civil charges against JP Morgan Chase over its sale of troubled mortgage-backed securities, the companys C.E.O., Jamie Dimon, made a phone call. He got one of Attorney General Eric Holders top lieutenants on the line, according to a report in Deal Book, and reopened negotiations. That happened in September. Weeks later, on Friday, the Justice Department and the bank tentatively agreed to a record $13 billion settlement.

title: Scientists Go Back to Work and a Skull Changes Some Minds
description: I brought some muffins! proclaimed Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as he greeted workers returning to the Environmental Protection Agency headquarters in Washington on Thursday. Seventeen days after the government shutdown began, scientists around the country  and as far away as the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station  resumed the work they were forced to halt during the standoff. The full extent of the damage on abandoned labs and frozen studies will take time to assess. But now is the time to appreciate small things, like the return of the Panda Cam, and muffins.

title: Panama Says It Will Release Most From Ship to North Korea
description: The authorities in Panama said Monday that they would release 33 of the 35 North Korean crew members of a rusting freighter impounded more than three months ago for carrying a secret stash of Soviet-era Cuban military gear hidden under bags of brown sugar.

title: What Does Terminal Mean? (3 Letters)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Tangy Pub Cheese With Potato Bread Chips
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

title: Tests for Newborns (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Molina Helps Cardinals Pitch Beyond Their Years
description: Michael Wacha wore a wide smile and a National League champions T-shirt as he held his crystal Most Valuable Player trophy on a podium at Busch Stadium late Friday night. Yadier Molina stood a few feet away, beaming.

title: Rangers Biron Is Comfortable With Decision to Retire
description: On Monday morning, the Rangers were skating at their Westchester County practice rink. At the same time, about 350 miles away, at his home in East Aurora, N.Y., Martin Biron felt no pangs of regret that he was not with them.

title: The Collections | The Top 5 Bridal Looks for Fall 2014
description: At the Fall 2014 edition of New York Bridal Fashion Week, some designers presented timeless wedding dress silhouettes in traditional shades of white. But others offered more whimsical options that were less recognizable as bridal gowns. There were both long trains and shorter, calf-length hems. Creams and ivories shared the stage with brighter shades that ranged from light peach to dark berry. Whether future brides opt for the fanciful (a colorful frock with lace flowers embroidered onto the skirt) or the classic (a sleek sheath with a pop of detail), theyre sure to make a statement.

title: Plundering Science, Bone by Bone
description: It is the dinosaur version of grave robbing: fossil poachers plundering a paleontological dig, frequently smashing ancient skulls and stealing valuable teeth, claws and feet.

title: Sounds Like a Haven for Troubled Students. Its Not.
description: And Miles to Go, Chad Beckims new play about a failing New York City public school, doesnt shy away from the tough questions. Well, at least not until the last third.

title: Netflix Hits Milestone and Raises Its Sights
description: Content is the new black.

title: Doctors Without Fear
description: Amid the crisis in Syria, medical professionals have taken up a herculean effort to provide needed care, and played a critical role in exposing the use of chemical weapons to the world.

title: Black History Across Five Centuries: A Journey of Many Dimensions
description: It always seemed pretty straightforward. And horrifying. Early African-American history was the story of thousands of Africans who were captured, shipped like cargo to the New World and sold into slavery, mostly to work and die on Southern plantations.

title: In Syria, Doctors Risk Life and Juggle Ethics
description: WASHINGTON  Months before a chemical weapons attack killed hundreds of Syrians and prompted threats of an American military strike, an anesthesiologist named Majid heard an explosion near his home in a Damascus suburb. He rushed to the makeshift hospital where he works and found patients with itching skin, burning eyes and shortness of breath.

title: Special PACs Spent Money at Resorts, Book Says
description: WASHINGTON  A new book from a conservative advocate of tighter campaign finance regulations seeks to draw attention to a number of questionable but legal fund-raising activities  some potentially damaging, others certainly embarrassing  that could prove uncomfortable for some on Capitol Hill.

title: Figuring Out Who Really Had the Last Word in the Bush White House
description: How different would the world be if George W. Bush had picked John Danforth instead of Dick Cheney to be his vice president? Mr. Danforth, a moderate three-term senator from Missouri and an ordained Episcopal minister nicknamed St. Jack, met for more than three hours with Mr. Bush. Karl Rove favored him over Mr. Cheney, as did Joshua Bolten, the campaign policy director. And only at Mr. Cheneys insistence did Mr. Bush interview Mr. Danforth.

title: All the Worlds a Bar at Channel From Esquire
description: During Prohibition, people desperate for a drink needed a password to enter a speakeasy.

title: A Late Arrival in Boston, Greeted With Hopeful Relief
description: BOSTON  The health of the Boston Symphony Orchestras music director has caused it quite a few headaches over the past few years. The tenure of James Levine, who held the position for seven years, beginning in 2004, was characterized toward the end by a demoralizing string of injury-induced cancellations. In the 2009-10 season, Mr. Levine was forced to abandon 60 percent of his scheduled appearances with the orchestra. His resignation in 2011 was followed by a period of uncertainty and drift.

title: ScienceTake: Flight of the Bumblebee
description: Harvard researchers have discovered that the bumblebee is a much more tactful navigator than its name implies.

title: Shakespeare in Rep Sells on Broadway
description: The new Broadway double bill of Shakespeares Twelfth Night and Richard III, running in repertory and starring the two-time Tony Award winner Mark Rylance as Olivia and Richard, had a solid first week of ticket sales, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The shows grossed $468,429 for a total of six preview performances  73 percent of the maximum possible amount, a high level of plays. The gross is notable partly because the shows are setting aside 250 tickets at every performance for an unusually low $25, which would theoretically lower the amount of money in ticket sales somewhat. The new musical After Midnight, a revue recreating the Cotton Club nightclub scene, also had a good first week, grossing $235,823 for three previews (or 64 percent of the maximum possible amount). Over all, Broadway musicals and plays grossed $24 million last week, compared to $24.6 million the previous week, which fell over the Columbus Day holiday weekend. Attendance at shows totaled 233,682 last week, compared to 232,400 the previous week.

title: Out of Darkness Comes Light, Movement and Music
description: Plagues, war, the eclipse of the classical tradition: there are reasons that people used to refer to 14th-century Europe as belonging to the Dark Ages. And yet the period produced some beautiful music, at once spare and complex, ascetic and sensual.

title: $50,000 Awards Go to 10 Writers
description: The Whiting Writers Awards, given annually to 10 writers who have exceptional talent and promise in early career, were announced on Monday. Each writer receives $50,000 from the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, established in 1963 by Flora E. Whiting. The awards honor fiction, nonfiction, poetry and plays and are intended to identify writers, the foundation says, who have yet to make their mark on the literary culture. The 2013 winners are Hannah Dela Cruz Abrams (The Man Who Danced With Dolls), Amanda Coplin (The Orchardist), Jennifer duBois (Cartwheel), Virginia Grise (Making Myth), Ishion Hutchinson (Far District: Poems), Morgan Meis (Ruins), C. E. Morgan (All the Living), Rowan Ricardo Phillips (The Ground), Clifford Thompson (Signifying Nothing) and Stephanie Powell Watts (We Are Taking Only What We Need).

title: A Storyteller Who Cant Be Pigeonholed
description: Judy Collins, that ageless wild angel of pop, has many faces, all of them magnificently on display at the Caf Carlyle, where she has opened her annual fall engagement.

title: In His Hands, Bach Meets Bluegrass
description: On a cool Monday night in late September, Chris Thile came to Rockwood Music Hall to play for a devoted audience that hung on his every note. The scene was nothing new. Mr. Thile, a singer, mandolinist and composer who regularly appears at prestigious concert halls and festivals with the progressive-bluegrass quintet Punch Brothers, routinely works up material for his concert tours at Rockwood, an intimate nightclub complex on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Deep Fried and Good for You
description: Fried food is probably not on anyones lists of healthy eats, but you have to start with this: Fat is good for you.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, Egypt, China and Pakistan.

title: An Odd Alliance in Patagonia
description: NEUQUN, Argentina  On the windswept Patagonian steppe, crews of roughnecks are drilling around the clock in pursuit of a vast shale oil reservoir that might be the worlds next great oil field.

title: Recipe Lab | Chocolate Caramels
description: Julia Moskin makes chocolate caramels with sea salt from Mast Brothers Chocolate: A Family Cookbook.

title: Discussing Chocolate With the Mast Brothers
description: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to talk about cooking with the Dining section. This month, join Julia Moskin and Rick and Michael Mast, of Mast Brothers chocolate, for a live video chat about chocolate  how it is made, and how to cook with it  on Thursday, Oct. 24, 2 p.m. Eastern time, right here on this page.

title: 10 Receive Whiting Writers Awards
description: The Whiting Writers Awards, given annually to 10 writers who have exceptional talent and promise in early career, were announced on Monday.

title: A Vagabond Troupe Gets Its First Home
description: Life as an itinerant company was not easy for Theater for a New Audience, which spent 34 years producing Shakespeare and other classical dramas in leased spaces, shuttling among Off Off Broadway theaters, school gymnasiums and even, once, a Y.M.C.A.

title: Street Style: Buttoned-Up
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Oct. 14.

title: A Tonic for Computer Hell: Getting Lost in the Woods
description: Several hours of my day were consumed in the special circle of hell one enters too often when dealing with telephone assistance on computer problems.

title: New Releases From DJ Khaled and Cass McCombs
description: DJ KHALED

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,273 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Shades of Oedipus for Hip-Hop Titans
description: SEATTLE  Four years ago, Drake played his first New York show, at S.O.B.s. Huddled up in a private area at the rear of the club was Kanye West, presumably curious as to how secure his own future was. Drake had been making noise as the first demonstrably viable post-Kanye rapper, one for whom emotional excavation was a virtue, one whod mainlined Mr. Wests middle-class sensibilities and created a new sound on that foundation.

title: Medicaid and the Incentive to Work
description: The Affordable Care Act is  to state the obvious  aimed at bolstering insurance coverage in the United States. But the law is so big that it will necessarily have widespread economic ramifications, economists think, including an effect on the labor market.

title: Nets' Turn to Be Talk of the Town
description: After decades of playing second fiddle in New York, the Nets, according to William C. Rhoden, are in position to capture the city's imagination. And the franchise in Manhattan is feeling the pressure.

title: Nets Turn to Be Talk of the Town
In Performance: Dee Dee Bridgewater
description: Dee Dee Bridgewater sings the number A Foggy Day in London Town from the Billie Holiday musical Lady Day, which had a run at the Little Shubert Theater in 2013.

title: Attack of the Sock Puppets
description: Hmmm:

title: Scott Dixon Wins Third IndyCar Title
description: Will Power won the race, but by finishing fifth in Saturdays 500-mile IndyCar season finale at Fontana, Calif., Scott Dixon clinched his third title in the series. Dixon, who also won the title in 2003 and 2008, had trailed Helio Castroneves in points much of this season. But a sixth-place finish in the race by Castroneves fell short of overcoming the 25-point lead Dixon held since the Houston double-header races earlier in the month.

title: Remembering, and Forgetting, the Flying Tigers
description: The decrepit state of a graveyard that is connected to one of the most famous World War II fighting forces in China has revived questions about the countrys ability to honor its veterans.

title: Politicians Extortion Racket
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  WE have long assumed that the infestation of special interest money in Washington is at the root of so much that ails our politics. But what if weve had it wrong? What if instead of being bribed by wealthy interests, politicians are engaged in a form of legal extortion designed to extract campaign contributions?

title: Honey Is Natural, but ...
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A Global Focus on Breast Cancer
Arkansas: G.O.P. Congressman Wont Seek Re-election
description: Representative Tim Griffin, a two-term Republican from a competitive district, said Monday that he would not seek a third term. Mr. Griffin, a former aide to Karl Rove and one of the Republican Partys rising stars, said he wanted to spend more time with his wife and children. His announcement was unexpected. The district, which includes Little Rock and several surrounding counties, was represented until 2011 by a Democrat for more than a decade.

title: Mario Cuomo, Vocal Foe of Italian Stereotyping, Finally Sees The Godfather
description: Mario M. Cuomos hate-hate relationship with The Godfather has been well documented. For four decades, he refused even to see any of the movies or, presumably, to read Mario Puzos book. He all but denied that the Mafia existed. And who could forget that unfortunate slip of the tongue during the 1992 presidential campaign, when Bill Clinton suggested that Mr. Cuomo, then the governor of New York, acted like a Mafioso?

title: Critics Wage Quiet Fight Against Ballot Measure on Adding Casinos
description: ROCK HILL, N.Y.  The Coalition Against Gambling in New York has no office, no paid staff and basically no money. Its Web site features a Goya print and a graphic depicting something called the Iceberg of Misery. The groups spokesman is a recovering technologist and an avid bowhunter with barely enough backing to make it to debates.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Silicon Valleys Secessionists, and the Motorola Money Pit
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Language-Gap Study Bolsters a Push for Pre-K
description: Nearly two decades ago, a landmark study found that by age 3, the children of wealthier professionals have heard words millions more times than those of less educated parents, giving them a distinct advantage in school and suggesting the need for increased investment in prekindergarten programs.

title: Tracking the Vocabulary Gap
description: A Stanford University study tracked how children recognize simple words.

title: Brazil: Consortium Wins Oil Rights
description: The Brazilian authorities on Monday awarded a license to develop oil production in a coveted deep-sea area to a consortium of five companies: Petrobras, Brazils national oil company; the Western oil giants Shell and Total; and two Chinese state-controlled oil companies. The group, the only consortium to submit a bid in the auction, will pay a signing fee of about $7 billion to start work on the 35-year concession. The deep-sea field, called Libra, is believed to be one of Brazils most promising exploration areas. Legislation requires the Brazilian company to take control of the new operation, but doubts persist among energy analysts as to whether Petrobras, which has soaring debt and is trying to reverse a decline in Brazils oil production, is overstretched with an array of offshore projects. The auction was carried out in Rio de Janeiro amid protests by oil workers and other groups that oppose the participation of foreign companies in Brazils oil industry.

title: On Subway, Tourism Push Promotes Upstate Stops
description: On the 42nd Street shuttle, long the province of the subway systems least subtle advertising, riders have been encouraged to drink orange juice, watch the Yankees and join Papa Smurf at the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: Medicaid Expansion Is Set for Ohioans
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  As a Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee in the 1990s, John R. Kasich wielded a ferocious budget ax. On Monday, as Ohios governor, Mr. Kasich defied his partys majorities in the state legislature to push through a multibillion dollar expansion of Medicaid under President Obamas health care law.

title: Plan Aims to Fix Sewers, but Its Cost to Residents Leaves a Bad Taste
description: LONDON  On a particularly hot summer day in 1858, the smell of raw sewage from the River Thames became so unbearable that legislators had the curtains of the Houses of Parliament soaked in chloride of lime. When that failed to repel the odors, members of Parliament simply abandoned the place.

title: Judge Hears Arguments on Legality of Detroit Bankruptcy Filing
description: DETROIT  It is hard to picture a city in worse financial shape than Detroit, where decades of mismanagement and misfortune led to the nations largest municipal bankruptcy filing.

title: Mattingly Gives Dodgers An Earful Over His Status
description: LOS ANGELES  Through all the turbulent years in New York, Don Mattingly carved a reputation as an elegant player who carried himself with an earnestness that did not betray his small-town Indiana roots. That portrait, like the nickname that accompanied it, Donnie Baseball, seemed apt.

title: The Real Story Behind the Citys Deliverance From a Blood-Soaked Era
description: The Republican mayoral nominee, Joseph J. Lhota, went all retro on us last week, offering a commercial that had a 1970s Escape From New York, Panic in Needle Park jolt.

title: Ex-Patients Police Mexicos Mental Health System
description: MEXICO CITY  On a recent morning, a collection of people grappling with mental illness roamed the grounds of a psychiatric hospital here, stepping into dirty, dilapidated rooms; exchanging tales of anguish; and peppering administrators with questions.

title: Texas A&M Pursues a Campus in Israel
description: HOUSTON  When Gov. Rick Perry visits Israel this week, he will leave a surprising piece of Texas behind: his alma mater, Texas A&M University.

title: The 3 Roles of Michael J. Fox
description: On Thursday, NBC will air the sixth episode of its new comedy series, The Michael J. Fox Show. In it, Fox plays a popular television anchorman who returns to work after having retired years earlier because of his Parkinsons disease. This, of course, closely tracks Foxs own story. An extremely well-liked actor, he last starred in a television series in 2000, which is when the tremors, stiffness and involuntary body movements that are associated with Parkinsons forced him to retire from Spin City.

title: Economic Theory, via YouTube and Cartoon
description: Forget Econ 101. Take a look at the lessons in Dalio 101.

title: Tradition of Not Voting Keeps Palestinians Politically Powerless in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Mayor Nir Barkat proudly trumpets the investments he has made over the past five years in the Arab neighborhoods of East Jerusalem: about $141 million for roads and infrastructure, $113 million to build 500 classrooms, more than $1 million for a single soccer field in Beit Safafa.

title: Start-Up Reinvents the Bicycle Wheel
description: Its rare that a company comes along and reinvents the wheel, but it looks like that is about to happen.

title: Confessions of a Serial Memoirist
description: I am a serial memoirist  words I never imagined uttering or for that matter stringing together to describe any writer 25 years ago, back when I wrote my first book, Riding in Cars With Boys. I sold the book in 1988 on a five-page proposal, using my agents advice: Pretend you have five minutes to tell a garden party why in the world they should be interested in the story of your life.

title: California: BART Trainee Was Running Train in Fatal Crash
description: The operator of a Bay Area Rapid Transit train involved in a fatal accident on Saturday was a trainee who was not yet certified to drive the train, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board said on Monday. The train, which killed two workers who were inspecting a section of track, was on a run for training and maintenance purposes during a strike by railroad workers, said the investigator, Jim Southworth. BART had said it would train managers to operate trains in order to provide a limited shuttle service during the walkout. Unions for the striking workers had warned that it would be dangerous to allow inexperienced operators to drive the trains.

title: R.O.T.C. Making Cuts to Expand Recruiting
description: COOKEVILLE, Tenn.  When Sarah Short arrived at Tennessee Technological University this summer, she had mapped out her four years of undergraduate study and well beyond: an affordable nursing degree and a commission as an Army officer.

title: Angry at Prague, Artist Ensures Hes Understood
description: PARIS  The finger, said the Czech sculptor David Cerny, speaks for itself. On that point, at least, everyone could agree.

title: Clock Ticking, Bloomberg Seeks Council Approval of East Midtown Rezoning Plan
description: The Bloomberg administration is scrambling to gather enough City Council votes to enact the mayors final plan for reshaping New York Citys skyline with a new generation of ever-taller skyscrapers.

title: Ruling Near, J.C. Penney Capitulates to Macys
description: Days before a judge was expected to rule in the long-running legal dispute between Macys and J. C. Penney over the right to sell branded Martha Stewart housewares, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and J. C. Penney scaled back the merchandising agreement at the center of the battle.

title: In Belated Jobs Report, a Search for Clues
description: Will it be worth the wait?

title: Sales Are Colossal, Shares Are Soaring. All Amazon Is Missing Is a Profit
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Nearly every day, Amazon announces a new venture.

title: Security Check Now Starts Long Before You Fly
description: The Transportation Security Administration is expanding its screening of passengers before they arrive at the airport by searching a wide array of government and private databases that can include records like car registrations and employment information.

title: Dont Like the Video? Tell It What to Do Next
description: TELEVISION viewers have been talking to characters in commercials for decades, even if those conversations have been one-sided and consist mostly of demands to pipe down. In an online initiative to help promote the 2014 Infiniti Q50 sport sedan, the characters talk back.

title: CeeLo Green, Star of NBCs The Voice, Faces Drug Charge
description: CeeLo Green, the singer and judge on NBCs hit talent show The Voice, was charged on Monday in Los Angeles with giving the drug ecstasy to a woman, the district attorney of Los Angeles County announced.

title: The Health Sites Chaotic Debut
description: President Obama rightly acknowledged on Monday that there is no excuse for the horrendously botched opening of the federal Web site consumers are supposed to use to sign up for health insurance policies under the Affordable Care Act. Unless the problems can be fixed soon, they threaten to undermine the ability of the health care exchanges to help enroll some seven million uninsured Americans in 2014.

title: Beijings Assault on Academic Freedom
description: Peking Universitys decision last week to dismiss Professor Xia Yeliang, an economist and advocate of the free market, is making news around the world. The dismissal could hurt Peking Universitys connections with American and European universities, and tarnish its reputation. In the spirit of academic freedom, universities that have collaborative relations with Peking University  Stanford, Cornell, Yale, the London School of Economics and many others  should be putting pressure on Chinas leading university to reinstate Mr. Xia.

title: How to Disarm the Debt-Ceiling Threat for Good
description: After Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, emerged from hiding last week to help negotiate an end to the debt crisis, he announced that Republicans would no longer use the same kind of extortion to get their way. Were not going to do this again in connection with the debt ceiling or with a government shutdown, he told The National Review.

title: Salmon Fishermen Battle Walmart on Certification
description: Early last year, Alaskas wild salmon fishing industry decided to end its partnership with the seafood worlds most prominent sustainability certification group in favor of its own labeling efforts. But the move quickly set drew a reaction from customers, as WalMart and others said they would no longer buy Alaskan salmon without the independent check.

title: A New Day in New Jersey
description: Gov. Chris Christie has repeatedly fought legislative and legal attempts to allow same-sex marriage in New Jersey. On Monday, he finally decided to drop his appeal of a state court decision issued in September that allowed gay and lesbian couples to marry.

title: Lou Scheimer, Whose Cartoon Studio Entertained Generation X, Dies at 84
description: Lou Scheimer, an Emmy-winning producer of television cartoons whose company, Filmation, was once the largest animation studio in the United States, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Gannett Links Drop in Profit to a Less Eventful Year
description: The Gannett Company reported a sharp decline in third-quarter profit on Monday, attributing the drop to a deep dip in advertising revenue from a year ago, when the Olympics and the presidential campaign provided a financial lift.

title: In Clinton Fund-Raising, Expect a Full Embrace
description: When a recent Manhattan fund-raiser for the Virginia candidate for governor Terry McAuliffe wound down and most of the donors had left the hosts swanky meatpacking district loft, President Bill Clinton stuck around.

title: Asia, Where Mobile Games Flowered, Extends Its Reach
description: TOKYO  When SoftBank, the Japanese telecommunications provider, announced last week that it had agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in a Finnish mobile game company for $1.5 billion, many people in both industries reacted with disbelief.

title: Considering the Fairness of JPMorgans Deal
description: Some on Wall Street have portrayed JPMorgan Chase as a victim of government zealotry.

title: Gamesmanship Continues to Color Jets-Patriots Rivalry
description: Rex Ryan conducted his standard day-after-game interview session on Monday via conference call, so we are left to imagine his body language as he responded to questions about his role in illuminating his new favorite obscure penalty, the call that boosted his Jets to a 30-27 overtime victory against New England.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 21, 2013
The Rules of the Road
Corrections: October 22, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Once Their Son, Now a Riddle
description: Star student, sociopath or a little of each? That is the troublesome question raised in Luce, a thoughtful, well-acted new play by J C Lee that opened on Monday night at Lincoln Centers Claire Tow Theater.
