The title character, winningly played by Okieriete Onaodowan, is a 17-year-old charter school student in an unnamed American suburb whose teacher, Harriet (Sharon Washington), becomes alarmed at the choice Luce makes when hes given an assignment to write about a historical figure.

title: Thingamajig
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  You know that thing, that  what is it called? That DOOHICKEY where you put words in a square box and cross them? Oh, right, crossword puzzles. Constructing them is a nice combination of LINEAR and non-LINEAR THINKING. So is solving them, I think.

title: In Area Already Filled With Bars, a Proposal to Add One More Draws Opposition
description: Manhattan has its squares  Times, Herald, Union, Pershing, Sherman, Verdi and, ever since a blogger christened it, Hell.

title: 2 Officers Convicted of Harassing Latinos
description: HARTFORD  Two police officers from East Haven, Conn., were convicted on Monday of violating the civil rights of Latino residents in a monthlong trial that exposed tensions in a town with a growing number of immigrants and led to a leadership change at its Police Department.

title: Injured Spider-Man Actor Makes First Appearance Since Performance Accident
description: With a dazzlingly wide smile and dancing bright eyes, the Broadway performer Daniel Curry greeted 200 friends and cast members from his show, Spider-Man: Turn Off The Dark, at a benefit concert on Monday night that raised $10,000 for his medical bills after a midperformance accident in August.

title: Protests as City College Closes a Student Center
description: It was just a small room, one of hundreds in City Colleges North Academic Center, but over the years the Guillermo Morales/Assata Shakur Student and Community Center had taken on a significance beyond its square footage. To student organizers who used it as their meeting space, it was a place for lesbian and gay activists, womens rights groups, community organizations and others to make common cause.

title: Maker of Animated GIFs Waits for Offbeat Moments
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  At 2:44 p.m. on a recent Sunday, Tim Burke took a moment from monitoring numerous N.F.L. games for the sports Web site Deadspin to post something that had nothing to do with football: a smidgen of a clip from an English rugby match he also happened to be following.

title: Flo: Portrait of a Street Photographer
description: This short documentary profiles the photographer Flo Fox who, in spite of near-blindness and multiple sclerosis, continues her work in the streets of New York.

title: Flo: Portrait of a Street Photographer
description: As a young, self-described hot chick in the 70s and 80s, Flo Fox hung out at Studio 54 and Area, in the same social circle as Andy Warhol and photographers like Andre Kertesz and Lisette Model. Today, worlds away from those underground art parties, she lives in an apartment building for disabled people, surviving with the help of Medicaid and Social Security.

title: Yanks, With Much to Address in Off-Season, Start by Cutting Some Ticket Prices
description: The Yankees hierarchy began its first day of organizational meetings Monday, the same day the team announced that most of its full season-ticket license prices would stay the same, and some would even decrease.

title: Giants Fans Are Blue but Not Angry
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The sun was just beginning to slip below the rooftops of an ocean of vehicles in the parking lot Monday night at MetLife Stadium, and Todd Boresen already had the Korean-style barbecue steaks sizzling. It was several hours before kickoff between the Giants and the Minnesota Vikings, and the lots were quickly filling up. Boresen said he had no doubt that they would.

title: The Drone Strike Capital of the World
description: Since the C.I.A. escalated the drone campaign in Pakistans tribal belt in 2008, it has attacked targets in Miram Shah at least 13 times.

title: Intersection: Flatbush Indie Fashion
description: Helen Milkson, 72, who was born in Grenada, has been living in Flatbush for 20 years. She likes to look special and doesnt go for fashion, she says.

title: Staff of Washington Post Bids Farewell to Grahams
description: WASHINGTON  The Graham family said goodbye to The Washington Post after eight decades of ownership with an emotional send-off reception on Monday night for roughly 650 current and former employees at its downtown headquarters.

title: Tax Withholding Still Controversial After 70 Years
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book, The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Word of the Day | uproarious
description: uproarious \p-ror-e-s\ adjective

title: Civilian Deaths in Drone Strikes Cited in Report
description: LONDON  In the telling of some American officials, the C.I.A. drone campaign in Pakistan has been a triumph with few downsides: In more than 300 missile attacks there since 2008, dozens of Qaeda and Taliban leaders have been killed, and the pace of the strikes, which officials frequently describe as surgical and contained, has dropped sharply over the past year.

title: Chinas State TV Backtracks on News of Corruption Inquiry
description: For a few hours late Monday afternoon, China watchers were left scratching their heads as they pondered the veracity of a 126-character tweet that, if true, would at long last end months of speculation about the political health of Chinas former domestic security czar Zhou Yongkang.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 22, 2013
description: The drones are like the angels of death. Only they know when and where they will strike.

title: Throwback Night as Giants Earn First Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  From the start Monday night, it was obvious the Giants were going to be liberated from their winless misery.

title: Giants Replay: Week 7
description: Eli Manning passed for 200 yards and a touchdown as the Giants recorded their first win of the season, a 23-7 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) PRETTY LITTLE LIARS In a Halloween episode, Emily (Shay Mitchell, above left, with Lucy Hale, center, and Ashley Benson); Aria (Ms. Hale); Hanna (Ms. Benson); and Spencer (Troian Bellisario) don their finest Edwardian costumes to crash the Ravenswood Founders Day Celebration after discovering a clue indicating that Ali (Sasha Pieterse) might be alive. Meanwhile, Caleb (Tyler Blackburn) travels to the town to help the girls  a move he comes to regret in the premiere of Ravenswood, at 9. There he meets the long-lost Uncle Raymond (Steven Cabral) of his new friend, Miranda (Nicole Gale Anderson), a feisty foster child, as well as the scandal-mired Luke (Brett Dier) and his twin, Olivia (Merritt Patterson). Only Remy (Britne Oldford) can help Caleb and Miranda connect the dots in this Pretty Little Liars spinoff.

title: Ducking Grief
description: In the months following my daughters death, there were times when I left my house that I could barely breathe.

title: Don James, Longtime Washington Huskies Football Coach, Dies at 80
description: Don James, who as the football coach for the University of Washington for 18 seasons transformed a little-known program into a high-profile powerhouse that won four Rose Bowls and a share of the national championship, died on Sunday at his home in Kirkland, Wash. He was 80.

title: News Quiz | October 22, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Bay Area Trains Roll Again as Strike Ends
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Traffic returned to its usual gridlock on the Bay Bridge here Tuesday, ferry passengers had more elbow room, and the overflowing charter buses that had been carrying disgruntled commuters to work were put to other purposes.

title: Pollen Study Points to Drought as Culprit in Bronze Age Mystery
description: TEL AVIV  More than 3,200 years ago, life was abuzz in and around what is now this modern-day Israeli metropolis on the shimmering Mediterranean shore.

title: Nokias New Tablet Arrives Ahead of Microsoft Deal
description: Nokias first Windows tablet, introduced on Tuesday, is a colorful device born under some curious omens.

title: Connections in an Amorphous World
description: All composers draw upon various musical styles. Very few are completely original. The challenge is to fashion the diverse influences into a distinctive voice. It is hard to describe what makes a composers voice authentic, but you know it when you hear it.

title: Test Yourself | History, Oct. 22, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Scalded by Coffee, Then News Media
description: Retro Report revisits an infamous McDonalds coffee spill and outsize jury verdict from 20 years ago in Scalded by Coffee, Then News Media. Watch the video and answer the following questions.

title: I Am Woman, Watch Me Hack
description: When she was a little girl growing up in the Bronx, Nikki Allen dreamed of being a forensic scientist. As a teenager, she liked studying science in school, and she thought forensics offered a way to give back to her neighborhood. Not insignificant, the job also looked pretty cool  at least based on the many hours of CSI Allen had watched on TV with her aunt.

title: Robert Capa: Finding a Fearless Photographers Voice
description: Robert Capa  born a hundred years ago today  was famous as a dashing, brave photojournalist who often put himself in danger. He was a pivotal figure in the history of photography and helped found Magnum before his death covering the French Indochina War in 1954.

title: How Much Does Your Neighborhood Define Who You Are?
description: Does your neighborhood shape who you are? Would you be a different person if you grew up someplace else?

title: Ex-Envoy Says Misunderstanding Runs on Both Sides of U.S.-Pakistan Ties
description: WASHINGTON  The meeting between President Obama and Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif at the White House on Wednesday is the most recent attempt by American and Pakistani leaders to reset a fraught relationship.

title: Soaring Prices of New Homes Defy Beijings Attempts to Cool Market
description: HONG KONG  Prices of new homes in China continued to soar in September, defying government efforts to cool the market and highlighting some of the challenges Beijing faces as it seeks to rebalance growth and rein in risks that have built up in the economy during the past five years.

title: Beijing Plans to Trim English Portion of College Entrance Exam
description: Beijing has announced a proposal to reduce the importance of English on the college entrance examination taken by high school students. The two- or three-day exam, known as the gaokao, has a critical role in deciding if and where students will attend college, so any change in the scoring will have a significant impact on what students study beginning in elementary school.

title: Sales Spur Talk of Hong Kongs Superman Turning Sights to Europe
description: Li Ka-shing, one of the worlds richest men, is known in his adopted hometown and business hub of Hong Kong as Superman, for his financial acumen.

title: New York Today: Round 2
description: Updated 12:47 p.m. | Tonights forecast calls for an aggressive Lhota.

title: A New Book Portrays Amazon as Bully
description: It was perhaps inevitable that Amazon would have a rocky relationship with book publishers. Publishers are analog, Amazon is digital. Publishers are New York, Amazon is Seattle. The large publishers traditionally did not know much about their customers, and did not really care. Amazon knew a lot about customers and made the most of it.

title: Impasses May Slice Into Profits on Wall Street
description: Updated, 8:39 p.m. | As the end of the year approaches, Wall Street employees and those who watch New York States coffers keep a close eye on just how much reward will be reaped by employees of financial firms.

title: This Is More Complicated Than I Thought
description: In my last post, I wrote about Caroline Scheeler and Joe Vajarsky, who saw their dream of opening an old-fashioned general store turn into a nightmare before they even got the doors open. They ran into a major cash crunch and began worrying that they were in over their heads.

title: Daily Report: Investors Love Amazon.com, Despite Lack of Profit
description: Amazon.com announces a new venture nearly every day: the purchase of an online education company, the development of a payment mechanism to compete with PayPal, updates to its tablet line, a fashion design competition, three new comedy pilots. But one thing it will not announce this month, David Streitfeld reports, is a significant profit.

title: U.S. and 10 Other Nations Back Peace Talks, but Syrian Moderates Are Uncertain
description: LONDON  The United States and 10 Arab and European nations expressed support on Tuesday for the convening of a peace conference next month in Geneva to begin negotiations on a political settlement to end the bloody civil war in Syria.

title: Indias Press Faces an Online Future
description: Two years ago, Samir Patil surveyed his publishing floor in Mumbai, one of 10 he owned, and saw death. It was not for a lack of lively activity. His company, ACK Media, shipped roughly six million books, magazines and DVDs across India every month. In 2007, he had bought the childrens comic book Amar Chitra Katha, eventually merged it with two other titles and set lofty goals, described here, to revitalize the once popular comics industry.

title: Space Oddity David Bowies Way, and Newer Takes
description: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Facing Vote on European Subsidies, Fishermen Cling to Way of Life
description: COMBRIT, France  In a world of giant trawlers and fish-farming operations, Gwenal Pennarun still sets out most days from this Breton village to catch sea bass the old-fashioned way, with baited hooks.

title: Agglomerating A Revolution
description: The two Nicks, Crafts and Wolf, have a piece right up my alley: they argue that the cutting edge of Britains Industrial Revolution, the cotton textile industry, benefited hugely from agglomeration. Indeed, it was very concentrated in a small area:

title: Red Pencils Ready?
description: For this weeks roundup of grammar, style and other editing missteps, I turn once again to the popular After Deadline Quiz. Try to identify at least one problem in each of the following passages; my answers and explanations are below.

title: In Performance: Dee Dee Bridgewater of Lady Day
description: The jazz singer Dee Dee Bridgewater plays Billie Holiday in the musical Lady Day, a bio-drama that features songs from various eras of the troubled singers career, including Lady Sings the Blues and Good Morning Heartache. In this video, Ms. Bridgewater sings A Foggy Day in London Town, a song written by George Gershwin, with lyrics by Ira Gershwin. Lady Day, written and directed by Stephen Stahl, is at the Little Shubert Theater.

title: A Dark Age of Empirical Work
description: A correspondent writes, in regard to my note on economics as science (or not), that the rise of empirical work is not entirely a good thing:

title: The Numbers Behind the JPMorgan Deal
description: JPMorgan Chase, which is close to striking a $13 billion settlement over mortgage practices, has been portrayed by some on Wall Street as a victim of government zealotry. The banks defenders say JPMorgan is paying for the sins of two firms it bought in the financial crisis, Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual. But as details emerge, Wall Streets fears of a largely punitive settlement may not add up, Peter Eavis and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

title: China Tries to Clean Up Toxic Legacy of Its Rare Earth Riches
description: TIANJIN, China  In northern China, near the Mongolian border, radioactively contaminated leaks from two decades of rare earth refining have been slowly trickling underground toward the Yellow River, a crucial water source for 150 million people.

title: Why Can Neil Patrick Harris Say Thats Too Gay and Straights Cant?
description: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Two Charged in School Lunch Poisoning Case in India
description: NEW DELHI  The police in India have charged a school principal and her husband with murder in the deaths of 23 children who were fed school lunches laced with insecticide, officials said Tuesday, in a case that shocked the country and contributed to concerns about food safety.

title: Weak Job Gains May Cause Delay in Action by Fed
description: Even before the federal government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis this month, the nations economy was lagging and job growth was sluggish. And the recent dysfunction in Congress seems likely to make the situation worse.

title: Investigators Raid Agency of Military in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Military investigators raided South Koreas Cyberwarfare Command on Tuesday after four of its officials were found to have posted political messages online last year, in what opposition lawmakers have called a smear campaign against President Park Geun-hyes opponents before her election in December.

title: In Store | Azzedine Alaas New Paris Boutique Is All Curves
description: Azzedine Alaa, the cult-status fashion designer beloved by women like Franca Sozzani, Stephanie Seymour and Naomi Campbell since skyrocketing to fame in the 1980s with beautifully made, body-hugging dresses, has a breathtaking new boutique perfectly suited to showcasing his designs. As a landmark retrospective of his greatest gowns at the Palais Galliera was drawing crowds during Paris Fashion Week (a ritual the enigmatic designer has long shunned), Alaa unveiled his new shop, housed in an 18th-century mansion just off the Avenue Montaigne. The space is adorned with impressive furnishings by Marc Newson, Kris Ruhs, Pierre Paulin and Charlotte Perriand, and a vertical garden by Patrick Blanc towers over the interior courtyard cafe. But the real stars are the dresses, coats, shoes and bags  stunning, elegant and unlike anything else around.

title: New York Sets Work Rules for Young Models
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed legislation on Monday night that will recognize fashion models under the age of 18 as child performers. The new law, which is expected to go into effect in 30 days, will have a significant impact on the casting of models for the next New York Fashion Week, in February.

title: Holding a Frightened Sparrow
description: Dear Diary:

title: Was a Question About Women and the Great American Novel Sexist?
description: Maura Casey, a Times reader and a former member of The Times editorial board, was one of the readers who was unhappy with a question posed Sunday in the Book Reviews weekly Bookends feature: Where Is the Great American Novel by a Woman?

title: Obamacares Headaches
description: Technical glitches bedevil the online health insurance marketplace.

title: J.F.K.: A Sampler
description: SUPERMAN COMES TO THE SUPERMARKETBy Norman Mailer.  Esquire, November 1960.Mailer got Kennedy better than anyone, even though it was his first major work of political journalism.

title: The Employment Rate Remains Stuck
description: The American economy continues to tread water underwater.

title: A Climate and Energy Roundup
description: If you care about greenhouse-driven global warming and related energy policies, I encourage you to subscribe to the Hot News feed from Climate Nexus and/or the Daily Climate. To keep a full view of the debate over relevant policies, youd also do well to track the flow of links from the Global Warming Policy Foundation, a pro-fossil, anti-regulation group* in Great Britain.

title: Fed Shift Now Seems More Distant
description: Forget about a Fed tapering in 2013.

title: Mourning a Miscarriage
description: It wasnt a baby. It was not a baby. It was just a bunch of cells put together in a petri dish that had the potential to be a baby. But it was never going to be born, I told myself after the D&C.

title: Little Sign of Jobs Impact From Health Care Law
description: Is the Affordable Care Act causing a surge in part-time employment?

title: A Visit to the Hermit Kingdom
description: SHANGHAI  Some of the passengers were clutching their heads, complaining about hangovers, staring with glazed eyes out of the tour bus at the rural scenery. For many of the people on our package tour of North Korea  mostly men in their 20s and 30s  drinks in our small hotel bar near the DMZ the night before had led to dancing with the waitresses until the early hours.

title: Bloated Government? Federal Employment at 47-Year Low
description: It was the summer of 1966. Lyndon Johnson was in the White House and the Great Society was roaring. In August, the federal government had 2,721,000 employees.

title: Kennedy, the Elusive President
description: As the 50th anniversary of his assassination nears, John F. Kennedy remains all but impossible to pin down. One reason is that his martyrdom  for a generation of Americans still the most traumatic public event of their lives, 9/11 notwithstanding  has obscured much about the man and his accomplishments.

title: In Our Pages: October 23
description: 1938 Benes Flies to Secret Hide-out

title: Whats Behind the Notion That Nonfiction Is More Relevant Than Fiction?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Rivka Galchen and Pankaj Mishra discuss the boundaries of fiction and nonfiction, and the way each form reflects the world in which we live.

title: Many Reasons for Chiefs Success, but Passing Isnt One of Them
description: The Kansas City Chiefs, the N.F.L.s last undefeated team at 7-0, have had as impressive a worst-to-first start as any in recent memory.

title: Buildup to the Second Mayoral Debate
description: Going into the second of three television debates, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican mayoral candidate, has criticized his rival, Bill de Blasio, for negativity in their first encounter a week ago.

title: Handybook, a Housecleaning Start-Up, Raises $10 Million
description: Investors are betting that the business of scheduling housework can be the next big thing.

title: Godwin and the Greenback
description: Oh, dear. Im starting to notice a shift in the scare talk. Cries that were about to turn into Greece, Greece I tell you are getting a bit fainter, maybe because of what Ive been writing. But taking their place are dire warnings that were endangering the dollars role as a reserve currency.

title: Neil Young Benefit Concert to Be Streamed Live
description: Every October, Neil Young and his wife, Pegi, gather some of Mr. Youngs colleagues for two benefit concerts for the Bridge School, a nonprofit school in Hillsborough, Calif., that specializes in teaching students with physical and speech impairments. The shows have long attracted international attention for their starry lineups as well as for the cause they support, and in recent years the school has released CD and DVD compilations of some of the best performances.

title: A Discouraging Picture
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Image of the Day: October 22
After Long N.C.A.A. Inquiry, Miami Loses 12 Scholarships
description: The N.C.A.A. on Tuesday cited Miami for a decade of violations in its mens basketball and football programs, penalizing the university with three years of probation and a loss of some scholarships.

title: Thirsty, Thirsty Hippo
Feeling For | Mens Watches with Classic Appeal
description: Sophisticated, understated watches that dont waste time on garish bevels or gussied-up faces.

title: Hyundai Will Recall 27,500 Genesis Sedans for Braking Problem
description: Hyundai will recall about 27,500 Genesis sedans from the 2009-12 model years because of a braking problem that had been the focus of an investigation initiated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration last Thursday, Miles Johnson, a spokesman for Hyundai, wrote in an e-mail.

title: Hoping Comebacks Have Just Begun
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Peyton Hillis felt as if he were appearing, if not starring, in a remake of The Natural.

title: BBC Radio to Resurface a Bowie Promotion From 1973
description: David Bowies Pin Ups album seemed slightly eccentric when he released it in 1973, even by the lights of someone who had made eccentricity an art. Here was a musician who had made his name as an imaginative, colorful songwriter, by way of songs like Space Oddity and concept albums like The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars and Aladdin Sane, turning his hand to an album of mid-60s covers.

title: Judge Orders Goldman to Pay Ex-Programmers Legal Bills
description: Updated, 8:05 p.m. | A federal judge has ruled that Goldman Sachs must pay the legal fees of a former computer programmer accused of stealing code from the bank, a decision that wades into a hot-button issue as more and more Wall Street employees find themselves ensnared in lawsuits and investigations.

title: A New Hotel in a Modernist Landmark
description: The new Langham, Chicago hotel offers travelers another downtown luxury option. But for design lovers it offers residence  or even just tea  in a Modernist landmark.

title: Senator Raises Questions About Protecting Student Data
description: A lawmaker who is a staunch advocate of childrens privacy is investigating whether the data collection and analysis practices of the growing education technology industry, a market estimated at $8 billion, are outstripping federal rules governing the sharing of students personal information.

title: Flying to the Stratosphere
description: An animation that demonstrates the flight experience.

title: Gates Buys a Stake in Spanish Builder
description: Updated, 2:35 p.m. | LONDON  Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, has purchased a 6 percent stake in the Spanish builder Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, known as FCC, becoming the latest investor to make a bet on the recovery of the Spanish economy.

title: Highlights and Analysis From Apples Event
description: Apple announced significantly upgraded versions of its tablets at an event on Tuesday, including an iPad Air, a faster and thinner tablet, and a new Mini that comes with a higher resolution display.

title: Balloon Ride to Offer Expansive View, for a Price
description: And now, a high-altitude adventure for the leisure class, people who do not want to be jostled as they sip Champagne and gaze down at Earths curved blue surface.

title: Dry Whites for Creamy Chowders
description: A conventional creamy chowder is a pleasure with wine. The richness of the broth and the brininess of the clams enhance all sorts of dry whites. Adding spinach requires a slightly more discerning selection to avoid clashing with the mild, pleasing bitterness of the green. I might steer clear of Muscadet or sauvignon blanc for that reason, but it still leaves many fine choices. A Chablis, for instance, a Mconnais or a California or Oregon chardonnay in a steely style would all be delicious. So would a good dry albario, an assyrtiko from Santorini or almost any of the myriad variations on dry or lightly sweet rieslings now produced around the world. Of course, you could do a lot worse than a pilsner, a dry stout or a good English ale.

title: Obama Advisers Offer Guarded View on Jobs
description: The verdict from President Obamas economic advisers: Better than nothing, not good enough, likely to get worse.

title: Cleveland Museum Director Resigns
description: The director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, which is nearing the completion of a major expansion project, announced this week that he would resign for personal reasons, effective immediately, The Plain Dealer in Cleveland reported.

title: Today in Small Business: What the Owner Takes Home
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: A Taste of Napa, on a Budget
description: Like a robust zinfandel and delicate oysters, Napa Valley and frugal travel arent exactly an ideal pairing.

title: Restaurant Report: Proprietors Bar & Table in Nantucket, Mass.
description: The little white house on slender India Street does not look much different from the rows of centuries-old buildings that line the cobblestoned streets of downtown Nantucket.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Bring Back Civility
Russian Credit Card Firm Jumps After I.P.O.
description: MOSCOW  Investors bid up the shares of the credit card company of the entrepreneur Oleg Tinkov on its first day of trading on Tuesday on the London Stock Exchange, as the consumer credit business booms in Russia.

title: Fantasy Football: How Rookie Wide Receivers Have Fared
description: Continuing with our rookie analysis, we turn to wide receivers. Many find it to be the position most difficult to predict. Instead of reranking each position, we grouped the rookies into tiers to describe their current status.

title: Amazon Raises Threshold for Free Shipping
description: Amazon.com tightened the requirements for one of its most popular shipping methods Tuesday morning.

title: Tortorella on Best Behavior as Canucks Visit Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  John Tortorella kept his composure throughout six minutes of questioning from reporters at Nassau Coliseum on Tuesday morning. In the New York metropolitan area for the first time as coach of the Vancouver Canucks, Tortorella handled gracefully a question that seemed likely to set him off: Was he surprised at the Rangers poor start?

title: The Wild Effect
description: After Cheryl Strayed wrote of her experiences in Wild, many other hikers have been drawn to the Pacific Crest Trail, seeking a new outlook on life.

title: Did Basic Errors Create the Health Insurance Mess?
description: The technology behind the federal health-insurance Web site is, were told, incredibly complex. But new disclosures suggest that the government and its army of private contractors made incredibly elementary errors in building the exchange.

title: The Gun Report: October 22, 2013
description: Yesterday morning, a student at Sparks Middle School in Nevada took his parents handgun to class and opened fire, wounding two 12-year-old boys and killing a beloved math teacher before killing himself. A student told CNN that she believes the shooter was a nice kid whod been bullied. That afternoon, in remarks he made to to the nations police chiefs, Attorney General Eric Holder noted that the number of active-shooter incidents in the country has soared over the past five years.

title: Claire Denis on 'Bastards'
description: The director discusses her latest film about a sea captain who returns to Paris after a family tragedy.

title: SAC Capital Retrenches as Insider Trading Inquiry Drains Firm
description: Updated, 8:00 p.m. | As federal authorities bore down on the SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund, its owner, Steven A. Cohen, assured his team of traders that the investigation would not affect its business.

title: From Barber Shops to Rooftops, Watching the Game
description: Whether working or running errands, fans found ways to watch playoff baseball. Even those at the ballpark sometimes had to jockey for a better view.

title: From Barber Shops to Rooftops, the Games On
description: The Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals will open the World Series on Wednesday night at Fenway Park, the tight little ballpark in Boston that had sold out for 820 consecutive games before the record streak ended in April. In this age of high-definition broadcasts and ubiquitous gadgets, baseball fans have any number of ways to follow postseason games. But fans once had to be resourceful when a championship was at stake.

title: Holding the Line in Maryland
description: On Oct. 21, 1863, an indignant delegation of slaveholders from St. Marys County, Md., on the western shore of Chesapeake Bay just across the Potomac River from Virginia, confronted President Abraham Lincoln at the White House. They demanded that he suspend recruiting efforts aimed at their slaves. The presence of armed colored troops was frightening quiet people, and producing great confusion, they told him. Lincoln listened sympathetically to the grievances voiced by these alleged Union supporters; he did not, he told them, want the Army behaving in any rude or ungentlemanly manner.

title: How the Furloughed Will Be Counted
description: There has been a lot of speculation about how the federal government shutdown will affect numbers for the October jobs report, due out Nov. 8. The jobs report is based on two different surveys  one of households, and one of employers  and it turns out that furloughed federal government workers will be treated as unemployed in the first survey but employed in the second. In other words, the temporary layoff of federal workers will probably increase the unemployment rate, but not (at least directly) depress the payroll job growth numbers.

title: A Brazilian-Style Meal in New York
description: Alex Atala, the acclaimed chef from Brazil, prepared dinner for about 70 people in Manhattan on Friday.

title: In Manhattan, Alex Atala Offers a Sense of So Paulo
description: The Brazilian chef Alex Atala was in the middle of preparing two canaps and five dinner courses for about 70 people in Manhattan on Friday when it dawned on him that he needed black plates.

title: Naomie Harris Gets Jazzed Up
description: The Girl: The actress looked fit for the Roaring Twenties last night, when she was honored at Elles 20th annual Women in Hollywood celebration at the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills.

title: Why a Stock Sale Could Be the Right Program for Netflix
description: Netflix stock has quadrupled since January. The companys chief executive, Reed Hastings, warns that momentum investors have become too euphoric. Diluting the punch bowl by issuing more equity is a better way to calm this rowdy party  and answer doubts about the online video companys balance sheet.

title: Tax on Medical Devices Becomes Recurring Theme in Budget Debate
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress searches for a deal to end the budget standoff, one unrelated issue keeps coming up: a tax on the sale of medical devices like heart implants and artificial hips, enacted to help finance the health care law.

title: Major Owens, 77, Education Advocate in Congress, Dies
description: Major R. Owens, a former librarian who went to Congress from Brooklyn and remained there for 24 years, fighting for more federal aid for education and other liberal causes, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Exploring Solar, Efficiency, Gas and More with Amory Lovins and Joel Makower
description: Last Thursday I spent a half hour onstage in San Francisco discussing energy trends and choices with the energy analyst Amory B. Lovins and green business maven Joel Makower. This was the capping event of Verge 2013, a conference on commerce and sustainability run by Makowers GreenBiz Group.

title: U.S. Officer Says Taliban Will Fight This Winter
description: BRUSSELS  A senior American military officer warned Tuesday that insurgent groups are expected to carry out an unusually aggressive campaign of violence in Afghanistan this winter, angling to create maximal disruption ahead of next years presidential elections and as Western forces continue to withdraw.

title: A Bourbon-Rye Blend, You Say?
description: In 2009, when he released Bourye, his oddball blend of bourbon and rye whiskeys, David Perkins, the founder of High West Distillery in Utah, decided to protect his ownership of the term even though, he says, he thought the name kind of dumb.

title: J.F.K.
description: THE INTERLOPERLee Harvey Oswald Inside the Soviet UnionBy Peter Savodnik  Basic Books, $27.99.

title: Most Latinos Do Not See a National Leader, Poll Finds
description: A majority of Latinos in the United States say they need a national leader to promote their interests but cannot identify anyone who fits that bill, according to a survey published Tuesday by the Pew Research Centers Hispanic Trends Project.

title: Revamped Les Mis Finds Its Valjean and Javert for Broadway
description: The London musical theater star Ramin Karimloo (The Phantom of the Opera, Love Never Dies) and the New York musical theater star Will Swenson (Murder Ballad, Hair) will face off as the bitter antagonists Jean Valjean and Inspector Javert in the reconceived Broadway production of Les Misrables this spring, the producer Cameron Mackintosh announced on Tuesday. Singing I Dreamed a Dream as Fantine  the role that won Anne Hathaway an Academy Award in the recent film version  will be Caissie Levy, who starred in the Broadway productions of Ghost and Hair (and was also in Murder Ballad this year with Mr. Swenson).

title: Tap and Swipe for a Good Cause
description: Mobile games are designed to be simple endeavors, something to pass the time while waiting in a doctors office or for a train. But the Global Gaming Initiative wants to elevate them to a higher purpose.

title: Earbuds Built of Sterner Stuff, With a Few Quirks
description: Everyone has had that sickening moment when you realize the crunch underfoot came from stepping on your earbuds. If you experience that moment frequently, you might consider the RHA 750i in-ear headphones  they are one durable set.

title: Vacuum Tubes in a Speaker, but Lacking Old-Time Warmth
description: Samsungs new sound bar has a number of advanced features and one antiquated one, but its the Edison-era technology that sets this speaker apart.

title: Fishing the Old-Fashioned Way
description: A vote by the European Parliament this week could determine whether subsidies continue to support big-fleet fishing or help steer the industry toward a more sustainable future.

title: An Industrious Eating Tour of Germany
description: Visiting Munich, Frankfurt and Berlin, where restaurant roots run deep.

title: Icahn Takes a Bow as Big Winner in Netflix Trade
description: Updated, 5:26 p.m. | Turns out Netflix may have fallen on Tuesday because Carl C. Icahn was cashing out. The hedge fund manager reported cutting his stake almost by half, to 4.5 percent.

title: Berlins New Pastrami Star
description: After unsuccessfully scouring Berlin for a good pastrami, Oskar Melzer decided to open Mogg & Melzer with his partner, Paul Mogg. The restaurants fare now rivals New Yorks traditional Jewish delis.

title: Controversy Over Statins for Older Patients
description: Should older adults take statins if they have elevated cholesterol but no evidence of heart disease? Its a surprisingly controversial question, given the number of seniors taking statins.

title: Capitol Dome to Get Its First Face-Lift in More Than 50 Years
description: Weather and plain old age have left the Capitol dome with more than 1,000 cracks and deficiencies like stains and rust, the architect of the Capitol said in a statement on Tuesday.

title: Reflections, Intimate and Layered
description: Over a 27-year period, from 1947, just weeks before he turned 34, until 1974, two years before his death, when he was already ill with debilitating heart disease, Benjamin Britten wrote five Canticles, unusual and extraordinary vocal works. In earlier times, a canticle was an extended vocal piece on a spiritual subject. Britten took this old genre and made it his own.

title: As Third Point Does Well, Loeb to Return Money to Investors
description: The billionaire investor Daniel S. Loeb will return as much as $1.4 billion to investors in his Third Point hedge fund at the end of the year for the first time in its 18-year history.

title: Le Restaurant
description: Inside the basement of a food market in TriBeCa called All Good Things, where the sole offering is a $100 tasting menu.

title: The Debate Over Judge Posners Unforced Error
description: Two weeks ago, Richard Posner, one of the most respected and iconoclastic federal judges in the country, startled the legal world by publicly stating that hed made a mistake in voting to uphold a 2005 voter-ID law out of Indiana, and that if he had properly understood the abuse of such laws, the case would have been decided differently.

title: Apple Targets Microsoft Office With Free Apps
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At an event meant to feature its latest iPad tablet computing devices, Apple on Tuesday took aim at one of the biggest and seemingly unassailable businesses of its rival Microsoft, its Office software for tasks like word processing and spreadsheets.

title: Down the Steps, Finding Wonders Within
description: First, the bad news. The restaurant under my microscope today is in a basement. It is closed four nights out of seven. Its sole offering is a $100 tasting menu that is not posted in advance. Substitutions are not allowed. And the name is impossible to say with a straight face: Le Restaurant.

title: Flu Shots Tied to Heart Benefits
description: Getting a flu vaccine is associated with a lower risk of death in people with heart disease, a review of studies has found, and the effect is greatest in those who have had a recent heart attack or chest pain.

title: Another Two-Night Orchestra Gig On a Conductors Crowded Rsum
description: When Bernard Haitink led the London Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday and Monday, it was hardly the last time New York would be able to observe the coming 60th anniversary of his conducting debut.

title: Nia Vardalos, Not So Instant Mom
description: The thing about Nia Vardaloss book, Instant Mom, is that I want to push it onto people. Lots of people. People who have looked at my family and said, Oh, weve thought about adoption. People who I kind of suspect might, for one reason or another, be thinking about adoption. People who I, in my status as she-who-knows-best-about everything, think should maybe be thinking about adoption. (I would never really do that.)

title: Text to Text | Twelve Years a Slave, and An Escape That Has Long Intrigued Historians
description: Last month we introduced our new Text to Text series, which matches Times content with excerpts from often-taught literary, cultural, historical or scientific material. Read more about the format, and consider submitting an idea.

title: Giving a Wife Her Front-Yard Grave, No Matter What
description: STEVENSON, Ala.  James Davis figures that his first mistake was asking permission. If a man promises his wife he will bury her in the front yard, then he should just do so.

title: A New Brooklyn Fare for Manhattan, Prized White Truffles and More
description: To Shop: A New Fare For Manhattan

title: Ballet Master Dips His Toe in the Ice Rink
description: Figure skating has glided into Edward Villellas life twice, both at life-changing moments. The first time occurred in 1977 when he was hired to choreograph an ice ballet for a Dorothy Hamill television special.

title: Rights Group Warns Against Bahrains Use of Tear Gas Against Protesters
description: CAIRO  A human rights group said Tuesday that Bahrain, which has been criticized for cracking down on opposition protesters, might misuse more than a million canisters of tear gas that the government is reportedly trying to buy.

title: How to Eat Anchovies
description: Melissa Clark offers a primer on a particularly polarizing fish.

title: Beats Signature Headphones Get an Upgrade
description: Responding to consumers who are seeking more features from headphones, Beats Electronics recently updated its ubiquitous Beats Studio headphones, which were originally released in 2008.

title: Anchovies 101: A Video Tutorial
description: Anyone who reads my column has probably noticed that Im obsessed with anchovies. They are my secret weapon, and after salt, olive oil and lemons, the thing I cant live without in the kitchen.

title: Some Key Job Sectors Turn Softer
description: Last year, restaurants and health care accounted for about a third of all the countrys job growth.

title: Art Matters | Two Artists, a Chevy Astro Van and a Statue of Michael Jackson
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Discussing Dissident Gardens
description: Updated, 9:30 p.m. | Thanks to all who participated in tonights lively discussion. If you werent able to make it feel free to leave your remarks in the comments section throughout the week.  Ginia Bellafante

title: Apple Exploits Microsoft Hesitation on Office
description: Updated, 5:04 p.m. | To reflect recent Microsoft remarks on iPad version of Office and a comment on Apples moves.

title: Kingside Opens, Momofuku Ko Is Moving and More
description: Headliner

title: For Starters, Unmasking Subtleties in Verdi
description: Every so often, a dancer from a major ballet company makes an entrepreneurial move, branching out from the institutional ranks with a strong-minded project. In 2011, Michele Wiles left her principal position at American Ballet Theater to found Ballet Next with the former New York City Ballet principal Charles Askegard. In 2010, Troy Schumacher, a corps dancer with City Ballet, helped to jump-start BalletCollective, which encourages multimedia collaboration.

title: Germanys Culinary Stars
description: FRANKFURT  When young lovers dream of a romantic European dinner in a back-street hideaway packed with locals, those back streets tend to be in Paris or Florence, not Dsseldorf or Nuremberg. When thrill-seeking diners book long-distance travel to taste some pathbreaking chefs strange new inventions, their planes land in places like Barcelona or Copenhagen, not Leipzig or Dresden.

title: Line by Line, the Artist Luo Ying Alters Chinese Tradition
description: In her studio in Wuhan, a giant city in central China known more for heavy industry than for art, Luo Ying picks up a fine-tipped brush, dips it in ink and begins delicately painting bamboo leaves on rice paper.

title: An Exploration of the Curious Case of Benjamin Britten
description: Benjamin Britten, whose centennial is being celebrated this year, wrote some of his finest works for the tenor Peter Pears, his lifelong partner and muse. Britten also composed works for friends like the guitarist Julian Bream, who met the couple at a party during the 1952 Aldeburgh Festival.

title: Counting Sheep, Wallet in Hand
description: IF THE UNSPEAKABLE ever happens to newspapers, the colors of my parachute are clear: morning talk-show producer, artisanal goat-cheese farmer, garbage-truck driver (presuming the depth perception issue can be addressed).

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Indonesia, the West Bank, England and Pakistan.

title: Spreading the Word From Behind Bars
description: Inmates in the brutal Angola prison in Louisiana are sharing religion thanks to the New Orleans Baptist Theological Seminary.

title: Sharing Tragedy and Grief Over Dinner
description: It is nice to imagine that on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, everyone who went off to work at the World Trade Center said a picture-perfect loving goodbye to the spouse and children before the towers were destroyed. Alec, a ghost in Jack Canforas consistently clever Jericho, did not. Jericho is also painfully significant, an intelligent intertwining of the nature of grief, cultural identity, fraught relationships and shared tragedy.

title: Sebelius Names Administration Veteran to Lead Tech Repair Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration did not look far for someone to lead the so-called tech surge to fix its troubled health insurance Web site: Jeffrey D. Zients, a management trouble-shooter already in line to take over as the chief White House economic adviser on Jan. 1, until then will manage the effort to resolve the technical failures.

title: Living In Valley Cottage, N.Y.
description: A more affordable neighbor to the Nyacks and Congers, with an interesting connection to Czarist-era Russia.

title: Rockwell and Tolstoy Collide in Valley Cottage, N.Y.
description: Valley Cottage, a small rectangle of green set amid the three Nyacks and Congers about 30 miles from New York in Rockland County, is a quiet suburb with a woodsy setting and an unexpected connection with Czarist-era Russia: Leo Tolstoys youngest daughter and secretary, Alexandra, who arrived in the area in the late 1930s, spent four decades establishing and nurturing a community for political exiles  a flourishing organization called the Tolstoy Foundation, through which the authors legacy lives on in the hamlet today.

title: Why Not Medicaid For All?
description: My Sunday column on the potential consequences of Obamacares botched rollout ended by sketching a scenario in which the programs Medicaid expansion is deemed a success while its reform of the individual market leads to much-higher-than-expected costs and much-lower-than-expected participation rates. This combination would no doubt be politically helpful to the Republican Party in the short run, but (I argued) it would actually leave liberals with a fairly clear path forward: Keep pressing the Medicaid expansion on states that havent taken it (and look for John Kasich-style Republicans to partner with), return to the Joe Lieberman-killed idea of expanding Medicare to 55-and-overs, and basically try to further shrink the percentage of Americans who arent eligible for one or both of those single-payer programs. This wouldnt amount to the full-on push for single payer that some people expect from the left if Obamacare fails or gets repealed, but it would move the U.S. toward the closest thing to single payer that were ever likely to get: A system in which both the late middle-aged and the lower middle class gradually get folded into government-run insurance alongside the poor, the disabled, and the aged; the individual market survives as a kind of de facto high risk pool (overpriced but technically accessible); and the employer mandate helps prop up employer-based health insurance for a shrunken but still substantial share of the population.

title: Lawsuit at Worcester Paper Delays Timess Sale of The Globe
description: A Massachusetts judge has temporarily blocked The New York Times Companys planned sale of The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette to the investor John W. Henry, citing a lawsuit involving the Worcester newspaper and its delivery workers.

title: Citing Shutdown, I.R.S. Says Tax Season Will Start Late
description: WASHINGTON  The Internal Revenue Service plans to delay the start of tax-filing season by a week or two because of the government shutdown, the agency said on Tuesday. But taxpayers will still have to turn in their 2013 returns by April 15 as usual.

title: Families, and Money, With More Than One Complication
description: The evil forces in Bastards, the new, grimly beautiful and somewhat unhinged film from the French director Claire Denis, enter wearing masks. These are not the usual monsters that slink through the shadows, growling and prowling while baring sharp teeth and talons. The evil here slips into the back seat of chauffeured cars and smiles a dazzling white smile before grasping a childs hand, patting a womans arm or slipping in a metaphoric knife. Evil like this only needs metaphoric weapons: power makes its bearers dirty but also keeps them clean.

title: Keeping a Foot in the Office Door Can Ease Mothers Anxiety
description: In her practice as a divorce lawyer, Margy Klaw sees many highly educated, middle-aged women who wish they hadnt left full-time work after having children. Faced with the prospect of failed marriages, she said, they are terrified that they wont be able to support themselves.

title: Another Liquor License Approved in Lower East Side Area
description: Manhattans so-called Hell Square, a three-by-three-block section of the Lower East Side that already has about 50 bars and restaurants, is getting another establishment that will serve liquor. State regulators approved a license on Tuesday for a planned private club that had drawn complaints from residents concerned that it would bring more traffic and noise.

title: Fantasy Football Week 8: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
description: Doug Martin. Reggie Wayne. Jay Cutler. Those were just three of the big-name players who were injured during Week 7 as the bad news kept coming for fantasy owners. Football is a cruel sport, but as we talked about last week, a large part of fantasy football is finding opportunity among others misfortune.

title: The Numbers Behind the Job Numbers
description: A look at how Janet Yellen, President Obamas pick to lead the Federal Reserve, may interpret the latest jobs report, and what those numbers say about how how the economy is really doing.

title: Morrissey on Pitching the Glamour of a Plain Life
description: Steven Patrick Morrissey of Manchester, England, a place more brittle and less courteous than anywhere else on earth, former singer for the Smiths, once and future hero for the misunderstood, and champion for powerless humans and animals, is also an inspired adman. The concept for the Smiths record covers, he explains in his new book, Autobiography, was to take images that were the opposite of glamour and to pump enough heart and desire into them to show ordinariness as an instrument of power  or possibly, glamour.

title: A Would-Be Diva From Suburbia Spends a Night in the Big-City Spotlight
description: Imagine GypsyMama Rose as a ferociously needy nightclub performer of the sort occasionally glimpsed on public access television belting Broadway showstoppers like Before the Parade Passes By. One such would-be diva, Miriam Passman, appeared at 54 Below on Thursday evening in the person of Charles Busch in his sidesplitting show, Ridin High.

title: Hearing Starts for Dancer Accused in Bolshoi Attack
description: A Moscow court on Tuesday opened and then quickly rescheduled the first public hearing in the case of an acid attack against the artistic director of the Bolshoi Theater, which seems set to look into personal grievances in one of the worlds premier ballet troupes. Pavel Dmitrichenko, above, the former principal dancer accused of paying two co-defendants to ambush the artistic director, Sergei Filin, with a mixture of sulfuric acid and urine in January, entered the courtroom in handcuffs and wore a slight smile as he stated his name and place of birth before the judge. Prosecutors were expected to read charges against Mr. Dmitrichenko on Tuesday but the case was rescheduled to next week because a lawyer for another of the accused did not attend the hearing. While the Bolshoi had been known for its atmosphere of extreme, and sometimes destructive, competition, the acid attack sent shock waves through Russias theater community and further exposed animosities among some of the troupes most gifted dancers.

title: Tracking the JPMorgan Investigations
description: At least seven federal agencies, several state regulators and two foreign countries are investigating the bank.

title: New Front in the Fight With Infant Mortality
description: As the health care bill that was to become known as Obamacare was making its way through Congress in 2009, Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, sought to block the requirement that health insurers cover a minimum set of health benefits determined by the federal government.

title: Growing a Wine Destination in South Dakota
description: We buzzed past fields of corn and soybeans, down slippery dirt roads and around the occasional tractor. At times, my wife and I heard cattle groan and whiffed the acidic scent of manure amid a landscape dotted with peeling, wooden barns and silvery silos.

title: A Chance to End a Billion-Dollar Tax Break for Private Equity
description: A recent court case has given the federal government a chance to sidestep Congress and eliminate private equitys billion-dollar tax break. The question is whether the Obama administration takes up the fight.

title: How to Fix the Glitches
description: PHILADELPHIA  NOW that we are past the government shutdown and debt ceiling debacles, all eyes are on Obamacare. For the last three weeks, the rollout of the federal exchange Web site, a centerpiece of the law, has been riddled with problems, leaving millions of Americans frustrated and dismayed.

title: Under the Influence
description: The in-demand composer, whose opera Two Boys had its premiere last night at the Metropolitan Opera, also shares his passion for Singapore, The Satanic Verses and more.

title: Kerry James Evans: From Combat Engineer to Poet
description: Kerry James Evans, whos just 30, has hard-knock credentials for a poet. He grew up in the South among the working poor, then spent six years as a combat engineer with the Army National Guard. And the poems in his first collection, Bangalore, just published by Copper Canyon Press, reflect (and reflect on) those seemingly sub-poetic experiences. In a recent e-mail conversation Mr. Evans, who recently received his Ph.D. in English from Florida State University, talked about his poetry and subject matter. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Falling Behind
description: Infant mortality has declined much less in the United States over the last 30 years than in many other developed countries.

title: Dana L. Moskowitz
description: Ms. Moskowitz, 32, is the president of the Evo Real Estate Group, which manages and leases office buildings.

title: Nico Muhly on the Philosophy of The Secret of NIMH and the Allure of the Sea Urchin
description: There may be no young composer who deserves greater credit for retailoring American classical music for the 21st century than Nico Muhly. Only 32, the Juilliard-educated musician has written many dozens of works for a variety of classical ensembles while also collaborating with numerous Pitchfork-approved bands, including Grizzly Bear, Sufjan Stevens, Antony and the Johnsons, the National and Bjrk, not to mention Phillip Glass, one of his heroes. He has released five albums, counting his 2009 soundtrack to The Reader. (He also scored the new Beat Generation biopic, Kill Your Darlings.) He has also repeatedly teamed up with another singular young talent who is pushing a traditional discipline forward, the choreographer Benjamin Milliepied, most recently on Two Hearts for the New York City Ballet.

title: Wheelies: The Nonluxury Lexus Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from around the Web:

title: Judge Allows Legal Challenge of Law to Continue
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge cleared the way on Tuesday for consumers to challenge President Obamas health care law on the grounds that the federal government cannot legally provide subsidies to people who buy insurance through the exchange run by it.

title: Twitter Sheds a Light on Fast Growth of Its Newest Acquisition
description: Twitter received plenty of plaudits when it announced last month that it would buy MoPub, an advertising technology company, for $300 million.

title: A Bubble Bursts
description: Rare earth prices soared after China imposed a two-month embargo on shipments to Japan in the autumn of 2010, but have now crashed.

title: Enigmatic Dickinson Revealed Online
description: The manuscripts of Emily Dickinson have long been scattered across multiple archives, meaning scholars had to knock on numerous doors to see all the handwritten drafts of a poet whose work went almost entirely unpublished in her lifetime.

title: The Emily Dickinson Archive
description: The online archive brings together thousands of manuscript pages relating to Dickinsons poems.

title: Mens Wearhouse Said to Weigh Bid for Allen Edmonds
description: Mens Wearhouse may try one of the countrys bigger upscale shoemakers on for size.

title: The Cry of the True Republican
description: I AM a genetic Republican.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Apples Tablet Focus and the GIF Wars Redux
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Case in Detroit Highlights Costs of Extra Pension Payments
description: The constitutions of some states, including Michigan, explicitly bar the cutting of public pensions. But what about extra payments promised to Detroits workers and retirees?

title: Murder Stirs British Debate on the Roots of Extremism
description: LONDON  Pavlo Lapshyn, a gifted 25-year-old engineering student from Ukraine, had come to Britain after winning a prestigious placement at a software company. A special awards ceremony had been held at the British ambassadors residence in Kiev, and in April Mr. Lapshyn arrived in Birmingham.

title: The Shanghai Secret
description: SHANGHAI  Whenever I visit China, I am struck by the sharply divergent predictions of its future one hears. Lately, a number of global investors have been shorting China, betting that someday soon its powerful economic engine will sputter, as the real estate boom here turns to a bust. Frankly, if I were shorting China today, it would not be because of the real estate bubble, but because of the pollution bubble that is increasingly enveloping some of its biggest cities. Optimists take another view: that, buckle in, China is just getting started, and that what were now about to see is the payoff from Chinas 30 years of investment in infrastructure and education. Im not a gambler, so Ill just watch this from the sidelines. But if youre looking for evidence as to why the optimistic bet isnt totally crazy, you might want to visit a Shanghai elementary school.

title: The Trouble at Health Cares Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer Plan Upsets a Brooklyn Campuss Neighbors
description: The city campus of Long Island University would like to think of itself as a Brooklyn institution. Its sports teams are called the Brooklyn Blackbirds. Its mens basketball team, which has qualified for the N.C.A.A. tournament three years in a row, once played in the former Brooklyn Paramount Theater. It sits across the street from Juniors, of cheesecake fame.

title: Lets Give Birds the Respect They Deserve
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Crackdown on an Outspoken Professor
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Operas Endowment
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick, Quiet Robbery Nets $60,000 at a Whole Foods
description: Past the colorful arrays of pumpkins and artisanal cheese, up the stairs and down the vitamin aisle, a gunman and his accomplice stalked through a Whole Foods in Lower Manhattan on Sunday night.

title: Struggling Newspapers Sell Off Old Headquarters
description: They were once major symbols of civic pride and influence, often situated in the heart of the city, and nearly equal in stature to nearby city halls, courthouses and other major public buildings.

title: Paul Dickstein, Kochs Budget Chief in New York City, Dies at 70
description: Paul Dickstein, a New York City budget czar who enforced stern fiscal discipline even  perhaps especially  in times of surplus during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: As Drug Costs Rise, Bending the Law Is One Remedy
description: Lee Higman, a 71-year-old artist from Bellevue, Idaho, who considers herself a law-abiding citizen, was shocked last month when she got a notice from the Food and Drug Administration telling her: A mail shipment addressed to you from a foreign country is being held.

title: Manhattans Vanishing Gas Stations
description: Perhaps there is no clearer sign that Manhattan space has reached a high premium than the continuing disappearance of gasoline stations at main intersections.

title: Anticipating His Next Play, McCarver Is Closing Out an Era
description: Tim McCarver will call the 24th World Series of his career, and probably his last, beginning Wednesday. At 72, he is retiring from Fox, where he has been one of the top analysts in the game. Although he has not ruled out a future role in baseball broadcasting, McCarver says he will, for now, pursue his passions for wine and cooking.

title: Future of Farming
description: Mark Bittman speaks to Wes Jackson from The Land Institute, who predicted that a prairie-like system capable of providing food for humans would be viable within 100 years.

title: Now This Is Natural Food
description: A few weeks ago at the annual Prairie Festival in Salina, Kan.  a celebration, essentially, of true sustainability  I sat down with Wes Jackson to drink rich beer and eat delicious, chewy bread made from the perennial grain Kernza. The Kernza we ate was cultivated at the Land Institute, the festivals sponsor and the organization Jackson founded here 37 years ago.

title: Bid to Move Atlanta Statue Opens Window to Past
description: ATLANTA  The description that accompanied an executive order by Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia this month was a mundane one: authorizing the relocation of a statue.

title: Egyptians Abandoning Hope and Now, Reluctantly, Homeland
description: CAIRO  In his years as a dissident, the book publisher had taken on Egypts autocratic government and its censors, aided revolutionaries during the uprising and protested in the streets to protect freedoms he thought he had helped the country win.

title: Shutdown Will Hinder True Gauge of U.S. Economy
description: Like a driver with a broken speedometer, economists are being forced to come up with new ways to gauge the economys strength as the aftereffects of the government shutdown distort the usual metrics.

title: Florida Officials Reveal 5 Earlier Prison Escape Attempts Using Forged Documents
description: MIAMI  Florida law enforcement officials, already embarrassed by the revelation that two convicted killers were released from a state prison after forging documents that allowed them to walk free, acknowledged Tuesday that they had discovered at least five previous instances of such forgeries.

title: Roma Abduction Case Prompts Birth Certificate Review in Greece
description: ATHENS  A powerful Greek prosecutor ordered an emergency nationwide investigation on Tuesday into birth certificates issued over the past six years, after a Roma couple were jailed on accusations of abducting a child found at a camp in central Greece.

title: At 219-Year-Old Building, a Reopening Takes Time
description: Ask Adam Weprin why it has taken so long to reopen the Bridge Cafe  the ancient, the venerable, the legendary, hurricane-drowned restaurant  and he pulls out a calendar.

title: Koch Brother Wages 12-Year Fight Over Wind Farm
description: OSTERVILLE, Mass.  If the vast wind farm proposed for Nantucket Sound is ever built, William I. Koch will have a spectacular view of it.

title: New Leaks, New Repercussions
description: Stunning new details continue to emerge from Edward Snowdens leaks about the vast electronic data mining carried out by the National Security Agency, setting off one diplomatic aftershock after another.

title: Tom Suozzi for Nassau County
description: The race for Nassau County executive is one of the most important election battles in the New York region this year. The Democrat, Tom Suozzi, is trying to retake the seat from Edward Mangano, the Republican incumbent who won it four years ago by a mere 386 votes.

title: Intellectual Disability and the Death Penalty
description: Eleven years ago, the Supreme Court banned the execution of intellectually disabled people in Atkins v. Virginia. Ever since, some states have worked to circumvent that ruling by defining intellectual disability using unscientific standards or by making it nearly impossible to prove. On Monday, the justices indicated that they may at last be ready to clarify the Atkins decision by agreeing to consider whether a Florida law defines intellectual disability too narrowly.

title: The United States, Falling Behind
description: Researchers have been warning for more than a decade that the United States was losing ground to its economic competitors abroad and would eventually fall behind them unless it provided more of its citizens with the high-level math, science and literacy skills necessary for the new economy.

title: Star Characters, Spun Anew, May Live Well More Than Twice
description: William Boyds new James Bond book, Solo, takes Britains best-known spy to the war-ravaged jungles of West Africa and the insalubrious streets of 1960s Washington, with interludes of sex, drinking, the suggestion of homoerotic torture and other familiar Bondian amusements. But in writing nearly 50 years after the death of Bonds creator, Ian Fleming, Mr. Boyd faced some contemporary dangers.

title: U.S. Asserts Terror Suspect Has Implicated Himself
description: A federal prosecutor in Manhattan told a judge on Tuesday that a Libyan man brought to the United States for prosecution on conspiracy charges after being held in military custody aboard a Navy ship made an incriminating statement to the authorities after being advised of his Miranda rights.

title: Sebelius Thrust Into Firestorm on Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  The first, and perhaps most painful, call for Kathleen Sebelius to resign as President Obamas health secretary came this month from an old family friend: Senator Pat Roberts, Republican of Kansas, who once boasted of a special relationship with Ms. Sebelius, forged when he worked for her father-in-law.

title: Harlem River, Cut Off From Public, Is Getting a Push Out of Isolation
description: One by one, the rivers around Manhattan have emerged from decades of industrial abuse. The Hudson River has its five-mile ribbon of parkland and active kayaking community; the Bronx River, the occasional beaver sighting; and the East River, a popular ferry service  all contributing to the sense that New York is, in fact, a river city.

title: Bostons Victorino Leans In, Gets Bruised and Gets on Base
description: BOSTON  Red Sox Manager John Farrell sat in the interview room in Detroits Comerica Park last week and explained why Shane Victorino had been hit by so many pitches, 24 in all. Victorino had been crowding the plate, Farrell said, ever since he stopped switch-hitting and started batting right-handed full time in August.

title: Lottery Numbers for Oct. 22, 2013
If Police Encounters Were Filmed
Trade for Beason Seemed Minor, but the Giants Get Big Results
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants sent a late-round draft pick to the Carolina Panthers for middle linebacker Jon Beason earlier this month, it hardly seemed like a significant transaction. While the Giants had not made an in-season trade since 1986, they had installed a revolving door at linebacker.

title: Corrections: October 23, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Doubleheader
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  How meta: games within a game. Solving this puzzle took me back to my childhood, and that of my kids, because the classic boardgames are always the most fun, arent they?

title: Family as a Hall of Mirrors
description: At moments during Fun Home, the beautiful heartbreaker of a musical that opened on Tuesday night at the Public Theater, you may feel youve developed quadruple vision, and not just because your eyes are misted with tears. Its also a matter of those three actresses playing the same character at different ages, a device that usually feels strained in theater, but here comes off as naturally as breathing.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 23, 2013
description: I wont postpone happiness until I die.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate
description: RECENT SALE

title: Four People Charged in Brawl at Jets and Patriots Game
description: Four people were charged with assault on Tuesday, two days after a brawl in which a male New York Jets fan hit a female New England Patriots fan in the face on the concourse at MetLife Stadium.

title: Sleeping in Opponents Shorts? Chicken Before Games? Terry Has Rituals
description: Regimented rules dictate Jason Terrys basketball life. One would strain to call them rational.

title: Russia Putting a Strong Arm on Neighbors
description: CHISINAU, Moldova  It was not enough for Dmitri O. Rogozin, a deputy prime minister of Russia, to warn darkly that it would be a grave mistake for Moldova to seek closer ties with Europe.

title: Wainwright Sees Beltran in Pinstripes, and Then Wakes Up
description: BOSTON  Adam Wainwright woke up sweating last week, terrified by a bad dream: his Cardinals had lost the National League Championship Series and had failed to get Carlos Beltran to his first World Series. Beltran then signed with the Yankees, won the pennant and sat on a podium saying, Im so happy to be a Yankee and in the World Series.

title: Ronald Shannon Jackson, Composer and Avant-Garde Drummer, Dies at 73
description: Ronald Shannon Jackson, an avant-garde drummer and composer who led an influential electric band and performed with many of the greatest names in jazz, died on Saturday at his home in Fort Worth. He was 73.

title: A Rematch Red All Over (Except the Green Monster)
description: BOSTON  John Axford had been with the St. Louis Cardinals only a few weeks before they clinched a playoff spot. Axford, a veteran reliever, decided then that it was time to learn more about his new team. He searched YouTube and found old World Series clips, including Bob Gibson closing out the Boston Red Sox here in 1967.

title: In a Harvest, Palestinians Cast a Light on Hardship
description: BURIN, West Bank  For most of his 58 years, Ahmad Najar has picked olives each autumn with his family, the women and girls cooking a hot meal in the fields as the men and boys topped ladders to fell the black and green fruit onto large tarps. On Tuesday, Mr. Najar earned about $21 for nine hours harvesting a neighbors grove, part of a new program that pays Palestinians whose trees have been destroyed by Jewish settlers to help farmers whose access to the land is limited to a few days by the Israeli authorities.

title: Greece Suspends State Financing for Far-Right Party
description: ATHENS  Greeces Parliament voted early Wednesday to suspend state financing for political parties whose leaders or elected officials are charged with serious crimes, part of a continuing effort to rein in the neo-fascist Golden Dawn, which is under investigation on charges involving murder, blackmail and other offenses.

title: Canucks Beat Isles, but Tortorella Has Other Reasons to Smile
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  John Tortorella called the game a mess, but he was in a cheerful mood on Tuesday after his first visit to the New York area since being fired last spring by the Rangers.

title: 16 Candidates Disqualified in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  More than half of the Afghan presidential hopefuls had their hopes dashed on Tuesday when the countrys election commission declared that their candidacies did not meet documentary or citizenship requirements.

title: Lhota, in Acrid Second Debate, Turns Up the Heat on de Blasio
description: His mayoral ambitions slipping away, Joseph J. Lhota shed his sleepy style to unleash a ferocious attack against Bill de Blasio on Tuesday night in an acrid debate that descended into a free-for-all of interruptions, name-calling and indignant lecturing.

title: Mets Harvey Has Tommy John Surgery
description: Matt Harvey had successful Tommy John surgery to repair a partial tear of the ulnar collateral ligament in his pitching elbow. Dr. James Andrews performed the operation in Gulf Breeze, Fla.

title: Chinese Newspaper Asks Police to Free Detained Reporter
description: Updated, 3:19 a.m. EST| A newspaper based in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou has published a bold, front-page appeal for the release of a detained reporter, prompting an outpouring of support online and sympathetic statements from prominent media and business figures.

title: Obamas Uncertain Path Amid Syria Bloodshed
description: WASHINGTON  With rebel forces in Syria in retreat and the Obama administrations policy toward the war-ravaged country in disarray, Secretary of State John Kerry arrived at the White House Situation Room one day in June with a document bearing a warning. President Bashar al-Assad of Syria had used chemical weapons against his people, the document said, and if the United States did not impose consequences, Mr. Assad would see it as a green light for continued CW use.

title: Bill de Blasio and the New Urban Populism
description: In an era of Clintonesque caution, when Democrats typically mute any expression of their leftward leanings, Bill de Blasio, who will almost certainly be elected mayor of New York City two weeks from now, does not concede an inch to the right.

title: Iran: Man Who Survived Hanging Might Not Be Hanged Again
description: The judicial authorities suggested they might not rehang a convicted drug felon who survived the first attempt to hang him and who has been convalescing in a hospital pending a second execution attempt. The semiofficial ISNA news agency quoted the justice minister, Mostafa Pur-Mohammadi, as saying, I do not think there is any need for a rehanging of the convict, although he said he would defer to the courts. The condemned man, identified only as Alireza M., 37, a father of two, was left for dead in the morgue this month after he had swung in a prison gallows for 12 minutes. His survival attracted worldwide attention and focused scrutiny on Irans heavy use of the death penalty.

title: France: U.S. Wiretapped Envoys, Newspaper Reports, Citing Leaks
description: The National Security Agency wiretapped the offices of the French mission to the United Nations and the French Embassy in Washington, according to an article published Tuesday in the French newspaper Le Monde. The disclosure, as well as similar material published in the German magazine Der Spiegel in September, was based on secret documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, a former N.S.A. contractor. Both reports cited documents from September 2010 that showed that the Americans had singled out French diplomats for surveillance while they were working in the United States. The article in Le Monde quoted an internal communications from Susan E. Rice, then the American ambassador to the United Nations, saying that the intelligence on how the French were forming their position on Iran, in particular, was helpful in keeping the United States one step ahead in the negotiations.

title: Deferral Sought for Kenya Trials
description: The African Union submitted a formal request to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday to defer, for at least a year, the trials of Kenyas president and deputy president in the International Criminal Court at The Hague in order to allow them to deal with the aftermath of last months deadly terrorist attack at the Westgate mall in Nairobi.
