The African Union said the attack showed that Kenya is a front-line state in the fight against terrorism and that the trials would prevent President Uhuru Kenyatta and his deputy, William Ruto, from fulfilling their constitutional responsibilities. Both are accused of crimes against humanity related to violence that roiled Kenya after disputed 2007 elections.

title: Rancor in Second Mayoral Debate
description: The second televised debate between Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio saw more acrimonious exchanges than in the first encounter. Mr. de Blasio was more defensive, but there were no killer blows.

title: Impossibly Light, Totally Sleek Handmade Bikes Built by a Tokyo Shipwright
description: Sueshiro Sano, a ninth-generation shipwright, makes lightweight, bespoke wooden bicycles in his Tokyo workshop. His bikes, which take three months to assemble and can cost up to $20,000, use Honduras mahogany and are custom built for a 100-percent tailored fit. Theyre also impossibly light  a result of Sanos well-honed boat-building methods  and have become objects of worship, and in some cases, derision, for hipsters and bike experts everywhere. Case in point: at a handmade-bike convention in Denver earlier this year, several incredulous participants accused Sano of using carbon fiber in his designs. (He doesnt.) But Sano, who built his first boat at 13 and subscribes to the Japanese principle of monozukuri (making things), shrugs off such accusations. For me, its about pride, he says. 011-81-3-5569-6567.

title: The Power of the Individual Mandate
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Annual Rise in Cost of Public College Slows
description: Tuition and fees at public universities increased less than 3 percent this academic year, the smallest rise in three decades, according to the annual College Board reports on trends in pricing and aid.

title: How Music Can Boost Our Workouts
description: Making music  and not just listening to it  while exercising makes the exercise easier, a remarkable new experiment finds, suggesting that the human love of music may have evolved, in part, to ease physical effort.

title: Word of the Day | libel
description: libel \li-bl\ noun and verb

title: Filing Ties Slain Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect to 2011 Case
description: BOSTON  A government court filing links the deceased suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, to a triple murder in Waltham, Mass., in September 2011, attributing the information to his now-dead friend.

title: Scientists Ties to Food Industry Raise Questions in Europe
description: LONDON  One scientist who advised Europes food safety regulators about animal feed additives sits on the board of a foundation backed by the dairy industry.

title: Big Lead Aside, de Blasio Holds Less Tightly to Line
description: Bill de Blasio, the toast of Haute Liberal New York, is on quite the golden roll. He attends tte--ttes with titans and was feted by a former secretary of state at a million-dollar fund-raising gala on Monday.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (Sundance) LAUREL CANYON (2003) Jane (Frances McDormand, above), an aging, hard-partying Los Angeles record producer, opens her California dwelling to her snobbish son (Christian Bale) and his fiance (Kate Beckinsale), both Harvard Medical School graduates. Alessandro Nivola plays the lead singer of the rock band whose album is being overseen by Jane, who has a history of sleeping with the musicians she produces. This situation is no exception, and soon the entire family is led into temptation. Having set up its domestic conflicts, the movie doesnt know exactly where to go or how far, but when the inevitable emotional explosions erupt, the mutual recriminations carry a sharp sting, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this film, written and directed by Lisa Cholodenko, who said she was partly inspired by Joni Mitchells album Ladies of the Canyon.

title: News Quiz | October 23, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: India-Pakistan Hostility Kills Trade on Kashmir Border
description: On Oct. 21, 2008, a caravan of trucks decorated with garlands crossed a tiny bridge over a stream in Kashmir and made history. Aman Setu, or Peace Bridge, is on the Line of Control, the volatile, disputed border dividing the Indian and Pakistani-controlled parts of Kashmir. The last time a civilian vehicle had crossed that bridge was before India and Pakistan fought their first war over Kashmir in October 1947, before the lines of control were drawn.

title: E.C.B. Vows Thorough Review of Banks at Risk
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Wednesday outlined the parameters for a wide-ranging review of commercial banks that is designed to expose and fix any problems and ultimately allow credit to begin flowing normally again, a prerequisite for faster economic growth.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 23, 2013
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Creating Animated GIFs From Sports Absurdities
description: In Maker of Animated GIFs Waits for Offbeat Moments, Sarah Lyall writes about Tim Burke, an editor at Deadspin, who monitors several sports events to catch unusual moments, which he captures as images, video or animated clips.

title: Do Not Fear a Beet Without Goat Cheese
description: A dozen less familiar recipes for the notorious root.

title: Could New York City Subways Survive Another Hurricane?
description: A good place to see how and why the Metropolitan Transportation Authority just barely survived Sandy last fall is the entrance to a tunnel at 148th Street and Lenox Avenue, in Central Harlem, where, just before the storm hit, a crew of carpenters built a plywood dam 8 feet tall by about 55 feet wide. That ad hoc, low-tech, last-minute construction held the New York Harbor at bay and not only saved the city hundreds of millions of dollars, but also made it possible for the subway to come back to life as quickly as it did.

title: Street Art From the South Bronx to Soweto
description: Who suspected royalty lurked in East New York back in the 1970s? Certainly not Martha Cooper, then a photographer for The New York Post, when she befriended a young graffiti artist who tagged HE3 on the walls of the Lower East Side.

title: Why Do We Take Selfies?
description: How often do you take selfies  pictures of yourself, with your cellphone camera  and send them to someone, or post them on social media? What kind do you take, and what reactions do you usually get? Why do you think there has been such an increase in this kind of picture-taking in recent years?

title: New York Today: When Cold Cases Heat Up
description: Updated 12:02 p.m. | How does it feel to close a 22-year-old murder?

title: The Conservative Who Hates Slush Funds
description: A new book, sure to wind up on the nightstands of all campaign finance geeks, documents the many ways in which a torrent of cash is corrupting members of Congress and providing benefits for the wealthy. The issue cannot get enough publicity, but the best news of all is that the book was written by a conservative.

title: The Faces of Balthazar
description: One of the more striking things about Balthazar, which I wrote about in this past Sundays Food & Drink issue, is how many workers have stayed there for several years. For waiters, it makes perfect sense  this is among the best service jobs you can find in New York because the tips are so good. (One server I spoke to is an architect who works only part time at his craft, because he makes more money at the restaurant.) But the management earns no tips, and neither does the back-of-house  still, those employees come in and peel potatoes, tenderize steaks, make stocks and generally make the place function. Below are portraits by Marvin Orellana of some of the people who have served Balthazar the longest, behind the scenes. (And one of a busboy, widely rumored to be a real estate magnate.)

title: Life With Boko Haram
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  In December 2010, Nigeria experienced its first wave of terrorist bombings at Christian churches. In 2011, we had our first-ever suicide car bombing, at the United Nations headquarters here. The explosion rattled my nearby office building. Flinging myself on the floor, I assumed it was an earthquake. A bomb was still the last thing on my mind.

title: Daily Report: Apple Challenges Microsoft, Offering Free Apps
description: At an event in San Francisco meant to feature its latest iPad tablet computing devices, Apple took aim on Tuesday at one of the biggest and seemingly unassailable businesses of its rival Microsoft, its Office software for tasks like word processing and spreadsheets, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: Trying to Explain Complicated Ideas Online
description: Conventional wisdom suggests that a Web site has 10 seconds to convince a visitor to stay. That makes things especially difficult for businesses that hope to convey complicated thoughts through their sites.

title: Spain Emerges From Two-Year Recession
description: MADRID  Spain pulled out of a two-year recession in the third quarter, with its economy growing 0.1 percent from the previous quarter, according to preliminary data released Wednesday by the Spanish central bank.

title: America's Latest Foreign Adventure
description: PARIS  When people ask what Im working on these days, I tell them about my new book, How French People Take Out the Garbage. Its all about the elegant, common-sense Gallic approach to trash, which I, of course, refer to as les poubelles.

title: Gambling With Civilization
description: The 50th anniversary issue of the New York Review of Books is out. My review of Bill Nordhaus is one of the pieces.

title: Anger Growing Among Allies on U.S. Spying
description: BERLIN  The diplomatic fallout from the documents harvested by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden intensified on Wednesday, with one of the United States closest allies, Germany, announcing that its leader had angrily called President Obama seeking reassurance that her cellphone was not the target of an American intelligence tap.

title: Don't Arm Thy Neighbor
description: SAN JOS, Costa Rica  I am not one of those who believe the United States days of world leadership are behind us. All my life I have been an admirer of our northern neighbor. I believe its strengths  its democracy, its founders wisdom, its peoples ingenuity and diversity  give it unique authority in the world. But many of its citizens and their leaders seem to take such authority for granted now, as if it were American property. The truth is, it must be earned, and today the United States is passing up opportunities to earn it.

title: 2 Commercial Property Giants to Combine in $7.2 Billion Deal
description: Updated, 10:01 a.m. | American Realty Capital Properties and Cole Real Estate Investments, two of the largest commercial property owners in the country, are finally seeing eye to eye.

title: Carrie, Love Your Work!
description: How the years fly! Only four decades ago, Carrie White was a misunderstood 17-year-old, flinging her mother across the room, dousing her mean schoolmates with blood. Now she is a successful entrepreneur of 55, with yet another box office hit about her life. Her business ventures over the years have been many: interior designer (conflict-of-interest disclosure, I once hired Carrie to move the furniture around my house); crane operator; transplant surgeon (The sight of a donor heart hovering over the operating table, which can be found on YouTube, is mesmerizing).

title: Turkey Adrift
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys announcement last month that it would buy a long-range defense system from a Chinese company is the latest sign that Ankaras attempts to strike an independent foreign policy have gone wrong.

title: Thanks for Your Great Driving
description: Dear Diary:

title: 2 Real Estate Firms to Join Forces
description: Two real estate investment trusts  American Realty Capital Properties and Cole Real Estate Investments  agreed to a $7.2 billion deal on Wednesday in which American Realty will buy Cole with a mix of cash and stock, bringing an end to tensions between the companies that have simmered much of the last year. Under the terms of the deal, Cole stockholders can choose either 1.0929 shares of American Realty stock, valued at $14.59, or $13.82 cash for each Cole share.

title: T LUXURY
description: If youre lucky enough to have some, let them make a brilliant statement against stark black and white dresses.

title: Advice About Assisted Living for Aging Relatives, Part 2
description: Readers have sent more than 100  questions and suggestions to Debra Drelich, a specialist in geriatric care, about assisted living and other special living arrangements for aging relatives. Part 1 of her answers can be read here.

title: Objects | Diamonds Are for Now
description: If youre lucky enough to have some, let them make a brilliant statement against stark black and white dresses.

title: Social TV Ads (Sort of) Come to Facebook
description: As Facebook and Twitter duke it out to be the town square for people nattering about their favorite television shows, Twitter has had a big advantage on the advertising side: it offers an ad targeting option that can help brands hit the same viewer twice, once on TV and once on Twitter.

title: Chemical Giant to Close Scottish Plant After Talks Fail
description: LONDON  One of the largest manufacturing plants in Scotland will be closed with the loss of hundreds of jobs, the chemical giant Ineos said on Wednesday, after employees there declined to accept an ownership plan involving pension and job cuts.

title: Muzaffarnagar Gang Rape Cases Languish in Police Files
description: NEW DELHI About a month after the first report of a gang rape was registered in the Muzaffarnagar district of Uttar Pradesh, the police acknowledged they have yet to question anyone named in the six gang rape complaints filed in the aftermath of last months sectarian riots.

title: Boeing Outlines Progress on 787s and Raises Forecast
description: Boeings chief executive said on Wednesday that the company was pushing hard to fix reliability problems with its early 787 Dreamliners that have frustrated several airlines.

title: One, Two, Three, Boo!
description: Theres so much thats predictable in the structure of counting books; even preschoolers can enjoy anticipating the numbers ascent or descent. But that format still leaves a lot of room for surprises. Ghost in the House, by Ammi-Joan Paquette, with illustrations by Adam Record, and Ten Orange Pumpkins, written and illustrated by Stephen Savage, bring the fun to spooky tales of ghosts, witches and mummies.

title: The Gun Report: October 23, 2013
description: In January, 13-year-old Michael Graham killed himself with his fathers gun at his home in Brewster, N.Y. On October 14, his mother, Sheila Kearney Graham, overdosed on pain medication. She was 52. Yesterday would have been Michaels 14th birthday.

title: Inside the Sugar Factory
description: Artifacts, and sugar, are everywhere in the Domino refinery, which has been shuttered since 2004.

title: Relics of the Domino Sugar Refinery, Frozen in Time and Syrup
description: They called it refined sugar. The process was anything but.

title: Vatican Suspends German Bishop Accused of Lavish Spending on Himself
description: BERLIN  Pope Francis, who has made humility and modesty his hallmarks, sent a swift and clear message to Roman Catholics around the world on Wednesday, suspending a German bishop accused of spending millions on lavish renovations to his residence and forcing the chief administrator of the bishops diocese into early retirement.

title: Rabobank Nears Settlement on Interest Rate Inquiry
description: LONDON  The Dutch lender Rabobank said on Wednesday that it was close to reaching settlements with American, British and other authorities over its role in setting global benchmark interest rates.

title: Criticism of United States Mideast Policy Increasingly Comes From Allies
description: ROME  As the United States grapples with some of the most intractable problems in the Middle East, it has run into a buzz saw of criticism, not from traditional enemies but from two of its strongest allies.

title: 1968: Black Power Protest at the Olympics
description: The black-gloved fists of the athletes Tommie Smith and John Carlos rose above the fold of the International Herald Tribunes edition of October 18, 1968, as the newspaper covered one of the most iconic statements in the history of the civil rights movement.

title: When the Listening Trumps the Tale
description: In Lower Manhattan, Foley Square is humming with potential tales. Lawyers are entering the courthouses nearby, federal workers are finishing up lunch on the park benches, commuters are catching the 6 p.m. train. Mundane? Perhaps, but to Dave Isay and the organization he founded, StoryCorps, each one of these lives could make for a fascinating story.

title: Laid to Rest in the Front Yard
description: James Davis has been involved in a dispute with the town of Stevenson, Ala., for burying his wife on his property.

title: 10 New York Stories That Might Make You Laugh, or Cry
description: It used to be a common sight near the Lexington Avenue passageway of Grand Central Terminal: a couple emerging from a back-lit booth, wiping away tears from reddened eyes, before collecting themselves and reluctantly rejoining the masses.

title: In Flipped Classrooms, a Method for Mastery
description: In traditional schooling, time is a constant and understanding is a variable. A fifth-grade class will spend a set number of days on prime factorization and then move on to study greatest common factors  whether or not every student is ready.

title: Homes in Warsaw
description: Polands market boom started in 2004, when the country joined the European Union, and ended in 2009, after the American mortgage crisis.

title: House Hunting in ...Warsaw
description: A CONTEMPORARY HOUSE IN WARSAW

title: In Our Pages: October 24
description: 1888 Uncle Sams Ledger

title: White House Official on National Security Is Fired After Twitter Posts Are Unmasked
description: WASHINGTON  In his day job at the White House, Jofi Joseph was known as a generally collegial guy, a junior but experienced staff member working on some of the nations most serious business  specifically arms proliferation, and especially involving Iran.

title: A Hotel Chain Drops Pornography Channels
description: Pornography is off the pay-per-view menu at all 171 Nordic Choice Hotels, Scandinavias largest hotel group. In a statement, Petter Storalen, owner of Nordic Choice, said the decision was prompted by the companys charity work with Unicef to combat child trafficking and sexual exploitation.

title: A Moot Effort to Burnish the Reputation of Goldman Sachs
description: I hate to be the bearer of good news for Jamie Dimon, but everything is going to work out O.K.

title: Today in Small Business: Why Loans Are So Hard to Get
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: At 24-0, Ace Is an Inspiration in Japans Series
description: Unless the typhoon season disrupts the schedule of the Nippon Series, Masahiro Tanaka will take the ball for the Pacific Leagues Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles in Game 1 on Saturday night, looking to continue one of the most remarkable runs by a pitcher in professional baseball, and doing it in a region desperate for positive events in the years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami.

title: Image of the Day: October 23
Whatever Happened to Freedom of the Press?
description: Stung by criticism of the Obama administrations heavy-handed tactics in dealing with the media, Attorney General Eric Holder announced new guidelines in July for protecting reporters from overly zealous prosecutors. He advertised the guidelines as a better way of shielding reporters in federal leak investigations, which sounded promising. But if he cares about this problem at all, Mr. Holder should now withdraw his demand that James Risen of The New York Times reveal a source for his 2006 book on the C.I.A.

title: Damage Control at the Hirshhorn
description: The new exhibition, opening Thursday at the Smithsonians Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, is built around works that document destruction.

title: Arranging an Encore in Manhattan
description: Jim Stake and Liam Harvey, partners in business and in life, live in a four-story lakeside town-house condominium with 2,600 square feet of space in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Bang! Kaboom! Art!
description: WASHINGTON  The rubble from a concert in which a piano gets smashed; a sculpture that slowly pushes apart its gallery; a drawing by a modern master completely erased by a rival  all are masterworks from a neglected trend in which artists have been more into breaking than making. Damage Control: Art and Destruction Since 1950, a show that opens on Thursday at the Smithsonians Hirshhorn Museum here, is built around such harm-full works.

title: Gliding High: Designing Paper Airplanes Based on the Physics of Flight
description: Overview | How do gliders fly? In this lesson, students design, build, test and modify paper airplanes based on the physics of flight and inspired by a Times article about the Perlan Project. Then, they test their planes in a contest and evaluate the forces of flight behind each design.

title: Fracking Fight Focuses on a New York Towns Ban
description: DRYDEN, N.Y.  This town in the Finger Lakes region is not the kind of place where one would expect a grass-roots uprising. Even its promotional brochure makes it sound sleepy, listing the main attractions as a few large dairy farms, some crop farms and several horse ranches.

title: A Business Owner Who Backed Off Tries to Step Back In
description: PARTIES THAT COOK is a 14-year-old event business founded in San Francisco by Bibby Gignilliat, a former marketing manager at Williams-Sonoma who followed her muse  first by going to cooking school and then by starting a business that offers cooking classes as employee-appreciation and corporate team-building events. It now handles events for as many as 300 in San Francisco as well as in Chicago, Seattle and Portland, Ore., where it maintains satellite offices. The company employs 11 full-time workers at its headquarters, and about 65 chefs, servers and dishwashers on a contract basis. Last year, revenue reached $2.2 million.

title: European Parliament Rejects New Subsidies for Fishing Fleets
description: PARIS  The European Parliament voted Wednesday to reject most new subsidies for the saltwater fishing industry and provide financial support for new ecologically friendly measures meant to prevent overfishing. But in a nod to commercial fishing fleets, the lawmakers did maintain some handouts to the industry.

title: Call It the Theater of Contrition
description: In the years since his affair with Monica Lewinsky, has Bill Clinton struggled to remain faithful to Hillary Rodham Clinton? Did Eliot Spitzer turn to a prostitute because his marriage to Silda Wall Spitzer had lost its spark? What need was Anthony Weiner satisfying when he sent explicit photos to female admirers and humiliated his wife, Huma Abedin?

title: How Does an Owner Who Stepped Away Reassert Control?
description: We just published a case study about the chief executive of an event company based in San Francisco who is in the process of reasserting control of her business. Several years ago, approaching her 50th birthday, Bibby Gignilliat, the founder of Parties That Cook, a company that offers cooking classes as employee-appreciation and corporate-team-building events, realized that she needed to resuscitate her long-ignored private life.

title: Showtime Renews Homeland and Masters of Sex
description: Showtime announced Tuesday that it was renewing its biggest current hit, Homeland, for a fourth season, as well as the new drama Masters of Sex for a second season.

title: Nissan and Suzuki Issue Recalls for Braking Problems
description: Brake problems have prompted Nissan to recall about 153,000 sport utility vehicles from the 2013-14 model years and Suzuki to recall 210,000 motorcycles, the manufacturers have informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Caterpillars Stock Drops, and 2 Big Deals May Be to Blame
description: Two of Caterpillars biggest-ever deals may have played a role in the $3 billion of market value that the companys stock shed on Wednesday morning.

title: Homes for $1,250,000
description: A federal-style house in Minneapolis; a Tudor in Denver; and a 19th-century brownstone condo in Boston.

title: What You Get for ... $1,250,000
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: Our Last Name Meant Bad Luck. So We Changed It.
description: What is your name? the judge asked my 3-year-old daughter who sat quietly, her feet dangling from her chair. She looked up, her big brown eyes barely visible over the imposing wood table in front of the judges bench. Go ahead and say your name, I said, shifting in the seat next to her, trying to fit my pregnant belly below the table. Lena, she answered almost inaudibly. I glanced at my husband, Russ, and wondered if he, too, thought this judicial inquisition was going to scar her for life.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Red Sox Take Game 1 From Bumbling Cardinals
description: BOSTON  Errors, missed pop-ups and fat pitches hardly seemed like the Cardinal Way. The St. Louis Cardinals had stormed into the World Series while priding themselves on their ideal of professionalism and strong fundamentals.

title: Feeding Fliers With Local Fare
description: Wolfgang Puck now has company: a number of airports across the country are opening restaurants from high-profile hometown chefs, offering local flavor to fliers.

title: Food Matters | For L.A.s Thoughtful Young Eaters, a New Breed of Catering Company
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: T-Mobile US Tries to Lure Tablet Customers With Some Free Data
description: T-Mobile US, one of the largest American mobile carriers, says it wants to change the way people use tablets. The carrier on Wednesday said it would give customers a small amount of free cellular data to use on their tablets each month.

title: Looking for a Bus or Train? New Sites Aim to Help
description: IF YOU WANT to search a single Web site for fares across multiple airlines, there are plenty of options  Priceline, Orbitz, Expedia  that allow you to do just that. But the same cannot be said if youre planning to travel long distance by bus or train. Typically you have to know the name of the company you plan to use and make a reservation through its Web site.

title: Hotel Review: Copacabana Palace in Rio de Janeiro
description: Rates

title: After Theres a Kid With a Gun Came Teacher Down
description: In a trembling voice, the student called 911 to ask for help as a shooting unfolded at a Nevada elementary school this week. The student said: This is a student from Sparks Middle School. Can you please send police out here? There is a kid with a gun.

title: Longing for the Wow at Apples Product Showcases
description: Apples much-hyped product demonstrations used to end with an emphatic wow!

title: The Simpsons: Springfield to Brazil
description: Doh. Homer Simpson a referee at next years World Cup?

title: Glaxo Sales Fall in China as Inquiry Continues
description: The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline reported Wednesday that its third-quarter earnings were badly battered by slumping product sales in China, a country where it faces a continuing bribery investigation.

title: Wheelies: The Heres Looking at You Kid Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Alan S. Blinder on Janet Yellen
description: Alan S. Blinder, an economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, talks about Janet Yellens handling of policy disagreements at the Fed.

title: Russia Reduces Charges in Greenpeace Case
description: MOSCOW  Russian investigators on Wednesday dropped piracy charges against the crew members of a Greenpeace International ship who staged a protest against oil exploration in the Arctic Ocean last month, but said they would still face lesser charges of hooliganism.

title: New York Public Library Postpones Release of Revised Renovation Plan
description: The New York Public Library will not release revised plans for its 42nd Street flagship renovation  or independent cost estimates of alternative options  this fall as expected, the library said on Wednesday.

title: Boston and St. Louis Orchestra Musicians Play Up the World Series
description: A World Series just isnt a World Series if there isnt a certain amount of trash-talking between the two teams supporters, but the world of high culture used to stand apart from it all.

title: 8 Questions for 3 Buffetts
description: Warren E. Buffetts son Howard Graham Buffett and his grandson Howard Warren Buffett have written a new book, Forty Chances: Finding Hope in a Hungry World, which chronicles their philanthropic work on hunger, farming and poverty around the world. This is an edited transcript of a discussion with Warren Buffett, his son and grandson.

title: An Afghan Interpreter Seeks a Visa That Is Unlikely to Come
description: Recently, a photo of a young Afghan man lying in a position that would usually be described as face down in the dirt was posted on the Facebook page for applicants to a special American visa program. In this case, however, the man in the photograph couldnt be described that way because his head had been cut off and placed on the small of his back so that his lifeless eyes stared at the camera. He had been an interpreter for United States Marines advising the Afghan Border Police in 2010, which is presumably why insurgents made an example of him. I dont know his story, but I can tell you Amins.

title: Theater Will Ignore NC-17 Rating for Blue Is the Warmest Color
description: Abdellatif Kechiches Blue Is the Warmest Color, which won the Palme dOr in Cannes earlier this year, has received a lot of attention  some salacious, some censorious  for its extended and explicit lesbian sex scenes. The film, about a French teenagers relationship with a slightly older woman, is opening in New York and Los Angeles on Friday (and in other cities soon after) with an unsurprising NC-17 rating.

title: Tea Party Group Begins Anti-Health Care Law Blitz in Four House Districts
description: WASHINGTON  Americans for Prosperity, the Tea Party group that has made rolling back the health care law one of its priorities, is starting a $2 million campaign of television, radio and Internet advertisements aimed at lawmakers facing tough re-election battles in four House swing districts.

title: Lobbying Heats Up Before Farm Talks
description: WASHINGTON  As the House and Senate prepare to meet next week to work out differences in their farm bills, lobbying efforts are intensifying to get last-minute changes to the 1,000-page legislation that sets the nations farm and nutrition policies.

title: Among the Ruins, Education Is Also Lost
description: Children in Haiti are languishing in camps or working in menial jobs because thousands of schools in and around the devastated capital of the country could remain closed for months or never reopen.

title: No Comment Necessary: Fight Nukes With Nukes
description: Via Philip Weiss

title: Keeping Score: Statistics to Watch at the World Series
description: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championships characteristics in our book, Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method. In particular, our work relates key statistical factors to concepts of sports psychology like leadership, consistency and minimizing errors. Based on this research, we focused on factors that might help predict the winner of the World Series between the Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals, which begins Wednesday night.

title: Scene City: Fashion Stars Take a Bow
description: Miley Cyrus, Marc Jacobs and Aretha Franklin celebrate Fashion Group Internationals 30th annual awards.

title: Roundup slide show
description: Roundup Slide Show

title: Appeals Court Throws Out Confidential Arbitration in Delaware
description: A decision by a federal appeals court has ended Delawares experiment with confidential arbitration.

title: Bill Mazer, Sports Fixture in New York, Dies at 92
description: Bill Mazer, who was a voice and face of sports coverage in New York for decades, pioneering sports-talk radio and becoming a television fixture while earning the nickname the Amazin for his encyclopedic recall of sports facts and figures, died on Wednesday in Danbury, Conn. He was 92.

title: A Wife Committed to Cruzs Ideals, but a Study in Contrasts to Him
description: WASHINGTON  At first glance, Senator Ted Cruzs wife, Heidi Nelson Cruz, seems to be just the sort of person the Tea Party supporters who celebrate her husbands anti-establishment positions love to hate.

title: Middle East Peace Talks Go On, Under the Radar
description: JERUSALEM  A recent Israeli editorial cartoon depicted the lead Israeli and Palestinian peace negotiators beleaguered on treadmills, with Secretary of State John Kerry between them. Hands on the controls, Mr. Kerry was shown saying, Im upping the tempo a bit more.

title: The Benefits of Having Your Own Moving Truck
description: After living here and there for a few years, the time finally came for me to consolidate my things and move them all to one place. The problem? All of my things had ended up in Boulder, Colo., and I live in Brooklyn. That meant I needed a moving truck, and moving trucks can be pretty pricey to rent for a cross-country move.

title: A Royal Christening in Britain Amid a Refrain of Coos
description: LONDON  Some spent the night in the English rain, huddling under tarpaulins and keeping warm with flasks of tea outside St. Jamess Palace. It was all to secure a good view of Prince George of Cambridge on his christening day Wednesday. The prince had not been seen in public since he was born three months ago.

title: Lorde and Eminem Battle at the Top of the Singles Chart
description: Heres a contest that few could have predicted even a couple of months ago: Lorde vs. Eminem. But the two  a megastar rapper who has sold tens of millions of albums, and a 16-year-old rookie from New Zealand  are currently contending for dominance of Billboards singles chart.

title: Nina Arianda Returning to New York Stage in Red Vienna
description: Nina Arianda, who who won the 2012 Best Actress Tony award for her turn as a dominatrix in Venus in Fur, is returning to the stage and staying on the dark side. She will star in the world premiere of Tales From Red Vienna, by David Grimm, which begins previews on Feb. 26 and opens March 18 at Manhattan Theater Clubs Off Broadway home at City Center.

title: An Evening of Mark Morris ... and Some Other People
description: There is Mark Morris, and then there are all the other choreographers who are deprived of possessing even a sliver of his art. At least thats what it felt like on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where Houston Ballet unveiled its opening-night program of four repertory ballets beginning with Mr. Morriss enchanting and sophisticated Pacific.

title: Following the Stars in a Rush to Riches
description: This years winner of the Man Booker Prize, The Luminaries by Eleanor Catton, is long and demanding, as Booker winners often are. In the past five years, two Bookers have gone to Hilary Mantel, whose Wolf Hall is at first a grueling read, since Ms. Mantel artfully complicated her Tudor tableau by eschewing names for pronouns. But Wolf Hall rewards the effort it demands, and in the end everything is fully, triumphantly clear. The same cannot be said for The Luminaries, nor is it Ms. Cattons intent.

title: A Night to Pay Homage With Their Wardrobes
description: When you are the recipient of a Fashion Group International superstar award, lots of people show up wearing your clothes.

title: Three Men Lean in for Mutual Support
description: The bassist Christian McBrides new trio is constant sleek fun, organized and coordinated. Its connected to a line in small-group jazz going back to the 1950s that made elegance and continuity and affability a priority, one that includes Hank Jones, Dr. Billy Taylor and, more recently, Mulgrew Miller. Its solos run hot when its time for them to do so, and within formatted spaces; then they subside and lead into the next solo, or two-way conversation, or three-way themes.

title: A Guitar Opens Up Some Musical Spaces That Only a Voice Can Fill
description: Fiona Apple has found a way to let her moods swing even more widely. She has always thrived on a precarious blend of the meticulous and the impulsive, and her current tour, which is billed as a duo with the guitarist, songwriter and producer Blake Mills, opens up new extremes for her to toy with. On Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, she was skittish and stubborn, baleful and whimsical, giggly between songs and, when she sang, cathartically serious. With the seeming casualness of a club show (despite a set list that has been consistent throughout the tour), the concert held a sold-out theater audience rapt.

title: Student Ensembles Sound Belies Its Origin
description: There are experts  Im not one of them  who can identify an orchestra by its sound. During Monday evenings concert of the Juilliard Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, I found myself wondering what these people would have heard if they had sat blindfolded through this program of works by Bartok and Bruckner, conducted by Alan Gilbert. As powerful waves of rich brass chords rolled out during the last movement of Bruckners Symphony No. 7, would they have guessed that the players are students, most in their early 20s? When the sound of the violins intensified with the heat and gleam of molten metal, could they have known that the section was almost entirely made up of women?

title: From the Wilderness to an Electric Role
description: Diane Davis was 12 hours from New York last June, vacationing in the Canadian wilderness without electricity or running water  but, luckily, with cellphone service  when her agent called her about an audition for the Primary Stages revival of The Model Apartment, Donald Marguliess surreal, darkly comic 1988 play. So I got in a canoe, with an iPad in a dry bag, and I paddled over to my friends house, Ms. Davis said.

title: Lundqvists Backup to Make N.H.L. Debut
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Henrik Lundqvists nightmarish season took another bad turn Wednesday when the Rangers confirmed he had a lingering injury that would keep him out of Thursdays game at Philadelphia.

title: Bach in a String Concert, Sharing a Program With Bluegrass
description: The most impressive musicians are often versatile, but few match the breadth of the brilliant mandolinist Chris Thile. Even in an era when eclecticism is the prevailing aesthetic, Mr. Thile, a member of the progressive-bluegrass quintet Punch Brothers, stands out for his novel artistic juxtapositions.

title: Q. and A.: Tom Byer on Soccer in China
description: In recent years Chinese athletes have won international competitions in sports ranging from archery to weightlifting. But their performances in soccer, one of the countrys most popular spectator sports, have long stagnated.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the West Bank, Gaza, Pakistan and China.

title: Anatomy: Blue Is the Warmest Color
description: In this Anatomy of a Scene, Abdellatif Kechiche narrates a sequence from Blue Is the Warmest Color.

title: A Seattle Theaters Broadway Credentials
description: SEATTLE  By the fall of 2008, Louis Hobson had starred in enough Seattle productions of Broadway musicals  Hair, Evita, West Side Story  that he decided to shoot for Broadway itself. Within weeks, the dream came true: He was cast as the two doctors in the Broadway musical Next to Normal, supporting roles that earned him good notices and better money during the shows 22-month run.

title: Could Obamacare Discredit Neoliberalism?
description: As a kind of companion piece to my last poston the liberal and conservative visions for health insurance, I strongly recommend reading this post by Mike Konczal, which strikes a note that you can expect to hear sounded more often on the left if the Obamacare rollout continues to go badly. Contra conservatives suggesting that HealthCare.gov represents some kind of discrediting moment for liberalism, Konczal argues that the potential policy problems associated with a nonfunctional web portal really just point to the problems with neoliberalism a much-debated term of art, but defined for his purposes as the post-1970s idea that social insurance should be heavy on private provisioning and means-testing, that it should preserve as much choice and competition as possible, and that it should be delivered at the state level or through state-and-federal coordination rather than by the federal government alone.

title: Sparse Competition and Higher Premiums
description: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Blue Is the Warmest Color
description: In the French coming-of-age drama Blue Is the Warmest Color, a high school student named Adle (Adle Exarchopoulos), finds romance with an art student, Emma (La Seydoux). In this video, the director Abdellatif Kechiche discusses a scene that takes place before Adle meets Emma, and involves a conversation she has with a girl at her school, Batrice (Alma Jodorowsky). Their exchange becomes an important moment in Adles self-discovery.

title: $45 for a Premium Hockney Viewing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Think of it as the art-world equivalent of extra leg room  a museums resourceful way to turn a customer perk into a profit. Along with selling its regular timed tickets, priced up to $25, for David Hockney: A Bigger Exhibition, which opens on Saturday, the de Young Museum here is also offering a premium ticket online for up to $45. This ticket allows visitors entry at any time on the day of their choosing.

title: Londons Tech City Takes Root
description: The British capitals growing credibility in the tech scene has attracted companies to East London  or Tech City, as some local politicians call the area.

title: Technology on the Thames
description: LONDON  Parts of this city have the outward signs of a budding high-tech scene. Run-down warehouses have been remodeled into gleaming office spaces. Some greasy diners have been transformed into trendy restaurants. And many wood-paneled pubs have become wine bars.

title: A Liberal Parts Ways With Fox
description: Sally Kohn, one of the Fox News Channels most visible liberal pundits, parted ways with the network this week and turned up almost immediately on one of its rivals  MSNBC.

title: Music History at Caff Lena
description: Since 1960, this venue in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been an important outpost of the folk music revival.

title: Everyone Except Mozart
description: The Amore Opera is in many ways recognizable as an outgrowth of the old seat-of-the-pants Amato Opera, now defunct. But the Amato knew its limitations and made itself lovable by tweaking pretension, starting with its miniature theater, fitted out with retractable chandeliers  la the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Folk Music Heaven, Upstairs
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The first sign that Caff Lena is different from other joints where guitars are strummed and coffee is sipped comes before you even enter the place. Next to it, off a picturesque side street here, runs Lena Lane, an alleyway commemorating the club and the woman who ran it and became a local legend.

title: Blurring Lines Between People and Other Creatures
description: At first glance, Melanie Maars dances are subtle creations, but by the final blackout, its hard to shake the feeling that youve traveled to a mystical land where nothing is what it seems. In Our Other, performed Friday at Danspace Project at St. Marks Church, Ms. Maar weaves an intricate tapestry pairing ideas related to nature and religion, humans and animals, sexuality and restraint. Its earthy, but refined. Sound emanates both from people and from nature, so that once youre good and settled inside Ms. Maars imagination, youre rarely sure where you are. A factory? A dewy forest?

title: Hollywood Stars Ask N.S.A. to Stop Mass Surveillance
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The debate over National Security Agency spying has gone Hollywood.

title: A Chef in the Field | Pumpkins
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Jury Finds Bank of America Liable in Mortgage Case
description: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | Bank of America, one of the nations largest banks, was found liable on Wednesday of having sold defective mortgages, a jury decision that will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.

title: A Sport Coat Meets a Topcoat
description: Theres a spirited new entry on the mens wear scene.

title: Sophie Calle Mounts an Exhibition of Missing Art
description: When the French artist Sophie Calles exhibition Last Seen opens tomorrow at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, it will mark an ironic homecoming of sorts for her.

title: A Roundup of Worthy Apps for the New iPads
description: Tablets have altered the barriers of the computer world, shattering the belief that a personal computer must have a keyboard. And while laptops have become associated with boring Excel documents and the other digital trappings of work, tablets are making computing fun again.

title: Joel Grey, M.C. in Cabaret, to Publish Memoir
description: Joel Grey, the actor best known for his role as the M.C. in Cabaret, for which he won a Tony Award and an Oscar, will publish a memoir with Flatiron Books, a new imprint of Macmillan.

title: Art You Can Live With
description: Josh Ingmire, whose Hundred Mile showroom opened last weekend in Rhinebeck, N.Y., thinks that the shop, which offers rugs, Carl Hansen classic furniture, fresh design from Established & Sons and other tasteful things, is perfectly located. The riffraff goes to Poughkeepsie, he said. (Rhinebeck, a historic village 18 miles north of Poughkeepsie, is, significantly, beyond the Metro-North commuter line.)

title: Designer Theremin
description: Dorit Chrysler plays a theremin designed by Franois Chambard at the Judith Charles Gallery, where a dozen one-of-a-kind theremins are on display in the show Odd Harmonics.

title: What Would They Do with Axl Rose?
description: Wild Art (Phaidon, $39.95), a new bricklike illustrated tome by David Carrier and Joachim Pissarro, aims to cover art that doesnt find its way to the galleries, at least for a while. The expected subjects are represented, like graffiti and street art, two forms that dont lack for attention, but so are plenty of weirder examples. Like Jason Merciers portraits of Kevin Bacon and Condoleezza Rice, made from the materials their surnames suggest. Or Kyle Beans sculpture constructed from eggshells, left. Or Carol Hummels crocheted sweater for a tree, above.

title: Eating in a Most Peculiar Way
description: For her Itinerant Gastronomy project, the artist Mary Ellen Carroll stages intimate dinners in non-culinary-oriented settings. On Sunday, she will host the heart surgeons Dr. Bud Frazier and Dr. Billy Cohn, the chef Hugo Ortega and several other formidable figures in a vacant office at the top of the Pennzoil Place building in Houston.

title: The Cavendish Invitational in Monaco
description: Look at the South hand. The dealer on your left opens one heart, your partner passes, and responder raises to two hearts. What would you do?

title: Discounts at Flor, Maine Cottage Furniture, Blue Dot and Luceplan
description: All regularly priced Flor carpet design squares are 25 percent off, in stores and online, through Tuesday (Fedora, originally $9 per square, is about $7 per square); (866) 281-3567, flor.com. Seating is 20 percent off at Maine Cottage Furniture, through Oct. 31 (the Margaret bench in mango, usually $520, is $416); (866) 366-3505, mainecottage.com. Blu Dot is discounting all its furniture 20 percent, through Nov. 10, at stores nationwide (the Shale credenza, regularly $2,699, is about $2,159; the Perimeter floor lamp, regularly $399, is about $319): (612) 782-1844, bludot.com. Luceplan is discounting in-stock lighting by up to 80 percent, through Nov. 17 (the Curl table lamp by Sebastian Bergne, originally $435, is $261; the Otto Watt task lamp by Paolo Rizzatto and Alberto Meda, shown, originally $530, is $318); 49 Greene Street (Grand Street), (212) 966-1399, luceplan.com

title: A Wave of Strange Creatures
description: Two years ago, Franois Chambard had not heard of a theremin, one of the first electronic instruments, though chances are he had caught its sound on movie soundtracks. But when Allen Farmelo, a music producer friend, told him about the device, which is played by waving ones hands around its two antennas, Mr. Chambard, the principal of UM Project, a furniture design company in Brooklyn, attempted to make one. Or 12.

title: Yes, Thats Right: Sconces
description: Why do you need a sconce? Brian McCarthy can give you a list of reasons.

title: A Blueprint for Misery
description: The Scandinavian artists Michael Elmgreen, 52, and Ingar Dragset, 44, like to place statues of imaginary unhappy inhabitants inside their sculpture installations. For the 2009 Venice Biennale, they floated a simulated corpse of a wealthy, balding art collector face down in a swimming pool. This fall, they turned decrepit galleries at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London into Tomorrow, the London apartment of Norman Swann, a mediocre modernist architect who has contracted H.I.V. and run out of inherited money. Along with about 100 objects from the museums collection, like an 18th-century Japanese ivory horse figurine and an 1850s plaster fig leaf used to make the museums male sculptures less shocking, evidence of Swanns fictional life is strewn about, including a passport, cigarette butts, unpaid bills, models of unrealized buildings and a biographical script 100 pages long.

title: Where Peace Comes Whizzing By
description: While making a movie, Carrie Schoenfeld built a fossil-fuel-free country house with her husband.

title: For Her Next Production ...
description: GHENT, N.Y.  Theres the everyday juggling of work and chores that most of us do, and then theres the amped-up kind that Carrie Schoenfeld  artist, writer, inventor  thrives on.

title: Only Slightly Mad
description: If youre looking for David Bromberg, the folk musician-turned-luthier-turned-recording artist (again), just follow the beads.

title: David Bromberg and Nancy Josephson: Duet for Violin and Voodoo
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  On the kitchen counter of the Bromberg-Josephson household, a voluptuous cremation urn glitters with sequins, glass beads and one very gnarly molar. Nancy Josephson, who bedazzles not just reliquaries but taxidermy, furniture and automobiles, envisions it as both her final resting place and a shout-out to her great-great-grandchildren.

title: Pension Alert Is Issued in Chicago Budget Talk
description: CHICAGO  Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Wednesday proposed a spending plan for his city next year that is full of nips and tucks: a 75-cent per pack increase in the cigarette tax, higher zoning permit fees for big developments, an end to some retirees health insurance subsidies and a rolling hiring freeze. Left alone, for now, were more controversial taxes, on property, sales and gasoline.

title: The Devil Is in the Details, but Few Take Notice
description: Haunted house designers have a curious relationship with their finished work. They fill each haunt with meticulous, lifelike details, yet the disorientation and fear they aim to induce doesnt encourage appreciation by the public.

title: Face to Face With My Inner Mean Old Man
description: When it comes to noise, I am, to put it generously, a sensitive neighbor. So when the bloodcurdling screams started emanating from the Gateways Haunted Playhouse up the street from my weekend retreat in Bellport, Long Island, several years ago, it irked me. I had just spent the summer battling the teenagers in the house behind me for talking late into the night on a screened-in porch. And now, with summer barely over, Id

title: How to Haunt a House
description: For designers who specialize in haunted houses, its high season. What scares them is how little time there is to furnish the home of your nightmares.

title: House Haunters
description: Pomona, Calif.  On a recent morning, Steve Kopelman stood inside a hangar-size building at the Fairplex event center here, drinking his third or fourth Diet Dr Pepper of the day and eyeing a giant inflatable goat skull. The skull had arrived by truck from Colorado two days earlier and had just been suspended above a plywood wall spray-painted black that had been hastily erected near the buildings main entrance.

title: The Over-the-Topcoat
description: Among the popular ideas now in circulation about how our primeval cave-man brain influences modern behavior is the theory that when we go shopping, women forage and men hunt. You know, just as they did back in Paleolithic times, when women brought home mushrooms (and a new mink pelt), and men brought home a mastodon (and a high-definition wide-screen cave painting).

title: Fall Fashion Trends: Jewelry, and Skirts that Flutter
description: Given the ubiquity of street photography, it can now be easier to trend-spot outside fashion shows than inside. Case in point: the big and bold retro skirts so many women were wearing at the shows last month. You almost expected Carmel Snow to pull up in a Cadillac Brougham. Zanita Morgan, a model turned blogger and photographer, was a latter-day Grace Kelly in a voluminous skirt and angora sweater; Eva Chen, the Lucky editor, was uptown chic in a brocade Tibi; and Eleanor Strauss, the style director of Shopbop, wore a shorter style with a fitted crop top and leather jacket. While the days are still mild, you can pull off a hint-of-skin top under a leather jacket or peacoat.

title: Competition Rises for AT&T, as Does 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: SAN FRANCISCO  T-Mobile USA, the underdog among the four big American phone carriers, has made aggressive moves to shake up the wireless industry this year  and AT&T in particular. But AT&Ts results have not budged.

title: How Winglets Work
description: Winglets help lessen the wind vortexes which normally form at the tip of an airplane wing during flight.

title: Openings, Sales and Events for the Week of Oct. 24
description: Openings and Events

title: Funding Circle, British Peer-to-Peer Lender, Expands to U.S.
description: When the soccer team F.C. Barcelona asked Nick Daffern whether his company could set up some merchandise kiosks at its legendary stadium, the Camp Nou, the British businessman knew he had to find some cash fast to fulfill the order.

title: Makeup Trend: Matte Base Layers
description: Modern matte, a shine-free finish without any hint of chalkiness, was a big trend at New York Fashion Week. Here are three products that can help lay a base for the seasons velvety blushes and eye shadows.

title: Prospect Park Closing on Friday for Obama Visit
description: A year ago, Prospect Park was closed for several days during and after Hurricane Sandy. In May, parts of the park were taken over by the Great GoogaMooga, a food and music festival. Now comes Marine One.

title: New Mexico Justices to Rule on Gay Marriage
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The New Mexico Supreme Court is poised to decide once and for all whether same-sex marriage is legal in this state, addressing an issue that the Legislature has for years failed to resolve and the governor has avoided  but that Democratic county clerks have embraced, under threats of legal action and at considerable political risk.

title: The Biggest Economy Killer: Our Government
description: The government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis inflicted a toll on the American economy, but that cost is only a fraction of the total damage that the federal government has been causing to the American economy.

title: New Clean Air Rules Would Do Little
description: STANFORD, Calif.  PRESIDENT OBAMAS recently proposed regulations to limit carbon-dioxide emissions from new power plants have been much heralded by environmentalists because they would make new coal-fired power plants too costly to operate. In truth, they accomplish almost nothing.

title: For Emily Ratajkowski, Blurred Lines Brings a Career Path Into Focus
description: It was a few days after New York Fashion Week, and Emily Ratajkowski was at the Gemma restaurant on the Bowery, huddled over a pot of chamomile tea and nursing a cold.

title: At the Bathroom Sink, Razors Face Off
description: The return of facial hair, whether in the form of artful scruff or hipster beard, has been a major trend in mens grooming over the last decade. But it cant last forever; at least, that is what the founders of several up-and-coming razor companies hope.

title: Oil Spill in North Dakota Raises Detection Concerns
description: DENVER  For several days last month, Steven Jensen smelled the oil, wafting up over his rolling wheat farm near Tioga.

title: Web Sites and Grave Sites
description: Republicans are apoplectic about Healthcare.gov, the official Web site for the Affordable Care Act.

title: Butch Warren, 74, Prominent Jazz Bassist, Dies
description: Butch Warren, a bassist who performed and recorded with Thelonious Monk, Herbie Hancock and many others and seemed poised for a high profile in the jazz world before his career was permanently derailed by mental illness and substance abuse, died on Oct. 5 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 74.

title: A Stylists Custom Fashion
description: TWENTY YEARS OF WRANGLING celebrities, dressing celebrities and styling celebrities has taught Mary Alice Haney that no designer dress on earth is right for everyone. Almost everything goes to the tailors at some point. So when Ms. Haney, a stylist and a former West Coast editor for magazines like GQ and Marie Claire, began to design her own collection, she wanted women to have options.

title: Adelson Suggests U.S. Nuclear Strike on Iran Ahead of Negotiations
description: Updated, Saturday, 3:54 p.m. | Sheldon Adelson, a leading donor to conservative politicians who share his staunch support for Israel, said on Tuesday night that the United States should begin negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program by launching a nuclear strike on the Iranian desert.

title: 2012 Leak Detection Study
description: A study found that emergency responders or members of the public were more likely to detect hazardous liquid pipeline spills than pipeline companies themselves.

title: Lawmaker Says Iran Has Halted Enrichment
description: TEHRAN  An influential Iranian lawmaker says his country has halted the production of enriched uranium up to 20 percent, a level that experts say is only a few technical steps from what is needed to produce a nuclear weapon.

title: Mickey Boardman: Keeping Up With His Followers
description: At a few minutes past 6 last Thursday night, Mickey Boardman arrived for Paper Magazines annual Nightlife Awards at Marquee. Mr. Boardman, the magazines editorial director, was wearing a black Lacoste shirt, Missoni for Converse sneakers, a Missoni for Target cardigan (Someone tweeted that Cate Blanchett wore it in Blue Jasmine) and oversize Prada womens sunglasses converted to clear prescription lenses, and he was carrying a Stella McCartney bag. In his hand was his omnipresent iPhone.

title: Nicola Formichetti Pays Tribute to Diesel
description: THE FULL IMPACT of Nicola Formichettis new role as artistic director of Diesel will not be felt until March, when he reveals his fall 2014 collection, but that is a long time to wait. Too long, Mr. Formichetti said.

title: Noel Harrison, Actor and Singer of Windmills of Your Mind, Dies at 79
description: Noel Harrison, the actor and folk troubadour best known for his role on the NBC spy drama The Girl From U.N.C.L.E. and his rendition of the Academy Award-winning song The Windmills of Your Mind, died on Oct. 20 in Exeter, England. He was 79.

title: Boy, 14, Is Arraigned as Adult in Killing of a Teacher Near Boston
description: DANVERS, Mass.  Christian Snyder, a high school freshman here, never liked math much, until he had Colleen Ritzer as a teacher.

title: The Rancor Against Roma in Europe
Lights! Camera! Inaction! Its Performance Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitters Scary Names and Facebooks Machines
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Bargaining With the Censors to Get Published in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Academy of Music Announces Winter/Spring 2014 Season
description: A new stage collaboration among Willem Dafoe, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Robert Wilson; a Matthew Barney film adaptation of a Norman Mailer novel; and a live presentation of Isabella Rossellinis explorations into the sex lives of squirmy animals are among the works that will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the first half of 2014.

title: Honor Killings in India
description: To the Editor:

title: Assessing Chemical Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinterest Raises $225 Million, as Valuation Jumps to $3.8 Billion
description: The tech world may be abuzz about Twitter, but a big new social network is showing that its no slouch.

title: Better News in New Study That Assesses U.S. Students
description: Amid growing alarm over the slipping international competitiveness of American students, a report comparing math and science test scores of eighth graders in individual states to those in other countries has found that a majority outperformed the international average.

title: Young Women, Drinking and Rape
In a Major Departure, Google Shows Banner Ads in Search Results
description: Googles search engine was once characterized by its simplicity  both its search results and ads were blue links against a white background.No longer.

title: Case Explores Rights of Fetus Versus Mother
description: JACKSON, Wis.  Alicia Beltran cried with fear and disbelief when county sheriffs surrounded her home on July 18 and took her in handcuffs to a holding cell.

title: Twitter, Women and Power
description: Twitter is on schedule to go public as a company next month, a sparkling symbol of innovation, technology  and stale, old thinking reflected in a board of seven white men.

title: Ad-Sponsored Editorial Content Draws Regulators Notice
description: THE practice of native advertising, or the use of editorial content for promotional or marketing purposes, is beginning to capture the attention of advertising regulators who are concerned that some content could be considered deceptive to consumers.

title: A More Nuanced de Blasio Emerges
description: Bill de Blasios runaway success in the polls as a candidate for mayor of New York City was built on crystal-clear convictions, uncompromising stands and black-and-white promises unburdened by the messiness of governing.

title: Some Iranians Seek to Renew an Old Chant
description: TEHRAN  Born during the hostage crisis days after the 1979 Islamic Revolution, the chant Death to America has enjoyed a long run on the Iranian stage. But it has been getting a little threadbare in recent times, and has even come under threat, with no less a person than the newly elected president, Hassan Rouhani, suggesting that the country no longer needed slogans.

title: Signs of Life in Euro Zone Could Point to Recovery
description: FRANKFURT  All the usual caveats still apply, but there is consistent evidence that the worst may be over for Europes economy.

title: Boy, 13, Carrying Toy Guns Is Shot Dead by Deputies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sheriffs deputies shot and killed a 13-year-old boy who was carrying a replica assault rifle they mistook for the real thing. The shooting occurred Tuesday afternoon in Santa Rosa, Calif., about 60 miles north of here, the police said.

title: Extravagant Wedding Raises Awkward Questions for a Beijing Official
description: If you thought marrying in Manhattan was expensive, try Beijing. A village official in the citys outskirts recently spent more than 1.6 million renminbi, about $260,000, on his sons wedding, local media reported. But such extravagance by a government employee who is not highly paid has drawn suspicion: Where did he get the money?

title: Heated Start in the Trial on Detroits Fiscal Future
description: DETROIT  The trial over Detroits eligibility for bankruptcy started Wednesday with starkly different interpretations of the events leading up to the citys historic Chapter 9 filing in July.

title: Year After Hurricane Sandy, Victims Contest Christies Status as a Savior
description: Hurricane Sandy turned Chris Christie into something akin to Americas governor, as the nation watched him express his states pain on the devastated shoreline the morning after the storm, then triumphantly cut the ribbons on reopened boardwalks on Memorial Day. Were stronger than the storm, he proclaimed in television commercials that ran in other states all summer.

title: LinkedIn Gets the Message: More Mobile, Please
description: LinkedIn is finally embarking on its mobile makeover.

title: Eye-Catching Wingtips, but They Arent for Show
description: United Airlines is testing the latest innovation in airplane design that may prompt passengers to do a double take. Called a split scimitar, its reminiscent of a medieval sword and is a variation on those doodads, known as winglets, that extend up from the tips of wings.

title: Veteran Reliever Knows About Facing Heat
description: BOSTON  Imagine the feeling of standing in the batters box in the World Series and staring down Randy Johnson. Only one player on the St. Louis Cardinals or the Boston Red Sox experienced this form of bone-chilling autumn pressure.

title: Republicans, Sensing Weakness in Health Law Rollout, Switch Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Emboldened by the intense public criticism surrounding the rollout of the online insurance exchange, Republicans in Congress are refocusing their efforts from denying funds for the health care law to investigating it.

title: Boehner on Shutdowns Fallout
description: Speaker John Boehner admits that Republicans failed, but that there are still problems to solve and that it is time for Washington to deal with them.

title: Skakel Gets New Trial in 75 Killing of Teenager in Connecticut
description: A Connecticut judge on Wednesday ordered a new trial for Michael C. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy who was convicted in 2002 of bludgeoning a neighbor with a golf club in 1975, saying his original lawyer had not represented him effectively.

title: Contractors Assign Blame, but Admit No Faults of Their Own, in Health Site
description: WASHINGTON  Contractors that built President Obamas health insurance marketplace point fingers at one another and at the government, but each insists that it is not responsible for the problems that infuriated millions of Americans trying to buy insurance on the Web site, according to testimony prepared for a Congressional hearing on Thursday.

title: Amid Rising Discord Over Indian Images, F.S.U. Has Harmony
description: Before every kickoff at Doak Campbell Stadium in Tallahassee, Fla., a Florida State student in facial war paint and an American Indian costume steers a spotted Appaloosa to midfield. As the horse rises on its hind legs, the rider, who is not an Indian, thrusts a flaming spear into the turf to the crazed accompaniment of the crowds droning chant and an arm gesture called the tomahawk chop.

title: The Judges Decision on Skakel
description: The judges decision setting aside the murder conviction of Michael C. Skakel amounted to an attack on the way the lawyer who represented Mr. Skakel before he was convicted had handled his defense.

title: Cardinals Are Sending Their Hot Rookie Pitcher to the Mound for Game 2
description: The St. Louis Cardinals will send the rookie sensation Michael Wacha to the mound for Game 2 of the World Series on Thursday, hoping he can continue his postseason success.

title: No Husband, No Friends
description: Thanks to Noah, the world is made up of people in twosomes. I never thought much about the ark until my husband died one bright, sunny November morning almost one year ago.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 8 Matchup Breakdown
description: Injuries have been wreaking havoc on football rosters (both real and fake) in 2013. Week 7 wiped several more big names off the football map, including Doug Martin, Reggie Wayne, Jermichael Finley and Jay Cutler. But as always, one players injury is anothers opportunity.

title: Left to Languish, Costly Fire Trucks Present a Reminder of Thai Dysfunction
description: SAI NOI, Thailand  In a weed-covered parking lot on the outskirts of Bangkok, tens of millions of dollars of never-used firefighting equipment sits decaying, punished by bouts of searing heat, monsoon rains and a flood that swamped the area two years ago.

title: Twitter Illiterate? Mastering the @BCs
description: Using Twitter sounds so simple. Type out no more than 140 characters  the maximum allowed in a single tweet  and hit send. Thats all, right?

title: Ted Cruz Takes On the F.C.C.
description: Senator Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican who helped engineer the recent government shutdown, has a new target for his obstructionism: the Federal Communications Commission. Last week, Mr. Cruz blocked the Senate from considering the nomination of Tom Wheeler to lead the commission  a candidate who leaders from both parties had agreed would be put up for a vote without delay.

title: The Deaths of Innocents
description: One of the arguments for Americas heavy reliance on drone strikes against suspected extremists has been surgical precision. The weapons are so finely calibrated and precisely targeted, officials argue, that only militants are killed, and that collateral damage to innocent civilians is rare. These claims were always hard to accept, especially given the governments refusal to provide corroborating data. Now two human rights groups, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, have marshaled impressive new evidence challenging them.

title: For District Attorney in Brooklyn
description: After losing the Democratic primary for Brooklyn district attorney by a wide margin and saying he was ending his bid for a seventh four-year term, Charles Hynes reversed himself. He is now waging an active campaign in the general election on the Republican Party line against the man who defeated him for the Democratic nomination, Kenneth Thompson.

title: Waiting for What Comes Next
description: The sky to the west is kettle-gray. The last leaves on the sugar maple in front of the house are flickering but hanging tight for now. Most of the hickory nuts have fallen, but sometimes I still hear one clatter onto the chicken-house roof. Another couple of months and Orion will be visible when the dogs and I go out for the last walk at night.

title: Outspoken Weir Will Be Quiet on Russian Law
description: It was just after 8 on Wednesday morning, and Johnny Weir looked  by his own assessment  gorgeous.

title: Confession in Baby Hope Killing Was Taped, but the Interrogation Was Not
description: It was a long interrogation. But after 22 years, the cold-case detectives could afford to be patient.

title: Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Oct. 23, 2013
Nicks Struggles as Free Agency Looms
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  This was going to be the year when Hakeem Nicks ran under dozens of Eli Manning passes, snatched them out of the air with his sure hands and ran all the way to the bank.

title: Corrections: October 24, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Wonder May Fade, but Lessons Linger
description: Its just a simple ditty, with a jaunty lilt. Its rudimentary lyrics have something to do with a boat and rope, and you can imagine its being sung mindlessly by sailors or perhaps by a little boy, as it is here. But listen to it again, and then again, and it starts to sound melancholy, and maybe even sinister. By the last time you hear it, it has acquired a voice of chilling, mortal finality.

title: Unwelcome Reversal
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Now this is a spiffy Thursday puzzle. It took a while for the theme to unfold, but thats the way I like it. No sense giving up all of ones secrets at once, right? Preserve a little mystery, thats the way to keep a relationship between constructor and solver fresh.

title: A Homely Relic on Wheels Awakens Nostalgia in Iran
description: TEHRAN  On a recent Friday afternoon, in the upscale Shahrak-e Gharb neighborhood in West Tehran, Porsches, Toyota Land Cruisers and Mercedes-Benz two-seaters drove up and down the street, music blaring from high-powered speakers that were quickly turned down for passing police cars.

title: JPMorgan Faces Possible Penalty in Madoff Case
description: Federal authorities are preparing to take action in a criminal investigation of JPMorgan Chase, suspecting that the bank turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: Every Game Brings an Extra-Large Challenge for Jets Allen
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It had been a long and hectic week for Antonio Allen, a stretch encompassing the birth of his son, Blake, on Oct. 15; his preparation for defending Rob Gronkowski, the Patriots behemoth tight end; and his 23-yard interception return for a touchdown, which started the Jets comeback in their 30-27 overtime victory. And so on Sunday evening, when he left MetLife Stadium, Allen celebrated the best game of his brief N.F.L. career by doing ... absolutely nothing.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 24, 2013
description: I didnt know unborn children had lawyers. I said, Wheres my lawyer?

title: J&R Alters the Blocklong Layout Its Known For
description: A stroll south of City Hall toward Park Row can inspire a wish list  guitars, computers, cameras, stereos, CDs, even vinyl records  in anticipation of the emporium, stretching from Beekman Street to Ann Street, that had long been J&R Music and Computer World.

title: 7-Year Low Reported in Piracy Off Somalia
description: Piracy off the coast of Somalia, once regarded the most dangerous sea passage, has dropped to the lowest level in seven years, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations said in a report submitted Wednesday to the Security Council.

title:
Health Care
Law Fails to
Lower Prices
for Rural Areas
description: As technical failures bedevil the rollout of President Obamas health care law, evidence is emerging that one of the programs loftiest goals  to encourage competition among insurers in an effort to keep costs low  is falling short for many rural Americans.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Panthers (3-3) at Buccaneers (0-6)
description: 8:25 p.m. Eastern

title: Tunisian Protests, by Islamist and Secular Groups, Delay Talks on Constitution
description: CAIRO  Deadly violence and street protests in Tunisia on Wednesday postponed talks intended to end a political standoff that had thwarted completion of a new constitution in the birthplace of, and a relative bright spot in, the Arab Spring revolts.

title: Sued Over Pay, Cond Nast Ends Internship Program
description: For Lauren Indvik, a business editor and soon-to-be co-editor in chief at Fashionista, the 2008 internship at Vogue was worth every sacrifice.

title: From Small Fire, a Great Fried-Knish Famine
description: Before halal chicken and rice, or egg-and-cheese sandwiches, the street carts of New York sold knishes  many of them of the square, fried variety, a hefty, gut-warming pillow of fried dough filled with seasoned mashed potato.

title: Pierce, Ex-Celtic and Current Net, Straddling Two Cities
description: BOSTON  Paul Pierce kept a low profile here Wednesday, but the two pictures he posted to his Instagram account during the day told a story.

title: Pakistani Premier Meets Obama to Mend Ties
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama welcomed Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan to the White House on Wednesday, seeking to bolster his new civilian government and mend perennially frayed ties between the countries.

title: Wise Dans Success Also Boosts Trainer
description: In horse racing, there is a belief that a horses talent cannot be determined by pedigree or auction price; it is the racetrack that is the judge of good horses, and they can come from anywhere. The reigning horse of the year, Wise Dan, is one of those horses.

title: Drownings Put Migration at Fore of European Meeting
description: BRUSSELS  In the aftermath of the drowning deaths of more than 360 migrants in a packed boat off an Italian island this month, the question of how to share the burden of the refugees and asylum seekers crossing the Mediterranean Sea is dividing the European Union ahead of a meeting of national leaders starting Thursday.

title: Sebelius Finds a Friendly Crowd in Boston
description: BOSTON  For Kathleen Sebelius, the Obama administration official who has become the focus of bipartisan anger over the bungled rollout of the online health insurance exchanges, a night out in Boston appeared to be a much-needed respite from scrutiny and criticism.

title: White House to Tweak Tax-Penalty Deadline
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Wednesday that people who obtained health insurance by March 31 would not face any tax penalties for being uninsured in the first three months of 2014.

title: Allan Stanley, 87, Dies; Helped Maple Leafs Win 4 N.H.L. Titles
description: Allan Stanley, a Hall of Fame defenseman who helped the Toronto Maple Leafs win four Stanley Cups in the 1960s, died on Oct. 18 in Bobcaygeon, Ontario. He was 87.

title: China Data Shows Uptick in Output at Factories
description: HONG KONG  An important gauge of manufacturing activity in China showed a larger-than-expected uptick for October, suggesting that the economy may have picked up some steam.

title: The Demise of the Fashion Eccentric
description: The meaning of a true eccentric isnt in the costume  its in the soul.

title: A Very Expensive Tea Party
