description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Word of the Day | nomenclature
description: nomenclature \no-mn-kla-chr also no-men-kl-chur\ noun

title: Italy: Berlusconi Indicted in Corruption Case
description: Italys former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, was indicted on Wednesday in a corruption case linked to the collapse of Romano Prodis government in 2008, one of his lawyers said.Naples prosecutors accused Mr. Berlusconi of paying a senator 3 million euros to leave Mr. Prodis coalition. Mr. Berlusconi is already facing probable expulsion from Parliament and possible house arrest for a tax fraud conviction, and he is appealing a seven-year prison sentence on a conviction of paying for sex with a minor. He has denied wrongdoing in all the cases.

title: Fall for St. Louis; Classic for Boston
description: BOSTON  Getting to this, baseballs biggest stage, had never been the Boston Red Sox strong suit. Generations passed without World Series appearances. Seasons were too often marred by misfortune, blunders, collapses; promise was unfulfilled, and hopes were annually dashed.

title: Time Warner Cable Reaches Agreement to Distribute Al Jazeera America
description: Time Warner Cable, one of the countrys biggest cable operators, has agreed to carry Al Jazeera America, giving the Qatar-owned broadcaster exposure to millions more households as it seeks to build an audience in the United States.

title: Mali: Suicide Bombing Kills 2 U.N. Peacekeepers
description: A suicide bombing believed to have been carried out by Islamists linked to Al Qaeda killed two United Nations peacekeeping soldiers from Chad on Wednesday at a checkpoint in Mali, officials reported. The United Nations peacekeeping force was established in April to assume security operations from France.

title: An Even Tougher Start for the Cardinals Than in 2004
description: BOSTON  Mike Matheny was behind the plate at Fenway Park in the bottom of the first inning of the opening game of the 2004 World Series. By the time he returned to the St. Louis Cardinals dugout, Boston had a 4-0 lead.

title: Dominicans of Haitian Descent Cast Into Legal Limbo by Court
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  For generations, people of Haitian descent have been an inextricable part of life here, often looked at with suspicion and dismay, but largely relied on all the same to clean rooms, build things cheaply and provide the backbreaking labor needed on the countrys vast sugar plantations.

title: Syria: Government Releases Some Female Detainees
description: Antigovernment activists said Wednesday that the Syrian government had released at least 15 female detainees in what appeared to be part of an ambitious regional prisoner swap.Last week that deal, brokered by several countries, freed Lebanese captives held by Syrian rebels and two Turkish pilots held in Lebanon. Syrian rebels had reportedly also demanded the release of the female prisoners.

title: Stripped of Statehood
description: The Dominican Republics top court has declared that the children of undocumented Haitian migrants are no longer entitled to citizenship.

title: Week 8 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
description: The standard N.F.L. matchup is hard to predict. In terms of probabilities for the favorite and underdog, a game is typically about a 62-38 percentage affair. When the underdog wins almost 4 out of 10 games, it can make for an exciting Sunday afternoon. But this Sunday probably wont be one of them.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 10:30 P.M. (MSG) THE GARDEN TRANSFORMED: SPECIAL EDITION This program chronicles the three-year, $1 billion renovation of Madison Square Garden, with glimpses of the Chase Square entranceway, Chase Bridges, the Defining Moments display of the arenas history and the Gardenvision scoreboard, above. It also features excerpts from a Thursday news conference; a question-and-answer session with Willis Reed, the former Knicks player and coach, and Mark Messier, the former Rangers player; and glimpses of 50 Cent, Mike D of the Beastie Boys, Chazz Palminteri, Al Roker, Tony Sirico and Robert Klein on the red carpet. At 7, the Rangers will meet the Flyers at the Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia.

title: News Quiz | October 24, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: The Last Jews of Kolkata
description: KOLKATA  On bustling Brabourne Road in central Kolkata, vendors line sidewalks packed with pedestrians, while cars, motorbikes and rickshaw pullers fill the street. Amid the urban din, the Magen David Synagogue sits silent and empty. A Muslim guard stands watch outside. With an estimated 25 Jews remaining in this city of 14 million people, the synagogue is rarely used.

title: Credit Suisse to Streamline and Shrink
description: Updated, 12:15 p.m. |Credit Suisse said on Thursday that it planned to shrink its investment bank and other businesses as it grappled with stricter regulatory requirements and a challenging fixed-income market.

title: Challenging the Chinese Government to Disclose Its Aid to North Korea
description: Nearly deaf and close to blind, a veteran Beijing protester who was sentenced to re-education through labor in her late 70s, Wang Xiuying, now in her 80s, seems an unlikely threat to Chinas secretive bond with North Korea. But she wants to know how much aid the Chinese government gives its neighbor, and she went to court to demand an answer.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 24, 2013
description: Use context clues and your knowledge of word roots to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

title: French Contemporary Art Fair Opens In Paris
description: PARIS  Mona Lisas smile may still draw throngs of tourists to Paris, but the citys contemporary art scene also has its own allure. This week collectors and art fans are invading Paris fresh from Londons Frieze for  the International Contemporary Art Fair, also known here by its French acronym, FIAC.

title: 6 Qs About the News | StoryCorps Turns 10
description: After Sarah Littman recorded an interview with her son, Josh, who has Asperger syndrome, and the interview was broadcast on National Public Radio, she received hundreds of letters of support. She put all the letters in a notebook, and whenever Josh had a rough day, they would read the letters together. PBS turned the interview into the animated short, above. Read the related article to learn more.

title: McKesson in $8.3 Billion Deal With German Drug Wholesaler
description: LONDON  The San Francisco health care services firm McKesson Corporation said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire a controlling stake in Celesio of Germany and will start a tender offer for its remaining shares in a deal valued at $8.3 billion.

title: Preview: Running From Crazy
description: In this clip from the coming documentary, Margaux and Mariel Hemingway revisit the home where their grandfather, Ernest, committed suicide.

title: Picturing the Gowanus Above the Muck
description: One day last October, Yunghi Kim went to the edge of a dock along the notoriously polluted Gowanus Canal. She took off her sneakers, rolled up her pants legs and stepped into the toxic muck. As a high tide lapped over her ankles, Ms. Kim dunked a camera wrapped in clear plastic bags beneath the surface.

title: The Importance of Not Being Ernest
description: Mariel Hemingway gets up early, perhaps as an unconscious homage to her famous grandfather, to watch the sun rise. Each morning, while still in bed, she and her live-in boyfriend, an erstwhile stuntman and actor named Bobby Williams, begin a series of predawn exercises that consist of breathing, stretching, contemplating the things theyre grateful for and visualizing the day ahead. Hemingway then makes the bed and a pot of jasmine green tea. She fills the hummingbird feeders with organic sugar water, feeds organic soy-free meal to the brood of egg-laying hens that live in her backyard and heads back to the kitchen to prepare a smoothie.

title: Has Baseball Lost Its Cool?
description: The Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals are battling it out in the World Series this week and next, yet does America care as much as it used to? According to a recent Op-Ed article by Jonathan Mahler, the game that we affectionately call our national pastime seems to have lost its cultural relevance  at least compared to football and basketball.

title:
U.S. Envoy Is
Summoned by
Germany Over
Spying Report
description: BERLIN  Leaders and citizens in Germany, one of Americas closest allies, simmered with barely contained fury on Thursday over reports that American intelligence had tapped into Chancellor Angela Merkels cellphone, the latest diplomatic fallout from the documents harvested by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden.

title: Increase in Activity Reported at North Korean Nuclear Test Site
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has increased activity at its main underground nuclear test site, digging new tunnel entrances in what could be preparations for another nuclear test, a Washington-based research institute reported Thursday.

title: With Winter Ahead, Can Chinas Smog Get Anything But Worse?
description: Following the airpocalypse in the city of Harbin this week, a question now hovers in the minds of many residents across northern China. It was summed up in a headline that ran on Thursday with a commentary in Peoples Daily, the Communist Party mouthpiece: In this season of central heating, will PM 2.5 drop?

title: New York Today: Send in the Ghouls
description: Updated 12:09 p.m. | Jeanne Fleming is planning a very, very big party.

title: A Chinese Newspaper Restates its Call for a Reporters Release
description: Updated, 7:15 a.m. EST | A Chinese newspaper has not backed down from its bold public request that a reporter detained in a defamation investigation be released. On Thursday, one day after the Guangzhou-based New Express ran a front-page story under the huge headline, Please Release Him, the paper followed up with another front-page call: Again, Please Release Him.

title: Small, Steady Growth for Europes Economy
description: PARIS  Europes fragile recovery remains alive, according to the results of a closely watched corporate survey released on Thursday.

title: Santander Profit Rises as It Sets Aside Less to Cover Bad Loans
description: LONDON  The Spanish lender Banco Santander reported on Thursday a surge in profits to 1.1 billion euros in the third quarter as it continued to benefit from declines in charges for bad loans.

title: Daily Report: London Works to Raise Profile as European Tech Hub
description: King.com, the maker of the popular Candy Crush game franchise, is trying to become the first London tech start-up to hit gold on the public market. And if the company is successful, it could help cement the citys reputation as one of Europes top start-up communities, Mark Scott reports.

title: Ford Maintains Earnings Streak and Raises Profit Forecast for the Year
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Ford Motor said on Thursday that its net income fell 22 percent in the third quarter, to $1.27 billion, as the company took charges related to revamping its European operations and its United States pension obligations.

title: North Korea to Release 6 South Korean Detainees
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a surprise move that could help ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula, North Korea said Thursday that it would release six South Koreans it has been holding in detention, South Korean officials said.

title: Ireland Vows to Review Cases of Roma Children Removed From Their Families
description: DUBLIN  In a case that has drawn scrutiny here, the Irish authorities on Thursday promised to review the circumstances under which two blond, blue-eyed Roma children were removed from their families in different parts of the country this week  only to be returned when DNA testing confirmed their parentage.

title: The Handyberwachung Disaster
description: BERLIN  Germany, of course, has already concocted a compound word for it: Handyberwachung. That would be spying on cellphone calls.

title: Christening the Earliest Members of Our Genus
description: Around 1.8 million years ago, human evolution passed a milestone. Our ancestors before then were little more than bipedal apes. Those so-called hominids had chimpanzee-size bodies and brains, and they still had adaptations in their limbs for climbing trees. But the fossils of hominids from 1.8 to 1.5 million years ago are different. They had bigger brains, flatter faces and upright bodies better suited to walking.

title: Jerusalem, Saved
description: JERUSALEM  The slang word combina entered the Hebrew language from Ladino, the tongue of Jews of Spanish origin. A combina is a clever dirty deal  a word at times used in admiration, at times used in disdain. When it was announced Wednesday morning that the mayor of Jerusalem, Nir Barkat, was re-elected to a second five-year term by a small majority, the response of Israelis was nearly unanimous: his victory came from a combina that failed.

title: Anthony Caro, British Sculptor, Dies at 89
description: LONDON  The British sculptor Anthony Caro, widely known for his monumental works using industrial metal, died on Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 89.

title: Ericsson Sales Slip, and So Does Its Stock
description: Shares of Ericsson, the maker of mobile telecommunications equipment, fell on Thursday after the company reported a decline in third-quarter sales. The Swedish company is grappling with a slowdown in investment by large cellphone carriers.

title: Madoff Case Looms Over JPMorgan
description: Federal authorities, suspecting that JPMorgan Chase turned a blind eye to Bernard L. Madoffs huge Ponzi scheme, are preparing to take action in a criminal investigation of the bank, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. Coming on the heels of a tentative $13 billion settlement over JPMorgans mortgage practices, the case poses another major threat to the banks reputation.

title: Subway Turnstile Haiku
description: Dear Diary:

title: Permira to Buy Maker of Dr. Martens
description: LONDON  Adding to its stable of consumer brands, the private equity firm Permira agreed on Thursday to acquire the British firm that owns the Dr. Martens footwear and clothing brand in a deal valued at 300 million, or $485.3 million.

title: At a Steakhouse Bar, Less Volume Cant Be Ordered
description: The bar behind the steak side of Harrys Cafe and Steak is a nice little lounge with some serious music problems. On one recent night, the playlist included, at pulverizing volume, Lady Gagas Applause, the inescapable Blurred Lines by Robin Thicke (at this point, no, we dont want it), Nicki Minajs Starships, and somewhere in there what sure sounded like a commercial for a Nissan Drive and Save sale.

title: White Girls, The Controversy-Courting New Volume From Hilton Als
description: What do Truman Capote and Michael Jackson have in common? Theyre White Girls, according to Hilton Als, the New Yorker writer whose incendiary new book  his first major work since The Women in 1996  brings up race and gender identity in modern America while blurring the lines between memoir, cultural critique and fiction. Its a pejorative term, similar to the use of black girl to describe a model of color in the fashion world, Als says. The white girls in this book are marginalized by the status quo because of their race and gender, or because they are trying to pass as a member of the world responsible for their disenfranchisement. Here, passages excerpted from White Girls (out Nov. 12 from McSweeneys; $24), which Als describes as a kind of philosophical whodunit.

title: Lazard Earnings Rise 75% on Deals and Cost-Cutting
description: An improving market for deals and cost-cutting bolstered Lazards third-quarter earnings, as the investment bank reported on Thursday a 75 percent increase in profit from the period a year earlier.

title: Football App, a German Start-Up, Gets U.S. Investment
description: BERLIN  Lucas von Cranach has come a long way since starting his professional career at a German machinery production company in the mid-2000s.

title: A Quick Trip From Playwright to Player
description: It was dinner break at the Public Theater for the cast and crew of the new musical Fun Home. They had spent the late afternoon fine-tuning small bits  some newunderscoring here, a less-than-crystal-clear snippet of French there. And with just three hours before that nights preview performance, the time had come to relax.

title: Its Getting Warm in the Tap Studio
description: Every so often, you hear someone bemoan the state of the American theater, perhaps even proclaiming that it is dying or dead. But thankfully there are companies out there like Richard Maxwells New York City Players, that understand the need to generate and support new work and thus keep the naysayers at bay. Like Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, which recently produced a festival devoted to the work of the playwright Lucy Thurber, the New York City Players are also nurturers. The companys American Playwrights Division presents full productions of works by emerging writers who also direct.

title: After a Concussion, Returning to School
description: The usual protocol here at the Parent-Teacher Conference is that you ask me questions about parenting and education, and I answer in 800 words or fewer. Today, however, I am asking the question, and in order to follow my own advice, will answer in fewer than 800 words.

title: Michelle Obama to Support Women Running for Office
description: Michelle Obama, a first lady who is often resists the stump, may be spotted next year helping women running for office. Next month in New York, Mrs. Obama will be a guest speaker at a lunch at the Democratic Womens Senate Network policy conference in New York.

title: Icahn Amps Up Pressure on Apple, but His Stake Limits His Leverage
description: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | When Carl C. Icahn starts making noises about a company, executives usually listen. But his campaign for Apple to return more money to shareholders might be falling on deaf ears.

title: The Comics That Refuse to Die
description: The popularity of EC Comicss horror and humor still flourishes.

title: Neil Blumenthal of Warby Parker on a Culture of Communication
description: This interview with Neil Blumenthal, co-chief executive of Warby Parker, the online seller of eyeglasses, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Theyre ... Theyre Still Alive!
description: This is a chilling and improbable tale of the living dead: Even though they were savaged by the politeness police and left lifeless some 60 years ago, EC comic books, which spawned notorious titles like Tales From the Crypt, Shock SuspenStories and Mad, have become the comics that refused to die.

title: Indignation in Europe Over Claims That U.S. Spied on Merkels Phone
description: The revelation that the United States may have monitored the mobile phone of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was greeted in Europe with a mix of righteous indignation and questions as to which leaders cellphone could be next.

title: 36 Hours in Milwaukee
description: Milwaukee is a city that evolves slowly. Its roots as a blue-collar town  as the German Athens, as Brew City  are still evident in the names of local landmarks (Pabst Theater, Pfister Hotel, Miller Park, where the Milwaukee Brewers play); the neatly demarcated enclaves that still retain strong traces of their ethnic origins; the countless cozy neighborhood taps; and the locals love of sausage, cheese and beer, not to mention the array of festivals (German Fest, Irish Fest, Polish Fest) that overtake the lakefront every summer. Yet this city  Wisconsins largest, population 600,000  is hardly a backward-looking place. Following a few decades of diminishing population, numbers have risen slightly in the years since the 2010 census, much of the increase due to young people moving into a few revived downtown neighborhoods like Walkers Point and the southerly, suddenly hip Bay View, with its bars and galleries. The result is a city that possesses a renewed vitality while still holding on to an Old World character.

title: Indias Battle Against Nutrition Data Deficiency
description: NEW DELHI- Paharganj is an area populated with decrepit, low-budget hotels, about two miles from the Indian Parliament in central Delhi. Thousands of poor Indians live in a labyrinth of claustrophobic, dirty lanes that veer away from the hotel-lined main street. Kusum Kumar, 37, a day care worker for the Integrated Child Development Scheme, the Indian governments social welfare program for children under 6, works out of a one-room tenement in an inner lane.

title: A Journeyman Catcher Has Reasons to Shout
description: BOSTON  David Ross came bounding into the Boston Red Sox clubhouse late Wednesday night, fresh off the field, his jersey untucked, shouting as loud as he could. He could have passed for a rookie, if only the gray-streaked beard had not given him away. He kept shouting as he went to his locker, giving high-fives and hugs along the way.

title: Former Detainees Right to Speedy Trial Wasnt Violated, Appeals Panel Rules
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan ruled on Thursday that the governments long detention of a valuable terrorist, first at a secret site run by the Central Intelligence Agency and then at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, did not deprive the suspect of his right to a speedy trial.

title: The Daily Show and the Wall Street Witch Hunt
description: Its a shakedown, witch hunt, scalping jihad, Jon Stewart of The Daily Show said, mocking financial televisions coverage of a $13 billion settlement over JPMorgan Chases mortgage practices.

title: 12 Years a Slave Leads the Gotham Nominations
description: The movie awards season begins in earnest with the Gotham Independent Film Awards, which announced its nominees on Thursday.

title: The Gun Report: October 24, 2013
description: Because online gun classifieds are under increasing scrutiny and Craiglist has a policy against selling guns, people are now unloading their firearms on the photo-sharing site Instagram. Yes, Instagram.

title: Anthony Caro, Who Followed Sculpture on a Path to Abstraction, Dies at 89
description: Sir Anthony Caro, a pre-eminent artist of the postwar era who created a new language for abstract sculpture in the 1960s with brightly colored, horizontal assemblages of welded steel that seemed choreographed as much as constructed, died on Wednesday in London. He was 89.

title: 10 Questions for Matt Bevin
description: Mr. Bevin, a 46-year-old investment executive, spoke with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC about his campaign to oust Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican minority leader.

title: Poetry Pairing | Monsters
description: With Halloween coming, this Poetry Pairing features Monsters by Dorothea Lasky and the 2008 This Land column In the Wilds of New Jersey, a Legend Inspires a Hunt by Dan Barry.

title: Court Lifts Limit on Contributing to Pro-Lhota PAC
description: It looks as though the super PAC era is coming to New York.

title: 10 Questions for Matt Bevin, Mitch McConnells Tea Party Challenger
description: Before Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky can face off against Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Democrat and Kentuckys secretary of state, he must turn back a primary challenge from Matt Bevin, a 46-year-old investment executive who has Tea Party support.

title: Appellate Ruling in New York Progress and Protection PAC v. Walsh, et al.
description: Read the full decision allowing a group supporting Joseph J. Lhota to accept unlimited contributions.

title: New Years Baby? You May Pay More
description: Traditionally, much hoopla surrounds the birth of the first baby of the New Year. But it turns out that can be an expensive bit of good luck.

title: Contractors Describe Limited Testing of Insurance Web Site
description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials did not fully test the online health insurance marketplace until two weeks before it opened to the public on Oct. 1, contractors told Congress on Thursday.

title: MTV Will Explore Youth and Revolution in Rebel Music
description: MTV is returning to its roots, sort of, with a new series that promises to highlight social change via slamming beats. Rebel Music, which begins Nov. 18 on mtvU, is a documentary-style look at six hotspots around the world  including Egypt, Afghanistan, Mali and Mexico  whose conflicts and culture are examined through the eyes of local artists and activists. The episode in Egypt was shot during the Arab Spring and focuses on the use of protest songs and social media; in Afghanistan, producers follow a young female rapper and a heavy metal band.

title: Today in Small Business: Crowdfunding Rules Released
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: British Tech Start-Ups Take a Financial Bent
description: LONDON  A vibrant tech community is in full swing here in the British capital, with social gaming apps and e-fashion start-ups vying to attract venture capital investment.

title: For a While, Her Life Is Yours
description: Blue Is the Warmest Color is a feverish, generous, exhausting love story, the chronicle of a young womans passage from curiosity to heartbreak by way of a wrenching and blissful attachment to another, slightly older woman. Although there is plenty of weeping and sighing, the methods of the director, Abdellatif Kechiche, are less melodramatic than meteorological. He studies the radar and scans the horizon in search of emotional weather patterns and then rushes out into the gale, dragging the audience through fierce winds and soul-battering squalls.

title: YouTube Said to Introduce Paid Service for Music
description: The competitive world of digital music is about to become even more crowded with the arrival of one of the most formidable forces on the Internet: YouTube.

title: 8 States Teaming Up to Support Electric Cars
description: WASHINGTON  In an effort to spur lackluster sales of electric cars, California, New York and six other states said on Thursday that they would work jointly to adopt a range of measures, including encouraging more charging stations and changing building codes, to make it easier to own an electric car.

title: K.K.R. Profit Buoyed by Rising Markets
description: Rising markets have proved good for Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its holdings.

title: Obama Urges House Republicans to Act on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday renewed his call for an immigration overhaul, telling an audience of activists at the White House that the fate of a bipartisan Senate bill now rests with Republicans in the House.

title: Image of the Day: October 24
Fantasy Football: 2013 Matchup Analysis
description: This chart looks ahead to the rest of the season and indicates what kind of fantasy matchup a player will have.

title: Fantasy Football: 2013 Matchup Analysis, Running Back
description: This chart looks ahead to the rest of the season and indicates what kind of fantasy matchup a player will have.

title: New York Public Library Hires Firm to Promote Renovation Plan
description: The New York Public Library is paying a prominent lobbying firm $25,000 to help promote the librarys controversial renovation plan, according to a contract obtained by The New York Times.

title: From Orbitz, a New Loyalty Program
description: Orbitz, the online travel agency, has started Orbitz Rewards, a loyalty program that it said was designed for simple use and immediate gratification.

title: Longtime Times Editor Named Politico Executive
description: Richard L. Berke, a longtime political correspondent and senior editor at The New York Times, was appointed executive editor of Politico on Thursday, in what Politico described as a testament to its influence and growth.

title: Hiring an End-of-Life Enforcer
description: The chilling dilemma of the unbefriended elderly, who dont have family or close friends to make medical decisions on their behalf if they cant speak for themselves, generated a bunch of ideas the last time we discussed it.

title: In Our Pages: October 25
description: 1913 Japan Deal Tests U.S. Relations

title: Poetry Profiles: Copper Canyon Press
description: Small presses are the lifeblood of poetry. Whether tucked behind the nurturing skirts of a university press, or weathering (mostly) harsh cultural indifference on their own, small presses are often the first to ferret out new and vital voices, to exhume lost masterpieces or to translate essential work from other languages.

title: With Sales Falling, an Owner Struggles With Pricing Strategies
description: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about their biggest concerns. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, started the discussion  and had the groups rapt attention for most of the meeting. She said last year, when annual sales were about $8.5 million, was the companys best since she and her sister took over in 2008. But this year, sales have been extremely disappointing.

title: Wheelies: The Andy Warhol Mercedes Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Food Matters | Fifteen Tons of Groceries, Sailing Down the Hudson
description: Food Matters | Fifteen Tons of Groceries, Sailing Down the Hudson

title: Clapper and Carney Get Slippery on Surveillance
description: Does anyone still believe anything the Obama administration has to say about surveillance?

title: Co-Sleeping, Reluctantly, With a (Wiggly) 3-Year-Old
description: At 10:45 on a recent evening, my wife and I are just falling asleep when our 3-year-old son, Jacob, cries out. Seconds later, we hear the pitter-patter of his feet in the hallway. My wife gets out of bed, picks him up and places him, half-asleep, between us.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Simply No Room for Uninvited Plus-Ones

title: All-Women I Remember Mama to Highlight Transport Group Theater Season
description: The Transport Group, a nonprofit theater company that specializes in American work, said on Thursday that it will present two plays during its 2013-14 season  an all-female version of John Van Drutens classic, I Remember Mama, and a revival of John Carianis Almost, Maine, which had a quiet, four-week New York run in 2006, and has since become a hit in productions around the world.

title: Lesters Game 1 Gem Comes Under Scrutiny
description: Although it looked as if Cardinals shortstop Pete Kozma was the one with Vaseline on his glove in Game 1 of the World Series, one Cardinals minor leaguer wondered if Jon Lester was loading up with a foreign substance Wednesday night to make his pitches more effective.

title: Obama Renews Immigration Push
description: President Obama spoke on Thursday morning, pressing Congress again to act on changing immigration laws.

title: The Night a Halloween Special Went Terribly Wrong
description: In 1967, Paul and Linda Webber were brutally murdered by their son, Donald, in their suburban home in a crime that shocked the small town of River Hill. Twenty years later, WNUF, a local television station, enlisted a pair of occult researchers to participate in a live special from that home in hopes of speaking to whatever evil spirits may have lingered there.

title: J. J. Abrams: By the Book
description: The Hollywood writer, director and producer, and creator of the novel S. is inspired by Chris Wares work. His graphic novels have the emotional wallop of a Philip Roth or Thomas Pynchon.

title: The Unions Most Undervalued General
description: Despite his brilliant victory at Vicksburg in July, some lingering doubts remained about Gen. Ulysses S. Grant when he took command of the besieged Union forces at Chattanooga, Tenn., on Oct. 23, 1863. Earlier, when his army was taken by surprise at Shiloh, he had amplified the misgivings of critics by denying the attack was unexpected and falsely claiming he was outnumbered two-to-one. More recently, a limp resulting from a horseback-riding accident during post-Vicksburg victory celebrations in occupied New Orleans fed persistent rumors of alcoholism.

title: Cross-Country Run in 1930 Ford Cut Short by Engine Failure
description: Some of the most marvelous success stories began with embarrassing failures. Thomas Edison, Soichiro Honda, even Henry Ford  they all faced defeat, but went on to become great.

title: Living With Cancer: Brains on Chemo
description: Over the past few months, a number of headlines in The New York Times have stumped me.

title: Highlights and Analysis: World Series Game 2  Cardinals 4, Red Sox 2
description: BOSTON  It appeared the Red Sox had done it again. They had bested another top pitcher, and David Ortiz had saved the day. But it was Boston this time, in Game 2 of the World Series, and not the St. Louis Cardinals, that made a game-turning mental mistake. The Cardinals went on to win, 4-2, to even the series at 1-1.

title: Twitter Sets I.P.O. Price at $17 to $20 a Share
description: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | Twitter took the first steps in the pricing of its eagerly awaited initial public offering on Thursday, setting a price range for its shares that was below what some analysts had expected.

title: Letters
description: The Devil That Never Dies

title: Gallery | The Buildings and Statuary of Central Park, in Gorgeous Watercolor
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Pirates Abduct Two Americans on Oil Ship Off Nigerian Coast
description: Pirates attacked an American-flagged oil industry vessel off the Nigerian coast early Thursday and abducted the captain and the chief engineer, both United States citizens, the Nigerian Navy and a private security firm reported. The abductions appeared to be the first involving American hostages in that region in at least two years.

title: Your Experiences in New Yorks Work World
description: Updated, Dec. 2 | I write a weekly column for The Timess Metro section called The Working Life, which focuses on work, the workplace and the evolving economy in New York City. My reporting will highlight your stories and experiences, and I want to hear about the biggest changes that have taken place in your working life over the last few years as the city has struggled its way out of a historic recession.

title: For Heidi Cruz, Grapefruit Juice Was Key to Political Career
description: Heidi Nelson Cruz, the wife of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and a managing director at Goldman Sachs, has one piece of advice she often gives to the young graduates she mentors: Be the person willing to do whatever it takes to get the job done, no matter how small the task may seem.

title: Activist Bet on Evercore Would Have Beaten One on Lazard
description: Nelson Peltz must be happy with his stake in Lazard. The activist investor jumped into the stock early last year. Since then, Lazards stock has gone up 50 percent, and its third-quarter results on Thursday show the firm is on the right track.

title: Crazy Crab 888
description: Inside the Burmese-Yunnanese-Malaysian-Thai restaurant in Flushing, Queens, that aspires to be a Cajun crab shack.

title: When Napkins Arent Enough
description: This is the best service Ive ever had, a woman at my table declared halfway through dinner at Crazy Crab 888. We were eating off paper plates, our hands in plastic gloves and our faces bathed in fluorescence, in a former bodega still anchored by a counter selling lottery tickets and Alka-Seltzer.

title: Perspectives on Painting: Investigating Early Italian Renaissance Art
description: We dont often take up the topic of art history on this blog, but we seized the opportunity to work with Hilda Werschkul, who teaches an introductory survey to art history course at the Fashion Institute of Technology, the School of Visual Arts, and Montclair State University, to help us design this guest lesson on early Italian Renaissance art.

title: Senator Intensifies Probe of Data Brokers
description: A Congressional probe into the multibillion-dollar data brokerage industry  companies that collect, analyze, sell or share personal details about consumers for marketing purposes  is intensifying.

title: A Slap Here, a Handshake There
description: James Wolcott, the redoubtable Vanity Fair columnist, has written better than anyone about many things, among them the largely forgotten Beat-era literary critic Seymour Krim.

title: All-Out Hustle
description: Postseason games can turn on plays made, or muffed.

title: Big Deal for Big Apple: 7 Balls at Warp Speed
description: WALDEN, N.Y.  TRY. Drop. Pick up. Try again. Drop. Pick up. Then? Try again.

title: Cats Are Works of Art (but You Knew That)
description: THE video reel opens with a big cat squeezing itself into a narrow-mouthed urn, a miniature comedy that ends with the cats tail poking sinuously out the top. Later, there is a poignant encounter between a hair dryer and a blind kitten, which flails its paws at the heat, wind and noise. Elsewhere, a black cat plays the villain, rudely swatting a pill bottle off a dresser, then turning to the camera to deliver a contemptuous yawn.

title: Despite Everything: Francis Spufford Talks About Unapologetic
description: Francis Spuffords books cover a wide variety of subjects, from polar exploration to his childhood reading to a blend of fiction and nonfiction about Soviet Russia in Red Plenty, which Dwight Garner named one of his 10 favorite books of 2012. In Unapologetic, Mr. Spufford adds to the diversity of his bibliography, this time mounting an impassioned argument for, as the subtitle puts it, Why, Despite Everything, Christianity Can Still Make Surprising Emotional Sense. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Spufford discussed his path back to religion from atheism, the low moments in Christian history, why Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens are not even wrong and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Martin Klimas Show at Foley Gallery
description: The Miser has long suspected that he has a mild case of synesthesia. While strumming a guitar, he experiences different colors according to the key he happens to be playing in: C is yellow, E is blue, D is green, and so on.

title: Tibetans Call Chinas Policies at Tourist Spot Tacit but Stifling
description: XIAHE, China  Buddhist monks in flowing burgundy robes hurried along the dirt paths of the Labrang Monastery, trying their best to ignore the scrum of Chinese tourists following their every move, many with cameras fit for paparazzi.

title: Vivian Schiller to Leave NBC News for Twitter
description: In a bid to reinforce Twitters mutually beneficial relationships with the news industry, the social networking giant on Thursday appointed Vivian Schiller to a newly created position, head of news and journalism partnerships.

title: All-Out Hustle
description: Everyone loves the hustle and drama of a playoff game, and Wednesday nights World Series opener between St. Louis and Boston provided new moments that fans will remember. The second inning, in particular, stood out for Carlos Beltrans catch against the bullpen wall and the moment when Adam Wainwright and Yadier Molina let a pop-up drop between them.

title: Accounting World, Still Resisting Sunlight
description: The accounting business has sometimes had an attitude of  how shall I put it?  contempt for those who would regulate it. The people who run the major firms know best, and regulators should yield to their superior judgment.

title: Celebrating Dylan From Coast to Coast
description: The Best Fest, a production company that presents charity tribute concerts built around the music of great rock songwriters  most notably, Bob Dylan, Tom Petty, Neil Young and the Rolling Stones  said on Thursday that this years Dylan Fest would be bicoastal, with concerts in New York on Nov. 11 and 12, and San Francisco on Nov. 20.

title: A Risotto of Late-Season Tomatoes
description: The last of the seasons tomatoes are not to be ignored. The best ones at this time of year are usually the meaty, late-ripening plum or Roma varieties. And their flavor is helped by slow-roasting. I folded them into a risotto to serve with our Chiantis. Though the risotto is fine with the darker, richer examples we tasted, it is especially felicitous alongside the more graceful, lighter ones.

title: A Canterbury Kiss
description: By Wesley Stace

title: New York Philharmonic to Stream Video Performances Next Week
description: The New York Philharmonic is revisiting a few highlights of its recent history, and inviting its fans to tune in and relive those events as well, by way of a five-day I  New York Philharmonic Festival, to be streamed on the classical music video Web site medici.tv.

title: Food Matters | Fifteen Tons of Groceries, Sailing Down the Hudson

title: Greenspan: No Saving Grace
description: Sorry about radio silence  family stuff and textbook deadlines fell in on me. But I would like to get in something about Greenspans new book.

title: Exploring Plan B
description: My wifes family and close friends are planning a surprise party to celebrate her 70th birthday. The planners have asked me to arrange for her to be at a certain locale at a certain time, and they have insisted on my secrecy. My wife told me that she hopes nothing is being planned for the occasion. She would like to celebrate her birthday with a quiet dinner for two at a fine restaurant. I am convinced that she is not being coy and would detest this surprise party. Should I blow the conspirators cover?

title: R.L. Stine to Revive Fear Street Series
description: R.L. Stine, whose Goosebumps books are a childrens publishing phenomenon, is reviving another beloved series: Fear Street, a best-selling line of young-adult horror books set in the fictional town of Shadyside.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: tainted breast milk, scoliosis and biking accidents. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: F.D.A. Urging a Tighter Rein on Painkillers
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday recommended tighter controls on how doctors prescribe the most commonly used narcotic painkillers, changes that are expected to take place as early as next year.

title: Adding Rauschenberg and Richter at MoMA
description: Fifty years ago, when Robert Rauschenberg was experimenting with the relationship between photography and painting in New York, Gerhard Richter was doing the same thing in Dsseldorf, Germany. This week, the Museum of Modern Art announced two acquisitions by these artists  both paintings from 1963  that illustrate their similar explorations. They were specific paintings we had our eyes on for years, said Ann Temkin, MoMAs chief curator of painting and sculpture.

title: Chucky, Now Part of the Family
description: The fearsome Chucky is now beloved in many ways.

title: Abrams and Kasdan Take Over Writing of New Star Wars Movie
description: There has been a (minor) disturbance in the force: Lucasfilm on Thursday said that Michael Arndt would be replaced as the screenwriter of Star Wars: Episode VII, which is scheduled to begin filming in the spring, for a planned 2015 release.

title: Recalling Painful Lessons in Forgiveness
description: My mother started screaming, and I whipped around fast enough to see her staggering from my car, hunched over, hugging her arm to her belly.

title: Force of Evil Becomes Cute and Collectible
description: Its been 25 years since an evil plaything terrorized moviegoers and forced parents to reassure their children that their toys wouldnt turn on them. Chucky, as the overalls-wearing miscreant was called, started his rampage in Childs Play, Tom Hollands darkly comic 1988 horror film about a little boy whose redheaded Good Guy doll is inhabited by the spirit of a foul-mouthed killer. With its depiction of a child in danger, the film was controversial to the degree that sometimes parents and parents groups get up in arms about having kids watch horror movies, said Don Mancini, the creator of Chucky and a writer of the film.

title: French Fault Banks Over Tax Evasion
description: PARIS  French lawmakers proposed measures on Thursday to combat tax evasion and faulted a chain of financial players, including banks, that enable a flight of tax revenue estimated at 80 billion euros, or $110 billion, a year.

title: Giants Pierre-Paul Says He Wont Be Fully Healthy Till Next Year
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul conceded Thursday what has been fairly obvious to those watching him play this year: he is not 100 percent healthy after off-season back surgery. But Pierre-Paul now believes he will not be completely healthy until next season.

title: Should Medical School Last Just 3 Years?
description: Sandwiched between three mind-numbing years of basic science courses and hospital rotations and the lockdown years of residency training, the fourth year of medical school has long been a welcome respite for future doctors. It is the only time in their medical education when students have few requirements and a plethora of elective course offerings  and the time to go on vacation and spend time with friends and family.

title: Agency Initiative Will Focus on Advancing Deep Brain Stimulation
description: Worldwide, 100,000 people have electrical implants in their brains to treat the involuntary movements associated with Parkinsons disease, and scientists are experimenting with the technique for depression and other disorders.

title: Ice-Skating Archive Seeks a New Home
description: The most comprehensive collection of equipment and souvenirs from ice-skating shows sits in an unprepossessing brick photo studio in Minneapolis. Costumes, skates, props, dolls, jewelry, spoons, posters, programs, tickets and even popcorn containers are neatly packed into boxes and binders. They date to the 1910s, when nightclubs started installing minirinks and appreciative audiences would carry star skaters through the streets after shows.

title: A Neighborhood Prowl Through the City of Chianti
description: Im in love with the sangiovese grape. This is no new infatuation. Ive always loved Chiantis, the wines of Montalcino and the various other expressions of Tuscan sangiovese. But this year the affair has intensified.

title: Ackman to Sell Part of His Stake in Canadian Pacific
description: More than a year after the activist investor William A. Ackman won a bitter battle for control of the Canadian Pacific Railway, he is cashing in part of his investment at a substantial profit.

title: John Ashbery Collects: Poet Among Things
description: Loretta Howard Gallery

title: A New Ethiopian Lodge With a Focus on Conservation
description: The first resort in Ethiopias wildlife-rich Bale Mountains National Park, Bale Mountain Lodge, opening Nov. 1, is poised to expand the African safari checklist beyond the Big Five.

title: Donald Judd: Stacks
description: Mnuchin Gallery

title: Kenya Assails Coverage of an Attack on a Mall
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyan journalists came under threat this week from the authorities over their coverage of last months Westgate mall attack, after video suggesting possible looting by Kenyan forces was broadcast on national television.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Australia, South Africa and Bangladesh.

title: Amazons Revenue Soars, but No Profit Is in Sight
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazons third quarter followed a familiar script: it sold vast quantities of things, lost money while doing so, and investors were delighted.

title: Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections
description: An exhibition at the National Gallery of Art takes a processional sweep through Byzantine iconography, with about 170 items for many centuries.

title: William Anastasi: Sound Works, 1963-2013
description: Hunter College Art Galleries

title: France Begins New Anti-Islamist Sweep in Mali
description: PARIS  French soldiers in Mali have begun a major anti-insurgent sweep with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers, the Defense Ministry said on Thursday, calling it the largest operation to counteract a revival of Islamist militant activity since France intervened early this year.

title: Annette Kelm
description: Andrew Kreps

title: Christoph Ruckhberle: Frhstck im Freien
description: ZieherSmith

title: G.O.P. Roots for Failure
description: In theory, lawmakers hope that government programs work well, and if they dont, try to fix them.In theory, our representatives hope that government agencies carry out their missions smoothly, and if something goes wrong, try to figure out what happened to avoid making the same mistake in the future.

title: Fantasy Precedes Melancholy Darkness
description: At first glance, it seemed the height of timidity for the excellent and adventurous conductor Pablo Heras-Casado to open the Orchestra of St. Lukes program on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall with a frequently heard staple: Mendelssohns Overture to A Midsummer Nights Dream. Big things are expected of this exuberant Spanish artist, 35, who was appointed principal conductor of St. Lukes in December 2011.

title: Lots of Dim Sum Feeds a Starry Career
description: First love dies hard.

title: Brisk Sales to Business at Microsoft; Devices Lag
description: SEATTLE  The person named to be Microsofts new chief executive will inherit two companies. One is thriving, the other is sluggish.

title: Ruling Lets Times Co. Complete Globe Sale
description: The New York Times Company completed the sale of the New England Media Group, which includes The Boston Globe, to John W. Henry on Thursday, after a Massachusetts judge lifted an injunction that had temporarily halted the sale.

title: My West Coast Marthas Vineyard
description: That first time I walked through the grassy dunes of Point Reyes National Seashore, back in 1997, it felt familiar. On this stretch of California sand, Id found the West Coast doppelgnger of Gay Head, on the southwestern point of Marthas Vineyard, from where Id recently moved. Though it was summer, I was wearing a fleece, and the sandstone cliffs of Limantour Beach were shrouded in fog. But the echoes of the Vineyard in Point Reyes were immediately clear: a rugged, relatively remote refuge with salty air, fresh fish and a strong sense of place.

title: Part Ostentatious, Part Intimate
description: If you like old clocks  and who doesnt like old clocks?  theres one you must see in the International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show at the Park Avenue Armory. Displayed by Richard Redding Antiques, one of the shows 67 vendors, its called The Hartmann Exhibition Clock, and its spectacular. A gleaming, complicated assemblage of gilt bronze, it has a neo-classical base from which columns resembling minarets made of basket-woven metal bands rise. These flank a roughly pyramidal tower of eight different clocks with enameled faces keeping time according to as many different systems. At the summit a little figure of Victory blows a trumpet. It also has a variety of automata, including small silver rods whose revolutions suggest streams of falling water.

title: Exploring Point Reyes
description: Sun and fog, oysters and organic produce in this area north of San Francisco.

title: A Fairy Tale Heroine Finds Her Magic Tree
description: In his ambitious Cinderella, performed by San Francisco Ballet on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater, the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon discards the magic pumpkin. Instead of a fairy godmother, Cinderella has four male Fates, who have the aura of the Blue Man Group, even though their faces are painted gold. Among other duties, they tidy the kitchen.

title: Excerpt: 'The Snow Geese'
description: Mary-Louise Parker and Danny Burstein in a scene from Sharr White's new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Christopher Wool at the Guggenheim
description: The museum is featuring paintings and works on paper.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 8 Tiered Player Rankings
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: Fed Proposes a Rule to Help Big Banks Stay Liquid in Times of Crisis
description: During the financial crisis of 2008, the big banks fell dangerously short of cash, forcing them to take out enormous government loans to survive the tumult.

title: Samsung Electronics Fined for Fake Online Comments
description: A Taiwanese trade agency has punished Samsung Electronics for paying people to post fake online comments that mocked a competitor.

title: Shes Glad to Be Onstage and Turning Back the Clock
description: Im glad to be anywhere, said Marilyn Maye, the inexhaustibly sunny 85-year-old trouper  who has every reason to be joyful  at 54 Below on Monday evening. In the opening-night performance of her new show, in which she jazzed up nearly 30 vintage show tunes, with a special emphasis on songs from Guys and Dolls, she exhibited no signs of the kind of faltering stamina that would seem almost inevitable for someone her age.

title: Their Names Are Legion
description: When Hu Yinan meets someone new, say, in a meeting or at a party, she prefers to introduce herself by her English name: Number.

title: Filling in the Blanks in the Tale of a Death
description: When Strike Back, Cinemaxs post-Sept. 11, globe-hopping counterterrorism series, began in 2011, something felt missing. In the premiere, a British special-forces soldier was kidnapped in Pakistan and executed, and people back in London were very upset, which made sense. But viewers were left wondering: Who was that guy? Why were we supposed to care so much about him?

title: Fangs Follow the Fairy Tales
description: During its short life so far, NBCs splendid fairy tale action-adventure Grimm  one of the networks few nonfootball successes  has been stranded on Friday nights. For company, the network has given it a motley crew of Dateline, a few disposable reality shows and the last months of Chuck.

title: Focused Effort to Narrow the Gender Gap on Corporate Boards
description: The dearth of women on corporate boards has been a persistent issue for decades. Yet little has changed over the years, despite much public hand-wringing over the stubborn gender gap.

title: After Muddy Waters Report, NQ Mobile Falls by Half
description: When the stock market opened on Thursday, NQ Mobile, a Chinese mobile security company, had a valuation of $1.1 billion. Just hours later, half of its value was erased.

title: Murder, Mayhem and Cross-Dressing Zombies
description: Dont be fooled by the unwieldy title: Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings is nothing if not narratively succinct. Hailing from the genre-loving Philippines, this batty horror-comedy, directed by Jade Castro (who was also one of the films three writers), knows exactly what it is and where its going.

title: Viewing for Your Inner Michael Myers
description: LETS say youre more Halloween than Halloween. You love scary movies, but the actual holiday makes you want to punch a drunken Dracula in the plastic fangs. Youd much rather turn off the lights, ignore the trick-or-treaters at the door, dig your nails into the couch and enjoy a good (or bad-good) horror movie at home. But first you must sort through the fright-flick detritus.

title: Internet Archive Will Shield Visitors
description: Reading, once the most private of acts, is going public. The simple act of buying a book can be automatically publicized through social media. The makers of reading devices know who skipped chapter three and how many people made a note of that lovely passage in chapter four.

title: Tripping All the Way to the Gates of Hell
description: If you enter Toad Road expecting a conventional horror movie, you will be sorely disappointed. But if youre looking for an uncomfortably authentic drama about the horrors of dedicated drug use, then this strange little number from Jason Banker (who also wrote the screenplay and wielded the camera) might just do the trick.

title: Social Media, the Spiritual Version
description: WASHINGTON  After arriving with no particular buzz, then being kept on ice by the government shutdown, Heaven and Earth: Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections has finally opened at the National Gallery of Art here, and its ambushingly resplendent, like a somber cloud with a fire inside.

title: Excursions in a Digitally Fabricated Landscape
description: If you havent quite wrapped your head around the concept of 3-D printing, or havent yet had a digital scanner wrap itself around you, now you can do both in Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital, at the Museum of Arts and Design. The technologies in this survey of computer-assisted art, architecture and design may not be entirely new; the Museum of Modern Arts 2008 exhibition Design and the Elastic Mind covered much the same territory and included some of the same artists and projects. But these tools are becoming more pervasive in both art and life, making this a good time for the uninitiated to get up to speed.

title: On the Road With the Vienna Boys Choir
description: In the opening of Bridging the Gap, members of the Vienna Boys Choir, clad in its traditional sailor suits, arrive in a rowboat on what is apparently the shore of New Zealand and plunges into welcome rituals with Maori people. The situation almost recalls a memorable scene from Lord of the Flies, in which a storm-tossed choir sings Kyrie eleison in procession on a beach, but the photography here has the color cranked way up, and a plummy, National Geographic-style voice-over pours forth platitudes and edifying narration.

title: Paintings Endgame, Rendered Graphically
description: Christopher Wool is one of many painters who have experimented with bringing their medium to extinction. They strip it of familiar attributes like imagery, brushwork or flatness, often ending up with some kind of monochrome that suggests the last painting that could possibly be made.

title: Stop by These Subway Stops
Wildlife Is Tame; Not the Humans
description: The Counselor, Ridley Scotts terrifying, implacable new movie, opens on a seductive scene. The setting is a softly lighted bedroom in which two people are murmuring sweet, dirty nothings under a white sheet. You dont see who they are until theres a cut to under the sheet, bringing you close enough to Michael Fassbender and Penlope Cruz to feel like an interloper.

title: TV Talk: Comedy Comebacks
description: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the surprise hits among this years new comedies.

title: Comedy Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Return Engagements

title: Youre Fired, in Terms Only a Boss Could Love
description: Through booms and busts, profits and losses, the vacuous jargon and happy euphemisms of the business world endure. In fact, they flourish. At a time when the nations economy is plodding and job growth is sluggish, corporations are coming up with new ways to sugarcoat words no employee wants to hear: Youre fired.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: In Jil Sanders Exit, Echoes of the Past
description: EVER SINCE she sold her company to Prada, in 1999, Jil Sander has not been sure she wanted to stay. She has left three times. The third occurred on Thursday with the announcement that she is leaving for unspecified personal reasons.

title: Response to a Citys Smog Points to a Change in Chinese Attitude
description: BEIJING  Emergency measures came swiftly in Harbin, the northeastern city blanketed with hazardous smog this week: Schools were shut down, buses ordered off the roads, the airport closed, police roadblocks set up to check tailpipe emissions from cars. City officials even fanned out in the surrounding countryside, ordering farmers to stop burning the cornstalks left in their fields after the harvest.

title: Brave Optimism of Tahrir Square Meets Other Fierce Forces
description: In the language of politics, the people is a great abstraction, an idea that can be invoked to justify noble projects and terrible crimes. The Square, Jehane Noujaims stunning new documentary, is partly about the contested status of the Egyptian people between the winter of 2011, when crowds of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square to demand the removal of President Hosni Mubarak, and the summer of 2013, when the army ousted his successor, Mohamed Morsi, and began a violent campaign against his followers in the Muslim Brotherhood. Mr. Morsi, the military and the demonstrators  and, for that matter, Mr. Mubarak himself  all claimed to be true agents and loyal servants of the popular will.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: What I Love | Dani Shapiro
description: The author and her husband left the city for Connecticut and found a more spiritual life.

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dani Shapiros Provident Move to the Country
description: Dani Shapiro, the novelist and memoirist, has awesome real estate karma. In the 1980s and 1990s, she lived in three of the Upper West Sides most storied landmark buildings: the Ansonia, the Dakota and the Hotel des Artistes. When she and her husband, the screenwriter and director Michael Maren, decided to move to Brooklyn in the late 1990s, they bought a town house in gentrifying Prospect Heights right before yoga studios arrived and prices escalated.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 25-31
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Man Beneath the Hairspray
description: Before Boy George, before RuPaul, there was Divine, the zaftig drag diva and provocateur of early John Waters films who, once glimpsed, was hard to forget. Facetiously dubbed the filthiest person alive for a notorious scene in the 1972 film Pink Flamingos, in which he ate dog feces, Divine expanded the concept of the drag queen from brash female impersonator into something much larger, more subversive and less gender specific.

title: Learning From Rejection
description: A rejection from a mortgage lender is no cause for shame. Instead, think of it as a call to action.

title: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 25-31
description: Hollow

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Understanding Preferential Rent

title: Spare Times for Oct. 25-31
description: Village Halloween Parade and Costume Ball (Thursday) Barring any disastrous weather  last years hurricane put an end to many holiday plans  Halloween celebrations will be in full swing. Billed as the Hallelujah Halloween Revival, the Village Halloween Parade will proceed up Avenue of the Americas, from Spring Street to 16th Street, at 7 p.m.

title: Palaces-in-the-Making
description: A run-down parking garage is for sale on the corner of Perry and Greenwich Streets in the West Village, and at least one of the bidders wants to tear it down to its bones and replace it with a 40,000-square-foot mansion  creating what would be the largest single-family home in New York City.

title: So Evil, They Cackle at Strategy Meetings
description: Who doesnt hate, at least a little bit, the high-flying wheeler-dealers who recently brought the world to the brink of economic collapse and were never held accountable? As you watch the Costa-Gavras financial thriller Capital, it may rekindle some of the rage and fear that people felt when the pillars trembled.

title: About Last Night | Old and Young New York Collide at a Gala for the Whitney
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Being Gay in Lebanon
description: Samer Dabouls Out Loud bills itself as the first gay film from Lebanon. Six rebellious young idealists break all the social and religious rules and decide to live communally. In hot pursuit are the relatives of the two who are gay, Rami (Ali Rhayem) and Ziad (Jean Kobrously), closeted lovers who were caught kissing and are marked for death for having brought shame to their families.

title: Youre Demised! Getting Fired Evolves
description: The Timess David Gillen explains how companies like HSBC, AOL and Hewlett-Packard are getting creative with the jargon behind major layoffs, from downsizing to right-sizing.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: New Debate About Sexism, and Battle for Power of the Internet
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: A Geriatric Biker Gang
description: There is undeniable exhilaration in the aerial shots of Go Grandriders, as a gang of motor-scooter-riding 70- and 80-somethings in matching helmets, shirts and jackets rides along majestic Taiwanese coastal roads. There is mystery, too, in this documentary about their cross-country ride, but mostly from omission in the sometimes inept storytelling.

title: Fishing as Therapy
description: Like a documentary antidote to the adrenaline flow of The Hurt Locker, the modest, becalmed Not Yet Begun to Fight shows veterans of combat in Iraq and Afghanistan undergoing an unusual but apt form of therapy. These warriors, hobbled by injuries and psychologically fragile, enter a program that treats the guys-guy pastime of fly-fishing as regenerative meditation. The directors, Shasta Grenier and Sabrina Lee, delicately find moments of openness in casual, lapidary interviews with five men at different points in recovery.

title: Troubles in the Kitchen
description: Joseph Levys ordinary documentary Spinning Plates rotates among the challenges faced by the proprietors of three restaurants: the 150-year-old Breitbachs Country Dining, in Balltown, Iowa; a struggling roadside Mexican joint in Tucson; and the chef Grant Achatzs Alinea in Chicago, which has three Michelin stars. While a lot could be said about each, and about food and culture generally, this dully structured film makes its points early and often, treading water before a purposely delayed big finish.

title: Crudely Closing a Generation Gap
description: Attending Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa, Johnny Knoxvilles new prankfest, could be life-changing. It may cause you never to use another vending machine, never to enter another bingo parlor, never to put your child on one of those coin-operated rides, never to eat in another diner.

title: Finding Love in a Cruel Time
description: One man and one woman against the world is a familiar story, among the oldest, told from Genesis to The Blue Lagoon. The Pin, a Canadian film about two young Eastern Europeans hiding in a barn during World War II, is a variation in which the couple are enclosed in menace. Here their island is an underground hiding place and the Yiddish they speak to each other.

title: Incalculable Loss, Inconsolable Mother
description: We have seen J-horror from Japan, K-horror from South Korea, and now, with Le-Van Kiets House in the Alley, V-horror from Vietnam. Postpartum depression takes a murderous turn in this slight exercise, which, for all its modesty, generates a measure of dread.

title: Filmmaker Chronicles His Battle With Illness
description: The title is When I Walk, but Jason DaSilvas hard-hitting record of his daily battle with primary-progressive multiple sclerosis is really an exploration of creeping immobility. From the moment his legs gave way during a 2006 Caribbean vacation, to the films improbably upbeat 2012 conclusion, Mr. DaSilva, a successful documentary filmmaker and just 25 when he received his diagnosis, ruthlessly chronicled his dismayingly rapid decline.

title: A Game of Shark and Minnow
description: In a remote corner of the South China Sea, 105 nautical miles from the Philippines, lies a submerged reef that the Filipinos call Ayungin. Theres little to commend the spot, apart from its plentiful fish and safe harbor. In most ways it resembles the hundreds of other desolate reefs, islands, rock clusters and cays that collectively are called the Spratly Islands. But Ayungin is different. It sits on the southwestern edge of Reed Bank, an area rumored to contain vast reserves of oil and natural gas. And its shallows are home to a World War II-era ship called the Sierra Madre, which the Philippine government ran aground on the reef in 1999 and has since maintained as a kind of post-apocalyptic military garrison, manned by eight Filipino troops struggling to survive extreme mental and physical desolation. Of all places, the scorched shell of the Sierra Madre has become an unlikely battleground in a geopolitical struggle that will shape the future of the South China Sea and, to some extent, the rest of the world.

title: DuPont to Split Into 2 as It Plans to Spin Off a Major Segment
description: The industrial conglomerate DuPont is splitting in two.

title: Group Linked to Kochs Admits to Campaign Finance Violations
description: A secretive nonprofit group with ties to the billionaire conservative businessmen Charles and David Koch admitted to improperly failing to disclose more than $15 million in contributions it funneled into state referendum battles in California, state officials there announced Thursday.

title: A Portal to the Old World
description: A G.P.S. comes in handy on the way to Dubrovnik, an exciting, handsome restaurant on an unprepossessing block on Main Street in New Rochelle. This authentic Croatian spot  my Croatian-American guests thought the only thing missing was the Adriatic lapping at limestone cliffs  is polished but not fussy, just like the dishes created by its Croatian owner and chef, Zeljko Tomic, known as Jerry.

title: To Combat Elder Abuse, Doormen Are Enlisted to Keep a Watchful Eye
description: Michael Marlow, a doorman at the Gracie Mews apartment building on the Upper East Side, does a lot more than just open doors for residents. He unscrews their jar lids, runs to the store for apple juice, listens to their complaints about spouses and children, and even reaches into his own pocket to lend a couple of dollars for cab fare.

title: American Comfort Food From Asia
description: Its interesting to recall how exotic Thai food once seemed, now that pad Thai is almost as American as spaghetti. My newest Thai favorite is Sweet Chilli on Park Road in West Hartford, a restaurant with a casually sumptuous look and soothing feel. It is often full but never loud. (And yes, the extra l in the restaurants name is intentional  meant to help distinguish its fare from Tex-Mex chili.)

title: Despite Rising Sticker Prices, Actual College Costs Stable Over Decade, Study Says
description: Every year, price increases at private colleges prompt a round of appalled responses and calls for corrective action. But even as some sticker prices approach $60,000 a year, the amount that students actually pay  because of increased discounts, grants and tax benefits  has barely changed over the last decade, according to a major analysis of college costs published this week.

title: Where Soul Food Is a Family Affair
description: There are no good restaurants in Valley Stream was a complaint I heard recently from friends who live there. I begged to differ and proved my point by taking them to Pretty Tonis Cafe. This very good restaurant, which opened in January 2009, seems to have been overlooked by some of the local residents.

title: City Says Principal Didnt Tell of Abuse Claim
description: In May, a student at a Bronx elementary school told his principal he saw a teacher kissing a 10-year-old girl in the back of a dark, empty classroom. Another student told the principal, Angelyn Donald, that the man and the girl had exchanged a sexually explicit note during class.

title: To Expand Offshore Power, Japan Builds Floating Windmills
description: OFF THE COAST OF FUKUSHIMA, Japan  Twelve miles out to sea from the severely damaged and leaking nuclear reactors at Fukushima, a giant floating wind turbine signals the start of Japans most ambitious bet yet on clean energy.

title: LinkedIns New Mobile App Called a Dream for Attackers
description: Security researchers are calling LinkedIns new mobile app, Intro, a dream come true for hackers or intelligence agencies.

title: Contribution Solicitation Form Offers a Choice
description: A donation to the efforts of Americans for Job Security would be nonreportable, while one to the Small Business Action Committee PAC would be, the form says.

title: Recalling the Republicans of Yesteryear
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukraine: Boxing Champion Throws His Hat in a New Ring
description: Vitali Klitschko, who is the reigning World Boxing Council heavyweight champion and leads an opposition political party in Ukraine, on Thursday declared his candidacy for president of Ukraine in an election scheduled for 2015. His decision to challenge the incumbent, Viktor F. Yanukovich, came in response to an effort in the Ukrainian Parliament to pass a bill that would prohibit him from running because he holds permanent resident status in Germany, where he has trained.

title: Those Bright Blue Bikes, to Love and to Hate
Anti-Semitism in Hungary
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellis Island Is Reopening With Damaged Museum
description: A year ago next week, Hurricane Sandy swamped Ellis Island and its immigration museum, ruining its electrical and air-conditioning systems and prompting the removal of most of its collection of artifacts.

title: Eagles Frustrations at Home and With Quarterbacks Have Persisted
description: PHILADELPHIA  The City of Brotherly Love is hardly imbued with that spirit when it comes to the Eagles these days.

title: Republican Consultants Interview With Investigators
description: An August report on Anthony Russos interview with representatives of the Fair Political Practices Commission and the California state attorney generals office.

title: New York City Amends Fee Policy for a Visit to the Met
description: Clarifying four decades of legal vagueness, the Bloomberg administration has amended New York Citys lease with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, spelling out that the Met is allowed to charge a suggested admission fee, as the museum has done since 1971 under an agreement with the city. The amendment adds that fees for special exhibitions may also be charged, a widespread practice in the art world but something the museum decided against in the 1980s.

title: Tailgate Parties Far Beyond Burgers and Dogs
description: For Robert Burzichelli, getting to High Point Solutions Stadium by 7 a.m. to set up his tailgate party before Rutgers football games offers the kind of restorative tranquillity often associated with yoga.

title: Winning Sports Fans Hearts by Giving Them Somewhere to Go
description: PROVIDING product samples is a relatively simple affair for many products, whether its fragrance brand representatives spritzing consumers in department stores or snack brand representatives handing out tortilla chips in supermarkets. For toilet paper brands, getting consumers to try the product on the spot is decidedly more complicated.

title: In White House Pitches, Rosy View of Health Care Site
description: WASHINGTON  Just days before HealthCare.gov went live with disastrous results, top White House officials were excitedly briefing lawmakers, reporters, Capitol Hill staff members and Washington pundits on their expectations for the governments new health care Web site.

title: Excitement Before Health Site Went Live
description: Before HealthCare.gov made its debut, President Obama and his advisers predicted how user-friendly and beneficial it would be.

title: Prospect Parks Closing Is Scaled Back
description: Parts of Prospect Park in Brooklyn will remain open on Friday, despite a presidential visit, the Prospect Park Alliance said on Thursday, contradicting earlier information that it would be closed from noon to 6 p.m.

title: Freedom of Speech Online
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fatal Rape in India
No. But I Play One on TV.
description: For 15 seasons, Law & Order: SVU has recreated a vision of New Yorks streets by casting extras who can be seamlessly woven into scenes.

title: Why the Government Never Gets Tech Right
description: MILLIONS of Americans negotiating Americas health care system know all too well what the waiting room of a doctors office looks like. Now, thanks to HealthCare.gov, they know what a virtual waiting room looks like, too. Nearly 20 million Americans, in fact, have visited the Web site since it opened three weeks ago, but only about 500,000 managed to complete applications for insurance coverage. And an even smaller subset of those applicants actually obtained coverage.

title: Anthony Caro, Sculptor, Dies at 89
description: Anthony Caro followed sculpture from the monumental to the abstract.

title: Would-Be Virginia Governors Spar, Continuing Bitter Tone
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.  Trailing in polls and outspent on the airwaves, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, who has sought to capture the swing state of Virginia by building on his Tea Party base, faced his last, best chance to reboot the race for governor in a debate here Thursday.

title: Fighting for a Hallowed and Grueling Ground
description: There are many who dread Cemetery Hill.

title: The Bad News for Local Job Markets
description: DURHAM, N.C.  THE September jobs numbers, finally released this week after the government reopened, indicate that the job market remains on a painfully slow upward trajectory.
