Unemployment has fallen a full percentage point since early 2012, but at this pace, our economy could still be years away from its prerecession level. To make faster progress, many analysts are banking on job growth from two key sectors, education and health care.

title: Hitting the Wall: For Marathon Charities, Numbers Are Slowing
description: By this time of year, the height of fall marathon season, the e-mails have long piled up: marathon aspirants seeking charitable donations from family and friends to help them secure a spot in a particular race. On race days, charity logos on runners gear have become as ubiquitous as mile markers, an integral part of an events feel-good message of fitness and philanthropy.

title: Timeline of the Skakel Case
description: More than a decade after the conviction of Michael Skakel in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley in Greenwich, Conn., a judge has ordered that Mr. Skakel be released on bail. Here is a look at how the case unfolded through the years.

title: Upstart in Miami Lures Luxury Stores From a Chic Citadel
description: MIAMI  For decades, the wealthy tourists and transplants who flock to South Florida bought their Chanels, Cartiers, Diors and the like at one place: Bal Harbour Shops, an open-air mall housing many of the highest-end retailers in the world around a courtyard of palm trees and koi ponds at the northern end of Miami Beach.

title: After Baby Hope Confession, Assessing the Value of Taped Interrogations
description: Q. The police commissioner announced more than a year ago that detectives would videotape their interrogations of suspects in serious cases like murder. Thats what they did in the Baby Hope case, right?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 24, 2013
Addicted to the Apocalypse
description: Once upon a time, walking around shouting The end is nigh got you labeled a kook, someone not to be taken seriously. These days, however, all the best people go around warning of looming disaster. In fact, you more or less have to subscribe to fantasies of fiscal apocalypse to be considered respectable.

title: City to Fit All Streetlights With Energy-Saving LED Bulbs
description: The amber glow of the New York City streetlight is going away. In an energy-saving effort, the city plans to replace all of its 250,000 streetlights with brighter, whiter, energy-saving, light-emitting diode fixtures in one of the nations largest retrofitting projects, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, said in a news conference on Thursday.

title: In the Skakel Case, 2 Women on 2 Sides in an Endless Vigil
description: For more than a decade, they have driven themselves to court hearings, sat a few feet apart through countless hours of harrowing testimony, and exchanged cordial greetings, if not quite warm ones.

title: The Ghosts of October
description: As I push my 4-year-old daughter on the swing, I wonder when the day will come when she will not need me to supply the power. My children remind me that time is marching on even when the frenetic pace of a parenting day convinces us that we dont have time to age.

title: French to Strike, but This Time Owners Call It
description: PARIS  The labor strike being something of a national sport in France, it should come as no surprise that its practitioners occasionally include professional athletes.

title: No to More Casinos in New York State
description: New York State is home to five casinos run by Indian tribes and nine casinos that are called racinos because they are large slot machine parlors near racetracks. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the Legislature now want to expand gambling by putting a constitutional amendment on the Nov. 5 ballot that would add seven full-blown casinos. The answer from voters should be no.

title: Seeking a New Relationship With Pakistan
description: After so many years of animosity between Pakistan and the United States, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and President Obama used their first meeting at the White House this week to begin to set the relationship on a more constructive path.

title: White House Officials Career Twitters Out
description: WASHINGTON  Until his Twitter adventures under the handle @NatSecWonk ended his career this week, Jofi Joseph embodied all the elements of a Washington clich, down to the security card around his neck. His degree in foreign service was earned at Georgetown, which propelled him to his first job as an analyst in the Congressional Budget Office, the ultimately anonymous D.C. gig.

title: @NatSecWonk Snark
description: A selection of Twitter posts about top administration officials written by Jofi Joseph, the National Security Council staff member who was fired for using an anonymous Twitter handle to knock public figures, reporters and colleagues.

title: In Search of Republican Grown-Ups
description: The leaders of the Republican Party, in full flight from their disastrous and juvenile shutdown stunt, now want to restock their ranks with grown-ups. Lets face it: it was not a good maneuver, Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah told The Times recently. Youve got to have the adults running the thing.

title: Allegation of U.S. Spying on Merkel Puts Obama at Crossroads
description: WASHINGTON  The angry allegation by the German government that the National Security Agency monitored the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel may force President Obama into making a choice he has avoided for years: whether to continue the age-old game of spying on Americas friends and risk undercutting cooperation with important partners in tracking terrorists, managing the global economy and slowing Irans nuclear program.

title: The Assistants: The Mensa Member
description: The first name on Urban Meyers list of assistant candidates: Tom Herman, he of the documented high I.Q. Herman, now Ohio States co-offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach, would prefer not to be known as the Mensa assistant, but he did list his membership in the group on his first rsum at his mothers suggestion, between his team captaincy and all-conference accolades. He asked various universities to remove that from his biography, but it trailed him like a blinking neon sign: Im smart. Really, really smart.

title: National Guardsman Accused of Shooting and Wounding 2 in Tennessee
description: ATLANTA  A Tennessee National Guard recruiter wounded two of his superiors on Thursday when he opened fire with a handgun at a military facility near Memphis, the authorities said.

title: The Assistants: The Roommates
description: Luke Fickell wanted to be a wrestler. He idolized Dan Gable, the godfather of grappling. His familys vacations revolved around wrestling tournaments. He won three high school state championships in Ohio and went undefeated. Yet Fickell ended up on the football team at Ohio State, where he made 50 straight starts at nose guard.

title: North Carolina Prosecutor Takes Shots at the Laws Hes Obliged to Enforce
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The criticism could not have been much harsher: North Carolinas Republican-led legislature had set out to undo 50 years of progress with a Tea Party-inspired playground of extremist fantasies that include tax giveaways to its richest residents and election law changes that make it harder for residents to register and vote.

title: The Assistants: The Traditionalist
description: Ed Warinner, who grew up near Canton, Ohio, and played for Mount Union, embodied the backgroundUrban Meyer sought.

title: A Matriarchs Cold Realities Pile Up
description: As a service to readers and copy editors, I feel the need to point out that The Snow Geese and The Snow Goose are not the same thing. The Snow Geese (plural), a new play by Sharr White that opened on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, is a sentimental tale set during World War I. The Snow Goose (singular), a novella from the early 1940s by Paul Gallico, is a sentimental tale set during World War II.

title: Cause of a Class Struggle
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Stacking entries one on top of the next in a crossword puzzle is the metaphorical equivalent of the clean and jerk in weightlifting. Its an impressive feat, difficult to do elegantly, and can throw your back out if youre not careful. Im sorry, I drifted. What I meant to say was that it should not be tried at home.

title: Rape Case of Prosecutors Friend Spins Into County Feud
description: CARMEL, N.Y.  Had it come into her courtroom, the domestic dust-up might have raised Judge Judys eyebrows: A sitting district attorney gives advice and money for legal expenses to a criminal suspect  his personal trainer  who is charged with the rape of an underage girl in the district attorneys jurisdiction. Then he sits back while his brother-in-law takes over as the suspects lawyer.

title: The Assistants: The Motivator
description: The voice that echoes across the practice field, that seems to be coming from a megaphone, belongs to Kerry Coombs, the special teams coordinator and cornerbacks coach.

title: Republicans Name 23-Year-Old to Head Youth Outreach
description: Seven months after a report described the Republican Partys image as old and detached from pop culture, it has hired Elliott Echols, 23, to serve as its first national youth director.

title: This Week's Movies: Oct. 24, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on "Blue is the Warmest Color," "The Counselor" and "The Square."

title: Corrections: October 25, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Visiting Nurse Service Cuts 500 Workers
description: The Visiting Nurse Service of New York laid off 500 employees on Wednesday, part of the fallout from state scrutiny of enrollment practices that drew fit elderly people into programs meant for frail and disabled patients.

title: Political Nonprofit Groups Skirt Disclosure Rules
description: A Republican political consultant raised money to oppose Californias Proposition 30, which would raise taxes on the wealthy, and to support Proposition 32, which would prohibit unions from using automatic payroll deductions to contribute to political campaigns.

title: Ohio States Staff Offers a Mix Thats Unmatched
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Urban Meyer started with a notepad, the first page blank. He scribbled OC and drew a line underneath. Same with DC. And OL.

title: Soliciting Millions From a Koch
description: A donor working with Anthony Russo called and e-mailed Charles Koch several times, seeking a contribution of several million in the effort on Proposition 32, according to an e-mail obtained by investigators.

title: Returner, Receiver, Rusher. Anything Else You Need?
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Josh Cribbs can be unpredictable on the field, where defenders are uncertain of how he will attempt to elude them and of where he will line up for the next play. The Jets hope to put Cribbs in several situations where he has space to use his legs. Those legs once made him one of the most dynamic players in the N.F.L.

title: Disturbing Aliens, Some From Space
description: It was all Nelson Eddys fault. Seventy-five years ago, at 8 oclock on the evening of Oct. 30, 1938, millions of Americans tuned in their radios to listen to NBCs Chase and Sanborn Hour, a popular variety show starring the ventriloquist Edgar Bergen and his dummy Charlie McCarthy. When Bergen and McCarthy finished their first sketch  a routine about trick-or-treating  the announcer passed the microphone to Eddy, a booming baritone then starring with Jeanette MacDonald in a series of MGM operettas.

title: Garden Renovations Come With a Tug of War
description: The $1 billion renovation of Madison Square Garden was unveiled Thursday, and there is much to admire about it, from the shiny lobby with its innovative 600-foot ceiling video screens to the steel-and-concrete bridges built high over the playing surface.

title: Drone Issue Hovers More Than Ever, Even as Strikes Ebb
description: LONDON  For years, American drone strikes in Pakistans tribal belt have been the subject of what might be termed a wink-and-keep-moving approach between the leaders of both countries.

title: Indignation Over U.S. Spying Spreads in Europe
description: BERLIN  Fury over reports that American intelligence had monitored the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel spread from Germany to much of Europe on Thursday, plunging trans-Atlantic relations to a low and threatening to recast the United States and President Obama from friend and ally to cyberbully.

title: The Toll of War
description: Millions inside Syria are struggling to find adequate food as government-run bakeries that provide bread have closed during the conflict.

title: Rethinking the Oklahoma Border (This Time Its About Water)
description: LAKE TEXOMA  Inside a dimly lit water-pumping station that juts over choppy waters, Denise Hickey toes an imaginary line that has fueled real disputes over water, oil and property taxes, dating back to the Louisiana Purchase.

title: Hardships Mounting for Refugees Inside Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Some five million Syrians are now refugees in their own country, many living hand-to-mouth in vacant buildings, schools, mosques, parks and the cramped homes of relatives. Others are trapped in neighborhoods isolated by military blockades, beyond the reach of aid groups. Already desperately short of food and medicine as winter closes in, they could begin to succumb in greater numbers to hunger and exposure, aid workers say.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 25, 2013
description: It is as if we are living on Jupiter or Mars. Everyone is looking at us from the window and we are in a separate world. Everyone left us alone, every single person on this planet.

title: Beltran, Sore but Eager, Returns as Fans Exhale
description: BOSTON  For Cardinals fans, it was a depressing sight: with their team already trailing the Red Sox in the second inning of Game 1, Carlos Beltran, St. Louiss switch-hitting star, was clutching his ribs in pain. He had just crashed into the short bullpen wall while saving his team the indignity of allowing a grand slam to Bostons David Ortiz.

title: Money Plays a Critical Role in Texas State Races
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: If You Build It on Public University Campuses, 1 Percent Must Be Public Art
description: Like giant Mardi Gras masks, four seven-foot-tall faces of woven bronze peer westward from a lawn outside Talkington Hall, a recently opened student residence building on the Lubbock campus of Texas Tech University.

title: With a Plants Tainted Water Still Flowing, No End to Environmental Fears
description: TOKYO  For months now, it has been hard to escape the continuing deluge of bad news from the devastated Fukushima nuclear power plant.

title: Instagram Will Begin Showing Ads in the Photo Stream
description: You knew it had to happen eventually: Instagram is getting ads.

title: Few Clues to the Spot Seen Round the World
description: BOSTON  Tyler Melling is a Class A pitcher who was 3-4 this season with a 4.93 earned run average. Because he is employed by the St. Louis Cardinals, who turn prospects of all pedigrees into stars, there is a strong chance Melling will somehow win 15 games in the majors next season. For now, his position is whistle-blower.

title: Court Upholds Life Sentence for Bo Xilai
description: Updated, 11:55 p.m. EST | The black van entered the courthouse compound around 9:40 a.m. on Friday. It was one in a line of other police vans. Journalists armed with telephoto lenses outside the courthouse in Jinan, Shandong Province, took photographs. Those pictures, once posted online, ignited the speculation: Was Bo Xilai in the van?

title: On Twitter, Eavesdropper Reveals Former N.S.A. Heads Train Chat
description: WASHINGTON  It was just a background conversation on the Acela train ride north on Thursday.

title: Dispute Over Canadian Senators Expenses Balloons Into Larger Political Scandal
description: OTTAWA  It began as a seemingly mundane dispute over expense claims from four members of Canadas Senate, an appointed body rife with patronage and long a source of minor scandals. And while the amount of money involved is not vast, it has become a major political scandal for Canadas prime minister and his government.

title: Bob Greene, Jazz Pianist, Dies at 91
description: Bob Greene, a pianist who was so besotted by the controlled yet fevered jazz of Jelly Roll Morton that he abandoned a writing career to perform the Jelly Roll canon and spread the Jelly Roll gospel, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Amagansett, N.Y. He was 91.

title: In Quake-Prone Israel, Public Is Advised to Take Cover, This Time Outside
description: JERUSALEM  For years, Israel has worked to educate its citizens to rush off the streets and take cover inside buildings during rocket attacks. But this week, the Home Front Command, the military department responsible for civil defense in times of war or national emergency, began a new public awareness campaign instructing people to run outdoors.

title: A Marionette Production of Sleeping Beauty, Created With Centuries-Old Techniques
description: The Milanese artisans of Carlo Colla & Sons Marionette Company who create sets, bodies and tiny costumes will also serve as puppeteers in a performance at the New Victory Theater in Times Square, beginning Nov. 1.

title: The Midterm Grade for HealthCare.gov
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: A Warning on Chemical Peels
description: In the late 19th century, German scientists discovered that an easy-to-make acid could rather neatly peel off a layer of skin cells. They promptly marketed it for skin rejuvenation. Today, that compound, trichloroacetic acid, or TCA, is widely used by dermatologists both to brighten up aging faces and to remove damaged skin cells, including precancerous ones.

title: Word of the Day | cohort
description: cohort \ko-hort\ noun

title: Portugal: Investigators Reopen Case of Missing British Child
description: Portuguese prosecutors on Thursday reopened an investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann from her British parents hotel room six years ago, when she was 3. The case, one of the most notorious recent child-abduction cases in Europe, was formally closed in 2008. But after a campaign by the girls parents, Kate and Gerry McCann, British and Portuguese investigators began reviewing the evidence two years ago and independently uncovered new leads. In July, British officials opened a formal investigation, and now Portugal has followed suit. Portuguese investigators did not specify what the new leads were, but according to the police in London they are separate from the ones being followed in Britain. Teams from both countries met a week ago to compare notes and to brief the McCanns on the progress. Madeleine disappeared on May 3, 2007, from an apartment in a resort in Praia da Luz, Portugal, while her parents were having dinner at a nearby restaurant.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: This Time, Error Benefits Cardinals
description: BOSTON  The St. Louis Cardinals returned to playing the brand of baseball they cherish: clean and crisp, coolheaded and clutch. And it still was not working.

title: If We're Spying, Are We Still 'Allies'?
Trottergate Raises Questions of Reckless Consumption
description: Just how many pig trotters can a Communist Party official devour?

title: Iraq: U.S. Pledges $1 Million to Help Relocate Iranian Exiles
description: The United States announced Thursday that it would contribute $1 million to a United Nations trust fund to help resettle Iranian exiles in Iraq who have been housed in Camp Hurriya, a former American military base near Baghdad. In a statement on the State Departments Web site, Marie Harf, a spokeswoman, said resettling the exiles in other countries was the only lasting means of guaranteeing the safety and well-being of those residing in Camp Hurriya.

title: Mr. Ortiz, a Modern Version of Mr. October
description: BOSTON  They are all scattered now, the legends of the fall of 2004. All except David Ortiz, who welcomed back seven of his former teammates before Game 2 of another World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals on Thursday at Fenway Park. Then he reprised what he did that October.

title: Video Shows Violent Demolition Standoff
description: A video circulating widely on Chinese Web sites shows the police clashing with people attempting to block the demolition of a hotel in the southern city of Nanning. The police said Thursday that they had fired tear gas and rubber bullets after coming under assault from people throwing Molotov cocktails, according to a report in the Beijing Times.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Bravo) STYLED TO ROCK Twelve burgeoning designers compete to become the newest member of Rihannas team as they undertake weekly challenges to imagine looks for celebrity guests. The music producer Pharrell Williams, the model Erin Wasson and Mel Ottenberg, Rihannas stylist (above left with Ms. Wasson, center, and Rihanna) serve as the mentors. But only half the contestants will be selected to display their designs for the client. In addition to a job with Rihanna, the winner will be awarded $100,000 and a fashion feature in Glamour magazine.

title: Week 8 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Cowboys (4-3) at Lions (4-3)

title: Amid New Storm in U.S.-Europe Relationship, a Call for Talks on Spying
description: BERLIN  While President Obama has tried to soften the blow, this weeks disclosures about the extent of Americas spying on its European allies have added to a series of issues that have sharply eroded confidence in the United States leadership at a particularly difficult moment.

title: News Quiz | October 25, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Iraqi Athletes Find a Haven in Beijing
description: For Iraqi athletes, dreams of competing at the highest levels of their sport can be thwarted by the simplest of hurdles, like being able to reach the gym.

title: Scenes From the International Contemporary Art Fair in Paris
description: PARIS  Has anything struck you? an interviewer with a video camera asked an elegant woman in a sea of galleries at FIAC, the French international contemporary art fair, which runs through Sunday. A few objects here and there, she said matter-of-factly in French. They manage to make posie du rien, poetry out of nothing.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Oct. 25, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | How to Haunt a House
description: In House Haunters, Steven Kurutz visits some haunted houses and talks to their creators.

title: A Conversation With: Human Rights Activist Sima Samar
description: Sima Samar, 56, is a well-known human rights activist from Afghanistan. A doctor by training, she founded the nonprofit Shuhada Organization, which has provided health care and education to Afghan women and girls since 1989. After the fall of the Taliban, Ms. Samar entered politics and became the countrys first minister of womens affairs. She heads the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission, which monitors human rights abuses across the war-torn country and also looks at educational programs, especially for women. She is also the United Nations special rapporteur on human rights for Sudan.

title: Spectacle Within an Argentine Limousine
description: Myriam Meloni didnt plan to use a chauffeured limousine to whisk her around Buenos Aires to photograph all stripes of Argentine limo-dweller.

title: Whats Your Favorite Restaurant?
description: Is there a restaurant you love to visit, whether because the food is fantastic, or because its just a familiar and pleasant place to go with friends or family? What is unique about it?

title: Samsungs Turn to Apologize to Chinese Consumers
description: While many consumers are debating the price of a latte after Chinese state television accused the coffee chain Starbucks of grossly overpricing its products in China, another global brand has been dealt a similar blow.

title: New York Today: Obamas Here
description: Updated 12:20 p.m. | All week long, one Brooklyn high school has been buzzing.

title: Kenyan Deputy Leader Dealt Blow at Hague
description: PARIS  The International Criminal Court on Friday told Kenyas deputy president, William Ruto, that he must attend most of his trial at The Hague, overturning a ruling that let him be present only on key occasions.

title: A Woman, Her Dog and a British Sports Car Dream Fulfilled
description: On a recent autumn day, Sue Howard, a sculptor from New Jersey, sat in the drivers seat of her fully restored 1963 Type 14 Lotus Elite Series-2. Her 6-month-old black miniature poodle, Draper, sat next to her, his tongue lapping at the wind. The days drive would be an hourlong journey on country roads to the Performance Garage Club in Frenchtown, N.J., where Ms. Howard houses a neat collection of British sports cars.

title: North Korea Hands Over Six South Korean Detainees
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Six South Koreans who had been held in North Korea on charges of illegal entry returned to their home country on Friday, after the North released them in a gesture that could help ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Norway Rejects U.S. Request to Help Destroy Syrian Chemical Weapons
description: LONDON  Citing regulatory constraints and time pressures, Norway said Friday that it had turned down an American request to help destroy chemical weapons as part of the effort to dismantle Syrias arsenal of toxic munitions.

title: Daily Report: Twitter Sets a Price for Its I.P.O.
description: Twitter took the first steps in the pricing of its eagerly awaited initial public offering on Thursday, setting a price range for its shares that was below what some analysts had expected, Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel report.

title: Two Stabbed to Death in Forbidden City
description: Two people were stabbed to death on Friday in the Forbidden City, a vast complex in Beijing of vermilion-painted imperial halls and stone courtyards that is now one of the capitals biggest tourist attractions.

title: Raising The Medicare Age, Revisited
description: Back in 2011, we almost had a grand bargain whose centerpiece would have been a rise in the Medicare eligibility age. Liberals were horrified, but it actually would have happened if Republicans hadnt balked at the idea of any revenue increases at all.

title: A Bronx Start, Then a Life in Israel
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Twitter Aims for $10 Billion Valuation
description: TWITTER AIMS FOR $10 BILLION VALUATION | Twitter on Thursday set an expected price range for shares in its initial public offering that was below what some analysts had expected, Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel report in DealBook. The social media company said it planned to sell 70 million shares at $17 to $20 each. At the midpoint of the range, the I.P.O. would raise about $1.3 billion and value Twitter at about $10 billion, excluding options. Including options and restricted stock units, Twitter would be valued at more than $12 billion.

title: Folding a Neighbors Laundry
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Anxious Parent Daily
description: When I was pregnant with my first son, I spasmodically clicked through to every parenting/pregnancy newsletter that landed in my in-box and obsessed over its contents until I was a twisted skein of parental anxiety. These days, I reflexively delete those same newsletters without reading, but that doesnt stop me from internalizing their frequently fear-mongering headlines and prognosticating doomsday contents:

title: Editing Microsoft Word Files on an Android Tablet
description: Q. I dont have a subscription to the Office 365 site, so whats the easiest way to read and edit Microsoft Word documents on an Android tablet?

title: How an Indian Strangers Blood Saved a Young Pakistani in Delhi
description: I ended up in India, oddly, because I could not get to Pakistan. I had lived half my life in Pakistan. Both of my parents are Pakistani, with family roots in and around the city of Lahore as far as either one could see. But I am a citizen of America. I was born in the United States and had spent the other half of my life living in this country. I was a few hours drive from New York when the planes struck in September 2001.

title: The Tweets That Roared
description: MEXICO CITY  Well call it tweet diplomacy.

title: F.D.A. Bids to Regulate Animal Food, Acting After Recall and Deaths
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that would govern the production of pet food and farm animal feed for the first time.

title: In Store | Waris Ahluwalia Opens an Old-World Market in Venice
description: Think of Waris Ahluwalia, the jeweler, actor and man-about-every-town, as a modern-day Marco Polo, bringing back implements of leisure from foreign ports of call: Morocco, Bali, India, Sweden, Lebanon. Next month, he opens his House of Waris Rare shop inside the library of Venices lavish Gritti Palace hotel. Im not just interested in well-designed trophies, he says. Whatever we stock should serve an actual purpose. He steers away from comparisons to Pariss Deyrolle or any upscale curiosity boutique, talking instead about revisiting ancient trade routes. In some ways this project is the culmination of a three-year expedition he began with the Luxury Collection, which owns the hotel and commissioned Ahluwalia as its global explorer. Everything sold at the shop  engraved tumblers hand-blown in Murano, vintage Fortuny fabrics fashioned into stuffed animals  is the type of affectionate object one might imagine, say, Ernest Hemingway gifting his mistress. Ahluwalia has stocked the shop with unique goods from artisans both emerging and established, including his own fine jewelry. You cant just ogle and awe, he says about these collectibles. You must engage as a patron. Its not just the items that are unique  so too are the people who make them.

title: Off the Charts: The Long and Short of Unemployment
description: Long-term unemployment  defined as people who have been out of work for at least a year  remains elevated in the United States, and is also a problem internationally.

title: For Some, Joblessness Is Not a Temporary Problem
description: MOST Americans who lose their jobs these days are able to find new ones quickly. But those who do not are likely to remain unemployed for a long time.

title: In Our Pages: October 26
description: 1913 Spanish Cabinet Resigns Office

title: The Light Touch of Sure Hands
description: It was a few years back that Richard Curtis  the writer behind such artfully accented guilty pleasures as Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill  began to mull the Meaning of It All.

title: Why So Few Women in the Panthon?
description: HOUSTON  In the politics of national identity, as with the politics of real estate, there are three cardinal rules: location, location, location. Few events better illustrate this truth than the current debate in France over whose earthly remains best belong in the basement of a hulking neo-Classical pile with a fissuring dome and bricked-up windows that looms over Paris  otherwise known as the Panthon.

title: Ridley Scott: Most Novelists Are Desperate to Do What I Do
description: Your new film, The Counselor, stars Michael Fassbender as a lawyer who gets in over his head on a huge drug deal. Its pretty harrowing.  Theres a deep sense of stress that starts about halfway through, and you cant put your finger on why. When youre reading the script, its like theres a series of cogs in a very clever clock. The cogs start to engage and  a good word is dread. And the dread sets in, and it stays there.

title: Ty Tojo's Juggling Act
description: The 15-year-old became the world-record holder in the seven-ball backcross this year. He is headlining Big Apple Circuss Luminocity, opening Friday.

title: 'Transforming Still Life'
description: Kate Bryan, Head of Contemporary at The Fine Art Society Contemporary on Rob and Nick Carter's painting on exhibit at the Frick Collection, "Transforming Still Life."

title: Listening to the Roar of 1920s New York
description: In 1929, New Yorks Noise Abatement Commission outfitted a truck with microphones and sound recording devices to measure the citys din.

title: The 10.13.13 Issue
The Lobbying Lobby Fights Back
description: Batali perfects the martini; Rihannas grade-school grammarian.

title: The Harvard Doctor Who Accidentally Unleashed a Zombie Invasion
description: Roughly two years ago, one of the most popular radio programs in America finally alerted the country to the coming zombie apocalypse. The weekend host of the radio program, Ian Punnett, was interviewing me, a Harvard Medical School physician and national expert on the compelling world of zombie neuroscience. Punnett asked me to help make sense of a new and terrifying threat to our planet, and I told him what I had learned from a discovered manuscript penned by a doctor from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who had succumbed to a zombie plague while studying its origins. The newly uncovered disease was called Ataxic Neurodegenerative Satiety Deficiency syndrome (A.N.S.D.), I explained, and the C.D.C. expert worried that the disease had been engineered by nefarious hedge-fund managers, in hopes that the stock market would plunge and become vulnerable to manipulations as the chaos spread.

title: Who Made That Coffee Lid?
description: In the late 1970s, when you ordered coffee to go, you usually had to tear a hole in the plastic lid if you wanted to drink through it. This maneuver was so awkward that you risked burning your hand. So in the 1980s, a number of food-packaging engineers tried to fix the problem. William and Kenneth Dart, of the Dart Container Corporation, created one of the first of a new breed of coffee-cup lids, filing a patent in 1981 for a plastic disc with a press-down tab that acted like a valve. The inventors called this feature a lip-engaging buttress; you pushed on it with your upper lip to release a gulp of coffee. Once you finished drinking, the tab snapped back into place to prevent spills. (Kenneth Dart, who made a fortune in this and other business ventures, later renounced his citizenship and moved to Belize, where he was exempt from U.S. taxes.)

title: Does the Golden Rule Hold Up in Modern Society?
description: The Golden Rule (usually defined as One should treat others as one would like to be treated) is attractive to people as a guiding principle for ethical conduct. However I feel that in our diverse, modern world, it is less than ideal. By assuming other people should be treated the way I want to be treated, it imposes my preferences and values on those around me. Wouldnt a better rule be One should treat others as they want to be treated?GARRETT FRY, MONROVIA, CALIF.

title: Hunting a Chimp on a Killing Spree
description: I raised the gun as the chimpanzee inspected a bunch of bananas, close enough that I could hear him softly grunting. Taking aim, I leaned back against a tree to control my trembling. My weight made the giant banana leaves rustle overhead, and he turned to face the noise. He walked unsteadily a few feet in my direction at first, clutching a bunch of bananas to his broad chest. Then he dropped the fruit and broke into a four-limbed run straight at me.

title: The Past Can Hold a Horrible Power
description: A man returns to his hometown after 20 years abroad. Something is clearly amiss. Neighbors are unaccountably hostile. The family farm is seemingly under siege. His estranged brother greets him with an ax in hand for a reunion rendered all the more tense by a rock crashing through the window.

title: Today in Small Business: Involuntary Entrepreneurship
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Israel's Duel on the Sun
description: TEL AVIV  Israel goes off daylight saving time on Sunday, like countries in Europe do. The clock will take a small step backward, but Israel will take a giant leap forward.

title: Think Back: America's Immigration Debate
description: The Timess Sam Tanenhaus explains government efforts to keep immigrants out of the country and links President Reagans amnesty for Latino Americans to todays debate.

title: Before Malala
description: NEW DELHI  Ever since Malala Yousafzai recovered from her shooting by the Taliban last year, she has been universally honored: As well as a nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize, she has been given everything from the Mother Teresa Award to a place in Time Magazines 100 Most Influential People in the World.

title: Clearing the Air in China
description: CAMBRIDGE, Massachusetts  IN the northeast Chinese city of Harbin last week, the air pollution was so thick that schools were closed, traffic became gridlocked and flights in and out of the metropolis were canceled. For years, severe air pollution and rising carbon emissions have been downsides to Chinas economic growth, even as that growth has lifted more than 600 million people out of poverty.

title: Seeing You Seeing Me
description: It was her derrire that first caught my eye. Specifically, it was the way the camera captured the pretty teenagers rear end in Blue Is the Warmest Color so that it was centered and foregrounded in the frame. It is a lovely derrire, no question, round, compact and firm, and I became well acquainted with how it looked whether tucked into snug jeans or perched prettily in the air when Adle, whos 15 when the movie opens, lies splayed sleeping face down in bed, as young children often do. The director, Abdellatif Kechiche, I realized fairly quickly, likes a tight end.

title: Dear Mr. President
description: The Letters of John F. Kennedy, to be published on Tuesday, includes correspondence to and from Harry Truman, Winston Churchill and Nikita Khrushchev, about nuclear weapons, the Cuban missile crisis and other momentous subjects. It also contains responses like the one Kennedy wrote to a young girl in 1961, which begins, I was glad to get your letter about trying to stop the Russians from bombing the North Pole and risking the life of Santa Claus. Martin W. Sandler, the books editor, estimates that two million letters came in and out of the White House during Kennedys presidency. Of course I didnt read two million letters, he told me in a telephone interview, but I went blind reading a hell of a lot of them.

title: How Did It All Happen?
description: President John F. Kennedy once remarked that in 1914, with most of the world already plunged in war, Prince Bulow, the former German chancellor, said to the then-chancellor Bethmann-Hollweg: How did it all happen? And Bethmann-Hollweg replied: Ah, if only one knew. If this planet is ever ravaged by nuclear war, Kennedy went on, if the survivors of that devastation can then endure the fire, poison, chaos and catastrophe, I do not want one of those survivors to ask another, How did it all happen? and to receive the incredible reply, Ah, if only one knew.

title: If Only One Knew
description: World War I continues to exert a powerful pull on the popular imagination, especially in Britain, France and Australia, which, although victorious, suffered much more heavily in the trenches than did the late-arriving Americans. (There is less appetite for remembrance in the states that lost  Germany, Austria, Russia, Turkey.) Its ravages formed a backdrop to the television series Downton Abbey and to the movie and play War Horse, and they are being recounted anew in a profusion of books tied to the wars centenary next year.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE OLD WAYS: A Journey on Foot,  by Robert Macfarlane. (Penguin, $18.) Macfarlanes expansive travelogue takes him from the British Isles to the West Bank and the pilgrims paths of Spain and the Himalayas. With a command of natural history, cartography, geology and literature, he tries to read landscapes back into being  sailing in the Atlantic and matching strides with footprints made 5,000 years ago.

title: Editors Choice
description: ROTH UNBOUND: A Writer and His Books,  by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) This clever account is an authorized critical life of the old school, but invaluably topped up with reported comments from the Roth of today.

title: Inside the List
description: People Person: Brandon Stanton, the man behind the documentary photo blog Humans of New York, has just released his first book  also called Humans of New York  and it makes its debut on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. Stanton, a 29-year-old Georgia native, started photographing strangers in 2010 after finding his way to New York from Chicago, where he had recently lost his job as a bond trader. My mom basically thought this was my glorified way of not working, he told ABCs Nightline last month. Like, oh, Brandons in New York taking pictures of people on the street and putting them on Facebook, you know what I mean? That description isnt far off the mark, actually. But it misses the primal voyeuristic appeal of Stantons blog, which only increased after he started interviewing his subjects and including short quotations or anecdotes with their portraits. (Q. Where are you from? A. Russia. If you see a doctor smoking, hes from Russia.)

title: Twitter Visits Wall St. to Preview I.P.O. Roadshow
description: Twitters roadshow may not get under way until next week, but on Friday, bankers and the public got a taste of how the company plans to pitch itself to investors.

title: Video Reviews of Blue Is the Warmest Color, The Counselor and The Square
description: In this weeks video, Times critics discuss the coming-of-age drama Blue Is the Warmest Color, the thriller The Counselor and the documentary The Square. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: On Beauty | Two-Tone Eye Shadow, Double the Effect
description: This season opposites attract, as eyes are dusted with complementary colors for a moody two-tone effect.

title: Morrissey on Morrissey
description: Slates Jessica Winter and The Timess Ben Ratliff discuss Autobiography, the new memoir by the polarizing British pop star.

title: Traveling Players
description: The young performer at the center of Daniel Alarcns wise and engaging new novel, At Night We Walk in Circles, isnt the only one acting. The book is full of players and posers, among them a widow who writes to the newspapers in her dead husbands name and mourners who performed their sadness flamboyantly, pushing the very limits of realism. Even the elusive narrator, a magazine writer, is playacting, pursuing a story that is unlikely ever to see print.

title: Restless Romantic
description: Surprise is the keynote of the best travel writing. The travel writer should be knowledgeable but not an expert, open in mind and body to the unforeseen twists of serendipity. But what we most require from travel writing, as opposed to mere guidebooks, is that elusive quality Nick Carraway defined as romantic readiness. Few 20th-century figures combined these traits in a more appealing package than the English writer Patrick Leigh Fermor, Paddy to his many friends, who died in 2011 at the age of 96. One of these was Diana Cooper, a famous beauty who turned up in the fiction of Evelyn Waugh. Now Artemis Cooper, her granddaughter, has written an affectionately intimate, informative and forgiving biography of Dianas complicated friend.

title: Her Dynasty
description: For historians, there is no more powerful aphrodisiac than an exciting topic buoyed by a raft of unexploited sources, raising the prospect of a revisionist look at an important figure or even an entire era. There are few leaders in modern Chinese history more layered with prejudice begging to be stripped away than Cixi, the dowager empress who ruled China for almost half a century until her death in 1908. For decades, she was condescendingly referred to in the West as the Old Buddha, the She Dragon, the usurper of a throne over whose disintegration she presided.

title: Root Notes
description: In Tony Palmers film A Time There Was . . . , Leonard Bernstein describes Benjamin Brittens music as seemingly decorative, positive and charming, and its so much more than that. You become aware of something very dark. He was a man at odds with the world in many ways. And he didnt show it.

title: The Governess and the Ghost
description: Upon the death of her father, bookish, dowdy Eliza Caine answers an ad for a governess position at Gaudlin Hall, a rambling pile in the outer darkness of Victorian-era Norfolk. Eliza  totally alone in the world, her sole companions the protagonists of Dickens, her recent dreams filled with dark graveyards and irregular vistas  seems primed for a richly horrifying experience. Arriving soaked to the bone and in the dead of night, the new governess of Gaudlin finds not the greeting of a warm fire and a noble family at its ease, but two eerily well-mannered children alone in an otherwise empty house.

title: The Reawakening
description: Just give in  I finally did  to the rough-edged charms of Sara Wheelers latest hybrid of historical narrative and travelogue. Never mind that Wheeler, a British author whose previous book, Terra Incognita, chronicled her adventures in Antarctica, commits the same sin as at least two of the six women writers she profiles: Fanny Trollope, whose withering account of life along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers, Domestic Manners of the Americans, infuriated American readers; and Fanny Kemble Butler, whose reflexively judgmental Journal of a Residence in America provoked a breach with her American husband. Wheeler seems not to have calculated the effects of her own gratuitous insults, whether aimed at the agreeable Fattytowns of the Midwest or the crap of contemporary America she encounters at a once-grand seaside resort community in Massachusetts. Even her praise can be faintly damning: On the whole Americans are a friendly, polite lot.

title: It All Adds Up
description: Recovering from an illness, I sat in my hospital bed reading Edward Frenkels book Love and Math. I was following along, scrawling equations on scratch paper when my doctor walked in and gazed at my work. Looks interesting, he said cheerfully. But when he came closer, he grimaced. Oh, yuck, its math, he said. Never was any good at math. I hate it! Then his smile reappeared. Hows your bowel? he asked.

title: On Guard
description: There are few jobs more toothless than those of museum guards. Their cautions are irksome, their inattention worrying, their reflexes dulled by the uneventful hours between bursts of activity. And yet, although poorly conditioned and compensated, they are called upon to protect rooms full of fragile, invaluable objects. Of those to whom little is given, much, apparently, is required.

title: Blithe Spirits
description: Metafiction is often more fun to write than it is to read. Everything on the page is the result of a series of strenuous choices, none inevitable, and reminding the reader just who made these choices (whether conscious or not) can be amusing, aesthetically useful and a great relief from the constraints of the traditional conventions of fiction. But intelligent readers may not need reminding, may even take it as an insult. They know who the puppets are and who the puppeteer. They have sought out fiction for a reason: quite often they simply wish the puppeteer would shut up, back away and get on with the storytelling.

title: Jamie Dornan Named as New Lead in Fifty Shades
description: The author of Fifty Shades of Grey, E.L. James, confirmed early reports that Jamie Dornan, an Irish actor and underwear model, has been selected as the new choice for the male lead in the movie adaptation of her erotic novel.

title: For 25 Days, Transsexual to the Core
description: Fans of the band Thirty Seconds to Mars, accustomed to the long hair, scruffy cheeks, dark sunglasses and rockers rasp of its frontman, Jared Leto, may find him unrecognizable as Rayon, an AIDS patient and transsexual with a drug problem in the film Dallas Buyers Club. The waxed eyebrows and concave belly are just the beginning.

title: 1996 Grand Jury Indictments for JonBenet Ramseys Parents
description: Grand jurors who reviewed evidence in the death of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey indicted both of her parents for child abuse resulting in death and being an accessory to a crime.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A one-bedroom in Greenwich Village with a pair of fireplaces; a two-bedroom in Tudor City with a spacious kitchen; and a two-bedroom in a prewar building in Brooklyn.

title: Martinez, This One a Cardinal, Sets Them Down at Fenway
description: BOSTON  He looked so familiar here, on this mound, this lithe, 6-foot-nothing right-hander from the Dominican Republic, rocking back and hurling his whole self into every pitch, unleashing something fast and nasty toward home plate.

title: A First-Person Defense of Writing in Jesus Voice
description: Sarah Young may be hard to find, but her books are everywhere.

title: Popcast: Morrissey on Morrissey
description: This week: a paper trail into the heart of Morrissey.

title: Deal With Union Prevents Closing of Scottish Plant
description: LONDON  One of Scotlands largest manufacturing sites will remain open following a settlement of a dispute between the plants owners and the Unite trade union that preserves hundreds of jobs and provides the facility with millions of pounds in government support.

title: Developers Return to the Fray
description: They waited out the crash, dialed back their dreams and scrambled back to serve an inventory starved market.

title: Return to the Fray
description: In a bear market, most developers are not inclined to hibernate like bears as a strategy for self-preservation. Be they a Macklowe, Zeckendorf, Trump or Barnett, their modus operandi borrows from feline superstition: if they have nine lives, theyre going to spend them all building or go bankrupt trying.

title: France Begins New Anti-Islamist Sweep in Mali
description: PARIS  French soldiers in Mali have begun a major anti-insurgent sweep with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers, the Defense Ministry said on Thursday, calling it the largest operation to counteract a revival of Islamist militant activity since France intervened early this year.

title: Snowden-Inspired Play to Be Part of Donmar Warehouse Spring Season
description: LONDON  The Donmar Warehouse, which is currently presenting Phyllida Lloyds all-female production of Julius Caesar at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn, on Friday announced the theaters spring season program. It includes two new plays, Versailles, by Peter Gill and Privacy by James Graham, as well as Brian Friels stage adaptation of Turgenevs Fathers and Sons, directed by Lyndsey Turner.

title: After a Stroke, Running a Half-Marathon
description: Six years ago I suffered a stroke that forced me to relearn how to walk. The other day I ran a half-marathon.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jung Chang Reconsiders Cixi
description: This week, Jung Chang discusses Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Sara Wheeler talks about O My America!; and John Williams has best-seller news. Parul Sehgal is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review
description: This week, Jung Chang and Sara Wheeler.

title: Dropping a Name (Or, Goodbye, John Wesley Harding)
description: Theres a rich tradition of fake names in rock music. Assuming them is easy: Im Elton John now! Im Ringo Starr! Getting rid of them is much harder: ask John Cougar (who had to ease into being John Mellencamp by slow degrees) or The Artist Formerly Known as Prince about the irreproducible hieroglyph that never caught on.

title: Speaking to Young Latinos, in English
description: MIAMI  Since 1986, Jorge Ramos has anchored the Univision networks 6:30 p.m. news broadcast, a vital source of information for the nations 50 million-plus Spanish speakers. But this week, his routine will change in a way that could have profound consequences not just for him but also for the American media landscape.

title: Women on the Verge of a Moral Crisis, as Set to Song
description: Brandy Clark 12 STORIES

title: Such Stuff as Dance Is Made On
description: Shakespeare, who turns 450 in April, doesnt seem to have lost any power to inspire creators in every art form. Dance is no excaption. Choreographers have been turning to his plays at least since Jean-George Noverre created Antony and Cleopatra in the 1760s, and theres barely a midlevel ballet company today that doesnt perform a version of Romeo and Juliet.

title: An Eternal Youth, Now 90
description: Like everybody else, I think Im never going to die, the composer and diarist Ned Rorem said, warming instantly to the subject of a recent interview: his 90th birthday. Thats sort of an unrealistic answer, and 90 is realistic, he continued. Everyone else can be 90, but not me.

title: Immigration Poses Threat of Another Republican Rift
description: WASHINGTON  A push to bring immigration legislation to the House floor, led by an unusual coalition of business executives, prominent conservatives and evangelical leaders, threatens to create another schism in the Republican Party and could have a noticeable effect on campaign contributions before the midterm elections.

title: Image of the Day: October 25
Updates on Americas Persistent Air and Water Pollution Challenges
Can't Go Without: Gabrielle Hamilton
description: Packing for visits to Rome with the chef and restaurant owner.

title: For Sebastian Vettel, the Coronation Awaits
description: Officially, Sundays Formula One race just outside New Delhi is the Indian Grand Prix, the 16th event of the season counting for the series World Drivers Championship.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: An 1882 Victorian in Larchmont thats fully renovated but retains original details; and a waterfront house in Fairfield that includes three fireplaces, two terraces, and a private dock.

title: BMW Releases Its New 2 Series Coupe
description: BMW announced Thursday details of its new 2 Series coupe models, the successors to the 1 Series cars introduced in 2004. The official debut of the 2 Series will be in January, at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

title: End of a Line Reflects a Weakened Peugeot
description: PARIS  The last car rolled off the assembly line at PSA Peugeot Citrons factory in Aulnay-sous-Bois on Friday, marking the end of four decades of production at the auto plant on the outskirts of the French capital.

title: Feeling For
description: From a Wednesday Addams-style Peter Pan collar to glitzy jewels fit for a Disney princess, here are some costume staples that will remain highly wearable parts of your wardrobe long past Oct. 31.

title: Bale Could Start for Real Madrid in Clsico
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The attention will understandably be on the newcomers Saturday, as the Brazilian star Neymar and the Welsh wing Gareth Bale are set to play key roles in their first Barcelona-Real Madrid Clsico game. But while Neymar works his way into the Barcelona attack and Bale eases into the Madrid midfield, the long-running comparison between their top teammates, Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo, continues unabated.

title: 5 Signs That Its Time to Seek Outside Help for a Struggling Child
description: The current open question in the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming brought forth some of the most helpful advice Ive ever seen from a crowdsource. I asked, How do you know when its time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond her years?

title: WQXR to Celebrate Polish Music With Online Festival
description: If youve been eager to brush up on your expertise in contemporary Polish concert music  a repertory that is plentiful and varied  now is your chance: Q2, the Web station run by WQXR, is presenting Celebrating Poland: Lutoslawski, Penderecki and New Music Now, an online festival that includes three 24-hour marathons between now (the first is on Friday) and Nov. 12, to be followed by a concert Webcast on Dec. 13.

title: Grand Jury Urged Charges in JonBenet Ramsey Case
description: DENVER  Nearly a decade before DNA evidence cleared the parents of JonBenet Ramsey in the killing of their 6-year-old daughter, a grand jury pursuing the case decided to indict the couple on charges of child abuse leading to the girls death, according to documents unsealed on Friday.

title: CommScope, Backed by Carlyle, Has a Rocky Debut
description: Private equity firms have been eager to sell companies to public investors this year, with the stock market on a tear. But on Friday, one company sold by the Carlyle Group had a rocky start.

title: Big Ticket | A Nascar Star Sells for $25 Million
description: An elegant apartment at 15 Central Park West with treetop vistas of Central Park just outside and a host of sophisticated customizations inside  like a built-in sushi bar in the great room overlooking the park  sold for $25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price for the 3,454-square-foot unit when it entered the market in May was $30 million, and the monthly carrying charges are $7,221.80.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jung Chang Reconsiders Cixi
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Orville Schell reviews Jung Changs Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China. Mr. Schell writes:

title: Skills Practice | Making a Presentation on Health Topics, Using the PechaKucha Method
description: Feeling stressed? Cant sleep? Too much homework? Students the world over complain of these problems, and this week weve suggested an exercise that can help them both research some solutions and learn a new presentation skill in the bargain.

title: Rituals and Restaurants in Rome
description: On the back of a motorcycle with my soon-to-be husband, who at the time was my secret Italian lover in New York, is how Gabrielle Hamilton, chef of the New York restaurant Prune, said she discovered Rome.

title: Inside the Walls of Fez
description: We spotted the craftsman first, alone in his workshop, a cubby barely larger than a closet. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of such stalls in the medina in Fez, an ancient city within a city of winding paths and centuries-old artisanship, where vendors tout their leather and oils on every corner. But this stall stood out. It was nearly bare, not crammed as most of the others were with doodads to be fussed and negotiated over. A few tools hung on the wall, alongside the red Moroccan flag with its green pentagram, and some old photos of the craftsman, now white-haired and wearing a traditional long robe.

title: Off Ireland, a Rugged Journey to Remote Ruins
description: If anyone can explain why 10,000 people each year make the stomach-churning passage to Skellig Michael, a desolate rock pinnacle eight miles off Irelands southwest coast, John OShea can.

title: The Gun Report: October 25, 2013
description: Because the Gun Report is a daily accounting, the details of the shootings we cover arent always filled in by the time we publish. So the report is rife with phrases such as unidentified victim and police have no suspects. In the days that follow, the identities of the victims and perpetrators, and the circumstances behind the violence, are revealed, but by then were covering a slew of new shootings.

title: Competing to Tell Jack the Rippers Story
description: Just before 9 p.m. on a recent Thursday in London, five guided tour groups, about 150 people in all, converged on a nondescript courtyard on the eastern edge of the central financial district. Some tour guides wore 19th-century top hats and long, dark cloaks. Others grasped photographs of mortuary corpses. And each guide jostled for the best spot: near the tiny flower bed in the far corner where, in 1888, Jack the Ripper murdered a prostitute named Catherine Eddowes  slitting her throat, slashing her face, pulling out her innards and walking off with her uterus.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Tell Her Im Not Here
description: Obama gets an earful from Merkel on American surveillance.

title: The Long Trip Into a Dark Season
description: I told myself I wasnt going to write about any more memoirs, at least not for a while. The act of honoring thy aging father or mother has already generated so many magazine articles and op-eds and blogs and books, including Katie Hafners account of moving her mother into her home and Katy Butlers story of her familys struggle to deactivate the pacemaker that kept her fathers heart beating while his brain and the rest of his body failed.

title: When Eat It Isnt the Answer: The Halloween Candy Dilemma
description: I have long been an advocate of a relaxed approach to what some parents term the problem of Halloween candy. Its Halloween, I wrote for Slate in 2011:

title: Storm Still Brews Over Scalding Coffee
description: Even 21 years later, its clear that the case of Liebeck v. McDonalds hasnt lost its power to provoke. The Retro Report video about the lawsuit featured here this week has been watched more than a million times on several websites and attracted hundreds of comments, many vehement.

title: For Cool Autumn Days, Warm Red-Cooked Flavors
description: The Chinese technique red cooking involves simmering meat with soy sauce, sugar and sweet aromatics like star anise and cinnamon. It happens in a wok, but instead of a quick high-heat stir-fry, it is a slow braise, more like a savory stew.

title: Eat Your Broccoli
description: When my son was younger he was happy to eat broccoli every day, as so many children are. I would steam it and drizzle vinaigrette over it; that was the way he liked it best. But by the time he was a teenager he grew tired of broccoli; he never wanted it, so I stopped buying it. He has always been a good vegetable eater, so I didnt mind; I didnt really miss broccoli either.

title: Plan to Tax the Rich Could Aim Higher
description: Bill de Blasio has made New Yorks Tale of Two Cities a centerpiece of his Democratic campaign for mayor. One New Yorker is rushing past an attended desk in the lobby of a majestic skyscraper, Mr. de Blasio said in a speech at the New School earlier this year, while a few miles away, a single mother is also rushing, holding her two young children by the hands as they hurry down the steps of the subway entrance.

title: Feeling For | Halloween-Inspired Finds You Can Wear Year-Round
description: Halloween is the one time a year when character dressing is O.K. for everyone, no matter what your age. But most style icons are better left to adults than pint-size trick-or-treaters. Wear these modern pieces to pay tribute to Edie Sedgwick, Andy Warhols legendary Factory girl; Wednesday Addams, the gothic adolescent with the braided pigtails immortalized by Christina Ricci in the 1991 film The Addams Family; and Disney princesses like Cinderella, Aurora and Ariel, those prim leading ladies who always get their happily-ever-afters. As an added bonus, all of these items are perfectly wearable the other 364 days of the year, long after the ghosts and goblins have been put to rest.

title: The Latest Getaway Holiday? Halloween
description: Halloween is no longer just one night of dressing up and eating too much candy on a school night. Like most holidays, its been amplified with a monthlong roster of events aimed at kids both young and old. For travelers, that means sweet deals from hotels and attractions looking to capitalize on those who want to celebrate all things darkly hallowed.

title: Its Time to Parse Pole-Dancing
description: Pole-dancing may be a recent fitness fad, right up there with aerial aerobics. But for the Filipina performance artist Eisa Jocson, its the politically complex subject at the heart of her one-woman show Macho Dancer. The title refers to a form of nightclub entertainment in the Philippines performed by young men for both male and female clients. Ms. Jocson, who has a background in visual arts and exotic dancing, intends to raise questions about gender, seduction and the economics of performance.

title: From Catchy Jolts to Minimalist Buzz
description: How do you want your jolts? Steady state, like a finger stuck in a socket? Or frantic, angular and quick changing, like a haywire carnival ride? Both kinds are available this week from experienced administrators of their chosen thrills: Thee Oh Sees, from San Francisco, and Melt-Banana, from Tokyo.

title: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Pink Pompon
description: The pitch reads: Whats worse than mean girl cheerleaders? How about resurrected mean-girl cheerleaders with supernatural powers? Find out more at Thursdays United States premiere of the horror film All Cheerleaders Die at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center at Lincoln Center. In this satire of high school horror movies, witchcraft is employed to resurrect the vengeance-seeking cheerleaders who died in a car accident caused by the football players.

title: Bachs in His Blood. Beethoven, Too.
description: The masterly pianist Andras Schiff, admired for his elegant and intelligent artistry, is also an insightful lecturer, as he demonstrated some years ago in a series of lecture-recitals on the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas at Wigmore Hall in London. (Audio recordings of those talks are available at Wigmore Halls Web site.) New Yorkers will have a chance to hear Mr. Schiffs engaging commentaries on music when he gives a lecture-recital on Tuesday at the 92nd Street Y. Mr. Schiff will discuss Bachs influence on Beethoven by comparing Bachs Goldberg Variations and Beethovens Diabelli Variations, playing excerpts from both. (8:15 p.m., Tuesday, Kaufmann Concert Hall, 212-415-5500, 92y.org; $62, $25 for people 35 and under.)

title: Recalling the Wave of Water and Panic
description: As the first anniversary of Hurricane Sandys onslaught of the New York region arrives, the Museum of the City of New York, with help from the International Center of Photography, is opening an exhibition of photographs whose size and scope seem intended to rival that of the storm itself. Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy, which began with an open call for images, draws on work submitted by more than 900 photographers, many of whom, as the museum says, were personally and profoundly impacted by the storm.

title: A Grand Old Name With a Gory Past
description: Investigation Discovery, the true-crime network, has made theme packaging of mayhem an art form, with shows grouping murdered beauty queens, dates that turned deadly or bad behavior involving twins. Its midnight offering to close out Halloween night on Thursday is a classic example: Bloody Marys, about murders linked only by the coincidence that they were committed by women named Mary.

title: The Great Republican Makeover
description: Big news from the Great Republican Makeover: The Grand Old Party has hired a 23-year-old to reach out to young people.

title: No More a Slave
description: Most people who study the Civil War are familiar with the classic autobiographical narratives, written by such luminaries as Frederick Douglass and Booker T. Washington. But there are countless other unpublished works, written by lesser-known men and women who successfully navigated the treacherous path from slavery to freedom. One of these, Come On, Children: The Autobiography of George Washington Fields, Born a Slave in Hanover County, Virginia, recently rediscovered in museum archives in Hampton, Va., is a particularly stirring and valuable account of a slaves path to freedom.

title: A Menagerie of Music Lives in a Box
description: In the annals of American music in the 20th century, no record label had a more unlikely origin or trajectory than Paramount Records. Founded in 1917 as a subsidiary of the Wisconsin Chair Company, which was eager to supply content for the phonographs it had begun to manufacture, Paramount took a scattershot approach to its business, recording more than 10,000 tracks of blues, gospel, hot jazz, treacly pop, and hillbilly and ethnic music before going bust during the Depression.

title: Hockney Returns
description: A look at works in a David Hockney exhibition in San Francisco.

title: Mariel Hemingways Smoothie Therapy
description: The first morning I visited Mariel Hemingway  actor, author, activist, granddaughter of Ernest  I watched as she and her partner, Bobby Williams, prepared a smoothie. This is part of her daily routine: because she comes from a family with a history of mental illness, addiction and suicide (a legacy explored in Running From Crazy, a new documentary directed by Barbara Kopple), health and wellness and the preventive measures that promote both are at the center of her life  and thus at the center of my article about her in this Sundays magazine.

title: Promised Fix for Health Site Could Squeeze Some Users
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that it would fix problems in the federal health insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, just two weeks before the deadline to sign up for coverage to replace health insurance policies being canceled because they do not meet new federal standards.

title: Hes Back, in a Defiant Blaze of Color
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Although it would be hard to tell from the volume of his work, David Hockney, now 76, has had a rough year. Last October, this celebrated British artist had a stroke, which left him unable to complete his sentences for a time. In March, one of his studio assistants in East Yorkshire, part of a tight-knit circle of aides, collaborators and former lovers, died in Mr. Hockneys home after drinking drain cleaner on the heels of a drug binge. And slowly but surely, Mr. Hockneys hereditary deafness has progressed to the point that he depends heavily on two hearing aids and still needs to lean in for conversations.

title: Scene City: Giorgio Armani Day in New York
description: A fashion extravaganza for Giorgio Armani at the SuperPier, with a marathon show, exhibition and celebrity-filled nightclub.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: The Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that would govern the production of pet food and farm animal feed for the first time. Related: Nearly 600 dogs and cats have died and more than 3,600 have been sickened after eating tainted jerky treats made in China since 2007.

title: For Better and for Worse, Long Before the Wedding
description: Jay Nickerson spent 20 years listening to a friend, the comedian and actress Suzanne Whang, talk about her relationships, silently thinking that she could do so much better than this guy, whoever the guy happened to be at the time. During those conversations, Mr. Nickerson, an actor turned special-education teacher, kept pushing away the nagging feeling that maybe he was the right guy.

title: Twitter Tantalizes, but Beware the I.P.O.
description: PERHAPS youve heard that Twitter is planning an initial public offering.

title: Giorgio Armani Runway Show Is an Extravaganza of Extremes
description: Fifteen years ago, Giorgio Armani brought a fashion show to New York City with a set and dinner so dazzling that fashion people with long memories still talk about it giddily. And that only happened after the police in Paris, where he had originally planned to show his Emporio Armani collection that year, shut down his production (with a reported cost of $1 million, two black tents and 1,200 guests waiting outside) at the last moment, citing security concerns. Mr. Armani retaliated by bringing the whole shebang to Wall Street, barely flinching at the expense.

title: How No-Strings Aid Affects the Poor
description: GiveDirectly is an unusual charity. Donors give money. GiveDirectly, well, gives it directly to the poor. It does not tell them how to spend it or when to spend it. And it does not give money to a specific group, like mothers or farmers or the elderly.

title: When Frankenstorm First Caught Our Eye
description: From time to time, the weather-forecasting authorities issue warnings of some type.

title: A Bachelorettes Night (or Four) to Remember
description: When Tracy S., a 33-year-old creative agency account director, began thinking about her bachelorette party, she knew getting out of town was a must.

title: Even More Money Coming to an Election Near You
description: After the 2010 Citizens United ruling, which allowed corporations and unions to overwhelm federal elections with unlimited independent expenditures, the courts began overturning reasonable state-specific campaign finance rules  in Montana, for instance. Now it is New Yorks turn.

title: Review: 2014 Acura RLX P-AWS Advance
description: Steering with the front wheels has worked well since the day automobiles were invented. Is 4-wheel steering better? Tom Voelk drives the P-AWS equipped 2014 Acura RLX to find out.

title: Publishing Executive at Amazon to Depart
description: Laurence J. Kirshbaum, a stalwart of New York publishing who joined Amazon in 2011 to lead its New York publishing imprint, will leave the company in January, Amazon said on Friday.

title: The Un-Facebook I.P.O.
description: Twitter seems to be avoiding Facebooks overreach  so far. The microblogging sites provisional pricing for its initial public offering is $17 to $20 a share. Calculations by Reuters Breakingviews suggest thats modest by the metrics available, though without profit these require a leap of faith. At least Twitter seems to be avoiding the premature heights of Facebooks flawed debut last year.

title: Health Insurance Options Arent Limited to Government Exchanges
description: WITH so much attention being paid to the troubled debut of the Obama administrations health insurance exchanges, another alternative has largely gone unnoticed: unless you live in Washington, D.C., or Vermont, you can also buy insurance outside the exchanges  by going directly to insurance brokers, agents or company Web sites.

title: The Grand Animal Costume Party
description: ITS every travelers little dream.

title: Spicy Mussels With Cauliflower
description: The sand and beards that come with mussels can be intimidating for the home cook, but cleaning them can be easy. Throw in some vegetables, and the results are delicious.

title: Review: 'Blue Is the Warmest Color'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Blue is the Warmest Color."

title: Were There Ever Liquor Carts at The Times?
description: Whenever the topic of liquor comes up at the magazine  as it always does, if for no other reason than that we publish a regular Drink column and two Food & Drink issues every year  my colleagues and I start talking about the liquor carts of yesteryear that were wheeled around the newsroom of The Times like the coffee carts of today. Everyone is so certain they existed, perhaps convinced by the drunken desk workers in Mad Men that all midcentury offices were filled with booze. Of course there was hard stuff on the drink carts! And yet, I havent been able to find any proof that that was ever the case.

title: Mussels, Difficult? A Myth Without Legs
description: I have a friend who makes kimchi from scratch, can produce molecular-cuisine-inspired foams and geles and has even deep-fried an entire Thanksgiving turkey on his petite patio.

title: Movie Review: 'The Counselor'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Counselor."

title: 'Tea'
description: New York Progress, an independent expenditure group backed by some labor unions, released an ad attacking Joseph J. Lhota.

title: Abramson and Tanenhaus on J.F.K.
description: Jill Abramson, The Timess executive editor, and Sam Tanenhaus discuss the many books devoted to John F. Kennedy, how his presidency changed the news media and the effect the assassination had on her.

title: A Bull Market in Overlooked Aston Martins
description: Prices for postwar Aston Martins have been very strong, with the recent peak coming at the Bonhams sale in Britain last May. There, the 1960 DB4GT Jet coupe with coachwork by Bertone sold for $5.2 million, the highest price ever paid for an Aston Martin road car.

title: Beyond Bond
description: As Aston Martin celebrates its centennial, we look back at some memorable models.

title: Scent and the City
description: SUFFERING from writers block? Try sniffing rotting apples.

title: An Undiluted Pedigree in the Hamptons
description: A pastoral and historic 3.7-acre piece of prime residential and agricultural property on James Lane near Town Pond, the idyllic gateway to the Village of East Hampton, is about to enter the market for the first time in more than three centuries.

title: Weekend Reading: 2 Key Players in JPMorgans $13 Billion Deal
description: At the end of a conference call on the night of Oct. 18, JPMorgan Chases chief executive and the attorney general left their top lieutenants to hash out the details of a tentative $13 billion settlement. The talks, led Tony West, the associate attorney general at the Justice Department, and Stephen M. Cutler, JPMorgans general counsel, could still fall apart over how much wrongdoing the bank will admit on its questionable mortgage practices.

title: Lincoln Center to Expand Discount Ticket Sales
description: Music and dance fans have long wished for the equivalent of the theater worlds TKTS booth, where tickets to concerts could be found at reduced prices. Lincoln Center announced on Friday that starting Tuesday, the box office at the David Rubenstein Atrium will sell discount tickets not only for events at Lincoln Center (which began offering discounted same-day tickets in 2010), but for a weeks worth of performances at New York City Center, the 92nd Street Y, Merkin Concert Hall and Miller Theater.

title: New York State Seeks to Scale Back Student Testing
description: The New York State Education Department, responding to concerns that standardized exams in reading and math have become excessive and unwieldy, will seek to ease the burden of testing.

title: Video: Acura Brings 4-Wheel Steering to the RLX
description: Automotive innovation over the years has given us seat belts, hybrid powertrains and  most importantly  cup holders. Steering? It has changed somewhat, but for more than 100 years most cars have done just fine with the front wheels handling that job.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 25
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include urban running crews, a sugar refinery in Brooklyn and same-sex marriages in New Jersey.

title: Potential Merger Would Vault Law Firm to Top 10 in U.S.
