description: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | The law firms Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe and Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman are in advanced merger talks, with an announcement of a deal expected as early as next week.

title: A Fitful Start-Up That Became a Symbol of Privilege
description: From its founding a century ago, Aston Martin created cars meant to appeal to the sporting instincts of upper-class Britons who appreciated their design, exclusivity and, perhaps, scarcity. Judging by todays models, which start at more than $115,000 and stretch to the brink of $300,000, the formula has proved durable.

title: Where St. Vincents Once Stood
description: The developers of a 200-unit condominium complex on the site of the former St. Vincents Hospital campus, which to its opponents was a symbol of the overdevelopment of New York during the Bloomberg era, hope to leave its contentious past behind.

title: Three Cellos in Conversation, Together, Alone and Intense
description: For all his vast experience in the orchestral world, the conductor Charles Dutoit has not been a particular champion of living composers. Over the years, though, certain pieces have clearly excited him, including the Polish composer Krzysztof Pendereckis Concerto Grosso, composed in 2000 and scored for three solo cellos and orchestra. Mr. Dutoit conducted the 2001 premiere of this work with the NHK Symphony Orchestra in Tokyo and has presented it over the years with other ensembles.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Just Dropped In to Take Your Pulse
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As corporate entities go, the Volkswagen Group is known for carrying out its affairs with a certain deliberation  of setting goals, conducting extensive research and delivering on its objectives.

title: Taut Wires as a Foil for Curves
description: Brian Brooks has become as known for his sets as for his choreography. His latest work, Run Dont Run, which had its debut on Tuesday, seats audience members facing one another on two sides of the BAM Fishman Space. Across their field of vision stretch hundreds of strings, like a giants harp laid on its side.

title: THE MAKING OF
description: The Milanese artisans of Carlo Colla & Sons Marionette Company who create sets, bodies and tiny costumes will also serve as puppeteers in a performance at the New Victory Theater in Times Square, beginning Nov. 1.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Home Births Pose Special Risks
description: Women who choose to give birth at home may be increasing the likelihood of particular health risks in their babies.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Civil War Comes Alive in Artifacts
description: The overall history lesson in Civil War 360 is fairly elementary, but this three-part series, which begins Sunday night on the Smithsonian Channel, does a commendable job of elevating museum objects from dry collection displays to living pieces of the past. And the three celebrity hosts walking viewers through the episodes seem genuinely moved by what theyre seeing.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Excerpt, Letoile de Mer by Man Ray
description: An excerpt from the 1928 film, alternately titled The Starfish, starring Kiki, and based on a poem by Desnos.

title: U.N., Fearing a Polio Epidemic in Syria, Moves to Vaccinate Millions of Children
description: United Nations officials said Friday that they were mobilizing to vaccinate 2.5 million young children in Syria and more than eight million others in the region to combat what they fear could be an explosive outbreak of polio, the incurable viral disease that cripples and kills, which has reappeared in the war-ravaged country for the first time in more than a dozen years.

title: Rio Police Officer Is Indicted for Torture While Lecturing on Smart Policing in New York
description: A Brazilian police officer who spoke at a technology conference in New York on Tuesday about the potential of a new smartphone app to aid in the pacification of Rio de Janeiros lawless favelas was indicted the same day by prosecutors back home in connection with a notorious case of torture and murder by her unit in July.

title: Wake Up, Sleepyhead: A Virtual Poke to Drivers
description: As automakers rush to assign more driving chores to computers, researchers who analyze driver workload could be left shaking their heads. Studies have shown that too much help behind the wheel may not always be an advantage for safety.

title: On the Road to Autonomous, a Pause at Extrasensory
description: The self-driving car, whenever it arrives, is sure to be hailed as a breakthrough.

title: Obama, at Brooklyn School, Pushes Education Agenda
description: President Obama on Friday visited the innovative Brooklyn high school he praised in his State of the Union address this year, to deliver a message about the urgency of education reform in the global economy.

title: What If We Just Gave the Poor Money?
description: Can we reduce poverty simply by giving the poor money, with no strings attached? A new study from Innovations for Poverty Action, a non-profit research organization, found that cash transfers of $300 or $1,100 to 500 poor Kenyan families helped reduce hunger, improve living conditions and increase investment in livestock and small businesses.

title: Strange Goings-On in a See-Through House
description: In 1957, in an exchange that passed quickly into performance lore, the critic Louis Horst published a blank column in response to Duet, a Paul Taylor dance comprising stillness and set to John Cages 433. I thought with longing of Horsts gorgeous expanse of silence Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater, during Hans was Heiri by the Swiss duo Zimmermann & de Perrot  not because this physical theater work is minimalist, but for the opposite reason. Blankness seemed the only possible antidote to this relentlessly busy and manic spectacle; it was like the desire to slip into a hermetically sealed, fragrance-free chamber after shopping at Sephora.

title: Obama Visits Brooklyn High School
description: The president went to the Pathways in Technology Early College High School, which he mentioned in his State of the Union address this year, to talk about education.

title: New Bolt Service on the West Coast
description: Bolt Bus, the intercity bus line and transportation solution for cash-strapped college students and thrifty business travelers alike, is expanding its service to include three more cities on the West Coast. On Oct. 31, the big orange buses will begin a new route with stops in Los Angeles, San Jose and Oakland, Calif. In honor of the occasion, the company is selling one-way tickets on the new route for $1 to passengers who book travel within the first four days of service, Oct. 31 to Nov. 3.

title: Bill Sharman, Two-Time Basketball Hall of Famer, Dies at 87
description: Bill Sharman, who was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame twice, first as a sharpshooting guard who helped establish the Boston Celtics dynasty of the 1950s and then as a coach who led the 1971-72 Los Angeles Lakers to a record 33-game winning streak and the N.B.A. title, died on Friday at his home in Redondo Beach, Calif. He was 87.

title: Beyond the Velvet Rope, With the Bumps and Grinds
description: After serving as a Russian nightclub for the original incarnation of Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812, Ars Nova has undergone another extravagant transformation, this time into a velvet-swathed house of neo-burlesque called the Tim Tam Room.

title: Stricken, an Actor Stays in Character
description: If an actor is going to collapse onstage in the middle of a performance, he might as well pick an appropriate moment.

title: Steeped in Hip-Hop Lore
description: For a time after The Wire completed its five-season run on HBO in 2008, Spot the Wire Character was a fun parlor game. Actors so indelibly linked to those Baltimore street roles often ended up disrupting other perfectly calm environments: the corner boy Bodie (J. D. Williams) in a FedEx commercial; the reformed thug Cutty (Chad L. Coleman) on I Hate My Teenage Daughter; and, of course, the ambivalent street recruit Michael (Tristan Wilds) on the too-clean reboot of 90210.

title: Calcutta Pairs at the Cavendish Tournament
description: The premier events at the Cavendish tournament in Monaco were the Calcutta Pairs. There were 16 entries in the womens and 60 in the open.

title: Pictures from the Week in Business
description: The jobs report delayed by the federal shutdown showed modest growth, but carried warning signs, and states joined together to promote electric cars.

title: Surviving the Etiquette Demon of Steubenville
description: Hang up the white gloves, Emily Post. Retire the oyster fork, Amy Vanderbilt. And step gracefully aside, Letitia Baldrige. Mrs. Mannerly has invited herself to your party and brought her 1967 etiquette class from Steubenville, Ohio, to Hartford.

title: Bringing New Life to Druids Sacrifice
description: I have had the enduring  and enduring and enduring  pleasure of seeing all seven performances of Bellinis Norma so far this season at the Metropolitan Opera. (What can I say? I like Druids.)

title: JPMorgan Reaches Deal With Agency Over Loans
description: JPMorgan Chase has secured important concessions in a $13 billion settlement over its mortgage practices, allowances that could ultimately reduce the banks financial burden and leave the government itself on the hook for a small portion of the cost.

title: A Farewell to Pianists Who Aim for the Gut
description: Few chamber groups deploy their musicians as oddly as the Bowed Piano Ensemble. The 10 players, students led by the composer Stephen Scott, stand around, and sometimes under, a concert grand, armed with items of all kinds  nylon fishing line, piano hammers, guitar picks, strips of paper, rolls of plumbers tape  and reach into the instrument to draw sounds from its strings. The music is tactile and otherworldly, sometimes percussive and often lyrical.

title: Through a Dance Kaleidoscope, the Throbbing Grooves of Souls Godfather
description: How many choreographers does it take to celebrate the many sides of James Brown? To do justice in dance to his incalculably huge and global influence? According to James Brown: Get on the Good Foot, an enjoyable miscellany of a dance revue that had its premiere on Tuesday at the Apollo Theater, the answer is 10.

title: After a 100-Year Sleep, a Beauty Wakes to Vampires
description: That the full title of Matthew Bournes Sleeping Beauty includes the name of its director and choreographer isnt vanity. Its truth in advertising. As do Mr. Bournes Nutcracker and Swan Lake (the international success, with the male swans), his Sleeping Beauty retains the Tchaikovsky score of this classic ballet. His version is still a fairy tale about a princess who sleeps under a spell for 100 years. But it truly is his. The subtitle is telling: A Gothic Romance.

title: Movie Review: 'The Square'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Square."

title: Prices That Fly Under the Headlines
description: LET us, for the moment anyway, dispense with the phrase record prices and forget about all the auction frenzy  the $120 million paid for a pastel by Munch; the $106.5 million for an oil painting by Picasso; the $104.3 million for a Giacometti sculpture. These numbers seem more like money in a Monopoly game than reality.

title: Serving Museum Patrons Something More
description: HIS voice barely audible above the screech of power tools, Saul Bolton  chef and founder, with his wife, Lisa, of the Michelin-starred Saul restaurant in a modest storefront in Brooklyn  was not only describing the construction site around him, but also the newest embodiment of his dream.

title: Welcoming Art Lovers With Disabilities
description: ON a recent Friday night, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York held its first public exhibition of original art made in its Seeing Through Drawing classes. Participants  all blind or partly sighted  created works inspired by objects in the museums collection that were described to them by sighted instructors and that they were also allowed to touch.

title: Auctions Organized by Theme, With a Narrative Pull
description: FOR Swann Auction Galleries, the inspiration for its Nov. 5 sale, The Armory Show at 100, wasnt far away. The auctioneers premises sit right across the street from the 69th Regiment Armory in New York, where the famous International Exhibition of Modern Art, whose displays of nontraditional paintings from Europe shocked the public and changed the course of American art, made its debut.

title: Pigeon Racing: Faster and Farther, but Fair?
description: They no doubt would plead ignorance. Or blame their coaches. Or say they were victims of jealous rivals who spiked their water bottles with banned substances, or claim that the liquid they had been squirting under their tongues was only flaxseed oil, not performance-enhancing drugs meant to turn them into rockets.

title: A Revamped Home for Philadelphias Favorite Son
description: WHEN the Benjamin Franklin Museum opened in the wake of the American Bicentennial in 1976, it had to be one of the funkiest museums ever conceived for the National Park Service.

title: Artists Take Up Digital Tools
description: PEOPLE have this idea about digital that you just press the button and the machine spits something out, which really couldnt be further from the truth, said Richard Dupont, a sculptor who makes startling distortions of the human form.

title: Photos of Luminaries, by a Luminary
description: Pablo Picasso comes first in the lineup, facing the viewer, one hand on his forehead. He is followed by Max Ernst, sitting in his studio in a majestic armchair, a cloud of cigarette smoke circling his head. Next is Piet Mondrian, perched behind his easel in front of panels that form a grid reminiscent of his paintings. Then we come upon Jean Arp, peeking around one of his own curvy sculptures, only one eye visible.

title: At 80, Mnuchin Remains a Passionate Promoter of Postwar Art
description: SINCE Robert Mnuchin recently turned 80, some might expect him to be slowing down. Instead, he is speeding up, or at least starting a new chapter with the Mnuchin Gallery. He opened it this year after parting ways with Dominique Lvy, his partner at L&M Arts, a gallery that was a prominent player in the art market during the economic boom, bidding large sums at auction.

title: In a Blaze of Hope, Flickering Menace
description: Trouble breaks in great, surging waves upon the Irish family in Sean OCaseys classic Juno and the Paycock, now being revived with all the requisite big heart and black humor by the Irish Repertory Theater. The waters swirl most strongly around Juno Boyle, the matriarch of a small family barely subsisting in the strife-torn Dublin of the 1920s. And when you first glimpse the careworn Juno, portrayed by the veteran J. Smith-Cameron, you may wonder whether this petite figure with the haunted blue eyes has the fortitude to endure the worst, and then the worse than worst.

title: Miami Museum Celebrates the Art of a Crossroads
description: MIAMI  MIAMIS status as a transnational city is highlighted in the programming and collecting strategies of the new Prez Art Museum Miami, formerly the Miami Art Museum, which reopens Dec. 4 in a new location overlooking Biscayne Bay and bordered by MacArthur Causeway.

title: At Historic Homes, Unearthing a Deeper View of Slavery
description: TUCKED into suburban Lawrence, N.Y., in the southwest corner of Long Islands Nassau County, Rock Hall is a hard place to find. But despite its relative obscurity, this stately, 18th-century Georgian manor has a new and intriguing story to tell, thanks to evidence uncovered through recent archaeological work.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Brooklyn, Italy, Madagascar and the Vatican.

title: Esteem for the Art of the American West
description: THE art of the American West has long been honored in the states whose history it records, but it hasnt always been accepted in the larger art world. Thirty years ago, it was often seen as an out-of-touch genre, fed by a love of nostalgia and history.

title: Obama Visits a Brooklyn School
description: President Obama went to Pathways in Technology Early College High School, and spoke to students Friday afternoon.

title: A Portfolio That Surprises Even Its Creator
description: DISTINGUISHED architects often wait their entire careers for a big museum commission. Many are still waiting.

title: Rights Exhibit to Display Documents From the Mighty and the Modest
description: A COMPENSATION claim from a former slave. A World War II guide helping officers adapt to women in industry. A newspaper for Japanese-American internees in Oregon. Those will be among the artifacts on exhibit when a new National Archives gallery opens in Washington devoted to Records of Rights. The centerpiece will be an original 1297 Magna Carta, the only copy on public display in the United States.

title: From a Twitter How-To, Another Lesson
description: It was in the wee hours of Thursday when Bill Costello, known as @BC on Twitter, realized that something unusual was happening. His phone kept vibrating, notifying him of activity on his Twitter account.

title: In Dallas, 10 Sculptures for 10 Years
description: A LOT of museums celebrate important anniversaries with special exhibitions in their galleries, but not the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas. For its 10th year, it is going much bigger  to all of Dallas. It has commissioned 10 public sculptures by 10 artists at 10 diverse locations around the 385-square-mile city, all on view as of Oct. 19.

title: So Many Stories to Tell for Mets Digital Chief
description: AFTER teaching a generation of journalists at Columbia Universitys Graduate School of Journalism about how technology was changing journalism and how they needed to change along with it, Sree Sreenivasan became the Metropolitan Museum of Arts first chief digital officer in August.

title: A Tell-Tale Display Brings Words to Life
description: TORTURED souls, restless spirits and the fear of premature burial are familiar themes in the works of Edgar Allan Poe. The author of The Raven, The Fall of the House of Usher and The Tell-Tale Heart found the mysteries of the grave fertile ground for his gothic tales of terror.

title: Museum Explores The Power of Poison
description: IN an office of the American Museum of Natural History, a team of scientists, artists and multimedia experts were discussing what had poisoned Skippy, a cute Jack Russell terrier that had keeled over sick in his virtual backyard. Was it the chocolate he found in the garbage can? Did a snake, or a black widow spider, bite him? Or was a poisonous cane toad to blame?

title: A Concealed Voice Rings Loud and Clear
description: IM glad as heck that you exist.

title: Galleries as the Art Worlds Leading Indicators
description: TASTE in art is in constant flux. One seasons penchant for abstract paintings may be anothers fascination with chocolate Santas, or lead balloons, comic strips, or a less-is-more aesthetic. Steering through this weather are commercial galleries, in the thick of things, taking the art worlds pulse. Unlike museums, where exhibitions are planned years in advance, galleries can be more nimble, finalizing shows a couple of months ahead of time. Indeed, there is probably no better barometer of current collective rumblings than whats being shown at the top New York and Los Angeles galleries.

title: An Obscure Building Where Surrealism Thrived
description: IT has been 74 years since World War II fractured the Surrealist movement, forcing many of its artists to flee Europe for other parts of the globe. But now one of their earliest gathering spots in Paris will be resurrected, figuratively, in Surrealism and the Rue Blomet, from Friday through Dec. 13 at Eykyn Maclean gallery in New York.

title: Museums Draw on Events That Shaped the World
description: MOST curators strive for novelty when they are putting together an exhibition. Museums nearly always want to boast that a show is the first, the largest, the longest or the fill-in-the-blank-est. For the New-York Historical Societys latest attraction, The Armory Show at 100, however, a measure of success is how closely its curators can recreate the experience of this seminal 1913 exhibition.

title: Venturing Beyond Art, to Give Ideas Their Space
description: OVER the last decade, business incubators  open-office-plan hives where people, many of them young, gather to try to think up the next big app or social media revolution  have grown into a cultural phenomenon, a vision of capitalism as a kind of share-happy, postmillennial commune.

title: Oral Histories of Hurricane Sandy
description: Like most museums dedicated to history, the Hoboken Historical Museum generally waits until a memorable event feels somewhat distant before inviting the public to revisit it. Not so with Hoboken: One Year After Sandy, Lessons Learned About Preparedness, Resiliency and Community, an exhibition scheduled to open this weekend.

title: A Place to Stay, Surrounded by Works of Art
description: CLAUDE MONET and James McNeil Whistler made art at the Savoy, a luxury hotel in central London. Monet painted Thames views at the turn of the 20th century, Whistler earlier drew the hotels renovations and pigeons.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Value of a Twitter User, and Googles Potential Floating Data Center
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: A New Parking Spot for Wheels Coverage
description: Thank you for visiting Wheels. The regular features of this blog, including Monday Motorsports, the Wheelies news briefs and reports on auto industry developments including vehicle recalls and technology updates, can now be found on the Automobiles Web page.

title: Roma, Feared as Kidnappers, See Their Own Children at Risk
description: PARIS  For centuries across Europe, children were raised on folk tales with a disturbing message: Wander into the woods and you risk being snatched by Gypsies.

title: A Chinese Fable Pits the Sea Against the Sky
description: Even the darkest evil is brightly beautiful in The White Snake, a play that doesnt want a single scene to whiz by without a wow from the audience. More often than not, this bold show, in its first East Coast production at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, sparks that kind of excitement.

title: Seven Days of Style | Rihannas Abu Dhabi Moment, 50 Shades of Jamie Dornan and New Model Rules
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREOct. 19  25

title: For Jim Hodges, a Survey of a Career Reflecting on Life
description: IN 1986, when Jim Hodges had just graduated from art school, he regularly destroyed his own finished works.

title: Real Politician of Louisiana, at Home
description: People marvel at the resourcefulness  and Dickensian plight  of waste recyclers in Mumbai shantytowns, those so-called slumdogs who gather, sort, crush and reconstitute mountains of paper, plastics, metals and glass.

title: The Trial of Bo Xilai
description: An appeals court upheld a verdict of life in prison for Bo Xilai, a Chinese official who was once among Chinas highest-ranking Communist Party leaders.

title: Gay Couples, Choosing to Say I Dont
description: When the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act in June, Brian Blatz, 47, marched into the kitchen of Fiddleheads, the restaurant in Jamesburg, N.J., that he owns with Dan Davis, 58.

title: Seeking Alternatives
description: Alternative asset classes, once the purview of hedge fund investors, are increasingly held by the general public in alternative mutual funds.

title: Anchored to the Water
description: Ask anyone on City Island who Luis Menchaca is, and you will get a blank stare.

title: How the Budget Debate Could Help the Economy
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Crying Foul Over Baseball Pants
description: A look at how hemlines have changed over the years.

title: Friday Night Music: Company
description: Ive been neglecting this blog a bit this week, partly because of personal responsibilities and partly because Im slaving away on my IMF lecture. I havent been doing much searching for new music either. But for some reason I needed a Sondheim fix, and found this quite excellent performance with some truly unexpected people performing. Stephen Colbert?

title: A Thrill Now Sadly Rare
description: When I was growing up in Brooklyn, bats were common. They roosted in abandoned homes, in attics, in little-used garages or behind decorative window shutters in both the most affluent and the poorest neighborhoods. My summers were filled with bat sightings, as were fall evenings after my homework was done. That bats were familiars, or consorted with the dead, never occurred to me. I only wanted to see one up close.

title: Is Pre-K the Answer for Child Literacy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cunningham | Inked
description: A highlight of Paris Fashion Week is always the Rick Owens show, where many of his guests arrive wearing black.

title: Islamists Repress Syrias Citizen Journalists
description: Syrian media activists working to establish a credible alternative to the state broadcaster in areas of the country held by rebel groups were dealt a blow this month in the northeastern province of Raqqa, where a radio station that aired criticism of Qaeda-linked militants was closed down by the Islamists and one citizen journalist was kidnapped.

title: Bottled Water Sales Rising as Soda Ebbs
description: Few things are more American than Coca-Cola.

title: Law Reviews and the Students Who Run Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Accusations of Racism Haunting Russia
description: MOSCOW  Russias readiness to serve as the host of major international sporting events like the Olympics and the World Cup faced new criticism after a top player from Africa said he had been racially abused by fans during a Champions League soccer match here Wednesday.

title: Photography From Lori Goldsteins Styling
description: Lori Goldstein: Style Is Instinct is a new monograph of Ms. Goldsteins exploration of style.

title: Lori Goldstein: With Her Magic, Fashion Becomes Art
description: A Versace campaign inspired by Valley of the Dolls; a W shoot featuring a model in falsies and padded underpants; a fun-house pictorial resembling the fallout from an explosion in a sample room. These are some highlights of the 35-year career of Lori Goldstein, perhaps the most influential fashion stylist whose name youve never heard.

title: Baseball Pants, a Sore Sight for Eyes
description: Its the World Series again, time for that hallowed rite of autumn: the news-media debate over why no one watches baseball anymore. Is it steroids? Overexpansion? A failure to inspire home run dreams in LeBron James when he was 5?

title: At the Glsen Respect Awards, Hollywoods Elite Is Shaken by a Story
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Jim Parsons from The Big Bang Theory was seated at a center table. The Carrie actress Chlo Grace Moretz had been spotted swishing around in pink polka dots. The dreamy soccer star Robbie Rogers was there being, well, dreamy.

title: Finding Love, the Old, Shallow Way
description: A Pew Center report released last week found that Americans are more comfortable than ever looking for prospective partners online: 59 percent of those surveyed agreed that online dating was a good way to meet people, a jump of 15 percentage points since the last survey, in 2005. A major development in the new survey concerned the smartphone. In 2005, iPhones didnt exist. Now, according to the report, 1 in 10 American adults, age 25 to 34, use a dating app on their phones.

title: Ronan Farrow: The Youngest Old Guy in the Room
description: Wow, hes handsome, one dinner guest said, peering over a throng of photographers.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. When I grew up in the 1940s, buildings had dumbwaiters in the kitchen, which we lowered by rope to the basement for the super to dispose of our garbage. When did they become illegal?

title: Getting People Tricked Out for Halloween
description: Kodi Hadrick, 25, is the manager  or boss lady, as her business card has it  at Abracadabra NYC on West 21st Street, a three-level emporium of costumes, for sale or rent, makeup, wigs, magic supplies, props and other paraphernalia essential to the season. This time of year, it is less a job than a way of life; as Halloween approaches, the store is open from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. She lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn  In real estate they call it Clinton Hill, but its really Bed-Stuy, she said  with her boyfriend, Scott Bredengerd, 31, who works in film production, and their dog, Rocko, a pug-boxer mix.

title: In Williamsburg, Any Excuse to Eat Pie
description: With the ripening of apples, pumpkins and the like, fall is pie-eating season, and should you find yourself in Brooklyn, a pleasant place to eat pie is the Blue Stove bakery, at 415 Graham Avenue, in the expansionary eastern regions of Williamsburg. A simple storefront with a long communal table and an old blue stove in back serving as a coffee-condiment station, the bakery turns out breakfast every morning, along with a daily pie menu with offerings like plum crumble and rhubarb custard. At this time of year, of course, most customers  including two friends who wandered in to satisfy their pie craving  come for the seasonal autumn favorites.

title: A Touch of the Old Country
description: Moldova, in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, is the only restaurant dedicated to Moldovan cuisine in New York City.

title: Its Sisi-Mania, as Nationalist Fervor Sweeps Through Egypt
description: In the months since Egypts armed forces removed former President Mohamed Morsi and installed an interim government of their choosing, a nationalist fervor has swept the country, spurred on in part by a robust media campaign that has hailed the army as heroes and promoted an image of its commander, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, as a benevolent leader who stands beyond reproach.

title: An Intriguing Product Thats Too Complex for Many
description: The sales pitches go something like this: A mutual fund that promises to zig when the rest of the stock market zags. Bond funds that protect investors when interest rates rise. Access to the most sophisticated hedge fund managers in the country, even if youre not particularly wealthy.

title: Where the Hunt for Mamaliga Ends
description: In the heart of old Brooklyn, on a prosaic stretch of Coney Island Avenue that runs through Midwood, among auto body shops and fast-food joints and commerce catering to Orthodox Jews, you will find what looks like a village house in the old country, with a forest in back and a quaint monastery in the distance.

title: For de Blasio, a Wider Lead in Finances
description: Bill de Blasio has for weeks held an enormous lead in public opinion polls over his Republican opponent, Joseph J. Lhota. Now he also has a commanding financial advantage.

title: A Thief Struck Many Banks, but Never Took a Dime
description: There was an element of genius in the string of bank heists that played out in New York City for 11 weeks over the winter and spring. No alarms. No threatening notes, no messy dye packs. No one even noticed the thefts right off.

title: Paul Reichmann, Who Helped Develop the World Financial Center, Dies at 83
description: Paul Reichmann, the Canadian real estate developer who made and lost billions of dollars while transforming the skylines of Toronto, New York and London, died on Friday in Toronto. He was 83.

title: A Poet With Words Trapped Inside
description: Can computers talk black vernacular? This is a question that haunts Ntozake Shange.

title: For Shorter Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinals History Remains in the Details
description: ST. LOUIS  The apostrophe in the Baltimore Orioles alternate logo faces the wrong way. The Mets have no pattern for their choice of jerseys on any given day. The Philadelphia Phillies forgot to make a press pin for their last World Series appearance.

title: Europe Turns Its Eye to Migration Policies, Amid Another Sea Rescue
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders agreed Friday on a timetable for overhauling the blocs policy on migration and asylum just hours after the scale and urgency of the challenge were brought into stark focus by the rescue of more than 700 refugees overnight near Sicily.

title: Civilians Killed by Drones
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota Agrees to Settlement in Fatal Acceleration Crash
description: Toyota agreed on Friday to a settlement with the families of two women in a fatal crash the morning after an Oklahoma jury became the first to find the company responsible for the unintended acceleration of a car.

title: On Staten Island, Agonizing Over Staying or Going
description: Some homeowners in Oakwood Beach, which was heavily damaged during Hurricane Sandy, have been offered buyouts by the state.

title: Banks Midlevel Executive Becomes a New Face of the Housing Crisis
description: Fuld. Cayne. Mozilo. Mairone?

title: Stop the Killing of Birds
description: To the Editor:

title: Deciding Whether Its Lights Out
description: This is the way a neighborhood ends.

title: Tentative Approval for Faster-Acting Hepatitis C Drug
description: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously voted in favor of a hepatitis C drug from Gilead Sciences. All 15 members of the agencys panel of virus experts voted to recommend approval of Gileads pill, sofosbuvir, to treat several forms of the disease, which afflicts more than three million people in the United States. The agency is not required to adhere to the groups advice, though it often does. Current treatments can take up to a year of therapy and cure only about three out of four patients. Gileads daily pill can cure up to 90 percent of patients infected with the most common form of the virus in just 12 weeks. Gilead, based in Foster City, Calif., is one of a half-dozen companies racing to develop more effective treatments for hepatitis C. The agency is expected to make a decision on the drug by Dec. 8.

title: Roll Out the Health Care
description: If youre a citizen who tries to keep up with current affairs, your latest responsibility is having a strong opinion about the troubled rollout of the health insurance marketplace.

title: Lottery Numbers for Oct. 25, 2013
Getting It Shipshape Again
description: Last year on the evening of Oct. 29, Michael OKeeffe  Buzzy to virtually everyone who knows him on two continents  had devised a plan for how he would proceed. High tide was scheduled to arrive at Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, the site of one of Mr. OKeeffes businesses, the River Caf, around 9 p.m. He would stabilize the barge that housed the restaurant, deal with whatever potential repercussions he could, and then get in his car and travel up Third Avenue to 30th Street in Manhattan, where another one of his enterprises, the Water Club, also sat on the East Rivers edge. High tide was set to arrive there at 9:56 p.m.

title: A Little Miami Heat
description: I was about to hang up the phone when Donna Shalala, the former Clinton cabinet secretary who is now the president of the University of Miami, interrupted me. She had something she wanted to say before our interview ended.

title: The Ad Campaign: Group Backing de Blasio Tries to Shackle Lhota to Tea Party
description: Expectations were high for a windfall of outside political spending to bolster Joseph J. Lhotas candidacy for mayor of New York. But it seems that the elections single largest super PAC expenditure will benefit his opponent, Bill de Blasio. Tea, a ferocious attack on Mr. Lhota, began appearing on cable channels on Friday and will also be shown on broadcast stations. The ad was paid for by a political action committee supporting Mr. de Blasio, New York Progress, which is financed by several of the citys most powerful labor unions.

title: Hip-Hop Figure Gets Life Sentence for Drug Ring
description: A former rap music executive who for years faced allegations that he was connected to infamous killings of two rap stars was sentenced to life in prison on Friday for running a multimillion-dollar drug empire.

title: Almost a Year After Massacre, Newtown Begins Razing Sandy Hook School
description: Behind a black fence that blocks the view from outside, the school in Newtown, Conn., where 20 first graders and six employees were killed by a 20-year-old gunman in December, is being razed.

title: Reparations From Banks
description: The governments attempts to hold banks accountable for their mortgage practices may finally be paying off. On Friday, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay $5.1 billion to the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to resolve charges related to toxic mortgage securities sold before the financial crisis. That amount had been negotiated as part of a broader $13 billion settlement  yet to be finalized  between the bank and state and federal officials over the banks mortgage practices.

title: At Grambling, a Proud Football Program at Risk
description: GRAMBLING, La.  All week, the football team and the athletic department at Grambling tried to return to normal, even if normal as they knew it was chaotic and underfunded and conflicted.

title: The Grambling Football Boycott
description: For years now, observers of college football have been predicting  and in some cases rooting for  a players strike to protest that universities are getting rich from unpaid student athletes. Last week, a boycott finally happened, at Grambling State University, a historically black college in Louisiana, but the football players brought attention to an entirely different sort of problem: budget cuts that have hurt the entire university.

title: N.S.A. Snooping and the Damage Done
description: President Obama spent this week trying to persuade Americas close allies, France and Germany, that the National Security Agencys extensive eavesdropping in those countries is under adequate control. He was not entirely successful. His efforts to reassure President Franois Hollande of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany seem to have been as incomplete as the explanations the administration has given to the American public about the agencys excessive domestic surveillance.

title: Drug Tests Falter as Way for States to Deny Public Aid
description: With safety-net spending under review around the country, proposals to make welfare and unemployment checks contingent on drug testing have become a routine rallying cry in dozens of states.

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: 12 U.C.L.A. at 2 OREGON

title: Keeping Hope Alive for Autistic Boys Safe Return
description: It has been more than three weeks since Avonte Oquendo, an autistic 14-year-old, slipped out the front door of his high school in Long Island City, Queens, and disappeared without a trace.

title: Corrections: October 26, 2013
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Getting It Together
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Barry C. Silks puzzles are always an adventure. He includes a lot of very interesting words and phrases in his puzzles, and he keeps his entries neat and clean. The clues are tough, end-of-the-week CIPHERs, but undeniably fair. If you are going to venture into Saturday puzzle territory, this is the place to go.

title: Billionaires Row and Welfare Lines
description: The stock market is hitting record highs.

title: Deborah Turbeville, Who Turned Fashion Photography Dark, Dies
description: Ms. Turbeville, who was 81, suffused her fashion shoots with imagery steeped in decay, dissolution and melancholy.

title: Deborah Turbeville, Fashion Photographer, Dies at 81
description: Deborah Turbeville, who almost single-handedly turned fashion photography from a clean, well-lighted thing into something dark, brooding and suffused with sensual strangeness, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: Former Suspect to Testify in Patz Case
description: Lawyers for a man accused of killing young Etan Patz in 1979 have won a court order in Pennsylvania that will force a convicted child molester who was long a suspect in the case to testify as a material witness.

title: Much Left to Learn for Younger Version of Federer
description: Sports thrive on a good master-apprentice tale, and the story gets even better when the apprentice finds a way to snatch the stone from the masters hand and finishes off the upset.

title: Chinese University Defends Outspoken Teachers Firing
description: BEIJING  He lectured students about the trespasses of the Communist Party, publicly belittled the countrys mighty propaganda minister and issued frequent demands for an end to single-party rule in China.

title: A Face in Progress
description: Carmen Tarleton is adjusting to her new face since undergoing transplant surgery in February.

title: Mexican Writer Mines the Soccer Field for Metaphors
description: MEXICO CITY  IN trying times like these, when the anguish and uncertainty can be almost too much to bear, Mexico turns to him, its philosopher-fanatic, to make sense of the seemingly nonsensical.

title: With Whiff of Nepotism, Knicks Tiptoe Toward Opener
description: The Knicks wrapped up their preseason Friday night with their first game in what the organization has described, on an endless loop in recent days, as a transformed Madison Square Garden. The arenas billion-dollar renovation was on full display: a warren of refurbished suites, a pair of sky bridges with spectator seating, a modern video board, among other improvements.

title: For Victim of Ghastly Crime, a New Face, a New Beginning
description: THETFORD, Vt.  At 1:30 a.m. on Valentines Day this year, Carmen Tarleton left her rural home here and drove through the frigid dark to Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston. Her doctor had called hours earlier with the news she had been waiting for: a suitable donor had been found. She would get a new face.

title: Angry Over Syrian War, Saudis Fault U.S. Policy
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Saudi Arabia has abandoned its traditional policy of discretion in recent weeks, signaling deep anger at the Obama administrations Middle East policies and threatening to break with its most powerful ally and pursue a more robust and independent role in supporting the rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

title: Nets Williams Looks Sharp in First Preseason Action
description: MIAMI  For all the hoopla that has swirled around the Nets  the spectacular trades and signings that have star-stocked their roster  the fact remains that their fortunes are knotted to the mercurial point guard Deron Williams.

title: Insurance for Floods May Force Relocations
description: The number of properties in New York City that will be required to have federal flood insurance will nearly double in 2015, and the accompanying higher premiums may mean that many city residents will have to relocate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday.

title: 3 Children Die in Bronx Fire
description: Three children were killed and three other people were injured in a fire at a Bronx apartment building on Friday night, the Fire Department said.

title: Following Dear Leader, Kim Jong-un Gets Title From University: Dr. Leader
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Make that Dr. Kim Jong-un.

title: At Grambling, Struggles for a Tradition-Rich Team
description: A boycott by football players revealed the brutal financial constraints confronting Grambling, one of the best known historically black colleges.

title: Whats Wrong With Skippy?
description: A dog named Skippy shows signs of being poisoned, but he get better  and visitors to the American Museum of Natural Historys show, The Power of Poison, can try to figure out what happened to him.

title: In Spy Uproar, Everyone Does It Just Wont Do
description: WASHINGTON  The angry protests from Germanys chancellor over the National Security Agencys monitoring of her cellphone and Frances furor over the collection of data about millions of its citizens have obscured a new reality: The digital age has merely expanded the ability of nations to do to one another what they have done for centuries.

title: Chinese Company Falling Short of Goal for California Jobs
description: LOS ANGELES  At the height of the recession, Los Angeles officials spent a year and a half wooing a Chinese high-tech business to open its North America headquarters here, with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger traveling to China to persuade its executives.

title: League Plans to End a Longtime Relationship With Riddell, Its Helmet Maker
description: The N.F.L. will end its nearly quarter-century-long sponsorship with Riddell, the helmet manufacturer, at the close of the season.

title: Loss of Power in Georgia Can Bring Trial, or Worse
description: KUTAISI, Georgia  Three days before Georgias presidential election, Ivane Merabishvili, the former prime minister and still a leader of the countrys main opposition party, sat in a courtroom here, in the glass box reserved for defendants held without bail.

title: Detroit Manager Denies Role in Bankruptcy Filing
description: DETROIT  Kevyn Orr, the emergency manager for Detroit, testified Friday that he was not hired by Michigans governor to lead Detroit into bankruptcy court.

title: Earthquake, and Much Smaller Tsunami, in Japan
description: TOKYO  An earthquake with a magnitude of 7.1 struck off the coast of Fukushima early Saturday, triggering tsunami and evacuation advisories for a wide swath of Japans Pacific coast, but recorded waves were far smaller than the destructive tsunami that hit the region in 2011. The Tokyo Electric Power Company, which operates the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, crippled by the 2011 tsunami, said that it had temporarily pulled workers back from the waterfront to a fortified building at the plant but that there were no immediate signs of fresh damage.

title: Cruz Takes His Stand on the Road to Iowa
description: DES MOINES  Senator Ted Cruz, the Texas Republican who has left senior members of his party worried about the political fallout from the federal government shutdown, argued here Friday that the battle over the health care law would invigorate Republicans in next years elections.

title: Ortiz Will Play First Base for Red Sox in Game 3
description: ST. LOUIS  David Ortiz fidgeted, shuffling his feet at first base Friday at Busch Stadium. He bent his knees, leaned over and took grounders while wearing a windbreaker and a cold-weather cap.

title: Learning From Veterans, Giants Lineman Earns Trust and Playing Time
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a season filled with blunders for the one-win Giants, even the equipment staff is not immune.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 26, 2013
description: One of these days in the near future, when I start to cry or I laugh, youre going to be able to tell by looking at me how I feel.

title: Detained Chinese Reporter Makes Confession on State Television
description: A Chinese reporter detained last week for allegedly defaming a company has confessed on state television that he filed a series of stories containing false information in exchange for payment from an outside party. The detention of Chen Yongzhou, 27, has triggered an unusually vocal campaign by his newspaper, the Guangzhou-based New Express, which had published front-page headlines Wednesday and Thursday calling for his release.

title: Mary Finch Hoyt, Aide to Rosalynn Carter, Dies at 89
description: Mary Finch Hoyt, who served as press secretary to Rosalynn Carter when she was first lady, died on Oct. 17 at her home in Washington. She was 89.

title: Florida: Guilty Verdict Reached in Murder of Casino Founder
description: Anthony Ferrari, a former owner of a Miami Beach security company who had ties to the Gambino crime family, was found guilty Friday of first-degree murder and conspiracy in the 2001 shooting death in Fort Lauderdale of Konstantinos Boulis, a restaurateur who founded SunCruz Casinos. Earlier this week, Mr. Ferrari took the stand, against his lawyers advice, and pinned the murder on Adam Kidan, a business partner of the former lobbyist Jack Abramoff, and on one of his own former employees. I never thought about killing anybody in my life, he said. Its just not in my DNA. Mr. Ferrari, 56, faces the death penalty when he is sentenced Dec. 16.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) CLOUD ATLAS (2012) Tom Hanks and Halle Berry, above, take on multiple roles  for Mr. Hanks, a Hawaiian goatherd, a scientist, a London gangster and a 19th-century quack; for Ms. Berry, a muckraking journalist, a researcher and the wife of a temperamental maestro  in this adaptation of David Mitchells 2004 novel, written and directed by Lana and Andy Wachowski and Tom Tykwer. Cloud Atlas is a movie about migratory souls and wayward civilizations, loaded with soaring themes and flights of feeling, as vaporous and comprehensive as its title, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that perhaps the films achievement should be quantified rather than judged in more conventional, qualitative ways. This is by no means the best movie of the year, but it may be the most movie you can get for the price of a single ticket. Its six sections also star Doona Bae, Jim Broadbent, Keith David, Hugh Grant, Susan Sarandon, Jim Sturgess, Hugo Weaving and Ben Whishaw. Together the filmmakers try so hard to give you everything  the secrets of the universe and the human heart; action, laughs and romance; tragedy and mystery  that you may wind up feeling both grateful and disappointed.

title: Tennessee: Recruiter Was Disciplined Before Shooting at Armory
description: A National Guard recruiter was charged Friday with shooting three of his superiors after he was told that he was being punished for misconduct. A criminal complaint filed against the recruiter, Sgt. First Class Amos Patton, says he fired a handgun and wounded his commanders during a meeting Thursday at an armory near Memphis. The filing did not detail the infractions that prompted the conference with Sergeant Patton, who was facing a reduction in rank and a possible dismissal from active National Guard duty. Investigators on Friday increased the number of soldiers hurt in the shooting because a bullet grazed an additional officer. All are expected to recover.

title: After an Attack, Receiving a New Face
description: Carmen Tarleton, who was beaten and burned beyond recognition by her estranged husband, is one of the few to undergo a full face transplant.

title: Giants Hillis Goes From Watching Monday Night Football to Playing in It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Peyton Hillis was walking alongside a New Jersey highway looking for dinner. Cars zoomed past at 60 miles per hour as Hillis warily navigated the edge of the roadway.

title: Nudging Girls Toward Computer Science
description: My Its the Economy column on Sunday looks at why traditional economic incentives alone dont seem to be enough to encourage more women (or men, for that matter) to go into highly lucrative computer science jobs, which can often provide great flexibility to boot.

title: One Play Saved a Game and May Have Saved the Jets Season
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  At the time, in the afterglow of the Jets season-opening victory, the play was hailed for what it was: a paragon of hustle and relentlessness and effort, of the way Coach Rex Ryan expects his team to compete on every snap. Enthusiasm lingered for about a day, the video clip shown in meetings and highlighted in the Play Like a Jet montage, and then it waned, lost to the churn of the season.

title: Living in a World of Fantasy Can Be Dehumanizing
description: When is a mans flesh and blood, pain and joy reduced to nothing but statistics: soulless numbers to be bought and sold?

title: Macrofoundations (Wonkish)
description: John Quiggin has a fun post debunking the notion, all too common among economists, that macroeconomics  the study of inflation, depressions, and all that  is somehow flaky and unworthy of the fields grandeur, that only microeconomics, derived rigorously from rational behavior, is real science. Keynesian macro, in particular, is often regarded with intense distaste, and a lot of economists would like to ban it from the field.

title: Why Is Obamacare Complicated?
description: Mike Konczal says most of what needs to be said about the underlying sources of Obamacares complexity, which in turn set the stage for the current tech problems. Basically, Obamacare isnt complicated because government social insurance programs have to be complicated: neither Social Security nor Medicare are complex in structure. Its complicated because political constraints made a straightforward single-payer system unachievable.

title: U.S. Womens Team: Cry, Laugh, Love and Compete
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the sports world, the history of the United States womens national team is the equivalent of a fairy tale. The team has completed seemingly impossible comebacks, maintained ridiculous winning streaks and featured moments of individual brilliance.

title: Sid Yudain, 90, Dies; Created Congresss Community Newspaper
description: Sid Yudain, who created what he called a community newspaper  Roll Call  for what he called the most important community in the world, probably  Congress  died last Sunday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 90.

title: Jovanka Broz, Titos Widow, Is Dead at 88
description: She was a peasant girl who became a decorated heroine in Yugoslavias brutal fight against the occupying Nazis, and in 1952 married her Communist nations most powerful man, Josip Broz Tito.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  This was one cryptic that needed a good wrestling to the ground. Richard Silvestri is a veteran cryptic and American-style crossword puzzle constructor, and his clues are tricky and multi-layered.

title: After Year of Working Around Federal Cuts, Agencies Face Fewer Options
description: WASHINGTON  In the weeks that led to the huge across-the-board cuts to federal spending early this year, Obama administration officials warned of dire consequences for the Justice Department: F.B.I. agents dropped from investigations, United States marshals pulled from their beats, federal prison guards furloughed.

title: Teenagers Prove Fickle When Choosing Social Networks
description: We know a lot about teenagers online. They emojis. They love GIFs  or jifs, depending on how you prefer to pronounce the word. And they love taking selfies.

title: For the Canadiens, Whatevers in a Name Is on the Back
description: The Montreal Canadiens decision this season to include the accents in players names on their uniforms was not born of cultural politics. It arose simply out of one mans desire to be accurate.

title: Corporations Push for Immigration Legislation
description: Corporate voices behind immigration overhaul legislation continue to grow  including some companies that have a history of close ties to the Republican Party, giving a hint of the growing tension surfacing between corporate American and certain House Republicans.

title: Saudi Women Rise Up, Quietly, and Slide Into the Drivers Seat
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Hackers defaced their Web site. Delegations of clerics appealed to the king to block their movement. And men claiming to be security agents called their cellphones to leave a clear message:

title: In Bulk Purchase of Free Agents, the Red Sox Go 7 for 7
description: ST. LOUIS  The Boston Red Sox had been together just a few days in mid-February, and everyone seemed happy with the newcomers floating around the home clubhouse in Fort Myers, Fla. Seven free agents had joined a last-place roster, all with playoff experience and a sunny outlook.

title: Iran Executes 16 Sunni Insurgents in Retaliation for an Attack
description: TEHRAN  The Iranian authorities executed 16 Sunni insurgents on Saturday, Iranian media reported, in retaliation for an attack a day earlier that killed 14 guards on the volatile southeastern border with Pakistan.

title: A World Away, the Seventh Game; Close at Hand, Condemned Nazis
description: The Protestant minister and the Roman Catholic priest had a $10 bet riding on the 1946 World Series. The minister, a Lutheran from Missouri, went with the St. Louis Cardinals, naturally. The priest, a Franciscan from upstate New York, was a Brooklyn Dodgers fan, but he went with the Boston Red Sox to make things interesting.

title: With Snap of Group Photo, 3 Members of Advocacy Group Face Trial in China
description: HONG KONG  Three grass-roots rights advocates face trial in eastern China on Monday, with the main charge against them stemming from a group photograph snapped in the courtyard of an apartment block. That brief gathering will be at the heart of the first courtroom test of how far the government will go to extinguish the New Citizens Movement, which has pressed the Communist Party leadership under Xi Jinping to embrace democratic change.

title: Federal Prosecutors, in a Policy Shift, Cite Warrantless Wiretaps as Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department for the first time has notified a criminal defendant that evidence being used against him came from a warrantless wiretap, a move that is expected to set up a Supreme Court test of whether such eavesdropping is constitutional.

title: Hans Ephraimson-Abt, Air-Crash Victims Crusader, Dies at 91
description: Hans Ephraimson-Abt, who became an internationally known advocate for families of air-crash victims after the death of his daughter on Korean Air Lines Flight 007, shot down by Soviet fighter planes in 1983, died on Oct. 18 in Short Hills, N.J. He was 91.

title: Born in Mexico, Living in Florida, Tiants Wife Is a Fervent Boston Fan
description: Thirty-five years after her husbands final game for the Boston Red Sox, a brilliant two-hit shutout that set up a one-game playoff against the Yankees, Maria Tiant remains a fervent Red Sox fan.

title: Hal Needham, Stuntman and Director of Action Films, Dies at 82
description: Hal Needham, a veteran Hollywood stuntman who later embarked on a less risky career as a director of action movies including Smokey and the Bandit and The Cannonball Run, both of which starred his friend Burt Reynolds, diedon Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Phil Martens of Novelis, on Consistent Leadership
description: This interview with  Phil Martens, the chief executive of Novelis, the aluminum producer based in Atlanta, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Information-Gathering Paradox
description: SAN FRANCISCO  CONSUMER trust is a vital currency for every big Internet company, which helps to explain why the giants of Silicon Valley have gone to great lengths in recent months to show how hard they are fighting back against government surveillance. Companies have released transparency reports, many for the first time, enumerating how many times law enforcement agencies demand user data; their executives have issued blistering statements; and several firms, including Facebook and Google, have filed lawsuits in a bid to reveal more about secret government orders.

title: Railroad Memories
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Revising Obamacare
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 27
description: The Web site designed to connect people with health insurance plans, HealthCare.gov, in its first two weeks has been found to have glitches that made it difficult for consumers to use. While President Obamas administration has vowed to address the sites problems, Congress has begun hearings into why those problems werent fixed sooner.

title: Gambling Debate Entangles Disney in Florida
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  Just around the corner from the poker room and within shouting distance of the greyhound track here at the Mardi Gras Casino, the Amazing Spider-Man slot machine beckons gamblers with its spinning masked superhero and his nemesis the Green Goblin.

title: Open Games in Moscow to Test an Antigay Law
description: MOSCOW  Viktor Romanov smiles slyly as he explains his plans to hold gay-friendly Olympics in Moscow just three days after the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi. These Open Games will be for athletes of any orientation and will consist of eight events, including basketball, badminton, swimming and indoor soccer.

title: Pick a Side: Nets or Knicks?
description: The Knicks and the Nets coexisted for decades without much rancor. Their annual meetings did not constitute much of a rivalry, partly because of their locations and partly because of too much losing between them.

title: Goldman Sachs, Buying Redemption
description: Goldman Sachs is a master at making money. Lately it has become a master at giving it away. Goldman  for many a symbol of Wall Street greed and excess  wants the world to know it has a charitable side. With the same calculation that earned it a reputation as the savviest trading house on Wall Street, it has staked out a position as one of the nations leading corporate philanthropists, giving away more than $1.6 billion since 2008.

title: Egyptian Satirist Returns to TV With Careful Barbs
description: CAIRO  As his popular television show returned to Egypts airwaves on Friday after a long hiatus, Bassem Youssef, an Egyptian satirist, took a swipe at the countrys new military leadership in perhaps the only manner such criticism remains possible: with great care.

title: Slaves of the Internet, Unite!
description: NOT long ago, I received, in a single week, three (3) invitations to write an original piece for publication or give a prepared speech in exchange for no ($0.00) money. As with stinkbugs, its not any one instance of this request but their sheer number and relentlessness that make them so tiresome. It also makes composing a polite response a heroic exercise in restraint.

title: Do We Invest in Preschools or Prisons?
description: CONGRESS is often compared to pre-K, which seems defamatory of small children. But the similarities also offer hope, because an initiative that should be on the top of the national agenda has less to do with the sequester than with the A.B.C.s and Big Bird.

title: Sunday Dialogue: The Rise of Incivility
description: Readers discuss the tone of public discourse in the digital age.

title: But What if Obamacare Works?
description: IN last weeks column, I wrote about what might happen if the new health care laws Web site remained a festering technological sore for months to come. (The answer: Nothing good.) But its still more likely that HealthCare.gov will be fixed by Thanksgiving and millions of Americans will (finally) be able to get a real look at what Obamacare is selling them.

title: Italy Breaks Your Heart
description: ROME  ON my first night back in Italy, at a dinner party in Milan, I watched and listened to a successful couple in their late 40s plot their escape from a country that they love but have lost faith in. They cleared the plates, opened a laptop, and began checking out real estate in London, where one of them had been offered a transfer. The prices horrified but didnt deter them. They have a 10-year-old son, and they fear that Italy, with 40 percent unemployment among young adults and an economy whose listlessness has come to seem the new normal, doesnt promise a particularly bright future for him.

title: As Media Change, Fairness Stays Same
description: MOST of the time, Michael Powell writes the Gotham column for the news pages of The Times, in which his liberal politics  thats his own description  may be understood, though not made explicit.

title: Division Street, U.S.A.
description: We dont talk much about the wrong side of the tracks in public anymore, but the distinction between one place and another is implicitly understood and often explicitly specified. That location matters greatly for housing values, for example, is taken for granted. Less appreciated is the persistence of neighborhood inequality and its extensive reach into multiple aspects of everyday life. An increasing separation at the top has intensified the effect of spatial divisions on everyone else.

title: Single Mothers With Family Values
description: WHEN Jennifer Maggio was in her early 20s, she was raising two children by herself on the $750 per month that she earned as a manager at a furniture store in Vidalia, La. She went to college at night and was living in subsidized housing when she felt God urge her to make an unexpected choice. I started tithing. To tithe while I was living on food stamps  that was a tough decision, she said. The conversation I had with God was: Youve got to be kidding me. This is about the pastor wanting a new truck.

title: Andrew Farnsworth
description: Andrew Farnsworth is an expert on the calls of migrating birds at Cornell Universitys Laboratory of Ornithology.

title: N.B.A. Preview: The Haves and the Have-Nots
description: The shrinking middle class has apparently become part of the N.B.A. conversation, as the league has had a recent and drastic transformation. In past decades, there were some upper-echelon teams (the haves), about the same number of bottom-tier teams (the have-nots), and a robust middle tier.

title: Narendra Modis Rise in India
description: In 2002, rioters in the western Indian state of Gujarat savagely killed nearly 1,000 people, most of whom were part of the Muslim minority. Now, barely a decade later, Narendra Modi, who was the chief minister of Gujarat at the time and still holds the office, is a leading candidate to become prime minister of India.

title: What the Pollen Says
description: Humans are biological survivors, part of an unbroken genetic stream linked to the remote past. Yet the history of civilizations  rising, flourishing, crashing  is episodic.

title: An Optimistic Investment
description: Initial public offerings sell investors a dream. Consider two offerings on the market right now: For about $20 a share you can buy Twitter, a money-losing company that, if all goes well, will someday convert its popularity into profits. Or for $10 you can buy a share in the promise of Arian Foster, a temporarily injured but talented running back who could one day be the next Emmitt Smith.

title: The A Train to Autumn
description: Leaf-watching season in the Northeast is dazzling but fleeting. If you havent already taken Amtraks Adirondack train, with its special glass-domed car, up the Hudson Valley and beyond to see forested riverbanks in their coats of many, many colors, youve pretty much missed that chance  the leaves have peaked, and dome car service ends Tuesday.

title: In Indonesia, a Push for Prohibition Strikes Fear
description: LEGIAN, Indonesia  They have defaced Britney Spears posters, denounced Pamela Andersons charitable work and threatened Lady Gaga and Miss World beauty pageant contestants. And now, hard-line Muslims in Indonesia, in concert with Islamic-based politicians, are eyeing new targets: Johnnie Walker, an award-winning local pilsner called Bintang, even the exotic drinks with cherries and little umbrellas favored by the countrys many international visitors.

title: A $13 Billion Reminder of Whats Wrong
description: It was the deal of the week  a possible $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department to resolve an array of crisis-related mortgage cases.

title: CNN Jolts Ratings Race With Blackfish
description: CNN scored a rare coup on Thursday night, both over its cable news rivals and in finding a way to bring younger viewers to its news programming.

title: Fatal Bronx Blaze Was Caused by Candles
description: A fire in the Bronx on Friday evening that killed three children was caused by candles that were apparently being used for light after power to the apartment was cut off because of unpaid bills, the authorities said on Saturday.

title: Insurers Stocks, Unhurt by the Dawn of the Health Care Law
description: The Affordable Care Act has been controversial  so much so that Republican objections to it were a principal cause of the recent partial shutdown of the federal government.

title: Rentals That Let You Fly the Coop
description: Chickens are soulful animals, Phil Tompkins says. They walk up to you and talk to you, he says. They want to interact with you. Theyre like a cat or dog, except theyre a chicken.

title: Riding Out Sandy in the Rockaways
description: WHEN the morning tide came in you could tell it was going to be a big one. I live in Arverne, a neighborhood in the Rockaways, and in the morning when I was walking up Thursby Avenue I could already see the water coming in on that first tide.

title: Nothing Personal: They Want to Eat You
description: ZOMBIES may be hogging the pop culture spotlight these days in World War Z and The Walking Dead, but now that the flesh-eating undead are selling Sprint cellphones in television ads, one has to wonder: have they finally jumped the shark as the monster of the moment?

title: The Mixed State of the Health Care Exchange
description: An early tabulation by the Advisory Board Company, a health care research and consulting firm, shows that more than 116,000 people have picked a private plan or enrolled in Medicaid coverage in the state exchanges. The Obama administration had projected that nearly 500,000 people would enroll in a plan by Oct. 31.

title: Health Site Woes Undermine Obamas Vow on Government
description: WASHINGTON  The implicit promise of Barack Obamas presidency, delivered during the 2008 campaign and again repeatedly since then, was that government would not face a debacle like the recent malfunction of the technology behind the presidents new health care marketplaces.

title: First Clsico Is a Charm for Barcelonas Neymar, Not for Madrids Bale
description: BARCELONA, Spain  There was a moment, just after the clocks at Camp Nou stadium showed that 16 full minutes had been played on Saturday, when Gareth Bale sneaked a quick glance at the crowd. It was not surprising; the home fans here erupt at 17 minutes 14 seconds of each half as a way to call for Catalonian independence, their chants evoking the year 1714, when the region lost its last traces of autonomy to Spain.

title: Week 8 Matchup: Jets (4-3) at Bengals (5-2)
description: 4:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Week 8 Matchup: Giants (1-6) at Eagles (3-4)
description: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Sharing Nobel Honors, and Agreeing to Disagree
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science has sometimes been awarded to economists who disagree profoundly. Notably, in 1974, the Nobel committee gave a joint prize to Gunnar Myrdal, a Social Democrat in Sweden and a proponent of the welfare state, and Friedrich Hayek, a conservative who believed that government should be minimal.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, October 27
description: No one is madder than me.

title: The Cashiers Check That Wasnt
description: Heads up, readers. This one starts like a pretty conventional Haggler episode, but then takes a turn for the weird.

title: Maybe Heaven Can Wait, but a Customer Cant
description: Patience is a virtue, we are taught. And when you think about it, much of our life is spent waiting for something rather than experiencing it, so that waiting becomes an experience in itself, filled with anticipation, annoyance, boredom or fear.

title: Seizing Marijuana in Northern California
description: The cultivation of marijuana has proved to be an economic boon for many communities, but there have been complaints about the use of public land by growers.

title: Eugene Fama, King of Predictable Markets
description: Eugene F. Fama, 74, is one of the winners of this years Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, along with Lars Peter Hansen, a fellow professor at the University of Chicago, and Robert J. Shiller, a professor at Yale.

title: Czech Election Reflects Dissatisfaction of Voters
description: PARIS  The center-left Social Democrats won the most votes in Czech parliamentary elections on Saturday, but fell short of winning a majority in a vote that underlined voters deep dissatisfaction with endemic corruption and the political status quo.

title: The Horse Sense That Builds Trust
description: As I was growing up, I often found myself in the role of family peacemaker and wondered what it would take for people to focus more on the ways that connected them rather than divided them  not just in families, but in communities and the workplace, too. The more I thought about it, the more the world seemed like one big dysfunctional family. When I was a young adult, these concerns led me to attend peace demonstrations, to visit India to seek inner peace and, finally, to become a psychotherapist.

title: For a Traveling Nurse, Freedom to Roam
The E-Cigarette Industry, Waiting to Exhale
description: Geoff Vuleta was in the crowd at a Rolling Stones concert last year when Keith Richards lit up a cigarette on stage, the arenas no-smoking policy be damned. Feeling inspired, Mr. Vuleta, a longtime smoker, reached into his pocket and pulled one out himself. People seated nearby shot him scolding glances as he inhaled. So he withdrew the cigarette from his mouth and pressed the glowing end to his cheek.

title: Clean and Dirty: Chinas Energy Binge
description: China rate of growth for energy consumption is far greater than that of the United States.

title: Inflation Falls
description: Normally, the Federal Reserve would work to keep inflation from rising significantly. But during the financial crisis, the Fed has been fighting to increase inflation because falling prices help slow the economy.

title: In Fed and Out, Many Now Think Inflation Helps
description: WASHINGTON  Inflation is widely reviled as a kind of tax on modern life, but as Federal Reserve policy makers prepare to meet this week, there is growing concern inside and outside the Fed that inflation is not rising fast enough.

title: Whos Left?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  I never thought I would hear myself say this, but thank the universe for the circles in this puzzle by Brendan Emmett Quigley. Otherwise, I would have been hard-pressed to spot the theme.

title: Vision of Prairie Paradise Troubles Some Montana Ranchers
description: MALTA, Mont.  On fields where cattle graze and wheat grows, a group of conservationists and millionaire donors are stitching together their dreams of an American Serengeti. Acre by acre, they are trying to build a new kind of national park, buying up old ranches to create a grassland reserve where 10,000 bison roam and fences are few.

title: The Arguments for Early Childhood Education
description: My Sunday column argues that the United States has a chance to establish a nationwide early childhood education program that would do more than anything to broaden opportunity and break cycles of poverty  but its frustrating that the issue barely registers on the public agenda. And President Obama, who proposed the nationwide program early this year and who privately seems committed to it, hasnt championed it very much in public.

title: Milestones in U.S. Marijuana Laws
description: Over the last century, the laws relating to marijuana have gone through an evolution.

title: Man Checking Guns Is Arrested at J.F.K., Authorities Say
description: A Tennessee man was arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday as he was checking in and officers discovered two pistols and two rifles, painted silver and purple, the authorities said.

title: Bill de Blasio for Mayor
description: The rise of Bill de Blasio, New York Citys public advocate, has been remarkable. In a clamorous primary campaign against better known, more seasoned candidates, he won the Democratic nomination without a runoff, by appealing directly and doggedly to struggling New Yorkers who see a city of lofty wealth rising out of their reach. With the election only 10 days away, Mr. de Blasio is polling so far ahead of the Republican, Joseph Lhota, that commentators have already anointed him leader of a national rebirth of left-wing populism.

title: A Library of Classics, Edited for the Teething Set
description: The humble board book, with its cardboard-thick pages, gently rounded corners and simple concepts for babies, was once designed to be chewed as much as read.

title: Gang Rape in India, Routine and Invisible
description: MUMBAI, India  At 5:30 p.m. on that Thursday, four young men were playing cards, as usual, when Mohammed Kasim Sheikhs cellphone rang and he announced that it was time to go hunting. Prey had been spotted, he told a friend. When the host asked what they were going to hunt, he said, A beautiful deer.

title: Going to the Fair
description: Thousands of spectators assembled to watch a grand procession winding three miles long through Chicago on Oct. 27, 1863. They cheered as columns of police, military companies, civic clubs and religious organizations streamed past. One hundred wagons brimming with farm produce rolled along the unpaved streets. Army musicians played military airs, and marching groups of flag-waving children sang patriotic songs. Spectators jostled to catch glimpses of a carriage draped with tattered Confederate army flags captured by federal troops.

title: A Champion of the Past Wins a Contest on the Rails
description: One reason chess is so popular is that it can be played anywhere. There is no need for a special field or court, and the equipment is rudimentary and easy to carry.

title: Serena Williams Pushes Her Limits in WTA Semifinal Win
description: ISTANBUL  For a disorienting hour at the WTA Championships on Saturday, the longest season of Serena Williamss career appeared to be catching up with her.

title: In the Funeral Industry, Too Few Spanish Speakers
description: The mariachi band filed onstage, stopping beside the ceremonys centerpiece: a candle-flanked coffin on display before an audience of funeral experts.

title: For Both Sides, Time Takes a Heavy Toll on Evidence
description: Christine Greer remembers spending afternoons playing in the West Texas sandhills with her grandmother, who would slide down the hills for hours despite the persistent aching in her arthritis-ridden hands.

title: Ethics at Fore of Secret Talks on States Laws
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Love Affair Between One Artist and Texas
