description: The four French hostages who were kidnapped three years ago in Niger by Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb have been released, President Franois Hollande of France said Tuesday. Mr. Hollande did not describe the conditions of the release of the hostages  Daniel Larribe, Pierre Legrand, Thierry Dol and Marc Fret  who were working for the French nuclear giant Areva, and Sogea-Satom, a subsidiary of the French construction group Vinci in Arlit, in northern Niger, when they were kidnapped in September 2010. Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility and later posted videos showing that the men were alive. They were believed to have been kidnapped by Abu Zeid, the militant groups deputy commander, who was killed in an airstrike in Mali this year.

title: Russia: New Indictment for Navalny
description: Russias Investigative Committee said Tuesday that it had completed a new indictment of Aleksei A. Navalny, the countrys most prominent opposition leader. The indictment charged him and his brother with embezzlement and money laundering, this time involving a commercial cosmetics contract worth nearly $1 million. The new charges came only two weeks after a judge suspended a five-year sentence in a previous conviction that had widely been denounced as politically motivated, allowing him to remain free though with his political future in doubt. Mr. Navalny denounced the indictment as an expected, though baseless effort to maintain pressure on him after his strong showing in the Moscow mayoral election in September.

title: In Doctored Photo, Chinese Officials Loom Large Online
description: Efforts to promote a visit by local government officials to an elderly pensioner in the eastern province of Anhui took an awkward turn after a poorly doctored photo spread rapidly on Chinese websites. By Wednesday morning, hours after it had begun to go viral, the photo had landed on the front page of The Beijing News.

title: From Todays Paper: After Storm, a Time to Plant
Argentina: Court Loss for Media Group
description: After four years of combat between the government and Argentinas biggest media conglomerate, the Clarn group, Supreme Court judges declared constitutional on Tuesday a law that forces media companies to shrink their broadcast divisions. The law, which was passed in 2009, has not been fully put in effect because of Clarns challenges in the courts. But the ruling means the group must immediately start the process to divestitselfof assets, according to Martn Sabbatella, president of the government agency enforcing the law. The ruling concluded that the law favors freedom of speech by limiting market concentration.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 30, 2013
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Schools Watch Students on the Internet
description: In Warily, Schools Watch Students on the Internet, Somini Sengupta writes about how new ways to monitor students around the clock are raising questions.

title: The President Wants You to Get Rich on Obamacare
description: Tom Scully bolted through the doors and up the stairs to a private dining room on the third floor of the 21 Club. Scully, 56, is slightly taller than average and has tousled graying hair, an athletic build and a lopsided smile. He typically projects a combination of confidence and bemusement, but on this rainy September afternoon, he was frenzied. Scully was scheduled to deliver the keynote address at an event hosted by the Potomac Research Group, a Beltway firm that advises large investors on government policy (tag line: Washington to Wall Street). Todays discussion centered on the most significant change in decades to the nations health care policy, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare. As Scully walked to the front of the room, some 50 managers from hedge funds, mutual funds and private equity firms tucked into the round tables. Others gathered in the hallway. A hush of anticipation hung in the air.

title: Where the Wild Things Are (at Home)
description: A plump teddy bear perches on the edge of a sofa, surrounded by floral wallpaper. A monk in a dimly lit room hangs his head, his shadow projecting menacingly onto the wall. Meanwhile, a skeleton tucks itself into bed, where a painting of Mary and Jesus watches over its slumber.

title: What Kind of Robot Would You Want?
description: More and more, robots are beginning to imitate  and look like  humans. And the idea that someday they will be partners of humans, rather than stand-ins or servants, is now driving research at universities and industrial laboratories.

title: Barclays Rebounds to Profit, Despite Fixed-Income Slump
description: Updated, 8:22 p.m. | The British bank Barclays reported a better-than-expected third-quarter profit on Wednesday but said that income in its investment bank declined, driven primarily by a 44 percent drop in its fixed-income business.

title: New York Today: Fall Colors
description: Updated 12:03 p.m. | Foliage season in the Catskills has come and gone. Vermont maples are brown or bare.

title: Wheelies: The Chinese Cherokee Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from around the Web:

title: Daily Report: Twitter Updates Its Interface as I.P.O. Nears
description: Twitter has gone visual. The social network, which has been built around 140-character snippets of text since its founding in 2006, has added photo and video previews to the feed of items that users see when they log onto the service from the web or mobile applications. In the past, Twitter users had to click on a link to see a photo or video, Vindu Goel reports.

title: ING Moves Closer to Repaying State Aid
description: LONDON  The Dutch financial services group ING said on Wednesday that it would pay 1.13 billion euros ($1.55 billion) to the Dutch government in November as it moves closer to repaying the state aid it received during the financial crisis.

title: Profit Surpasses Forecasts at Italian Oil Giant Eni
description: LONDON  The Italian oil company Eni, troubled by turmoil in Africa and a corruption scandal at its drilling subsidiary, reported an adjusted net profit of 1.2 billion euros for the latest quarter, a 29 percent decline from the period a year earlier.

title: How a Start-Up Retailer Can Manage Cash Flow
description: In my previous posts about the efforts of Caroline Scheeler and her husband, Joe Vajarsky, to open Outpost General Store in Wayne, Ill., Ms. Scheeler explained how they ran out of money even before they opened the doors. Her big fear was that she was not going to have enough money to fill the store with inventory.

title: As Prosecution Opens Its Case in British Hacking Trial, a Claim of Conspiracy
description: LONDON  The prosecution opened its case on Wednesday at a phone hacking trial here, telling the jury of nine women and three men that four people involved with The News of the World had already pleaded guilty to phone hacking and that he would prove that the illegal acts were a conspiracy approved by some of those on trial now, including two former editors, Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson.

title: Another Look at the Empress Dowager Cixi, This Time as the Great Modernizer
description: Chinas sprint past India and practically every other developing country over the past three decades has raised a difficult, politically charged question: Who laid the foundations for the prosperity that Deng Xiaoping nurtured from 1978 until his death in 1997?

title: The Father Who Fought for Lorenzos Oil
description: Augusto Odone surely was one of the best fathers of all time. Along with his wife, Michaela, Mr. Odone defied and then amazed the medical profession when he devised an apparent treatment for his son Lorenzos incurable neurological disease. The treatment was called Lorenzos Oil.

title: Taking Questions on How to Research Family History
description: This weeks Ask an Expert features Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, who will answer questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members.

title: Advice About Assisted Living for Aging Relatives, Part 3
description: Debra Drelich, a specialist in geriatric care, has been answering readers readers questions about assisted living and other special living arrangements for aging relatives. Part 1 of her answers can be read here. Part 2 can be read here.

title: Guardian Scholars
description: New programs to assist former foster children with college.

title: Out of Foster Care, Into College
description: BY definition, foster children have been delinquent, abandoned, neglected, physically, sexually and/or emotionally abused, and that does not take into account nonstatutory abuses like heartache. About two-thirds never go to college and very few graduate, so its a safe bet that those who do have an uncommon resilience.

title: Pricewaterhouse to Buy Booz Consulting Firm
description: Updated, 1:42 p.m. | PricewaterhouseCoopers said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the consulting firm Booz & Company, bolstering its advisory business, a chief source of growth for the firm.

title: Contrite White House Spurns Health Laws Critics
description: BOSTON  The White House on Wednesday blended expressions of contrition for the troubled rollout of its health care law with an aggressive rejection of Republican criticism of it, as the administration sought a political strategy to blunt the fallout from weeks of technical failures and negative coverage.

title: A Train Through Kashmir
description: On a summer afternoon, Mohammed Yasin, a fruit trader from Banihal in Indian-administered-Kashmir, made a video of his seven-year-old sons first train journey. Mr. Yasin, 36, held his mobile phone out of the window to capture the passing landscape as they hurtled across the valley of Kashmir.

title: In Singapore, Building Businesses for the Next Billion
description: SINGAPORE  Years back, my first serious job began in a warehouse in a jungly part of this island nation. I returned there last week. The same building, somewhat refurbished, is now five stories of start-ups, accelerators and venture capital offices, surrounded by modern high rises.

title: G.M.s Earnings Are Down on Overseas Sales; Chryslers Are Up
description: DETROIT  General Motors and Chrysler will forever be linked as the two Detroit car companies that needed government bailouts in 2009 to survive.

title: Saudi Men Sing No Woman, No Drive in Mock Homage to Ban on Female Drivers
description: Updated, Nov. 5 | The women who got behind the wheel in Saudi Arabia on Saturday to defy the countrys ban on female drivers werent just getting a thumbs up from some men passing in cars on the road  they were also getting support from a group of Saudi comedians that continues to bring more attention to the campaign.

title: I Sing the Bike Electric
description: A long, long, time ago, when Twitter did not exist and the Winklevoss twins were still in high school, I got into biking. Though I was 48 when I started, I had the power and speed of a longtime features writer. Even on trips with people who appeared to be in their late 70s I was last. My last long trip, which I took with my friend Herb, was in California wine country, when the temperature was in the low 90s.

title: Hurricane Sandy Haiku
description: Dear Diary:

title: Israel Gets a Mixed Message on American Jews
description: JERUSALEM  The Pew Research Center released a comprehensive and nuanced study on Oct. 1 about the character of the American Jewish community. The reaction here was typical Israeli apprehension about Jews place in the world, mixed with a general sense of confusion over how to interpret the results. Most discussions focused on two aspects: The high percentage of interfaith marriages and the vast support among American Jews for Israel.Fifty-eight percent of Jews who married between 2005 and 2013 have a non-Jewish spouse. Mixed marriages inevitably lead to the assimilation of Jews into American culture, and tap long-standing Israeli fears over the future of the Jewish people. To some Israelis given to these worries, assimilation is tantamount to accepting annihilation.

title: 45 Killed in Fiery Bus Crash in South India
description: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh  A private bus burst into flames on Wednesday after it crashed into a culvert on its way to Hyderabad, burning 45 passengers to death, including one baby. Seven survived, including the driver.

title: 5 Suspects Are Held in Attack in Beijing
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities announced on Wednesday the arrests of five suspects described as Islamic jihadists who they say helped orchestrate an audacious attack near  Tiananmen Square, the political heart of the nation, that left five people dead.

title: Internet Subscribers Aid Growth by Comcast
description: Comcast, the nations largest cable provider, told a familiar story through its third-quarter earnings on Wednesday: overall growth despite continued slippage in television subscribers, and unflattering comparisons to last year.

title: Color Controversy at SNL
description: Criticism over recent remarks by a cast member have shed light on the absence of black women on Saturday Night Live.

title: From the Underground to The New Yorker
description: Art Spiegelmans work is plumbed for a museum retrospective in New York.

title: Strips and Stones
description: Its no accident that Art Spiegelmans drawings of himself almost always show a butt hanging off his lower lip. Mr. Spiegelman, now 65, smokes the same way he does everything else  with feeling and with urgency. In his SoHo studio not long ago, he lit up a Camel while fretting about how he was going survive without tobacco on a 20-hour flight to Australia in a couple of days. He puffed on another while talking about the exhibition of his work that opens next Friday at the Jewish Museum. Just thinking about it, he said, made him feel like a rat disappearing up its own rear end.

title: Sebelius Apologizes for Health Sites Malfunctions
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, gamely defended the problem-plagued rollout of President Obamas health care law on Wednesday and tried to explain the cancellation of hundreds of thousands of individual insurance policies.

title: Prominent Muslim Brotherhood Leader Is Seized in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Egyptian security forces on Wednesday captured Essam el-Erian, one of the last few prominent leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood still at large after a crackdown that began with the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, another of the groups leaders.

title: Sebelius Apologizes at Hearing
description: Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, gave an opening statement at a House hearing on the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov.

title: In Maine, a Weekend of Toboggan Building
description: Skiing often takes center stage as winter nears, but a historic New England inn has focused on the craft of another fun snow activity: sledding.

title: Foreign Support for Syrian Rebels Is Hindering Deal, Assad Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria told the United Nations special envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, on Wednesday that no political solution could be reached in Syria without an end to international support for the fighters battling his government, underscoring how far apart the sides remain as global powers try to arrange peace talks next month.

title: Today in Small Business: AdWords or Bing?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Was Rate Shock Necessary?
description: Something thats floating around in the discussion of Obamacares apparent losers is the idea that the kind of regulatory changes driving rate shock for many consumers were essential to the design of health care reform with the implication being that whether or not they were the absolutely ideal policy, and whether or not the president was completely honest about their impact, once the White House settled on its mandate, regulate, subsidize approach to health care reform they became essentially inevitable. Heres Josh Barro, for instance, in a post I linked to on Monday, making the case that what were seeing is the necessary consequence of the way the law brings insurance to the currently-uninsurable:

title: Homes for $525,000
description: A contemporary in Santa Fe, N.M.; and a condo in downtown Nashville; and a midcentury modern in McHenry, Ill.

title: What You Get for ... $525,000
description: SANTA FE, N.M.

title: Besides Location, a Beatles Connection Helps in Real Estate Market
description: This has been a banner year for over-the-top auctions of artifacts from the periphery of Beatles history. A guitar they barely used was auctioned in May for $408,000. A Ferrari that John Lennon once owned sold soon after for nearly $579,000. Now Lennons early childhood home at 9 Newcastle Road, in Liverpool  a red-brick terrace house he lived in intermittently between 1940 and 1946, and left when he was 5  has sold for $771,000.

title: Neil Gaiman to Join Bard Faculty
description: The award-winning fantasy novelist, comics creator, screenwriter, director, library defender and Twitter presence Neil Gaiman will be adding another line to his already long rsum: college professor. Bard College announced Wednesday that Mr. Gaiman would be joining its theater and performance faculty in the spring, where he will teach an advanced writing workshop exploring the history of the fantastic, approaches to fantasy fiction, and the meaning of fantasy today, among other courses, according to a statement from the school.

title: Rentiers, Entitlement, and Monetary Policy
description: Bill Gross is at it again, coming up with yet another reason for the Fed to tighten despite a still-depressed economy and inflation falling well below target. He is, of course, not alone  it has actually been amazing how wide a variety of reasons people in or close to the financial industry have come up for tight money in an economy that seems to need to opposite. Many of the people making these arguments started with dire warnings about runaway inflation; but when inflation failed to materialize, they didnt change their policy views, they came up with new rationales for doing exactly the same thing.

title: Federal Inquiry Into Indian Firm Puts a Focus on Widespread Visa Abuses
description: A federal investigation into visa use by Infosys, the Indian technology outsourcing giant, has brought to light widespread abuses in the industry and prompted investigations into other foreign outsourcing firms, federal officials said Wednesday.

title: Some Find Path to Navajo Roots Through Mormon Church
description: TUBA CITY, Ariz.  Linda Smith lost one son, a methamphetamine addict, when he hanged himself in jail. Her other sons are heavy drinkers, fathered by a man who she said nearly killed her one night in a fit of rage, driving her from her home on this corner of the Navajo reservation to Provo, Utah, where she found solace in the Mormon Church.

title: 196.2 Miles, Only Some in a Tutu
description: I have viewed fall foliage by driving past it, hiking through it, flying over it in a small plane. This year 11 companions and I tried a far less sane method. We ran past it. For 196.2 miles.

title: Award-winning Paragraphs
description: John Taylor has accomplished something sort of amazing: he has managed to write the two worst paragraphs Ive read this week. Here they are:

title: House Hunting in ... Portugal
description: A SIX-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY IN CASCAIS

title: Real Estate in Portugal
description: A six-bedroom contemporary home in the resort town of Cascais, Portugal, is on the market for $2.24 million dollars.

title: Storage in the Cloud, Kept at Home
description: When Western Digital released its My Book Live hard drive last year, it seemed like a convenient way to store content in a personal cloud, alleviating privacy and safety fears associated with other cloud services.

title: The Story Behind the Racial Profiling Article in The Times
description: A strong article by J. David Goodman in Wednesdays New York section was the first substantial treatment in The Times about the recent claims of racial profiling at two Manhattan stores.

title: A Colorful and Attractive Speaker Thats a Bit Silly
description: The JBL Spark Bluetooth speaker is a little bit silly, but that is what makes the device charming.

title: Ban on Gay Bias Gains Key Supporter in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, said Wednesday that he would vote for a nondiscrimination bill that protects gay men, lesbians and transgender people, putting the measure within one vote of gaining the support it needs to overcome a filibuster.

title: Protecting Children From Toxic Stress
description: Imagine if scientists discovered a toxic substance that increased the risks of cancer, diabetes and heart, lung and liver disease for millions of people. Something that also increased ones risks for smoking, drug abuse, suicide, teen pregnancy, sexually transmitted disease, domestic violence and depression  and simultaneously reduced the chances of succeeding in school, performing well on a job and maintaining stable relationships? It would be comparable to hazards like lead paint, tobacco smoke and mercury. We would do everything in our power to contain it and keep it far away from children. Right?

title: The Gun Report: October 30, 2013
description: According to a recent Gallup poll, personal safety and protection is the top reason Americans own guns today. Of 309 gun owners polled by phone at the beginning of October for the organizations annual crime survey, 60 percent cited that as the main reason for having a firearm; 36 percent said they owned guns for hunting; and 13 percent cited recreation and sport. Despite its frequent use as an argument against gun control, only 5 percent cited Second Amendment rights.

title: Willie Nelson to Write New Memoir
description: A new memoir by Willie Nelson is to be released by Little, Brown and Company in 2015, the publisher said on Wednesday, describing the book as the unvarnished, complete and tremendous story of the country music stars life. Mr. Nelson, who is 80, has previously written Willie, an autobiography published in 1988, and Roll Me Up and Smoke Me When I Die, a road journal. The new book promises to be more personal than his other books, sharing untold stories that involve Ray Charles, Waylon Jennings, Johnny Cash and Merle Haggard, the publisher said.

title: Two Latino Theaters in New York to Merge
description: To advance their dream of a highly visible Hispanic performing arts institution with stages in two boroughs, Pregones Theater in the Bronx and the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater in Manhattan, are merging. The marriage of two longtime gems of Latino theater in New York is to be officially announced Nov. 4 at a celebration at the Time Warner Center.

title: App Smart: Music Games
description: Highlights of game apps with a strong musical component, as reviewed by The Timess Kit Eaton.

title: T WINTER LUXURY
description: As luxury brands try to crack the exploding Chinese market and the Chinese seek to export their own fashion stars to the West, Melvin Chua  bon vivant, image maker and cross-cultural connector  is the man in the middle.

title: Singing With Monsters and Playing Some Tunes
description: Remember when it was cool to hook up a plastic guitar to your PlayStation and amateurishly thrash your way through heavy metal tracks in the game Guitar Hero? I still recall how sore my thumb got from playing that game. Games with a strong music element have evolved since Guitar Hero was first introduced and many of them have been tailored for smartphones and tablets.

title: Painting Freedom
description: Sometime in the early fall of 1863, the artist Eastman Johnson composed a small work that he titled The Lord Is My Shepherd. At first glance, the image seems to posit the gentle nature of a formerly enslaved man reading the Psalms as a model of emerging humanity and citizenship. Johnsons warm, sepia-toned brushwork provides little detail in the architecture of the setting. The young black man sits on a folding stool with a canvas seat, absorbed in the book he holds in his powerful hand; a dark blue coat lined in scarlet is draped over the back of the chair, possibly hinting that he has served in the Union Army. Wide wooden planks mark the transition from hearth to floorboards, sketching out a crude dwelling.

title: Clippers Wont Win on Expectations Alone
description: LOS ANGELES  Audacity has never been in short supply at Staples Center, and so it was that before the Lakers tipped off the season Tuesday night with a visit from their neighbors, the Clippers, a coach stood in the hallway outside his locker room waxing about one of his first duties last summer: scouting potential routes for a championship parade.

title: Why I.P.O.s Arent All Theyre Cracked Up To Be
description: Twitter is halfway through an eight-city road show, pitching its initial public stock offering to institutional investors and joining what is shaping up to be a resurgent market for I.P.O.s.

title: Two Financial Advisers Accuse Twitter of Secondary Market Fraud
description: The secondary market for private company stock is a shadowy world, where ownership is often unclear, paper fortunes trade hands with ease and valuations can soar as demand for hot private stock outstrips supply.

title: Behind the Roar of Political Debates, Whispers of Race Persist
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama last week sought to turn attention from health care to immigration  in other words, from one racially divisive issue to another.

title: A Romp and a Relay
description: The group races known as the Ragnar have caught on. Heres how to run one. (A tutu is optional.)

title: Afghan Officials to Meet Freed Taliban Official in Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan officials said Wednesday that a delegation would travel to Pakistan soon to meet a senior Taliban leader whom the Pakistani authorities said they were releasing from prison last month but whose whereabouts since has become a point of contention.

title: Suicide Blast and Attempt Deal a Blow to Tunisia
description: TUNIS  A suicide bombing in a resort area on Wednesday and the thwarting of another, the first such attacks in more than a decade, dealt a new blow to Tunisias fragile transition as it grapples with rising Islamist extremism and political deadlock between secular and Islamist parties.

title: Tricksters Trek From Los Angeles
description: Since Ricky Jay and his 52 assistants have been retired for several years now, magic has done something of a disappearing act from New York theater. But lovers of prestidigitation (I just love to write that crazy word!) can rejoice at the arrival of Nothing to Hide, a slick, smart new show starring two young talents, Helder Guimares and Derek DelGaudio. They were spotted at the Magic Castle, a private club for sleight-of-hand artistes in the Hollywood Hills, by the ubiquitous Neil Patrick Harris.

title: Image of the Day: October 30
Perils in Philosophy of Austerity in the U.S.
description: The Grand Bargain is off the table. Thank goodness for that.

title: Mashable Names Jim Roberts to Oversee Content Expansion
description: Mashable, the digital media site, said Wednesday morning that it had hired Jim Roberts as executive editor and chief content officer, part of its push to expand the range of its content.

title: Shirking a Moral Duty
description: Months after two tragedies claimed the lives of more than 1,200 workers at clothing factories in Bangladesh, it is shocking that just a handful of Western retailers whose clothes were made there have agreed to compensate victims and their families for their losses, according to a report released last week.

title: New World Symphony (German Contest Remix)
description: The Berlin Philharmonic gets most of the attention among Berlins symphony orchestras  there are at least half a dozen, depending how you count them. But one of its competitors, the Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester Berlin, is making a bid for 21st-century street cred in way that its hard to imagine the staid philharmonic emulating.

title: Hotel Yoga? Everyones Invited.
description: Yoga classes at hotels have long been a popular guest amenity, but now some properties are opening them up to the public as well.

title: A Year After Sandy, a Turkish Restaurant Rebuilds
description: A year later, normalcy has nearly returned to Istanbul Restaurant, in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. But in the days after Hurricane Sandy laid waste to the New York coastline, Riza Atas thought he had been washed out of business. His Turkish restaurant, a neighborhood fixture for 17 years, had been all but destroyed. His tables and chairs wound up down the block. His landlord hauled 30 containers of garbage out of the deluged basement.

title: Bill Moyers to End Television Show
description: Bill Moyers told public television stations on Tuesday that his interview program Moyers & Company would end with the Jan. 3 show, keeping to the two-year timetable he and the programs funders committed to when he came out of a 20-month retirement in January 2012. The news was first reported by the trade publication Current. Mr. Moyers, who was not available for comment, said in a letter to stations that while the show would disappear from television, he and his staff were exploring the possibility of continuing to serve audience members through his Web site, billmoyers.com, with the goal of engaging them in the renewal of democracy. He noted that the show had more than 315,000 Facebook fans, a number that is growing by several hundred people daily. They  like so many of our viewers  take their citizenship seriously, he wrote.

title: As Talks Open, Democrats Show Signs of Division
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and congressional Democrats, astonishingly united through recent fiscal fights with Republicans, were showing some divisions as budget negotiations opened on Wednesday between the House and Senate to avert another crisis in coming months.

title: St. Anns Warehouse to Break Ground on New Home in Dumbo
description: Renovations will begin Thursday on a permanent home for St. Anns Warehouse, the performance space in Brooklyn.

title: Stepping Into His Friends Shoes
description: Ruben Santiago-Hudson has starred in August Wilsons plays, winning a Tony Award for Seven Guitars in 1996. He has directed Wilsons plays, recently winning Lucille Lortel and Obie Awards for The Piano Lesson. And he served this year as artistic director for New York Public Radios readings and archival recording of Wilsons 10-play cycle about the African-American experience in the 20th century. In other words, he has become perhaps the foremost interpreter of this legendary playwright, who died of liver cancer in 2005.

title: C.F.T.C. Approves Tighter Commodity Trading Rules
description: In October 2011, as the futures broker MF Global teetered on the brink of collapse, it dipped into client accounts in an effort to avert bankruptcy.

title: In Our Pages: October 31
description: 1938 Milk Bar at Waldorf-Astoria

title: Text to Text | Einstein and Where Science and Religion Coexist
description: In this Text to Text, we take on the question of the compatibility of science and religion, with an excerpt from a Times Opinion piece written by Albert Einstein in 1930; a 2013 report on a conference between scientists and Buddhist monks hosted by the Dalai Lama; and a video in which the theoretical physicist Richard Feynman talks about trying to find answers to lifes big questions while living with doubt.

title: Noted Art Lawyer Is Suspended
description: A prominent art lawyer, Ralph E. Lerner, has been suspended from practicing law in New York State for a year for improperly charging clients for $50,000 in car-service rides for himself and his family over a decades time, the ABA Journal of the American Bar Association reported.

title: Russia Denies Reports It Spied on Group of 20 Officials
description: ROME  Russia denied reports in the Italian news media and elsewhere on Wednesday that Russian spy agencies distributed special USB thumb drives doctored to let them eavesdrop on delegations attending last months Group of 20 summit meeting in St. Petersburg.

title: The Uproar Over Insurance Cancellation Letters
description: Kathleen Sebelius, the Health and Human Services secretary, took a lot of grief Wednesday from Republicans on the House Energy and Commerce Committee who were outraged that some peoples individual insurance policies had been cancelled because of health care reform.

title: Dark Matter Experiment Has Detected Nothing, Researchers Say Proudly
description: The former Homestake Gold Mine in Lead, S.D., has a hallowed place in the history of physics as a spot where nothing happens.

title: Designer Thomas Heatherwick to Create Centerpiece for Hudson Yards Project
description: The innovative British designer Thomas Heatherwick has been tapped to help create a multimillion-dollar public space and artistic centerpiece for the Hudson Yards development on the West Side of Manhattan, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Astronomers Find Earthlike Planet, but Its Infernally Hot
description: Kepler 78b, a planet some 400 light-years away, is like hell on earth.

title: The Place to Celebrate
description: The baseball clubhouse is home to the ultimate acknowledgment of victory. Pop that cork.

title: A Toast to the Winners
description: At Fenway Park, the nonalcoholic bubbly is probably on ice.

title: Fed Extends Stimulus as Growth Stumbles
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is still waiting for clear evidence that the economy can grow decently without its help.

title: Shares of Blackstone-Backed Real Estate Trust Rise in Debut
description: Updated, 4:20 p.m. |

title: Questions Remain About Unwinding Failing Financial Giants
description: At a Federal Reserve conference last week, I was once again contemplating orderly liquidation authority and how it has changed under the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporations single point of entry proposal, which would put the holding company of a failing financial giant into into receivership, but allow its operating subsidiaries to still operate.

title: After Second Thoughts, a First Home in Bedford Stuyvesant
description: Donald and Fabiola Roman met as teenagers at an Upward Bound program, though they attended different Brooklyn high schools.

title: Submit Your Questions for DealBooks Nov. 12 Conference
description: Updated, Nov. 1 | Our annual DealBook conference provides a platform for readers to discuss the intersection of finance, technology and the corporate sector with top executives, investors and policy makers. Whether or not you attend the Nov. 12 conference at our headquarters in New York, you can submit questions below for the panel.

title: Frankenstein Manuscript Comes Alive in Online Shelley Archive
description: Mary Shelleys Frankenstein, famously conceived during a waking dream in the stormy summer of 1816, has inspired countless plays, movies, comic books, even iPhone apps. And now, the original manuscript is also the centerpiece of the first phase of the online Shelley-Godwin Archive, an ambitious digital project that goes live on Halloween.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: About Time
description: Richard Curtis narrates a scene from his comedy featuring Domhnall Gleeson and Rachel McAdams.

title: 1,500 Units to Be Added in Settlement, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government announced Wednesday that it had given final approval for 1,500 new apartments in a particularly contentious Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem and moved forward on plans for a controversial park and tourism center here, prompting Palestinian accusations that it is not taking the Washington-brokered peace talks seriously.

title: Choi Division
description: The Los Angeles chef and restaurateur Roy Choi was once a gambler and nearly a gangster, and a stoner from youth who was quick to fight, slow to wake. Born in Korea in 1970, he came to California two years later and grew up amid the dangerous currents of immigrant possibility: at his parents liquor store in Koreatown, until it failed; at his parents restaurant in West Anaheim, until it failed; at his parents jewelry store in Orange County, which made his family rich.

title: Judge Rules for Metropolitan Museum in Admissions Lawsuits
description: A New York State Supreme Court judge has ruled in favor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in two lawsuits contending that the museum, under a 19th-century state law and the museums original 1878 lease with the city, has no legal authority to charge a suggested admission fee, as it has done for more than four decades.

title: Filly Can Add to Storybook Rise at Breeders Cup
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Princess of Sylmars pedigree changed with one well-placed kick, and her roots were not promising to begin with. She was born at Sylmar Farm in Pennsylvania, a state that is not known for producing high-caliber thoroughbreds. She made an inauspicious debut last October, when she took fourth at Penn National Race Course, off the beaten path in central Pennsylvania.

title: Borscht Belt Republicans
description: Has anyone else noticed how much the GOP position on Obamacare resembles the classic borscht belt joke about the two ladies at a Catskills resort? Lady #1: The food here is so terrible, its inedible! Lady #2: And the portions are so small! Republican #1: Obamacare is slavery! Republican #2: And its so hard to sign up!

title: Greek Police Say 10 Officers Have Links to Golden Dawn
description: ATHENS  The Greek police on Wednesday announced the findings of an internal investigation into suspected links between the force and the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party, which is the focus of a criminal investigation, saying that 10 officers had been linked to the party but that no signs of organized cells affiliated with the group had been discovered. The inquiry began last month, after the killing of an anti-fascist singer by a self-professed supporter of Golden Dawn. The killing was the culmination of a string of assaults attributed to members or supporters of the fiercely anti-immigrant party, which has 18 seats in Greeces 300-member Parliament. Out of 319 police officers questioned, 15 were arrested on various charges, including illegal weapons possession and trading in contraband goods, and of those, 10 were found to have direct or indirect involvement with the criminal activities of Golden Dawn, according to the head of the polices internal affairs unit, Panagiotis Stathis. The investigation found no organized cells, factions or unconstitutional hubs but highlighted inadequate supervision within the force, he added at a news conference. The 15 officers who were arrested were suspended pending the outcome of their cases, a police spokesman said.

title: What It Means to Ban the Box
description: Some readers misunderstood my blog post yesterday on Target banning the box.

title: Iran Denies Halt to 20 Percent Uranium Enrichment
description: TEHRAN  Iran has never stopped 20 percent uranium enrichment, Irans top nuclear official said on Wednesday, contradicting an influential lawmaker who last week said the country had voluntarily halted its production.

title: A Modern Flood Barrier Aims to Protect Verizons Landmark Building
description: To protect their Manhattan settlement in the 17th century, the Dutch built a wall.

title: Sebelius's Difficult Day on the Hill
description: Highlights from the testimony before a House committee by Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, who called the first month of the HealthCare.gov site flawed.

title: A Halloween Risk: Racism in Disguise
description: Are Halloween costumes an annual excuse to frighten or to offend?

title: Bankruptcy Filing Is a Stunning Fall for a Brazilian Tycoon
description: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | The flagship company of the Brazilian entrepreneur Eike Batista, who once boasted that he was on his way to becoming the richest man in the world, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday.

title: Kindness, and Cold Shoulders, After Sandy
description: Yana Fishman stood on the porch of her townhouse Saturday and remembered what it was like to come home to something straight out of a nightmare.

title: Decoding the Feds Statement
description: The statement on Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

title: How to Live: A Compendium of Wisdom One Snippet at a Time
description: Last weeks issue of the magazine included the 100th interview Ive conducted for the One-Page Magazine. To mark the occasion, I culled my favorite unpublished moments from two years worth of interviews, which have ranged from three minutes (the comedian Kathy Griffin) to 55 (Dustin Diamond of Saved by the Bell fame). The first one I did was with Dr. Oz on how to look five years younger, the 100th with the architect Moshe Safdie on how to be worldly; one of the most memorable conversations was with Rodney King on finding inner peace.

title: Fall Fashion Is All About the Soft and Furry Bits
description: Designers were not averse to showing scads of fur for winter, and retailers followed suit, picking up lots of the fluffy stuff. Are you ready to join the party? Rita Ora is. Ms. Ora appeared at a recent event in a Fendi sweater with a mink front in multicolor stripes (above, center). Undeniably fabulous, the Fendi costs roughly $7,000. Happily, great pullovers and cardigans with furry bits are plentiful, minus a zero on the price tag. Pair any of these with jeans or a leather skirt. Anything more teeters on too much look.

title: Several Skin Products Include an Obscure Nut Oil
description: Tama-who? Tamanu. Derived from nuts that grow on trees found mostly in Southeast Asia and the Polynesian Islands, this newly modish oil can heal scars, help skin repair itself and soften lines and wrinkles, say proponents. Below, three new products that contain it.

title: Why Chrysler Needs an $18 Billion Valuation to Justify an I.P.O.
description: Chryslers valuation needs to hit $18 billion to justify an initial public offering. Thats the point where the union trust fund that owns 41.5 percent of the automaker would reap more than it could get from controlling shareholder Fiat. But its also way more than either owner has ever considered to be a reasonable price.

title: You Make the Call: Inappropriate Travel Behavior
description: This week in the Travel section, Stephanie Rosenbloom tackled behavior on airplanes, examining why we act the way we do while traveling. (Bare feet anyone?)

title: F.D.A. Finds 12% of U.S. Spice Imports Contaminated
description: NEW DELHI  About 12 percent of spices brought to the United States are contaminated with insect parts, whole insects, rodent hairs and other things, according to an analysis of spice imports by federal food authorities.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of About Time
description: In this video Richard Curtis, the writer and director of the comedy About Time, narrates a scene featuring Domhnall Gleeson as a man with the ability to time travel and Rachel McAdams as his love interest.

title: More Vexing Challenges for That Mississippi Lawyer
description: John Grishams Sycamore Row revisits Clanton, Miss., the site of his first and still most famous book, A Time to Kill. Just three years have passed since young Jake Brigance crusaded his way through Clantons most racially inflammatory murder trial. It is 1988, and Jake now has a small practice, a big reputation and a housing problem created when Ku Klux Klan members torched his lovingly restored Victorian home.

title: This Time Out, Parting Is Such Sung Sorrow
description: SAN DIEGO  The sound of rock n roll is the sound of romance and rebellion, and there are no greater romantic rebels than Romeo and Juliet, Shakespeares heedless young lovers, who defy the authority of their warring tribes, marry in secret, and willingly embrace the dark fate that unhappy circumstance has ordained for them. The Last Goodbye, a new musical adaptation of the play at the Old Globe Theater here, audaciously attempts to find the spiritual kinship between Shakespeares tragedy and the keening angst in the music of Jeff Buckley, the singer-songwriter who died in 1997 at the age of 30, as his promising career was gaining momentum.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Norway.

title: A Statement of Purpose From First-Time Visitors
description: For all the economic turmoil within many classical-music institutions, there are encouraging stories out there as well. For one, the San Diego Symphony. This orchestra, which gave its first concerts in 1910, has endured periods of financial crisis when activities ceased, most recently in the mid-1990s.

title: Jeep Delays Fuel Tank Recall; G.M., Bentley, Lamborghini and Nissan Issue Recalls
description: Four months after Chrysler agreed to recall about 1.6 million 2002-7 Jeep Liberty and 1993-98 Jeep Grand Cherokee models over rear-impact fire danger, owners still have not been told by the company to bring their vehicles to dealerships for repairs.

title: Puccinis Passions, Still in Stark Production
description: For a time after the critically savaged opening of Luc Bondys gritty, spare and somewhat smarmy production of Puccinis Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera in 2009, some nourished the forlorn hope that the Met would come to its senses and revive the immediate predecessor, by Franco Zeffirelli, widely beloved for its grand and hyper-realistic sets. But it is clear by now that the Bondy version  revived every year since its premiere and shorn of its worst excrescences, sexual and otherwise  is here for at least a while. So it is probably time to stop the comparisons and accept or reject it on its own terms.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This month, four novels that explore the needs and fragility of human psychology, and two books about life (and the search for life) far from Earth.

title: In a Surprise, Pakistan Says Fewer Civilians Died by Drones
description: LONDON  In a surprise move, Pakistans government on Wednesday sharply revised downward its official estimate of civilian casualties caused by American drone strikes in the tribal belt, highlighting again the contentious nature of statistics about the covert C.I.A. campaign.

title: For a High-Powered Career, Its Finance vs. Tech
description: Wall Street or Silicon Valley? Thats the choice facing many ambitious students across the United States looking to gain a toehold in a powerful industry after graduation.

title: Katy Perry on Top in a Dismal Week for Music Industry
description: Record sales over the last week were kind to Katy Perry and Lou Reed, but for the music industry over all they were terrible.

title: Back to St. Louis on the Way to Brazil
description: Vedad Ibisevic admits he is not much of a baseball fan, even though the team from his adopted hometown, St. Louis, was again in the World Series.

title: Mobile Ads Fuel a Jump in Profit at Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Perhaps Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, should ditch the hoodie and dress up as a mobile phone for Halloween.

title: La Scala Confirms Barenboim Departure
description: The Teatro alla Scala in Milan has confirmed that Daniel Barenboim will step down as musical director at the end of 2014, two years before his contract is set to expire. He will probably be succeeded by Riccardo Chailly, a Milanese conductor. In an interview, Carlo Maria Cella, a spokesman for La Scala, said that Mr. Barenboim had no comment. Mr. Cella confirmed that the conductor had sent a letter to the opera house saying that he would conclude his tenure with a production of Beethovens Fidelio, which opens the operas 2014-15 season.

title: New Guidelines Aim to Help Financial Caregivers
description: Your aging aunt, worried that she wont be able to pay her bills if she becomes sick, signs a power of attorney document making you her legal agent for financial decisions. Or your retired father needs help managing his monthly Social Security payments, and the government appoints you as his representative payee.

title: Office Romance: Ghost Stories
description: Sometimes late in the day, I head up to the 15th floor. Like a moth lured by a candle flame, I am drawn by the light coming into the west side of our building. It bounces off the Hudson River, sweeps over the parking lot above Port Authority, pours in through the floor-to-ceiling windows and ignites the frosted-glass walls of the conference rooms, stirring up light spirits. People passing by disintegrate into shadow selves, sometimes completely disappearing into the walls. The light along the stairs bookending the southwest and northwest sides of the building swelters at the witching hour, causing people to evaporate. The shades that line the windows are scrims for a sinister Broadway show. Weird things happen with the light on the sixth floor, too. A shadowy figure appears suddenly on a filing cabinet. A hand darts up from the depths of a cubicle. Edward Scissorhands is trapped in the carpet.

title: American Academy in Rome Names New President
description: PARIS  The American Academy in Rome is expected to name Mark Robbins, the executive director of the International Center of Photography, as its new president. Mr. Robbins, an architect and artist who has also been the director of design at the National Endowment for the Arts, will follow Adele Chatfield-Taylor, who is stepping down in January after 27 years as the head of the independent research institution.

title: A Singer Is Tough on Herself
description: How much longer will Sky Ferreira not get what she wants? The agony of disappointment is wearing on her, and animating her. See Nobody Asked Me (If I Was Okay)  which turns lashing out into a sticky, moody song  from her bracing, aggressive and surprisingly tender debut album, Night Time, My Time (Capitol).

title: Wrangling Data From a Huge Variety of Fitness Gadgets
description: The human body is in data overload.

title: Churches and Cheap Seafood Off the Coast of Chile
description: Around dusk on my last day in Chilo, an archipelago just off the coast of southern Chile, I finally made it to the farthest point on the island of Lemuy, winding around sheep farms on tidy dirt roads to a little town called Detif, home of one of Chilos traditional wooden churches, which are recognized as a World Heritage site by Unesco.

title: In the Backwoods of Lost River, a Gay Retreat
description: The beauty of Lost River  beyond its rolling green hills and picturesque grain silos and clear streams snaking through West Virginias hardwood forests  is its surprising cosmopolitanism. The area, in the states eastern panhandle and just two hours from Washington, is definitively the backwoods, with poultry farms and scant cellphone service and grocery-store cashiers who say Whats that? when asked about organic milk.

title: Proving That the Medium Really Is the Message
description: LOS ANGELES  To walk into Waking Up in News America, a rarely seen room-size installation by the artist Robert Heinecken, is to enter weirdly familiar Marshall McLuhan territory.

title: Neck Tatts, Cadillacs
description: By Blitzen Trapper

title: A Mix of Duets and Solos Proves a Recipe for a Feast
description: The urge to combine a soprano and mezzo-soprano can be easily understood by anyone whos ever made chocolate milk. Its the same alchemy: mixing something pure and light with something dark and syrupy to make something sweet, substantial and refreshing.

title: Shining Despite the Shadow of Guest Vocalists
description: The pianist Robert Glasper has been moving between the cultures of jazz and hip-hop  or, technically, the R&B that extends from the New York hip-hop a generation ago. Hes a natural multitasker, a guy who enjoys looseness, hybridity. Since he established himself in New York in the early oughts, his gigs have often felt like workshops or rehearsals or parties, whether in small acoustic-music rooms or at bigger clubs with serious speakers, like the Best Buy Theater, where on Tuesday night the Robert Glasper Experiment performed, or at least accompanied its guests.

title: Robert Glasper and Friends at Best Buy Theater
description: The Robert Glasper Experiment, led by the pianist, performed at the Best Buy Theater to celebrate the bands new album, Black Radio 2.

title: Your Recipes for Holiday Sweets
description: When it comes to holiday gifts, its the thought that counts. But what happens when your thoughts run blank, and you just cant think of anything to get all the people on your list? Like your nice next-door neighbors, the ones who take in your packages when youre not home? Or your second cousins third husband whose name you pulled out of the secret Santa hat?

title: No Lights, No Camera, No Action
description: Often a documentary tackles a topic that, however tempting, poses visual challenges (or exhausts the imagination of the filmmaker). That problem is the focus of Golden Slumbers, a film about Cambodian cinema, a history wiped clean by the Khmer Rouge. In the hands of the filmmaker Davy Chou, that vanished past becomes a remembered fantasy, expressing the absence of much more than a couple of hundred missing melodramas.

title: Though the House Is Closed, Inside, Saties Ghost Giggles
description: Pay attention! The opening movements of Dark Theater, the choreographer John Heginbothams new work to music by Erik Satie, show straightaway a true theater artists instinct for commanding his audience. The six dancers  dressed by Maile Okamura in lime green body tights with high red collars  burst into movement that exhibits sharpness, energy, formality and, yes, oddity. These qualities all feel right for the music, too. Dark Theater, which opened on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Fishman Space, captures several facets of Satie  not least his very precise eccentricity.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Majority Owners Seek to Buy Out Others
description: After nearly a month of upheaval at The Philadelphia Inquirer, including the abrupt firing of the papers top editor and lawsuits among its owners, the majority owners on Wednesday offered to buy out the minority investors, in what they described as an effort to provide stability to the company.

title: Kimberly Chandlers Style
description: Some of Ms. Chandlers style choices in 2013.

title: Feel the Chill
description: By Blitzen Trapper.

title: Scene City: Auctioning Art for Those in Need
description: Alec and Hilaria Baldwin and Coco Rocha were hosts at the Artwalk NY benefit for the Coalition for the Homeless.

title: Thirsty Man
description: By Blitzen Trapper

title: A Lonely Passion: Chinas Followers of Friedrich A. Hayek
description: As quixotic causes go, working in China to spread the ideas of Friedrich A. Hayek, the Austrian-born liberal economist and philosopher of freedom, is up there.

title: Under Fire, Hedge-Fund Billionaire to Sell Choice Art
description: In the two decades that the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen has collected art, he has been not only a high-profile buyer but also a high-profile seller, disposing of a painting one season, a sculpture the next.

title: Furr
description: By Blitzen Trapper

title: A Bandleader in His Element
description: Jimmy Heath picked up his tenor saxophone at only a couple of choice moments in his first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday, and somehow he made that feel almost magnanimous. Leading his big band in the second of four nights at the club, he was in brisk conductor mode, often moving his small frame with the spry dynamism of a jack-in-the-box. His fallback demeanor, gleeful but alert, suggested the air of a machinist watching his parts whirl magically into gear.

title: What Would Mr. Roper Say?
description: Who would have guessed that 36 years after she helped introduce jiggle TV as part of the original Threes Company cast (and decades after she first touted the body-shaping benefits of the ThighMaster), Suzanne Somers would have been recruited by The Wall Street Journal to offer criticism of the Affordable Care Act? Her article, The Affordable Care Act Is a Socialist Ponzi Scheme, in which Ms. Somers cited the Canadian health care system as a cautionary tale and quoted (somewhat inaccurately, it appears) Churchill and Lenin, quickly caught the attention of the Twittersphere.

title: New York Raising Age to Buy Cigarettes to 21
description: Buying cigarettes in New York City is about to become a lot harder for young people, as lawmakers on Wednesday adopted the strictest limits on tobacco purchases of any major American city.

title: Missoni, More Than a Zigzag
description: The night of Sept. 18, at La Scala opera house in Milan, more than a few heads turned when Rosita Missoni, the 82-year-old matriarch of the famous Italian knitwear company, made her way to a seat near the center of the first row. Eva Cavalli, in a white pantsuit, sat next to her and gently wrapped an arm around Mrs. Missoni, as her husband, the designer Roberto, all in black, doted. Giorgio Armani, among the many familiar designer faces gathered for a party sponsored by Cond Nast, paid his respects as well to this proud, bright-eyed woman whose cropped white hair is punctuated by a thin braid at the nape of her neck.

title: At Todd Snyders New Store, the Past Gets a Workout
description: THE NAME OF the new Todd Snyder store that opens on Saturday in NoLIta is City Gym. While catchy, this may confuse people who are more familiar with the designers two-year-old collection of finely tailored dress-up designs than his hit sweats collaboration with Champion.

title: Kimberly Chandler Coming Into Her Own
description: Kimberly Chandler is no stranger to the camera. In the last couple of months alone, she has been snapped on the red carpet at the Broadway opening of Romeo and Juliet; in a front-row seat alongside Kerry Washington at the Alexander Wang show; and at the New York premiere of Boardwalk Empire, snuggled beneath the arm of her husband, Tyson Chandler, the towering center for the New York Knicks. Clearly she has in a brief span of time learned to make the camera do her bidding.

title: Mystery Man, Painting the Town
description: It has been a perfect tempest in a teapot, the distracting, frothy combination of art, money, celebrity and urban exploit that Banksy has brought to New York. This British graffiti artist, purported millionaire, activist, filmmaker and prankster spent the last month roaming the city, perpetuating what is  depending upon your point of view  street art, political resistance or vandalism.

title: Following the Grim Reaper, Equipped With a Camera
description: If there was ever an argument against binge viewing, its Time of Death, a documentary series beginning on Friday night on Showtime. Over the course of six hours we watch eight people sicken and die, succumbing to cancers and other diseases at ages ranging from 19 to 77. For the viewer, some recovery time between episodes is probably a good idea.

title: Red Sox Rout Cardinals, 6-1, to Win Series in Six Games
description: BOSTON  The Fenway Park crowd was eager all night, standing, yelling, cheering. All that pent-up energy exploded as Shane Victorino crushed a Michael Wacha fastball high off the Green Monster, scoring three runs. Victorino pounded his chest and yelled as he advanced to third base. It seemed over then. The Red Sox had the lead.

title: 'Our City'
description: The most recent ad from the de Blasio campaign focuses on many different voices in New York.

title: Scaring Up Some Dough for a Cause
description: When Alec Baldwin and the Halloween Parade were both new to New York, he saw his sixth-grade teacher walking with a gay contingent. He waved. His teacher waved back.

title: How Outing Lost Its Power to Shock
description: What if they threw open the closet door and nobody cared to look inside?

title: Qatar Removes Statue of Zidanes Head Butt After Complaints
description: Updated, Thursday, 2:59 p.m. | Just four weeks after Qatars Museums Authority unveiled an unusual work of public art  a 16-foot statue of the French soccer star Zindine Zidane head-butting the Italian defender Marco Materazzi in the chest during the 2006 World Cup final  the exhibition, which was supposed to have been permanent, has been called off.

title: Zarin Mehta Is to Oversee a California Concert Hall
description: When Sanford I. Weill bought a 360-acre estate in California wine country three years ago, the area had plenty of attractions  gourmet cuisine, fine hotels, a beautiful climate  everything but a major concert hall for the culturally inclined Mr. Weill. Fund-raising problems and the economic downturn had stalled the completion of the nearby Green Music Centers auditorium at Sonoma State University.

title: Womens Pairs at Cavendish in Monaco
description: The womens pairs at the Cavendish tournament last week in Monaco attracted 16 pairs. After a round robin, the top half moved into the one-day A final over 42 boards.

title: Ik Ud: The Wildness of Clothes, but Not for Fashion
description: Ik Ud was standing inside the Lelia Heller Gallery in Chelsea in early October during the installation of his show, Style and Sympathies. The exhibition, which will run through Nov. 9, was set to open the next day. Many works were in cartons, others leaning against the wall; a few were hung. There was the smell of fresh paint.

title: Whos the Greenest Designer Out There?
description: The fashion industrys acceptance of the need to address environmental concerns in design is still in its early days. Only two years ago, Melissa Joy Manning, attending her first meeting of the Council of Fashion Designers of America as a new member, raised her hand and asked with a red face what the council was doing to promote sustainability. There were blank stares, but a few designers approached her later and formed a committee on the subject this year.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Driving While Glassed, and N.S.A. Infiltrates Data Centers
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Lhota as Manager: Swift Decisions and Long Weeks
description: They have staked out positions on taxes and charter schools, pedestrian plazas and sugary drinks. But the Republican and Democratic candidates to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have rarely expounded on the biggest day-to-day challenge that awaits them in City Hall: managing a bureaucracy of 300,000 workers.

title: Restoration Hardwares Next Move? A Quarterly Journal for Art Lovers
description: The home furnishings giant Restoration Hardware  or rather, RH, as it was rebranded in 2012  may bring to mind ecru linen sofas and distressed steamer trunks. But under the lead of co-C.E.O. Gary Friedman, the company is muscling its way into the business of contemporary art. On Nov. 9, it will also become a publisher, with a quarterly called RH Contemporary Art Journal that will be available for free to visitors of its new wood-beamed art gallery on West 16th Street. The debut issue is a glossy, minimalist affair that feels rather like an exhibition catalog, except for the heartfelt introductory letter from Friedman. (Fans of Restoration Hardwares source books will recognize his favored sign-off  Carpe Diem, Gary.) Both ventures are part of RH Contemporary Art, a platform that also includes documentaries, artist residencies and a web emporium, all aimed at selling creations by the artists it works with (who currently number about 50).

title: House Votes to Repeal Dodd-Frank Provision
description: Updated, 9:27 p.m. | The House of Representatives, with bipartisan support, passed legislation on Wednesday that would roll back a major element of the 2010 law intended to strengthen the nations financial regulations by allowing big banks like Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase to continue to handle most types of derivatives trades in house.

title: Pop-Ups, Sample Sales and Other Events Starting Oct. 31
description: Pop-Ups

title: Signs Point to Coming Scarcity of iPad Minis
description: Apples full-sized iPad, recently renamed the iPad Air, will be available in stores on Friday. But the release date for the smaller iPad Mini remains somewhat of a mystery.

title: T WINTER LUXURY
description: The Italian countess Marina Cicogna has lived her life on her own terms  photographing her jet-set companions, winning highest honors at the Venice Film Festival and throwing parties that are still talked about decades later.

title: Eavesdropping on Allies
Roommate Held in Killing at Queens Nursing Home
description: For the two men who shared Room 308 in the beachfront Beacon Rehabilitation and Nursing Center in the Rockaways, the off-white curtain divider was a source of strife.

title: Radiation Fears Are Real
How a Nouveau Riche China Is Investing in Art
American Austerity
description: The budget deficit has fallen more sharply in the United States than in most other developed countries over the last several years.

title: If Parents Skip the Online Spying, Should Teens Pay for Their Freedom?
description: When it comes to monitoring a childs life online, how much is too much?

title: U.S. Attorney to Recommend Lawsuit Against Bank of America Over Mortgages
description: The staff of a United States attorneys office plans to recommend that the Justice Department sue Bank of America over the packaging and selling of mortgage-related investments before the financial crisis of 2008, the firm disclosed in a regulatory filing on Wednesday.

title: Three Feet High and Rising
description: It was in 2002 that Alexandros Washburn saw Red Hook, Brooklyn, for the first time. And almost instantly, he said: I fell in love with it. Red Hook is about people who make things: they make maps, they make fashion, they make art. Its micro-manufacturing work. What you make is who you are. And add to this, the sparkling relationship to the water.

title: Charley Harper Designs That Takes Cues From Flora and Fauna
description: Charley Harper, a prolific artist who died in 2007, was not widely known until the fashion and housewares designer Todd Oldham became a supporter. Mr. Oldham spent five years documenting Mr. Harpers cheerful modernist work and is now the creative steward of his archives.

title: Something for Pandora: A Ceramic Box With a Lid
description: Frances Palmers new charm boxes were inspired by a 2002 show of the work of the Austrian decorative artist Dagobert Peche at the Neue Galerie New York, the Manhattan museum specializing in early-20th-century Austrian and German art. She kept the catalog in the Connecticut ceramics studio where she throws earthenware pieces, and was encouraged to create the collection when Rene Price, the Neue Galeries director, heard of her interest.

title: Should I Remove Built-Ins?
description: Q. I have lots of built-in furniture in my apartment. Should I remove it before listing my home for sale?

title: More Than a Chaise, a Thing of Beauty
description: The French interior designer Jacques Garcia has ladled on opulence in hotels and restaurants from Moscow to Miami Beach and in homes for private clients like the Sultan of Brunei. His encrusted portfolio now has a new gem: the Hotel Selman, in Marrakesh, Morocco, a luxury resort for which he designed all the furnishings, including Le Meridienne Victor, above, a stately chaise. Fashioned after the French sofa known as a rcamier, the piece is edged in contrasting trim, which highlights its contours. Its a shape he has long loved, said Agnes de la Mure, Mr. Garcias director of product development. Unlike his designs for Baker, the American furniture company, where each piece must stand on its own, the $10,500 chaise blends in with its surroundings. But it emanates from the same philosophy, Ms. de la Mure said: Elegant nonchalance. Information: 212-684-0707 or cotefrance.com.

title: Designers Visions Turn to the Gold Coast
description: A 50,000-square-foot gargoyled house, in a town on Long Islands Gold Coast that inspired F. Scott Fitzgerald, is ready for your awe. This weekend, Hempstead House in Sands Point, a former residence of the Guggenheims, will open the Design Showhouse at Hempstead House, a showcase of 12 rooms transformed by decorators into tributes to creative trailblazers. (For instance, Julie Moir Messervy reimagined a music studio for Yo-Yo Ma, above.)

title: All in a Daybeds Work
description: After three decades of designing homes in the city, from expansive lofts to space-constrained apartments, Laura Bohn has come to appreciate the versatility of a good daybed.

title: Endless Road Trip
description: For one family on an epic 23,000-mile journey, home is wherever the VW takes them  so long as their followers keep paying.

title: Dry for Now, and Ideally Forever
description: After seeing his house knee-deep in water, New Yorks chief urban designer is determined to keep it from happening again.

title: A Widows Difficult Path to a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Base With Fan Base
description: All Adam Harteau and his wife, Emily, wanted to do was take an epic 23,000-mile, 20-country road trip to the southernmost tip of South America and back. Everything that followed  the blog, the corporate sponsorships, the cookbook theyre writing, the export business  has been a savvy improvisation.

title: Plants With Spirit
description: Twenty years ago, I made an accidental hajj to a founding site of American Druidism. We called it the Hill of Three Oaks and thats what it was. The main attractions were Ultimate Frisbee and beer  an improbable pairing, best left to the elite class of frolickers.

title: If a Druid Rings the Doorbell
description: How will you be celebrating Samhain this year? Whats that? You say you wont be observing the high Druid holiday of the ancient Celts? With all due respect, youre probably wrong and you probably will.

title: Jailing Pregnant Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebel Stronghold Falls to Congolese Army
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  The last major population center controlled by a feared Congolese rebel group fell to government soldiers on Wednesday, a significant turning point in an insurrection that has brought further chaos and instability to the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: A Childhood Home, and Poets Muse
description: Julie Carlsons childhood home, a modest but elegant, mid-19th century white clapboard near the main street of Wellfleet, Mass.  also known as the seacoast of Bohemia, as Mary McCarthy slyly described the town  has been evoked so many times in the poems of so many late-20th-century poets it deserves its own anthology. Patricia Goedicke imagined its white curtains like loaves of bread. Deborah Garrison wrote how The porch that needs painting peels its white skin in the sun. Cynthia Zarin decried its penetrating cold in the winter, and the knocking boilers burned old heart.

title: A Desk Worthy of Starbucks
description: Last year my wife and I dropped $300 and way too many hours on a big new desk for our fireplace room, thinking it would be our younger childrens go-to study spot.

title: Putnam County Prosecutor Immersed Himself in His Friends Defense, Emails Show
description: Adam Levy, the district attorney of Putnam County, N.Y., involved himself extensively in the legal defense of his personal trainer and friend against rape allegations, a collection of emails he wrote indicates.

title: Discounts at ABC Carpet & Home, Bellino Fine Linens and Modani
description: Many tables and chairs are up to 30 percent off at ABC Carpet & Home, through Sunday (a hot pink bistro chair, originally $195, is $149); 888 Broadway (East 19th Street), 212-473-3000, abchome.com.

title: Obama Defends Health Care Law
description: In Boston, President Obama vowed he would not let Republicans try to turn the health exchange websites problems into ammunition with the aim of overturning the health care law.

title: In Russia, Conflating Journalism and Hooliganism
description: MOSCOW  It was just a usual business trip for him, Alina Zhiganova said, describing how her husband, the photographer Denis Sinyakov, set out in September to document Greenpeace Internationals voyage to protest oil exploration in the fragile environment of the Arctic Ocean. He delayed his departure to be present for the third birthday of their son, Vasily, and planned to return in time for his own birthday on Oct. 16. They planned to celebrate it in Paris.

title: UEFA Orders Partial Ban on Fans in CSKA Moscow Racism Case
description: MOSCOW  European soccers governing body on Wednesday penalized the Russian club CSKA Moscow after its fans racially abused a black opponent during a Champions League game last week, ordering it to bar fans from the section of the stadium where the chants originated during the clubs next home game in the competition.

title: The Man Who Loved Cemeteries
description: THE novelist needs both a dictionary and a cemetery. Graveyards offer more than your eventual remaindered resting-shelf. Approached in the joyful spirit of mortal play, they provide historic bullet points, bird sanctuaries, excellent fictitious names, and the lifelong source of such sweet calm.

title: Golf and Spanish on Bloombergs Agenda
description: In January, while the new mayor worries about whether his sanitation commissioner can handle the next big snowstorm, Michael R. Bloomberg will be hitting the links.

title: Too Many Bodies, Too Little Space
U.S. Accuses Germany of Causing Instability
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Treasury singled out Germany for criticism in a report released on Wednesday that said Berlins reliance on exports was holding back its struggling partners in the European Union.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Bengals (6-2) at Dolphins (3-4)
description: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

title: Vote on Labeling Modified Food Spurs Costly Battle in Washington State
description: SEATTLE  A ballot measure in next weeks election will give voters here the chance to make Washington the first state to require the labeling of genetically engineered foods. But the question of whether to put a few words on a package has touched off a surprisingly high-stakes, big-dollar fight with potential implications for other states.

title: When Judges Dont Know Everything
description: A name familiar from a 2008 Supreme Court death penalty case was back in the news the other day. A federal district judge in New Orleans granted a new trial to Patrick Kennedy, convicted in 2003 of brutally raping an 8-year-old girl. He has been serving a life sentence in a Louisiana prison, spared the death penalty by a Supreme Court ruling that capital punishment for the rape of a child, unaccompanied by murder, violates the Eighth Amendments prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Ideas Explored for Reducing Dangerous Hits
description: With injuries and suspensions from dangerous hits on the rise in the first month of the N.H.L. season, some general managers are supporting an effort to broaden discipline so that coaches and clubs, as well as players, are punished.

title: With Skakels Conviction Voided, Prosecutors Seek to Keep Him in Prison
description: Prosecutors objected strenuously on Wednesday to letting Michael C. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy convicted in the 1975 murder of a Greenwich teenager, leave prison while they appealed a court ruling that set aside the conviction.

title: In Dispute Over a Song, Marvin Gayes Family Files a Countersuit
description: Robin Thickes song Blurred Lines is one of the years biggest hits, but behind the scenes the song is the focus of a bitter dispute that led Wednesday to the family of Marvin Gaye filing a copyright lawsuit.

title: The Curse of the Second
description: Maybe theres no such thing as a happy second-term presidency.

title: The Spies Who Loved to Damage Our Reputation
description: Perhaps theres more we could do to antagonize American allies.

title: Grudge Spectacle
description: The Obamacare hearings before the House Energy and Commerce Committee are a grudge spectacle.

title: It Slices, It Dices, It Looks Great in Your News Feed
description: NEW commercials for Bella, a kitchen appliance brand, highlight its coffee makers, toasters, juicers and slow cookers, but the product that gets the most screen time is one that Bella doesnt make: a smartphone.

title: Senator Rand Paul Is Accused of Plagiarizing His Lines From Wikipedia
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Rand Paul, the Kentucky Republican who is among his partys top 2016 presidential prospects, has found himself accused of plagiarism.

title: Alabama Surrenders
description: State officials in Alabama have agreed to throw out major provisions of that states unjust immigration law. The agreement, which was announced Tuesday and awaits a federal judges approval, resolves lawsuits brought by civil-rights groups, churches and the Justice Department against the statute, H.B. 56, the most extreme attempt by any state to harass and expel immigrants.

title: Younger Players Face Bigger Concussion Risk, Report Says
description: High school football players are nearly twice as likely to get concussions as college football players and high school athletes in other sports, and as many as 20 percent of athletes who get a concussion have symptoms that linger more than two weeks, according to the Institute of Medicine.

title: Looking for a Way Around Keystone XL, Canadian Oil Hits the Rails
description: HOUSTON  Over the past two years, environmentalists have chained themselves to the White House fence and otherwise coalesced around stopping the Keystone XL pipeline as their top priority in the fight against global warming.

title: A Reminder of a Conflict That Faded Into History
description: LA ANGOSTURA, Mexico  On the grassy, windswept hill where soldiers from north and south fought one of the most important battles of the Mexican-American War, the crunch and grind of a sand and gravel mine deafens any attempt at contemplation.

title: The Hat With the B
description: On the Q train Wednesday morning, I was sandwiched between two men in Red Sox caps, with Game 6 of the World Series just hours off. All the way to Times Square, the men stood unmolested, even unnoticed.

title: Church Near Trade Center to Echo Landmarks of East
description: A gleaming, monumental and unmistakable symbol of Orthodox Christianity would rise at the south end of the National September 11 Memorial under plans drawn up for the new St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church.

title: From Anonymity to Scourge of Wall Street
description: The architect of a recent legal crackdown on Wall Streets dubious mortgage practices was not the attorney general, a United States attorney or a rising star in the Justice Department. Instead, it was Leon W. Weidman, an unassuming 69-year-old career prosecutor, toiling away in anonymity 3,000 miles from Washington.

title: Voters Anger Over Shutdown Is Inspiring Democrats to Run
